One thing that was different was the fragrance which was a nice "clean" smell that my detergent does not have.Overall I really liked the Wisk Deep Clean PowerBlasts Laundry Detergent as it fits my style of laundry - 90% large loads with vary little variability.  One thing to keep in mind is that the PowerBlasts packets should not get wet or the moisture will eat through the bags and then you'll have a great big mess rather than a bunch of individual packets.

**Note: I received a free product in exchange for an honest review.**I have many different pairs of headphones as I'm constantly search for one that I "really" like. I have been using a set of Sony MDR-J10 Headphones with Non-Slip Design at work to listen to music as well as to do on-line work-related classes. I like them because the sound is nice, they give good overall audio range playback, and are comfortable on my ear AND if someone steals them, I'm only out about $13.  I typically do not like buying earbuds because the one-size-fits-all manufacturing is rarely a size that fits "ME" - the earbuds are either too big or too little or sound like crap or have a cord that's too short or whatever.The Soundpeats M20 headset has a metal housing which is nice and the sound cords are of the the rubbery "spaghetti" variety which resists tangling. Soundpeats does not include the hard case like some of the other, more expensive, headsets that I've gotten, which is too bad but then you get what you pay for. There were two other earpieces in the box so you have another set plastic tips in case you lose yours or they get too full of "crud".I compared the M20 headset to the other headsets I have and the sound is very comparable to some of the higher end ($40-$50) earbuds that I own.  One thing to note is that since the M20's also include a microphone, the speaker plug has three sheaths on it.  This is compared to normal earbuds/headphones that have only two sheaths on the plug.  So if you plug it into an audio extension cord or a basic MP3 player that are designed for two sheath plugs, the sound will be very bad - it'll sound almost like mono.  However, if you plug the M20 into your phone or iPad or other microphone-capable device, the sound will be normal.Overall, I thought that the Soundpeats M20 was a nice pair of earbuds.

I'm not sure there is anyway that I could dislike these shorts more.  I have a 35-36" waist.  These pants, despite being 36", were so big, I put them on over my jeans and they were still huge.  Considering they have a stretchy waistband and how over-sized they are, I should probably have asked for a 32".  As far as looks, they are so short I feel like I'm back in the 70's or 80's where everyone wore short shorts.  I mean the overall LOOK of them is ok, but they are just really poorly proportioned.  Very bad design from Wrangler...

*** NOTE: I received a free product sample in exchange for an honest review. ***The UNU Superpak 10,0000 mAH portable charger is really a great battery and I own many due to my reviewer status (it seems like every electronics company out there makes there own battery...). The Superpak charges very quickly which I like as I've had some batteries which took hours to charge. It also gives up its charge to your electronics very quickly which again is notable as I've had issues with this as well from other manufacturers. With a 10K mAH charging capacity, you can resurrect several dead devices and is really more capacity than you'll normally need. However, if I had to be honest, I'd tell you that I agreed to review this product simply to get the 2-in-1 lightning/micro-USB cable. Anything that will allow me to get rid of one of the cords out of my travel bag is a good thing. I was also pleasantly surprised when the lightning cable actually charged my iPad since - again - I've had issues with after-market cords not syncing my iDevices.Overall, I'm greatly satisfied with the UNU Superpak and would happily purchase other products from UNU.

*** NOTE: I received a free sample of this product in exchange for an honest review. ***As someone who is squarely middle with some of the wonderful "male" health issues that age brings, I thought I'd give Vox Nutrition's Premium Tribulus Terresteis Testosterone Supplement a try.  The thought of having more energy both during the day and in bed seemed like a winner as well as the prospect of a muscle booster.After taking the product religiously for 2 weeks (one pill, one time a day as recommended), I experienced an improvement in my overall mood/disposition and energy level which was a similar affect from the previous Testosterone supplement.  Unfortunately I didn't experience in my sex drive or anything in bed, but I guess you get what you get.  Thankfully I also did not experience any of the side effects that are possible.  We'll see if I experience the same crash that I did the last time where for 5-7 days I was in an AWFUL mood after going off the supplement.  Maybe I need to see the doc about low testosterone...?I read alot of the reviews and as a Vine Voice product reviewer, I can tell the fake marketing drivel from the real thing and there are many 4- and 5-star reviews that I know are legitimate.  However, I have personally experienced this difference in product effect from the other side of the coin from taking Saw Palmetto.  I know for a fact it is helping because I've gone off it several times to make sure its still worth buying and I can tell the difference when I've stopped the supplement.  However, my urologist tells me he rarely prescribes it to his patients because its so hit and miss.  Some nutritional supplements are just like that.

The Myfox BU0201 Smart Home Alarm System is a pretty slick DIY alarm system, however it does have its drawbacks.In the "starter" system, you get the main alarm unit, one key fob, and one door/window "intelliTAG".  Once you download the Myfox app, it takes only about a minute to tie the app into the "Link" homestation, apply the intelliTAG to one or your door/window openings, and then set the round alarm in a central location.  The Myfox "Link" system allows up to 50 alarm devices, 50 key fobs, or four security cameras (all sold separately) so the system is very dynamic and expandable.  The intelliTAG's use detection algorithms to determine whether a blow to your window is someone trying to break in or just someone knocking.  I wasn't able to test this, since I'm not going to try and break down my own door, but this is a pretty neat function.  The key fob "talks" to the intelliTAG so that you don't set the alarm off when walking into your own house and with different key fobs, you'll know who enters/exits your house and when.  The key fob looks classically stylish in white, but is pretty large with a diameter similar to a half dollar and about a half inch in diameter.  With the fob on my key chain, it was pretty large to stuff in jeans my pocket.I'd like say that you have an initially large purchase and then the expansion of the system is relatively inexpensive, but this is not really the case with Myfox.  Each additional intelliTAG costs $49.99 (Myfox BU2002 IntelliTAG, Smart Sensor for Home Alarm (White)) so in my house I would need to spend almost $800 to alarm all my windows and doors and my first floor alone.  Want to install cameras?  They cost $199.99 a piece (Myfox Wi-Fi Security Camera) plus $29.99 for a wall-mount bracket (Myfox BU4010 Wall Mount, Bracket for Security Camera (White)).  So if I were to install three of them (one at my front door, one at the back and one at the garage) and mount them all with Myfox brackets, it would be almost $690.  Need more than one key fob?  They cost $29.99 apiece (Myfox BU3001 Wireless Keyfob).  I would need four more for my family so that would be almost $120.  So a system that seems pretty economical at a starter price of $279, now looks like its a gigantic money dump at a price north of $1600 to cover my house.Overall, I'm not really sure if this is a project that I would want to invest in because you really can't just have the starter unit and call it good.  If you are in for a penny, you are in for pound and if you were to by the base homestation unit, you are basically signing up to alarm the rest of your house which will probably run you close to $2000 at the minimum.  Is it worth it?  The system is certainly advanced with the intelliTAG's being able to tell the difference between a bird strike and someone actually trying to break into your house so I guess you just have to decide how much your peace of mind costs.

*** NOTE: I received a free product sample in exchange for an honest review. ***The Stickcons Bling Stickers For Your Sneakers are honestly pretty awesome!  In the package you get hundreds of little reflective rhinestones that have self-adhesive glue on the back.  The stones are connected in chains so that you can attach them in nice long, straight rows without having to put them on one at a time and having your rows look like heck.  If you want to make smaller patterns with the chains, simply take a scissors and cut the little strings anywhere you want and go wild!  I was somewhat concerned that the glue wouldn't attache correctly to cloth sneakers, since the product photo has the Stickcons attached to smooth rubber, but neither of my daughters had any problem putting them on either of their pairs of tennis shoes (as you can see in the attached pictures).Overall, I couldn't have been happier with the Stickcons - it was super easy to apply the Stickcons (my seven- and ten-year old daughters each spent 5 minutes - tops - on their "creations") and my daughters absolutely loved the look of them.  I'm not sure how long they'll last, but my daughters will enjoy showing off their fancy shoes until the Stickcons drop off!

I (and more importantly my seven-year old daughter) really liked the Zebra Cadoozles Starters Mechanical Pencil set.  They are very easy to hold and write with and the clicking action to advance more lead is very easy to depress.  The multiple colors are a fun way to write whether you are doing school work (with mom's or the teacher's approval) or whether you are just scribbling.  I always use mechanical pencils at work, since they never need to be sharpened and you can select pencils with varying lead hardness and thickness and its just one more skill for little kids to learn.One thing I think its necessary to note, even if it seems pretty obvious to me, is that these are NOT coloring pencils.  Nowhere on the product does it say these are coloring pencils.  They are mechanical pencils and as such the hard, thin lead is not really suitable for coloring pages.  You can do shading, but the coloring will be light.  So make sure you know what you are buying.

The Otterbox iPad Mini Folio Case is probably the most heavy duty, impact resistant case I've ever seen/used as the magnetized folio cover completely wraps around the front face of the iPad Mini to cover the screen and secures magnetically to the rear of the case.  The exterior cover is a woven cloth that  is smooth to the touch while the interior is a textured rubber coating.  Although it is unneeded with the rubberized interior, I would still buy the screen protectors that you can get three for $1 from many different Amazon vendors.The hard plastic shell is also entirely rubber-coated and holds your iPad Mini.  In fact its so tight, it takes a little effort to put it in and pull it out again.  The shell is perfectly cut with openings all the in the proper places for your rear camera, audio port, speaker, and microphone.  In addition, the volume buttons are raised above the case, but take a firm push in order to actuate the two buttons.  The hard case also rotates so that you can view the iPad Mini display in either portrait or landscape mode.  When stood up, the rubber interior keeps the iPad Mini angled upright in four grooves (the product imagery shows five grooves, but mine has four).Overall, there are some drawbacks from the sturdiness of the case design.  For starters, the case weighs almost as much as my iPad Mini itself (13.6 oz as compared to 15 oz for my version of the iPad Mini).  13.6 oz isn't really significant, but when it almost doubles the weight of your product, it is very noticeable.  Secondly, the cover is clearly designed for users who prefer to place their iPad Mini's on a table or desk as the cover is VERY VERY awkward to hold when you flip it open and use your iPad Mini in your hands.  There is a way to do it - you essentially fold the cover back on itself, but it feels weird.  Again the weight comes into consideration here as it makes the iPad Mini that much heaver to hold.  Finally the front edge of the flap that wraps around the back of the case does not lie flat like is shown in the product imagery and sits curled up in front of your iPad Mini when you have it sitting on a table or desk.  Since it has a big magnet in it, all Otterbox had to do was put a magnet on the inside face of the cover and you could have pushed this lip down on itself.Overall I liked it and its a great cover for traveling as you could drive a car over the case and nothing would happen, but for everyday use in my opinion it is too heavy and bulky for convenience.

My daughter really loved the Crayola Story By Me kit.  Enclosed you'll find a blank cover page (plus a spare), 16 story pages, a submittal page with a place for your child's picture and a short bio, and instructions for submitting the package to get your child's story turned in for printing.  Once completed, Crayola will send you one copy (on 5.5" X 8" paper) plus the access number to order additional copies for either yourself or relatives.  Shipping both ways is included in the price of the product.  An eight-color set of washable markers is included with the box.Before my daughter starting writing/drawing her story, I made a copy of the story page, the submittal page, and the cover page so that I could make replacement pages in case she made a mistake.  This was a good thing because she decided that the first page she did "wasn't good enough" and threw it away.  The book can be up to 16 pages so it pays to make extra copies.  Although you could use the markers to draw pictures and write the story, I would suggest that your child use a pend or pencil for the story part as Crayola will not correct misspellings so if they can't read the words, your child may be disappointed in Crayola's "interpretation" of what he/she wrote.I know that it is relatively simple to self-publish your own books nowadays, but having all the templates and pages laid out for you to just follow was handy.  And $22 for all the pages, markers, the book, and shipping both ways seems to be a fair price to me.  There is a hardbound version of the "Crayola Story By Me" (Crayola Story By Me Hardcover Kit) that is $28, designed for a slightly older child (age 6 and up), and gives you a 7"x9" hardcover book.**********UPDATE**************My daughter finally got around to finishing her book and it turned out GREAT!  It took app 3 weeks for Crayola to send the book back to us and it was all printed on glossy paper and staple bound.  The cover page and all the inside pages are essentially photo transfers of whatever your child writes or draws so be aware of that.  Not only do they not correct spelling errors (which is stated on the instructions), they do not retype any of the written words.  The only thing that Crayola types is the "About The Author" and the "Dedication" sections.  My daughter was so happy to get this and Crayola even sent a bookmark along with it.  Pretty cool stuff!

** NOTE: I received a free sample of this product in return for an honest review. **This ebook has some really wonderful designs that will keep anyone engrossed - young and old - for many hours.  Considering the big coloring craze that is on-going, this book compares favorably with many of the other books that I've seen at the major bookstores.  In order to actually color, the book comes with a PDF link so that you can print any or all the pages outside of Kindle.  I liked this option as you can print multiple sheets of the same page in order to try different designs or color schemes out.

The ACCO Five Star Locker Organizer is pretty decent.  The magnet on the back is very strong, which follows the product literature, and appears to be "slam proof" for school lockers.The four round magnets are also strong and hold paper onto the whiteboard equally well.  There are four pushpins that are shipped on a rubber block.  I threw away the rubber block as it is not attached to the whiteboard and will fly around your locker when you close it.  There are ample holes in the lower front face to push the pins in which is fabulous.  However, the number of pins shipped is somewhat inadequate - you probably want to grab 5 or 6 more thumbtacks to augment those shipped along with the product.The pen, although somewhat cheap, writes and erases adequately.  You need to push very hard to completely erase even fresh writing which leads me to believe that writing that has been on the board for several days/weeks will be troublesome to erase.  The primary drawback I saw in the whole package was the pen itself - it just doesn't stay on the board as the magnet is very weak.  I even removed the plastic covering around the eraser so that the magnet would be in direct contact with the board and it didn't help.  If you slam your locker, this thing is going to go flying everywhere.  Maybe if you put it in the little gap between the locker face and the front of the whiteboard it might stay in place, but I doubt it.  Seems to be a pretty obvious design flaw.Overall, I thought the Fiver Star Locker Organizer was up to the task despite the issues with the marker.

** NOTE: I received a free sample of this product in return for an honest review. **The Lavievert Leather and Canvass Laptop Case/Bag is a very attractive and functional unit for you to use as a work bag or for those people who travel.  The pocket for your laptop is just under 14" long and about 8" deep so depending on the thickness of your laptop, you can fit probably a 13.5 inch laptop in the bad.  I don't own a MacBook and my HP laptop has a 17" screen, but as you can see from the pictures it fits an standard sized iPad plus a legal pad with room to spare.Inside there is a plethora of pockets including those for business/credit cards, pens and pencils, note pads, phones, other small electronics, and two zippable pockets (one of netting) to put in such things as charging cords, change, keys, money, etc.  With both the iPad and a legal notepad in the large slot and several of the smaller pockets full, I had no problem closing the case and fitting the magnetic snaps together.  The Interior and exterior is made of a sturdy blue canvass which is smartly contrasted with the leather top and snaps.Overall, I can see my wife using this on a daily basis for her home business.  As she takes her iPad and supplies to various meetings, everything is right there for her to use without having to dig through her purse or a shoulder bag.  Two thumbs way up on this one!

*** NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product in exchange for an honest review. ***I was very eager to try out the Colore Brilliant White Chalk Markers as not only does my wife homeschool, so she regularly uses a Whiteboard, my daughters also love to go out and draw on the driveway. The Colore White Chalk Markers do take a little bit of work in order to get them ready to use - probably about 3-4 min per pen of shaking and pressing the writing tip until the liquid chalk was properly soaked into the tips - but after that they work every single time with no problems.I was somewhat concerned about the semi-soft "felt" tips becoming ruined by writing on our concrete driveway and/or the pens not writing very well, but the girls had no issues and made nice artwork. Since they were essentially "painting" the chalk onto the concrete, they also didn't have to press very hard which alleviated my concern about ruining the tips.  We also had no problems writing on the windows of my car and the writing easily wiped off.The instructions suggest that you do not use the pen on any porous surface as the liquid chalk will soak into the surface and/or bleed, but it wasn't a major issue for me. I tried writing with the pens on a normal sheet of colored paper and eventhough it spread out a little, it dried quickly and didn't streak. I also used my hardwood desktop to pressing the pen tips into the liquid chalk reservoir in order to wick the chalk into them and it cleaned up easily without soaking into the wood.Overall I couldn't be happier with the pens and look forward to purchasing more in the future!

The PediaSure Sidekicks Smoothie is, to be very frank, awful.  I mixed in a little less than 4 spoonfuls of the mix (with the scooper included in the packet and a little more than 3 cups of milk (3/4 of a cup of milk to one spoonful of powder) so that it would be a little thinner than recommended.  Even with that, the mixture was basically - disgusting with an aftertaste of strawberry.  Even putting it in the fridge for a little bit to cool it off.  It just turned brownish colored and some of the mix separated into a scum on the top.  I poured it out after that.Overall, I can't see any kid drinking this in the suggested mixture.  Maybe if you added in ice cream and some more fruit and made an actual smoothie with the powder they would, since it contains Calcium, Vitamin D, Fiber, Potassium, 24 essential vitamins and minerals, but not like this...

*** NOTE: I received a free copy of this product in exchange for an honest review. ***As a 6'6" person, I've always had back pain and misc joint pain (probably from under-exercising). In my current job, I spend many days a year traveling and between the criminally small airplane seats and strange beds, I frequently have back and neck pain that sticks with me during my business trips and for days after I return. I have taken Glucosamine and Chondroitin in the past and I always felt like it helped to smooth out my aches and pains, but its probably been 10 yrs since I've taken it regularly. Because of my mildly chronic pain issues, I jumped at the chance to try out 100 Naturals 1500 mg of Glucosamine, 1200 mg of Chondroitin, and 2000 mg MSM tablets. There are many different suppliers of Glucosamine on the market and on Amazon and 100 Natural's product is in the same price range per pill as most of the others - some higher, some lower, but most of them are right around $0.10 a pill.After taking the product religiously for 3 weeks (five pills daily which I split up into two separate doses), I experienced a reduction in my overall pain level, stiffness in my back, neck, lower legs, and joints in general, and saw improvement in my overall mobility. However, this did not come overnight.  One thing people need to remember is that most supplements take a few days or weeks to build up to the point where they are having a noticeable affect on you.  This is why you see alot of reviews that say "I took this for a week and nothing happened.  It sucks!" - when if the person had used it for another week he may have experienced the positive effects he was looking for.  Maybe, maybe not.  Its tough to tell sometimes as you will get one person who swears by the product and another who didn't get anything out of it.  As a 45-yr old male, I experience urinary issues so I've been taking Saw Palmetto to help with it. I know for a fact it is helping because I've gone off it several times to make sure its still worth buying and I can tell the difference when I've stopped the supplement. However, my urologist tells me he rarely prescribes it to his patients because its so hit and miss. Some nutritional supplements are just like that.So although this bottle only lasts for 40 days, which doesn't seem like a long time for $23, it has more Glucosamine, Chondroitin, and MSM than most of the joint supplement products that I've seen (and tried) on Amazon.  Good stuff!

*** NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product in exchange for an honest review. ***I was very eager to try out the Colore Chalk Markers as not only does my wife homeschool, so she regularly uses a Whiteboard, my daughters also love to go out and draw on the driveway. The Colore Chalk Markers do take a little bit of work in order to get them ready to use - probably about 3-4 min per pen of shaking and pressing the writing tip until the liquid chalk was properly soaked into the tips - but after that they work every single time with no problems.I was somewhat concerned about the semi-soft "felt" tips becoming ruined by writing on our concrete driveway and/or the pens not writing very well, but the girls had no issues and as you can see, made nice artwork with all the colors. Since they were essentially "painting" the chalk onto the concrete, they also didn't have to press very hard which alleviated my concern about ruining the tips.  We also had no problems writing on the windows of my car and the writing easily wiped off.The instructions suggest that you do not use the pen on any porous surface as the liquid chalk will soak into the surface and/or bleed, but it wasn't a major issue for me. I tried writing with the pens on a normal sheet of paper and eventhough it spread out a little, it dried quickly and didn't streak. I also used my hardwood desktop to pressing the pen tips into the liquid chalk reservoir in order to wick the chalk into them and it cleaned up easily without soaking into the wood.I like the squishable rubber pen holder as it keeps all the pens in one place and upright. Overall I couldn't be happier with the pens and look forward to purchasing more in the future!

I found "Devotion" to be an interesting combination of a "War Story" meets "Buddy Book".  "Devotion" tells the true story of Naval pilots Tom Hudner and Jesse Brown and their exploits and struggles during the early days of the Korean War.  Told in repeated flashbacks, author Adam Makos delves into their personal lives to flesh out the reasons for the color-blind affinity between the pair as well as their exploits in and out of the cockpit prior to their defining moments which are kicked off when Brown is shot down over Chinese-held Korean territory.  Parallel to the recounting of the exploits of the two pilots, Makos also follows several Marine soldiers who later fought as the 1st Marine Division in the Chosin River Valley in the winter of 1950 when the Chinese stormed across the Yalu River and nearly surrounded the lead elements of the UN force in North Korea.I've seen comparisons between this book and Laura Hillenbrand's "Unbroken".  Additional, his writing style and extensive use of actual dialogue from events that are from over 65 years ago (which must have included a certain amount of "artistic license") somewhat mirror the books of author Jeff Shaara.  However, having read both Unbroken and several Shaara books honestly the comparison is only superficial and Makos' book should really stand on its own as a classic unto itself.  The only REAL similarity I saw in Devotion and the Jeff Shaara books that I read were that I really grew to know the men in the book such that I felt every death as if I had been there.  Buy-in to the tale being spun and swaying you to emotion is a rare quality in an author.Overall, I greatly enjoyed the book.  The self-sacrificial and "I was just doing my duty" example that Tom Hudner shows us in "Devotion" as well as the struggles that Jesse Brown endured in Jim Crow America and the Navy should be held up as a role model for all of us, young and old alike.

I see why this was an 'add on' item... it's garbage!  No matter what I clipped it on it would fall over and wobble as I tried to wind the floss onto the bobbin.  I can hand wind a bobbin much faster than using this.

I put off getting this for years but finally succumbed as I'm starting a fractal pattern and wanted both hands free and the ability to flip from front to back quickly.  It is very well made, high quality materials, and easy to assemble.  If I'm forced to find a fault it would be that flipping back and forth as I do causes one of the outer knobs to eventually unscrew and fall off.  Really not a big deal.  After a few times of being startled when the knob hit the floor, I started to tighten it every now and then - problem solved.  Some others have mentioned the hoop seems cheap.  I understand why they feel that way, but I'm not having any difficulty with it and it stays as tight as any other wooden hoop would.

It's metal, comes with magnetic strips, and holds two 9x11" pages side by side.  It's everything I need for cross stitch patterns.  Like a few others, the lip intended to be at the bottom causes more problems than it's worth - so I simply use the board upside down.  The lip doesn't really hold anything since it prevents the board from being completely stable when used with the recommended stand.
Good idea for cross stitching.  It (sort of) helps keep 2 strands of floss separated which makes railroading a bit easier.

I used this for the first time to grid a large fractal piece I'm working on (I don't see how a fractal design could be done without gridding). This product shows up better than ordinary fishing line because it's not as transparent.  I have various colors of fishing line, but it all seems to 'disappear' due to its translucent nature.  Given the difficulty of the piece I'm working on - the Easy Count Guideline has been worth every penny and then some.

My 12-year old, 75 lb. Black Lab LOVES these.  When you open the resealable bag (big plus!) you're hit with a wonderful blueberry aroma (another plus!).  I'm not saying Raven's breath smells like blueberries after she eats one, but she enjoys chewing on it and I have no doubt that it helps release tartar.  She gave them 5 stars!

I have a personalized plate and needed a frame that wouldn't cover up the bottom of the E making it look like an F.  This is narrow and does the job.  Use caution when installing as it is very thin, weak plastic so over tightening could cause it to snap in half.
Strong, easy to use (I have weak wrists and hands), and does the job.

I'm starting a 100 color fractal piece and use this for the predominant color (black) so as not to take up too many slots in my Pako Floss Organizer for this one color.  It's nice that they supply extra magnetic strips to place on the back if desired for attaching it to a metal board.  It is made of thin card stock and won't last forever, but for me it serves its purpose well.

I like that this comes with a magnetic ruler as well as magnetic re-positional strips.  However, the sharp edges (which don't bother me) should be taken care of by the manufacturer.  I'm sure many who would use this have kids who could slice a finger just picking it up.  The other complaint is that it would have made more sense to make it 8 1/2 by 11" standard page size (9 x 12 even better).  For the current project I'm working on my larger 12x18 won’t fit into the available space, though I much prefer that board.

I wasn't expecting much - many wooden frames are so poorly made that they don't hold the fabric taut for very long.  Often it's because they are slightly out of round, but this one tightens and stays tightened for hours with no re-adjustment.  And the tightening screw's end is dipped in rubber so it can't come out and get lost.  No splinters or rough parts, yet not so polished that the fabric slips through - which is my beef with plastic hoops.

I have been cross stitching on and off for 20 years and finally broke down and bought this.  What was I waiting for?!?!  It's fabulous!  Works perfectly - holds the floss and needles neatly and compactly.  I'm startling a 100-color fractal piece and may very well order a second one so all of my floss will be readily available.  Though not intended to be so, the plastic it comes in actually makes a decent "case" for taking along.  I coil the floss behind the organizer then shut the plastic and off I go.

I sleep on my side near the edge of the bed.  Also, I have a sleep number bed that I love and since buying that bed I do not toss or turn at all during the night - as still as a corpse.  In the morning I only have to neaten up the side I sleep on - the other side of the bed looks like no one was ever there.  I preface with this because I find this pillow works pretty well for me, but if one were to simply turn to the other side during the night their head could fall off the pillow or result in a crick in their neck since this pillow is a dense, solid, unwavering hunk of 4-5" foam.  Oh, and if you sleep with your arm under your head or pillow it raises it pretty high and when I tried it for the sake of "research" it was uncomfortable for my head, neck, and arm.So, as with any pillow, a review may not be very useful since everyone has a different sleeping pattern and preference.

I desperately needed a new scale.  The old one was unsightly but still worked.  Due to the color under the glass is looks like a gorgeous slab of silver sitting on the bathroom floor.  Is easy to wipe clean, looks high end, and the numbers are easy to read.  It seems to have a slightly larger area for standing on and, because it's thin therefore close to the floor, feels secure for even my 85 year old mother to stand on though she is a bit "wobbly" these days.I tested it by weighing several people and large items; for each it was perfectly accurate - except when I weighed myself.  I'm pretty sure it added about 10 lbs.

I find most make-up remover towelettes to work pretty well and I use them when I travel.  Mascara is always more difficult to remove but it can be done with this product and the ingredients list is better than most others on the market.  While there is no alcohol, I find the towelette feels silky while removing the makeup but for a few minutes after my face feels a bit dry, but then that goes away and leaves my skin feeling soft and clean.  Three to four swipes and I'm makeup free.  While they did add unnecessary scent, I did not find it to be very strong nor did it linger.The reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars is due to the packaging.  I really dislike the sticker cover; I prefer a snapping plastic cover like Burt's Bees has - no worry about it becoming "unstickable" due to wet hands.

This Galaxy Tab4 Folio case could not fit any better!  It's snug yet all of the cut-outs for buttons and the charger are readily available.  It also has a elastic band to hold a stylus, 2 small open-ended "pockets" for cards, papers, whatever, and my favorite thing - an elastic strap to slip my hand under so I don't have to grip the edge and accidentally turn an unwanted page, no accidental backing out of a game just as I'm about to defeat a difficult level, and I won't be turning it off as I hold it.  I ride a ferry to and from work each day and with this WACO folio I can drape the cover over the top of the steering wheel to read - no hands required.  If I were designing a folio case for my G-Tab4 it would look just like this with all of the same features.It also has an elastic band that holds the cover in the open position unlike my Snugg iPad 2 Leather Case Cover and Flip Stand with Elastic Hand Strap I have for my iPad which does not have the band to hold the open cover open.For the price I was not expecting something so well made and nice looking.  It does not look cheap though some may find the silver-gray lining to look like an old man's suit - I find it to be soft enough so it doesn't scratch yet seemingly durable.  I would highly recommend this if you are looking for a folio case for your G-Tab4.NOTE: It appears that the review section for this product also has reviews for a similar product with a keyboard - I am not reviewing that version.

This is a godsend. Had a detached garage built a few years ago and neither the builders nor I can find the keys for the man door! This only presents a problem when the power goes out and I can't get into the garage to manually operate the garage door opener. Since the power goes out several times a year I find myself wondering why the heck I haven't replaced the lock, however, a few days later I forget about it until the next time.I had a friend install this for me and he had no trouble at all. In fact, he is considering buying one for his garage. The lock looks high tech and kind of classy. I like that I can set up different temporary codes for the gardener and others needing access to my garage.  I'm impressed with the battery jump start option since I rarely remember to replace my fire alarm batteries yearly until the incessant chirping goes off!  And the light to see the keypad is helpful as my man door is under the shade of several cedars.After using it for 3 weeks (and 1 power outage) I've decided to buy one for each if the exterior doors on the house.

Certainly better looking than tradtional dimmers but, more importantly, it dims a variety of bulb types.  The extra colors included was a bonus but requires finding a plate to match whichever color chosen.  Not a big deal since I wouldn't expect Leviton to include 3 plates.Simple to install and works well.  Interesting to hear others mention the click and strobing when used with LEDs.  My intent is to replace the current lighting system with LED lighting; once I do I'll add to this  review.

I did detect an artificial cough medicine-like taste, but not terribly strong as the chocolate overpowered the raspberry.  If you like really sweet drinks then this will satisfy.  Personally, it's too sweet, especially when its Protein claim and the alleged health of V8 contraindicates the super sweetness.  Unfortunately, my review is of little help as I see (taste) both sides.  I would not buy it.  Too much like drinking candy...with a hint of Robitussin.

Not a cookbook I will use regularly, but it certainly inspires me to try to make my own sausage someday soon.  I grew up on a farm, Grandma made wonderful sweet blood sausage.  Later my Dad began experimenting with sausage recipes and became quite good at making pork sausage.This book has lots of interesting background material, excellent instructions, great photos, and many wonderful, inspiring recipes.  The first one on my list is the Habanero and Maple Breakfast Sausage.  Readily available ingredients and a straight forward process.This isn't a cookbook for a novice, but for someone with knowledge, if not actual practice, of sausage making.  A curious chef with a love of meat beyond steak on the grill and the roast for a holiday meal.
Does the job perfectly, but I would rather have a second cable (to keep in my vehicle) instead of the useless stylus.  Great quality and I like the folding prongs.

I bought this as an emergency travel/office charger for my Nokia Lumia 520 phone.  Turns out this product is of much higher quality than the charger that came with the phone.  The cord is sturdier, not flimsy, and the prongs stay in the socket better.

A couple of years ago I bought Etymotic Research MC5 Noise Isolating In-Ear Earphones (Black).  This is a mini comparison to the GOgroove in-ear noise canceling headphones.GOgroove:far more comfortable in the ear.  I can wear them for 8 hours without realizing I have them in my ears.stay in my ears - even if I'm in full rockin' mode. ;-)fairly good noise cancellation.the price is right if you're not an audiophile - the bass is somewhat lacking.Etymonic:better noise cancellation, blocks out noisy kids on the plane, the neighbor's yappy terrier, and unwanted conversation at the office.somewhat richer sound; better bass and mid range.difficult to get them to seat correctly in my ears and once properly inserted they don't stay in if I move too much.hurts like a sonnofa_______ after about 10 minutes.  I've tried all sizes of ear tips included, all of them hurt my ears.As with all in-ear headphones, it's really dependent upon the shape of a person's ear canal.GOgroove gets 5 stars for comfort and 3 for sound and noise cancellation...therefore a 4 since comfort is very important to me.
Previous reviewer Brian Bella said it all, and much better than I could.  The only thing I can think of to write as a review of my own is - "Why, Mr. McCarthy, why?"
I'm surprised that something this small can actually get rid of the occasional dampness in some of the rooms in my walk-out basement.

Works like a dream. The onscreen touch pad makes scrolling and finding controls simple and intuitive.  I like that it holds a full ream of paper, but of course that makes it rather large - not a consideration for me but could be if space is limited.  I've scanned and printed wirelessly from my iPad and computer plus from a memory stick.  I do wish it had a slot for an SD card though.I've had other wireless printers including Epsons, HPs, and a Brother.  This was the first time I had to download a driver to get a printer to connect wirelessly.  Not a big deal but it did irritate me a bit since all of my other printers magically connected in seconds.While the printing is fast and clear, The color isn't quite as exact as I'd like.  As a quilter, I sometimes copy fabric to "preview" my design.  Fabric is a difficult copy with all printers I've used, but this printer seemed to be slightly less accurate in terms of color matching.  I also copied and printed a PowerPoint slide and that color was ever so slightly off as well.  I'm not saying it's a deal breaker for me, but I could see it as a problem for those whose intent is color perfection.  My Epson XP610 does a better job achieving color accuracy.This has all of the features one would need for a home office or small business.  My favorite feature is that it prints on both sides automatically; no manual page flipping is required.My concern is, or rather will be, its ink consumption.  Both of my other Epson printers drink ink at an unbelievable rate.  (Almost cheaper to replace the printer 4-5 times a year than buy ink!).  Perhaps the money I save on paper can be applied towards ink.All in all, I'm very happy with it and would recommend it to others.  The lack of an SD card slot and minor color inaccuracy are what downgraded it from 5 to 4 stars.

I like the content of this book a lot.  The designs are beautiful and the instructions are very clear and easy to follow.  My complaint is that it is a poor quality self-publication.  Cheesy font and the photos are slightly blurry and off color, though the detail is still fairly easy to see.  The cover is beautifully photographed so I was very surprised to see such inferior quality on the inside.  And because of the inferior quality I feel the MSRP of $24.95 is much too high (glad I didn't pay that much!).  Truthfully, had I seen this in a book store I might not have purchased it.  However, the content is inspirational.

Easy to write on, easy to erase, and easy to hang on the wall (came with all of the necessary hardware though the anchors are a bit too short - I re-installed longer ones).  The 2 included magnets are strong enough to hold several thicknesses of paper, including card stock.  I hung it in my crafts room to keep track of projects as well as do a bit of designing on it. Since it only hangs from the top I can take it down and move it elsewhere when needed then hang it back up again.

I heard about this book when Ms. Thomas was being interviewed on a radio station I listen to.  Plus I have also always liked and respected her.  Though many of the stories were inspirational I found that the women had educational and/or financial support - I was expecting some of the stories to be more of a' pull yourself up by the bootstraps' type story and also thought there would be a bit more about women over 55 successfully (and reasonably) changing careers.  After a while it seemed like the same old story over and over.  Not that I wouldn't recommend this - I would land have! - and I certainly understand the 4 and 5 star ratings but it didn't quite live up to what I expected from listening to the interview.

It works as it should - nothing fancy.  The detente is good as is the key spacing.  I bought it because my laptop's keyboard stopped working so this is allowing me to use the computer until I figure out what I want to replace it with.  I'm thinking Surface Pro 3....

I get tired of the same 4 colors of markers.  Plus, I prefer to color code my various projects and these allow me to do that.  Since the point is narrow (for a dry erase marker) I can fit more information into the small dry erase wall calendar squares.  I've not had any problem erasing them like I do with some of the other markers, and they have no odor.

I am an 11 year old Black Lab.  I love to swim at the beach, hike in the woods, go snowshoeing, and romp through mud puddles.  I am very clean but Mom sometimes thinks I need a bath.  Now that I'm older she says my feet smell like "old dog" feet - whatever that means... She got this shampoo and used it on me and went on and on about how great I smell.  I think it smells weird - not dog-like at all.  What's wrong with old dog feet?  But if it makes her happy and I get an extra biscuit out of the deal then so what?  I'll put up with it even though the Doberman next door and the 2 Mastiffs on the other side tell me I smell like a girlie Poodle.  Not the image I'm going for.Humans!?!?  Go figure!

After forgetting to charge my iPad overnight a couple of times and being at work with a dead battery I purchased this charger.  I really like it a lot.  It's compact, the prongs flip down and it stays in the wall, doesn't fall out like some I've tried.  It has 2 ports - A and NA.  A is for iPads, iPhones, and other iStuff and the other NA port is for everything else.

Bought this for a 2-week trip to Chile.  Worked well on their 220 volt system though it cannot be used on High Heat and High Fan when operating on 220.  Once I got home to the US I moved my current hair dryer to the guest bathroom and am using this one now.  It has a strong fan and the heat options are accurate.The retractable cord and folding handle make it less cumbersome in the suitcase and it's easier to store at home too.
Was able to tighten my slightly overstuffed luggage enough to have it qualify as carry-on rather than checked baggage.  Very strong and easy to adjust.
Used this for 2 weeks while in Chile (220 volts).  It is very compact, works great, held all of my various power cords and USB cables.  It also fit snuggly into the outlets.
Used this for 2 weeks while in Chile (220 volts).  It is very compact, works great, held all of my various power cords and fit snuggly into the outlets.

I'm in a hotel in Chile - well into my vacation.  This LP book is of little to no help whatsoever.  I have traveled internationally for decades and always relied on LP with great success.  This Chile & Easter Island 2012 version is nearly useless.  Not the usual hotel and dining recommendations and reviews; very limited and the better options are missing.  Everything sounds the same, for instance all the restaurants sound the same, not enough detail to draw from when making a decision.Also missing is the personalized pieces of advice I've grown accustom to in my other LP books.  In Chile one of the key issues is finding public restrooms.  Other LP books inform you of this difficulty when traveling to certain countries or regions.  This book does not.  FYI: if you look desperate small store or gas station owners will usually let you use them after apologizing for the cleanliness and condition.  (When you're desperate to go, who cares?).  Most do not want the toilet paper (if they have any) to be flushed.Truthfully, this book seems to have been written by someone who has not thoroughly traveled the country.  The descriptions are somewhat neutral and seem similar; almost cut-&-paste-like.  I have used LP books as my only source of information and advice when traveling to Morocco, Iceland, Korea, Sweden, and Norway.  Thanks to LP each of those trips was fabulous.  This current trip to Chile will be also be fabulous but not as a result of the ease of referring to LP.  I hope this Chile book is an anomaly rather than the 'new and improved' way of supplying us with information.  If so, I'll be switching to another source.

Since I am familiar with how to reset a combination lock I was able to do so even though this came with instructions written only in Japanese.  However, the English version can be found in the Amazon description therefore I won't deduct a star.Tumblers move easily and smoothly, but can be a bit hard to read.  I like the length of the cable and its width is sturdy yet narrow enough to easily fit through even the smallest openings in luggage zipper pulls.
As a quilter I find nothing better than silk thread.  It's a pleasure to sew with by hand and machine.  I like this color variety pack.  Can't wait to start my next quilt.

I have a very old garlic press that I love.  However, it doesn't have the self-cleaning capability that this one claims to have.  I do like that this OXO garlic press has square holes that make the garlic appear minced rather that pulverized.  However, the "nipples" on the backside really should be 1/2 mm longer to clean the holes better.  A 5 for mincing and a 3 for cleaning.
This has a pleasant fragrance and lathers well.  Doesn't seem as drying as some body wash does.  Would get this again.

I'm traveling to a 220 volt country in a week therefore need a dual voltage straightener.  So far, I've tried it with my 110 voltage and it works as expected.  Not sure what the purpose of the 25 heat settings is though; I think low, medium, and high would suffice.It was shipped to me in a plastic bag with the model number handwritten on a 3x5 index card.  There was no original packaging.  Made me wonder if it was used or refurbished.  If there are special instructions for use with 220 (as there is with hair dryers) I am unaware of it since I did not get any info with the straightener.
Pros:  no static electricity and long enough to tuck into slacks if desired.Cons: The neckline is cut too large so it gaps about 3” while wearing it.
I like this cable better than the one that came with my iPad.  This one is sturdier yet not so stiff that it becomes unruly.

The wallet is practical and the Rfid blocking seems to work fairly well, perhaps a bit spotty though.  I tested it with my electronic office key card - most of the time it wouldn't unlock the door but a couple of times it did unlock.  I couldn't duplicate the problem well enough to ascertain exactly where the inferior blocking was.Despite that, the fabric is a bit rough and looks somewhat cheap.  The internal compartments hold cards and passport, as stated but it leaves me feeling like it won't hold up.  However, my intent is to only use it in the airport when traveling.I wrote too soon...I am currently on vacation in Chile and on the second day one entire side of the passport pocket ripped.  I will be returning this as soon as I get back home.

This is exactly what I expected.  A very well made small "purse" that I use when flying to keep all if those small items such as a comb, chap stick, mints, pen, reading glasses, and necessary paperwork in one place in the seat with me.  This couldn't be more perfect for my needs.

Gorgeous pictures, full of inspiration, easy to understand, clearly written instructions.  I have always been intrigued by 3-D /optical illusion quilts but assumed they'd be difficult to piece.  The scariest aspect for me was learning how to select the right fabric to ensure the 3-D depth.  No longer, Ms. Wise's well written book has giving me the confidence to tackle the quilt on the cover.  She inspires creativity.  I foresee my future and it is filled with dimensional quilt making.
What can one say about shampoo?  It lathers well, has a good fragrance and does not seem harsh on my hair (long, thick, and fine).

I've tried a variety of oils on my long, thick, fine hair.  This one has a fragrance that is somewhat better than other oils, particularly Argon oil which just plain stinks!  This Dove oil also seems to hydrate my hair without weighing it down or making it look oily.  One of the better oils I've tried over the years.  Still not "hair model" worthy, but pretty good.

We have a great little dachshund, now over ten years old, and she loves her new dog bowl and dish. In the past, she's been apt to knock pet food and water onto the floor. Thankfully, we have tile, but it's left small messes to clean up. This dog bowl and mat are a perfect solution: easy to use, easy to clean, and fully functional. The red fits for male or female pets, and the silicon stops it from creating any metallic clanging that could scare off jumpy pets.

If you ever ride a bike or walk to work through the city, or find yourself mountain-biking or climbing at dusk, you understand the importance of a good flashlight that can easily be mounted to your transportation. I got this through the mail, and I was impressed not only with the nice, compact box that it comes in, along with slots for the various components, but also with the flashlight itself.This thing is powerful. With a few twists of the end, it can be zoomed to a very direct beam, or be zoomed out so that it provides a large round swath that will cut through the darkness and highlight any parked cars or poles or trees or whatever else. When you hold the green button for a longer moment, it will also provide a strobe option. The rechargeable battery is a plus, but there is a fitting that can make three AAA batteries also work in it.For those serious or recreational riders, this is a great little flashlight. And it's awfully handy even if you're not riding a bike. It's one of the best rechargeable batteries and powerful flashlights I've come across. Love it!

My wife and I appreciate good showers, and the AquaFlow 5 Function is one of the better ones we've found for its price. It is easy to install, and it offers five different functions: a rainy mist (which we liked a lot), a regular rain (which we also liked), a steady flow (which was okay), a harder steady massage-type flow (which was pretty good), and then a drizzly option (which seemed very unnecessary).With three or four decent options, we were happy with it, and the only recommendation I'd give to the designers is to add some sort of grooves along the circular frame so that its easier to grip with wet hands while trying to shift between functions.If you want an economical choice, this is definitely recommended.

I've read some great books by King, including one of my favorites, 11/22/63. With expectations high, I opened to the first page of Revival.Revival is a quick, easy read, but if you're looking for something different from King, look elsewhere. It starts in Castle County, Maine, with a young boy who is wowed by the town's new preacher, a charismatic man with a penchant for electricity. When the preacher loses his family in an accident, he abandons his religious beliefs and leaves town. The boy grows up, joins a rock band, and eventually runs into the preacher-turned-carny act later in life.It all seems very familiar from King. Once again, he leads into nostalgia and what seem like semi-autobiographical snippets about '66 Ford Galaxies, losing virginity, playing rhythm guitar in rock bands, carnivals, and dealing with heroin addiction. He meanders. He throws out bits of quasi-wisdom learned over time. To keep some tension, he keeps reminding us of the former reverend and his electricity-inspired "cures." It all promises a horrifying, disturbing conclusion, which it tries very hard to deliver, but it all dies before it can be revived. King's attempt to scare us is based on nothing more substantial than his own juvenile fears from reading Lovecraft books. His version of the afterlife is just as hard to swallow as any of the ones he tries to debunk.I was hoping for something new and fresh from King, but Revival doesn't live up to its own name. I wanted to like this. I tried to like this. In the end, though, I was very disappointed. I felt like King was beating a dead horse. And in fact, he was. He gives us a glimpse of his motivation behind this story, directly referencing the book Heaven is for Real, and its notion of a wonderful afterlife. Revival seems to be his stony-eyed answer to that, his peek into the void. And it's a ludicrous, silly peek. There is not even one full page of genuine suspense or fear. King's earned his right to some nostalgic rambling, but we've heard it all before from him. I'm ready for a real Revival.

The spiral slicer arrived quickly, and it's a nice looking gadget. I loved the idea of a quick and easy kitchen tool for adding some style and pizazz to salads, casseroles, and so on. In theory, it all works well. You put your vegetable of choice in either end and twist, the same way you would a screwdriver. The blades, which are very sharp, slice and dispense into your bowl or dish. Easy enough.A few small quibbles, though. First, the stainless steel handles aren't real smooth on the edges, and I was almost afraid I'd get cut when gripping them tightly. That didn't happen, but it would be nice if they were smoothed. The entire tool is lightweight, which is nice, but it feels like it could break in my large hands. (I'm a six-foot tall guy.) Also, the video I thought would come with the order is actually something you access online.Overall, the spiral slicer performs as advertised, though I would've liked to see it upgraded on toughness and smoothness of the handles. If you intend to do lots of big-party prep, this will wear you out, as it's all done by hand. For smaller scenarios, it's a perfect little item, and quick for setup and cleaning.

Why do you need this? Anyone with small children knows what it's like to lug around heavy equipment, from car seats to strollers to portable cribs. We feel like we're moving an army just to go to the holidays at the relatives' house. Who wants to add another thing to the list?Imagine my surprise when this came through the mail and we opened it up. It is lightweight, foldable, and flexible, easily packed in a light nylon carrying case that can even fit underneath the seat of a car. In seconds, it can be removed from its case and popped open into a fully functional play pit for children. Fill it with pit balls (not included), and you have a ball pit for a boy. Cover the top with a blanket, and you have a perfect fort and hiding place, or a tea room for two little princesses. The zippered round doors on either end can close in a small toddler, or be open for kids making their way through this fun contraption. It's roomy enough for two children to play in.Our grandson loves the colors and was instantly excited when he saw it. I wish I was a small kid again, just so I could climb inside and join in the fun.

These accessories are well-thought out. Not only does the drinking straw provide safe water, but these items can be easily tucked away to enhance and elongate the experience for those who are serious or casual about their outdoor adventures. The tubing and syringe provide easier access, so you don't have to lay on your belly to suck water from a pond through the straw, and the extra bags and filter items mean you won't have to worry for a long time about being out of safe, clean, drinkable water. Diercon is doing something right, and despite some English irregularities on the packaging, they back up their products with good service. Definitely a winner.

I received this in the mail quickly, along with the additional filters, piping, and syringe for easier access to pond water. I've wanted to try this product ever since first hearing of it. I'm an avid camper, hiker, outdoorsman, and this seems like an indispensable tool for anyone in the wild.The product itself is easy to use, though a basic instruction sheet would've been helpful to explain some of the setup. It's all pretty self-explanatory, though. Not a big issue. On the humorous end, the descriptions on the packaging seemed to be written by someone who speaks English as a second-language. There were some odd turns of phrases and words. Again, not a big issue. I was surprised to see that my unit had only a 1-year warranty mentioned on it, when the Amazon page states that it has a 2-year warranty. Perhaps they're getting rid of old stock first, but that is a big difference in promises stated.Overall, this product is easy to use, and has the potential to save lives. Definitely recommended.

I ordered and received this quickly through the mail, hoping for good things. I didn't expect it to work so effectively, though! The Powerbank Flashlight does everything as advertised. It has a very powerful flashlight beam, while still fitting in your pocket. It can be used on a dim switch and strobe switch as well. And, for road trips, camping trips, flights, whatever, it works fantastically at charging any item you can connect it to with the included USB cord, from laptops to cell phones. Now if only this had a way to attach it to keychain or belt loop, it would be perfect. This is now an indispensable part of my supplies for any trip, and it's just plain handy around the house. I love the my Powerbank.

This is a handy little urinal for our young grandson. He loves the color and design, and we're thankful for anything that helps him stay on task when it comes to potty-training. The spinning target is a great little twist, to keep a young man focused. And it's not difficult to dump this into the big people's toilet and rinse it if need be. My only real complaint, and it could be an issue for others, is that it's made to fasten to a tile bathroom wall, which just isn't the norm in American bathrooms. It can stand on its own, on the floor, but there is the risk of it being knocked over, and it then sits lower than expected. Surely, there's a way to make this work better for US customers. Still, it's a nice little training tool for those with young ones in the house.

Ninie Hammon continues to impress. Each of her novels takes us on a journey into the hearts and minds of a wide cast of characters, and each story dives deeply into serious subjects. Don't get me wrong. Her books will entertain you and keep you flipping the pages. She pulls no punches, and no characters are safe. But she will also move you emotionally, whether she's exploring the horrors of genocide in Sudan, the nuances of the death penalty, the pain of abuse, or the effects of drugs on a small community.In "Home Grown," we meet Sarabeth Bingham, a woman returning after college to her hometown in the hills of Kentucky. Her father, the newspaper editor, has been murdered, and she must not only deal with his funeral but with the trial of the indicted killer. When she takes over her dad's paper, she doesn't realize that it will lead her on a deadly trail into the truth of the county's drug market and the real identity of her dad's killer. She meets old friends, makes new enemies, and flirts with love. Lurking, though, at the edges of her world, a ruthless man will stop at nothing to keep her from bringing down his kingdom.Hammon takes the real-life facts of one of the nation's largest drug busts, over 182 tons of illegally grown marijuana, and mixes those in with some memorable characters and unforgettable scenes. This is hard-hitting stuff, showing us drug use, brutal murders, and suicides. As usual, Hammon spends some time setting up her story and conflicts. There's a lot to keep track of, and there are at least five main characters with "B" names, which makes that chore tougher, but she twists all these plot threads into a story that you can't put down.This is the fourth Hammon novel I've read, and I can't wait for her fifth, "Black Sunshine." I know it will serve up more of her trademarks: unflinching honesty, relevant issues, deep characterization, and a climax full of suspense and surprises.

H.G. Wells is one of my favorite authors, and so it was with no small thrill that I discovered this relatively unknown work of his in my local library. At under 100 pages, it is a one-sitting story, and I plowed through it quickly.Our first-person narrator is a croquet player, an Englishman raised by his wealthy aunt. While sitting on a terrace at a resort of sorts, he strikes up a conversation with a doctor. The doctor feels the need to get a weight off his chest, and our croquet player agrees to hear him out. Soon, the doctor works himself into a froth, worried about some Evil that lurks about the premises and beyond, something that others think even oozes up from the ground. The croquet player thinks over these things, then meets another doctor the next day. This doctor says the first man has been driven mad by the fears of modern man's violence and monstrous inclinations. But this doctor seems nearly as mad, his insanity wrapped in a sense of man's primitive past that has reared up through modern civilities and displayed its true colors.Written between the two world wars, this novella is an attempt to study the dark side of human nature. Wells, devoted to evolutionary and Darwinistic theory, tries as he may to come up with an explanation for an evolving humanity that seems instead to be devolving on many levels. He makes a concerted attempt to debunk any religious types in his book (and in most of his books, for that matter), but he fails to come up with anything as frightening or believable as Robert Louis Stevenson's Jekyl and Hyde symbolism. Sadly, his scientific effort at a metaphysical question comes up flat. Nevetheless, I love his scientific honesty to face the question at all.In the end, the croquet player is given a choice between being a quiet, apathetic victim to this evil, or being a vigilante who fights against it. The croquet player's final decision is a telling and ironic one.

Like Jules Verne (whom Wells references in this novel), H.G. Wells wrote with keen imagination and a prophetic eye. From his cautionary tale in "War of the Worlds" to his ethical explorations in "The Island of Dr. Moreau," Wells added a rich and controlled anger in his writing. He coupled imaginative storytelling with a readable style that endures over a century later."The First Men in the Moon" suffers from its now-known lack of accuracy in details regarding the moon, but that makes it no less enjoyable. In fact, this is one of the more carefree and adventurous of Wells' books. From the moment Mr. Bedford encounters an inventor named Cavor to the moment they leave earth's atmosphere to the scenes in which they battle Selenites in the craters of the moon, we are pulled along in this surprisingly fast-paced, funny, and creative tale. And, though some details are now outdated, there are quite a few that proved remarkable accurate, considering men did not land on the moon for nearly seven decades after this book was penned.I loved Wells' ideas with the fauna, mooncalves, and social systems within the Selenite colonies. He brings great energy and fun to this story. Near the end, he proves his prophetic abilities when he says, "All about me . . . a leathery noise like the rustling of beetle wings, and a great bleating and twittering." Seems he even predicted Twitter. Regarding a book as serious as "War of the Worlds," I would never make such a wisecrack, but "The First Men in the Moon" is a book worth a few hours of fun, adventure, and a few smiles along the way. Only in its final pages does Wells give us a characteristic caution, and one with a touch of sad irony.

One of Steinbeck's earlier novels, "To a God Unknown" is often overlooked by teachers and avid readers. Reviews here gave me two incorrect impressions: first, that it was set in the early 1800s, when it's actually the early 1900s; second, that it's preachy, when it's actually full of questions and murky answers. And that's what I liked best about it."To a God Unknown" follows Joseph Wayne, who has been blessed by his dying father. Joseph heads from Vermont to California's rich farmlands. He believes his father is watching over his endeavors, embodied in a tree on the land. He loves his homestead, invites his brothers and their families to join him, and together they create a paradise for themselves. Yet darkness lurks along the edges, in a glade full of foreboding, and in the dissensions between siblings. It's hard not to be reminded in small ways of the biblical story of Joseph, blessed by his father, disparaged by his brothers, but neither the biblical references nor the pagan sacrifices can be easily categorized here.Steinbeck spent five years writing this book, though it's a barely a third the length of "East of Eden," which was written much quicker. I can see the wrestling here in the characters, Joseph, Elizabeth, Rama, and so on. Each of them views life and death through different eyes and beliefs. Each of them embraces or shuns the land, based on these beliefs. Steinbeck gives rich descriptions of the terrain and the foliage, and he inhabits it with this rich cast of characters. As in almost all of his works, the vibrant energy of life throbs throughout, and yet is laced with the inevitability of death.While not my favorite Steinbeck novel, I'm amazed that this is not better known and talked about more. It is full of deep searching and struggle. These people wrestle to understand God, the land, life, love, and death. They make courageous choices and foolish ones. In the end, they seem to be children in so many ways, trying to please a God unknown.

Stephen Zimmer is a prolific writer, producing five thick volumes in two separate series over the last few years. His imagination knows few bounds, and he draws from a deep interest in spiritual themes, political dangers, and human emotions. Spirit, soul, and body all get their time on the page."The Seventh Throne" tells the continuing Rising Dawn Saga, with humanity threatened by greedy business, dictatorial governments, and polluted scientific and medical endeavors. On the streets of a country patterned after America, young men and women resist armed troops and try to get videotapes into the public eye, revealing the conspiracies taking place. Our mortal heroes also face threats from Fallen Avatars, Nephilim, and renegade An-Ki (werewolfish creatures). On the good side, though, many An-Ki want to help the humans, and Adonai has not left mankind without assistance through Watchers and Avatars. Even as these battles take place on familiar soil, Frederick and his cohorts dive into the depths of the Void and the Abyss, on a search for Erishkegal, who long ago showed mercy to the children of the Nephilim and took a huge risk that has paid off in unexpected ways. Frederick's journeys are mind-stretching, awe-inspiring, terrible, and awesome. And woven into all of these, Zimmer gives us bits of wisdom about the nature of man, the nature of good and evil, and the beauty of redemption and grace.I enjoyed the first two volumes in The Rising Dawn Saga, recognizing the breadth and depth of Zimmer's vision, but at times found myself skimming sections that included long descriptive passages and a large cast of characters. In this third volume, it all clicks. I didn't want to miss a word. The descriptions are beyond most anything I've read in fantasy, from mythic monsters to emotional human connections, and the creativity is delivered with a barrage of ideas. Zimmer paints an urban fantasy that ranges from the darkest shades of the Abyss to the brightest hues of Adonai's heaven. In between, we find humans fighting dictatorial forces, wolfish creatures walking the earth, and demonic beings applying their deceptions to governmental decisions.In "The Seventh Throne," Zimmer reminds us what "epic" truly means, as opposed to its cheap application to so many things in today's society. My mind was stretched, my heart touched, and my breath taken away. Then, to raise the stakes even higher for the next book, Zimmer delivered a final surprise that shifts our paradigm once again. On every level, this throne rules!

I've always been a fan of biblical Daniel, admiring his struggles against his culture, his tendency to dream and interpret dreams, and his courage in the face of the lions. As a child, I read his story over and over, so I approached Kingstone Media's "Babylon" with a bit of skepticism.Boy, was I proven wrong!"Babylon" is a work of art, bringing to life the story of Daniel, of King Nebuchadnezzar, and of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego in the fiery furnace. Those scenes alone are almost worth the price of this volume. The colors are so rich, the panels exploding with meaning.I never imagined seeing biblical scenes brought to the page with this much drama and vibrancy. If "Babylon" is an indication of the quality of artists and storytellers in the Kingstone stable, than this is a new medium worth watching, reading, and supporting. I'm a novelist with one of Kingstone's imprints, but these comic/graphic-novels are turning me into a fan of this style of storytelling as well.

"The Last Convert of John Harper" is based on a true story of a kid who had brushes with death, later became a pastor, and ended up on the fateful voyage of the Titanic.The story is an engaging one, and some of the artwork and coloring of the Titanic's final moments are gripping. The research is handled well, and the drawings take us back to that time period, which many know well from the James Cameron film. While John Harper's story leads off this enjoyable comic, a scene from the Titanic might've given it a stronger hook and then allowed us to go back and revisit John's childhood and his compulsion to preach the gospel. Instead, we get a bit bogged down in that preachiness, before discovering the power of this true tale."The Last Convert" is a great reminder of God's working in all of our lives, from young to old. The historical bits are footnoted, giving this story some great research and background in the back pages. It's worth the money, especially for those who feel called to share the gospel.

Ever wondered if Dekker would write something to equal his Circle Trilogy? Fear not. Ever wondered if he could collaborate with another author and come up with something even better than his individual novels? Fear not. Ted Dekker gives us high-concept storytelling, while Tosca Lee provides her seamless prose to deliver the first book in a new trilogy--"Forbidden," "Mortal," and "Sovereign.""Forbidden" tells the story of Rom Sebastian, an artisan in the distant future who becomes the recipient of a mysterious vial of blood. This blood holds emotions in it, love, anger, jealousy, and sorrow. But in the future painted by Dekker and Lee, humanity is barely human, having had all other emotions genetically weeded out except for fear. Fear keeps everyone in line, obeying the Order, and safe. It's a brilliant concept, exploring what it means to be human, to be alive. It also explores the seductive dangers of remaining stale but safe. Even as Rom discovers new emotions exploding within and tries to use them for good, his counterpart, the son of the reigning Sovereign, has manufactured his own way to experience emotions and uses them for selfishness and evil. Soon, these two men are on a collision course for the rule of the nations and the choice between fear (Order) or freedom (Chaos).The story starts with a somewhat drab feel, intentionally displaying the results of this "safe" world. It soon picks up speed as Rom and his companions set out on a mission to find a prophesied boy who will lead the way toward something new. Yes, there are quite a few recurring motifs from Dekker's earlier books, particularly the Circle Trilogy--everything from horses, alleyways, blood, and wastelands--but it is given a whole new direction here, which I loved. I would've liked more world-building, though, since the story is set nearly 500 years in the future. While we see references to electricity and underground trains, they seem to be forgotten as horses and a more mythic feel take over. Security systems seem nonexistent, for example, which could've been easily explained by the fact this is a "safe" society where such things are unnecessary.Despite the tiny quibbles, "Forbidden" is a great start to a new trilogy, at times reminding me of the repression in "Fahrenheit 451," and at others, of the political infighting in "Gladiator." The narrative sparkles, while the action scenes get increasingly intense. A beating heart pulses between these pages. And the conclusion leaves us thirsty for more.

Growing up in the church, I saw a constant struggle by parents and pastors to get young ones interested in reading the Bible. New translations and flashy covers were attempted, with some success. But what Kingstone Media does with this colorful adaptation to the comic/graphic-novel is a wonder.This is only volume one, which takes us through the first half of the Old Testament, with vibrant storytelling and pictures. We see Moses receiving the Ten Commandment, Esther becoming queen, Samson fighting with a donkey's jaw bone, and Elijah swept into heaven in a chariot. It is easy to follow and beautifully sketched. A thread runs through the volume, showing the constant search and desire for a redeemer, a savior, giving us promise of greater stories to come in future volumes. Although the adherence to a strict 4000-yr-old earth is not something I necessarily agree with (there is a lot of time available in the time the "earth was formless and void"), I found no quibbles biblically with the interpretations here.Kingstone is the answer I was looking for as a kid and a young teen. Now the question is, will retailers and readers recognize the gift now available to them?

On the recommendation of some Nigerian friends, my wife and I grabbed a copy of "Skin" and sat down for a Saturday evening movie. We expected good things, but we were bowled over by the deep questions and emotion in this film, based upon the true story of Sandra Laing growing up in South Africa during the time of apartheid.Sandra looks black. Which means she cannot be in a relationship with a white or even shop in the same store as the whites. But here parents are both white, and her mother swears that she has never been unfaithful. As Sandra heads to school, the color of her skin becomes an issue for students and parents, not to mention a heartless school master. Sandra's father vows to fight for her, and indeed the question of Sandra's identity is taken to the supreme court, where they judgment decades ago was based solely on appearance. Sandra is classified "black," but later, when genetics and heritage became the standard, her classification is changed to "white."The problem is that Sandra now finds herself in love with a black man. Her father is outraged and goes to extremes to stop the relationship. Her mother seems to be on her side, but then turns against her, stuck between an angry, violent husband and their grown daughter. Sandra is forced to make choices, more than once, that deal with heritage, color, identity, and family. Does love cross these lines? Does love erase these lines?In the end, "Skin" is a powerful movie, told with honesty, grace, hardship, and a cast of fantastic actors. The emotions range from humor to horror to sorrow to muted joy. It is a story that reminds us not only of the injustice of apartheid and racism, but of what it means to be human. I highly recommend it.
