Very nice playmat, obviously fits in with the Schleich farm and horse figures and buildings.My biggest criticism is that when using fence on top of this mat, it is VERY wobbly, and constantly falling down.  Just a breath seems to knock any standing pieces over, and I'm not sure if that's due to the pile of the carpet (maybe it could be tighter to prevent this?), or maybe how light the pieces themselves are.In any case, a nice mat for your Schleich stuff, not garish at all like some playmats, but I do wish the edges had weights or something, as the kids keep  tripping on them.

I've tried several "calming" products over the years for my dog, from the pet store bought, to Amazon, and this is so far the best I have found.I first used it with my 75 lb mutt (13 YO) on 4th of July when we were at my sister's house and I had forgotten to bring my current stock of calming tabs.  Thankfully she had some (this brand in fact), and they worked great!  In the midst of the large fireworks show going on nearby, he was fine!  Couldn't believe it.  He gets more nervous when my 3 kids are being loud and rough in the same room he is, so that is quite a feat.Anyway, I received this to review, after I had already tried it, and realizing it was the same brand only after I got it!  Excellent timing...this will be my new "go to" for sure when it comes to calming tabs.

So I have three kids under 10, and have had several "kids" phones, most of which are crap (and they were also highly rated I might add).  I assume the manufacturers of the other ones I have spent all their product design budget on cutesy design or durability, and none on the drivers or sound quality.This is the first pair that I would listen to myself, just because the sound quality is quite decent.One thing missing on these that I have seen on all other kid designated headphones, is a separate volume control.  These don't have one, so I guess they are "kids" due to the high impact plastic used, the size, and the colorful design, as well as the max decibel ceiling.As mentioned in another headphone review I wrote, maybe most parents (and apparently manufacturers) don't care about sound quality for their kids.  They probably think that crummy sound is good enough for kids, or simply don't care themselves, .  But I have a different view.I consider music to be a very important developmental step for kids, so I really am interested in letting them hear GOOD music (along with any other crap they may like, which is fine), AND good sounding music.So these headphones definitely deliver in that category, but if you really must have the in line volume control for some reason, you will need to look at other models.  I personally have not found that to be such a great add on myself.  And these ARE sound volume limited, so the thing that concerns me most from a hearing safety concern, is already there.These seem quite durable, fit great, and the cord is not over long, like the Kidz Gear pair we have, which is in a constant state of tangletude.Highly recommended if you care at all about sound quality for your kids.The other models I have tried most recently and compared to these are:KidzGear - Huge cord = tangled mess.  Sound slightly better than the truly awful sounding Califones below, but not much betterCalifone (the ones that have animal faces on the ear ups) - these were the absolute worst for sound quality, but they have the best tangle free cord of the three

Just to get this out of the way right off the bat, the link that was shipped to me was not working properly on arrival.  The Link is a small plastic disc shaped object, but they require that you insert the actual prong that goes into the outlet, into the Link, which I think is problematic (and not just for me apparently).Mine didn't work at all, even when I heard the "click" that indicates the plug is seated properly.  Myfox may want to consider shipping the Link already connected IMO.  I'm no engineer, but I would guess that is where the problem lies.Anyway, customer service was top notch, and I got a replacement piece immediately, which worked perfectly, and from that point on, setup was extremely easy.In practice, I like this system overall, but my biggest criticism is the potential cost to make it minimally effective (unless you want to roll the dice and only buy one link for the door or window you think someone will try to break in).You are only shipped with one FOB, which lets the system know if someone came in or out the door, and can set or deactivate the system, so if you have more than one person at home, that's going to be an extra $30 per person (on top of the $279 system as shipped).  You also only receive one sensor, which is great if you only have one door and no windows.  If you have several doors and windows like most of surburbia, I hope you are wealthy, because this is going to cost you.  $50 for every sensor adds up fast.  For me personally, if I were to tally the costs for my home:$279 for the base unit - covers one door, and includes one FOBextra FOB for wife: $302 sensors for back door and door to patio: $1005 sensors for external, ground level windows:$250So for me, if I wanted to be covered, and taking full advantage of the FOB functionality, the cost would be $659.  If you have kids, and want fobs for them also, keep adding.Now onto the good, which is considerable.  First, the design and aesthetics of the whole system is top notch.  The key fob is nice and small, and svelte, even.  The sensors are hardly noticeable, and are one piece units (not two like traditional magnet based systems).The alarm is nice and LOUD.  When we accidentally set up off the alarm at 6:30 the first morning, I went close to the siren unit and could feel the sound waves pummeling my kidney.  It's that loud.I LOVE the fact that you can adjust the sensitivity of the sensors from the app...that is just awesome functionality in my book.I do think they need to add a one pager to the material shipped to you with tips, or even add tips to the app setup process - like "where to place the sensor (I had to dig in the FAQ to find that best practice for placement is horizontal or vertical, depending on whether or not it's a door or window, and for doors, at the top, about 2/3 the width of door AWAY from the hinge).I will not be buying the camera personally, just because I don't feel the need to, but I will be buying another fob and some additional sensors.  I have tried a few systems (some with cameras, some not), and I like this one the best so far, and feel comfortable going "all in".Recommended, with the cost caveat depending on # family members and doors/windows.

Some of the better healthy bars I have tried in terms of sheer taste.  Larabars are ok, but a little too gooey/mucky for my taste.These have the perfect texture and sweetness, and definitely taste like they have more than 10g of sugar.  Impressive.I will definitely buy these as long as they are reasonably priced.

My 13 YO mixed breed has not been eating well lately at all...skipping meals, not eating his "morning crunchy bone" per normal, and VERY little food at night.  Probably due to heat, but maybe due to age as well, not sure.Anyhoo, I thought I would try this out to see if he ate it any better, and even though the first time I mixed it up, I thought it was way too watery, he lapped it up like he had never eaten before!  So maybe he is just tired of his current food (and I buy premium stuff).So just based on that anecdotal evidence, and the fact that it's easy to store, mix and serve, I am quite pleased with the results.The fact that he didn't get sick switching on the fly like that from his current food to this, was a bonus as well.Highly recommended.

The first thing that strikes you about this beast is how good it feels in your hands...really solid, built well...quality.The second thing that strikes you (me at least), after you screw the lid on, and test out the button, is how cheaply made the top is.  The button is so mushy and cheap compared to the rest of the mug, that it really stands out.Having owned soo many of these type vacuum mugs over the course of a decade, I feel confident predicting that the top mechanism will wear out long before the container does...leaving you with a topless (!) mug.Seriously, if you're going to put in the obvious effort to make and market something as being quality, do it right!  ESPECIALLY the top.  9/10 failures or problems on my previous mugs have been with the lids.Anybody can make a sturdy metal cylinder...but to make a well built lid for that cylinder that lasts...that is apparently a challenge based on what I've seen in the market.  I give the container itself 5 stars, but the lid, 1 star.  Thus the 3 star rating..."It's OK".EDIT:  I hate to downgrade, but I took another star off this mug because after several uses, that top is worse than I first feared.  Just horrible action.  So many better options out there on the market for these, that there is no need to settle for a crap lid.

EDIT (11/10/15)See update below  - added one star after finishing the bottleOK shampoo, but I use it just occasionally, and only for our 4YO boy - simply not enough conditioning (if any?) going on in this bottle for longer girls hair.Smell is quite overpowering, but not unpleasant - I would say right on the verge of smelling like teen spirit (AXE, etc), so if you or your kids are allergic to strong fragrances, stay away.  Also, if you are looking for natural ingredients, stay away, you won't find it here.And that's not a knock...as I said, I use this occasionally, to get the slight (hopefully) boost in moisture that my son's hair needs on occasion.  I also use more natural/environmentally friendly shampoos on a more frequent basis with him since there are sooo many options for that now.Almost doesn't make sense to buy these chemically heavy shampoos anymore unless price is absolutely the highest concern.UPDATE:  I added one star to this since it does something that many "combo" kids' hair wash (shampoo + conditioner) do not, which is really moisturize the hair.  At first I didn't notice, because it is subtle, but I can really tell a difference when using this, that the conditioner is in there, and works.  It's obviously not the same effect as using a dedicated conditioner, so it's more like Pert, in that it conditions a little.OTOH, I REALLY hate the "fragrance" - it's really strong, and smells like eau de hooker to me.  Not taking off for the fragrance, because that is a personal preference, but thought I would note that it is obnoxious and overpowering (to me).

Stitching is of very high quality, as is the material itself.  Very thick (which may be a good or bad thing depending on your environment).They need to adjust their size options on the listing, because currently XXS is not even listed on the Amazon size chart.  I got an XXS for a 4 almost 5 YO, and it was a bit big, FWIW (he is average build and height for age).Impressed with the quality overall, but at this age, honestly, they will wear these sizes for one season and done, so really except for comfort, durability is not my biggest concern.

Really like this line from Dove, and have used the facial cleanser/moisturizer for men, the deodorant, and now this bar form soap.I started using it because they used to offer an unscented version as well (throughout the line as far as I could tell), but it appears they have stopped producing that option unfortunately.I like this bar because it's dual purpose face/body, and I have to admit, I feel like the little beads clean a bit better than normal smooth soap after working outside in the yard for 2 hours in 100 weather.The only downside for me personally is the scent, which thankfully is not too strong, relative to other similar "men" products, but it's definitely noticeable.  Not taking stars off for that as it's just a personal preference, but really, IMO, if you want to smell like something, use some decent cologne, instead of smelling like an unholy potpourri of the cheap fragrances they put in these cleaning products, from shampoo, to hair products, to shaving cream, to soap.  /rant

It's OK, the handle itself is nice, molded rubber, and frankly, it does what it states it does - grates or zests, and quite well I might add.  Much better than other utensils I have had in the past.The only big nasty here (and it's a pretty big one) is the very cheap bent steel which is very sharp, and I am not referring to the tiny blades that grate, but the actual edges that are folded up.  On the ends of the blade, are two extremely chintzy black plastic pieces which I imagine will be off after one washing.Still for the cost, hard to argue much here.  The zesting is nice and consistent, and as long as you are careful where you grab this, and how you wash it (probably recommend dishwasher so you don't get cut), it should be fine.

I found these to be merely 'OK', and if given the choice between this, and a Larabar Uber, which it is obviously trying to compete with (or other way around maybe?  Even the typeface on the package is the same!), I will go for the Uber every time.Uber just tastes better, isn't mostly peanuts, and is larger - these bare bars are ridiculously small.  At least make the package somewhat fit the size of the bar.  As is, the package extends WAY beyond the length of the bar.  Booo!Would not recommend only because better (IMO obviously), similar bars out there.

Excellent earbuds that are by far the most comfortable I have ever tried.IMO, NO earbuds are actually comfortable for very long, but after at least 6 or 8 others I have tried, these are by far the MOST comfortable of those.  I think it's due to the largish design that at least for my ears, allowed them to stay in place, which is my biggest gripe about buds in general - constantly falling out.Also should note that you receive a very nice case, with more than enough different sized plugs for your specific ear hole shape.  The default ones that came with mine were ever so slightly big, and when I went to the next size down, heaven!If I could give 4.5 stars, I would, as the sound is also REALLY good in these.  Also probably due to the size of the drivers, which comparably, are huge compared to other buds.Really impressed with these overall, and can highly recommend them to anyone who might be opposed in general to the idea or feel of typical earbuds. Until I tried these, I had basically given up on the idea of earbuds I could wear for more than just a few minutes, but these have made me a believer in the format again.Well done, Yamaha.

I hesitate to give this 4 stars, and I do so only because the product works (so far) as advertised.We bought a new minivan recently, and I noticed in amazement, how long the tires stayed shiny weeks after buying the car off the lot (new).  I wonder now if the dealership didn't use this or a similar product on their car lot.The good:- works GREAT so far, but I do have my doubts about the 6 month claim...that seems...excessively long.- everything you need is included in the box, no skill, or weird, specific car care tools needed- REALLY makes a difference in how your vehicle looks...deep shine on black surfaces has a tendency to do thatThe bad:- Really just one, but it's a doozie.  OMG, SO many little rules and disclaimers built into the instructions (thus the almost 3 star rating).  For me personally, it's right on the line of "that's way too much effort for shiny tires", but if you are a car nut, or clean car freak, this is the product for you.  Yes, it takes a lot of work, but yes it also delivers the results that you won't get from just spraying some STP tire cleaner foam on your tires and leaving it.Some of the restrictions are:1. Must be in a well ventilated area (believe it sister, this stuff smells REALLY toxic)2. Must not apply in heat or sunshine3. Must not get wet (they even list DEW as "getting wet" and recommend you put the car in the garage for 24 hrs after applying) after application4. tire must be ABSOLUTELY free of all dirt, grease, oxidation, etc.  Until when you wipe it with a white cloth, it comes away clean.  Do you realize how HARD you must work at cleaning tires to get to that point?  It's not easy, and the tire I used this on are relatively new.  Can only imagine the effort involved for older tires.So as you can see, yes, the product is brilliant, but I would only recommend for car care freaks who already spend tons of time cleaning and using chamois on their Preciousesssss.  Others need not apply, and in fact you can even make the tire looks worse with streaking and whatnot if you don't follow the instructions (according again, to the instructions).  And apparently, if you DO screw up, and it streaks, another coat will not fix it!  That's pretty much verbatim from the instructions...so be careful out there!  :D

This is the second compression shirt from Underworks I bought after being blown away by the tank top version ("body shirt").For some reason though, Underworks does not have a consistent size policy.  They list a chest size of 44-47 for XL on this "chest binder", but on the other Underworks shirt I bought, 44 would be L, and the only difference between the two is the width of the material on top of the shoulders...one is wide, and one is narrow like a traditional tank top).  XL for the "body shirt" is 49-53!  Huge difference, and I think even an inch off in size (for your chest) would make a world of difference in the effect and fit.So the 'body shirt' (with the narrower shoulder strips) fits me PERFECTLY, with my measured 44" chest.  I bought this chest binder in XL using their scale (XL = 44-47), which is a bit loose, and the results of the slimming effect are obvious less than the other shirt.I will say that the extra width of the shoulder straps on this shirt makes it easier to put on and off (the thin strips of the body shirt/tank top, tend to roll up too easily I think)But overall, my impression from both shirts is astonishment and how comfortable they are, and how well they slim my chest, which frankly is embarrassing (used to work out my pecs daily at a gym, for years, and now they are paying me back for that!).Cannot recommend this strongly enough, but make sure of fit.  Hopefully the company is good with returns.  IMO it should be REALLY difficult to get on and off, but not uncomfortable once in place.  If it's not difficult to get into or out of, you probably need to go down a size.

Used this without any preconceived notion except maybe for the brand, which I am ambivalent about for the most part.But after spending some time on my '08 Mazda CX-9, wow!  Completely impressed.  Mom was visiting while I was doing my car, and I was so impressed (and so was she), that I did her mini-van as well.There are some materials that really improve with a coating or two of this, compared to others, but specifically of note are tires, which prevents me from using the nasty tire foam I have used for years, and windshield wipers, which seem to "grey out" first.Really, very impressed with this so far, even though it takes quite a bit of elbow grease, if you want great results.  I could see how if you are not a neat person, you might make a mess with this, so buyer beware.  It's basically like shoe dye...so make you you have a wet paper towel or something handy while applying.Also, like other similar products, I think the answer to optimal results is LAYERS, not one heavy coat.  Put on an initial coat, then come back and another.  If it's REALLY greyed out, you may need one more.I am leery of the claimed "more than one year" shine, but even 6 months with this kind of difference in look would be worth it IMO.Highly recommend if you have lots of black rubber and plastic parts on the exterior of your car.  In my particular case, the molded plastic parts responded much better to the coats than rubber, which tended to streak when applied, but still looked better than previously.

I've been in sales for about 20 years now, constantly flying to other countries, so luggage is something I am quite familiar with, having bought more than a few cases this size over the years (at least 5 or 6).I also have three young kids who often travel, so I have tried different kids luggage as well.I have high hopes for this in terms of durability, as the last attempt at having each kid have their own cutesy suitcase ended with me carrying the broken (during the trip) animal-faced hard cases due to shoddy quality.  Smiling anthropomorphic luggage is great until it breaks, and then those smiles seem to be sneering at you and your fumbling.  Evil.Anyhoo, this piece looks like it smartly rides the line between "adult" luggage, and the cute, but poorly made kiddy stuff.Overall, construction seems tight, but I do wonder about the longevity of the plastic clam shell which is a little thin (I am sure, due to making it as light as possible).  We'll see - I will report back after a few trips.Also note that the verbiage claims "in line skate wheels", and uhhhh, no.  Wheels, yes, but not the inline skate variety that you see on so much luggage these days (and in line skates for that matter!).  Still, the wheels seem fine - again, need to test further to see how they hold up.If you care about looks when it comes to luggage (I don't, but my 10 year old who uses this does), you will be fine, here.  Very good presentation, not to kiddy, but still a little fun.  I can see a teen using this even, without any shame.Fasten points are nice and sturdy, rolls really well, ridiculously smooth, and the variety of options in terms of moving the bag are REALLY nice when traveling.  This is a spinner, but it also has handles on two side, and of course you can pull behind you as well (on two wheels).So far, highly recommended on first look.

Orange and Cinnamon was the only real surprise here, in that it has a unique (in a good way) flavor profile, whereas the other teas in this sampler tasted similar to other brands I have tried for the same type (chamomile, et al)Overall a good purchase if you are just looking to try different kinds of tea, (personally I love samplers of any kind of food items, due to my obsession with having lots of choice), and I will definitely be picking up a dedicated box of the orange tea in the future.

What a waste of money.  There are "black lights", and then there are black lights.  This, sir, is no black light.  Yes, it is tinted purple, but a.  it's incredibly weak, and would not even light up some black light glowing spiderwebs 2 feet in front of it, and b. even when things were placed directly in front of it, it didn't give it that glow that you get with a proper black light.I guess I will keep looking for MR16 black lights, but this is sure not it, and wow what an expensive lesson.

I will start off by saying that I recognize that this company produces some of the highest rated shower caddies on Amazon, but for my particular shower and tastes I guess, it just does not impress at all.First, it's very cheaply made, and shows.  The fact that it's so light weight means it will likely be moving around a lot in your shower, even when there are bottles in it.There are no suction cups, or even rubber backing on this to prevent or minimize sliding/movement/swinging, so that was a bit of a letdown.More to the point, is that the actual sizes of the non-adjustable shelves doesn't make sense, since the lowest shelf is extremely short, almost forcing you to put most items in the top shelf, which is awkward.One thing I do like is the blue plastic on the front - it's a nice touch and really makes it look nicer than just a wire rack BUT it also obstructs your view of the things behind it.  Double edged sword I guess.I was looking to replace our rusted over the shower door unit, which has a towel rack on the exterior side, and a similar rack to this one on the inside, but I am still searching for a better solution to either of these.  Thinking maybe a tension adjustable pole is the way to go here, even knowing the prices are way way up there on those (but hopefully a more permanent solution, and would look nicer to boot).Just can't recommend this one with so many others out there, including ASIN: B002XISHF2 .

Since I'm not a food biologist, I really don't have a way of knowing how the content of these compares to the extremely expensive pills for joint support that my vet suggested for my dog.I can only note that compared to the hard, but clean pills, the way these are packaged seems inconvenient and unnecessary on two points:1. My dog eats the pills as quickly/easily as he does these very messy, stinky globs of chewy.2. The package is such that when you pull back the celophane wrapper, it stays curled back and "open" as it were.  Nothing to close it back or keep it fresh (or keep bugs or whatnot from trying to get to it).Again, it's hard to comment on the quality of the ingredients (which seem to be very similar to the ones in my expensive vet pills), but as for the other traits, I personally didn't like the packaging (compared to other "systems", or even just dry pills, whose bottle top you can just close shut, and don't get your hands all nasty when you get them out), so I would not buy these normally, especially with so many other options out there.

Really high quality reading lamp, that we actually use for a low level light when it's bedtime for our 9YO daughter.4 stars because the quality of the construction is excellent, and best of all, the quality of the light is IMO perfect.  Not too bright, not too dim, and color temperature is not the blue tone you get with so many LED reading lights these days (we have several).The clamp, as others have mentioned, is EXTREMELY sturdy, and I'm so glad considering we are putting this on our pre-teen daughter's headboard.  Light hasn't moved since I clamped it there weeks ago.My only minor nit, is that when I clamped the light down on top of the headboard (from the top), the flex in the "necK" of the light didn't seem to like being in the position I wanted (cobra like), which I thought was strange considering I assume it was designed for that position.  Probably wouldn't notice this unless you are clamping DOWN on a vertical surface though (like a headboard).I will try a few more positions for the clamp, but even as is, hasn't caused problems, and our daughter loves it.  Especially compared to the previous book clamp lights she had, which constantly fell off, or had battery issues, or just plain stopped working.Highly recommend.

Love this unit, especially now that I have installed it and it's been in use during some very dry, indoor conditions.When I first opened the box it was packaged in, I thought immediately that it was likely going to be junk, given the poor quality and shoddy packaging (just cheap plastic), and the relatively light weight of the base unit itself.Well, it may be cheap (and I think this is intentional - i.e. a low cost, but high functioning weather unit), but I absolutely love the results to date.I have three kids, some of whom get really dry, stuffy noses in winter.  They all have their own bedrooms upstairs (master BR is down), and we also have a main living area that varies wildly in temperature and humidity due to proximity to the kitchen, doors opening and closing nearby, and a fireplace to boot.The fact that I am able to set a sensor in each room and monitor the humidity levels so easily and quickly is just awesome.  Nothing complicated here, but I think that's the reason I like it.  You simply glance at the large sized numbers and can immediately get a very clear picture of what is going on, temp and humidity-wise, all over the house.I have not had the problem with range that others have mentioned, and we have a very large house, with all three kids bedrooms quite far from the main base unit.I will likely add two more sensors to the three that came with this, just to cover the master bedroom, and the outdoors.  The only disadvantage that I can see that adding units will cause, is that you won't be able to see all units' readings at a glance, since you will have to scroll by pushing a button, to see more than 4 readings at a time.  Not a big deal, and actually if they had made the font size smaller to accommodate additional units, I guarantee you most would complain that the numbers are hard to read due to the small size *they are perfect as is, I can read it from 12+ feet away.The fact that you can calibrate these (given the cost) is amazing to me, and I found the instructions MUCH better than I was expecting on first seeing the unit after unpacking.  Every one of my remote units was within 1% of the rh reading on the existing hygrometer I had, but I am not sure if that is typical or not.Overall, I highly recommend this if you are interested in a very reasonably priced weather unit that was obviously designed for simplicity and cost, but also "just works", and works well I might add.

Overall, I am pleased with this wine rack, and was pleasantly surprised to note just how many slots it has.On a positive note, the finish of the wood is very nice, a neutral earthy tone, but at least mine is much lighter than what is shown in the picture.  I would call it almost grey-green, but that sounds bad - it really is a pleasant, neutral color.  The wood is also EXTREMELY smooth to the touch, which I was pleasantly surprised by.  They really did a great job of finishing this.I also like the difference in shape to hold the rear part of the bottle vs the front.  I have a wine rack table I bought from Pier One many years ago that has a rack with no differentiation in size between the front and the back, and I have had more than one bottle fall out due to the poor design.Now for the negatives, which are not that big of a deal, and I don't see them having a long term impact on my use or enjoyment.For one, the wood used here is extremely lightweight (probably pine, because of the cost), and thus is susceptible to dings, dents, and in my case, when I was putting it together, pieces around the pre-drilled holes chipping off.  Fortunately, this didn't happen in a spot that is visible after assembly.  Bottom line: don't expect oak here, it's definitely cheap wood, but the finish will hide any dings or dents that will happen I think.Finally, just a nit to pick about the instructions, which I found a bit frustrating.  Primarily because I noticed that the picture in one of the first graphics is wrong (can't remember exactly which step, but it showed one of the pieces as having two dowels, that in reality only had one) which made assembly take a lot longer than it needed to.  OTOH, they did nicely package the hardware in separate bags, and marked by step!  Love this idea, and I wish others would follow suit.Overall, a good to very good wine rack I think, but note that it holds a whopping 56 bottles - if you typically have only a few bottles of wine laying around, and want somewhere to store them, this rack is not for you, as I think less than 10 bottles would look a little silly.

I guess I will once again come down on the minority side of a product, and say that I was quite disappointed with this.If it wasn't for my 6YO saying she liked it, I would have given it 2 stars instead of 3 (but I guarantee you she will not ask to play with this again, unprompted).Overall, this seems like a nice package, and they way the box presents it, is really well done, so I think as gift, this would probably be impressive (initially).  The problems I have with it are pretty basic though...the unique "thing" about this set is that you can create "figures" that stand up, using the included tattoos (ponies, faeries, butterflies, etc).  That's a cool idea, in theory.  In actuality, even my 6 YO could not get a decent transfer onto the dough.  I tried 2 or three, and never got a perfect one, and that was following the directions precisely (and be 10x more careful than a typical 4YO would).As for the other features, pretty standard fare for play-doh type sets...there's a teapot that is used to extrude the dough, but as with every single one of these sets we have used before, clean up after the fact is a real chore (and I should say that my 9YO had trouble extruding...VERY difficult to push down and get the dough to come out with the filter in place).So overall, while this is going to look good on the toy store shelf to your kid, and is going to seem like a great bday present gift when first opened, once you actually start to use it, the luster is lost pretty quickly.Can't recommend this really, when there are so many other, better sets out there.

I think it's interesting, and a little disturbing I guess, to see a website like the Environmental Working Group (ewg.org) give out ratings to so many companies's products that are claiming non-toxic, gentle, green ingredients, when in fact they are apparently just subbing out traditionally used, toxic ingredients, for new, not as known, ones!I'm no chemist, so I have to rely on such independent sites to get my information.  And while the company's claims of "no parabens, sulfates, phthalates" is true, it's ALSO true that it has what some would consider to be a toxic chemical in it (albeit just a trace amount).So for me, considering there ARE now (thankfully) a boatload of similar, health conscious products on the market (and readily available in any Target or grocery store), I will tend towards those instead of this brand.I love the fact that this is fragrance-free, and it feels and smells EXACTLY like the product I have been using for years now, on all three of our kids, which is Johnson and Johnson's version of this (fragrance free, dye free foaming shampoo/soap).  It's good stuff, and I haven't found anything better to date.If I am going to the extra effort and expense of buying so called "green" products, then I want them as green, clean and non-toxic as possible.  This particular soap unfortunately doesn't seem to qualify.

This will be my third, and final Moen faucet, I think, at least concerning their low end stuff (assuming they have a higher end line even).First impressions right out of the box are that this is a REALLY cheaply made product.  So much plastic, that I have my doubts about how long this will last.  The current, "goose neck" designed Moen we have in our kitchen sink currently is leaking from the spout of the pull out wand head, and there doesn't seem to be any way to get to the parts that likely need replacing to fix it (i.e. if I want to fix it, I guess that means buy a new faucet).One last caveat here, is that the instructions are not clear at all, IMO, and quite frustrating (and this is not my first rodeo when it comes to installing plumbing fixtures, either).To end on a positive note, I was so disappointed with the "action" of the button out of the box, that I almost didn't install it.  It felt VERY mushy, and I was hoping that it was only due to it being dry, and that water pressure would make it perk up.  Happy to report that once water is flowing through, the button action is much more precise, and better with tactile feedback than it is when you just take it out of the box and click it on and off, dry.Appearance-wise, this faucet looks ok...for now, but I am quite unimpressed with the amount of plastic used here, and I have the feeling that I will be replacing this one, too, within a few years.  A plumber once told me that you really have to spend $400+ to get a decent kitchen faucet these days, that will last what people expect them to.  I have yet to do that, but getting tired of replacing these, so I guess a $500 that lasts 10 years is better than 3 faucets @ $250+ each during that same time.

So I am a bit of a remote hoarder...I tend to be hard on mine (I also have three young kids), so they wear out quickly in my house, but I also have NEVER found The One (including Harmony One, which I was pretty disappointed in) where I have said "THIS is the remote I want to live with for the next few years!".I've used many different setups in the past:1. Separate remotes for everything (cable box, TV, receiver, DVD player, etc)2. A mixture of using the A/V receiver remote for most functions, but this also required using one or two additional remotes (but still fewer total used than 1. above)3. A hard button, universal remote (made by, shocking no one, the "Universal Remote Control" company - not kidding) that was highly praised at the time it was out, and is still considered a "classic" remote (even though it was a BIG pain to program...no fancy shmancy online or software setup like with the Logitechs today)4. Several Logitech Harmony remotes, ending with the Harmony One, which was generally highly regarded, but I never liked it personally, and mine really only lasted a year or so before the range got really poor, and it began to be very sluggish and slow in general.Having said all that, I LOVE this remote.  It marries the best of both remote worlds...the flexibility and power of a touch screen, with the simplicity and great tactile feedback of a hard button remote.  The only quandary you will be faced with when using this system is "which is closer, my smart phone, or the "simple" Logitech remote?", OR in some cases, "what do I need to do?" (some things the smartphone app is better at/easier doing, and some things the hard button remote is easier).All is not perfect in Peace, Love and Harmony Land, but soooo close, that I had to give five stars because finally, after SO many years of getting remotes wrong (in my dissenting opinion), Logitech has turned it around and is heading in the right direction (again).So many things that switching to this system from the Harmony One "fixed", that I wish I had made the switch as soon as this Smart Control system came out.  I really hate gushing in general, but I love doing it when it's warranted.  It's warranted here, IMO.PROS:- DUAL systems to cater to those who prefer touch, and those who prefer buttons.  Use both, or either one!  I think this works extremely well, and I find myself using both on a constant basis (with preference to the hard button remote).- This finally puts to rest any problems you may have had with IR, RF, BT, PS3, IRS, OPP, etc....problems...FINALLY I don't have to use a dongle and separate remote just to turn my PS3 on and off (as I did with the Harmony One).  FINALLY I don't have to worry about range, and pointing the stupid Harmony One RIGHT AT (and close in) the device I am trying to control for it to work.  In fact, I didn't even have to program ANYthing (that may be because I imported settings from Harmony One).  Just SUCH a clean implementation of multi...tech (in terms of the "beams" I guess), that I don't even care what device needs to use what tech anymore...because this baby does it all in the background for me!- ALMOST perfectly designed hard button remote.  It's small, so it fits your hand much better than that crazy long previous Harmony remotes, which often required two hands to use (one to hold, one to press the top buttons or touch screen).  It feels like it is very well made, with high quality materials - a nice rubberized matte plastic on the back with good grippiness, and relatively short throw buttons on top, which will hopefully last for years without wearing out.-An app that I was expecting to be horrible based on reviews, but I have nothing but praise as it has worked flawlessly for me so far.  I wonder if the poor reviews are from people who downloaded the app but don't own the correct remote maybe?  Or maybe the poor reviews based on an earlier version of the software?  No idea.CONS:- By far, my biggest complaint with this system (really, my ONLY complaint), is that the hard button remote does not have backlit buttons.  To me personally, that is a HUGE flaw on any remote, considering that I like to watch TV/movies in the dark, and when you have a bright screen in front of you, the resulting backlight effect is pretty darn strong, making reading tiny letters really hard (and I have better than 20/20 vision, so it's not that).  But due to the pure awesome sauce that is this system, I will gladly overlook that inconvenience to get all the other goodies it provides.  For now, at least.  If they don't add backlit keys to version 2, I will be pissed.- I guess the only other nit I would pick, is that SOMEtimes, when I pick up my phone to use as the remote, the app will have to "RECONNECT" with the hub, and that takes a second (and the time it takes to connect varies, interestingly), but to date it has not been that big of a deal, just something to consider for someone planning to only use their iPhone as control...One last thing to add...I sit about 10' away from the devices I need to control, all of which are in a cabinet, which is pretty much blocked (line of sight) by a coffee table.  The cabinet has opaque frosted glass doors (devices are behind those doors), which are almost always closed.  Even with all that, my system works perfectly, and I didn't even set it up the optimal way, according to directions, nor did I even use the extra dongle they give you to boost the signal INSIDE cabinets, as suggested.  In my excitement to try out the new remote, I just set the main hub on top of the entertainment center, and it has worked great that way - no problems at all with it "talking" to any of my devices that are enclosed.Obviously, I like this.  I "lahkit alaht" (Dumb and Dumber).  Even if you have been turned off by Logitech's recent offerings in remotes (like me), I highly recommend you give them one more shot.  Primarily, because they so dominated the remote control market for so many years, that it forced most other makers to quit, or go to the high end installer markets (i.e. there's not a whole lot out there any more to choose from).  If you have run into range or line of sight problems, TRY this.  If you are disgusted with the ugly, insanely long and horribly designed two-hander Harmony remotes, TRY this.My only hope is that the next version implements backlit buttons on the hard remote, and maybe, possibly adds a power cradle, but after years of dealing with those, I am not sure I don't like this return to simplicity much better (the hard button remote just uses batteries, nothing internal to charge).EASY 5 stars here, and major kudos to Logitech for turning their Harmony series around, from imminent doom, to a shining beacon of...radio frequency/BT/wifi...light..?  :D

I don't do this much when reviewing an item, but this vac is so bad, I would give it no stars if that was possible.  Even if I didn't compare it to the Roomba that it's trying to copy, I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, for any situation.I'm not even going to go into all the reasons this is junk, because the top three should be sufficient enough to warn anyone that thinks they will be saving money by getting this over a Roomba.  Trust me, you are better off with a broom and dustpan than this.The only positive thing I can say about this is that it's relatively inexpensive and that the idea of the cleaning cloths is great (I wish the Roomba's did this).As a vac though, this "Super Maid" fails on all levels...in most cases creating more mess than was there in the first place due to an incredibly small bin, very little suction, but maybe most important, the fact that ANY little non flat surface completely stumps this unit, and it's not smart enough like Roomba, to know that it's stuck, so will stay there infinitely I guess, until it runs out of batts, just spinning its wheels, and throwing debris everywhere.  Lovely.Also, since there is no way to block off certain areas (like with beacons), it will try to go everywhere, and it's just not made for that.Bottom line is that you will end up having to monitor this constantly while its in use, which really defeats the purpose of these, no?  And not only that, the actual vacuum function is horrible.  Roomba is bad, but this is much worse.  On top of that, it falsely (almost laughable actually) claims to pick up NAILS on the box, and other heavy objects!Just a flat out lie, as it even has trouble with Cheerios in my experience.I could go on, but I won't.  Just trust me - this is a terrible, terrible robotic vac, and I tried to think of even one situation where it might be useful and practical, but no - I got nothing, sorry.One star for the wet mopping idea (which is great in theory IMO), but in actuality, zero stars if I could.

I have more than a few Mr. Beams' items in my house (ceiling light in shed, multiple stair/step lights for both inside and out), and have been pleased with all of them.The fit and finish on this light is excellent, and has much more of a quality feel to it than my other items.  Soft touch rubber in appropriate places, hard (but not cheap feeling) plastics in others.  Really nice, sturdy unit.My biggest complaint is related to the fact that this requires big, heavy D batteries, which A. is unusual these days, so most people probably don't have a lot of use for this size battery in many items, and B. 4 D batteries add relatively quite a bit of weight if you are taking this hiking or camping.I think I would have preferred that the unit used C's, or give the option for a rechargeable unit (instead of, or in addition to the battery option).Otherwise, the 2 level light is brilliant. and the weather sealing and proofing is quite evident.Highly recommend if you don't consider the D battery requirement to be too inconvenient. I guess you could always use AA batteries in an adapter though, to cut down on weight.

We have used these many times in the past, so we're pretty familiar with both the brand, and these wipes in particular.Noticed that they are quite a bit drier than normal (and even relatively for other wipe brands as well), and I see now that others mentioned the same thing.  As I recall, these have always been on the thin side, which is not great for big blowouts, but of course that is probably part of the green manufacturing at play.Definitely just "OK" now whereas the previous version would have received 4 stars.  I probably will not be buying these again.

I've bought cheap, $200+ swing sets from some of the typical manufacturers, and I got about 2 years out of the last one.  This one is so much better in every single way, except one:  we are missing the most fun swing accessory of all (that we had on a previous Flexible Flyer model) - the awesome yard swing!  If it had this, or at least the option to add this, it would be even better than it already is.No parts missing, delivery of crate was uneventful.  The quality of this has to be seen and felt to be believed.  I'm 5'10" and about 190, and I can swing, slide and hang on every part of this thing it's so sturdy (and the thing doesn't move even when I'm on it with my kids!).  No concrete or supports needed at all.My only gripes, other than the lack of options to fit other kind of swing accessories:1.  the plastic covering for the swing chains (where you hold the swing) is now extremely tacky after our first summer, and I guess due to the summer heat.  Considering this set is marketed for high temps, I was a bit disappointed in that.2. It's not going to burn you, but again, they market the coating to be specifically designed to not get so hot in the sun...which is not really the case (at least where I live).  It definitely does get too hot to the touch unless you have some kind of covering or shade.  I guess it could be worse (pure, uncoated metal), but the reality doesn't live up to the marketing for this feature.But those are relatively minor gripes...I have 3 kids, aged 3 through 9, and they all love this.  Can't recommend enough.

This is the third Oral-B electric toothbrush we have had in the past 13 years or so, and I am impressed that they just seem to get better with every generation (that we try at least - apparently they have hundreds of different models out there!).I hesitate to give 4 stars here, only because I feel that the "extras" included with this high end model are almost ridiculous, compared to the other less costly models.  However, the toothbrush itself, in its basic function of cleaning your teeth, is fantastic, and noticeably better than the previous generations I used.Reasons this gets 4 stars:- spectacular brushing power, action, and results that you can feel (especially if you have not used a good, or modern electric toothbrush)- battery life is crazy good now, you could easily take this on a 2-3 day trip (more?) with no charger- I like the new design for the brush holders.  Our previous model held the brushes in a very confined, vertical compartment, which I felt did not let them air out at all.  This new layout is much better IMO (though takes up more space).- Very small nitpicky thing, but finally I only have to push the button ONCE to stop the brush - on the previous model, you had to push the button 2x for some reason (first world probs!)Reasons for my considering giving three stars:- this particular model is an obvious attempt to cash out on what is at its base model, a great product.  If you look at the comparison chart on the Oral B site, the higher model features, IMO, do not add any value at all, and seem to simply be feature bloat justification to charge more money.- the "travel" case has become ridiculous  - WAY too big and heavy for any serious traveler.  My mother, who packs three suitcases for a 3 day trip, would think this case is awesome.  A real traveler would not consider ever packing this monster.  Yes, it's nice, yes it's quality and well-made, but very anti-travel.So overall, very easy to recommend this, but I would certainly also recommend checking out the Oral B site and looking at all their offerings in this line to see if you really want the extra features that they have added on this model.For me personally, I could care less about the wireless linking between my toothbrush and a digital face that either scorns or praises you, depending on how it thinks your brushing session went.  Judgmental little bastard!  I also don't brush based on zones, or time, or anything, except experience of having done the task for the past 30 plus years.  I don't need a trumped up emoticon to guide me how to do something I've successfully done for so many years (and apparently my teeth are in great shape, according to my dentist)!  :DBottom line is that this toothbrush to me represents the pinnacle of electric toothbrushes, and I believe so strongly in the power of these to clean your teeth better than using a traditional/manual toothbrush, that I have "electric toothbrush" on my family gift list, for all those who don't yet have one.  They really are superior cleaners, and while this particular model is probably a little over the top in terms of features you don't need, at its core, it's a great tool.

We have a few other toys from this company, including the sea plane and the tug boat, both of which are used quite often in both the pool and the bath tub.Compared to those, I would put this rocket slightly ahead in terms of enjoyment factor for our 3 YO, primarily because it's a little more interactive, with two astronauts and a detachable module.I'm personally less interested in the green aspect of these toys (although it's a factor), than I am the idea that in play, sometimes "less is more", which seems to be lost on the current generation of teens and younger.  Specifically, the toys this company makes are great BECAUSE they fly in the face of most modern toys:- they don't have electronics or run on batteries,- they don't make noise or have stickers- they aren't packaged in ridiculously gaudy boxes with Fort Knox level security ties.Is it too minimalist?  I personally don't think so, and in fact I think kids NEED these kinds of "slow" toys these days in the face of Playstations, iPad minis, and robotic animals.  Just good fuel for the imagination, not to mention these will seemingly last forever, they are so sturdily and simply made.Really enjoy everything we have from this company, and looking forward to more offerings (although they already have a pretty extensive catalog).Highly recommended.

Having three children, ages 3 to 9, I find it difficult to play board games these days that include that wide of a range.  On the rare occasions that one or two of the kids are separated, and especially if the youngest is absent or napping, it's much easier, but still a challenge to find something that engages a 3 year+ spread.Many times, if I want to play something that all three can play, we have to go lowest common denominator, and end up with the most simple games, like Candyland (UGH), or simple match games, etc.Recently though, I had the rare treat of being able to break this out and play one on one with my nine year old, which arguably is probably slightly above the recommended "most fun for this age" group.I've played TONS of board games over the years, not to mention all the ones from my childhood, and frankly, I have to say this one gets a mere "meh" from me.  If I could, I would give it precisely 3.5 stars, somewhere between "It's OK" and "I like it", but probably comes down closer to the "It's OK" side.I'm not really down on the game, but it's basically yet another matching game (and it admits as much on the box), with some polish thrown in (BIG die, big, colorful cards, big art on the playing board) to make it seem more exciting.I think kids old enough to play this will see through the fact that it's just not that fun (unless they have never played a matching game before), and will quickly be bored.  I noted that my eldest daughter immediately picked up the accompanying book and started to read that, which to her was more interesting than the game play itself.  :DI'm probably not as down on this as my review comes across, but with so many high quality board games out there for kids in this age range (readers, basically), there is no need to settle for merely an OK game.  Plenty that are much more creative, much more stimulating, and just more fun.In its defense, and going back to my original point, I did successfully play this with all three children, with the 3YO playing together with me.  He was happy to play "the big kid's game", even if I did most of the decision making.  So kudos for making a game that can be played across a broad age range, but again, ultimately, for good readers, I would recommend other, more original and stimulating games before this one.EDIT after playing a few more times:  I actually like this a little better now, that I have played more than once with the two older kids.  I also notice them playing it by themselves on occasion.  Solid 4 stars.  Just a side note...I noticed the 6YO in tears once when the older kid made her give her one of her cards that she liked.  She's a bit immature for her age, so that is more a testament about my kid's inability to deal with..."strife" than it is with the game I guess.  But just note this is not a "yay! everybody wins!" kind of game (thankfully), since there are times when things/cards are taken from you, and you can also "punish" others.

See update below after 2 yrs of useFirst: Contrary to popular belief, a 5 star rating does not indicate "perfect" in Amazon's system, but "I love it".  (4 stars = I like it FWIW)I have three kids, aged 3, 6 and 9, so I have a garage full of child sized vehicles - from scooters, to trikes, to big wheels, to regular bikes.  I also have three ride-ons that use the same action as this Radio Flyer.  Needless to say, I am VERY familiar with ride on toys...from researching and buying, to assembling and repairing.If you are in the market for a ride-on that uses "plasma car" action (back and forth motion to move the vehicle), this one is highly recommended, and a great value at current asking prices on Amazon.  Since I own what I guess are the three most well known ride-ons that use this action, I'll give you a quick comparison based on my experience:The original Plasma Car:  currently selling for about the same price as this Ziggle on Amazon.  While we owe this model our gratitude and respect for bringing the concept about (I think), it's been FAR surpassed by the other two I own, in just about every category except price (and only a few dollars difference from Ziggle at the time of this review).  PASS.  All plastic, LOUD, not smooth at all, and most importantly, it's very difficult to go fast so many kids end up just using their feet on the ground to self propel.  Cool shape?  Yes!  Great, original  idea?  Also yes!  But again, I would not recommend this to anyone with so many other better alternatives in the market.  Also, the travel of the front wheels is so restricted, relative to the other two below, that you have to "twist" twice as fast or more, to get up to the same speed (which in most cases is not even possible).EZY Roller:  This gets FULL 5 stars from 130+ Amazon reviewers for a reason:  it IS all that, and IMO, sits at the top of the plasma ride-on food chain.  This is the mack daddy, but also costs exactly twice as much as the Ziggle.  What that extra $$ gets you is:  more age flexibility (even adults can ride the EZY, with an included extension), a hand brake, a lower to the ground profile, and I think EVER SO SLIGHT of an edge in terms of speed (compared to the Ziggle).  Also HIGHLY recommended.  Get this if you plan to use with older kids, or on hills (since it has a lower center of gravity).Radio Flyer Ziggle:  The reason I am so impressed with this model, is that the build quality is SO good (as good or better than the EZY), yet costs half as much!  I watched my 6 YO test out the EZY and the Ziggle back to back, and finally asked her if she could only choose ONE, what would it be, she chose the Ziggle, I think because she liked the way it turned, and that she felt the handlebars gave her a little more control (EZY only has foot control).  Both of these will zoom though, so I would not even consider that in the equation.I guess my only concern is that they used foam (it is dense, but still) for the hand grips, and I can tell you from experience that that material will likely not last more than a season.  We will see though...maybe I'm wrong.Editing to add after many days of play:  Unless you have one kid, or one ride-on per kid, the seat adjustment on this is a big pain, with 4 bolts and nuts that need to be unscrewed and screwed again each time you adjust the seat.  There are plenty of better ways to do this (ask me how I know), so it's too bad they chose not to use a much faster release mechanism for the seat.  Since I have 3 multi-sized kids, and if I were Dad of the Year (I'm not, therefore I didn't), I would have to remove and re-attach the seat for each kid since they are such different sizes.  The middle kid and the fun-sized kid could probably share a setting, but it wouldn't be comfortable.I should also note that adjusting for length on the Ezy Roller is just as tedious (even more so, maybe, considering you have to use extension pieces that are separate).  Not a huge knock for either ride-on, just a wish list item for a Dad that is basically the riding toy mechanic for three kids, and the neighbor kids as well.So in summary, an easy 5 stars here (4.5 if I could), and kudos to Radio Flyer for putting out such a high quality toy at this price point!  We have a couple other of their outdoor wheeled vehicles (a wagon, and a trike), and this one by far has the best quality feel to it.Edited to add comments after a year of use (10/20/14):  Still going strong after a year, and much usage by our 3 kids, plus plenty of neighborhood kids.  Definitely stand by my 5 star rating...this little 4 wheeler is still smooth as butter, and often preferred over other available "garage vehicles".  :P  It's probably been left out in the rain a couple times at least, and definitely kids too big for it have ridden it, but shows no sign of wear at all.  Again, it's obvious this thing is VERY well made.UPDATE (11/10/15):  Still in top shape after MUCH use for the past couple years.  This has also come to be the most coveted "vehicle" in our garage.  It's just such a great ride on, and as the kids have gotten older, I notice them doing tricks on it that I never knew were possible before....basically drifting at high speeds....so fun...I wish I could ride it!  :D  Can't heap enough praise on both the design and durability of this great toy.  Well done, RF, well done!!  Maybe the best, most fun ride on out there.

After having reviewed the outstanding, but slightly spendy RAB outdoor motion lights, and going through way too many cheap, big box home store offerings that die after a year or two, I am happy to say that this light appears to strike a great balance between quality and price.  I was wondering why there wasn't any competition in this space, but here comes a company I had never heard of, with several offerings in the sector recently.I notice that the price has increased quite a bit for these since I first saw them on Amazon, so not sure if that trend will continue or not.  If it does, I recommend you price compare against the similar RAB offerings.PROS:- easy to install- no bulbs!  LED "dots" put out an amazing amount of light for what they are.  I would definitely recommend this kind of light in an area where you might have concerns about breakage (balls hitting it, etc)- cost, relative to other pure LED offerings, is nice, but again, check against RAB before buying IMO, as their stuff is obviously better made, but can be expensive (and you will have to buy bulbs, which if you get LED outdoor floods, can be about $30 EACH).-Sensor seems to work great- Energy efficient - just crazy how efficient these little LED "nibs" are!  For anyone leaving a security light on all night, or one that gets "tripped" by motion frequently, cannot recommend enough that you switch to LED immediately.CONS:- aesthetically, just as boring and rather ugly as all the other stuff you typically see at the big box stores.  Nothing new here, same old design,- pricing is variable - as of this writing, only about $20 less than the better made, better looking RAB models (but again, note RAB does not come with bulbs, which the All Pro doesn't need)- no 50% power mode - this is one of my very favorite features of many motion detector lights, and even many of the crummy lights at Lowe's have this (sometimes called "Dual Brite" mode).  Not a deal breaker at all, more like "I miss this on the lights I have that don't have this feature".- color - this is probably my biggest beef with the light, but also very much a personal preference.  The light temperature on these is very much in the "cold, blue" variety, which is unappealing to me, at least for residential use.  Fine for businesses, but I personally like the warmer temps for house use (that goes for inside as well).  The too white, almost blue cast, feels very clinical.  Again, YMMV, since some prefer this color.Overall, I have to give this 4 stars for cost, energy efficiency of the LED's, and NO BULB!  What remains to be seen, and what fails so quickly on most consumer motion detectors, are the crummy sensors.  I am hoping the one included with this unit will last for years (and if not, I will come back here and update the review of course).UPDATE 10/17/14:  one year later, still working, no problems at all.  The bluish color of the light is very annoying though, but as mentioned before, that is a personal preference more than a design flaw.

I was so excited to try this since I have three kids, and many times they will run to open the door whenever the doorbell rings, which drives me nuts.We also use an older VTech answering system for our home phone which is connected to an Ooma VOIP system.  I have replaced the batteries twice in the older Vtech now 2x, and still will not hold a charge in the hand held units, so it was time to upgrade.On first impression, this phone looks sleek and modern compared to my older Vtechs, albeit a bit large and gangly (tall).  Unfortunately, right out of the gate, I was disappointed to note that these very tall units do not stand up vertically on their own very well compared to my older, wider units.  And considering that that's exactly the position you want these to be in so you can view the screen, that already is a pretty big strike in my book.  They WILL stand up on their own, but barely, and are prone to fall over/get knocked over.On the plus side, the button push action is nice, and the buttons themselves are well done...highly polished, nice feel.  The construction of the entire thing feels fine as well - not perfect, but very good.Since we only use our house phone for international calls, and very occasionally for someone that still has our old landline number, I won't focus much on the call quality aspects, or the telephony aspects, as these seem pretty standard to me in terms of performance (and I think most of my call quality is dependent on my Ooma bandwidth/signal more than the phone hardware).  Answering machines seems to work fine, and the voice is clear and easy to understand.But the main reason for this unit is its video/doorbell capability, and in that, as noted by others, it fails miserably.  GREAT idea...I want so much for this product to work, but really poor execution and I cannot recommend in this stage.  Hopefully VTech will go back immediately and release a V2 of this and fix the two major problems that so many others here are complaining about (which I echo): 1. video quality, even in decent light, is extremely poor for this day and age, to the point that it is difficult to make out who is at the door, and 2. if there is any backlight when someone rings the bell (a common occurrence apparently, as it is at my front porch as well), you can forget being able to see who is there.I would also like to add that again, given the modern day audio compression capabilities, as well as modern digital storage capabilities, there should be a LOT more doorbell chimes than the ones available here.  Better still, charge $10 more and let the user make their own!  Just an idea, and I guess most people don't mind the chimes included, but they could have done a lot more in terms of the flexibility with the door chime tones here.In summary, pass on this model until they update the video tech inside (and please either weight the base or change the format of the hand units so they can stand up on their own!)

Literally the first time I used these shears on a small jasmine vine, one of the rivets that holds the blades together, popped out, never to be found again in the mess that is my mix of tall grass and mulch.  I tried to repair them, but noting I didn't have the right sized nuts and bolts, decided this was not one of those instances where I will just shrug off an inferior product, that I end up fixing myself (especially after the FIRST use!).So I sent a pic into Fiskars (online return/warranty system is very nice and easy FWIW), showing the problem.  I received no feedback for weeks (by this time, my jasmine vine was out of control of course), then one day received a box with a set of their lowest quality shears inside.  Not extendable, and they look like the cheapest shears I have ever seen.  I doubt they will last a season, with the obviously cheap plastic they used for the handles.Talk about a slap in the face.  My time is worth more than dealing with that kind of stuff, and I wish they would just lower their prices and forego the "lifetime warranty!" deal if that is how they roll.  I would never have purchased the shears they sent me, so basically I should have just bought another set (NOT Fiskars obviously) of shears when the originals broke.  Ah well, you live you learn.  Buyer beware on these, I see at least three other instances of this same problem happening in these reviews.UPDATE: To be fair, and as a credit to the company's customer service, I actually did contact them later to let them know that I wasn't happy about the switcheroo.  They promptly sent a replacement for the exact shears I originally bought.  Kudos for that!  Hopefully this pair will not fall apart when I start to use them.UPDATE to UPDATE :)  The replacement extendable shears also fell apart (in the exact same manner as the originals) after using them about 4x.  Wow.  That is some seriously shoddy manufacturing.  Either that, or I am The Hulk and didn't know it.  Perhaps I have superhuman strength which simply overpowers mere iron and steel.  I'm beginning to wonder if Fiskars, like Craftsman, sold out to Chinese manufacturing, resulting in blatantly obvious reduction in tool quality after the change.

Great lock, great brandMoved into a new house in January, with an assortment of different brand locks, different types, and styles from the previous owners, so I decided to do some research since I thought it best to just replace all (for looks, security and ease).  I decided on buying Schlage, from everything I had read, and I have not been disappointed at all.  Yes, the brand is pricey, but IMO, well worth the extra cost.This touchscreen deadbolt has proven to be no exception, and is a good step up from the Schlage BE365 that has the keypad with rubberized buttons (which I also own and have used for 6 months or so).  It's very much worth the extra money ($50 at the time of this review) since this is something you will use every day.Several reasons I prefer this model over the BE365 with the hard buttons:1. The BE365 lock manual notes that you should change the code on the lock every few months so you don't cause the buttons to wear down unevenly (thus giving visual clues as to what your code might be).  This upgraded model hopefully prevents that by using a completely flat touch screen surface that does not show fingerprints (it has a nice, matte, sturdy feel to it).2. This model auto locks after 30 seconds if you turn this feature on, something I turned on immediately since I have sometimes left the house, forgetting to lock the door using the BE365.  This feature alone would have been worth the extra cost to me.  Someone else mentioned that the lock unfortunately does this with the door both open and close, so you do have to be careful if you are talking to someone with the door open, so you don't bang up your frame.3.  Aesthetically more pleasing, IMO. Has a more modern look, and looks and feels much more substantial, if that has any bearing at all.  Dunno what the psychological impact of a wimpy looking lock vs. this industrial strength, Robocop looking one has on potential burglars, but I would imagine it might have some small effect.4.  Tamper technology:  this lock incorporates a built in alarm feature which I really like and have on another Schlage unit that is just a standard door handle, going to the garage.  Works very well, and I love the fact that you can adjust the sensitivity based on how paranoid you are!  :D  I have mine set to the "only sound the alarm when someone tries to kick the door in" level, otherwise, I find it too sensitive, and going off during times I didn't want it to.  If you don't already have an alarm system, the door chime is a nice bonus as well.5.  Increase digits for the code.  On the BE365, you are limited to a 4 digit code, but this lock allows you to input more (up to 8).  In theory, the 4 digit code should be enough to keep even the most foolish (or drug addled) burglar busy for hours, but adding even one more digit just makes me feel better, and decreases the odds exponentially, of someone guessing the code.6.  You don't have to use two hands.  On the BE365, after putting in the code on the keypad, you have to manually turn the deadbolt, and assuming you also have a door handle, have to push that as well.  Yeah yeah yeah, first world problems, but if you have your hands full, this extra little touch is a NICE thing to have!  One less thing to have to fumble with to get in your house is great IMO.7. ANSI 1 rated lock, compared to ANSI 2 of the BE365.  No idea what that actually means in the real world, outside of some certification, but supposedly you are getting a more secure lock, the lower the number.Can't comment on the Nexia/Z Wave features as I have no interest in remotely controlling my lock.So overall, a highly recommended upgrade.  I have installed and uninstalled MANY Schlage handle and locks since we moved in, from the simple handles, to handles with alarms built in, deadbolts, and finally this one.  They were all a pleasure to install due to the quality of the materials included (LONG bolts that go into your frame, instead of the short puny ones you get with lesser locks).  I personally found the installation on all of mine to go as smoothly as possible as it can when installing door hardware (which is often fraught with unforeseen hiccups due to warping, fit, hole precision, etc).

Love this unit, even though mine arrived with a gasket (around the inside of the enclosure that makes it waterproof) with a small hole in it.  Certainly enough to have let water in, and I am glad I happened to notice before I chunked this into my pool to test it out.  Added a bit of silicon in the hole, and no problem now.Love the look, love the feel, seems like a quality built product, and I even like the sound.  I would have preferred AirPlay in addition to or instead of Bluetooth, since it's less compressed, but for my intentions (poolside), it's fine, in terms of sound quality.The reason this only gets three stars ("It's ok"), is because as other reviewers mention, it has NO playback buttons - only an on/off button, and a volume control!  WTH.Since I use this by the pool, the idea was for me to have this speaker at the edge of the pool while we swim.  But now let's say I am listening to a playlist, and a song I hate comes up (or one of my guilty pleasure, filthy rap songs), I have to get out of the pool, dripping wet, get my phone, and click (again, wet).  Booo!  Completely defeats the purpose and flexibility for me at least, of its waterproof-ness and should really have been included in a unit at this price point.I have more than 3 different portable speakers like this, from different brands, and all of them contain the VERY basic functionality of being able to PLAY, FWD, STOP or REVERSE.  In fact, it's such a basic thing, I just assumed this unit had it when I ordered it.  I certainly would not have had I known.But if you can get past that pretty big limitation, or that limitation doesn't affect the way you would be using this, then I can still highly recommend.

I used one of these for some outdoor deck steps down, and it was perfect - until it stopped working (due to water in the unit) within a couple of months.There is absolutely NO weather proofing on these, so I can't understand how they can claim it's an outdoor light?  Not even a seal/gasket around the battery compartment, which would be necessary if you don't water to get in (which it did in mine, as well as the two detectors.  You can see visible droplets in both the motion and light sensors, not to mention the wet batteries).Also, the metal connections for the batteries are awful on mine...very poorly made, to where I had to really fight to get the batteries in, with all three connecting to the terminals.Skip this unless you are only using indoors IMO.  I guess you get what you pay for.

These are great chairs, if you never take them outside, or let them get wet.Both of the ones I ordered rusted within three weeks (see pic posted in customer images), so I sent one back for a refund, and kept one.The reason I kept one is because I really do love the chairs, from the color, which is unique, and a perfect match for pool water, to the comfort, which is amazing.  REALLY comfortable, and I personally had no problems with the locking mechanism (it IS very cheap plastic, though, so I doubt it will last more than a couple years if that).BUT, the rust...big problem.  Obviously they didn't coat the hardware (screws and such), as these rust first.  Next the metal to metal contact areas of the chair rusted (they just spray the powder coating on, so this is just a poor spray job, since it IS possible to get this right).  This is a major problem since this is all along the frame, and immediately visible.Based on recent reviews vs. first reviews, I also believe Strathwood either changed manufacturers mid production, or the manufacturer themselves changed the process, or machinery...because the more recent reviews complain about rust quite often, but older reviews do not (and some of those even state they have left outdoors no problems).

First: the good.As most have commented, this is truly a thing of beauty.  In terms of looks, simplehuman has probably just achieved the pinnacle of trash can beauty with this unit - it is SO aesthetically pleasing.  From the way the metal is bent, to the fit and finish at the seams, etc. , just top notch all around.  It just screams "quality!" (as it should, for the crazy price they are asking).  It's the Porsche 911 of trash cans.Having said that, I used this for a week or two, and found that in terms of practicality, it's inferior to my uglier, older stainless steel, foot pedal trash can (not simplehuman, another brand I can't remember), which I have now reverted back to using.I wanted so badly to like and keep this one, I really did.  The stainless steel used on this unit shows almost NO fingerprints compared to mine, which shows everything.  This unit also hides the bag completely, and with mine, you can see the bag stuck in between the top and the main body....ugly.So why in the world would I not use this new, svelte, knockout?Two reasons, but the biggest by far is that the open/close mechanism is IMO, inferior in daily use, to the foot pedal.  I get the impression from all the marketing and instructional material, that simplehuman wants people to just "brush up against" this to open, but this is quite awkward compared to simply stepping on a pedal.  Half the time I tried to open this way, it wouldn't, which is frustrating.  But worse, after just a week or so of use, the lid stopped closing consistently, or rather stopped STAYING closed.  I push it down, it pops back up.  Push down, pops up.  Ugh.  No thanks.  Like so many things of excessive beauty, they often have an Achilles heel of practicality, and it's the case here as well unfortunately.  But even hand opening is a pain when you have your hands full of dishes or what not.The second, more minor reason I stopped using this is the facing of the trash can, but this is highly personalized as to how your trash can "space" is set up, and if your space requires a narrower trash can.  Most of our trash cans for the kitchen have been in the same shape as this unit, but open on the narrow side, as opposed to the wide side, as this one does.  Opening on the short side allows you to put the trash can in more narrow spots if necessary, so in terms of fitting somewhere, the decision to have the can open on the wide side restricts the flexibility quite a bit (and especially since this a LARGE trash can).Ms. Trashcan Universe now lives in the garage, where every once in a while, I will peek in to sadly gaze on the tall, slender beauty, stoically accepting her fate of being relegated to "back up trash can" status.If simplehuman would make a trash can with this same care, design, and quality, but using a foot pedal instead, it would no doubt be 5 star material (but do get that insane price down a little!).
