The price was right for this (under five) so I gave it a shot.  Its definitely a Samsung product, so reviews that say otherwise either aren't looking at the packaging or they mistakenly received something else.Oddly, the packaging description is incomplete.  It states on the back "provides exceptional protection from without forfeiting style"  From what is a good question.  I'm guessing the people putting the statement together were indecisive about what they wanted to formally state the case would protect against and then forgot to go back and fill it in.The case itself is thin, hard on the back, rubbery/siliconey on the sides/rim.  It doesn't significantly change the size of the phone.  It offers rim protection on the screen face that'd let you lay it face down without scratching but I'm 99% sure that if you drop it face down it'd offer little to no protection.  Side drops might survive.  Back drops would be iffy as its just a thin plastic back about the same thickness as the battery cover under it.The case has a little static charge most of the time, so everything sticks to it and on the white case, everything shows.All I wanted was minimal case protection and a better grip without making the device even bigger than it already is.  I got that.  If you want a good degree of protection for drops/screen damage...not the case you want.

I bought this opener roughly 7 years ago.  I was looking for a pair of new remotes and an outdoor keypad for my existing opener, then realized that those 3 things cost close to the price of this opener which was on sale with free installation.Its much quieter than the 19 year old screw driver unit and opens/closes the door quickly.  That's the good part.  Now for the bad parts based on long term ownership.The battery dies after about four years.  That's $25 to replace.  Then all of a sudden none of the remotes, including the keypad, would open the door reliably or at any sort of distance.  I tried changing the batteries to no avail, then looked it up.  Seems a lot of people have these problems and blame it on the remote losing power.  Since I had 3 remotes all suddenly not want to open the door, I knew it wasn't the remote.Some fix it by extending the antenna wire out to the door or outside through a wall or vent.  But it appears that the internal circuit board has lost its sensitivity.  Chamberlain says it was due to voltage spikes and it needed a surge protector.  My other now 26 year old opener still works beautifully, and most of my neighbors still have both original 25-26 year old Genie's.  So either Genies are made to take a power spike or (much more likely) Chamberlain uses cheap capacitors to save a few cents.  Its $70 for a replacement board, although it fails often enough that there are a number of youtube video's that show how to replace it.The sensitivity of the wall plate that senses motion and turns the lights on also fades when the remote control sensitivity does.Nice quiet fast GDO, but you'll spend $100 on batteries and $240 on logic boards over a 20 year life span.

The echo very quickly melded with my family.  Its the quick and easy to-do and shopping list creator.  I used to keep lists out the wazoo and then forget to bring them with me when I shopped.  Now I have a sync'd to-do list and shopping list on my phone and all of my devices.  The microphones are very good!  I have a 2500 square foot 2 story house and I can talk to Alexa from anywhere on the first floor or yell down the stairs to her, she gets it right most of the time.  Its cool to be able to ask for simple things like "how many tablespoons is 6 teaspoons?" or "set a timer for 20 minutes?" or "What is 568 divided by 14?" when I'm washing something in the sink or have dirty hands.And music?  I'm often fiddling around in the house and being able to ask it to play a particular type of music while I work and get commercial free play is wonderful.  I listen to far more music.Downsides?  Its big and really requires some central placement.  No shoving it under a cabinet behind some boxes.  The audio quality seems more $99ish than $199ish.  The bluetooth audio isn't as crisp as streamed audio due to compression/codecs but that's true of all bluetooth speakers.  But its no big deal, I have a nice spot on my counter and I'm not an uber audio quality nerd, so I'm perfectly pleased with it.I do have trouble sometimes remembering that she's a robot.  I still say "please" and "thank you"!I leave the remote control upstairs so I can easily add things to my lists or get some music playing without having to yell down the stairs.  I can see how a couple of remotes distributed throughout a household would help extend the capabilities.  It'd be nice to be able to have 2 or 3 of them and have them sync'd to play the same music throughout the household or to use them as an intercom type system to talk to others.My son thoroughly enjoys using the remote with the "simon says" capability to say funny things to me when I'm downstairs.The best part is that Alexa keeps getting new features all the time, and it can grow into an even more powerful product as the software improves.I'll be very happy when I can call it Jarvis and it speaks with an English accent.  Then all I need is the AmazonBasics Iron Man suit.

While it might be mighty fine jelly, its not the flavors in the title but the flavors in the picture.  Half is grape, a quarter red raspberry and a quarter blackberry.  No cherry.There is about enough in each packet to barely put a bit on some toast.  You'll need 2-3 to make a PB&J.  Which resolves my concern about the volume.I could find no markings whatsoever to say what the expiration date is, but I'll keep looking.Lastly, it was loaded in the box with the "Other side face up" in large letters pointing up, and packed with lots of cases of heavy cans.  A bit smushed but it surprisingly made it intact.

Actually you can't, but understanding the enemy will help keep them out of your house and perhaps off your property.The small argentinian ant you're well familiar with if you live in California is different from most ant situations.  Most ants will fight with other similar type ant colonies, they live with one queen to a nest, and they'll often avoid repopulating a dead nest.Not these guys.  Most of them came from a single colony and so have the genetic marker that makes them think they're all from the same nest/colony.  Multiple queens will inhabit a nest.  And they have no problems with moving right back into a dead nest.  So the whole concept of 'killing the queen' or being rid of them is out the window.  In fact, once the queen is dead they'll go through a process of converting a hatchling to a new queen.They also maintain a scent trail that will last for many years, right into your kitchen, bathroom or other areas where they have previously found food/water and shelter from extreme weather.  They are very fond of driveways, crowns in the road and large concrete spans where they can be protected and avoid drowning in the rain.  When its hot out, your air conditioned house is a great place to be.This is a war of attrition, but I've 'won' that war on many properties.First thing you need to do is get rid of excess food and water sources outside.  I've seen them eat everything from fallen fruit to dog poop.Next when you see a line of ants, follow that trail to the furthest place away from your house you can locate and put one of these baits down.  Set it on the ground, pull out the stakes and press the top.  Don't try to do this while you're holding it unless you like getting it on your hands. Cover it with something to keep the sun off, unless its already in a shady place.  Stake it if necessary.  Monitor each one you put out to see if the ants are still feeding on it, its empty, or its dried out.  Keep replacing until you stop seeing the ants.I've tried every bait I could buy and frankly this is the only one they take to.  They've largely ignored everything else.  They certainly like proteins but aren't interested in protein baits.  I sometimes will put a little bit of pet food on top of the white crown, it does draw more ants in but they'll take the terro while they're there.This is basically sugar, water and boric acid.  The boric acid acts as a drying agent but it takes time to kill the ant.  So it can bring it back to the nest and feed it to the queen and the ant larvae.  Given enough of it, you will kill the nest, but as described above it'll be repopulated.I restrict using this to within about 15' of my house.  If you have lots of time, money and persistence you can drive them to the property boundaries.In the fall just before the real rain starts (hoping to see that again soon after 4 years of drought) get one of those water hose-screw-on insecticides that kills ants and spray all around your foundation for a few feet away from the house and a foot or so up the side of the house.  Spray the edges of all concrete including big cracks and seams.  In the spring once the rain is over but before the serious heat kicks in, do that spraying again.  I have a 2500 square foot house on 1/2 acre and this costs me about $50-75 a year for Terro and the spray.If they get into your house, resist the urge to vacuum them up.  Remove the food/water they were interested in and put a Terro bait at the nearest point of entry you can find.  I actually use these outdoor ones instead of the indoor ones.  Simpler and less messy, and they hold more.  Let them continue eating the bait until they're gone...which might take a week or more.  You'll see a pattern of lots of regular looking ants, then when those are all gone from the nest you'll see some burlier versions, about 1.5x the size and thicker.  These are the queens/nests guards who have come in search of food because the workers are gone.  You might even see the queen escorted to the food source, she'll be a lot bigger.  Then you'll see really small ones, these are the newly hatched and the last ditch effort to get food for the nest.Our objective here is to reduce the population and make the area immediately around your house unfriendly, and to prevent them from entering your house.  When it rains they'll migrate to a dry warm place with food.  When the real heat comes out and things dry up, they look for cooler surroundings with a water/food source.  After a few years of keeping them out, their scent trails that keep leading them into the house will no longer be effective and the job gets easier.After a few years I've found that they decide that my neighbors are less trouble than I am.

I tried a few call block products but found that they're incompatible with my uniden phone.  No caller ID is passed to the phone when its called no matter how I configure it.  Its just an Ooma Telo with a wire to the blocker and a wire from that to the phone.  Call Waiting ID passes, but not initial caller ID.I also found that the first two rings on a call are 'eaten' by the telo/sentry combo.  In other words, when someone calls your phone won't ring until the 3rd ring on the callers end.  This made for some issues with Ooma voicemail picking up the call before my home answering machine did.  And I've had a few instances where Google Voice voicemail picked up the call when people call my GV number that's forwarded to the Ooma.Deciding to live without callerID, knowing that only my whitelist calls (or persistent human callers) will get through, I kept the Sentry.I've been running it in "off" mode for about two weeks, Everyone I know has called and been added to the whitelist.  I blacklisted a handful of numbers that were autodialers.  In another week or so I'll turn the device "on" so it'll block all non whitelisted calls with the voice recording to press a number to get through. I had such a setup built into a VOIP phone system from AT&T about ten years ago and it was extremely effective.  Not only did I never get a telemarketer or political call, once that system had been in place for a year they simply stopped calling.  I must have landed on a lot of "never answers" lists.Simple, easy to use.  Mine came with no cords/cables which wasn't a problem for me as I have a hundred phone cords, but it seemed silly to save 50c and not include one.  The instructions sheet was also minimal, but a full manual is available online.I'll report back once I've had a month or so of "on" operation.  Now all I need is one of these for my cell phone. ;)

This does absolutely nothing. I put two 'stamps' next to each other right in the middle of the primary water path and I still have to use the toilet brush exactly as much as I used to without it.I gave it two stars because it makes the bathroom smell good.I had high hopes for this cutting back on the cleaning frequency, but I'm disappointed.

This app includes excessive permissions for a game, and it includes 'analytics'.  Analytics are programs that watch what you do, gather information from your phone and about you, and this is then sent to a server either operated by the app developer or someone who has paid to be the recipient.Sometimes these analytics and 'extra' bits that look at your information slow down your phone/tablet, sometimes they break.  Sometimes they don't get removed when you remove the app.Think carefully before installing an app.  Make sure its something you really are going to use.  Evaluate the permissions closely.  Look it up to see if it has any of the handful of analytic packages included.  Free apps or paid apps.  Any device.

My first impressions weren't good.  "Holy cow, this thing is too big and too heavy!".  I was going to return it.  Then I used it for two days.  Without hooking it to a charger and still had 48% power.  It made the phone easier to pick up and hold, although it feels like you have a brick in your pocket and the handy 'phone pocket' in my pants is too small for it to fit.This basically changed the way I used my phone.  I used to have it hooked to the charger when I wasn't actively using it.  Now I can leave it on the  table next to the couch in the living room (no ac outlets) and use it all day as a remote control for all my toys.  And if I forget to plug it in before bed, it doesn't really matter.  It took about 2 hours to not even notice the size and weight and actually see them as an advantage.Multiple batteries and car chargers work for a lot of people.  I hate prying the back off the phone to switch up and carrying little plugs when I travel.  An external battery works, but I like how easy this has made it to pick up the phone vs my skinny old phone, and I like how easy it makes to hold it

I used to use quicken years ago and it was wonderful for tracking finances, automatically downloading my brokerage and banking data, and doing practically pushbutton taxes at the end of the year with turbotax.I'd gotten away from it for some years due to the incessant forced upgrades and pushing for revenues.  I've just been using my couch potato portfolio and watching my bank account, and having an annoying tax day once a year.I recently started using Mint, a free finance product that was bought by Intuit, the maker of quicken.  I was surprised at how quickly it could marshall up my current finances and transactions, sort the latter into categories with 98% accuracy and tell me what I was spending money on and how.  Very simple interface.  There were just a few more things I wanted, like for it to download more than 18 months worth of data, perhaps find the cost basis for investments, and do more processing on my Lending Club account.  I can see data to either 1993 or 1998 at my brokerage and they have cost basis information available for viewing.So I tried Quicken 2015.  Which was a mistake and if I could give it back for a refund I would.  It actually does less than Mint in many areas.  Specifically it didn't label my accounts (ex: calling my Discover card 'credit card 123456789' instead of 'discover'), it failed to categorize a lot more expenses and transactions, it didn't download any more of the available data (which may be my brokerages limitation), and it didn't even download my Lending Club transactions while Mint did.I know Quicken is very powerful and the ideal tool for people who like to get down in the weeds on their financial transactions, but I just expected it to be much more than Mint in every way and its not.If someone has a way to screen scrape vanguard for all of my data and get it into a format quicken will import, I'd be appreciative.  All of my significant financial information is there and I can see it, but it has names of funds/stocks/bonds instead of symbols and what they report is erratic.

I've had one of these for more than 20 years.  In that time, one of the plastic teeth that engages the bowl has broken off.  That will happen if you dont hold the lid down tight while pulling the cord.  After washing the salad, place the bowl on a towel on the counter, hold the lid down (and the spinner) firmly and pull the cord gently with the other until the salad is dry.If you put the lid on and pull the string hard without holding the lid down, I can see how it would break.  And you don't have to pull very hard, which is probably how the string broke on some people.  You're just trying to get a little water off some lettuce, not start a lawn mower.Never had a broken string and as mentioned, just the one tooth broken off because the lid wasn't properly seated.  The whole thing has gone in the dishwasher 100+ times with no problems (top shelf).  Untether the line after washing and let it dry, then turn the inside of the lid to re-coil it.

I have an older tamarack whole house fan which just doesn't move enough air.  I use this fan to supplement it when the hotter weather comes in.  It moves considerably more air than the 1200cfm tamarack fan.  I was initially concerned about the huge dimensions as I have casement sliding windows.  No problem, I can turn it on its side and adjusted it to fill the sliding portion of the window.  While I was test fitting it, I saw that I could tuck the 'top' part behind the mounting for the wood blind and the bottom on the sill and it'd stay there just fine.  I can slide the window open and closed with it sitting there and remove it in the winter by just pulling it out.  I've never used the screws or mountings.The reversible aspect is great.  Once I've drawn most of the warm air out of the house I can reverse it and pull cool night air into the bedroom where its mounted  Normally I'd have to run air conditioning from late April to late October, but this lets me get away with cooling the house in the evening with the fan at 1/10th the cost of air conditioning.In fact, I just bought a second one to speed the process and distribute the air flow.  Under $150 for a load of bi-directional whole house air circulation with 5 minutes of free and easy installation works for me.Its not a small or thin or unobtrusive fan.  Its not quiet but I have no trouble sleeping in the same room with it on high.

These beef and elk protein sticks aren't as greasy as a slim jim, but I wish they had a little more fat in them.  The low fat content gives the stick a slightly mealy mouth feel.I found them to be mildly sweet and not really spicy at all.They could dial the spicy up quite a bit before I'd take that aspect seriously.Very good stick, but it'd be great with a little more fat and heat.

This is unlike the other 'stuffingless' toys I've bought, its a giant squeak toy.  Which the dogs love, however I'm not a big fan of squeaky toys.  There are two large squeakers, one in the front half and one in the back half.  The tail is empty and like most other stuffingless toys.Mine will rip it apart to get the squeakers, which is why I generally don't buy toys with those in it.I saw it as a 'you might like' item and just bought it without reading the fine details.Update: It didn't even make it 24 hours.

This tastes and has the same greasy mouth feel as your regular slim jim, with a little kick.  I don't think I'd describe it as 'freakin hot', but its got a lot more bite than the regular flavor.  It also seems to vary from stick to stick.  I've had a couple that were indeed pretty spicy, and some that seemed half as hot.  Still, they're good and we like them.  I wouldn't shy away for fear that they'll be too hot.  I'm actually looking to see if I can get a smaller amount of the habanero but it seems Amazon just wants to sell the giant box of full size sticks.

Compared to the average meat stick these are pretty large.  I'd actually like a bit more fat in it, but this is an example of the high protein/low fat approach to eating.  The texture is a little mealy due to the reduced fat.  Still, its a good eat and both my young son and I enjoy them.  Spice is mild.

This is a tough little toy and one of my shepherd and labs favorites.  It actually lasted over a year of them chewing on it (lightly) and pulling between them.  The little legs don't last long, but it held onto its stuffing after that.  The head came off in a major pulling contest and then it lost most of its stuffing.  The scrap is still a preferred toy to carry around and for pulling, but I bought another one and they're starting to work that into their toy routine.  For some reason, little scraps of old toys are still the most fun.  I have no doubt that a serious toy destroyer could chew this in half in short order, but they both seem to have decided not to shred this one.Despite being labeled as a toy for smaller dogs, these two are 80lbs each.

The little plastic cover swings down to protect the smaller microusb connection.  It works with windows, mac's and SOME android devices.On the android end, you need a newer version of android, the hardware capability to do "on the go" connections and the drivers on your phone or tablet.  There are some otg compatibility testers and some otg helpers in the Play store that can tell you (a little unreliably) if your android device will work with an otg flash device like this and help you mount it.  I'll say again that the helpers and compatibility testers aren't 100% reliable.If you have a brand spanking new flagship phone, it'll probably work.  Not any of the Fire devices I have will mount it, the phone, the fire 6 and the 7" hdx don't work.There is also a form factor issue with this product.  On the underside where you can't see right under the swivel for that plastic cover is a little keychain ring. If you have a thick protective cover on your tablet or phone, this prevents the drive from getting all the way in.  You can either nip it off with a tool or make a little groove in your cover.  Most of the devices I have excepting a PC had this problem.This was a bit of a disappointing purchase.  Its a well made product, the performance is good, the price is great.  But it doesn't work on half of my devices and won't fit in most of the rest without a field modification.  The OTG compatibility isn't the devices fault but the keyring thing is a real problem.  I'm betting someone wanted that feature thrown in at the end and it wasn't well tested.

This is a four port USB hub with a 5th port to connect to your PC, game console or anything else that takes a USB 2 or 3 connection.  That one port will then allow you to connect 4 devices at USB 3 speed if you've plugged it into a USB 3 host port, otherwise it should work on anything that supports USB 2.  You could use this on an Xbox 360/One, a PS3/4 or a computer.It is a non powered device, but it does have a plug for a 5v power adapter.  You won't need that for a keyboard or a mouse, but you will for hard drives or anything that pulls more than marginal power.  Some PC USB ports can provide a pretty good amount of power but the game consoles generally won't.I use this on a PC to connect a video camera, a wireless keyboard/mouse plug and to have an available port to plug in a flash drive.  I've also been able to plug an external USB3 hard drive into it, but my PC ports feature a 'supercharge' capability that lets them provide additional amps of power to a device like this and whatever I connect to it.  That feature is provided by my motherboard coupled with software provided by the motherboard manufacturer.So far its performed as well as any other good USB3 hub I've used, and its tiny and light as a feather.  Easy to velcro or sticky tape somewhere.
These were a bit smaller than some of the single packed kneecaps, but still very well appreciated by my dogs.  They were about 80% the size of similar offerings.

The M1 Gaming Mouse comes attractively packaged with an actual manual and a cd containing Windows XP/Vista/7/8 software.  The cd is a 'mini' disc, probably to allow packaging in a box smaller than would be required for a full size disk.  The manual is 10 pages in color and in readable English.  It adequately describes how to install the product, its software and how to operate it.The mouse is extremely glossy, in fact you'll see my reflection in the photo I took of it.  In the photo it looks like the mouse is silvery, but its solid black.  I've also added a photo of the main menu of the configuration software.  It fits my hand well, and I have medium size hands.  My ten year old son has also used it and says it feels fine for his size hands.  Its rounded in the back and all angles from the middle forward.  I have an expensive 7000 series Microsoft laser mouse which cost around 3x what the M1 goes for.  The buttons on the Microsoft mouse seem a bit firmer and sturdier, but only when I have one in each hand.  Separately, its a minor difference.  The M1 has more raised surface for gliding on the bottom than the MS one.  The M1 is perfectly symmetrical, so it could be used right or left handed, while the MS mouse is right handed only.Its a corded mouse, which is prized by gamers for being more accurate and with no wireless response lag or interference.  The cord is covered with a braided fabric cover, which looks a little better than a plastic one.  It has a number of LED lights, which can be configured for color and solid/slow pulse.The mouse is plug and play with Windows 7, but you can load the optional software for configuration purposes.  You may change what each button does, assign macro's to each button, and there are multiple profiles so you can set up buttons/macro's for a particular game or app.  You may also cycle through the various profiles by assigning that function to one of the buttons, so within the same game/app where you'd like different capabilities depending on the circumstances, you can employ a different profile with a click.There are also advanced settings that let you fiddle with polling rate, DPI, sensitivity and so forth.  Highly configurable.We'll try this out with the usual load of games we play, like Skyrim and Arkham Asylum, along with every day app use.  I'll update if I find any issues or with any compliments about particular observations.  Otherwise, looks like a well priced, highly configurable, well functioning product.

These are the markers you'll need to write on dark colored items that have at least a little porousness.  I needed to write on my son's black karate foam helmet and gloves, and put his name on his bike seat.  Since all were black and all I had were black sharpies, I got this set.  Good price for six markers in three colors.  They worked great for the purpose and will probably last me 5 years.

This remote allows you to turn the xbox one on and off, navigate the basic menu's, and control media playback.  I use my XB1 as a blu ray player, and its annoying to go to pause a movie and see that the controller has powered off.  I have a media remote for my 360 and PS3, so I figured I'd get one for the XB1 for non gaming purposes.It fits in the palm of your hand and all buttons are within a thumbs reach.  Its not beautifully crafted from the finest Corinthian leather, its just inexpensive plastic.  It is an infrared remote so it has to be pointed at the xbox.  Xbox one controllers use wireless and this is different from that, so range and where you point matters.  I've found it reaches about 12' with a new pair of AAA batteries, which were not included.Controlling the tv?  There aren't any facilities to train the remote, so I believe the tv control part works only if you have a Kinect, which the Xbox one uses to control channel and volume on a tv.  You'd press a button on the remote, the XB1 would see it and tell the Kinect to send an IR signal to the tv and that's probably how that works.  I don't have a kinect so I can't test it right now.I found the buttons worked pretty much all the time and didn't require any special effort to work.  I've also seen the 'real' microsoft remote and it doesn't seem any fancier or better working than this one, but the 'real' one costs a lot more.So if you want a cheap remote to basically hit pause and play and turn the XB1 on and off, this is well recommended.  I don't think I'd try to play Halo with it, but maybe that'd be a special challenge

I was directed at this product to help with a pulling dog problem.  Unfortunately after seeing it I recognized that I'd bought one years ago for one of my first dogs.  The problem with it is that if they turn facing you and crouch with the front feet sticking out, they can back right out of it and that's exactly what he did.

Lets talk about the halo effect.  The halo effect is caused when a pretty person says something that fits your confirmation bias.  A confirmation bias is when someone tells you in great detail and with strong effect something you already suspect is true.  Whether it is true or not doesn't matter.  The halo effect has an attractive person confirming your beliefs or your fears about things like ground up yoga mats in your food.A word about the 'blowing agents', which have been used to create air bubbles in foods, rubber seals and yes, yoga mats.  You aren't eating rubber, you aren't eating yoga mat.  You're eating food which contained (note past tense) a chemical that created a airiness and bubbles in a piece of bread and left behind nothing harmful whatsoever. Carbon dioxide bubbles are also used for industrial purposes.  Will you never drink soda or any other carbonated drink again because its also used as a tertiary scrub for oil fields to increase yields?  Of course not.  Yet, it wouldn't be ridiculous to apply the same logic set and have a pretty blogger with a computer background print a headline that says "Oil in your cola!"Blowing agents cause airway inflammation in factory workers manufacturing or using large amounts of the product who don't wear masks.  So does baby powder.  "Baby powder will kill you!"The blowing agents were made 'illegal' in some countries because when presented with a PR nightmare and alternatives not used for other nefarious purposes like baby food jar seals...Parliament decided to go the easy route and order a change.  But all products on the shelf or in warehouses (including baby food) could continue to be sold until it was exhausted.  Which took up to 2 years.  The 'babes' were advised not to push the issue further, because in an actual court using actual facts, the ingredient would be shown to be completely safe and they'd look stupid.  But in the public mind they could use factless negative PR to get people to pay them $18 a month for stuff they could get for free somewhere else.This is what happens when you leverage fear among people who don't know the science and won't become their own 'investigators', and the person doing the investigation is not only not a scientist, but also not an effective investigator.  Its what you get when you're an advocate not backed up with associated expertise.Its a shame because there really are a lot of things wrong with our food and our health advice.  She just doesn't choose to go after those.Bear in mind, this is someone who once noted that world governments are conspiring with drug companies to control the population with flu shots.  If that's the sort of thing you believe, then you're already completely doomed.  I don't think it even makes it as a 1960's 007 movie plot.  Not even Sean Connery could pull that one off.I believe that influential people who aren't scientists or researchers can bring together those scientists and researchers to help regular people understand the facts about health and nutrition, even when the mainstream may not be giving the best advice.  But when you leave out the people who actually know something, or rely on the deep fringe to give the influencer their own confirmation bias...no good will come of it.Bill Nye is not a scientist.  But he has a knack for explaining science to other people with the support of a wide range of actual scientists with real credentials.As far as confirmation bias, I'm sure that you can Google almost anything and get a handful of results in support of your thoughts.  Hitler was really Elvis.  Dogs can fly.  Google also tends to give you more of what you've been looking at and as much highly correlated and related page results based on your history.  So if you're someone that often looking up things that are a little 'out there', Google will work hard to give you more of what you want.  After all, if they just said "no results" when you asked if the mafia really controls all world governments, you'd change to Bing.

I've had one of these for about 16 years.  The handle broke off after a few years and I wrapped some duct tape around it.  On occasion the tines bend and I've just bent them back.  Its challenging to use in vine type grasses that grow along the ground, but once you get the hang of it, its no problem.Easily the best scooper I've ever bought and it'll probably last me for the rest of my life.  I've left it outside in a bucket the whole time and I other than negligible surface rust its as good as new.My methodology for using this is in conjunction with a small black plastic bathroom size rectangular garbage can with a plastic bag in it.  The one I have will take a plastic grocery store 'tee shirt' bag.  Scoop in one hand, plastic garbage can in the other.  Scoop, turn it upside down to dump inside the can and tap the scooper on the edge of the can to knock any klingons off the rake.  I even showed my 9 year old how to do it and he has no trouble with it.

I find Asics gel-33 shoes to be very comfortable.  I bought a pair a couple of years ago and find myself going to those over my other sneaks.  Soft comfortable sole insert and a very generous heel padding.  But my old ones were wearing out and nobody carried that model anymore.  They were gel-33 type shoes though, so I took a shot at the 'nerve' versionHonestly they fit and feel exactly the same, although they're a bit lighter.  I wasn't entirely thrilled with the pictures but I like the style fine in real life.  I've worn them two days in a row, the break in took about an hour.  Its nice to know I can stick with the various gel-33 models and still get the comfort I like.  I have occasional arch support issues with some shoes, and find that the shoes with a weak outside toe box let me supinate a little on the right foot.  I don't have either problem with these shoes.

This is a really nice leash.  Its 8' long, while many dual handles are 6.  This gives my dogs a little more room to roam which is nice considering I'm walking two large dogs.  The closer handle is about 18" from the clip.  The leash material is heavy braided nylon strapping and is at least 4x as heavy duty as the strap in my 140lb-rated retractable leash.  I have absolutely no worries about the quality or expected life span of this leash.Each handle has an extra perforated leather or leather like layer on the inside.  Its soft and comfortable.  This is a very well made leash.Should I have any problems with it, I'll update the review.

This is your basic one piece non hard plastic case.  The phone goes in easily enough and would come out without too much trouble but not on its own.  Good fit, plenty of room for button and charger access, no blocking at all.  Semi flexible but not a silicone soft.  Protects the screen when placed face down as there is a little lip that would keep the screen off the table.  Good protection for the back and all four sides.  Wouldn't save the phone from a high drop onto concrete, but nothing would without adding a lot more bulk.I bought a holster case for the Fire Phone and this case fits the holster.  I like the protection on this one so I'll keep them both and use this case inside the holster from the other one.Edit: after using this case for about a month I'm very happy with it.  It still fits perfectly and has offered excellent protection and a better grip than the bare phone.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NFZZ2E6/

I have mixed feelings about this one.  The case portion is hard plastic and doesn't offer a lot of top and bottom protection.  It slides easily in and out of the holster part and the cutouts are spot on.  The holster part is really nice.  The good part is that the fosmon case I also bought offers better protection and it also fits in the holster.  In fact, just about any form fit case should fit the holster.The little pop out stand really isn't that hard to get out, but it needed a little extra pressure to go back in.  One side seated and the other side stuck.  Perfectly stable and I'd expect it to break off within a year or two because it doesn't seem that sturdy.I got this for an excellent price.  The iphone version was selling for 2.5x as much and has thousands of solid reviews.  I like it and will keep it in combination with the fosmon case.  Keeps the phone handy and from being sat on if I forget its in my pocket.  But the included case portion wouldn't offer any protection for a top or bottom drop.Edit: After using it for a few days, I think my use for this is going to be limited.  Its pretty large and pretty heavy.  Hung on a pocket it a sticks out and its pretty heavy and bulky.  On my belt it sticks up under my shirt and is a bit challenging to get out because the phone is pretty long.  I've used it on dog walks where I have a leash in each hand and I want the phone to take a picture of something, but in everyday use the vertical holster is just a bit unwieldy.  Nicely made product and a lot for the price if its really the sort of case/holster you want.Edit #2: Thanks to a commenter, I see that the holster clasp pivots so the holster can be horizontal or almost any position in between.  See the comments for details.Nice little holster for five ninety nine.  Works great with the fosmon case that offers more protection and I got the pair for under ten bucks.

Normally your various mass market food purveyors overplay their "crazy spicy flaming chicken sandwich" or "insanely hot salsa" so when I saw this say it was crazy hot, I rolled my eyes.As I explained to my 10 year old when I was opening it "If they make it too hot then many people won't be able to eat it and they might not buy it again".  I've said stupid and largely incorrect things many times in my life, and this was no exception.I have to say it has a nice flavor.  For 5 seconds.  Then the heat kicks in.  I know that many people have varying response to capsaicin.  But I normally eat a lot of pretty spicy food and I can tolerate it very well.  This stuff is hot.  Really, really hot.The good news is that after the first one, the next 8-10 chiploads aren't as bad, probably due to the class 12 chemical burns on your tongue.  I liberally applied full fat yogurt and a bit of milk and that took it down a bit, but its taken a good 15 minutes for things to really settle down.I'd better go put a roll of toilet paper in the freezer.  I think I'll need it tomorrow...

Its an attractive charger.  It lights up red while charging and green when its done, the clear parts you see have the colored LED's at their base and those are what lights up.  You won't need a night light in the room these are in.We've used the controllers all day long without running out of juice.  While I haven't timed it, they seem to recharge in just an hour or so.The two pieces slide/snap together, and thats the only assembly.  Time will tell how long the batteries last and I'll update the review if its less than 3-4 years.  I've gotten that much time from the other nyko units I've used before for the xbox 360.

I put this inside my directv hr24-100 dvr as a replacement for its 5 year old drive.  Not the easiest thing I've done as it requires popping numerous delicate plastic prongs to remove the top and the carrier the disk is in is also extremely fragile plastic and has screws on the bottom side that are hard to access.  However I managed it in about 30 minutes and only cracked one non essential plastic piece.Directv doesn't want you meddling inside the boxes, but they haven't wanted this model receiver returned for quite some time as its getting a little older.  The only major risk is that you break it and have to pay for a new one.The 2TB's of storage is way better than the 500GB drive it came with.  Its the maximum an HR24 series dvr can address.  The genie models can go higher, however.The drive is quiet, cool running, and other than giving me a lot more storage space is indistinguishable from the original.You could put the drive into an external case and connect it via e-sata but I've had no end of problems with that when used with a handful of recommended cases.  The drive disconnects, sometimes there are performance related issues, and every other time the dvr was rebooted or I had a power failure it'd come up on the internal drive and I'd have to reboot it again.  Once we had a power outage in the middle of the night and I didn't know it'd happened and missed a whole days worth of shows.  These problems disappeared when I popped the same drive inside the dvr.

These arrived fast with a nice note encouraging me to call them if there were any problems.The cases are a firmer plastic than the usual squishy silicone ones, but not hard plastic.  They have a little 'give' and provide rear/side/front edge protection.  They don't cover the screen but it does wrap around from the bottom and sides to make a 'lip' around the screen edge.  So you can put the phone face down and the screen won't touch the surface the phone is on.The fit was perfect.  Its very nice to have a collection of cases in different colors for such a low cost.  I had a similar softer silicone case, but it didn't fit as well as this and that one case cost me about the same amount last year.I also applied one of the included screen protectors.  It went on pretty easily with a few small bubbles that I worked out to the edges.  The fit was precise and it looks good as well.Protection-wise, I'd think if you dropped the phone from 4-5' up onto concrete you might have a broken phone.  But other than that this should protect against minor drops, scratches and scrapes just fine.

I bought this to replace an aging dual core nook tablet that I'd hacked and put regular android on.  The NT has been a good tiny tablet for me for a while, but it was time for a faster, newer replacement with an improved screen.  The 7" HDX fits the bill.  Its very fast, has a beautiful screen, and has been a pleasure to use.The regular price for a new one is a bit stiff, but they're available from time to time refurb or 'used like new' for a very good price.

I'd have rated this tablet higher back when it came out, but at point its a little slow and the new 'sangria' OS hasn't made it to this older tablet, if it ever will.  That's a little disappointing because it hasn't been discontinued for long.  For a company trying to push their own private ecosystem, you really have to do a bit more while you're still in the 'catching on' phase.The screen is beautiful, the network performance is very good, but the performance drags a little compared to my fire phone and its good for a hard freezeup about once or twice a week, requiring a reboot.I didn't pay much for this, about a quarter of what the new HDX costs, but I still have a little occasional buyers remorse.  In the 8.9 HDX price range, there are a lot of competitive tablets without the specter of losing updates.  My old ipad 2 still gets apple OS updates and my older nexus phone still gets them from google.

I've had a few of these for a couple of years, along with the 'bento bowl' and the large blue treat 'ball'.  The problem with the fire plug is that if you have a long nosed dog like a german shepherd, they'll figure out after a bit that they can chew sideways just under the rim and pop the treat out in 10 seconds.The blue 'ball' version is thicker between the treats while this slims between them, so that trick doesn't work with the ball.  Get that one if you have a dog with a long powerful jaw.  If your dog has a shorter nose, these will work.The bento bowl works well also, but it gives more access to the treat because the rubber portion is fairly small.  I haven't had the treat popped out of that one but it only lasts an hour or so while the treat in the blue 'ball' lasts for about 4-6 hours.I've had five large dogs chewing on these for years...a malamute, a rottweiller/mastiff mix, a pointer mix, a lab/pit bull and a german shepherd.  Plenty of tooth holes in the surface but no pieces torn off.I can get the treats into these just using my hands, but its hard.  To make it easier, get it in as far as you can and then use the tip of a butter knife to leverage it in the rest of the way.

I was diagnosed by my doctor with a gluten intolerance about two years ago. I was experiencing a lot of digestive issues whenever I ate it. These cleared up once I eliminated gluten from my diet.But to be honest, I really missed the food (bread especially...GF bread is just not the same). I was really curious to see whether these digestive enzymes would make it possible for me to OCCASIONALLY indulge in the real thing.I personally had a good result using these. While I wasn't 100% symptom-free, I saw a major reduction in my normal symptoms (bloating, gas, constipation, and inflammation).Just to make sure it wasn't a fluke, the next day, I ate the same item without the pill and I had my usual reaction to it.There is a little bit of trial and error when taking these. The instructions say that you can take 1-3 pills before you start eating gluten. Each pill covers you for 20g of gluten and lasts about 90 minutes. My problem is, I'm not sure how many grams of gluten are in some of the things I would want to eat (that type of information is not usually listed on the nutrition label). With trial and error, you can figure out the right dosage for your body and meal.I don't think you would want to pop these pills all the time, but they are helpful when a gluten-free option is not available (dinner out with friends, a holiday meal with family). They have enabled me to enjoy some of these foods I've missed without the digestive consequences.These are intended for those with a gluten intolerance, but not for those with Celiacs disease. If you have Celiacs, unfortunately, you have no option but to avoid gluten all together.Will I be using these everyday so that I can go back to my old way of eating....probably not, but I will definitely keep these on hand for special occasions  (hello, Thanksgiving dressing) or when I'm in a dining pinch. For me, they reduced my digestive symptoms by about 90%.

I've used a number of baby carriers over the last six years (wraps, a few varieties of soft-structured carriers), but this is my first time using this style of carrier. I have actually really liked it. It was fairly easy to put on and take off by myself without any assistance. My child weighs just over 20 lbs at the moment. It felt about the same as wearing a heavy backpack. The shoulder straps are fairly well padded, but after wearing it for an extended amount of time, my shoulders were a little bit achey and I didn't feel like it offered a ton of support at my lower back.There is a buckle that goes across the hips to help displace the weight, but what this is seriously lacking is a chest strap. I'm not sure why it doesn't have one. It would certainly help displace the load and help to keep the carrier a bit more secure. The confusing thing is that the image on the inside of the attached Kelty brochure shows a woman wearing a carrier with chest strap (but this model doesn't include one).What I love:*I love the kickstand that makes it very easy to load and unload my child. (We've also used it as a make-shift chair at my son's flag football game).*The 5-point harness is fantastic. I feel confident that my child isn't going to fall (or crawl) out of the carrier while he's on my back.*The colors are nice and the fabric feels durable. The handles on the chair help make it easy to put on without assistance.What I don't like:*The lack of a chest strap/buckle*It can sometimes be challenging to fit the child's legs throught the leg holes due to the way the material/belt curves around the waist.*It does not fold compactly for storage.*It's ideal for short trips or errands, but it's not especially comfortable for longer treks.I've been pleased with this over all. My son absolutely loves riding in it. I'm sure it will fit different body types and heights differently (I'm 5'3). While it's not the world's most comfortable carrier, it's definitely not the most uncomfortable, and it's much cooler and more comfortable than wearing the soft-structured carriers on my back (plus I've never acquired the ability to put a child in a back soft-structured carrier by myself).It has some neat features that I would defintely recommend to other parents and caregivers.

My hair tends to be on the dry/frizzy side. I have a bit of natural curl and wave to my hair. I felt like this conditioner did a good job of moisturizing my hair without it feeling weighed down or limp.The fragrance is similar to other Dove shampoos I've used in the past. The scent is not floral or too heavy. It's great for guys and girls alike.I felt like it left my hair feeling softer and looking healthy.

I have really liked this shine cream. It does a much better job of adding shine and cutting back on frizz.I've used oil based shine serums in the past, but they tend to leave my hair looking greasy. I didn't ever have those issues with this shine cream.I love the scent and I feel like it helps add a bit of shine and frizz control.

I used this conditioner in conjunction with the shampoo of the same variety and I was very pleased with the results. It did leave my hair softer and added a bit of body as well (I dried it with a blow dryer and a round brush).The fragrance is not overly floral which makes it great for everyone in the family. The scent reminds me of the salon shampoos.I was pleased with the results, especially at this price point.

I used this shampoo in conjunction with the conditioner and I was very pleased with the results. It did leave my hair softer and added a bit of body as well (I dried it with a blow dryer and a round brush).The fragrance is not overly floral which makes it great for everyone in the family. The scent reminds me of the salon shampoos.I was pleased with the results, especially at this price point.

It took me about five minutes to play through all three games on this device. It does seem to help learn some basic site words. The graphics are basic, but entertaining. However, for kids used to playing on tablets or LeapPads, the graphics may be a little too basic. My four-year-old thought that it was neat, but I'm not sure that it's going to hold his attention for the long term.As a mom, I also wish there was some way to plug in headphones.

This is such a fun color. It is a very pale green, but it looks bright and cheerful. It lasts about as long as other nail polishes I've tried (after a few days it started chipping a bit). It applied very well and offered a good amount of coverage. It's a great color for summer.

I have naturally wavy/curly hair and I enjoy wearing my hair curly when possible (sure beats drying and straightening it.) I was hoping this Shaping Gel Cream would help give my curls a little additional definition, but it actually ended leaving my hair looking rather wet and crunchy. This does have a fairly strong hold, so if you're lookking for a super-strong curl shaping cream then this might be a good fit.The fragrance is nice, but the product itself is super sticky (I have to use soap and water to clean it off my hands after applying it to my hair. It does help define curls, but less is definitely more.

My hair is not perfectly frizz-free after using this product, but it is an improvement. The product has the look of a creamy lotion. It's very easy to apply and has a great fragrance (it reminds me of the smell of products from the salon). I have naturaly curly/wavy hair and so my hair tends to stay on the frizzy side. I definitely prefer this over the oil-based anti-frizz products. This does not leave my hair looking greasy at all, which is a big plus in my book.

0:39 Mins As a family, we've been trying to cut down on some of the waste we create in our home. One way we're trying to do that is to eliminate the need for things like plastic wrap or foil. These Silicone Suction Lids have been a great and easy way for us to cut down our usage.I've found that the largest size works well for my serving bowls (things like vegetables, mashed potatoes, or rice). The medium bowl is a good size for soup/cereal bowls, and the smallest size is good for 2 cup prep bowls, mason jars, coffee mugs, or tea cups.We've started using these instead of plastic-wrap in the microwave. they're very easy to place on top of the bowl or dish and then heat up as usual. They can also be used in the oven up to 450 degrees, but we don't actually use much round bakeware, so these probably see the microwave a lot more often than the oven.We also use them for sealing and storing leftovers in the fridge. My one main criticism is that that seal is easily broken. If you have a dish in the refrigerator and the lid gets bumped by another item or as your shifting things around it's very easy for the lid to break the seal in shift. Also, you can't really stack things when using the lids because of the ridge from the handle. At the same time, the suction is strong enough for me to be able to lift the bowl up by the lid without it falling loose.These are easy to keep clean and to store. We actually keep these on top of our plastic wrap and foil boxes. I find that 8/10 we are able to use these lids instead of the foil or wrap. (I just need to acquire a rectangular lid for my 9x13 pans). They can go in the dishwasher, but I've found that it's often just as easy to give them a quick swipe with some dish soap.

These dark wash boys denim shorts are a great length. I have to admit my favorite feature of these pants is the adjustable waist band. My son tends to have a rather thin waist and rear and pants typically seem to fall off of his frame. These feature an elastic band on the interior waistband that allow you to cinch the waist in and keep the shorts from falling down. This helps the pants continue to grow with my son which is fantastic from a mom's point of view.The denim seems to be high quality and the wash is nice and dark. I like that I can dress these up with a Polo shirt or a button-up or they can be very casual with a t-shirt.

I have naturally wavy hair. I've started using this to give a little bit more definition to my curls. I apply it to damp hair and scrunch my curls and then dry with a diffuser. I really like that this mousse helps give definition to my hair without making it feel crunchy. I also noticed a reduction in the amount of frizz I experience.The fragrance is nice and the dispenser was very easy to use. Not sticky, good results.

We live in a very arid part of the country. The winters, in particular, are very dry. This is honestly, one of the best humidifiers I have tried. It has a very large tank and can run for days before it needs to be refilled.I did find that on the highest setting that it lasted for about 12 hours, There was so much moisture in the air that my carpet almost felt damp after running for that long. Most of the time though, I run it on the lowest setting. With a completely full tank, it does get pretty close to the 100 hours they advertise.I find the cool mist to be refreshing. Whenever my kids start coming down with a cough or a cold, I make sure that this is running in their room. I do think it has helped.I like the built in silver that helps keep things clean. This humidifier seems much easier to maintain than other models I've tried in the past. You basically just need to rinse and wipe out the tank and use a special included brush to clean the disc. This is so much easier than messing with filters.In case you are wondering, you cannot use any types of fragrances or oils with this humidifier. They will damage the unit. The mist can be directed to a certain direction by turning the disc on the top.The nightlight feature is handy for use in a kids room. You have the option of a light on the dial, or a light on the tank, or no light at all. I've found that the light on the tank almost is too bright for my kids at night, but it's very easy to toggle the light on or off. I also like that the light on the dial turns red whenever the water level is low.All-in-all this has been a great addition to our home. I'm tempted to get a second one for my other child's room so that I'd have one available for his use as well.

For the past few years I've been buying Charmin Ultra-strong, primarily because I wanted a toilet paper that wasn't going to fall apart when I used it.I have to admit, I think the Ultra-soft has won me over. It's super soft and still held up well. It feels a bit thicker than some other toilet papers I have tried in the past and it's definitely soft enough to use for blowing your nose as well (we often use toilet paper if we don't have a box of tissues in the house).The 24 pack is great because I know it will last my family for a while. I love being able to restock the bathrooms without having to make a trip to the store all of the time.

To be honest, I'd didn't find this to be a particularly thrilling read. The premise is interesting enough- a family with the ability to travel back I'm time to visit different eras in history.Unfortunately, the delivery failed a bit. To me, it read more like a "let's figure out how to teach the history of the park" rather than something my kids want to read. Don't get me wrong, I wholeheartedly believe that things that are educational can also be entertaining, but I felt like this one missed the mark.The characters didn't have very much depth to them, they were essentially there to set the scene for the next lesson.If you're doing a study on the National Parks, then this could be a handy way to introduce new information, but if you're looking for a entertaining read for your child, you may want to keep looking (unless, of course, your child really digs the Great Smokey Mountain National Park).

I personally had a difficult time drinking this. It had a very strong chemically taste to it (that I think probably comes from the artificial sweetners). I didn't realize when I selected it that it contains sucralose (but that's my fault) .The health benefits seem nice. I was hoping for something that would give me a little bit of boost pre-workout, but I just honestly had a difficult time getting the stuff down.If you are a fan of things sweetened with Splenda then you'll probably like this just fine, but I was a bit disappointed with the flavor.

I did the thing you're probably never supposed to do: I tried a new sunless tanner the night before I was in my sister's wedding.Although I wasn't 100% satisfied, I felt like it did a fairly good job. The color was reasonably natural. I applied it with the mitt. Although I didn't  necessarily have streaking, I did have some places that I did not adequately cover. It is kind of difficult to see where it has been applied. I thought I was thorough, but I still managed to miss a spot or two.My other recommendation is that you wait a while before applying clothes. I had a spot on my back where apparently the tanner rubbed off when I was pulling my shirt on. So wait until everything is COMPLETELY dry before crawling into bed or getting dressed.I did like that this did not have that nasty sunless tanner scent. It was not bad. You could totally go out after applying it.I still need to practice a bit more before I will be 100% satisfied, but all in all, it's not a bad sunless tanner.

I've been using this to charge my iPad 2 mini. The cord is very short which can be both an asset and a liability. I recently tried the white chalk color. It took at least three coats to get full coverage. Next time I'm going to try a good quality top coat on top of the color to see if that will help it last a bit better, but on its own, I wasn't able to get anywhere near the 1-2 weeks that the description states.The color would be nice for French tips, etc, but you would need to make sure to do multiple coats to get full coverage.

It is very nice and very sturdy. I have an extra large dog (a mastiff) and I will say this collar BARELY fit his huge fat neck! I cannot make it any longer, but luckily it does fit him for now. He responded well to it, and I was a bit worried as I have never used something like this before. He does not even need it too much though because he is a good listener as is. I love having this when I take my morning jogs and hikes with him. Great product!

Great product in a tiny little box :)I received this product for little or no cost in exchange for an honest review.Very happy with the quality and was surprised at how fast the charge is for an "off brand" product (one I had never heard of). Would recommend for the cost and will be purchasing again!

My husband has been having trouble sleeping so when we were offered to review this product for an honest opinion at little to no cost I jumped on the opportunity! We are so happy with the results! This product taste great and has helped my husband have great sleep and to relax more. His mind oftens wanders off in too many directions at night, so no matter how tired he is he simply cannot rest or fall asleep.Love the product and the name!

These are so nice! They are also a lot larger than they appear in the photo! I am very happy with the product, the size and the awesome quality! The color is so beautiful and goes with virtually any designed kitchen. I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for an honest review and I absolutely love them!

These were received for free or little charge in exchange for an honest review - these socks fit as described.They are very nice quality, not too thick and not thin. They are incredibly comfortable, I am very happy with them!

High Quality gloves - company is easy to work with and communicate with.I am very happy with the purchase. I love the colors that they offer for females and the sizes are accurate.These are going to help a lot with weight lifting which I recently got into.. it has been rough on my hands!

I am absolutely in love with this Beer Growler, we have used it for so many outing (and no not just for beer). It has been a pleasure to have reviewed this product (this product was given to me for free in exchange for an honest review). It is of the highest quality and is so nice. The color is also a wonderful brown and the top screws off and turns into a cup (very smart). We are extremely happy with the product!

Many different uses for this awesome little combo pen! I highly recommend a stylus for anyone that owns an electronic device.I was able to purchase this item for little or no cost in exchange for my review.I think this is a steal on pricing for all the little perks you receive. I give it 5 stars, because that is my honest opinion of the product. It is great!

So very excited about this product and the discovery of it.Although I cannot speak for long term use yet, I can tell you that I immediately put this thing to use in our home and it worked.I had received this product for free or little cost in exchange for a review and I am happy to write that I give this 5 stars plus!

I received this product for free or little cost in exchange for an honest review.The packaging is nice for this product, so that is always the first thing I look at.Second, this was the only clear Vitamin C I have ever seen in a serum!The smell is almost odorless. It goes on and takes a minute to absorb but leaves your skin feeling very soft.I also use it on my hands and feet.Vitamin C is great for many, many reasons and there isn't a day I do not use it.Great product!

These are awesome. I use these every night and sleep so much better.I was able to receive these for free in exchange for an unbiased review.I am very happy w the quality, packaging, and the feel. They are not tight, they fit comfortably.

It is magic in a tiny container: I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.After using this product consistently you notice a difference in wrinkles. Highly recommend and I am very happy.I have developed fine lines next to my eyes and this product has seemed to help.
My husband is just in love with this. He keeps it in his wallet at all times :)I received this for free in exchange for an honest review - very happy I was chosen!

Sunsella has outdone themselves again.I received this product in exchange for an honest review.Sunsella also makes a scraper and I LOVED that product so I am soooo happy I got to try this one!It comes packaged in a nice little box (great for gifting) and it stores wonderfully! Very happy.

Talk about energy! This is a natural way to get it!Healthy and taste great! I received this for free in exchange for an honest review.i had never tried this product before, and now that I have I know I will be purchasing more in the future.If you need an energy boost this is the stuff for you.

I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.I had never owned one of these, but I can tell you now that I do I will always own one (this one specifically).It is easy to hold.It is the perfect size.It is packaged great if you were thinking about getting this as a gift.

I was fortunate and able to review this wonderful product for free in exchange for a review.It has done wonders for our huge mastiff. I recommended this to everyone I know... so happy that I found this!

I was able to receive this product for free in order to leave an honest review.WOW what a huge bottle! You are really getting what you pay for and I will definitely be purchasing from this supplier in the future! Fish oil has many wonderful benefits and I cannot say what a good thing these pills have done for my body. My hair, my face, my nails, everything is so much healthier. A++

I was able to try this product out for free in exchange for an honest review.This is much easier to take for me than a pill every day - I always forget with pills.I add this to my smoothie and it works wonders. There are many, many benefits to taking Tumeric and being that this is Organic is another great quality of an already high quality product.I have heard they have cinnamon but have not had the pleasure of trying that just yet ;) Perhaps I will be purchasing!

Great product - I was lucky and got to review this product for free! Very happy with the results so far. I would suggest anyone trying to get their lashes to grow to give this a try for the cost. I am a fan!

Works great and I love that our dog is able to walk through this with ease.We were skeptical but had the opportunity to try this product out for free in exchange for an honest review. I am glad we gave it a shot because it was worth it!Having children that run in and out all of time and trying to open our screen was irritating but this makes it easy and still keeps the bugs out! I am happy with the product

Taste great and gives you the extra energy you really need when working out hard.I had a great opportunity to review this product for free for an honest review.I am now a Natura Formulas customer after trying this product and my very picky husband agrees!

Hugh Grant plays a screenwriter who won an Oscar fifteen years ago, but now is unemployed and broke. His agent arranges for him to take a job teaching screenwriting in a university in upstate New York. It's the last thing he wants to do, but he has no choice. There, he gets off to a bad start, sleeping with one of his students and insulting a tenured formidable member of his department, played by the amazing Allison Janney, by telling her he hates Jane Austen, her area of expertise (a fact made all the more funny due to Grant's prior role in the Austen classic "Sense and Sensibility"). He then meets a single mom played by Marissa Tomei who both challenges him and brings out the best in him. While it definitely has some morally questionable moments, this is a laugh-out-loud funny movie, filled with great supporting characters, and is ultimately a story of redemption. Those who have ever dreamed of becoming a screenwriter will find it especially enjoyable.It is unrated, but would probably be PG-13 for one swear and sexual suggestions.

Lisa Duffy, an author and speaker for the CatholicMatch institute, overcame a painful divorce and annulment, remarried in the Church, and has spent the past twenty years ministering to those who have been wounded by divorce.In "The Catholic Guide to Dating after Divorce," Duffy provides authentic Church teaching on divorce, annulment (including the benefits of going through the process), remarriage and receiving the Eucharist. Sharing her first-hand experience, she understands the pain of going through a divorce. "Rebuilding after divorce is hard work and it requires patience and persistence . . . It is easy to lose sight of the fact that we are lovable, valuable, and God still has great plans for us."Soon after her divorce, co-workers and other well-meaning individuals wanted to fix her up on dates, but Duffy cautions that one must "take the time to properly heal from your own divorce before entering into a serious dating relationship."How does one do that? Duffy offers five attraction factors that help an individual become a better version of themselves. These "five factors will help you become the best, most attractive version of yourself, and pave the way for you to experience greater satisfaction in your relationship, and to improve your ability to give and receive love." These five factors include being available, being affectionate, being a communicator, being faithful, and being magnanimous.Duffy has extremely high standards for individuals to meet before being ready to date after a divorce (or to date in the first place). If everyone met them, no doubt the world would have many more happy marriages. However, we live in a world of imperfection. Perhaps it would be more practical to aim for the high standard, but be willing to accept an 80% success rate in both oneself and potential partners.Duffy offers concrete advice and areas for individuals to work on to heal from divorce and prepare for dating. "The Catholic Guide to Dating After Divorce" is a book many divorced Catholics can benefit from. It also might make for good reading for parish priests and pastoral ministers to help in their role as counselors to the faithful.

Colette Lafia, spiritual director, writer, retreat facilitator and part-time school librarian, knows something about having dreams not come true. She and her husband are infertile and all their prayers and efforts to conceive a child came to naught. In addition, her sister died of breast cancer, her husband's business failed, and she suffered from chronic insomnia.Such was Lafia's life in October 2002 when she traveled to the Abbey of Gethsemani in Kentucky searching for some peace. There she would meet Brother Rene, "an elderly monk with a warm and down-to-earth disposition . . .[who] would become [her] spiritual companion, teacher, and a source of inspiration for seven years." The two bonded quickly and begin an epistolary relationship in which Brother Rene would help Lafia to learn the value of surrender."Surrender is the spiritual aspect of acceptance, inviting and allowing us to hold our experiences and lives with grace in every moment." When we have embraced surrender, "we stop wanting our lives to be something other than what they are and begin to recognize what is right in front of us, the life that is truly our own."It was an important lesson that Lafia would need even more as she cared for her father who was dying of Parkinson's disease. He, too, had to accept the gift of surrender as he needed to release control and let others care for him.Lafia writes in beautiful and honest prose, sharing her weakness and struggle as she comes to terms with the life that she lives and the new opportunities that God provides. An attitude of surrender can be beneficial at any age, but is perhaps most suited to those who have experienced some great loss in life, be it of family members or a long hoped for dream.After life has dealt some fierce, painful blows, one must dig deep for the ability to go on. A spirit of surrender can only serve to help that process, and "Seeking Surrender" offers a gentle roadmap to letting go.

It is evident from the very first pages of "Arriving at Amen" that Leah Libresco is a highly intelligent woman. A former atheist, she came to believe in God through a logical process, a proof by contradiction.She describes seven types of prayer: petition, confession, the examen, the rosary, the divine office, lectio divina, and the Mass, and shares how she came to understand and utilize these forms of prayer in her own life.Unlike many of us who have embraced the Catholic faith since birth, Libresco has a constant spirit of questioning. She comes to these prayers from a radically different perspective. As an example, she attempts to explain transubstantiation via algebraic formulas. While such an explanation was beyond the intellectual capabilities of this reader, one has to give Libresco credit for originality and a fresh look at traditional prayers and rituals.Libresco holds St. Peter in high esteem, describing him as having "a loud faith" - always bold, always questioning, always trusting in God, and always moving forward. It is this faith that she wishes to emulate and she invites her readers to go along for the journey.

"Between Heaven and Texas" is a prequel to the Cobbled Court Quilt Series. Fans of the books will recognize Mary Dell as a big-time quilt instructor from Texas who is friends with Evelyn, owner of Cobbled Court Quilts, but you don't need to know that or to have read any of those books to enjoy this one. It follows Mary Dell as she grows up in Texas on a huge ranch in a town called Too Much.  She faces her share of adversity, but she is a woman with pluck, personality and fashion sense as big as the state she calls home. You can't help but want her to succeed. This is a great book to read when you feel like life is giving you too much to handle. It's theme is making the best of what you got and the importance of sisterhood. A Great Read - I didn't want to put it down!
I love Neutrogena Rainbath - it is so gentle and soothing on my sensitive skin. The ocean mist provides a light, pleasant scent. Definitely recommended to anyone who likes smooth, soft skin.

This planner has an elegant, professional feel with the suede type cover. It's large - full notebook size - so it won't get lost. It offers both a full month calendar as well as a quarter page for each individual day. There is plenty of room for each day's appointments and/or assignments. It lies flat when open. There is also a convenient folder pocket in the back. The only negative is that the cover is difficult to close once you have opened the planner. Overall, a very well thought out planner.

"Inside the O'Briens" is not the type of book I usually review. Focusing on an Irish Catholic Boston family, there are passages in this book that are so anti-Catholic they made my blood boil. In addition, the f-word is used so often, it almost becomes part of the background of the novel. There is also lots of premarital sex going on (although only one semi-graphic depiction). So, why am I recommending it? Because at the end of the day, this is an incredibly powerful pro-life novel about the value of life at all its stages and in all its circumstances, even the ones that are most painful to imagine.Lisa Genova is a Harvard educated neuroscientist best known for her novel, Still Alice, about a woman suffering from early-onset Alzheimer's. In "Inside the O'Briens," she paints a portrait of a Boston cop suffering from another disease, this one much less well-known, but no less devastating. Huntington's Disease, which I admit I had never heard of before reading this book, is a way of life for 37,000 people in the United States. It is a genetic disease which means that children of someone who have it have a 50% chance of developing the disease.Inside the O'Briens focuses on the cop himself as he faces life with this disease, and on his youngest daughter who struggles with making the decision of whether to find out if she carries the gene. There are also three other children who play less of a role in the story, and the mother, a devout Catholic, who has her own struggles facing this new way of life.This is a well-woven story that educates and makes you think at the same time. It would be a great book club choice that would foster much discussion. Genova is hoping to raise awareness and money for Huntington's research through this book.

I've always been a local history buff and so I was excited to see this new edition from Images of America focusing on Baystate Medical Center, the largest medical facility in the Springfield, MA area. The roots of the medical center go back to Springfield City Hospital which opened its doors in 1870 in a farmhouse. It is interesting to read the historical text and view the images of the various institutions, buildings, and charitable donations would ultimately lead to the medical center we know today, which is still always in a state of change, evolving to better care for patients. The number of transformations also explains the various wings and configurations of the hospital, a building I get lost in every time I visit!The medical center also has a storied history as a center for nursing and medical education. Images of the students and their dorms are also very interesting. One might be surprised to find that many of the doctors and nurses are photographed with a cigarette in hand - a sign of very different times!This book would be of value to anyone who enjoys learning about Massachusetts history as well as to those who are interested in the evolution of medical care.

This well-designed water gun has good shooting power of approximately 15-20 feet. It is lightweight and easy to use. You would definitely want to buy two in order to have a water fight! Able to be used at night due to the light. Lots of summer fun!

In getting this haircutting kit, I was upgrading from a more basic Wahl kit. This one definitely has a more professional feel and look. It is heavier in the hand, but still very easy to use. It cuts well and cleans up easily. Save your family tons of money by cutting hair at home. This is definitely worth the purpose.
