From 1992's shattering "Little earthquakes" to 2011's haunting "Night of hunters", Tori Amos has certainly come a long way. With 12 studio albums, and 40+ singles, her compelling songwriting genius has produced countless moments to treasure forever. Celebrating 2 decades of recording, Tori decides to pay a visit to her back catalogue. She does not really need a reason for revisiting her own stuff whenever she pleases, but this anniversary calls for a special flashback. Never one to follow the usual tactics of most artists, even when it comes to re-releasing old material, she does it in her own unorthodox way. Instead of gathering the obvious hits, she makes an unexpected selection of tracks to comprise this career-retrospective release, that serves more as a reminder of her idiosyncratic artistic persona rather than a typical greatest hits package.Drawing from 10 of her 12 albums, "Dust" presents a 14-song setlist that forms a Tori-fic concept record. Being the mother of these babies, Tori is entitled to her own cherry-picking, no matter how peculiar it seems. Not afraid of giving birth once again to her girls-songs, she goes one step furher and re-records them with full orchestral backing (courtesy of the Netherlands-based Metropole Orchestra), and she manages to offer new perspective to some of them, often even surpassing the tremendous strength of the early versions. Bold or unnecessary, re-interpreting such a repertoire is a challenging experiment, thus, she can be forgiven for the occasional self-indulgence. "Dust" is a pretty accessible record for newcomers and casual listeners alike, representing Tori's prolific catalogue. New arrangements, new vocals, new old, new gold.

Billed as Bjork's "break-up record", "Vulnicura" leaves little to speculate. The cover image of Bjork with a gaping chest wound, provides a visual representation of the album's thematology. As for the curious title, when broken down, the latin words "vulnus" and "cura" respectively translate to "injury" and "healing". Though hardly a novel concept, Bjork takes this personal and introspective matter, and skillfully renders it universal, by creating an album in which to find solace, despite its heartbreaking content. After a long period of philosophical (and often pretty inaccessible) albums, she returns with the most human-centered album of her career, which, to those familiar with her work, is some kind of apocalypse. Especially, when considering that the record leaked, and was rush-released, a fact that seems to have done Bjork an inadvertent service, thus, allowing listeners to focus purely on the the actual material. The album's 9 songs, chronicling the story of a relationship, are almost inextricably linked with one another. However, special mention has to be made of the album's glorious centrepiece, "Black lake", and the dramatic opener "Stonemilker". Reaching further than ever before, with "Vulnicura", Bjork proves that she is a phenomenal artist and, also, an amazing human being: wacky, weird, wondrous, wonderful.

Comebacks are hard, but Fall Out Boy seem to know how to avoid the risk of a possible failure. As it would be rather predictable to attempt recapturing their successful brand of alternative punk-pop sound once again, instead, they choose to borrow from different genres and mix various elements, creating a sound that is very different from their previous albums. With numerous samples, plenty of pop culture references, roaring guitars, killer hooks, and sharp deliveries, the result is a small triumph. Single ''Centuries'', which turns Suzanne Vega's ''Tom's diner'''s hypnotic "du du du du" melody into a contemporary anthem, and pre-destined hit "Uma Thurman", which brilliantly juxtaposes the "Pulp fiction" actress to "The Munsters" theme tune, are devilishly irresistible slices of electro-rock. "American beauty / American psycho" is filled with such complexities, which, combined with their skilled songwriting, work really well for the most part of the album. What the band intended to produce was the right level of artistic progress and fun, as they said, and that is what they did. With the teen angst that was prevalent in their early albums being replaced by a more mature sound, seems that Fall Out Boy have reached their experimental phase, and what a pleasure it is to be doing so in such a winning manner! (Note: Vinyl fans will love the frosty clear blue-coloured LP, I know I did, it looks totally awesome!)

"Blow us a kiss, we'll blow you to pieces", says the verse to "Killing strangers", opener (and one of the standout tracks) to "The pale Emperor", a fireshot at American culture, reminiscent of its creator's glorious, infamous past. "We're killing strangers, so we don't kill the ones that we love", bears the chorus. Hmm, scary thought but so very true... "You're a paper doll, I fold you how I want", he goes on on "Warship my wreck", to continue: "Cannot say, I'm breaking the rules, if I can glue 'em back together", displaying a vulnerable side that has very rarely been heard in the past. Along with single "Third day of a seven day binge" and closer "Odds of even", these cuts - that are some of Marilyn Manson's best ever- are rather indicative of the overall thematology and sound of this new album, his best in a decade.On "The pale Emperor", his 9th studio record, Manson unleashes a soul-baring mood of his frayed character. Nothing scary or intimidating about it. Instead, with just a few bursts of the delicious stadium glam rock of the past, MM feels less bold and adventurous than in the past, often sounding, well, pale. But the few punchy tracks are enough to make up for the plenty midtempos on here, and also show his knack for hooks that appear sickly sweet but are rotten to the core, proof that no-one else does wasted decadence with such swagger as his. Heavier elements are very low compared to previous albums, becoming exceptions rather than standards, but there is reason for this: "I realised that I need to focus more on creating than destroying", said Manson in a recent interview with Metal Hammer, giving an insight into his change in mind-frame.Back in the late '90s and early '00s , Marilyn Manson's videos used to be small works of art, full of symbolism, incredible cinematography, exceptional set/costume design. His music was equally compelling; hammering anthems and breathtaking ballads with personal and universal quality or appeal, containing agression and fragility, frustration and optimism, often all within one song. Everything about MM meant or signified something, stirring controversy and fascination, making him a true gothic industrial icon. My personal favourite, "Holy Wood", is a little too heavy, too ambitious and too self-indulgent, however it is a stunning, intense landmark of an album, a timeless 70+ minute opus of musical, lyrical and artistic genius. But nothing stays at the height of their power indefinitely, which is only natural.Marilyn Manson can boast that he is a man aware of what has been going around him. "The pale Emperor" feels like the product of a clear mindset, from someone who is not trying to relive his former glories or reclaim the edginess that made his name in the first place. That would be stupid to do at this point; equally pointless is to go into the new album, expecting another "Antichrist superstar" or "Holy Wood". Although "The pale Emperor" is pretty far from incomparable to MM's top material, it significantly boosts his relevance (which is rather necessary, following his failed-glam-figure status of late years), being an honest album that manifests that Manson's music can work surprisingly well without the shock element. Being wicked certainly suits him (after all, he is the former God of F*ck), but he is more than that.

Released in 2005, "Corpse bride" had most wondering whether it could top Tim Burton's magnificent, groundbreaking classic animated romp, "The nightmare before Christmas". Although it is very much in the same thematic vein, it is even darker in tone, with its creator's gleefully morbid imagination at full speed. Despite its grotesque title, with a charmingly original storyline based around someone accidentally "marrying" a corpse, "Corpse bride" may sound like an odd, slightly twisted concept at first, but it ironically proves to be a most inviting and heart-warming film. Reknowned for his weird and macabre tales, Tim Burton here presents a story that finely balances between romantic pathos and gruesome laughs, creating a hilarious and bittersweet animated operetta. The voice casting is first-class, and the mood of the film is greatly aided by the wonderful dark, jazzy score and songs by Danny Elfman. Among the biggest achievements is the exquisite animation. Being the first stop-motion film to be created wholly on digital cameras to capture an ultra-sharp image (which is complimented highly by the blu-ray transfer), the bonus features give some amazing insight into how this dreamy gothic fairytale was created, and the effort involved in bringing it to life. A stunning film to look at, visually, and a true work of art, technically, "Corpse bride" is utterly mesmerising, one of Burton's best pieces of work ever (and a cut above "The nightmare before Christmas"). Enchantingly sublime, it is nothing short of a masterpiece.

Initially dubbed Tourism 2, 2rism and T2, "Travelling" is the sequel to the 1992, 7+ million-selling album of "Tourism". Followed on from the massively successful world tour of Roxette's "Charm school" album, it features a mix of studio and live material, newly-arranged old songs, stripped down or acoustic versions, big ballads and power pop numbers. Although it could easily have been scattered and unfocused, instead, it is a cohesive and fun collection, finding the band reunited, rejuvenated, and sounding as good as they ever have. Filled with the hook-laden pop brilliance one has come to expect, there is a strident Beatles-esque feel, making the album sound refreshingly different to their previous ones. Per Gessle's talent for writing irresistible, catchy pop songs, assisted by Marie Fredriksson's fragile and powerful vocals, are the reasons to their songs sounding nostalgic and fresh at the same time, and improving with repeated listenings. Proof of their never-ending inspiration, is the new version of their classic hit "It must have been love"; with 5 other already recorded versions, it could seem rather unnecessary to add another one. Listening to Marie's mesmerising delivery, with an orchestra backing the track, surprises and excites. Roxette have always been a breath of fresh air in a world full of the stench of pop mass, just like their fellow Swedes, the all-conquering ABBA, were some decades earlier. If you like to travel in style, "Travelling" is a perfect accessory.

(Former Nicki Minaj hater, hence the title) With hype from MTV VMAs, and previously released singles "Pills 'n' potions", and especially "Anaconda", as well as one of the best guest line-ups of the year (including Chris Brown, Drake, Ariana Grande and Beyonce), expectations for her new album were high, but Nicki Minaj has definitely delivered. Making a departure from the dance-pop-flavoured second album, the cartoonish rap queen presents on "The pinkprint" a harder, edgier sound, closer to her traditional rap-hip-hop beginnings, brightened with poppier melodies, and most surprising of all, actual singing. Her tongue can run faster than one can spell Iggy, but only a few songs on here can approach the velocity of previous material. With the album's lyrics touching upon themes of family, insecurities and loss, among others, it is surely more fitting. She engages in her usual fast flow on a couple of fun and uptempo cuts, and it works in her favour (with the exception of the utterly skippable "Anaconda")."Feeling myself" is among the most interesting upbeat tracks, but I am not going to spoil the fun by giving away the "fun" element of it, it has to be listened to! "Trini dem girls" is another one. Yet, for all the album's fierceness, it keeps returning to heartache, mostly evidenced by the slower cuts ("I lied", "Bed of lies"), particularly by the absolute standout, closing track "Grand piano"; an unexpected ballad that features piano (naturally) and, wait for it, a violin! Vulnerable and personal, showcasing immense growth vocally in contrast with the almost robotic delivery of the past, this is Nicki Minaj deeply connected to her own artistry, sharing a rare moment of intimacy with the audience. All in all, "The pinkprint" reveals a different, more balanced side to Nicki Minaj's character, presenting some of the most superlative work of her career. Never thought the day I would speak so positively for her "Minajesty" would come, but here it is. Just like its minimalistic, elegant cover art, "The pinkprint" is bold and memorable.

Documenting the band's unique performance of the "Ghost stories" album to an exclusive audience of fans in March 2014, "Ghost stories live 2014" presents Coldplay's ground-breaking production, nominated for Best Live Coverage at this year's UK Music Video Awards. Shot in a custom-built amphitheatre at Sony Studios, in LA, and filmed by Grammy-nominated director Paul Dugdale, it is a most enjoyable spectacle, capturing this very special occasion. Frontman Chris Martin said that this sequenced film is basically the band's originally conceived idea: a visual representation of the "Ghost stories" album. Listening to these songs while watching the overhead imagery, actually feels much more satisfying than just listening to the immersive dreamlike soundscape of the album which, ever since its release, leaves me with the impression that is void of a certain something. After watching "Ghost stories Live", I may have found some missing element; this visual seems to be working as a great companion to it. The release also contains an exclusive live album, recorded between April and July 2014 at the band's shows in London, Sydney, Paris, Cologne, NY and LA. The package is completed by 8 music videos, including 2 films for B-Sides "All your friends" and "Ghost story", plus the extended director's cut of the "Magic" video. Beautiful, enjoyable, this is Coldplay at their finest.

Taking into account the fact that concision is not Joni Mitchell's forte, one can imagine how impossible a task it was condensing 40 years of recordings into a mere disc, as was originally intended. She was obviously expected to fail, while trying to distill her own back catalogue down to a single, ballet-themed disc. So, here is a 4-Act ballet based on 53 songs that make up this stunning collection, organized into different thematic acts, with many sonic adjustments, presented in a glorious box set. The process, she says, was a lot like making a film. "I had forty years of footage to review. Then, suddenly, scenes began to hook up, ...themes began to develop. Moods sustained. I was getting there... When this long editorial process (two years) finally came to rest, I had four ballets or a four-act ballet - a quartet. I also had a box set." We now have it, and it is nothing short of amazing.Compiled, annotated, and designed by herself, the hardback book contains 53 songs spread on 4 discs, with their lyrics printed on the book's glossy pages, 6 new paintings, and an extensive autobiographical text, illuminating aspects of the recording process. Showcasing her wisdom and intelligence, through the soulful and jazz-inflected music created over the years, and with emphasis given on material from her overlooked albums (this is the only fault of this astonishing collection, ie "Cactus tree", "Big yellow taxi" and "Woodstock" are some glaring ommisions),"Love..." is a long overdue career-retrospective. It stands as a gorgeous potrait of this most idiosyncratic artist, whose legacy will never cease to amaze. "Love has many faces", indeed, but this particular album is a labour of love that has the face of an archetypal singer/songwriter stamped all over it. Joni genius.Tracklisting:CD 101. The release of "Re-classified" is rather puzzling, as it is neither a new album, nor an EP. With 7 songs already featured on previous versions of "The new classic", the 5 brand new cuts ("We in this b*tch", "Beg for it", "Trouble", "Iggy SZN", "Heavy crown") could be the second disc on a repackaged version of Iggy's debut album. Anyway. More than half of the songs on Iggy's first album were about her experiences making it in music, and how cool she is. On here she is getting all materialistic, further bragging about her new-found success. No surprise then, since she certainly has strong energy and confidence to support this persona. However, she is also enjoyable, and even more relatable, when she becomes more introspective, showing that she has potential for making music that is equally substantial and impactful. For the time being she is offering delicious hits, which is fine. I just wish that her thematology becomes more varied in the future, and not just boast about superficial acquisitions. That is when she will become a real "class" act.

For "Listen", his follow-up to 2011's smash "Nothing but the beat", David Guetta said that he changed his working methods, building tracks acoustically rather than adding vocals to a beat. Whatever the method, the result is as impressive as ever. As with any DG album, the list of collaborators is nothing short of stellar. Many of the tracks may utilise familiar formulas, but when they sound this good it is anything but negative. In fact, what I enjoy most about the new album is the creativity with which he pushes the musical envelope with some tracks and the artists that he chooses to collaborate with. Mixing dance, pop and electronica, fantastic beats, killer hooks and a sprinkling of powerful vocals, he has crafted another solid dance album, filled with potential smash hits. Lead single "Dangerous" featuring Sam Martin is so out of left field that had me taken aback by its stunning brilliance. But it is "The whisperer", his new collaboration with Sia, that will really catch everyone off guard (unless anyone is expecting a piano ballad from him). He may be accused for producing formulaic EDM, but he sure is the golden goose churning out golden egg after golden egg. This might as well be a platinum one.

Ever since 1994, there is one Christmas album that I keep buying religiously every year for the seasonal gifts. That is Mariah Carey's "Merry Christmas". Cheerful, jolly, a little melancholic too, beautifully assembled inside-out, a perfect package. Although her second attempt with "Merry Christmas II you" failed to excite me as much, Mariah's poppy vibe is a guaranteed winner. There you have a wonderful collection of festive classics as well as some new cuts (that are 20 years old by now!), beautifully executed and presented in new old-fashioned style. Mariah's voice is a perfect instrument suitable for those trademark ballads she is best loved for, as well as for traditional numbers. Single "All I want for Christmas is you" is a true Christmas classic, only topped by Wham's "Last Christmas", which is arguably the most Christmas-associated festive song; but Mariah's version of "O Holy Night", is also spectacular, just like her fittingly subdued version of "Silent Night", and the melancholic, newly-penned at the time "Miss you most (At Christmas time)". Many artists have subsequently presented festive albums, however, Mariah's gorgeous collection of religious and secular songs remains unsurpassed. Right then, I'm off to order a few more copies! Merry Christmas, everyone, 'tis the season to be jolly!

Up until a few years ago, the only "zig" I knew was the Spice Girls' "zig-a-zig-ah!" from "Wannabe" (teenage fixations are dangerous!). Listening to this collection, cleverly presented in reverse chronological order, has made me realise that David Bowie is an artist rather underrated by my generation. Prolific is an adjective often used to describe him, and his songwriting, as well as his ever-changing music styles; these 59 tracks are proof. What impresses me more than anything is that, despite his later work which I am more familiar with, most of his early material sounds even more interesting. Unable to form an opinion since I am not a fan, still I find his shift from troubadour to glam rock king, and others changing roles in between, certainly admirable. Diversity and experimentation were obviously no strangers to him! The artwork and the packaging offer an extra nice touch to an item which is special by itself. Presented in a gatefold cardboard case that opens to reveal 4 images from different stages of DB looking in the mirror (vanity is no stranger to him either!), it is certainly worth spending a little extra in order to have the more comprehensive 3-disc package which includes 2 booklets (these could have been more detailed), a necessary accompaniment to all retrospective releases, but often ommitted by many. As a casual listener of DB's music, "Nothings has changed" seems pretty comprehensive and rather essential. Some things change, some don't. I am just pleased that I finally got to get properly introduced to Ziggy Stardust!

Depeche Mode are my favourite band. They have not stopped progressing throughout the years, while maintaining their original trademark DM qualities. Mostly, though, I love them because they never fail to excite me with every release, ever since I became acquainted with the sublime "Songs of faith and devotion", which somehow shaped my music taste. And then there is Dave Gahan; the ultimate male singer/performer, the embodiment of a charismatic band leader. Here is DM presenting their 25 & 27-11-2013 live performances for the acclaimed "Delta machine" record, which saw them boasting their classic DM element while pushing their sound furthermore.Filmed and recorded by their longtime creative collaborator, Anton Corbijn, "Live in Berlin" is a polished, mastefully assembled presentation, sheer proof of the band's energetic and timeless appeal. Spread over 2 CDs and 2 DVDs, the set list is nicely balanced, featuring new material and older hits. What is included are: the "Live in Berlin" full show audio across 2 CDs, a "Live in Berlin" DVD, a second DVD, entitled "Alive in Berlin", which includes the full live show, behind-the-scenes footage, interviews with the band and fans, and a 2-song acoustic session ("Condemnation" and "Judas", filmed at Salon Bel Ami, a brothel in Berlin). Also included is the 17-track deluxe edition of 2013 "Delta machine" album 5.1 mix on blu-ray.All these come packaged in a stylish lift-off box, that includes 5 mini-jackets housing the aforementioned discs, plus a 16-page booklet, illustrated with tour photos. Despite the obvious non-HD picture quality (director's artistic choice, apparently), and the lack of extras, what is more important is the fact that this release captures DM in great form, unlike their previous tour package which was pristinely presented but showed the band in just good form. Good is not acceptable from them, only great will suffice. "Live in Berlin" is another testament that DM continue to produce exciting albums and compelling live shows right up to the present day.The Devotional Tour was DM's most excessive, in all aspects, live experience; the Singles Tour, and the Exciter Tour, were a much needed step down; Touring the Angel found them coming right back to the top; Tour of the Universe was a hit-and-miss affair; and now the Delta Machine Tour, a musical and visual creative high. DM are the only band who succeeded in being consistently relevant, without sacrificing their artistic integrity, with vision and thoughtfulness showcased in every aspect of their work. As I have said on another occasion, in a time where pretty much everything is "depeche", they most certainly are not.

I am old enough to remember how big and exciting news was the release of The Division Bell [2011 - Remaster], back in 1994, but young enough to think of the subsequent 20 years as a lifetime. The impact of that album was tremendous. So much, in fact, that I felt almost obliged to purchase the recent, spectacular and precious in all aspects, The Division Bell 20th Deluxe Box. Whenever the name Pink Floyd comes up, I genuinely feel nothing but utmost respect for this band who has remained consistent throughout their 49-year course, showcasing unique talent and vision in their discography, and exhibiting integrity like very few other bands have. "The endless river", athough featuring mostly instrumental pieces, presents everything that defines Pink Floyd: it is psychedelic, ambitious, emotional, haunting, occasionally self-indulgent, ultimately distinctive. As this is their final record, I am excited to be able to enjoy the first new Pink Floyd album in 20 years, hoping that, in another 20 years from now, I will be reminiscing about the past, thinking about how excited I am feeling now, just like I did back in 1994.

When God gives us a gift, no one can take it away. God's gift to Whitney was her angelic voice. Whitney Houston was a vocal prodigy. Her voice was the platinum standard of what a woman's voice should be. What distinguished her from her peers was that she was a rare artist who could interpret a live vocal performance in different ways, and still make it sound just as good, or even better, than the studio version. Her ability to play with melody was underrated genius. Her natural talent was simply incomparable. Her range and voice control was impeccable. No cracks or out of tune pitch, just effortless delivery. Her soaring voice was able to move mountains and skies, showcasing a tremendous technique while simultaneously touching the hearts and spirits of people, bringing comfort and strength, instilling pride and faith.We do not aways know what our gift from God is, or even how to use it. All we need to do is keep our faith. Alhough Whitney did know how to command her instrument, she lacked faith, and so allowed her demons to take over. No one is perfect, and we all have struggles. Hers were made public, but she stood tall. One can say whatever they want about the gradual deterioration of her voice due to her addictions but, up until she sang her last note, she sang live. For better or worse, she had integrity when it came to her singing. She knew at points she sounded weak but she never faked it. She showed that it was not about perfection or the expectations of others. She had to sing as good and powerful as she could at any given time, it was all about singing, about the performance, the emotional intent and the impact she brought out in her performances. Although not even comparable with her vocal prime, her voice had the weight of her life on it, always so emotional.There are not enough superlatives to describe how awesome she was. Prodigy, tour de force, myth, icon, diva, legend. "Whitney Houston live: Her greatest performances" illuminates the insurmountable career of the undisputed Queen of Soul whose spirit will never die, and whose musical legacy shall remain unmatched. From her auspicious television debut on The Merv Griffin Show to her glorious comeback/farewell on Oprah Winfrey (one of her final public appearances), this magnificent collection will be forever reminding audiences that, under dozens of stage lights and maddening crowds, in order to silence a crowd all this woman ever needed was a spotlight and the gift in her throat. She was, and always will be the best. Nippy, I look to you, and I will always love you.Note: DVD includes 2 extra tracks, "My love is your love" music video, plus Whitney and Mariah Carey's duet of "When you believe", as performed at the 71st Annual Academy Awards (1999), both not featured on the CD of the set.

Now, this is an early Christmas treat! Always been a fan of the Divine Miss M.'s acting and musical work, she is such an accomplished all-rounder, always mixing up her repertoire, I can never tire of her (can anyone with good taste, really?). Having recorded throughout the years different styles such as ballads, rock 'n' roll, cabaret, boogie-woogie, this, her 25th solo album, pays tribute to girl groups from the past 7 decades. All the way from the irresistible swing of '30s trio The Boswell Sisters' album title track to '90s TLC's heartbreakingly gorgeous "Waterfalls", this marvellous collection is guaranteed to get feet tapping and throats singing along (a tear or two may also be expected from daydreamers). Any true fan would be a fool to miss out on this; casual listeners, too, will surely get carried away by its brilliance. Beautifully assembled in all aspects (song selection, production, artwork), and delivered with Bette's unmistakable trademark fervour (Miss M. sounds bigger and Bette-r than ever), "It's the girls" is a fantastic, fun record; bonny, bouncy, breezy ...ultimately, Bette!

1989: Pop music was inspired, emotive, meaningful, entertaining. Most of the hit songs written in the '80s still sound great and most have stood the test of time. 2014: Pop music has devolved to being bland, repetitive, processed, soulless. And as about as lasting as the fizz in an open can of soda. 25 year-old pop sensation Taylor Swift is a professional who knows how to develop her craft, she is incredibly successful, and this is why her brand new album is deemed newsworthy. "1989", named for the year she was born, is co-written and co-produced by herself, and pop svengali Max Martin and fellow partner Shellback. Here is this young lady sheding her country-pop profile, and going full pop, making a bold transition from a teen country superstar to a young pop diva. Surprisingly (or perhaps not so much), she totally succeds. Taylor-made to the last detail, oozing confidence, maturity, and showcasing her undeniable talent, "1989" proves to be a winner.Even more refreshing is the positive outlook of TS. Somewhere between the catchy hooks, and the simplicity of the lyrics, one is reminded that, some things that might seem important, really they are not in the scheme of things, and we should shake a lot of it off and move on. This most enlightning perspective is among the purposes music is supposed to serve, and one that any accomplished pop artist should be able to perpetuate. From her 2006 debut's incredible success onwards, Taylor Swift has been going from strength to strength. 8 years on, she has become a fixture in the music industry and, ultimately, a defining force. There is something to be said for a pop artist who does not trade in sleaze. I may be a GaGa devotee, a Rihanna maniac, a Lana Del Rey worshipper, a Madonna fannatic, but this young lady has talent, taste, and she is making the most of her opportunities. "1989" will most probably become another record-breaker. I say, good for her.Standard and deluxe editions come with 5 different sets of 13 exclusive Taylor photo prints, a nice touch (and a clever commercial trick) that makes worth purchasing the physical copy of the album; reminiscent of collecting artist memorabilia, so '80s, so nostalgic.

Following the completion of the re-issues series that started in 2013, it was only inevitable that a collective set would follow, too. So here it is, "The complete studio albums" box set by the iconic pop femme fatalle Belinda Carlisle. In the tradition of most similar releases, the set gathers all 7 studio BC albums in their standard editions (not the recent expanded ones), presented in replica mini-LP sleeves, simply but nicely packaged in an elegant clamshell box. Anyone with an interest in Belinda will have heard the music on the original releases, however I will make a few comments about each album.BELINDA, BC's solo debut, emerged in 1986, a year after former band - and America's most successful all-female group - the Go-Go's, were gone-gone. "I have a feeling of starting out again", she said at the time. "I don't know what's going to happen. But the Go-Go's went No. 1 on their first album, so anything's possible." As was proved, it was. Fresh from rehab, and in great contrast to the Go-Go's punk image, for her own image and sound Belinda adopted a more innocent and feminine look, successfully re-introducing and re-launching herself. The album was a promising first effort, which would lead to a fruitful solo career, as subsequent releases attested. Featuring hit singles "Mad about you" and "I feel the magic", the heartbreaking "Stuff and nonsense", and the achingly melancholic "Since you've gone", "Belinda" captured the essence of Belinda, and also many hearts (mine included) along the way. (3***)HEAVEN ON EARTH (1987), proved to be Belinda's breakthrough album internationally, and also her most successful. Single "Heaven is a place on earth" reached No. 1 all around the world; "I get weak" and the hauntingly beautiful "Circle in the sand" were smashes, too. Clean of drugs, happy with her husband, and basking in the adoration of millions of fans while on Good Heavens! tour, Belinda's confidence was newly restored since the Go-Go's split, taking her to great - personal as well as professional - heights. Along with Madonna and Michael Lackson, Belinda was on top of her game during those years, establishing her name for good with her sleek 1980's power pop-rock quality. "Nobody owns me", she claims on one of the album highlights, and that was possibly true then. "Heaven on earth" could not have been more prophetic as a title, a heavenly record in every sense. (4****)RUNAWAY HORSES arrived 2 years later. Although it maintained Belinda's popularity, it did not reach the commercial peak of "Heaven". Apparently, there were disagreements regarding promotional tactics; it did not help either that US so-called music experts snubbed it at the time. Still, "Horses" sold very well worldwide, reaching gold, platinum and double platinum status in many markets. It spawned 6 hit singles (arguably all 10 songs could have been released as singles), an impressive accomplishment on its own, even more so considering the circumstances. The pop brilliance encountered on this record is unparalleled, that is why it is considered to be Belinda's magnum opus, a bona-fide record, a pop landmark; it is indeed all of the above. Her personal favourite song is included here ("Summer rain"), mine, too ("Vision of you"). 1989 was a great year for pop music, "Horses" is one of the reasons. Hop on and enjoy the ride. (5*****)1991's LIVE YOUR LIFE BE FREE found Belinda in the midst of a severe drug problem. Interestingly, and ironically enough, this set of songs is her most optimistic and carefree; plus, she looks at her absolute best on videos and photo shoots from that era (the unforgettable "Do you feel like I feel" video is simply iconic). Dangerously poptastic, full of catchy choruses and addictive melodies, the album sounds effortlessly engaging. Considering the cancellation of the promo tour due to her pregnancy, it faired pretty well, despite Belinda claiming later on that this is her least favorite record. Obviously this has to do with the fact that she was not pleased with how her label was handling her music at the time. But with so many brilliantly crafted pop gems one after another, "LYLBF" is one of her all-time best, a close second to "Horses". And take notice of the great statement the anthemic title track makes, thanks for that Belinda! (5*****)REAL followed in 1993. More guitar-based and raw, it was a departure from the perfectly polished pop of previous albums. Affected by motherhood, Belinda consciously chose to change direction with this, offering a more personal and mature set of songs, which lacked the immediate, broad commercial appeal of past albums. A change in her image was obvious, too, hardly wearing any make-up on the stark cover and inside photos, as if trying to strip altogether (hmmm, please do!). Contributing to the overall sincerity is the fact that she co-wrote most of the songs, which also explains the intensity of her delivery. "Lay down your arms" and "One with you" are the record's instant grabbers, the rest of the album calls for repeated listenings before coming to appreciate it. "Too much water" and the almost religious "Where love hides" are favourites. Although it was hugely ignored, "Real" is the real deal. Really. (4****)After briefly re-uniting with the Go-Go's, Belinda returned to the recording studio, and resumed working. In 1996, she released her 6th solo album, A WOMAN AND A MAN. Consisting of sleek, finely-crafted, perfectly accessible songs, this is Belinda's most safe and balanced album. This was her gift to the faithful fans, who stood be her since the very beginning (thanks, our pleasure!). Showcasing an artist at her most confident and alluring state, on this album she shines vocally, exhibiting precision and emotion simultaneously. I fondly remember her tres-chic UK TV appearances for the promo of "Always breaking my heart", where she wore some lovely dresses with cherry prints on them, what a classy lady! The album included several hits, and revitalized her solo career in Europe. As a result of this success, it was released in the US, a year later, but with no much luck. A fan-favourite. (4****)In 2007, Belinda released her 7th album, VOILA, her first full-length solo studio album in more than 10 years. "After discovering and coming to love French music, I decided to record these amazing songs myself, with a playful, contemporary feel.", she said. The result is a most unexpected surprise, but a rather pleasant one! Living in France explains her almost impeccable pronounciation, but it is her trademark tremulous vibrato that matches perfectly those songs, breathing sexiness and sophistication to standards which have been re-interpreted countless times, such as "Ne me quitte pass" and "Avec le temps". This was certainly an out-of-the-box choice, one risky task which she skillfully accomplished. "Voila" is magnificent, just like Belinda herself. Merci et bravo, Belinda, vous tes une chanteuse magnifique! Felicitations! (4****)From her punk roots to a French language album, Belinda Carlisle has certainly come a long way. Regardless of her personal weaknesses, her remarkable artistic progression, and the fact that she kept a healthy distance from the demands of the industry (occasionally paying the price for it), they say a lot. Pop may be frivolous and fleeting, but she is acknowledged as an iconic popstress, though an underrated one. This is a collection guaranteed to entertain casual listeners, and excite pop fannatics. Anyone who is in for a pop trip, they will treasure this forever. Me, I will be forever in love with this flame-haired beauty with the razor sharp cheekbones.

Sexy, outrageous, camp, flamboyant, risque, grandiose; if one had to find the right word to describe Army of Lovers, that would be "excessive". Any other epithet is an understatement for this "gay" band behind those hysterical crazy disco hits of the 90s. Never in the history of popular music there has ever been a group as both ambiguous and universal. AOL were so much more than just a fun trio / quartet singing and dancing; their fabulous, fluffy pop songs were pure fun, utterly entertaining, transcending boundaries and breaking barriers. This is the most comprehensive AOL compilation out of the 3 that have been released, featuring a fantastic 18-track selection from their glorious repertoire. An essential purchase for any pop lover, even for those who are not familiar with the genius of Alexander Bard (the man behind AOL, and various other band-projects over the years), it is likely that most will crave for more. Given the sheer perfection of their material, it is totally beyond me how they have received such little recognition, when they could have exploded to become the absolute global pop extravaganza of all time. Because they were that great. Guaranteed to get even the laziest of feet tapping, and with the lyrics printed on the booklet, you'd be a fool not to groove and croon along to these stellar tunes! "Les greatest hits" is an absolute corker collection of utter pop brilliance. Purchase immediately, indulge selfishly!

Multi-million album sellers such as "The colour of my love", "Falling into you" and "Let's talk about love", established Celine Dion as the undisputed easy-listening popstress of the '90s. In the '00s, it was "A new day has come" which maintained that glorious status. From then on, she has been mostly pre-occupied with motherhood and coping with her husband's health issues, exhibiting a most admirable dedication to her family. Somewhat inevitably, she did not meet with the audience's high expectations ever since; with the small exception of 2007's 3-million-selling "Taking chances", which only produced a couple of minor hits, none of her English or French albums made much of an impact. 2013's "Loved me back to life", CD's first album of original material in 6 years, arrived in hope of placing her back to her throne, but its reception and commercial success were equally disappointing. Although it is refreshing to witness an R'n'B flavour on some tracks, and her edgier than usual approach on others is surprisingly welcome, most of the songs on here are under par. Saving the set from total mediocrity are the hauntingly euphoric title track, the unexpectedly groovy for Celine's standards "Somebody loves somebody", and the stunning "Breakaway", hands down her finest recent recording. Thanks to these aforementioned tracks, "LMBTL" shows that CD should not be underestimated in the current pop world. Even if this set failed to spark her old diva flame, it shows there is still fire burning inside her.

"To have been given the opportunity to record these classic, timeless songs on such a significant label as Blue Note ... is truly a privilege for me", said Annie Lennox about "Nostalgia". "I really do want to be loved, but I'm also prepared to be hated". That is one honest, true artist. One that I adore. And one that frustrates me by releasing new albums at such a slow pace that often makes me think that Eurythmics were all she ever did, and the sole reason I love her for. Thus, I find it difficult to slander her for releasing yet again another album of standards. But I cannot get excited, either. Just like 1994's "Medusa", "Nostalgia" is a set of favourite classics that really offers nothing much. In fact, this time around the selection of songs, often makes any new interpretation sound boxed (can anyone put a fresh spin on "Summertime"?) which is unfair for an artist of such tremendous vocal skills. Gorgeous voice, strong personality, mesmerizing stage presence, all that have made Annie Lennox truly iconic, will never be forgotten. But "Nostalgia" is pretty much another forgettable affair (when was the last time anyone played "Medusa"?). Being an avid Annie fan, I have purchased amazon's lavish exclusive casebound book edition, but I cannot but be honest and express my disappointment for an icon who appears like a dull diva. I will always stand by her, because I know she is a diva, period.

It has been quite sometime since someone who is coming from a talent show, showed true artistry, and released an album not made to be massively consumed, but instead created with care, aiming to showcase material that is worthy of the artist's true potential. In Ella Henderson's case, that was somewhat inevitable. Choosing to sing one of her own songs in the 2012 UK X Factor auditions proved that she was in a different league, and as the show progressed, her talent shone through. She may not have won, but based on these songs, she is destined to enjoy the greatest success of any other fellow contestant. Her anticipated debut record is packed with beautifully crafted songs (all of which she co-writes), merging together a most enjoyable variety of styles. Even more impressive are her performances. Ella is a young girl turning into a woman, yet her voice is so full that is beyond anyone's expectations how she is bursting with genuine emotion, singing her heart out in the most engaging way. One can literally hear her voice break on the verge of tears, and cannot help but wonder of what's to come from her in the future, if she can already exhibit such fervour, and deliver with such consistency. I could argue that she is without doubt the best British reality show non-winner ever, and "Chapter one" is easily the best debut album from one. Take a look at her on the cover, and notice the little detail under her right eye; sure, that sign of a tear is intentional, but it is the subtlety with which it is portrayed that makes it special. A sheer pop revelation, bound to soar. Here's to many more chapters to come!

Nothing scarier than marketing strategies these days. Using as cover art a photo of a man (drummer Larry Mullen) embracing the lower area of another man's semi-naked body (his son) can only be perceived as a suspiciously cheap trick to engender controversy rather than an artistic statement. Pretty ironic when the album in question is called "Songs of innocence", and it is by one of the biggest bands worldwide. Automatically installed directly to no less than 500 million people's music libraries, provided that they were Apple subcribers, "SOI" inevitably made history upon its release. And, although the songs were made available at no cost, it is no secret that this unprecedented move was part of a negotiated deal between the American technology giant and the band's label - one that is reported to worth $100 million. Going to your local record store to purchase your favourite album never seemed so last century. Songs of innocence, signs of innocence lost, no doubt."I don't believe in free music, music is a sacrament.", were Bono's words on the day, making it all the more confusing. Actually, the power of the album is to be found within its sacramental atmosphere. It seems that the key to understanding and appreciating the new record, is to leave all names, facts, prejudice and hype aside. Because the songs on here are pretty good. Less textured musically and more sonically appealing than most of their recent efforts, the new album harkens back to the musical style of the early days. While it pays tribute to their musical inspirations, "SOI" is recalling the group members' youth in Ireland, being reflective of the band discovering themselves, finding their place in the world, and touching on their childhood experiences. Bono finally lays down his political megaphone, and writes personal and vulnerable lyrics that come across naturally, highlighting the emotive essence of the record."Songs of innocence" is not radical in the ways that ie "Achtung baby!" was, but it is personal, inspired, cohesive and enjoyable. It will not win U2 any new fans; in fact, the lack of ambition and innovation will probably disappoint some of the old ones. They grasped at success so tightly in the last decade, not realizing they had lost it. Here, they throw out their past conventions, focusing instead on what they do best, and producing a solid record in their catalogue. Former soul-less corporate rock gives place to a deeper, intimate concept record, one which is not likely to be remembered as their promised rebirth, stillit is fresh, honest, freed from political convictions. Presenting most of what was mostly missing from recent albums, U2 are proving that they can still be compelling when not crushed under the weight of their own ponderousness. It may not catapult them back to their status of the past, as one of the greatest rock bands around, but "SOI" is very welcome.

Originally released sporting a black and white photo depicting a bowing girl in front of what looked like an umbrella, "Adore"'s reissue cover presents the complete picture frame in colour; the girl apears to be one of the petals of a blossomed red rose. How beautiful, indeed. The Smashing Pumpkins have always incorporated poetic elements in their work, but on "Adore" poetic they became. Whereas previous albums were more punchy and straight-forward affairs, on this, a dark, melancholic, melodic, introspective quality runs through each of the 16 songs, appropriately, as during that time the band were dealing with death and seperation (frontman Billy Corgan's mother's death, his divorce, the reunion with his father, asking drummer Jimmy Chamberlin to leave the band etc.). Experimenting with electronic sounds, fusing a '70s rock essence with '80s synth-sounds, and '90s techno-tempos was, indeed, a strange change in direction for the band, especially considering the phenomenal success of their multi-platinum and critically acclaimed previous 2 records.Despite being poorly received by critics and fans upon its 1998 release, "Adore" really attained the very same heights as the kicking "Siamese dream" and the magnificent "Mellon collie and the infinite sadness", despite sounding nothing like either of the two. Actualy, "Adore" is entirely different to any former or subsequent SP album. Even B. Corgan's signature angry scream here is replaced with a voice that sounds warm and human. Brimming with creativity and emotion, and transcending all expectations, this conceptual album was conceptualized in the most unexpected and alternative manner. Raw usually means hard, but it can also mean fine and beautiful; that is exactly what "Adore" is. Probably the most underrated rock album of the '90s, possibly one of the finest, the definition of true art (listening to the tinkly piano melody cut short in the end of the set will make you never forget them). This brand new reissue is a first-class opportunity to introduce/revisit the Smashing Pumpkins brilliance, they will effortlessly melt your heart, if you let it open. Mine is still bleeding.

Lana Del Rey: Insatiable bitch, damned diva, innocent lolita, dark angel, femme fatale, desolate princess, American trash, universal Goddess, revolutionary, provocateour, icon, bimbo, siren, mermaid, human, alien. Ultimately, the most controversial artist of this decade."Born to die": Haunting, somber, uninhibited, eclectic, sultry, hypnotising, brooding, euphoric, glorious, mesmerizing, otherwordly, masterfully epic, heavenly sublime, helplessly addictive, bona-fide masterpiece, magnum opus. Ultimately, the pop record of this decade.

Released a few months after the sublime "Born to die", "Paradise" enhanced the mystery about the dark angel better known as Lana Del Rey. Being deeper, darker and dirtier than its predecessor, each of the EP's 8 songs is utterly mesmerising and addictive, making it a perfect companion to her glorious debut. "Ride", "Cola" and "Gods and monsters" are arguably the highlights, but the absolute standout track on here is the cinematic "Body electric", a euphoric, Bond-esque ode with compelling lyrics and a matching melody, inspired by the same-titled poem of American poet Walt Whitman. "And I will show that nothing can happen more beautiful than death", he writes on "Starting from Paumanok"; surely LDR identifies with him. Listening to these songs feels exactly as if death is the only salvation from the troubles of one's mortal existence. With this year's "Ultraviolence" (a diverse, slow-burner of an album) LDR proved that she is an adamant artist, but with "Paradise" she showed her artistic intentions. Her "Paradise" feels more like "Paradise lost". But it is heavenly, nevertheless.

This calendar has some of the must stunning photography I have seen on any calendar ever.  Each month features a vacation spot and highlights some of the best features of that place, also provides a tiny language lesson - basically how to say "What's up?" in the language of the place.Honestly, the spaces for each date could be larger.  Busy people might want to use another calendar to record their appointments.  However, this is the perfect calendar for our kitchen.  We basically use it to record vacations and other events involving the whole family (typically not more than one per day) - and also to have something beautiful to look at.  I think Lonely Planet calendars will be in my kitchen from now on.

This film wasn't easy to watch, and it commenced haunting me as soon as I had finished.It is in many ways a self-consciously arty film, from the 50s jazz score to the black and white cinematography, to the performances.  Based on a true situation (Dylan Thomas's reading tour in the US in the 1950s instigated by the academic John Malcolm Brinnin), the filmmaker has created settings and dialogue to enhance the situation of an alcoholic, brilliant Welsh poet pinballing between New York taprooms and the stuffiest Ivy League reading rooms.  Brinnin as played by a nearly unrecognizable Elijah Wood is frightfully uptight.  He has chosen to attach to the most volatile possible character to launch his academic fortune - a venture almost guaranteed to fail.  This movie has a sense of doom hanging over it from start to finish.  Even when Brinnin brings Thomas to his childhood vacation home in Connecticut to dry out and recharge in the 4 days between New York and a critical appearance at Yale, the mood is gloomy and menacing rather than serene.  In fact, I actually had to fast-forward during a wild evening with neighbors who were determined to one-up each other with horror stories.  (Side note:  the movie was actually filmed in Swansea, Wales, in 18 days.)It's no spoiler that Thomas's tour of the States could actually be viewed as successful, no thanks to Brinnin's efforts to contain his appetites.  This is a depressing story and no punches are pulled.  I don't need to watch it ever again, but like I said, it is haunting me.  It really is a very well-made movie.

This shelf isn't going to work for me.  I am giving it the same rating as the average of all the reviews to date.It's not that easy to tell from the picture, but this shelf is primarily a heavy plastic with stainless steel structural details.  It has a small surface so its functionality is limited.  I would not be confident to attach it with the waterproof glue included - have had too many shelves come crashing down in the middle of the night - and the tile in my shower defies the insertion of screws for the alternate mounting option.  It may work in some capacity other than the shower, I'm currently figuring that out.  As a "luxury shower basket" it is quite impractical and way overpriced.

I was a little familiar with Richard Bausch, having read Thanksgiving Night.  I thought the plot summary of this book sounded quite compelling and I was excited to get a copy to read for the Amazon Vine program.  Considering that the Advance Reader's Copy is almost a year old at this point, I still thought maybe the general public just needs to be made more aware of Mr. Bausch's work.  Having finished the book, I think maybe they are aware of him and choose not to read his stuff.Natasha and Faulk are two of the most overwrought characters I can remember appearing together in the same book.  I would never diminish what happened to them - Faulk going through 9/11 in New York and Natasha's horrific experience in Jamaica, on top of not knowing whether her fiancé had died in the attack - but they both become so weak.  They go from attractive protagonists to complete victims, both of them.  And all that angst is so draining.  The effect is exacerbated by Bausch's cool, detached writing style.  I felt like he didn't have much compassion for his characters, his creations.  Natasha has her awful secret, and her friends and family are overwhelmingly worried about her, and she's just a mess.  Faulk's insecurity becomes his defining character trait.  He has the whole story written, in his head and on paper, of why she has withdrawn from him.  He keeps badgering her, she keeps withdrawing from him, and it's not pretty.  The booze is flowing, mostly down Faulk's throat.  They have moments of connection but it's really just a veneer of pretending things are okay, and that's as good as it gets between them.When The Talk finally takes place, Faulk is very drunk, and Natasha is distraught.  There is screaming and property damage.  The ending provides a shred of hope for the future.  I think you would have to be very gullible to hang on to that.Richard Bausch's writing style sometimes reminds me of John Cheever, whom I like quite a lot.  The difference between the two is humor.  Cheever always seemed to have a great deal of affection for his characters.  Sometimes Bausch seems like a boy pinning insects down to a board and observing them.Readability matters a lot to me and is the reason I gave the book 4 stars instead of three.  I was never bored - frustrated yes.  I think Bausch started with a very intriguing concept about the aftermath of 9/11.  I don't particularly care for the direction he took, but I'm not ready to give up on him yet.

It has been a while since I was at school - we never had these cute shelves available.  I do have a locker at work, but mostly this struck me as a very versatile product and I wanted to try it in other places besides lockers.My husband made fun of it at first and urged me to take it to work, but it wasn't long before he found a use for it, plunking down a package (from Amazon) by the door to take upstairs on his next trip.  I am currently using it in our bathroom which is in the midst of remodeling, to keep a few items off the floor.  Eventually this locker shelf may make it to my place of business, where my workspace is in dire need of organization, or I may just buy another one.  In general I would classify this as one of those what-did-I ever-do-without-this products.  It is light and portable and provides that extra surface one needs so often, in addition to its organizational features.  A great discovery - five stars.

First impressions are important.  These towelettes, both the White Tea and the Peach Willow Bark, smell absolutely great and the initial contact is truly refreshing.  Unfortunately, that's all the good news about this product.The Peach Willow Bark towelettes are intended to exfoliate.  They are very mildly abrasive, not too harsh at all.  However, both towelettes leave a residue on my face.  Several minutes after application, my skin is sticky, and several hours later it is greasy.  I have a slightly oily T-zone but in general my skin is pretty dry.I do love the scents and will find a way to use them - probably as hand wipes after picnics - but I will not be purchasing additional product.

I am not a Nerf expert, but luckily someone in my orbit is.  Unluckily for this product, he is probably not the target demographic for this particular model.Reading through the other reviews, I can see that a fair amount of adults also consider themselves Nerf aficionados, which means my son is in good company.  He takes his Nerf products very seriously and has tried the competition which, Hasbro/Nerf will be happy to know, falls short.  (It truly is Nerf or Nothin'!)However, this N-Strike SharpFire Blaster is his least favorite Nerf product.The different configurations including a holster get a thumbs-up.  Also it is a plus that the gun comes with 10 darts since they tend to get lost.  Unfortunately the plaudits stop there.The process of loading one dart at a time is tedious.  The gun does not have much power which makes it tough to aim.  This is an old-school model which has quite a bit of kid appeal but is just not sharp enough for more seasoned Nerf enthusiasts.  In all honesty, if I felt qualified to review the product on my own, I would probably give it 3 stars.  I suspect there are a lot of young'ns out there who are absolutely thrilled with this gun.  However, I know from personal experience that for the older demographic, it's not so great.

We are fans of the TV series and glad that the show led us to these books.  The Tempe of the books is quite different from Tempe on the show.  In the books, Tempe splits her time between Montreal and North Carolina.  (Speaking in Bones takes place in NC).  In the books, Tempe lives alone and is the primary driver in solving cases, with the sporadic help of a few mildly eccentric law enforcement officials.  Tempe is divorced and in a rather complicated relationship with Montreal Police Detective Andrew Ryan.  Her most sustained relationship is with her cat Birdie.  Her mother Daisy and sister Harry make periodic appearances, but primarily Tempe is a solo act, and that's the beauty of it.  The reader gets to hang out with Tempe.Speaking in Bones tackles issues of backwoods fundamental religion and also cybersleuthing.  I learned a lot as per usual.  Kathy Reichs definitely does her research.  The plot progressed steadily, the book was tough to put down, and the ending was very satisfying.  (No spoilers, but Tempe spends most of the book avoiding both her tax accountant and Ryan's marriage proposal.)I love hanging out with Tempe and am always a little sad when the story comes to an end.  The Tempe of the books is less quirky than Bones on TV - maybe not quite so entertaining but still a very neat lady.  The spouse and I go back and forth whether books in a series can be read out of sequence.  He absolutely refuses to start a series in the middle.  I haven't read all of the Bones books but jumped at the chance to read this latest one, and I definitely think if you want to start reading about Bones here, well jump right in.  Reichs is excellent at providing just enough of the backstory.  I enjoyed Speaking in Bones every bit as much as any other book in the series, and it's a solid 5 stars for me.

My old hair dryer was a Conair - I think.  It is so old that some of the markings have worn off, and it still works great.  This new dryer - I will call it the "1875 Folding" for short - appealed to me because of the folding handle feature.  I jumped at the chance to receive an 1875 Folding to review.First impression - it is noticeably lighter than my old dryer.  Second impression - the attachments actually stay attached!  With previous dryers the attachments would fall off and/or get tangled in my hair so I discarded them pretty quickly.  When I turned on the 1875 Folding with the concentrator attached, I was a bit disappointed.  The air flow on High was just not as powerful as expected.  I have long thick hair and usually go with high heat and high power.  This one was not blowing me away, so to speak.Overall this dryer just does not feel as solid as my old one.  I like that the dual heat and power controls are right next to each other on the handle.  They are easier to manipulate.  However, the plastic seems thinner and cheaper.  I suppose if you are going to do a folding handle, the handle itself will be lighter and feel flimsier.  The retractable cord does work great, which is a major consideration for me.  Personally, even with a folding handle, I would not travel with this dryer.  There are other dryers out there with folding handles (but not retractable cords) that are equally powerful and significantly smaller and lighter.  (Every ounce counts!)I like to finish off my hair drying session with the Air Curler (check it out, I think it's pretty awesome), and this is where the 1875 Folding earned an extra star.  Without the concentrator attachment, my hair swirled around in the Air Curler cylinder like crazy and dried/curled faster - an improvement on my old dryer which did a more than adequate job.  I may stick with the old dryer for Phase 1 of the drying, and use the 1875 Folding with the Air Curler.  A rather elaborate plan, considering my usual minimum-fuss approach - but hey, whatever works.

We have been watching the Longmire TV series and like it a lot, so I jumped at the chance to review this book for Amazon.  The spouse has already started reading the Longmire books from the beginning and recommends them highly.  However, I have never had a problem starting in the middle of a series.It undoubtedly helped to be familiar with the characters from TV, but the characters in the book are different.  There is no Branch.  Vic is different in appearance but not so much in her temperament.  Most notably, the character of Walt himself is very different in the book.  The TV series has quite a bit of humor but it is relatively subtle, and Walt's character is a straight-on, steely eyed Wyoming lawman.  The Walt Longmire of the books has a sense of humor.  He also does not hesitate to express emotion.  I like the book-Walt better.Candidly, the first part of the book seemed a little lighthearted.  The denizens of the courthouse are somewhat playing it for laughs.  It is an easy way for the reader to get to know the characters.  The imminent arrival of Walt's daughter Cady and her daughter Lola has everyone excited.  Yes, there is a death, and a mystery involving a poisoned Indian, dinosaur bones, and a visit from the FBI.  In typical fashion Walt is focused on solving the case while everyone around him is urging him to get things ready for his baby granddaughter's visit.  I don't want to spoil anything but just say that when Cady and Lola arrive, things get serious and the tone changes abruptly.  Walt really gets the chance to show his heart, and the story from there made me shed a few tears.Craig Johnson's writing style is very reader-friendly.  With so many distractions and reasons to put a book down and go do something else, this book made me want to stay curled up and turning pages.I enjoyed this book quite a bit and found the ending to be especially gratifying.  Now I am going to go back and start at the beginning of the series!Edited 5/4/15 to add:  Now having read the first four volumes in the series, I have to agree with other reviewers who suggested that the existence of the TV show has had an impact on the books, and not necessarily for the better.  Although I did enjoy Dry Bones and am keeping the 5-star rating (mostly for the ending), to me the earlier books are much richer.  It's like reading literature as opposed to pop fiction.  I would not go so far as to say the latest book seems dumbed down, but the earlier books definitely have a lot more depth.  Regardless, I am hooked on the series, will read it through to the end, including rereading Dry Bones.

My 6 year old Chihuahua likes these Jerky Treats.  She doesn't seem overly excited for them but she eats them every time.They're a nice size for her.  I thought with them being called jerky, they would've been a bit tough and taken at least a few minutes to eat but they're actually pretty soft and easy to bite off pieces and chew.  My dog has them gone in about a minute.I like to think these treats are truly supporting her joints as stated.  Hard to say say for sure but something is better than nothing I'm sure.My dog digests these just fine and seems to like them just fine.  I would recommend giving them a try.

This is a really nice Flying Disc.  The dogs absolutely love playing with it.The disc is pretty large.  About 8" across.  The disc is not flat.  It has a neat wavy edge which I think is nice because it makes it easier for the dogs to pick it up.The disc has a pretty good weight to it (about 10 ounces) so I'd say it's probably best for larger dogs only.  It flies pretty good but lands hard so I wouldn't want to worry about a smaller dog getting hit with it.The disc is very solid and durable.  It's holding up incredibly well.  The quality is great.  We have the Currant color option and love the color.I think this is an awesome disc for larger dogs and I would highly recommend it.This product was provided free of charge for an honest review.

This game is pretty fun.  We've just played it with those of us in our household so far and that includes my husband, 14-year-old daughter, 12-year-old son and myself.  The kids enjoy it way more than mom and dad but we don't think it's bad.  They just happen to think it's incredible.The game is very fast and easy to learn.  There's nothing complicated at all in figuring it out.You choose somebody to be the Guesser.  This person draws a card and silently reads the "dilemma" that matches the color of space that their "mover" is on.  They then take the Dilemma Dial and lock in their choice of what they think the other players will choose.  The Guesser will then read the dilemma out loud to the other players and those players will discuss it and come up with an answer.  If their choice matches the Guesser's choice, the Guesser gets to move forward but if it doesn't match, they may have to move backwards.  It's then the next player's turn to be the Guesser.The Dilemma Dial has 4 options on it.  I KNOW they will choose A/B and I THINK they will choose A/B.  The 2 KNOW options will either allow you to move forward 3 spaces when correct or make you move back 2 spaces if incorrect.  The 2 THINK options will only move you 1 space forward if correct but if incorrect, you don't have to move backwards at all.  You stay put.There are 3 types of cards in the mix.  They all get shuffled together.  The main cards are coded blue and titled Would You Rather...?  This is what I described above.  The other 2 types of cards are quite a bit less and have different playing instructions.  The green coded ones are titled Would You Rather...Blank?  These cards have words in brackets that need filled in from the other players.  You may have to tell them to name a body part before you can fill in the blank.  This allows for some creative fun.  The 3rd type of card is the red coded ones that are titled Would You Rather...Challenge?  This card basically requires the Guesser to choose A or B and fight their case for why that one should be chose and then they have to choose another player to fight for the opposite option.  The other players not in the debate choose who was most convincing.  These can be fun but they can be dull too.  We had one that said High Five or Low Five.  How boring!  Anyway, the winner of this gets to move forward 3 spaces.Overall this game can be pretty fun and entertaining.  We've played a few games and I should point out that it's much better when you have an even number of players because when players are split on their choices and don't want to budge, it can be pretty long and drawn out.  Some of our games have lasted a really long time.One thing I didn't get was the fact that the card holder wasn't big enough to hold all of the cards.  Not a huge deal but it just doesn't make sense.Some of the cards are gross, some funny, some just plain dumb and some head scratching.  With 160 cards and 5 dilemmas per card, that's a lot of dilemmas.  It won't get repetitive for a long time.  We haven't really come across anything yet that I didn't think wasn't kid appropriate.  I think this game is just find for kids 12 and up.  Probably geared for those 12-16.  My kids love it.  I'd recommend it.

I absolutely loved this book, especially the first half.  I had an incredibly hard time putting it down and when I did, I couldn't quit thinking about it.  I think I even dreamed about it a couple nights.  It was so suspenseful and terrifying.I instantly felt drawn to the girls and my heart couldn't help but go out to them.  I couldn't wait to see what they would do and how they would move on from every bad luck situation that they encountered.  They were hit with one thing after another and just when you'd think their poor lives couldn't get any worse, they did.  I even shed some tears along the way which is very rare for me.This was a well written story that will stick with me for a very long time.  It's the 4th book that I've read from this author.  I didn't think I'd find one as good as Still Missing but this one is right up there with it.  I loved it and would highly recommend it.This book was provided free of charge for an honest review.

The Cups that I received are a little different than what's shown in the picture.  The design/pattern is different and the bag states NOW CRACK RESISTANT.  My guess is they tried to redesign the cups and make them better but they're actually worse.The main problem is the fact that the white rims are chipping so that you see blue underneath the white.  It looks like paint chipping.  There's little flakes of white all over the cups.  It's not just a few of them, it's all of them.  This is how they arrived.  I would want to thoroughly rinse each and every cup inside and out before letting anyone drink out of them.  That can't be good to swallow plastic flakes.Aside from the chipping issues, the cups are very flimsy.  They're really thin and they bend and make cracking sounds way to easily.  They may be crack resistant but you'd think they'd feel sturdy in your hand, not less sturdy.These cups are more of a teal blue or pool water blue.  A pretty color.  For some reason I was expecting a dark blue color but they're not.  Just an FYI for those who are looking for a specific shade of color.The cups work fine but after a good rinse out and wipe down but that kind of defeats the purpose of disposable cups.  I'm not fond of these cups and wouldn't recommend this particular set.

I think this is a pretty nice Panasonic Shaver System.  It comes complete with a self-cleaning station.This shaver can be used on both wet and dry skin.  I think it provides a really close shave with minimal irritation (sensitive skin) that leaves the skin soft and smooth.  The shaving process seems to be a bit slower with this shaver as compared to previous shavers.  It’s not bad, just slower.This shaver runs really fast and strong but it’s actually quite a bit quieter than most shavers that I’ve come across.  The cleaning station is pretty quiet too.  The last one I used was pretty loud, this one isn’t bad at all.The cleaning station also doubles as the charging station.  You simply fill the water tank and dump in a pack of detergent.  1 pack is included and it should last for about a month.  After you’re done shaving you place the shaver into the station and press a button to start the cleaning process.  The shaver will be cleaned, dried and charged.  In my house this shaver is always placed on the charging/cleaning station after use so it’s always fully charged, cleaned and ready to go.I think this is a really nice system.  I would rate it 4  stars and recommend it.

I have the Toy Breed Adult option and we have 2 Chihuahuas who love this food.  One of them is about 16 years old and has had all of her teeth removed so the smaller the pieces the better in my opinion.  These pieces are very easy for her to chew and eat.  These pieces are incredibly small.  Probably the smallest pieces of dog food I've ever seen.Both dogs will choose this food over others when mixed together.  They seek out these pieces and pull them out to eat.  They digest the food well and seem to really enjoy it.I like the bag that this food comes in because it's resealable.  It has a zip top that makes it easy to close and keep it fresh.I would highly recommend trying this dog food.

These Jeans fit pretty decent.  They're a bit tighter in the rear though.  Aside from that, they're good and comfortable.  They look nice.I have the Dark Stonewash color option and it's a great color.  They're dark without being too dark.  A really nice blue color.These jeans are your typical 5 pocket, zip fly with button closure.  These jeans feature a Comfort-Waist feature though which gives a nice stretch to the waistband making it more comfortable in that area.  Although you can see a difference on the inside of the waistband, nobody will ever know from the outside.These jeans fit pretty well even though they're a bit tighter in the rear.  They look great.  I'd recommend trying them.

These Jeans fit great, as expected.  They're really comfortable and they look nice.I have the Vintage Stonewash color option and it's a nice color.  They're not light and they're not dark.  They're what I'd call a medium blue, right in the middle.These jeans are your typical 5 pocket, zip fly with button closure.These jeans fit nice and look well.  I'd recommend trying them.

I think this is a really great binder. It has several different features that I really like.This is a 2" zippered binder that has an optional shoulder strap for carrying that's adjustable.At the front of the binder there is a prong closure flap that opens to a small zippered pocket that is great for pencils and other writing utensils.  Below that is another softly lined and padded pocket that's great for electronic devices such as iPad's, Kindles or other tablets or reading devices.When you open the binder you have a vertical 5-Tab/6-Pocket expanding file behind the front cover.  Colored tab inserts are included.  There is a velcro strap to help keep the contents in place.The 3 ring fixture is mounted on a large flat plastic surface that can actually be removed from the binder if desired.  This plastic portion is inserted in an open pocket on the inside of the back cover.  580 sheets is the capacity of this binder.This binder great quality and seems pretty durable.  It's stated that you can fold back the front cover to maximize desk space but I feel as though I'm going to break something if I try to force it so we've chosen not to do this.I think this is a great binder and if this is the type of thing you're looking for then I would highly recommend it.

I have shoulder length hair that's wavy to frizzy, thick, dry and frizzy.  This Shine Enhancing Cream doesn't do much for me.For starters, the directions aren't as clear as they should be.  It tells you to apply to damp or dry hair, avoiding the roots.  It doesn't say how much and it doesn't state if you should/can blow dry it after.  I've tried it on both damp and dry hair, before and after blow drying.  I just don't get good results.It's supposed to smooth frizz and enhance shine but my hair seems frizzier and I don't notice any shine.  My wavy style looks okay with this and it doesn't leave my hair greasy, stiff or itchy.This product isn't bad, it just doesn't do anything good either.  2 1/2 Stars.

I think this Cleansing Oil is okay.  It's not my favorite by any means but it's not bad either.The biggest thing I'm not fond of is the way you apply it.  You pump it onto dry hands and apply to dry face.  Then you add water.  It just feels and seems weird.  I'd rather wet my face and then apply a cleanser or use it in the shower which you can't do if you need dry hands and face.It does a good job cleaning my face and doesn't dry it out.  My face isn't oily afterwards but it's not dry either.  Just a bit different than what I was expecting.I think this oil smells fine and it's not irritating to my sensitive skin.Overall this product is decent, just not my personal preference.

This Detangling Spray works great for tangles.  My daughter has really long hair that's always filled with tangles.  This detangler is very helpful for her and it can be used on both wet or dry hair which is good.The Swirlberry scent is awesome.  My daughter and I both love it.  I'm sure most girls would too.Although this detangler works well for tangles and makes her hair pretty soft, it doesn't do much for frizz & shine as it states that it does.  Not a big deal because the important thing for us was getting the tangles out.  We use other products when we want something more.Overall I think this is a great detangler and we would highly recommend it.

This Light Weight Weather Proof Cream is decent.  I have shoulder length hair that is wavy to curly, thick, coarse, frizzy and dry.  This product helps some but overall not a whole lot.This cream reduces my frizz but not by a whole lot.  I still have a pretty good amount of frizz.
