It dissolves readily, and my spa chemistry stick shows the alkalinity to increase after adding it to the spa.  For the most part, I'll buy the brand that is least expensive.  One 2 pound container lasts me about 4 years.

How often can you call a printer "fun to use"?What do I like about this Epson XP-630 wireless color photo printer?- good directions, so it is easy to put together... install ink, internet set up- quality of 4x6 photos - excellent- photos come out dry, don't smudge- love the ability to print a photo from my phone using an app!  It instantly sends attachment, photo, email via wireless and prints on printer.- easy to load paper- scanner makes sense, easy to use, send it to cloud, computer easily- seems well built, like it will lastOn the down side, the ink is expensive (like most color printers on the market).

I don't want this review to seem overly complicated.  The odors from "number 2" - dropping a loaf - mostly come from volatile sulfur compounds (VSC) like hydrogen sulfide.  The odors don't emerge from the water; rather, they are released during the deposit (do I need to make myself more clear?).  Therefore, odors are not "neutralized" by any kind of contact with this product, Poo-Pourri, on the surface of the water.I suspect the essential oils overpower the other odors.  That is, the VSC are present, but either your olfactory receptors are being captured with the airborne molecules from the essential oils, or your brain is paying more attention to the essential oils than the VSC.  I don't think this is olfactory fatigue, it is a different process.  It's like using Vick's Vapour Rub to keep from smelling decaying flesh (did you ever watch a SCI show?).  The odor is still there, but it is being masked.The loaf still smells, but you have a hard time smelling it.  This probably means that people with a sensitive nose will smell the VSC.So what does this mean for my review?  First, I don't believe the action of the Poo-Pourri is as claimed.  Thus, the manufacturer is not telling the consumer how it really works.  Ding.Next, the instructions say to spritz it in the toilet 3-5 times, and then the "essential oils create a film on the surface of the water." This does make a film, but the purpose of the film is that the product spreads over the the water surface, increasing volatilization, so the molecules spread rapidly in the bowl and beyond. This volatilization is effective, and you probably only need ONE spritz, two at the most.  So you are wasting product if you follow the printed directions. Ding.Lastly, the bottle top is not as secure as I would expect.  Can you picture even a little of these essential oils leaking in a suitcase?  I could smell the leakage when I took the bottle out of the package. Ding.So the product works as a masking agent, you can stretch out the life of a bottle by using less, but the bottle will leak.

My package did not come with multiple colors, but rather with 8 black Dry Erase Markers.  As markers go, they leave a firm line on the white board.  The diagonal tip allows for finer detail, but in a large classroom, you need big and bold letters, so you have to watch how you hold the marker.The odor is less offensive than some other name brand markers.

This sterling silver ring feels hefty and well-constructed.  The manufactured opal is brilliant and showy.  The size is true (mine was a 6).Really, this is a very nice ring, and matches well with other blue opal Beaux Bijoux products (Sterling Silver Created Blue Opal 20mm Hoop Earrings), as well as other sterling silver blue opal products (Blue Lab Opal Inlay Thin Band Ring in Sterling Silver Size 6).

"I like it" should be changed to "they like it." The two middle-aged cats are enjoying this cat food. I'm surprised they eat it with that third ingredient being brown rice, but there must be enough chicken in it that they like what they see (and taste)!

"I like it" should be changed to "they like it."  The two middle-aged cats are enjoying this cat food.  I'm surprised they eat it with that third ingredient being brown rice, but there must be enough chicken in it that they like what they see!  The hairball issue?  Can't tell... I think regular brushing does a better job at reducing these messes.

Am I the only one that has difficulty using this product?  You can't be light colored one day, and tanned the next... people talk!  So how do you start off with a very gradual tan?  I can't figure it out.  I want to reduce the sun damage to my skin, but I also don't want to look painted.  And if you try a "test area" on your skin, well, then you have a darkened test area for the next week.I watched the YouTube video on the product, but how do you apply around your fingers and palm?  Your face?  Not covered!  I don't want to look like a clown for a week!  And be careful if you are going straight from light-skinned to Moroccan Tan Ultra dark!  It will be noticed!

Classic Swiss Army knife, with mini-scissors, emery board, and blade, as well as tweezers and toothpick.  Whatever style you get, the quality is there.  The animal prints made this one a unique gift for a friend.

I have a Thule backpack (Thule EnRoute Escort Daypack for 17-Inch MacBook Pro and 10-Inch Tablets - Gray (TEED-117)) that has been a part of my profile for the past 2 years.  I love the quality and the performance.  It's a bit large when I don't have a lot to carry, however, especially if I am just taking my computer down to Starbucks.  So I was excited to try out this model.First, quality.  The material, the sewing, and the straps all seem to be first rate.  No dings here at all.Now performance.  One side has a bottle holder, and the other side has a padded pocket for either glasses or a phone.  These are okay.  But there are three things that I really have problems with.  First, there needs to be a bit more padding at the bottom of the pack.  I want enough padding in the bottom so that it it is dropped from chest height (it's a pack, right?), the edge of my computer is safe.  I'll put my own padding in the bottom of the computer pocket because I don't trust the padding that this pack comes with.  Second, I have always wanted a computer backpack with a watertight cover.  The photo provided with this product looked like the top flap folded over, a bit like a dry bag.  But it is possible for the top flap to close and the sides to be open, allowing water to enter.  With my computer inside, that's a no-no.  And finally, if you are thin, the straps aren't that secure on your shoulders.  A chest strap would have helped here, as would have more ergonomically designed shoulder straps.Since I planned to use this when cycling to my office or Starbucks, I liked both the orange color and the loop for attaching a blinky light.  I also liked the handle on top when carrying it like a briefcase.
This gift of sterling silver hoop earrings went over very well!  The manufactured opal stands out, and each piece has some "heft" (they don't look or feel cheap in any way). Very secure latch.

Great colors, and I like that they are silicon, thus heat resistant.  However, after one use with tomato sauce, they are already showing the "tomato stain."  Disappointing.UPDATE:  I added a star back.  After 2 passes through the dishwasher, the tomato stains disappeared.

This cat food, Purina Beyond Natural (?) Dry Cat Food, has no "grain."  Grain is defined as wheat, corn, and rice.  Here are the ingredients: Chicken, chicken meal, pea protein, pea starch, cassava root flour, dried egg product, beef fat preserved with mixed-tocopherols, dried yeast, canola meal, pea fiber, natural flavor, dried carrots, phosphoric acid, potassium chloride, sodium bisulfate, salt, L-Lysine monohydrochloride, taurine, calcium carbonate, choline chloride, Vitamin E supplement, zinc sulfate, ferrous sulfate, manganese sulfate, niacin, Vitamin A supplement, copper sulfate, calcium pantothenate, pyridoxine hydrochloride, Vitamin B-12 supplement, thiamine mononitrate, riboflavin supplement, Vitamin D-3 supplement, calcium iodate, menadione sodium bisulfite complex (source of Vitamin K activity), folic acid, biotin, sodium selenite.The two cats are enjoying this cat food, mixed with their Science Diet standard dry cat food or alone.  As time goes on, I'll monitor their continued reaction, hair balls, and fur condition.

When I picked this book up, it was unclear that this novel requires that you've read the previous two books in this series.  I hadn't, and by page 103, I gave up.  It is not a stand-alone novel.To fully understand the nature of the "Long Earths," the trolls, and especially Lobsang, you have to start from the beginning.

In Children Of The Comet, author Don Moffitt mixes one story about trees engineered for life on comets with a story about spacefaring people returning to Earth's solar system to a point in time some 6 billion years after they left.The trees have a humanoid population, and the cultural characteristics of these people (superstitions and religion, technology, gender divisions) are predictable.  Torris, going on his "vision quest" with other young men, has the highest ethical standards, while Brank, another man on his vision quest, has the lowest.Yawn.For the technologically advanced spacefarers returning to their origins, we again have the ethically challenged versus the ethically pure.Double yawn.And then the two stories become intertwined.  But this intertwining seems forced and artificial.  This tale just never really makes it out of the starting gate.

When it comes to binocs, I don't claim expertise, but I do claim experience.  I have 4 Nikon binocs (from 8x23 to 10x50), 1 Vanguard (10x42), 1 Simmons (12x50), and (now) 3 Bushnell binocs.  Fundamentally, you get what you pay for, and you use what you can carry.I have these Bushnell binocs:Bushnell Legend Ultra HD 10x 42mm Roof Prism Binocular, Realtree AP Camo (see photo for comparison with this model)Bushnell Legend Ultra HD L-Series 10x 42mm Binoculars, BlackBushnell 10 x 28 Explorer Waterproof BinocularsI THINK both of the Legends are the "L series."  You can see that they are similar in size, and though I can't find the weight for the Realtree model, it seems a bit heavier.So here's the bottom line.  This is a very nice mid-price binocular that is easy to use and small enough to carry around.  Remember, if you don't carry it, you don't use it.  There are some similar models in this "L series," so you should be able to look around and find the best deal.  If you don't need, or can't afford, this model, there are other models that will fit the bill.  Stick with a known brand, and stay away from ANYTHING under $50.

I have every reason to like this calendar.  I love the LP guide series.  And I love scenic calendars!  However, this 2016 Lonely Planet Wall Calendar rubs me the wrong way.Take a look at that cover photo on the calendar! That's what I expect... great photos.  I mean, LP has tens of thousands of great photos to choose from, and those 12 months should be in good company.Some of the photos in this collection are not the highest quality.  Perhaps that is a matter of perspective.  What is a good photo to me might be a great photo to another.  That's a matter of taste.What I really can't take is the omission of women in the photos.  If you try real hard, you will probably find 1 or 2 women in the "wine downpour" photo.  Other than that, LP seems to think that purchasers of the calendar want to focus on men.  Male worshippers in India, male cheese chasers in the UK, a man hiking, a man camping... get the picture?This isn't being PC... this is simply being representative of the world.  And that is the expectation I have of Lonely Planet... accurate depictions of the world.

There are times you really need a heavy duty foil.  For me, it is when I am grilling fish and veggies. A light ( aka normal) foil tears easily.  This foil does the job.  The box is designed well for tearing off a sheet of the appropriate size.Don't forget to recycle those clean pieces of foil!

This has got to be one of the best Joe Pickett novels written by CJ Box, and I've read them all. There are stories within stories, and you will just be caught up in the suspense.Four stars instead of five, for Box retelling the "scientific fraud" story about federal biologists in Washington state planting lynx hair in fur traps to document lynx presence and get public lands closed down.  The real story is quite different.  I'll post a link to it in comments.

These Rose Gold and Rhodium Plated Sterling Silver Two Tone Diamond Filigree Hoop Earrings (1/10cttw, I-J Color, I2-I3 Clarity) are just under an inch in diameter (see photo).  As compressed hoops, their appearance changes when viewed from the side compared to from the front.  I think they would be more attractive in plain gold versus rose gold, but that is a matter of taste.And they are light! You won't even feel like you are wearing anything.  Fancy hoops!

There is a use for this trap, but the shorter travel length of the "killing bar" means that you have to pay close attention to trap placement.  This trap will work for medium sized rats that set off the trap when they approach it from the front.  A larger rat, or a rat approaching the trap from the side, has a much larger chance escaping or being injured.Easy to use, and easy to set, but the conventional wooden Victor rat trap is preferred.  In the attached photo, look at the size of the springs.  The traditional wooden trap has much superior springs for delivering a killing blow.

These black Hefty trash bags are sized at 30 gallons. This is a conventional size that will fit within most outdoor trash bins. They have a drawstring for cinching and, at 1.05 mil in thickness, are appropriate for most waste.  Initially, I thought that I would not use them with anything sharp or pointy (like wood trimmings or nails).  However, I've used two with 20-25 pounds of dirt, cut stems, and other plant debris (I weighed them).  The stems haven't poked through, and the bag hasn't ripped.

"My analysis focuses on haole as a colonial/neocolonial form of whiteness situated in Hawaii..." (p. 33)."If many haoles could have their way, the word 'haole' would be banned as impolite at best, pejorative at worst" (p. 34)."'You have three choices.  You can be a haole, a dumb haole, or a dumb 'pucking' haole'" (conversation between UH professor Phyllis Turnbull and a California student.  I substituted "pucking" for the obvious insulting word; p. 54)."When haoles talk about anti-haole violence, they often reference 'kill a haole day' in the public school system - a recurring event when haole kids were supposedly targeted for violence and humiliation" (p. 79).In her PhD work, author Judy Rohrer analyzes the nature of "haole" - really, being white (and privileged) in Hawaii.  The quotes above are to give you a taste of the issues discussed. It is a thoughtful essay.  I agree with some of her points, and disagree with others.  I am discouraged that so many aspects of Hawaiian culture have been appropriated for the tourist trade, and I recognize the grievous harm done to Hawaiians for centuries now.I also recognize that when specific words are used to spout hate, goodness isn't the result.Thoughtful.

Wildlife cop Joe Pickett (as well as author CJ Box) is back on the saddle!  In Stone Cold, game warden Joe Pickett has to interact with his kids, his wife, his coworkers, the Wyoming governor, the FBI, and it seems everyone in Medicine Wheel County, whose population seems to include Mr. Nate  Romanowski.Great story, perfect pace, and Pickett continues to develop!

What is with Nevada Barr?  Or should I say, what is with Anna Pigeon's biographer?  In Destroyer Angel, you get about 72 hours of misogyny, cruelty, barbarism, and torture.  Long-time fans will recognize how different this book is from Anna Pigeon's earlier tales.  You learn nothing about the place and nothing new about Anna.And don't get me started on the ending.  Very, very disappointing.

Sir Adrian Boult is known to most people as the conductor of the soundtrack to David Lean's "Lawrence of Arabia," even though he in fact didn't conduct a single note of the soundtrack (the whole thing was actually conducted by composer Maurice Jarre. Boult's name appeared in the film credits only in order to secure a recording grant from the British government, while at the same time, Jarre's name was featured prominently as conductor on the soundtrack recording LP. Apparently, no one noticed the discrepancy!).Boult was primarily a conductor of classical music, and he had an incredibly wide repertoire, a fact which may surprise those who consider him a British music specialist. That's probably due to the fact that Boult's non-British recordings never had wide release outside of the UK. Save for his cycle of Brahms symphonies and a couple of LPs-worth of Wagner bleeding chunks, his presence on US record shelves was confined primarily to the music of RVW, Elgar, Holst and other Brits.So it's very nice that EMI (now Warner) has seen fit to release an entire 11-CD box of his German repertoire (the box cover proclaims "from Bach to Wagner," even though Wolf's short "Italian Serenade" is included as well). In general, the recordings and performance come off as sober, middle-of-the-road affairs, with a fairly high standard of orchestral execution in variable recorded sound. Winds tend to be very forward, which makes for interesting listening in the Brahms Symphonies, for example.There is a lot of Wagner in this set. A LOT. And although most of it is well-played, there's nothing interpretively special about it that will make one forsake their Furtwängler and Karajan recordings (also on EMI). Boult provides interesting, low-key endings to both the Parsifal and Tristan Act I preludes, and the Good Friday Music comes off very nicely here. Recorded sound is a mixed bag, though.I am a fan of Boult's way with the Bach Brandenburgs, which are a big-band affair, though informed with what was the then-emerging HIP movement ideals. The recordings feature the late-lamented David Munrow on recorder in both the 4th and 2nd concertos, a feat in the 2nd that is aided by some subtle spotlighting in the mix.Boult's Mozart and Beethoven is also big band, which is alright with me. He draws a fine singing quality from the orchestra in these recordings which are damned for today's audiences by their extreme competence and excellent balances. Such things are - sadly - no longer admired in our thrill-a-second entertainment environment. His Schubert 9th gains traction as it moves along and is entirely satisfying.Sir Adrian was the Ever-ready Bunny of classical music. Forced into mandatory retirement from his post at the BBC in 1950 at age 61, he spent the final 28 years of his long life recording and performing just about everywhere else, primarily with the LPO - and occasional even with the BBC! - with whom he made the majority of his EMI recordings. Those recordings do him proud, and it's very nice to have access to his German rep recordings through this box set.Recommended. Grab it while it's available.

Anja Harteros, Soprano; Daniela Barcellona, Mezzo-soprano; Wookyung Kim, Tenor; Georg Zeppenfeld, Bass. Munich Philharmonic Choir; Munich Philharmonic; Lorin Maazel, Conductor. "Live" recording from the Philharmonie in Gasteig Munich, February 6,7 & 9, 2014.My first-ever experience with hearing the Verdi Requiem was at a Severance Hall performance with the Cleveland Orchestra & Chorus conducted by Lorin Maazel back in 1972. The soloists on that occasion were - are you ready? - Martina Arroyo, Shirley Verrett, Placido Domingo and Bonaldo Giaiotti. Needless to say, it was a tremendous performance, especially for a high-school student who was making his first forays into the world of orchestral concerts. Little did I know that that performance would rather spoil me for the rest of my life when it came to Verdi's magnificent Requiem, but it pretty well did.In the ensuing years, I heard Maestro Maazel again conduct the Requiem at the Blossom Music Center with a less-stellar cast of soloists, while also participating in performances as a chorus tenor in venues like St Bartholomew's Church in NYC (with organ!) to a performance at Carnegie Hall that featured close to 600 musicians in the orchestra and chorus. I even sang in a concert at Carnegie Hall that featured Verdi's "Libera me" movement from the mass he and a dozen other Italian composers wrote to honor the death of Rossini. So I'd say that I have a fairly intimate knowledge of the piece from the inside and the outside.Which brings us to this new Sony recording of the piece under the direction of Maestro Maazel. The good news is that his wonderfully distinctive interpretation is on full display here, aided by great playing by the orchestra, an excellent chorus and with recorded sound that is pretty darn good for a live recording. Where it fails to compete is in the vocal soloists, all of whom sound rather young and under-developed to take on a piece like the Requiem. Yes, the singing is competent and occasionally expressive, but this quartet simply can't compete with the typically star-driven vocal quartets that grace most recordings of the Verdi Requiem. I say that as one who has been involved in performances in the NYC area where a group of up-and-coming but unknown solo singers have sung their parts with an artistry that's only a few rungs below the very, very best. So, while I was hoping that this might have been one of those occasions, it isn't, and more's the pity.With all of that said, it is still good to have Maazel's Verdi Requiem finally inscribed for posterity on commercial CDs. The Verdi was something of a signature piece for Maazel, and I've always been baffled that none of the record labels for whom Maazel recorded extensively over his lengthy career - DG, Decca, Philips, EMI, Sony, Telarc et al - ever elected to record the piece with him in his prime, and to provide him with a set of world-class soloists and a renowned orchestra and chorus for the occasion. But for whatever reason, it never happened, and we should be grateful to Sony for setting things right to a large extent, even considering the caveats voiced above.For those who know the Maazel way with these large and sometimes sprawling scores, you'll be pleased to know that he is much less indulgent in terms of stretching ritardandi etc than he could be on occasion. He is possibly the only conductor I know who actually observes Verdi's marking of "stentando poco a poco" (holding back - note by note, little by little) in the "Dies irae" sequence, though even here the effect is less pronounced than I remember it from the performances he conducted in Cleveland. Maazel was also a wonderful accompanist for solo artists, and he does a fine job here, both in supporting his solo singers and in leading them through a few passages that are usually taken more broadly by singers with greater technical resources. The orchestra also sings under Maazel's leadership, and I must say that it is refreshing to hear a true *legato" coming from all of the performers throughout the recording. Balances are spot on, and the chorus is tastefully given a little more presence in the soundstage than is often the case.I would have given this recording 5 stars had the soloists been closer to the major league types who have graced recordings of the Verdi Requiem in the past. At 4 stars, this is still a highly recommendable version, and a fitting tribute to a great musician who left us all too early in 2014.Recommended.

I owned the initial CD release of this set. As others have noted, that set included copious program notes that really help to give one an insight into the music. I gave that set away to a friend who's a bigger fan of Stravinsky than am I. I acquired this 22-CD set from a third-party seller for all of $20.99 plus shipping and a little tax. It's worth it to once again own these recordings (it's a shame that Sony didn't see its way clear to include the booklets on a CD-R, or to make pdf's of the booklets available online). Then again, there's plenty of music out there that's just as challenging as is Stravinsky's that can be enjoyed on the purely aural level without any need of a written apologia/explanation.I am not the world's greatest Stravinsky fan. I find probably half of his music enjoyable. The rest seems incredibly light weight and meandering to me. Outside of his early ballets - Firebird, Petrushka and The Rite - it tends to go downhill for me. Yes, I like Apollo and Orpheus well enough, and the melodramas come off well here (mainly due to the contributions of tenor George Shirley), but I have never warmed to The Soldier's Tale or the Symphonies, for example. I can't stand the Symphony of Psalms, but that's probably because I've had to perform the vocally un-ingratiating chorus tenor part on more than a few occasions. Ugh!As an interpreter of his own music, Stravinsky is - IMHO - just OK. There are plenty of musicians who do it better, at least if you consider his oeuvre on a piece-by-piece basis. I like his Firebird and Petrushka here, the Rite, not so much, though it actually sounds better in this issue than it does in any number of other Sony CD issues of this same recording that are currently available.So, worth having, especially at the price. I see that Sony is planning an über-complete Stravinsky set for October, 2015. That set will include all of his mono recordings as well and looks to run to 57 CDs in length. However, it also looks to have a healthy price tag attached to it (currently pre-ordering @ $219). This present budget issue is a good deal, considering everything.Recommended.

Warner Music having acquired the EMI catalog has opted to issue these EMI recordings on their French Erato label, which makes perfect sense.I've performed quite a few of Poulenc's choral works over the years, including Sécheresses and Figure humaine (though I've never had the opportunity to perform his Gloria). I became a Poulenc fan back in my college days, and I remain a fan, even though I never really explored his music much outside of his vocal works. This set provided the opportunity to do just that, and at only $35, it was an easy choice to jump on the bargain.After listening to a number of the discs, I'm more convinced than ever that Poulenc's real forte was in the vocal realm. His solo piano works, for instance, are but confections compared to his vocal works, which plumb the depths of emotion and expression. His chamber music while enjoyable isn't the equal of his vocal utterances either. That said, EMI/Erato could have made better choices when it came to works like the Mass in G, which receives a weak performance by a men and boys choir.I'll take the occasion of this review to recommend that you become familiar with his early work Sécherreses, which combines Poulenc's original voice in a Stravinskyesque work for chorus and orchestra. It's pretty unusual and has received only three commercial recordings - the here-included 1984 EMI-sourced recording led by George Prêtre; a 2007 recording on the Swedish Nosag label conducted by Sonny Jansson; and the very first recording which was recorded at a gala anniversary concert of Les Six given on November 4, 1953, by the Societé du Concerts at the Théâtre du Champs-Élysées, hosted by Jean Cocteau.The only complaint I have is that there are no texts or translations enclosed. Disappointing when texts and translations were included in many of the EMI issues. Why not scan those booklets and include the texts on a CD-R?Recommended - as a collection filler, as a great intro to Poulenc, as a comprehensive edition and for the performances and recordings, which are for the most part top notch.

This 70-CD set presumably concludes DG's issue of what they consider to be Herbert von Karajan's recorded legacy on the yellow label. Every CD in the first three sets in this series was remastered using DG's Original Image Bit Processing (OIBP) techniques, and to great effect. One can't be so sure that's true for this set. Falstaff - which features the cover art from the initial Philips LP/CD release - utilizes the DG CD label look, as do all of the other DG-released recordings.The CD labels for all of the DG-labeled discs indicate they were mastered using the OIBP process. The Decca issues feature a Decca FFSS LP label look, but there's no indication anywhere in the set to lead one to believe they have been remastered, though one might assume as much based on the practice followed for all of the other CDs in this 4-set series.Let me start by addressing the supposed "completeness" of this set, and of this series. It is something of a bonus that DG have seen fit to include Karajan's opera recordings that he made on Decca, as they include a few of his finest efforts in "Boris Godunov," "La boheme" and "Madama Butterfly." His "Nozze di Figaro" is a top-flight mix of an interesting use of expressive parlando in much of the recitatives, great acting and some fabulous singing in the showcase arias and ensembles, coupled with a very sensitive orchestral accompaniment - and a studio recording, NOT a live performance as advertised elsewhere. His early Decca opera recordings of Aida, Fledermaus (with the Gala Sequence), Otello (with the Act 3 ballet music) and Tosca are very welcome here, and add substantially to this set had it been limited to only operas released on DG.But here's the rub with this box and this series:1. It's nice that DG included Karajan's Decca opera recordings...so why didn't they also include his 9-CDs worth of Decca orchestral recordings that were made with the Vienna Philharmonic in the 1960s? Seems to me that those very-fine-on-average recordings could have been included in the earlier sets, especially the recording of music from Giselle, which was basically a career one-off for Karajan. And what's with the cover art they used for the Decca recording of Tosca? This set was originally released stateside in RCA's Soria Series with much nicer artwork. Perhaps the cover portrait of Price that adorns the included CD set reflects the cover art Decca used when the rights to the recording reverted entirely to Decca. I don't know that, just making an educated guess.2. There are a number of live opera recordings that were released by DG on CD that are not included. I'm thinking of the Fidelio, Die frau ohne Schatten, Tannhauser, Murder in the Cathedral and Coronation of Poppea that were released on DG CDs in the late 1990s. Was there a licensing problem including them in this set? All of those performances were done at the Vienna Staatsoper, and I wonder if - perhaps - the licensing fee was just too high to include those sets in a box being sold at a super budget price.3. What about Karajan's very earliest recordings that were made just prior to and during WWII? These recordings have been released a couple of times on DG CDs. Why they weren't included in this series is a mystery.4. As nice as it is to have the excellent live performance of Haydn's "Creation" included - which gives us Fritz Wunderlich's full assumption of the tenor role, an assumption that was cut short by his untimely death during the recording of DG's studio version - what does it have to do with opera? I'm glad it's included, but there's no reason to have included it outside of someone being nice at DG, and not forcing us to buy this recording in its stand-alone CD issue.5. The lack of libretti for the operas is really unforgivable, as almost all of these recordings featured libretti in their earlier LP and CD issues. DG could have easily fit all of the libretti onto a single CD-R and included it in the box, a solution that worked just fine for EMI when they issued their Complete Karajan sets back in 2008. Truth be told, the opera box has even LESS info available than did the orchestral boxes in this series, as the LP-covers used in the orchestral works at least duplicated the liner notes that appeared on the back of the LP jackets (readable if you possess a good magnifying glass).So, there are issues here, even if they pale when set against the musical performances set down on these CDs and revealed through some accomplished remastering.I'd now like to offer a few reviews of specific recordings to give potential buyers a feeling for 1. the strength of the performances, and 2. the remastered sound on the CDs (those wishing more in depth reviews of the individual operas can avail themselves of reviews written elsewhere on Amazon):Bizet: the included recording of "Carmen" was Karajan's second studio recording of the opera, third if you include his movie version, and it's the weakest of the three. Karajan's preference for light voices at this stage of his career is a negative, especially in this opera. What the singers in this DG production can't deliver in sheer vocal weight and glamour they attempt to deliver through vocal acting that wears thin on repeat hearings. It's also a bit disconcerting to have the spoken dialogue voiced by actors, rather than the singers themselves. Not a bad idea in theory, but in practice, the differences between the sung and spoken are glaring - one is keenly aware that the voices just don't match up. Recorded sound is good, better than I remember from the initial CD release. There are better Carmens available, but no one buying this set is buying it based on the strength of the included Carmen.Lehar: Karajan's recording of "Die lustige Witwe" is quite enjoyable, a reminder that he was usually very successful when he ventured into the lighter fare. While many prefer Schwarzkopf's Hanna to that of Harwood, I'm not in that crowd (the best onstage Hanna I ever had the pleasure of hearing was sung by Mary Costa). Karajan utilizes a cast that looks odd on paper but works in practice. I have slight grievances with Kollo and Hollweg in the tenor leads, but they still do quite well. The orchestral playing is gorgeous and the interpretation - while not dripping with nostalgia - is excellent. The second CD in the set is filled out with a selection of Suppé overtures. Remastered sound is excellent.Leoncavallo/Mascagni: The La Scala-based "Cav-Pag" is a classic, with really great performances from the lead singers. I used to find the Cav a bit on the low energy side, but now I hear it as a beautiful rendition of music that too often takes on the countrified persona of the chorus of villagers. I owned these recordings in their LP and early CD versions, and the sound on this OIBP version is really good - it enhances what were already recommended performances.Mozart: The above-mentioned "Le nozze di Figaro" comes up very well in whatever mastering has been included in this box. Getting reacquainted with this recording after not hearing it in probably 20+ years was a satisfying experience. I like José van Dam's Figaro more this time around while I am less enamored of Frederica von Stade's Cherubino and Ileana Cotrubas' Susanna, while Anna Tomowa-Sintow's Countess isn't the equal of other singers in this role. Still, less enamored doesn't equal displeasure - the cast overall is excellent.Don Giovanni is an opera that I have been trying to find enjoyable for 45 years...and it isn't happening. I've performed in it a couple of times and have heard just about every recording, and I still run screaming from the encounter. So, I'm probably not the best person to comment on the included recording, but I will. Orchestra and interpretation are good as is the cast, save for the insufferable Kathleen Battle's mouse-sized voice singing Zerlina. Inexpressive and monochromatic at best, her voice and her overly precious singing doesn't fare well set against the remainder of the cast. Ramey is a good Don if not in the Siepi class, while Baltsa and Tomowa-Sintow are enjoyable if not competitive with legendary singers who have taken these roles. Sound is clear and colorful. If Don G is your cup of tea, you'll probably enjoy this.Mussorgsky: Karajan was a champion of the Rimsky-Korsakov version of Boris Godunov, and that's the version presented in the fabulous Decca recording included in this set. Personally, I'm also a Rimsky man when it comes to Boris. I know all the arguments against it and I really don't care - no other version engages and moves me as does Rimsky's. The performance itself is incredibly well performed - strong, direct and of a massive scale. Ghiaurov's Boris is a tour-de-force, and he is in particularly excellent voice here. The entire cast is first rate, strong and idiomatic. The choral sound produced by the combined Sofia and Vienna Staatsoper choirs is overwhelming, while the Vienna Phil plays magnificently, with outstanding work from the brass and woodwinds. Karajan has the full measure of this piece and delivers what I consider to be a near-definitive all-around version. The recorded sound is of demonstration quality, and the remaster has removed any hint of hiss from the analog masters. This recording is one of the highlights of this set. Indeed, it's a highlight of Karajan's entire recorded operatic oeuvre. Highly recommended.Puccini: The 1972 Decca "La bohéme" was a classic upon its release and remains so to this day. Mirella Freni and Luciano Pavarotti are both in tip-top form, pouring out streams of golden Italianate tone that is completely satisfying on its own. Yet that tone is coupled to interpretations that are moving and individual. The stars - both earthly and heavenly - were aligned when this gem was set down. The overall cast is excellent, though one might quibble with Harwood's Musetta. The orchestra is tremendous (even considering the rather blatant clam in the trumpets in the penultimate bars of Act 2), while Karajan fully captures the emotional gamut that this opera runs in its relatively short time frame. The recorded sound captured at the Jesus Christus Kirche in Berlin is of demonstration quality. Recommended on every level imaginable.Karajan followed up his Bohéme recording with Madame Butterfly, set down in 1974 with Freni and Pavarotti again appearing in the lead roles. Luxury casting extends to the use of the Vienna Philharmonic and the inclusion of Christa Ludwig's Suzuki, which is finely drawn and wonderfully sung. I do feel that Pavarotti sometimes verges on the edge of lapsing into a croon, but he never really steps over the line. His Pinkerton isn't the usually boisterous, obnoxious American, but is perhaps a more innocent take on the character. At least it's a multifaceted performance, even if one never finds themselves in real sympathy with the character. Mirella Freni is the sweetest Butterfly on disc, and I must say that I prefer this recording to her later DG remake with Sinopoli: what she gains in drama under Sinopoli she loses in the little-girl innocence she displayed under Karajan. I count this Decca recording as my desert island version of the opera. I would note that after years of gouging consumers by spreading this recording over 3 full-priced CDs, DG/Decca have somehow found a way to fit the thing on 2 CDs for inclusion in this multi-CD set. Recorded sound is once again of demonstration quality.Karajan's DG "Tosca" is an analogue recording from 1979. The sound is quite phenomenal, though the performance isn't the norm, featuring two romantic protagonists in José Carerras and Katia Ricciarelli who sing beautifully but whose voices are a bit on the light side. I have a hard time imagining this particular Cavaradossi being any kind of a revolutionary, just as I have a difficult time believing that this Tosca had it in her to commit murder, even as an act of total spontaneity. I will say that I enjoyed Ruggerro Raimondi's Scarpia - chalk it up to old age, as I rather disliked his performance when I first heard it on LPs.The digital recording of "Turandot" dates from 1981, and while it features a good interpretation and great playing and singing from the Vienna Phil and the Stattsopernchor, it is generally let down by the leads, none of whom can match the performances available elsewhere. Katia Ricciarelli's assumption of the title role was widely and justly criticized when the recording was released, and it hasn't been helped in this new issue. Sad, because this recording was set down only two years after the above-mentioned Tosca, and while the voice is still pretty to listen to in the middle range, the high range is now a mess. It's almost like she sings one way in the middle voice and then allows her larynx to ride high in her throat to reach the high notes. Nilsson she's not. Domingo's Calaf also suffers when compared to the great exponents of this role. His voice is under tremendous pressure most of the time, especially in the high range in which he sounds very uncomfortable, bulling his way through passages that others sing with power and finesse. No one will hold it against you when you find yourself pulling down recordings by Merli, Corelli, Pavarotti or Bjoerling as a corrective to the Domingo Calaf. Hendricks' Liu is too light by half, and that greatly limits her ability to express this role the way it is usually sung, where the artist singing Liu often walks away with the vocal honors for the evening (i.e.: a finely spun high pianissimo delivered by a voice of some vocal heft is always going to be more impressive than the same pianissimo effect delivered by a smallish voice, if for no other reason that there's more dynamic variation between the singer's basic vocal sound and the pianissimo in the larger voice). This is definitely an example of a recording where the "orchestra as protagonist" approach to opera has diminishing returns. Sound is very good, if ultimately lacking the clarity and color of the Mehta version on Decca.Verdi: Karajan's second studio recording of Falstaff was recorded by DG, but released on the Philips label at the time so as not to compete with Giulini's DG recording that was released at the same time. A few decades later (after the Philips label ceased to exist), the recording reverted to and was released on DG at full price, with later midline issues on Decca. For this issue, DG has utilized the original Philips art work and branding for the CD sleeve while using the DG look for the CDs themselves. Overall, the performance is excellent, with real star turns by veterans Giuseppe Taddei and Rolando Panerai in the key male roles, with Christa Ludwig, Raina Kabaivanska and Trudeliese Schmidt as Quickly, Alice & Meg, respectively. While all of these veterans' voices had seen better years by the time the recording was set down, the experience and entertainment value they bring is palpable. The young lovers are taken by Francisco Araiza and Janet Perry, with mixed results. Araiza engages in quite a bit of off-the-voice crooning that's uncharacteristic of his normal vocal approach, while Ms Perry's extremely small voice has nowhere to go in either direction to make a dynamic point. No, one needs to listen to a singer with a wealthier voice - like Anna Moffo in Karajan's first recording - to get the full effect of what a role like Nannetta offers the singer. The orchestra and Karajan's interpretation are top drawer - powerful when needed, funny and intimate when required. It's a real mystery why this opera - Verdi's ultimate - isn't more well-known and -loved among the general public."Il trovatore" is the famous live recording from Salzburg in 1962. Most vocal aficionados place this performance near the top of the heap, despite the just-OK mono sound. To my ears, the performance has a rough first act, with Zaccaria nearly coming apart in Ferrando's opening aria. Price starts off a bit off-center, but gains her footing by the Act 1 trio. Corelli gains strength through the performance as well. Bastianini struggles through "il balen," but also improves as the show moves along. I have always felt that Simionata had an off night as Azucena. The Chorus of the Vienna Staatsoper and the Vienna Phil give us an Austrian version of Verdi, which is to say it's not the most idiomatic Verdi you'll ever hear. Karajan plays things rather straight, though there are a lot of coordination problems between the stage and the pit. Acts 3 & 4 fare best overall. Nice to have this included, but not a first, second or even third choice in my books.Wagner: Karajan's "Ring" has been my go-to version for decades. While it doesn't feature an unassailable cast (which Ring does?), it has enough great singing in it to satisfy most vocal aficionados while the interpretation and orchestral execution are the thing of legend. This is a Ring that surprises in both its nuance and - on occasion - bravura. The sound is quite good - better than it ever was on LP or the initial CD release - if not in the Decca class. Comparing the Act I "Die Walkure" in this set to the previously issued DG Originals version revealed no discernible difference in the sound, at least to my ears. Having recently purchased the fabled Solti Ring on BluRay audio disc, I would hope that Universal gives the same treatment to Karajan's Ring in the near future.All things considered, this is a nice conclusion to the series.

Either my ears are shot or the majority of the amazon reviewers of this recording are hearing things I'm not, or maybe things they're imagining they're hearing.As others have noted, the recorded sound on this disc is mediocre, at best, with no sense of depth and an overall flat sound to the proceedings. Considering this is the Vienna Philharmonic one would hope for something much better.But the real problem with the recording is Boulez's way with the music, which lumps into long stretches of ennui punctuated by the occasional highlighting of interesting detail. The third movement suffers the worst, starting off with a way-too-exacting reading of the opening rhythm in the strings. Compare to Karajan (in any of his recordings) who treats the opening bars with great nuance and subtlety, allowing space for the rhythm to grow and grow until it is being hammered out in the orchestra leading into the first mini-climax of the movement. It's the difference between imagination and the perfunctory delineation of notes and rhythms.As with many Boulez recordings on DG, the sound is shallow and unattractive, and one wonders who is making the decision to present such sound to the consumer.I happen to love Boulez in certain late-Romantic works: Gurre-lieder, Debussy's Pelleas, and the orchestral music of Ravel & Debussy. I know he has it in him to present an echt-Romantic view of music when he so desires. Sadly, that desire is no where to be found on this release.Of course, others are tripping over themselves singing this recording's praises. Go figure.Boulez is a great musician and conductor. The Vienna Phil has this music in their blood. DG has made some great sounding recordings over the decades. But believing that the magical brew is alive and well on this release is a case of The Emperor's New Clothes.Look elsewhere for Brucknerian greatness (try Vienna/Karajan on DG or Berlin/Maazel on EMI/Warner).

This CD of Schubert and Schumann lieder (recorded in 1965 & 67, respectively) has become something of a classic among classical music fans, whether they are vocal aficionados or not, and for good reason. It's an excellent program that includes many of the best-known songs by both composers, not to mention a near-definitive recording of Schubert's "The Shepherd on the Rock."The program starts off with "The Shepherd," with Ameling joined by Jörg Demus on the Hammerflügel, with Hans Deinzer on clarinet. Ameling's deceptively easy vocalism sails through the piece, capturing each mood with nuance and subtlety. Her diction is excellent throughout and not overdone. Other Schubert favorites included are "Gretchen am Spinnrad," "Seligkeit," Im Frühling" and "Der Musensohn." 19 of the CD's 28 tracks are dedicated to Schumann and include "Widmung," Der Nussbaum" and "Der Sandmann."The CD mastering from 1989 still holds up quite well, with a minimum of hiss and compression from the analog source material. It should be noted that the various tracks are sourced from different recording venues, with varying acoustics and different pianos. It's not bothersome, but it is noticeable.German texts and English translations are supplied, though not in a side-by-side layout. Program notes in German, English, French & Italian.Highly recommended

As much as I like Bernstein in Mahler and Beethoven, I really dislike his way with Sibelius.That's an opinion that I formed early on in my journey with classical music, back in the days of the LP, in fact. Now that I think about it, I probably have not heard these recordings since they made their first appearance on CD. But being one who is always open to reevaluating my position on music and/or musicians, this newly remastered version of Bernstein's Sibelius cycle provided an opportunity to look anew at one of my favorite composers seen through the eyes of one of my favorite conductors.Alas, I'm left with my existing feelings well intact - Bernstein just doesn't "get it" when it comes to the Sibelian ethos. His Sibelius is hyperactive, goosed and boosted beyond the point of excitement into the realm of the ridiculous. Such an approach - which, truth be told, is fairly one-dimensional - tends to make the music sound much less interesting and less deep than it actually is. Sure, there are those always interesting "Lenny" moments where the conductor elevates a secondary or tertiary voice to "I hadn't noticed that before" prominence, but doing so doesn't add anything to one's appreciation or understanding of the music, especially when a byproduct is that the true leading voice gets buried. Elevating Sibelius' ostinato motor rhythms to prominence makes as much sense as would elevating an Alberti bass to prominence in a classical sonata.The First and Second Symphonies suffer the most from this approach, with both pieces coming off as strangely inconsequential compositions (his DG remakes are far, far superior). The Third rather hangs fire most of the time, with the closing bars ending in a most-perfunctory manner. The Fourth is so far off course from the norm that one might be taken in by the prospect, but the almost-always forte dynamic approach causes the various choirs of the orchestra to play at a heightened dynamic level for their parts to cut through the din, and this results in a tonal quality that misses the composer's intent. There is no mystery here, no sense of anything lying beneath the notes themselves.The Fifth fares a little better (as does Pohoja's Daughter), but it is let down by a bland final movement, with the final disconnected chords despatched in the tritest of manners. The Sixth is an uncommitted affair that comes off as a read through, rather than a performance, with a finale that is a not-always-successful scramble for notes and ensemble at a speed that's too fast by half. The Seventh starts out promisingly enough, but Bernstein then elects to goose up the tempi and the dynamics to the extent that this 4-movement-symphony-in-1-movement loses all sense of being a unique direction for the composer. Somehow, Bernstein makes it sound...common.The performance of the Violin Concerto is another overheated, square, monochromatic and ultimately off-putting affair. I invite you to compare this version to the Ferras/Karajan version on DG to hear what is missing in Bernstein's approach. It's night and day. We get something of a bonus in the way of Bruch #1 being coupled on this CD (conducted by Thomas Schippers) - not the greatest performance, but a superior performance to its Sibelius disc mate.The final CD in the set is a "Great Performances" disc of Grieg Peer Gynt Suites 1 & 2 and Sibelius' Finlandia, The Swan of Tuonela and Valse triste. Again, it's hard to feel that Bernstein has any real affinity for these pieces. He just doesn't trust them to work on their own merits and seems to feel compelled to pick and pull them into something that he can relate to. Compare his Grieg to Beecham or Karajan and you'll see what I mean.For the sake of completeness, I'd mention that the set also includes Luonnotar (coupled with the 1st Symphony), featuring soprano Phyllis Curtin. Having had master classes with Ms Curtin back in 1974-75, I don't want to be too harsh with her, but her performance misses the other-wordly quality evoked by other sopranos like Karita Mattila and Soile Isokoski, whose voices have an easier top range and who can at least disguise the effort necessary to sing this piece.I can't express how disappointed I was with this set, due entirely to Bernstein's interpretation (the re-done sound is excellent, while the playing of the NYPO is top notch, save for a few blemishes here and there). Compared to Sibelius masters like Herbert von Karajan and Lorin Maazel (try his Pittsburgh set, also on Sony at about HALF the price of this one) who find layer after layer of interest and nuance in this music, Bernstein hardly qualifies as the Sibelian country cousin. Sibelius' music operates on many levels, and it's very odd that a musician of Bernstein's stature seems to be blind and deaf to most of those levels. This is Sibelius taken not on the composer's terms, but on those of the conductor.As there are many great Sibelius options out there these days at every conceivable price point, I find myself unable to recommend this version on any level. Indeed, I would even recommend Sir Colin Davis' just-reissued RCA cycle above this - it features sound and interpretations that are superior to the set under review - even though I found myself calling that set uncompetitive in an amazon review I penned just a few months ago.I wish I could be more enthusiastic, but I can't.Two and a half stars - it's okay...barely.

The nice thing about this power strip is that of the 12 standard AC outlets available, 6 run along the sides of the unit (as one can see in the product image), allowing enough space between each outlet to plug in the kind of oversized power cord head that seems to be a feature of much AV equipment these days. On most strips, you have only the option of plugging such a head into the end outlet, and even then it often covers part of the outlet above it, making that outlet unusable. With this unit you can actually avail yourself of all twelve outlets.Recommended, even at the price, which is a bit high for what a typical power strip goes for these days.

This is a very utile storage unit. I got it for my son who needed to organize his multiple game consoles into something other than complete chaos. This unit is nice because the shelves have more space to hold the larger game consoles than is usually the case.That said, it was a bit of a challenge to assemble this unit as the instructions contain few if any words. It's all pictures, and sometimes an arrow pointing this way or that way isn't enough to give a clear indication of what needs to be done in the correct sequence. Getting the middle glass shelf installed - one of the final steps in assembly - was a bit of a PITA.No matter, we got it done in less than an hour, and it's doing the job with style.

I went for the "book" version of this BluRay, even though it ran a few dollars more than the standard BD packaging. Very nice!This movie isn't as well known as other Wayne oaters like Rio Bravo or El Dorado, and it doesn't possess the magic of those films either. In fact, it can seem a bit meandering when compared to other top-drawer Wayne fare. But no one bats a thousand and being a B-level success as opposed to being an A level success is often a case of splitting hairs in the eye of the beholder.I can still recommend this movie, especially if it's not familiar to you. It is entertaining. The BD production is very good as well.

If you have room for but a single lieder recording in your collection, this is the disc to own, for it captures the unique and magnificent voice of tenor Fritz Wunderlich to perfection.Now, granted, the piano playing isn't the most-imaginative, and Wunderlich himself interpretively surpassed this studio effort of Dichterliebe in his live performance at Edinburgh in 1966 (captured on a MYTO CD), but all things considered, one couldn't hope for a more-sensitive approach to this repertoire, performed by one of the most-gorgeous voices to have ever been recorded, any time, anywhere.Highest recommendation.

This film was long unavailable to the public, so it's nice to have it issued on a very good BD transfer.The story of the film's being shot in 3D and 2D, its very short-lived and limited release in 3D theaters and its subsequent absence from the film canon makes this issue particularly welcome. Sound and video are both excellent, with lots of detail in the picture and very clean dialogue on the soundtrack. 5 stars for the excellent extra features that are included on the disc.I recommend reading the various reviews at BluRay.com, which provide a good overview of the film and its history.Recommended.

No need to review the story of this well-known classic -I'll limit my comments to the BD presentation.First off, I had trouble booting this BD in two of my BD players. Both produced a black screen after I hit the play button. I did a thorough cleaning of the disc with a lens wipe, and that did something because the BD then played flawlessly. So, I saved myself a return/exchange that I didn't need to make.The movie comes up well in its BD guise, with sound and visual acceptable if not a huge improvement from the DVD version. As this film gets aired on TV somewhere at least once a month, you may not feel the need to own this on BD.Recommended if you're a Wayne fan or a collector.

My son got me this set as a Fathers Day gift. A good choice as it's not something I would buy for myself!I'm a musician but not an organist. My brother, however, was an organ major and often featured "God with us" from The Nativity as one of his concert showpieces, and being a church singer for many years, I heard quite a bit of Messiaen.That said, I was never fortunate enough to hear Messiaen on an instrument that is the magnitude of that at Notre Dame! The instrument is tremendous - colorful, powerful and clean. Latry has both the technique and the imagination required to show this music in its best light. And DG's recording is superlative, with just the right balance of clarity and reverb. And I thought Notre Dame was a tough space in which to record.My not-an-organist opinion? Buy this set. It really is unique, and uniquely well done.

These mostly excellent, late-1970s performances of Beethoven's two masses would make a fine addition to any music collection. Strange that I never encountered them in their earlier guise on LP (or CD, either).Special notice goes to tenor Robert Tear, who sings really well in both works, especially the D Major. I've not always been a fan of his singing, which can tend to get stuck in his throat, with too many glottal attacks used to start phrases and to enter the high range. But here, he sounds very conventional in the best sense of the word (perhaps because neither work calls for the solo tenor to scale the high range. That's left up to the poor tenors in the chorus!).Over all, I prefer Sir Colin's later remake of the MS on RCA, which features a better chorus and soloists and a more-flattering acoustic, not to mention digital sound that is pretty much state of the art.Still, for the price - recommended.

Rio Bravo is simply one of the best-crafted Westerns one will ever encounter, and that's taking into consideration that the story line provides a bare minimum on which to hang the entire film.Director Howard Hanks has the full measure of the genre and his incredible cast, who to a person provide high entertainment value. Can one really blame him for remaking this film as "El Dorado" a few years later (and pulling off perfection yet AGAIN in the process!)?As much as John Wayne is great in "Quiet Man" and "The Searchers," he's really enjoyable here, with his easy and audience-inviting manner of "reacting" more than acting. Dean Martin is superb, as is Angie Dickenson, who defines what it means to be quietly smoldering. Yowza!Rio Bravo is one of those films you can watch over and over again and never tire of. The BluRay transfer is excellent, with special mention to the soundtrack also being cleaned up and improved.A note on the pricing: after being unavailable domestically for a few years - and with third-party sellers asking ridiculous prices - the BluRay of Rio Bravo was re-released in the USA on June 2, 2015, and is now available from Amazon for under $10.Highly recommended.
They do the job and the price is incredibly low. I used these to connect my wireless cable box to my stereo set-up, which sits about 12 feet away. Worked like a charm.

Excellent product that fit the bill at our new digs, where my BluRay player sits quite a ways away from my flat screen TV. It's a heavy duty cable that's nicely and loosely wrapped in a coil. The right-angle adapter came in handy in securing the cable to the back of my wall-mounted flat screen TV. I'd also mention that the cable comes with a separate keychain flashlight that my son grabbed for his use.Note: I am experiencing audio drop outs on my TV set speakers using these long cable runs. The video is fine, but the audio will roll off and come back intermittently. And, the problem doesn't arise on all chapters on a specific BluRay - the extras may play just fine, but the main show has the problem. Weird. A friend of mine who is an audio techie says it's a common problem with long HDMI cable runs. Fortunately, there are no problems with the audio feed going from my Panasonic BD player to my pre-amp (using a 3-foot RCA cable), so I can mitigate the drop out problem by simply using my stereo set up for audio playback and turning off the speakers on my TV. I mention this as a caveat if you are thinking of buying this 50-foot cable.Still, recommended.

Those reviewers who call "The Conquerer" one of the worst movies ever have apparently not seen critically acclaimed stinkers like "Ordinary People" and "Little Miss Sunshine." I mention those two over-rated snoozers because 1. the acting and direction in OP is a lot worse than that in "Conquerer," and 2. the story and characters in LMS are a lot more far-fetched than those in "Conquerer."This is a typical epic film from the 1950s. It features a great all-around cast that does what great casts did back then - deliver a movie at a level that showcased their talent and professionalism. Most of the main characters in this film are taken by well-known and talented actors. It's not like they all suddenly forgot what they were doing. They put their talents to work and it shows.Sure, John Wayne sounds like John Wayne, but wouldn't it be worse if he tried to be something he never was? Do we expect actors to learn a Mongolian accent to speak English dialogue? That would be a lot more farcical than what we have here: a star delivering a star performance that his fans would enjoy. All of the actors adopt a "white man come, big trouble" way of delivering their lines. That's just the way it was in the 1950s, a convention accepted as readily as Nazi officers in movies speaking with a British accent. White people playing Mongols? Well, white people played everybody back in the day.The battle scenes are effective and more-realistic than the norm for the time. The musical score by Victor Young is really delightful, a mixture of quasi-Borodin and Rimsky-Korsakov, with a "love theme" that's quite appealing.Is the story historically accurate? No. Guess what? It's Hollywood.Give this movie a chance, preferably by viewing it uninterrupted on DVD with the sound piped through your stereo set-up. You might be pleasantly surprised.I'll be watching this movie a lot more than I will modern movies with historic/mythical story lines like Kevin Kostner's "Robin Hood" and Mel Gibson's "Braveheart." At least "The Conquerer" does its Hollywood era proud in a way that those updated versions never will."Jet Pilot" was entirely unknown to me. It's pretty standard stuff, except that Janet Leigh gets to light up the screen with her beauty and presence.I plan on reviewing Disc 1 in this set at a later date.Recommended.

Those reviewers who call this one of the worst movies ever have apparently not seen critically acclaimed stinkers like "Ordinary People" and "Little Miss Sunshine." I mention those two over-rated snoozers because 1. the acting and direction in OP is a lot worse than that in "Conquerer," and 2. the story and characters in LMS are a lot more far-fetched than those in "Conquerer."This is a typical epic film from the 1950s. It features a great all-around cast that does what great casts did back then - deliver a movie at a level that showed their talent and professionalism. They put their talents to work and it shows.Sure, John Wayne sounds like John Wayne, but wouldn't it be worse if he tried to be something he never was? Do we expect actors to learn a Mongolian accent to speak English dialogue? That would be a lot more farcical than what we have here: a star delivering a star performance that his fans would enjoy. All of the actors adopt a "white man come, big trouble" way of delivering their lines. That's just the way it was in the 1950s, a convention accepted as readily as Nazi officers in movies speaking with a British accent. White people playing Mongols? Well, white people played everybody back in the day.The battle scenes are effective and more-realistic than the norm for the time. The musical score by Victor Young is really delightful, a mixture of quasi-Borodin and Rimsky-Korsakov, with a "love theme" that's quite appealing.Is the story historically accurate? No. Guess what? It's Hollywood.Give this movie a chance, preferably by viewing it uninterrupted on DVD with the sound piped through your stereo set-up. You might be pleasantly surprised.I'll be watching this movie a lot more than I will modern movies with historic/mythical story lines like Kevin Kostner's "Robin Hood" and Mel Gibson's "Braveheart." At least "The Conquerer" does its Hollywood era proud in a way that those updated versions never will.Recommended.

Sorry to be the bearer of VERY bad news, friends, but I am obliged to report that the 2014 remaster of these EMI recordings by Warner is quite decent on three of the discs, while an absolute disaster on the fourth (it's especially painful as I make this report on the 25th anniversary to the day that Karajan was lost to the ages).That fourth disc is CD #3 in the set, which contains Symphonies 4 & 5. I know these recordings very, very well. I have owned the 4th & 5th Symphonies in this set on Angel USA LPs and cassettes, British and German EMI LPs, the initial EMI "Studio" CDs and finally, the remaster that EMI did for their 2008 Complete Karajan box set, which I assume was the same master that graced their 2-CD Double Forte issue, which I also owned. All of these versions presented the sound of the Berlin Philharmonic under Karajan as I remembered from my encounters with them at Carnegie Hall: warm, blended, colorful, with the ability to crescendo to incredible fortissimos without the sound ever gaining an unpleasant and unnecessary "edge."I ordered this Warner set with the expectation that the sound would basically stay about the same as always, with maybe a slight uptick in the clarity of the inner voices, a smidgen more hall ambience and maybe a little more lifelike quality in the instrumental color.That isn't what we've got here when it comes to the 4th and 5th Symphonies.What we've got is a reimagining of these recordings that would have probably driven Karajan apoplexic. The basic warm and atmospheric quality of these analogue recordings has been jettisoned for an edgy and LOUD presentation that bears no resemblance to the way these recordings always sounded on EMI, and even less resemblance to the way these artists sounded in the concert hall. It's as if the engineers have decided that, "people think Karajan's recordings are mushy, right? We'll fix that! We'll boost the volume and increase the high partials so every strand of the recording sticks out like a HIP enthusiast's wet dream! We can do it! Now, turn those knobs and dials!!!"Now, there's an easy fix for what Warner hath wrought: cut your treble gain by about 25% and maybe reduce the volume level while you're at it. With these corrections the CD sounded more like what I remember from its earlier EMI incarnations.The other three discs in the set are fine. The digital recordings included - Symphonies 1, 2 & 6, along with the Karelia Suite and Valse triste - sound about how they did in earlier issues. Maybe there's a bit more clarity to be had, but things are basically the same. The rest of the recordings - En saga, Finlandia, Tapiola and The Swan of Tuonela - feature good, remastered analogue sound, though I found that boosting my volume control brought an unwelcome edge to the sound that wasn't there in any of the earlier EMI versions. Warner offers no indication anywhere as to what recordings in this set are digital and which are analogue, a rather curious omission, to say the least.BTW - I see that Warner is planning on releasing all of these CDs as singles, utilizing the original LP artwork and bearing a sticker price of $26 PER CD (I assume these are SACDs)! I can only imagine what this means: "here, folks. We've done yet ANOTHER remaster that is better than our budget-issue. Cough up even MORE cash and enjoy!" Who knows? Maybe they'll take this opportunity to revisit their remaster of 4 & 5.These 5-star performances get knocked down to 3.5 stars for the botched sound offered on Syms 4 & 5 in this Warner set, even though one can enjoy even that particular CD if one does what I did and cuts their treble gain significantly - and maybe fiddles around with god-knows-what-else on their pre-amp.Coulda been a 5-star review, but you can't botch two MAJOR pieces in a set like this and expect not to be called on it. Enterprising listeners would do well to seek out the earlier EMI CD issues of these recordings.

These recordings are excellent representations of the Abbado way with music. Everything is alive and beautifully played with details registering as needed. What's missing is that final sense of passion - granted, maybe an all-too-obvious passion, at that - that sets off the greatest cycles from the merely great.I would place this cycle behind Ormandy on Sony - also available at a budget price - and Karajan on DG, though Karajan's cycle must be heard in the latest OIBP mastering for best effect, and that's presently available only in the expensive "Karajan 1970s" box set. If you can afford or need only one Tchaikovsky cycle, then go with the Ormandy.That said, there are many fine options out there, including Muti and Maazel. But for the under-$20 asking price, this Abbado set should be a strong contender.Recommended.

Here's yet another Bach Guild Big Box that's worth acquiring.The "Messiah" recording included is one of my favorites, featuring a great group of soloists, an excellent chorus and orchestra and a mainstream interpretation from Johannes Somary.The other Somary-led performances included are self-recommending: I well remember the stir they caused when they were first released on Vanguard LPs back in the '70s.Particular note goes to tenor Alexander Young, who features prominently in Messiah, Jeptha, Judas Maccabaeus and Theodora, and who was - with Richard Lewis - the premiere Handel tenor of the mid-to-late 20th century.Great music, unbelievable price.Highly recommended.

Last year, my son got me the Criterion BD of "Charade" for Father's Day. This year, it was this BD of "Foreign Correspondent."My son has good taste.There's no need to review the film itself, which I consider to be a classic, and not just a Hitchcock classic. I'll reserve my remarks for the BD transfer, which is excellent, including the soundtrack, which is very clean and lifelike.The extras included are also very engaging and do enhance one's viewing.Highly recommended.

This 28-CD set effectively presents Sir Neville Marriner's Argo label recordings - from his very earliest recordings, through the onset of the digital age - and serves as a nice remembrance of a man who turned 90 in April. Not being a Marriner aficionado, I have no idea what percentage of his entire Argo discography is represented by these 28 discs, but I would guess that it's substantial.The packaging is simple and sturdy. The outer box lifts off from the top, exposing a weighty paper box that houses the CDs. Every CD is presented in its original LP sleeve, though the discs themselves do not sport that unique shade of green that served as background to Argo LP labels, nor are the CDs given the now-ubiquitous LP surface look. It's nice to once again see the unassuming cover designs that graced Marriner's Argo LPs. A few pieces from shorter albums have been grafted on to some CDs to take advantage of CD playing lengths. Unfortunately, the original liner notes that featured on the back of the LP sleeves are missing, replaced with the most-rudimentary of track listings.The CD booklet includes all of the dates and recording venues for each CD, which is nice. A short article on Marriner and the ASMF appears in the back pages of the booklet.Included as "bonus" discs are Marriner's 1962 recordings made for the L'oiseau-Lyre label, along with three ASV (Academy Sound and Vision) productions that - I assume - were planned for release on Argo until Decca finally put the Argo imprimatur to rest: Weber Symphonies, "The French Connection" and "The English Connection."Edit: 7/3/14: I've now listened to the entire set, and I'm happy to report that the sound is fairly spectacular - open, colorful, well-blended and direct. Disc 6 contains the famous Four Seasons recording - very nice to hear this again after maybe 20 years. It really is excellent, as is the recording of Vivaldi's "La Stravaganza."I can recommend this wholeheartedly, holding back one star for the lack of liner notes and the non-complete nature of the set.

Let me say straight out that the Bach recordings of John Eliot Gardiner are absolute anathema to my musical sensibilities, and that I find 90% of HIP performances of Baroque choral music to be wimpy, neutered and irritating beyond belief. Overwrought speed and faceless singing have nothing to do with Baroque style - or ANY style - IMHO.When it comes to Bach's B Minor, it gets even worse. The only HIP recording I like out of the lot is Harnoncourt's first version  on Teldec. There's a lot of solo singing in the B Minor, and it better be good, because it's demanding. And the choruses are no slouch, either. The chorus better be damn good, because there's a lot of expressive music contained in this piece.Which brings us to Robert Shaw's masterful, Grammy-Award-winning, RCA Living Stereo version of the B Minor. It is - in a word - tremendous, and tremendous on every level. Soloists, great - check! Chorus, great - check! Orchestra is very, very good if not great, but it hardly matters. Shaw's interpretation? Distinctive, and about as unique as you could hope to find today in the cookie-cutter marketplace of HIP recordings of this piece. Shaw presents a point of view here. If you don't like it, it's your loss, not his.Make no doubt about it, this recording will engage your musical senses and leave you with a sense of fulfillment.I have to say that a number of my HIP-enjoying friends have had to admit that this recording bowled them over.I'd also mention that back in 1999, I offered this recording in the BMG Living Stereo packaging as a featured selection through the now-defunct Musical Heritage Society. We sold roughly 17,000 copies of this 2-CD set within the first 2 months of it being on sale. That at a time when retail sales of new releases by major classical artists were tallied in, at best, the high dozens. Not bad for selling a Bach mass to the masses, wouldn't you say?Very highly recommended.

American-born soprano Anna Moffo's (1932-2006) RCA recordings always fall easily on the ear. Her voice possessed a sexiness that matched her physical beauty (said physical beauty earned her the moniker "La Bellissima").This album is no exception, though the rep itself is something of a stretch for her vocally (and many of these selections were rarities of a sort when she set down this album in 1962). Moffo's lyric instrument didn't possess the long-breathed stamina nor the power of her spinto contemporaries Leontyne Price and Martina Arroyo. If you're familiar with those singers in these and other Verdi selections, you may find Moffo a bit limited in the expression, variety and depth that she can bring to this weightier repertoire. What she did possess, however, was a voice that brought you in as a listener and caressed you with a warmly feminine and non-stentorian sound, and that aspect of her art shines a very different light on these selections. No problem, as Verdi is a big boy and his music can easily stand up to a variety of approaches.The voice is enjoyable to listen to here, even if it's more naturally suited to Puccini and the lighter Verdi roles like Gilda and Violetta. While it's nice to hear Moffo singing arias from, say, Otello and Ernani, you won't find yourself wishing that she had recorded those operas in their entirety.Still, it's good to have this album back in the catalog in *its* entirety. Moffo's recording career spanned two decades, and this album was recorded when she was arguably at the height of her power and popularity. Her art is best heard in the Rome-based recordings of complete operas she made for RCA - Madama Butterfly, La Traviata, La boheme, Rigoletto, etc - which feature casts one would have heard at The Met back in the day.BTW - the whole "collaboration" thing with the conductor doesn't count for much at this late date. Most people who buy this album are going to be scratching their heads over that marketing ploy (ie: no one is buying this album for the conductor).Recommended.

I purchased this as a replacement for my daughter's Dell 1545 laptop. Last year, I bought a non-Dell version of this battery for under $15. Within a year, that battery was failing, and her laptop was giving her a "replace your battery" message.This Dell replacement - while costlier - works far better than did the off-brand. The charge is stronger and lasts a lot longer, and her computer seems to be running much smoother than it did with the old battery.Sometimes you just need to bite the bullet and plunk down the change. You get what you pay for.

Rene Leibowitz's fabled Beethoven Symphony cycle with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra makes a welcome reappearance as a costs-next-to-nothing MP3 download. Recorded in - I believe - 1961 for LP release on Reader's Digest, in recent decades the cycle has also appeared on CDs from Reader's Digest, Menuet, Scribendum and Chesky.This cycle is renown for the energetic playing of the orchestra, in large part because Leibowitz opts for fairly fast tempi in the Allegros and an overall objective approach when it comes to matters of rubato. The orchestral playing is very good, even if one can occasionally quibble with the sound coming from various choirs at various times (I'm not that enamored of the solo oboist, for example). There are also occasions of loose ensemble playing, some of it quite obvious. It's what you'd expect from a cycle that didn't have the benefit of multiple retakes.
