Whether these problems irritate over the long haul is an individual thing.It isn't at all a stretch to say that Leibowitz anticipates the HIP movement to a certain extent in these recordings, though the ghost of Toscanini hovers writ large over the proceedings, even though Leibowitz was a very vocal critic of Toscanini's approach to Beethoven.While Leibowitz is forward looking in his choice of tempi, he embraces the 1960s zeitgeist when it comes to matters of first-movement repeats - which is to say he's a bit cavalier in their observation, playing the first movement repeats only in symphonies 1, 5, 6 & 8, while ignoring the repeat in the Finale of the 5th. No big deal - such selective practice was the norm in performances and recordings at the time this set was committed to disc. Speaking of tempos, I can't say I'm a fan of Leibowitz's race through the instrumental *recitativo* in the Finale of the 9th. More "recitativo" and less "but in tempo" works better for me.I've been acquainted with these recordings since I purchased them on Reader's Digest stereo LPs back in 1970. They don't wear out their welcome, even if they ultimately sit just outside of any top ten list one might put together. Their main fault is that Leibowitz's objectivity tends to narrow the set's virtues - while its virtues are front-and-center and always enjoyable, repeat hearings don't necessarily reveal new layers of interest, as do, say, Toscanini's recordings. The Ninth is particularly enjoyable (*pace!* my comment above), featuring an excellent solo quartet (Inge Borkh, Ruth Stewart, Richard Lewis and Ludwig Weber) and chorus (Beecham Choral Society) who are well-balanced into the soundstage of the recording.The sound of the MP3 is very, very good, with a nice hall ambience that mirrors what I've heard on hard media over the decades. There are, however, a few glitches here and there that would probably cause one to exchange a CD for a new copy, had one paid CD prices for the recordings. At $1.09 for the entire cycle PLUS a whole lot more, it's easier to dismiss the glitches as incidental and unimportant distractions to one's basic listening pleasure: if you're listening to these while exercising, said glitches are no more distracting than that dog barking off in the distance.I highly recommend this download: 4 stars, holding back one star for the aforementioned glitches.BTW - if you find that you like this cycle so much that you want to own it on CD, I recommend going for the inexpensive "Menuet" versions. They seem to stay in the catalog, while others go oop and start costing an arm and a leg. I owned both the Menuet set AND the Chesky set at one time. When it came time to opt for one, I ended up keeping the Menuet version. I simply found it better overall than the Chesky. So, save your money and your valuable time: go for the Menuet versions. Better yet, bide your time - someone else is sure to reissue this set on CD at a budget price sometime in the near future.

I've had the fortune of hearing the Mahler 9th performed any number of times in the concert hall. My first experience was with Bernard Haitink conducting the Cleveland Orchestra at Severance Hall in the 1970s. My next time was hearing Karajan and the Berlin Phil at Carnegie Hall in 1981. I heard Maazel and Cleveland play it at Carnegie in 1982, and lastly, Dohnanyi and Cleveland at the NJPAC in Newark in the late 1990s. Each one of those performances were very special - similar in many respects, yet also individual and different.None of those performances featured the kind of histrionics found in Bernstein's various versions. All of them played the score *as music,* without a non-musical subtext hitting one over the head. I have to say that I rather like that approach, because if there's one thing Mahler DOESN'T need it's help goosing up the histrionics.This DG production is a very accurate reflection of the performance I heard at Carnegie Hall, though it was recorded in Berlin. The beauty of the orchestral playing is stunning, and the interpretation is unique and very satisfying. Unlike Bernstein and others, Karajan doesn't try to blow you away with every movement. He realizes that most symphonies have ONE main climax, and he builds to that climax. Karajan pays meticulous attention to the subtleties of Mahler's score, executing Mahler's myriad changes of dynamics and tempi with both nuance and high precision. As much as I like Bernstein in this piece, Karajan is more adept at giving us what Mahler actually wrote in the score, rather than overly personalizing the music. I'll say it again - the beauty of the orchestral sound is a highlight of this recording. Considering that this is a "live" recording, it's amazing to consider the confidence conductor and orchestra have in each other to play the way they do. And, I have to say that Karajan is more successful at pulling off the Second Movement than are others. It all sounds logical in his hands, possibly because - again - he takes a more-nuanced approach that is very respectful of Mahler's musical signposts.What really makes Karajan special in this piece is his treatment of the denouement that follows that climax. There's an inevitability about the Finale in this recording that provides the answer to the three movements that preceded said finale - those movements find their resolution in the finale, as it were. While I found the Finale of Karajan's analog studio recording of this piece quite good, I felt that other parts of that recording were less successful. No problem with that here.This is music making on a very, very high level, so I'm not surprised to read the many glowing reviews of this recording. Neither am I surprised to read the few negative reviews - some people just don't get it. Or, as pianist Israela Margelit once told me, most critics live mediocre lives, and they're most comfortable with the mediocre. They don't understand greatness any more than they understand the truly bad, so they see the great as it if were bad.This recording IS great. Ignore the naysayers and try the recording for yourself.Again, highly recommended.

Why on earth did Decca not include ALL of Blomstedt's San Francisco SO legacy in this box? He recorded the complete Sibelius & Nielsen Symphonies with the SFSO, and both are highly recommended and highly sought out sets. Yet, here we get only one-CD worth of each composer. It would have taken all of 5 more CDs to include the complete symphony cycles of both composers.And where's the Schubert 5 & 8 and Rosamunde? Where's Ein Heldenleben & Metamorphosen? Bruckner 6? Where's Also sprach, Till and T & V? The Sessions/Harbison CD? What about the other Hindemith disc (Noblissima Visione, Der Schwanendreher & Concert Music)? Am I missing anything? Hello, Decca. Anyone home? That's at least 6 more discs worth of Blomstedt/SFSO recordings that are missing from this box.Honestly, you wonder what people at the record labels are thinking these days. This set looks to be aimed at least in part at completists, yet it isn't complete. In fact, it contains about half of what was recorded by Decca in SF during Blomstedt's "San Francisco Years."Universal has no problem issuing complete sets of recordings by artists who recorded far more for them than did Blomstedt (Karajan & Bernstein, for example). Sure, they're more popular than Blomstedt, but isn't that the point? Why not make it a complete Blomstedt and have done with it?Lame. Another missed opportunity.

These recordings are of both historical and musical interest. How could they be otherwise? They're the first recordings of a man who 25 years after his death still evokes praise, scorn and indifference among music lovers.The performances have both the hallmarks of a young musician looking to make his interpretive mark on the world and the musical traits that came to be Karajan trademarks over the decades. A well-balanced, well-developed orchestral sound that was his own, coupled with interpretations that are mainstream. The youthful indulgences on display here - the occasional unwritten rallentando, the stretching of a rest to achieve clarity, etc - are just that, youthful. These are gestures that were eventually dropped from the Karajan ethos in favor of an approach that elevated the forest - rather than the trees - of musical interpretation.The sound is generally good, better than I expected, though the top end can become a bit shrill and the winds don't have the greatest presence.Seen with 20/20 hindsight, these recordings were the start of something big, that big being the eventual career that Karajan carved out for himself. Would that career have happened were these recordings all one had to go on in determining musical value and interest? No. Would that something big have happened had EMI not promoted Karajan so heavily in the 1950s? No. Still, when viewed through the prism of today, these recordings do display traits that one can see as being echt-Karajan, even at these early dates. And, they are highly musical performances that can be enjoyed without the need to toss about the caveats one often sees when discussing performances from early in a musician's career.Ultimately, this is a set for Karajan fans only. And even that's a stretch - I'm a pretty big fan, and even I didn't bother picking up this set until it dropped below $10 on amazon. For me, this set rounds out my near-complete Karajan collection. For most others, acquiring these recordings can hardly be a priority.Recommended for fans.

No doubt about it, this is a once-in-a-lifetime performance of the 9th.Yes, there are a lot of warts, big and small. Yes, the performance is highly indulgent, especially with the addition of those "sul ponticello" effects in the first movement. Yes, the trombones miss their big entry in the finale.Yet all things considered, this is a performance that demands to be heard at least once. Ignoring it amounts to one committing a serious sin of omission, of sustaining a self-inflicted musical wound, as it were.It may not be your way with Mahler or even Mahler's way with Mahler, but it's a committed performance of an interpretation straight out of the genius camp...or the looney bin, in equal parts. Take your pick.Definitely not a Mahler 9 to be listened to casually (is it ever?), and probably not the Mahler 9 you'll pull down from the shelf all that often, but a Mahler 9 that you'll feel better off for having heard.*The sound is slightly improved in this single-CD "Originals" remastering when compared to the 2-CD set issued back in 1992.Highly recommended.

The animation in this movie is great. The story is a bit formulaic, sort of what I've come to expect from Disney these days.I really didn't care for the songs nor the performances thereof. I can't see any of them being remembered two years from now.This was a gift for my daughter's 17th b'day. She liked it a lot, having seen it in the theater with her HS friends. I guess that's all that really matters.

I purchased the Sony RCA "Masters" libretto-less version of this Ring last year (ASIN: B006XOBFJC), the one that says on the back of the box that it was produced with a 24-bit process. I really liked the sound on that version, and I'm particularly fond of the bang-up job done by Ren Kollo as Siegfried. He's simply the best Siegfried available in any of the studio Rings.I have just purchased this Eurodisc/Sony "deluxe" version of the Ring, mainly because I found it elsewhere for $25, which is about what you'd pay to get the included Stewart Spencer English translation separately (bought it for the translation and packaging, got the music for free!). This presented me with an opportunity to A-B test the two versions to see if there was any difference in the sound.I did this by blind testing the versions against each other. I picked the "Dawn Duet & Rhine Journey" from Götterdämmerung as my test - about 10 minutes worth of music that goes from pianissimo to fortissimo and includes some singing as well. I sat down with my Dover score and listened to the selection straight through on one version, followed by the other version, not knowing which was which.The results? Well, the versions definitely sounded different to my ears. The second version I listened to had slightly greater clarity and a slightly more-open sound stage. The extended clarinet solos in the Dawn prelude sounded a hair more realistic in the second version. The instrumental color was more spot on. Compared to the second version, the first version seemed a bit cloudy. The second version also featured a slightly firmer bass end. I felt the voices were slightly forward-balanced in the first version, more integrated into the picture in the second version without losing any presence.Also - and this is important - there was absolutely no change in volume as I moved between the two discs. Often times when CDs are remastered the engineers transfer them at a slightly higher volume level which people then mistake as the disc having more presence or clarity, even though you can get the same effect by just turning up the volume on your old disc. At least I was able to remove that as a variable.Opening the carousel after listening, it turned out that the first version I heard was this Eurodisc version, the second was the RCA Masters version, the one with the 24-bit logo on the back of the box. The 24-bit version did sound slightly better.Does this mean anything? I don't know. I didn't expect to hear any difference at all between the two versions, both of which have a reissue (P)-date of 2012. But I definitely heard a slight difference. I've always assumed the 24-bit thing on the back of these Sony boxes is a marketing gimmick, ie: taking advantage of the fact that 24-bit mastering consoles are the norm in CD production these days, and promoting it like it means something. Only in this case, it seems to mean something.The key operating word here is "slightly."I'll need to spot check around the rest of the cycle to see if my evaluation holds up.My recommendation at this point would be to get the RCA Masters version if you want the best sound; get the Eurodisc version for the beautiful packaging and sound that is only slightly less good.On edit: 1/12/15 - AND...I now own THREE copies of this Janowski Ring, as it is included in the super-budget, 40-CD "Richard Wagner: Great Recordings" box Sony issued in February 2013. That set is going for UNDER $16 on amazon these days and represents the cheapest way to pick up this Janowski cycle. I haven't had time to audition those particular CDs, so I am assuming that the Eurodisc mastering is the one included there, as the covers to the included CDs are the Eurodisc versions.

This 4-DVD set offers 4 WWII movies whose naval-oriented subject matter is a bit off the beaten track."Sink the Bismarck!" is probably the best known out of the quartet, and it features good acting all-around, a compelling story and a nice musical score. Having Edward R. Murrow appear as himself reading radio updates from London is a very nice touch, and adds a sense of truth to the proceedings. B&W but shot in Cinemascope."The Frogmen" is a B&W movie I remember from my youth. A very young Richard Widmark has the lead role, with Dana Andrews and Jeffrey Hunter in secondary roles. It's the story of the Underwater Demolition Teams operating in the Pacific. This is a straight-forward action flick with little time spent on personality conflicts, outside of that between Widmark's character and the frogmen team - he's replacing their recently KIA leader. Aspect ratio is 4/3. Good stuff."The Enemy Below" is the only color movie in this set. It's a compelling cat-n-mouse picture that toes a familiar line: my enemy is just as smart if not smarter than me. A US Destroyer chases a German U-boat across the South Atlantic. By the end of the movie, both ships are ablaze and both crews are rescued and united in a mutual respect, proving that the men sent to fight wars and the peoples at war often have very different takes on the nitty gritty of war.I'm a bit embarrassed to report that I had never even heard of the Marlon Brando thriller "Morituri." In fact, this movie is the reason I purchased this set - I caught the movie about 1/4 of the way in on TMC last week and really liked the story and the telling. That inspired me to look for the film at amazon, and voila! here it is! Besides Brando's excellent portrayal of a German undercover agent working for the Brits to commandeer a shipment of rubber bound to Germany, the rest of the cast is top-drawer, including Wally Cox (aka the voice of the cartoon character "Underdog"), who makes a rare acting appearance as a German doctor. Yul  Brenner plays the ship captain, and the German roles in the cast are filled out by a number of actors who always seem to crop up in war films from this era, among them, Martin Kosleck, Eric Braeden and Hans Christian Blech, not to mention George Takei in a very early film role.There's really nothing in the way of extras on this discs outside of trailers.I purchased this DVD set firm in my assumption that none of these films is going to be released on BluRay any time soon.Recommended.

No need to review the movie itself - it's a classic.The HD transfer is spectacular, both visually and aurally. Crisp visuals and a cleaned-up soundtrack, with very little hiss or congestion for a mono track.There's also a nice group of bonus features included.Highly recommended.

This book is a very easy read and an excellent place to start one's journey if they are on the cusp of seeking to move away from a religionist's view of the world into a view based more upon reason and empirical evidence.It's important to recognize that Stenger has set out to "show" that god doesn't exist, not to "prove" god doesn't exist (a task that is really not achievable - one can't prove a negative, especially when that negative is an invisible supernatural being who may or may not reside in the reality we all deal with every day). It's a semantic difference, but an important one. To Stenger's credit, he is clear that this book is an exercise in arguing the non-existence of god from the "lack of evidence" perspective. Paraphrasing Donald Rumsfeld, Stenger avers that absence of evidence can be evidence of absence, at least in the case of god.Stenger creates a model to explore the god hypothesis, basing that model on the traits the major religions assign to their concept of what constitutes god (though let's be honest, Stenger's contact point to religion is 95% Christianity, with other religions given only fleeting reference). This has the advantage of eliminating the whack-a-mole debate one gets into with religionists/philosophers when their vision of god goes off the rails to include alien beings, the ultimate consciousness...or, The Force. Let's face it, when most people talk about THEIR god, they're talking about the god that was indoctrinated into them by one of the major religions when they were only children, not alien beings or The Force. Might as well keep the conversation where it belongs.Science doesn't usually deal in absolutes, and so it is with Stenger's subtitle: "how science shows god doesn't exist." What Stenger shows is that science has so reduced the need for the idea of god that god is basically hiding out in the gaps, if not already dead, awaiting his demise, holding on by his fingernails as the lack of empirical and even theoretical evidence reduce the chances of his existing to a statistical improbability. So, while one could say that science shows god doesn't exist based on Stenger's model, it doesn't show every possibility out there of what might be considered to be "god" doesn't exist. How could it?Best thing about this book? The scientists have thrown off Stephen Jay Gould's belief that religion and science are non-overlapping magesteria, and are finally claiming ground in the "why are we here?" argument.Recommended.

Disclaimer: I received a bag of these in exchange for my honest review. I do not 'reward' companies with positive reviews when I receive a free product. I am inserting this disclaimer because there has been a lot of hype about fake reviews lately, and some folks seem to think Vine Reviews are in this category. My reviews are all honest, whether I pay for a product or not.Review:Personally I loved these clusters. I love the crunch, and the flavor is fresh and light. I have had a lot of dried fruits, both the standard, and freeze dried. It appears some folks do not care for the texture of these. When fruits are freeze dried however, this is the texture you get. I happen to love it. When you bite into them, there is a burst of fruity crunchiness. If you chew them up pretty quickly, you get to experience that texture throughout. If you chew slowly and let them sit in your mouth for awhile, they become similar to cotton candy, as they sort of melt into a small soft fraction of the size they were. I like to eat them both ways. If I had to compare them to something a lot of people have tried, I'd say, Imagine the fruity pieces of Captain Crunch Berries, but fresher, lighter, and not so sickening sweet.Ingredient wise, they are simply made of raspberries, apples, fruit pectin, and apple juice. No preservatives, no artificial colors or flavors. They are not of course as healthy as whole fresh raspberries and apples, but then again they are not as unhealthy as the vast majority of other fruit snacks out there.I would have given five stars if the price was better. At the time of this review, eight bags will run you $29.96. That comes to approximately $3.75 per bag. There are 3 skimpy servings per bag. My husband and I ate the bag all in one sitting, and he could have easily eaten a couple of bags himself.In summary, I love the taste and texture of these little fruit bites. I have had a lot of freeze dried fruits, and although these aren't my all time favorite, they do rank highly. If they were a better price I would have given five stars. Because of the cost though, I will not buy them for myself and a star gets taken away.Personally I'd rather have a fresh piece of fruit, but for the 'convenience/snack' niche these are supposed to fill, I think they do a good job.

Just listened to this for the first time and I Love, Love, Love it! I saw that he was going to be singing it on tonight's episode of The Voice, but I just couldn't wait!I was a bit surprised because it's a bit more up tempo than a lot of his stuff. But there is no doubt who is singing the song. You get to hear that old-soul, bluesy style that is unmistakable Sawyer. One of my favorite things about this song (and others on the album) is that the sound of his voice comes through clearly. By that, I mean that the background music does not steal the show. as is often the case when producers get too excited about the bling. (Sorry producers, but this is a pet peeve of mine)...we don't want the voice to be a little part of what you hear, in the midst of all the clang/bang of background music. We want the voice to be the focus, especially when that voice is Sawyer's. And with this song you definitely get that!Bottom line, Sawyer clearly owns this song. I really hope it becomes a huge hit. I am looking forward to seeing him sing it live on the Voice tonight!

I have many tops and pants in the Cuddl Duds fleece, and I love them all. Most of them I get at Walmart at about $6 cheaper, but I liked this blue color so I bought it here. In person, the color is a little more teal than the blue shown in the picture, but it is still a nice color.The fabric is the softest, coziest thing I have ever felt against my skin, and I live in it all winter. I wear this brand of fleece both for daytime clothes and for pajamas. This particular top is almost exactly like the ones at Walmart, except for one small difference. The tops from W... have a thumb hole at the end of the sleeve. The hole is great for keeping your sleeves down when layering on another article of clothing. This top from Amazon does not have the hole. Instead, there is an embroidered icon of some sort (maybe CD for Cuddl Duds)? The icon looks nice and adds a bit of what may be considered 'bling' to a simple fleece gal like myself. Personally I'd rather have the thumb hole, but that minor issue is not enough to take any stars away. I absolutely love this top and it seems to be well made, in addition to being comfortable.One final note about washing instructions....the label says cold water, gentle cycle. I do not do that. I use warm wash, cold rinse (regular cycle) and it works fine. I have been doing this ever since I got my first fleece Cuddl Duds over a year ago and they all look as good as the day I got them. Also, some folks do not use fabric softener on fleece. I do. I tried the foil ball in the dryer, but it did not work, I still got static cling on these. So I went back to using dryer sheets and all is well. Also, my laundry detergent has fabric softener in it and I have no problems. I use the Ecos Brand detergent from Costcos and this line of fleece comes out looking great every time. Some of my Cuddl Duds have probably been washed 40+ times, and still look good. I'm not saying do what I do, I'm just saying I'm a bit careless about the washing instructions and have not had any issues.Bottom line, I love this fleece. I'm thinking of moving to the Arctic Circle so I can wear my Cuddl Duds in the summer too! Haha!

First let me say that I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review. Despite the recent attention that has been given to so called 'paid reviews' not being legitimate, that is not the case here. The items we "Viners" receive for free are taxable to us, and we are honest in our opinions. If you search my reviews, you will see that the 'free' items I review do not always get a favorable rating. I have given one star, five stars, and everything in-between.Ok, disclaimer over, here's my honest opinion of this iron:To be short and sweet, I absolutely Love it! I am a quilter and currently have four irons. This is my favorite. I love so many things about it, so I'll address one at a time:Steam Function:This works perfectly. You can adjust how much steam you want to use, and of course you can adjust whether it comes out of the the bottom plate, or you can do a direct spray from the handle area. Both work like a charm. No sputtering, no dripping, just perfectly misted steam every time.Heat Settings:The heat settings on this are digital rather than a turn dial. I honestly don't care whether my setting are chosen digitally or with a dial, as long as it works. This works. As far as the heat settings go, I really like a good hot iron for pressing my quilting cotton, both before cutting, and when pressing seams. The cotton setting is nice and hot, the perfect amount of heat for my quilting fabric. My first test was this: I took a scrap of fabric, folded it in half and pressed it just to test the sharpness of the fold. I have to say, that was the sharpest fold I have ever seen. It was all I could do to unfold it and lay it somewhat flat on my ironing board again. Then came the next test...I wanted to press out the fold and have the scrap perfectly flat again. A dry pressing didn't do it, but when I shot it with steam, that's all it took. Absolutely no indication that there was ever a fold pressed in the fabric. Part of this effectiveness I believe has to do with the weight of the iron...I cover that a bit more further down. This is impressive to me, because with a couple of my other irons I really have to press and re-press to get those fold lines completely out, even with steam.Soleplate:This is probably my favorite part of the iron. It is extremely smooth, and glides over my fabric like a dream. Not only that, the pointy part of the soleplate is shaped in a way that I can get into tight seam areas better than I can with any of my other irons. It is very 'corner friendly', and precise pressing is definitely the result.Weight:This is not my lightest iron, so I was initially concerned about that. But I find that the slightly heavier weight was in no way a hindrance. In fact, I feel the weight adds to how effectively the iron smooths out those wrinkles!All in all, I feel this is an impeccable iron. Granted, I am usually fairly pleased with most irons, but this one definitely outshines them all. I hope to get lots of use from this, and if anything negative turns up I will be sure to update this review!

This is an attractive cheese board. There are little rubbery feet on the four corners that keep it from slipping, and the size is just right for my purposes.Although the design is beautiful, I assumed the background was white like the photo. It is clear, and therefore the red cardinal does not have the same striking impact as what the photo shows. I have to admit I was a bit disappointed. After closer inspection of the photo, I can only assume that it is difficult to impart a 'clear' background photographically. I just wish the description would have said "clear glass". rather than just 'glass'.Other than that one issue, it is an attractive well made piece.

I was so excited to try this. I usually cook from scratch due to the lack of good quality, organic food that is already prepared. I live in a rural area where these types of conveniences are hard to come by....our store has mostly just the basic, GMO laden, MSG filled products.When I saw this organic soup I was hopeful that I found something to get me through those occasions when a 'scratch' soup wasn't feasible.To be blunt, I only ate two bites, then threw it away. When I took the first bite, I thought, Yuck...this tastes just like the processed stuff our store already sells. Then I thought, no, surely it's not that bad; so I took another bite. That's when I realized that yes, it was that bad. If I had to describe the taste, I'd say it was like eating something that came from a malfunctioning Star Trek food replicator. I threw the rest of that batch away and gave the other unopened cartons to my neighbor.To be fair, I am very used to my own awesome soups. I guess an unrealistic part of me was expecting an 'organic' soup to taste less processed. Lesson learned, this is a processed soup even if it is organic.That being said, if you are already used to eating soups that are canned or processed in any way, you may not be too put off by this.But if you do a lot of homemade, don't expect the 'organic' label to bring you home cooked flavor. I generously gave three stars in case I'm being overly critical. My honest opinion is probably more like two stars, and that's only because of it's merits of being organic.

I purchased this for two reasons: It had dough hooks, and the price was right. I figured if it didn't work well I wouldn't be out much.I had recently seen a more expensive brand with dough hooks on a shopping channel, but their price was about five times the cost of this one.I'm so glad I took the chance! I make a lot of homemade bread, and was tired of using my kitchenaid stand mixer. The bowl on that isn't really big enough for 2-3 loaves worth of dough, and so the dough just kept crawling up the blade and hit the main arm of the mixer. I kept having to scrape it down, and I finally quit using it altogether for dough....it was easier to hand knead.Then the shopping channel demo on the 'other brand' hand mixer convinced me it would be great to have one with dough hooks. It would allow me to mix in a bigger bowl, and be able to just move the whole mixer around so it would get to all the dough in the bowl. To make a long story short, this mixer works GREAT!I begin with sourdough starter, and I find that when it's still pretty thin it's easier to just spoon-stir it. Then when the flour additions start thickening everything up, I use this hand mixer. Once the dough is at it's working consistency, it works best to run the mixer for a bit in one section, move the mixer slightly and run in another section, etc. Everything gets really mixed in this way. After the initial dough 'resting' phase, I use the mixer again for a five minute kneading, moving from section to section. For most of my kneading I just use the first or second speed and it works perfectly. No bogging down at all.Finally bread making is a pleasure again! Bottom line, this is probably the best $13 purchase I've ever made! (Actually it was $12.83, I think.)

See Additional comment below this original review:Original Review: This is a beautiful set of towels, mitts, and potholders. I got the chef print, and the yellow is a soft, yet deep buttery color that matches my kitchen perfectly.The first thing I did when I received them, was put them through a wash. I wanted to see how they would hold up. Color wise, there was definitely some fading, but they still look really pretty. Structurally, the towels are very thin, and after that one wash I can tell that they will not last long. They are a bit of a loose weave, and almost every towel had pulled threads/snags by the time I took them out of the dryer. They look to be in about the same condition as towels I have had for the last 8-10 years.That being said, I love the oven mitts & potholders. The mitts are a bit smaller than any of my other ones, which is a benefit in my opinion. They are less cumbersome than large bulky mitts, and are easy to get on & off. They have plenty of thickness to them, and they fully insulate my hands from hot dishes.I rarely buy new kitchen towels, as I tend to keep the same color scheme for years. But mine were getting old, and these were offered to me for free in exchange for my honest review. Since they matched my colors so I was glad to try them out. If I were to see this set in a store I would be able to tell that the towels are pretty thin, but I would probably still buy the set. The Amazon price at the time of this review is at about $22.00. For six towels, two mitts, and two potholders, I think it's a fairly decent deal. If the towels hadn't snagged after just one washing, I would've given five stars.Additional Comments 8/28/14: Well, I reduced my rating to two stars. The potholders are both starting to come apart at the seams. The binding is coming apart and the fabric is fraying. I washed them once, and have only used them a few times as it has been too hot to cook much. I was pulling something out of the oven today when I noticed the fraying. I have had other potholders for years, and never had this problem. The dish towels look like regular dish towel fabric, but after using a few times I see that they are not as absorbent as any of my other towels. Even though the towels are thin, the nap is a bit stiff and the threads almost seem to have a water repellent property to them. Basically this is a cheaply made set, even though the design is really nice. I'm giving two stars instead of one, because I do love the design, and for those who have to pay for the set, at least the price is pretty low. Glad I got them for free!

This is my first time trying this body cream, so I do not have any reference to how it compares with the old formula. All I know is, it is heavenly! I'm not a connoisseur of scents, so I don't know that I can be very eloquent in my description of it....but I will try:It has a soft, yet very rich scent, very nutty, and maybe a tad bit of vanilla & fig. I do not detect much of a fruity scent at all, unless you count the fig.Texture-wise, it is fluffy & light, very moisturizing without being overly oily.This is one of my favorite body creams. I tend to switch around a lot and I seldom come back to the same product once it's gone. This one however, will probably end up being one of my mainstays. Meaning, throughout all my switching around I will always have a jar of this available. It is a yummy scent, that pampers my dry skin beautifully!

These Chums are my favorite retainers ever! I love that they just slip onto the ends of the ear pieces. Unlike those rubber-bandy things that go way up on the sides of eyeglass ear pieces, these are way more understated and unobtrusive!These go on pretty easily, once they're on they stay on. I couldn't care less about the tips being fish shaped, but that certainly isn't a detriment either.To get away from the type of rubber-band retainers that go way up on the earpiece I ended up ordering these, as well as a pair of the Gripz brand retainers to try. I like these Chums a lot better, basically because the Gripz brand pulled at my hair too much when taking my glasses on and off.These 'Chums' are definitely going to work well for me. If I ever loose them, I won't hesitate to buy more!

This was a bit hard to get used to, as I normally use the Hobbs Heirloom 80/20 fusible batting. I have come to realize that all fusible battings are very wrinkly out of the package, and you really need to smooth them out quite a bit before using them.The Hobbs fusible is much softer and more pliable than this June Tailor one, and it is easier to 'hand' smooth right off the bat. This June Tailor batting is way stiffer, but a little less wrinkly to start with.This batting says to steam press it, but I did not do that at first. I generally  prefer a dry iron, for reasons I won't get into here. So anyway, I used this batting on a wall hanging with applique. I proceeded to smooth the batting as much as I could, then I made my quilt sandwich. I pressed the back side first, then the front side, starting in the centers and gently smoothing as I went out. The result was a hard, warped wall hanging, that almost felt like it would break in half if I folded it. It didn't of course, but that's my way of explaining how stiff it was.I proceeded to quilt my wall hanging, and I re-planned my quilting to try and flatten the warped areas. That worked somewhat, but there was still warping. It almost looked like a curved platter. Low in the middle and all the edges curved up. I could've served tortilla chips in my wall hanging!Finally, I thought well, I'm gonna go ahead and steam it. My applique was securely sewn down and quilted by then. The result......MAGIC!I should've used steam in the first place. Everything flattened out perfectly, and it was even slightly less stiff. It reminded me of that plastic window stuff....you know for weather proofing? If you've ever used it, you know that when you run the blow dryer over it, all the warped areas magically flatten out. Well that's what the steam iron did. All the areas on my wall hanging that needed to be flat went flat, and all the areas that were already flat stayed exactly the same.I entered the wall hanging in our annual quilt show and got a blue ribbon! (Photo Shown).To sum up, I will explain the reason I only gave four stars instead of five. Bottom line, I like working with the Hobbs better. I like that it's more pliable, and that I don't have to use steam. All things considered, I feel the Hobbs it's just easier to work with. I will still use the Tailor brand in a pinch though.

I am extremely bummed to have to give these shoes only 3 stars.First impression out of the box was that they felt very heavy, and very stiff. But no star deduction for that, I just figured they must be good solid shoes! I couldn't wait to try them on; Which is where my disappointment set in.First, I will say that I normally take a size 37 in these types of shoes, and in Dansko's I also take a 37. But based on various reviews, I decided it would be a good idea to order up one size in the Sanita's, so I did. I ordered a 38, and both shoes came stamped with 38.I put the left one on first. It was like putting my foot into a piece of formed concrete, but I was still able to slide my foot in fairly easily, and once on they were pretty comfortable (Very similar to Dansko's). The right shoe however would not even go on my foot. So then I put on a pair of thin hose to try and make it work, but I still could not get my foot in the shoe. I do not have wide feet, they are normal width and somewhat bony. The edge of the leather on the top part of the shoe, felt like a piece of iron jamming into my top foot bone. I think if I forced it any more it would have broken skin, or created a bruise.Finally I gave up. I held the shoes up against each other, and the right one did look slightly smaller than the left, but not much.After all this, I decided to experiment. I got a fairly new pair of my Dansko's out (size 37), and put the right one on. Then on my left foot, I put on this Sanita shoe (size 38). The Dansko 37 actually fit looser than the Sanita 38 shoe!So for me anyway, I assume a size 39 'might' work in the Sanita brand. I ended up boxing these up for a return though. I decided not to exchange them, because I really don't know for sure whether to go with 39's, or try another pair of 38's in hopes that they both match.And in case anyone is thinking maybe my feet are uneven, I will say that I am 57 years old, and I have bought many, many pairs of shoes over the years. I have never had a pair that were so mismatched size-wise.On a positive note, I did love the look of these in person. I do want to eventually try some more Sanita's, but I will wait until I can try them in person.Hopefully others will have more luck with these. I debated whether to give four stars instead of three, since everyone else seems to love these. But since I had no choice but to return them, I felt that the three star rating was generous enough.

I love everything about this baker. It's beautiful, it's sturdy, it cleans up easily, and it has cooked everything perfectly so far. There is no seasoning required, and the size is perfect for DEEP dish lasagna. I don't really need the length of a 13x9 for my lasagna, for just myself and my husband I'd rather have the depth. I put a lot of stuff in my layers!In fact, a lot of casserole pans are just too shallow in my opinion. So this is a refreshing option for those of us who like 'deep-dish' food!The only thing I was a bit surprised about is the weight of this pan. I know it's cast iron, and I know cast iron is heavy. I have several cast iron skillets, and a few other cast iron pieces. But for some reason, I just didn't expect this to be as heavy as it is. Maybe heavy skillets just aren't as big a deal for me, because I only use them on my stove top and do not have to do any bending while handling them. Others have commented on the weight in a favorable light, and I can understand their thinking. But when my joints are acting up, this is a bit uncomfortable to get in and out of the oven. Fortunately I have a strong husband though, so it's not much of an issue for me.But back to the positive.... so far I have used this for lasagna, baked chicken, and a couple of casseroles. It worked great every time, and I look forward to using it a lot more!

There are pros and cons to this vacuum, but all in all I like it and enjoy using it.Pros....Suction: Surprisingly, this little vacuum has great suction. I cannot believe how quickly the dirt collects in the canister. For bare floors, I can't set it on the lowest setting, or it sucks so much I can't drag it across my linoleum. But the second lowest setting works great.Weight: This is probably the thing I like most about this vacuum. Compared to my heavy duty vacuum cleaner, this one literally feels weightless! I do have a lightweight broom vac that I keep in my basement, but it does not have the suction that this one does.So to sum up the pros, the weight/suction ratio is tremendous; It's has the suction of my heavy duty vacuum, with the weight of my tiny broom vac.Cons....Flexible Hose: There is a plastic clamp-like thing on the front of the vacuum handle that the flexible hose attaches into. When using, the hose keeps falling out and I keep having to put it back. I'd tie it in permanently, but that would hinder my use of the attachments.Edge Cleaning: I should say "NON Edge-Cleaning", because no matter how I maneuvered the vac along the walls, etc, it did not clean the edges very well at all. My heavy duty vac easily excels in this area. If you want edge cleaning with this vacuum, you will definitely have to use the attachments.Those are my pros and cons. A few other notes to consider are: The cord is 19 feet long. I did not realize how short this was until I had to unplug/replug a few times when doing my living room. It is advertized at the 19 feet though, so this did not affect my rating. I have attached an extension cord that I will leave on it permanently.Also, the washable filter is easy to remove, wash, and reinsert. It does look a bit insubstantial though, so time will tell how long it lasts. If anything noteworthy arises concerning this, or any other issue I will update my review.

These scissors are great for both kids and adults. They are nice and small, easy for little hands to maneuver, yet the holes are made so that adults can use them too. Unlike my previous craft scissors, these scissors have one hole larger than the other. For me, I can easily fit my thumb in the small hole, and 2-3 fingers in the larger hole which allows for better control when cutting around tight curves.I have found these to be great for my sewing box. Being a quilter, I like to have a lot of these small scissors handy. I have a pair by my ironing board, a pair in my 'binding' box, a pair by my sewing machine, and a pair at my cutting table. I don't know that they would hold up to cutting several layers of fabric or anything, but I have rotary cutters for that. For paper cutting, light fabric cutting, applique, and crafts, these definitely do the job.Now that I am stocked up with these craft scissors, I expect to get a lot of use out of them. If I run in to any negative issues in the future, I will update my review.

This replaces an older pair of bolt cutters we have. With our old ones, it takes a 'lot' more effort to get them to work.My husband has a taxidermy business and uses all kinds of cutters regularly. He often uses heavy gauge wire...just about every day actually. He also needs to change the length of a bolt periodically, and for all jobs these bolt cutters work wonders! Just before writing this review, he cut a bunch of six gauge wire, and he said they 'cut like butter'!He has used them to cut several things so far and we see no sign of nicks or dulling in the blades. They are truly heavy duty cutters!I also love the design of these cutters. They fold up nicely to save space, then they open easily and securely lock into place when you need to cut with them.Haha, he said I could have his old cheap bolt cutters for my craft room, to cut my floral wire with! You know, the stuff that you can bend a few times and then break? I declined his offer, but I may use these heavy duty ones once in awhile to cut heavier wire in his shop....just for the fun of it!

I received this knife for free in exchange for my honest review. My husband is a taxidermist and a hunter, so I thought this would be a great product to try.When it arrived we immediately took it over to our shop and got out a tanned hide that needed prepping. He used the knife to thin a few areas on the nose pad. This was mainly just to test the sharpness of the blade, as fine shaving like this generally works better with small thin bladed knives. Nonetheless, he liked the way it worked and the blade seemed nice and sharp....to use my husband's words, he said "Wow, super sharp!"Next, he took some scrap hide pieces and went into his salting room which is windowless. With the lights out in that room it is pretty dark. He had me to turn out the lights, then he proceeded to use the knife in the dark with only the 'knife-light' on.I'll just sum up quickly here by saying he is really excited about this knife. He can see extremely well in the dark when using it, the blade really is very sharp, and he is really excited to take it with him hunting next season.A hunter always hopes of course, to get their deer while there is still plenty of daylight, but you never know what circumstances you might run into. Even on just a dark cloudy day, the light on the knife would still be of help!Bottom line, even tho we received this for free, we feel it is definitely worth buying. Now that he's tried it, if he lost it, or it fell out of his pack or something, we would definitely pay $59 for another one (that is the price at the time of this review). Of all the things we have received to review over the last few years, this definitely ranks as one of our favorites!!!

These work perfectly for both myself and my husband. I got the extra large for him, and the medium for me. My husband is a taxidermist so he wears gloves for certain jobs. He is able to feel through these and maintain his manual dexterity while protecting his hands. There is a slight texture which helps when he is working with anything wet or slippery.For me, I like to use them for cleaning house, coloring my hair, and clipping my doggie's hair in those special places that get 'dirty'. I have medium size female hands and the medium gloves fit perfectly. There is just a tiny bit of room in the fingertips, so a woman with longer fingers would probably like this size as well. These hold up nicely during use, and even though I received both sizes for free in exchange for my honest review, I would have no problem buying them when I run out. They are probably my favorite disposable gloves I've ever tried. And to put that in perspective, I did receive another brand of disposable gloves to review quite some time ago. I did not like those as well and did not give as favorable a review!

I got these to use in the morning when I make smoothies with my VitaMix. A little background.....My Vitamix wasn't blending very well, so I called the company. I was told I needed to start it on low, then turn it all the way up as high as it will go and leave it there for at least 30 seconds to a full minute. I don't know if any of you have this machine, but it is the loudest freaking blender I have ever had in my entire life! Which is why I always tried getting it to work on low speed.Anyway, with it running full blast I always have to tightly cover my ears and step away from it. It was horrible to take my hands away from my ears long enough to turn it back down, so I got really good at turning the speed up and down with my foot!My husband suggested I buy some hearing protectors, and at first I was skeptical. I had already tried those foamy ear plugs, and put my good heavy duty 'stereo' headphones on over the plugs thinking that would help, but of course it didn't. Since these hearing protectors look similar to my headphones I thought they would probably be ineffective too. But out of desperation and caving to my husband's insistence, I finally bought these after a couple of hours of research. I didn't want to spend a huge amount of money, but I didn't want to go deaf either.The result? I truly am in shock over how much these helped. Before I even tried them with my Vitamix running, I knew they were going to help tremendously. When I first put them on, I was amazed at the complete and total silence of regular household noises. I took them back off and started tapping my foot on the kitchen floor to see how loud it was, then put them back on while continuing to tap. I could feel the vibration of my tapping, but I could not hear it in the least. Right then and there I made some smoothies so I could test the noise of the Vitamix.  I can still hear my Vitamix running, but I can stand right in front of it with these on and the noise is very low. I can hear myself talk with these on, but it's very far away sounding. I wish my husband would've suggested these a long time ago! They are one of the best things I've purchased in years!!!

I have several sets of earbuds, so I have a lot to compare these with. I judge this type of product mainly by two criteria.....fit and sound.As far as sound goes, they are as good, and maybe slightly better than my favorite buds that I normally use. I say 'slightly' better because it really was hard to tell. But after switching buds back and forth several times during a few different songs, I do think these might sound slightly more 'full'. That being said, the price tag on these is about three times what I paid for any of my other sets. I'm glad I received these for free in exchange for my review. If I had paid $79, I would have returned them.I will say that the wires on these are definitely a bit more substantial than any of my other buds. So I'm guessing that the construction is probably decent. My biggest complaint about these is the fit. These come with four sizes of tips. I tried all four and the only ones I could kindof get to work were the very smallest ones. I even had to kindof hold those in snugly to get the full effect of the sound.As for use with a cell phone, (I always use buds when on my cell) these will not work for that purpose. When talking with these in, they slowly work their way out.If these fit better, I would have rated them higher. As it is, these will basically sit in a drawer and be my 'emergency' ear buds.

Sorry I'm not joining in on all the five star reviews here, but according to review guidelines five stars mean "Love It", four mean "Like It", and three mean "It's ok". As classy and well made as this watch is, I have to be honest, and go with the three star "It's ok" rating.Maybe I'm just not used to watches this big, but this thing looks absolutely Huge on my wrist. Like a big man's watch! I usually like big bold jewelry, which is why I accepted this watch to review. And I worked several years in a jewelry store, so I'm no stranger to a big 'gold' presence. But as bold and beautiful as it looks in the photo, I felt that in person it was just too much. It's not just the dial that's big, the band is pretty thick & masculine looking too. I had my husband to try it on and although it was about the right size that he'd wear, it is a bit fancy for his tastes.There are a couple of things I do like about the watch; The dial is very easy to read, and it clearly has an elegant, expensive look. The stainless steel core, plated with gold is a combo that is generally safe for those who are allergic to more inexpensive metals. (I mention this based on my jewelry store experience....I personally do not have issues with inexpensive metals.)My one piece of advice to those who are considering buying this, is to make SURE you like a huge manly look on your wrist before buying this. I put a ruler under the face of the watch, and it measures 1 1/2" across including the gold rim around the dial. So it might be a good idea to cut a circle of paper with a 1 1/2" diameter and lay it on your wrist before you spring for this one!One final note, most people will not have the correct tools to remove links, so you will need to take it to a jeweler for that.

Without being able to see ingredients, I accepted this cleanser for free in exchange for my honest review.It does cleanse well, although my skin tends to be dry and does feel a bit tight after using this. The tight dry feeling isn't a huge factor though, because after my shower I always follow up with a toner and then a good moisturizer.On less effective cleansers, I sometimes get a bit more residue on my cotton pad when using my toner. I know this product cleans really well though, because my cotton pad is as clean/white as new when toning after this cleanser.If you are mindful of ingredients though, don't be fooled by the advertised "White Tea & Vitamin E". This product also has a lot of questionable, not to mention downright bad ingredients in it. My biggies to avoid are the parabens and this has a nice variety of these buggers, including one of my all-time no-no of ingredients, 'propylparaben'.If this was a face cream or lotion, it would've merited only one star. But since it is a product that is on my skin briefly then gets rinsed off, I am generously giving three stars.So here's the bottom line:If you don't care about ingredients and just want something to cleanse well; AND your skin is either normal or oily, then I say go for it. You will probably love this.For those of you who don't care about ingredients but tend to have dry skin.... If you like to cleanse and go, your face may feel a bit tight after using this. If you have dry skin and use a moisturizer after wards, you'll be fine.If you care about ingredients, you should be able to find a lot of healthier alternatives, no matter what skin type you have.Personally, I will keep this in my shower for emergency use. If it ever gets used up (which I doubt), I will not replace it.

This works on a variety of doors, and does not damage the surface in any way.The upper portion that goes over the door has a flexible tab-like thing underneath, that catches to keep it snug on narrow doors, and flexes in for use on wider doors. All of the parts that touch the door are made of a really soft rubbery material that grips, gives, and does not leave marks.The hooks are ok, and it's nice that there are two of them. If I had to find a negative, it would be that the round wire part that attaches the hooks to the main door sleeve (see product photo), tends to rotate quite a bit. So I find that I need to regularly rotate the hooks to straighten them, especially after use. I did not take away a star for that, because it doesn't affect the functionality in the least, and it's easy to straighten. It's just the sort of thing that an anal person like myself would point out.All in all, this is a great improvement over the old stiff hooks from way back when. I did receive it in exchange for my honest review, but I would have no problem paying for another one should I find myself in need. The price tag at the time of this review is $7.99....I feel it is well worth it.

I've used a lot of Avery printing supplies in the past, and they are all great. These cards are no different. Printing on them is a breeze; text and colors are sharp and vivid using 'card stock' setting and high print quality. Even with standard print quality they look great, maybe just not quite as vivid.As usual, these cards punch out perfectly, leaving no rough or unfinished looking edges. I love being able to design my own professional looking cards and have the option of changing things up a bit whenever I want, rather than ordering  several hundred at a time and being stuck with them forever. Of course, in my business, I do not go through tons and tons of cards, so this is a very fun and cost effective solution for me. For those of you who run through your cards like crazy, ordering from an outside company would probably be more cost effective. But these would still be great for whipping out something a little different once in awhile, or for getting you through in between orders if you happen to run out.All in all, a good product that works great for a great variety of business/marketing purposes.

I absolutely, positively, love, love, love these cards! I was able to fit so much information on them, including business name, contact info, logo & slogan, and even a price list on the inside. For printing preferences, I chose card stock & high quality, and they turned out beautifully!To create in your cards in Microsoft Word, you will need to download the template if you do not already have it. The Avery product number is '8820', and the template number '5302'. Typing in either number at avery.com will take you to the proper template to download. Or, if you want to use one of their pre-made designs, you can even do it right on the Avery website and print your cards from there. You simply replace their generic info with your own.  All fields are lined up and ready to go, and there are tons of designs to choose from. This is great for those of you who do not have MS Word.I ended up doing something different however....I started with the MS Word template but felt a bit restricted there. Design-wise, I feel I can do so much more in Photoshop, so I made my own template there and filled in the printable areas. They turned out perfectly lined up when printed! If you love the creative freedom you have with Photoshop (or the Elements version) and want to set up your own template in Photoshop, please look at the comments section. Immediately after posting this review I will post the instructions in the comments. That way I won't crown this review with a lot of info that only a few will probably want.Also, I am posting a photo of the cards I created, so you can see how they line up on the sheet. Lined up this way, when you print the front, then turn them over and print the same thing on the back, they will turn out just right. (You will have two card 'fronts' and two card 'back' per sheet.) These are not my final product, I have some tweaking to do. But the pic should give you a good idea how to line up your text in case you opt for the Photoshop instructions.Bottom line, I am extremely happy with these cards. Although I received them for free in exchange for my honest review, I will definitely buy more of them when I run out!!!

I have had this machine for going on a year and a half now, so I have given myself plenty of time to use it before writing my review. I will try to be quick and to the point on the pros and cons I have found, although it's sometimes difficult to be brief on a machine of this caliperPros First:*I absolutely love the large throat space and can easily quilt everything from table runners to lap quilts and wall hangings. I wouldn't try to quilt anything in the full/queen/king size ranges, but that's just me. Others may find it doable.*I also love the smooth, even stitches that this machine produces. I rarely need to play with the thread tension, but when I do it's easy to adjust and I don't have to fight with it! Also, there are plenty of accessories (including quilting foot and 1/4" foot, of course), and I love that the 1/4" foot also has markings for 1/4" from the end of the fabric (so you'll know exactly when to turn the corner for binding,etc).*I'm saving my all-time, absolute favorite feature for last, and that is the simple, lowly, thread cutter. I always thought it'd be handy to have, but turns out it goes way past handy! Quilters will know what I mean when I say it is so awesome to automatically have your top/bottom threads cut whenever you need to start a new line of quilting. Not having to reach under the quilt to clip the bottom thread is heaven! Even when just doing straight line piecing I have found that I love the automatic cutter. Now, when I use my other machine, I really miss that automatic thread cutter!Ok, Cons next:*The bobbin placement is a bit difficult to get used to. My hands are about average sized, and it was hard to get used to maneuvering the bobbin case in from the side. Plus, I really had to crane my head down and sideways to see, which could be uncomfortable for someone like me who has periodic neck issues. I'm not saying you can't do it if you have large hands, but I am saying you may have difficulty, especially at first. All that being said, I am used to it now and can do it easily, so no star deduction for this feature.*Next con is the feed dog/presser foot pressure features. It is very subtle, and oftentimes I cannot even tell that I have made any adjustments. I have to go from one extreme to the other to really notice even a minor difference. I mention this because, my neighbor has a competing machine that is pretty much like this Brother in every way, just more expensive. (Her machine starts with a 'J'). I have tried hers, and the pressure adjustments are much more responsive than mine, so either my machine is just a little whacky, or there is a reason for the price difference. This is the one and only negative feature I subtracted a star for. I really wanted this feature, because as I said I tried it on the competing machine and it worked like a charm. So it was one of the selling points for me. Needless to say, because of this I find free-motion quilting easier on her machine than on mine.Next I will just share a couple of observations that do not fall into Pro or Con categories, and these comments do not affect my star rating:Threading for me, wasn't intuitive compared to other machines I've had and I found myself looking at the instructions pretty often in the beginning. Now I can whip it out pretty fast, unless I haven't used the machine in several weeks.Also, although the speed capability is nice, I find that I personally cannot always use it maxed out. Sometimes my seams get a tiny bit off when I go too fast. The foot pedal is very easy to control tho, so this is really just my issue, not the machines'.My last comment is more of a 'wish' item. If only this machine had even just a couple of decorative stitches it would be a pretty complete package. As it stands now, if I want to incorporate a zig-zag or even a simple 's' curve stitch into my quilting, I have to go back to my little machine with the small throat space. But I knew this was just a straight stitch machine when I bought it, so of course no star deduction on that either.All in all, I love this machine and fully expect to get a lot more use from it. I was actually considering five stars instead of just four, but the pressure adjustment issue was enough to slightly edge my rating down.

This is the fifth brand of coconut water I've tried, and my favorite so far. To be honest, I'm not a huge fan of any coconut water but it is a pretty healthy beverage so I try to drink it periodically. Of all the brands I've tried, the main difference I can taste is in the freshness. Some taste like they've been sitting around awhile...almost spoiled in fact. But at least three of the brands I've tried taste pretty fresh. And of all those, this one tastes the freshest, followed closely by a brand called 'Taste Nirvana'.My husband is the real coconut lover in the family, and he loves coconut water. When he tasted this one, he also said it was his favorite, and he used the word 'fresh' to describe it as well.Although I received this for free in exchange for my honest review, this is the brand I will buy now, as it's the easiest one for me to get down. (and my husband of course, guzzles it!And now, an interesting tidbit....The main reason I ever decided to try coconut water in the first place, was because I saw a health show on tv where a doctor was saying that coconut water is so similar to human blood, that in emergencies they can use it for blood transfusions. (This is a fact that can be verified with online research). It has electrolytes in it that are similar to those in our blood, and it is easily absorbed by the body. For this reason I consider it an especially great drink for recuperation after a workout!

This handy little chopper is a great alternative to a bigger food processor. So far, everything I have tried chops up perfectly. The more you 'pulse' it, or the longer you run it on continual speed, the finer the pieces. And for the most part the pieces are uniform in size. I have chopped carrots, onion, celery, cucumber, and frozen raspberries (for a dessert recipe). The only thing that had a few larger pieces was the carrots, but I chopped a big batch of them, and there were only 3-4 slightly bigger pieces; they were very easy to pick out.The noise isn't too loud, it's quieter than my full size processor. It's not quite as fast as a full size, but the speed difference is negligible. Plus, in the long run it's quicker, because it's a breeze to clean, and I don't have to haul my bigger one in and out of the cabinet all the time now. This is so small I can just leave it on my counter top. I love that you can just chop in the bowl, then put a lid on it for later use.The bowls that come with this are exactly the same size as some pyrex bowls I have, and I can use those with the blades as well. That makes it very handy for chopping up a variety of items and storing them separately for later use.I am very happy with this so far. I have used it almost daily since I received it, and expect to get a lot more use from it!

This works like a cleanser and toner in one. All you do is put some on a cotton pad and clean your face with it. No rinsing required! I love how easy it is.I have done the same thing with my natural toner when wanting to clean my face in a hurry. This cleansing water works better. It gets dirt/makeup off with less effort.My skin doesn't feel the same afterward as it does with the toner....with this product, I at first had to kindof get used to what I thought was residue. But I started noticing that my skin was not drying out so much throughout the day as it would with regular cleanser and/or toner. So I think what I must be feeling is some sort of humectant that is attracting moisture to my skin.Basically, my toner makes my skin 'feel' cleaner afterward, but my cotton pad feels more gentle with this cleanser and hours afterward my face feels more moist. Sometimes I don't even use lotion now. With my toner, my skin would be bone dry after 15 minutes, even with my toner-then-lotion routine.

If not for all the tiny round silver things that fall off, this tissue would've gotten five stars.The paper is all beautiful and it's a great price for the amount you get, but I ended up using just a few sheets and putting the rest away. Some  pieces of the tissue do not have the silver circles attached, but it's hard to get one of those pieces out without loosening some silver from the other pieces.The circles are small, flat, discs just a tad bigger than glitter. I wanted this mostly to put in decorative tins with baked goods. Turns out I couldn't use much of it, because I certainly didn't want that stuff on my goodies! In fact, I don't really want it anywhere at all!So please bear in mind that this rating and review is coming from someone highly opposed to glitter of all kind. (I have thrown away all xmas decorations with glitter, and when I get a card with glitter I slip it into a clear baggie to keep the glitter contained.) Don't get me wrong, it's beautiful, and if you like glitter, you will love this tissue. But if I'd been able to see it in the picture (or description), I never would have bought it.

This coffee maker has some nice options. We like the programmable timer so the coffee is ready when we wake up in the morning.Also, there are 4 brewing choices. The first choice is to just use no specific brew setting at all; this will make regular coffee just like any coffee maker not equipped with brew settings. The other three choices are 1. A small pot (2-4 cup brew), 2. Bold coffee, 3. Extra Bold coffee. These three settings slow down brew time to different extents, causing the water to stay in contact with the grinds longer, which allows more flavor to come through.We like a light roast coffee, but we end up using a lot of it because we still like plenty of flavor without the charred taste that medium and dark roast coffees can sometimes have. So we thought we'd try all of the different settings, especially since we only make a 4 cup pot each day. We were hoping we'd be able to use less coffee.Well the 2-4 cup setting, as well as the bold, and extra bold settings all brought out a bitter, burnt, charred characteristic that we didn't like, even when using less coffee. So then we tried the standard setting, with the regular amount of coffee and although it wasn't really charred tasting, it was a bit more bitter than usual. So then we tried using less coffee than normal, and on regular setting, and that's where we found our perfect cup of coffee!So even on the standard setting, you will need less coffee. For those of you who love strong coffee, or for those of you who love a certain brand that rhymes with 'charbucks', the bold and extra bold settings will really bring out that type of flavor, while using less coffee.As for the other features, the thermal carafe is awesome! We drink our coffee pretty quickly so we don't really need that feature, but I always keep hot water on the stove for tea throughout the day. Now I can heat my water on the stove, pour it onto the carafe (or just run plain water through the coffeemaker), and it stays hot for a few hours. Anything that saves electricity, is worth taking advantage of in my book.I hope to get years of use from this coffeemaker. If I have any adverse issues in the near future, I will be sure to make an amendment to my review.

I've had these for about a week now, and use them every day to walk my dog. I will never be without them now!The rubber is soft enough to stretch onto my boots, but still sturdy. The cleats work wonders, I now feel very secure on our icy roads. I live in NW Montana and we finally got our winter snow & ice the past several days, so I was glad to be able to use these.Previously I had a different brand. Those were round shaped (a hard rubber circle), that was really difficult to pull onto my boots. And on those, there were only cleats under the ball of the foot, not the heel. They worked, but walking was very awkward...with no cleats under the heels, they were way lower than the ball of the foot where the cleats were. So with those, I was trading slick roads for awkward walking.With the Stabilicers, walking feels completely comfortable. I can't say enough about these....I guess I am just so pleased to find something that works so much better than my old pair. The only advice I have, is to make sure you order a big enough size. I am a female with a shoe size 7 1/2. According to the size chart on the packaging, a ladies shoe size from 5-8 is supposed to order a small. But after reading reviews of this product from other sellers, I decided to order a medium and I'm glad I did! They fit nicely on my winter boots, my hiking boots, and even on my regular shoes. Since this seller does not list sizing (at the time of this review), here are the numbers:Men shoe size 4-7, and women 5-8, Small.Men shoe size 7.5-10 and women 8.5-12, MediumMen shoe size 10.5-13 LargeMen shoe size 13.5-16, X-LargeLike I said though, it'd be a good idea to order up a size, especially if you are in the upper range for your size category. My husband wears a size 12, and we are going to order an extra large for him, even though the chart recommends large. If that does not work out I will post a notation. If there are no amendments, that means it worked out great for him.Bottom line, I absolutely love these, I don't think I could fall if I tried!

I will say right up front, that I do not use dry kibble for my dog's regular diet, I have him on a homemade diet that I prepare myself according to the guidelines of experts such as Dr. Becker, etc. I won't get into the reasons I feed my dog a homemade diet, that is a whole different bandwagon.But my dog is spoiled, and he gets treats for just about every reason known to man. That can get expensive, and it the calories can also add up. So I periodically get a small bag of the highest quality dog food I can find, and give him one piece at a time for his treats.This dog food consists of really tiny pieces of kibble, so for my little Jack Russel it works great for treats. There are a few larger pieces throughout, but even those are small. If you feed kibble for meals and you have a small dog, this will be great.Now for the quality of the food.....First I will list all the good things about the ingredients in this food:*Contains freeze dried lamb (in addition to the standard lamb meal).*Also has freeze dried lamb organ meat.*No gluten, and no grain (this means no corn, wheat, rye, etc).*Has montmorillionite clay (nutrient rich, great for detoxification).*My dog loves it (to be honest, he loves pretty much everything).*Has a lot of natural healthy ingredients, such as pumpkinseeds, blueberries, squash, and green tea.I will add here, that even though this product has no grain or gluten, it does have starch in the form of tapioca. There is really no other way to form the kibble though, some sort of starch is necessary.Now I will list the biggest thing I don't like about the formulation:*It has Ground Flax....I know, many of you are probably thinking, "wait, isn't flax good?"Well yes, generally flax is awesome, and it's best eaten 'ground' if you want the benefit of the healthy fats and lignans, etc. The problem, is that flax goes rancid very quickly, especially when ground. Sure there are some preservatives that help (vitamin e, etc), but that is not enough to insure that the flax stay fresh. If you doubt what I'm saying, do your own research. I would much rather see coconut oil (a much more stable fat), added to dog foods.Fortunately, this is just a small bag, and the contents fit in my refrigerator. If you decide to feed this to your dog via larger bags, please try to keep it as airtight as possible, and in a spot that is as cool as possible. This will prolong the shelf life. And who knows, maybe there is so little flax, that even if it does go rancid the result is negligible.I don't mean to pick on this food, as I feel it is fairly high quality 'for a kibble'. The thing is, that it's not just this dog food. Just about every dry kibble food I look at has ground flax.And I for one, will never give any dog food a five star rating if it has flax in it. So please take my rating in that context.Bottom line, I think compared to other dry kibbles out there this is amongst the top in quality. And for tiny treats, a small bag like this will last a long time!

This sprayer is so easy to use! Instructions are clear and to the point. My main application is for stain rather than paint. I have used it on the log siding on the sunny side of our house (a small portion of our house where the logs fade quicker), as well as on the floor boards of my porch. This is my first time with a electric sprayer so I can't compare with others of it's type. But compared to the pump sprayer we always used before, this is a dream!It puts out a smooth even spray, no clogging or spotting, and the job goes very quickly....even with the frequent refills required for a larger job. Cleanup is a breeze when all you have to do is throw out the liners! The capacity of the canister is a bit small for larger jobs, but that is not a con in my book, because this is not being marketed as a large capacity sprayer. Plus, this size is so easy to handle and maneuver!I received this item in exchange for my honest review, and I take that responsibility seriously. I do not give out five star reviews just in 'appreciation' of a free product. It is my sincere opinion that this sprayer provides a convenient way to get small to medium sized jobs done quickly, and I honestly could not find one negative characteristic to mention!

Before buying this, I did a lot of research on the grinder attachments that fit the Kitchenaid mixer, as well as on stand alone grinders. No grinder had 100% great reviews, so I really had to read about all the good and bad for each model. After much deliberation I finally decided that this grinder would be my best bet. I hoped that I would have the same experience as the other 'positive' reviewers, and I was not disappointed!To put it simply, this grinder works perfectly! Although it's may not be as fast as a commercial grinder, it is way faster (and easier) than the old manual hand grinder we used for years. I used this for two large deer that our family harvested this season, and was very happy with the speed. I constantly inspected the venison for grease and metal shavings that others found in various grinders...but there were Zero of these contaminants from this grinder in our meat. I like that the grinder plates and cutting blade are stainless steel. There are no plastic parts that I could see. We cleaned it before we used it, then again after.
