The cutting mechanism is exactly as advertised: very sharp.  And the file is also sharp and effective. However, The plastic housing covering the clippers is far too large.  It gets in the way so that it's tough to get the clippers themselves into the correct position. It's also hard to see exactly where in the nail you are going to cut. Finally, there is no little metal thingy that folds out to help clean under the nails or around the cuticles. I miss that a lot.  While very sharp, I'm still looking for the ideal fingernail clipper.

This is the second product that I ordered from Hallomall and after a week I ordered two more.  Motion activated lights are great, but who wants to pay to have them installed?  This small, lightweight solar operated LED has two modes of operation, off then dim after motion detection or dim and then bright after motion.  In both modes, it goes live when it gets dark.  We use the latter.  The bright mode is exceedingly bright for its size and weight, and the solar cell generates enough power to keep it on for at least 12 hours.  It has an adhesive backing for easy mounting or a single screw hole for a wood screw.  All in all, a great device for the price.Highly recommended.JM Tepper

For the second time in a row, Hamill has ventured very far from his comfort zone.  Fans may be dismayed to find a second consecutive novel with no horror or supernatural tropes, but never fear, WILD FYRE is an exciting, hard to put down thriller nonetheless.  This time around we are in the realm of science fiction, or perhaps more specifically, cyberfiction. No aliens, time travel or quantum mechanics, just good old fashioned AI with all its trappings.WILD FYRE opens with narration by Ed, the default leader of a group of 10 smart and creative but otherwise normal guys who have habit of not lasting too long at a job. They are just too creative and easily bored.  Ed's special talent is to find the perfect job for anyone. Something that they will excel at, even if it is not exactly what they think they are good at.  As it happens, Ed has spent most of his career finding jobs for this group of ten friends, with a long string of happy employers and employees.  Several of the group happen to be computer geeks of one sort or another. So much of the technobabble here is about servers and coding and hacking.  In fact, the chapter/section headers are formatted like the start of bits of C code and the names themselves like C OR Pascal function calls.  But one need not know a thing about any of this stuff to fully enjoy the novel, and the tech takes a back seat to the character-based story of what happens when one of the group, Jim, sets out to write some code that will simplify his life by predicting ahead of time when to turn on the lights, start the coffee and so on.  Jim is killed on the first page, and the rest of the novel concerns the how and why.Hamill shows off once again his consistent skill at creating (mostly) very likable and human characters that you would like to be friends with.  We learn about them through conversation and dialogue, which are both also especially strong points of his writing.  The ten meet on a regular basis for lunch and the conversations are fascinating. The technospeak has perfect verisimilitude (Hamill apparently used to be a programmer or systems analyst) which is fun for old coders like me to read but which will not interfere with enjoyment by folks who don't know a nybble from a byte.And finally, unlike so so many indie authors, WILD FYRE and Hamill's other novels are all (with one exception - and that a single sequel) totally self-contained, one off novels.  One can start WILD FYRE (or any of his others) without fear that one is signing on to a multi-book, (almost) never-ending saga.  The end is the end.Recommended.JM  Tepper

This is a well-made, very simple, solar powered LED flood light designed for outdoor use.  It comes with a plastic stake that can easily be driven into the ground, and both the LED spotlight and the solar cell panel are adjustable. One could also mount the on an exterior wall.  This inexpensive LED spot is brighter than the low voltage (12 V) lights that I had installed) at much greater expense) to light the path from my deck/upper lawn to the lower lawn.  I will be buying more of these.Recommended but NB:  I have only had this for a week. So far it has worked perfectly.  i something changes, I will post an addendum to this review/JM Tepperdisclaimer: I received one of these spots in exchange for an honest, no strings attached review.  If you check out my reviews, you will see that I do not not guarantee or always write a favorable review.

I've been on an Ike Hamill binge since I first discovered him via a review request several months ago.  For I guy I never heard of, he turned out to be this incredibly prolific writer who wrote stuff that was right up my alley. A little supernatural, a little magic, a little sci-fi, some graphic horror, and excellent plotting and pacing.  Believable dialogue and characters that did not act as if they had been struck down by the stupid and banal virus.So when I saw that PUNCH LIST had just been released, I grabbed it and moved it to the head of my queue.  It is a very quick read, and totally ambushed me.  Every thing that I liked about Ike Hamill's writing was on display, except for the fantasy, magic, sci-fi, and graphic horror.  This is a totally different kind of read.  It is principally a coming of age story of 17 year old Jeff Vickers, during the summer between his junior and senior years in High School.  Jeff is a good kid, a bit on the shy side.  Early on his oldest friend and close neighbor, Angie (10 days older and best buddies forever) introduces Jeff to a clique of new friends.  They are all great guys plus Angie.  Their characters are much better developed than the usual supporting cast, and added greatly to the storyline.  They are all "good" kids.  They do well in school, one plays football but is smart, gentle and kind (Vick), one is openly gay (Danny) and imagines himself an actor and is accepted by all, one (Adam) is younger brother and colleague to a science guy and so on.  They hang out in Adam's basement (Adam's folks have a large house with a pool) where they spend hours in intellectual games and conversing about their summer jobs, future, and each's philosophy of life.Jeff has no girlfriend, nor does he seem to be looking for one. Angie, who both kid's parents think would be an ideal match for Jeff, is going out with a college student 9 years older, and is thus unavailable.  One day, in Vick's car, Jeff sees a girl named Jessie who Vick knows, and instantly falls head over heels in love. Jessie happens to be renting a room over the garage at Adam's house (very convenient), and before too long, the two are seeing a lot of each other.  And the meaning of the title becomes clear.Good writing is good writing, no matter what it is about.  And despite the fact that this is nothing like any of the other Ike Hamill books that I have read in terms of genre or plot devices, it is still indubitably Ike Hamill just like THE BODY by Stephen King is nothing like THE STAND or 'SALEM'S LOT but is still quite recognizably Stephen King.  And here's the most amazing thing about this newly released novel: it was written in 2009, 2 years before Hamill published his first novel.  I suspect that it was touched up here and there in the intervening 6 years, but maybe Hamill was just born knowing how to write.Finally, there is a delicious twist near the end that I did not see coming at all, despite there having been at least a few clues given by the author.Highly Recommended.JM Tepper

INHABITED is the fifth or sixth Ike Hamill novel that I have read since first discovering him less than 6 months ago.  Hamill has a unique style of writing that makes one want to think.  Most of his novels are a little like David Lynch movies, where things are often not as they seem and one has to fill in the blanks for oneself.  The previous Hamill novels that I've read were all thrillers, Stephen King-like in plot (but completely original), and mostly horror, sometimes tinged with science fiction.  One trademark of Hamill's clean, brisk prose is that quite frequently things are deliberatey left vague, or ambiguous.  The monsters are just off-screen, just beyond our sight. The explanations for things are just a fraction of an inch beyond our grasp. That makes them even scarier than they ought to be, which is plenty scary.INHABITED is about two groups of teenagers, one a bunch of friends, the other a group of students, who are exploring an old mine for different reasons. Both are fairly well equipped for a single day (or nighttime) excursion into the old mine.  But almost as soon as they enter the mine, they find trouble.  The two groups get separated into smaller groups.  Things start to disappear.  Strange sounds are heard, and odd artifacts found.  What started out as a lark becomes deadly. And then it starts to get scary.INHABITED is another completely original story.  It's not what you think. But it is completely, indubitably, Hamill-like. Just when you think things can't get any stranger, they do. Just when you think it's finally over, it's not.  Hamill plays about with the flow of time.  INHABITED is plot-driven, but like the other Hamill novels I've read, the main characters, and there are several, are pretty well fleshed out.  The pacing is excellent, and the novel is hard to put down.Hamill appears to be something of a writing machine. He only started self-publishing in 2011 and he already has by my count 13 novels in print.  I haven't a clue how he manages to write that quickly, or that well. But he does.  I really hate to say this, because it is so badly overused, but if you like Stephen King (as I do), i'm fairly certain you will like INHABITED and other Ike Hamill novels (try TRANSCRIPTION and THE CLAIMING next).Highly recommended.JM Tepper

INFERNAL NIGHT is (I believe) the first short story collaboration between F. Paul Wilson and another author that pairs FPW's Repairman Jack with the other author's hero, in this case, Heather Graham's  Michael Quinn, the detective half of Graham's Cafferty and Quinn series of paranormal (Quinn was brought back from the dead and Caffetry owns an antiques shop that deals in "unusual" items) detective novels.  In this very short story (38 pages), Jack takes a case from a rich eccentric who flies him down to New Orleans (Cafferty and Quinn's home turf) on what seems a simple case, that he takes only because he's bored since Gia and Vicks are visiting relatives in Iowa.  Of course, nothing is a simple as it seems and Quinn and Jack discovers that they are both being scammed.It's not bad, but it's just too short to be able to sink one's teeth into fully, regardless of price ($0.99).  I didn't get any sort of feeling for what kind of character Quinn really is, or what it might be like to read more of the Cafferty and Quinn series.  This is in sharp contrast to a subsequent pairing of Jack and super spy Codename: Chandler in the novella CODENAME:CHANDLER:FIX, by FPW, JA Konrath and Ann Peterson, that gave insight into both Jack and Chandler's personalities and modi operandi.The best thing about INFERNAL NIGHT is hinted at by the title, and will only make sense to fans of Repairman Jack.  For us, it was a lovely bit that filled in a bit more of the Secret History of the World long after I thought I had seen the last of it.  That's about as specific as I can get without a spoiler alert.Overall, just OK.  If you're looking for more excellent, new Jack,  try CODENAME:CHANDLER:FIX.JM Tepper

SEEDS OF A NEW BIRTH: A GENETIC ENGINEERING SCIENCE FICTION THRILLER is the first of a series of SF novels concerning a genetically enhanced 'Kindred", all offspring of Flip MacDougal who, in a hokey lab accident while visiting a friend, has his sperm altered and in an equally hokey plot contrivance, goes about for "one last night" with a group of former lovers who, Flip has just discovered, knew each other and had been sharing him, as a kind of no-strings-attached sex toy.  Each becomes pregnant from the last one night stand (despite that fact that all had been using birth control of one sort or another even though Flip had had a vasectomy many years ago.  Each experiences an accelerated pregnancy and delivers a girl in 9 weeks.  The children grow at an accelerated pace and possess awesome telepathic, telekinetic and other super mental abilities.I was primed to like this novel. The description was right up my alley. But the writing turned out to be only fair, and there are a number of errors that are either typographical or from ignorance (e.g., confusing stallion with gelding, confusing peak with peek and so on).  This is not great literature, but is serviceable enough for the story.  My biggest problem, however, and one that I could not overlook, was the terrible and unrealistic science in the science fiction.  The opening lab scene where Flip spills a beaker of some highly dangerous molecular biological reagent and then is told to to to the bathroom to wash his hands is truly laughable in many ways.  Dangerous reagent such as the one imagined here are never on a lab bench top- they are inside protective laminar flow hoods in specially designed Biosafety Level 4 containment rooms that people cannot just walk into.  Forgetting all this for a moment, if a spill such as described were to happen anyway, the decontamination process would be local and immediate, before Flip could nonchalantly walk to the bathroom, touching who knows how many doorknobs and handles in the process, and having a pee, all before bothering to wash off in the sink (while contaminating the sink and bathroom in the process.And then there is the magical reagent itself, that is described only in the barest of sciencey-sounding terms that make no sense.  But that's OK, since the whole story depends of Flip impregnating all these women with his newly mutated sperm, years after he had a vasectomy, which, in case you didn't know, cuts and ties off the tubes that deliver sperm to the outside world.  Finally, the reagent was created to affect the germ line (sperm and egg) - why then did Flip also develop telepathy?  I could go on but think I've made my point.If you don't care at all about the non-existent science and logic, and are enchanted by the idea of superpowered telepathic, telekinetic babies a lá John Wyndham's far superior and terrifying THE MIDWICH CUCKOOS (later turned into at least two films entitled Village of the Damned ), then you might like this.  On the other hand, for one that is a serious reader of science fiction, this one (that I downloaded for free) is a pass, which is what I intend to do with the rest of the series.JM Tepper

SCENES FROM THE SECRET HISTOR OF THE WORLD is a helpful chronological listing of all F.Paul Wilson's works over the years dealing with TSHOTW, complete with brief introductions written especially for this compendium.  At $0.99 for this Kindle-only epub, it offers glimpses of all the novels and short stories that comprise TSHOTW, in chronological order (not in order of publication), and includes books and stories that are not part of either the REPAIRMAN JACK series or the ADVERSARY CYCLE.  Although there is almost no new material here (except for the very brief intros to each entry), and one cannot buy this and read it like a novel or an anthology, it is interesting nonetheless for FPW fans who might well have read all of the RJ novels or the ADVERSARY CYCLE, but not the rest of the canon.  It might also serve as an introduction to TSHOTW and to both of the series referred to above for a newcomer to FPW's world.  Even for die-hard fans who have read (or think they have read) everything about TSOTW, there is a never before published very detailed chronology of the major characters and players in TSOTW that alone is worth the $099 for fans like me.Recommended.JM Tepper

This is an unusual offering from author  Bill DeSmedt and  physicist John Adler. This is not your usual kindle only novel.  Allow me to explain. More than 10 years ago (2004), first-time author Bill DeSmedt published an outstanding sci-fi action thriller called SINGULARITY.  In addition to excellent writing and plotting, the science was superb (see my, and other reviews for SINGULARITY). Recently (in late 2014) DeSmedt released the sequel to SINGULARITY called "DUALITY".  It too, was excellent, and the science behind the fiction well founded in contemporary concepts in artificial intelligence and quantum computing (yes, that's a real thing).Here, in THE SINGULARITY FILES:AUDIOBOOK AND SCIENCE SEMINARS, a free kindle offering from authors DeSmedt and Adler, there are links to free downloads of SINGULARITY, read by the author, as well as printed excerpts from SINGULARITY and the sequel, DUALITY.  None of this appealed to me, free or otherwise, since I had already paid for and read both SINGULARITY and DUALITY. But, the new "Bonus Feature" that made me download this item  was the "Science Seminars".  These are 17 or so chapters (or seminars: "Doctor Jack's Soapbox Seminars") that comprises about 50% of the text in this highly unusual kindle-only offering.  THESE SEMINARS ARE THE ONLY THING THAT IS COVERED IN THIS REVIEW.  For the novels themselves, see the Amazon review pages for the novels. (Both are superb).The"" "seminars" are written by a physicist, ProfessorJohn C. Adler,  who provided the nitty gritty science behind the black hole and quantum mechanics that are central to SINGULARITY's plot. Adler focuses on black hole physics and a bit of cosmology to bolster his theory, written up by DeSmedt in the novel as fact, that the Tunguska Event of June 1908 was caused by a microscopic black hole consisting of a magnetic monopole impacting the earth, but not exiting, instead, orbiting inside the earth, around its center of gravity.  This is an immensely cool idea.  The "seminars" are a mini (or micro or nano) course in black hole physics for the layman with a little thermodynamics and quantum physics thrown in.  One need not be a physicist to understand them, just curious with a bit of high school physics will do.  I enjoyed them very much, although there was little new there that I had not already come across after reading several non-fiction books in quantum physics and relativity by folks like Brian Greene, Stephen Hawking, Paul Davies and others.  But for others who are curious, but not curious enough to want to wade through a bunch of (completely enjoyable and well written) physics for laymen, Adler compresses a ton of stuff into relatively few pages.  Bravo to him! It is a fun, interesting and easy read.  One small quibble is that it is (deliberately I think) written in a folksy, homespun style, often agrammatical, that set my teeth on edge at times. But this complaint pales in terms of the great job of making some very heavy (heh, heh) concepts in physics completely comprehensible to the average joe.Finally, you ought to read both SINGULARITY and DUALITY.  Or at least read the reviews.  They are both outstanding.Highly Recommended (how not, since it's free?)JM Tepper

DUALISM does for AI and quantum computing what SINGULARITY did for black holes, relativity and quantum mechanics. DUALISM isn't a sequel as much as it is a new adventure for Bonaventure and Knox, the heroine and hero who saved the world from a madman in SINGULARITY.This time out the excellent science behind the fiction revolves around true AI, made possible because of the advent of large scale quantum computing. Consultant Jonathan Knox is hired by the world's 4th richest man, who is a tech genius,to find his kidnapped 6 year old daughter. Time is of the essence since the little girl suffers from a seizure disorder that requires constant treatment to prevent permanent brain damage and death.But the as Knox gets closer and closer to figuring out who is behind the kidnapping, the situation morphs into a much more widespread threat to the entire USA. Bonaventure enters the picture, and the pace increases to supersonic.Well defined characters with distinctive voices distinguished DeSmedt's first novel and the same is true for DUALISM. Excellent research and scientific believability are also hallmarks of both novels. Ten years is a long time to wait for a sequel (The upcoming sequel was announced around 2005), but the wait was worth it. I just hope I don't have to wait another decade for TRIPLOIDY, the announced third in THE ARCHON series.Recommended.JM Tepper

Advice that is often given to aspiring writers is something like "write what you know".  It must be good advice because so many end up at one time or another having their protagonist be a writer of some kind.  Stephen King has done it on multiple occasions (e.g., MISERY, THE DARK HALF, BAG OF BONES), and one recent example that I liked very much was THE PEN NAME by David Jacob Knight.TRANSCRIPTION is Ike Hamill's contribution to this large body of work and it is a winner.  Hamill is an amazingly prolific writer of horror fiction that I only found recently.  TRANSCRIPTION is the fourth of his novels that I have read, published late last year.Thomas Hicks is a journalist/writer who discovers a curious fact about a soon to be destroyed old prison.  Over the course of several decades, 4 men, who were notable for going on horribly violent, gruesome and mayhem-filled murderous crime sprees, all did so after being incarcerated in one cell in the prison.  Hicks becomes intensely curious about this strange pattern, and manages to get permission to spend one night in the infamous cell just before the long-decommissioned prison is about to be razed to the ground.Flash forward to the present where Hicks' son, James, is an early middle-aged agoraphobic alcoholic shut-in who spends all night writing, but never publishes anything.  James lives along in an apartment complex and is befriended by a much younger guy named Bo, and eventually two of Bo's female friends, Chloe and Danielle.  Slowly, as the novel flips back and forth between the late 1970s via Thomas Hicks' diary and letters written to his then-infant son, and the present, the explanation for James' bizarre behavior is revealed. It is a horror that James has carefully kept bottled up, but it is is accidentally unleashed and has the potential to destroy the world.Unlike some of Hamill's other novels that I've read so far, this one has no SF and is flat-out horror.  Although there are some pretty gruesome scenes early on, it is the slow reveal and insidious nature of what is really going on that is the centerpiece of the novel.  I'll apologize for repeating myself because I've said this in other reviews of Hamill's work, but the plot of TRANSCRIPTION really did remind me of a Stephen King novel.  I'll go further here and predict that Uncle Stevie would read TRANSCRIPTION with a smile and think, "Hey, this guy's not bad".  The plot is completely original and the writing is solid.  There are really only 5 characters, Thomas and James, and Bo, Chloe and Danielle.  The first three are the best developed, but I think I'd be friends with the all of them. At a compact 281 pages or so (I read my copy on my iPad), there is a lot of plot development and suspense building in relatively few pages.  I found the ending solid and appropriate, although your mileage may vary.Highly Recommended.JM Tepper

INSTINCT is part two of a two-book single story that began with EXTINCT.  Read no further either here or in the novel itself until you have read EXTINCT; the two are not novel and sequel but parts one and two of one story.The epic journey to find the source of the apocalypse continues.  Robby fell into some sort of catatonic state at the end of INSTINCT, and is being carried along and cared for by Brad, Lisa, and Romie as they try find the rest of their group that fragmented during the latter part of EXTINCT.  We get some more explanation of what is going on and what has happened.  In the interests of avoiding spoilers, if you have already read EXTINCT I think it is safe to say that Robby believes that all the events that have occurred are part of an alien invasion, but of an original and bizarre kind.There are very clear hints that this has happened before, and that it is possible to do something to stop it  There are strange glyphs in a completely unknown language that survivors find strewn, graffiti-like, written or painted on walls and various surfaces.  Looking at them under certain conditions causes very strange behaviors in the viewer.  The narrative drops in and out on several different groups of survivors who have banded together, first to just survive and then try and do something about what has happened.  The main characters speak with different voices and we care about them.  Some new ones are introduced and some old friends die.  Again, the "feel" of the story, but not necessarily the writing style, was very Stephen King-like, either by intent or subconsciously, as author Hamill lists King as one of his major influences.Just as in EXTINCT, the writing and pacing are excellent, and the book is hard to put down.  The characters are memorable, and mostly likable.  The ending is a real ending and is satisfying, although there remain several unanswered questions of the who and how variety that might bug some readers.  The same was true of Hamill's THE CLAIMING, and I think it is just a part of his own unique style of story telling.  It didn't really bother me at all.Recommended.JM Tepperdisclaimer:  I received an electronic copy of this novel in exchange for an honest review.

BERZERKER is my first Theo Cage novel.  It's a SF-horror story set in North Dakota, one of the double handful of states that I have never visited. If the climate in BERZERKER is anything like that in the real North Dakota, I think I'll just take a pass.Royal Canadian Mounted Policeman Sean Chiller (nice double or triple entendre there), his wife, Tracy, and their little girl, Ashley, are on their way to Fargo ND to seek treatment for Ashley's cystic fibrosis.  She's got it bad, and lives on intravenous antibiotics delivered through an indwelling central line.  The prognosis is grim with conventional medicine but there is a clinic in Fargo, ND (not NYC, Boston or Quebec??) that offers a possible state-of-the-art gene therapy cure. It's winter and there is a horrific blizzard dumping feet of snow as Sean and family are en route.  Eventually the conditions are so bad that, in need of gas, they exit the highway and find themselves in a tiny town called ominously, Berzerker. The townspeople are strangely unfriendly, the one "hotel" is dirty and disgusting, and Ashley is running a fever and the Chillers have run out of antibiotics. The power goes out and thing go from bad to really fahrblonjet.BERZERKER is both sci-fi and horror, and both elements are done well.  As a biologist, I need for the science to be at least minimally feasible and that criterion is satisfied, with a McGuffin that involves genetically modified organisms or GMOs. The horror is scary, and the suspense, particularly at the end is high.  Interestingly, the suspense does not revolve around a big reveal, as what is really going on in the town of Berzerker is revealed to Sean and the reader about halfway through.  But there are other twists and turns to the plot, and eventually all the birds come home to roost.Recommended.JM Tepperdisclaimer: I received an electronic copy of the novel from the author in exchange for an honest review.

I first came across Ike Hamill with THE CLAIMING, an excellent and original modern horror tale.  I really enjoyed it and found that he had written several others (actually something like 13 since 2011, a remarkably large number of novels)!  I asked his what he recommended next and he said EXTINCT.  EXTINCT is actually part 1 of a two part novel (the second half is called INSTINCT and is not so much a sequel as a continuation of the former.  EXTINCT starts out introducing a number of characters in several settings.  Very soon, extremely odd and bad things start  to happen. People disappear in broad daylight.  A strange, rapidly growing prickly new vine appears in a Maine field. Strange tornadoes, killer streams and then a massive snowfall.  Pretty soon, the large majority of folks up and down the Northeast are dead.  Survivors meet up with one another (a la THE STAND) and follow Robby,  a preternaturally intelligent young teenager, to search for the source of the catastrophe.EXTINCT reminded me of a Stephen King novel, in particular THE STAND in several ways.  The coming together of strangers in the  face of a world-ending apocalypse, nature gone rogue, a young hero who knows more than he should, and an arduous, epic journey.  The writing is very, very good. Not quite as graphic as SK's, perhaps less vividly descriptive, but with excellent pacing, plotting and characters nonetheless.  The mystery of what is happening is revealed only very slowly throughout the novel, adding to the tension and suspense.And there is a kind of resolution and ending, but one that is much more like a semicolon than a full stop.  It is as obvious that there is more to come as there would be if the author had ended with "To be continued...".  Nevertheless, a number of the early reviewers quite clearly failed to see this and gave this novel one or two stars because there was no ending.  This did not matter to me, because it was so clear that all I had to do was look at Amazon to find that the second part of the story had already been written and published.  I suppose this accounts for most of the earliest reviews consisting of one and two star pans of the novel while the vast majority of the latter reviews were 4 and 5 stars.I liked it a lot, and downloaded and started INSTINCT immediately after reading EXTINCT.  If you like Stephen King's stories, I'll bet you like Ike Hamill's too.Recommended.JM Tepperdisclaimer:  The author sent me an electronic version of this novel in exchange for an honest review.

ONYX WEBB: BOOK TWO: EPISODES 4, 5 & 6 picks up immediately after the events of BOOK ONE; This is actually a very long serialized novel, akin to Stephen King's THE GREEN MILE, that will ultimately comprise 10 books and over 2,000 pages.  As in the first installment, it constantly switches time periods; from the mid-1930s, the 1980s and 2010.  It begins again with a section narrated by Onyx, as a ghost in 2010.  The three main threads established in book one begin to converge as we get some strong hints to the relationship between Onyx and at least one of the other two main character/families in the novel.We get a lot more of Onyx in BOOK TWO: EPISODES 4, 5 & 6. Onyx is now all grown up and has, against her father's wishes, run off with Ulrich Schröder at the end of BOOK ONE.  Ulrich has gotten himself into some trouble and is now on the run with Onyx in tow.  Daddy was right, and Ulrich is NOT the kind of guy that you want anywhere near your daughter, but, well that's how life goes sometimes.  Onyx has turned onto a beautiful,  trusting woman who is also a fantastically talented painter, blindly in love with Ulrich.The founder of the Mulvaney dynasty, Declan, is an orphan in a church run orphanage, where things are, shall we say, no bed of roses.  One of the connections between threads is revealed in his story, that also takes up a substantial portion of the story, both in the 1930s and 2010. The story of Koda and Dane continues and gets complicated and a ghost in the story is introduced.And then there are Juniper and Quinn, and his Quinn's best friend, Wayne, in the late 1970s and 1980s the latter of whom finds himself in some serious trouble.Amy more would be bad spoilers and I want to avoid that at all costs.  I raved about the first installment , ONYX WEBB: BOOK ONE: EPISODES 1, 2 & 3 with a five star review.  This one is even better and I am completely hooked.  I am repeating myself when I say that the writing and pacing are terrific and that all the main characters are very well drawn and realistic  Some are very likable and some not.Highly recommended but needless to say, you MUST read part one first.J.M. Tepperdisclaimer.  The authors were kind enough to gift me a Kindle copy of ONYX WEBB: BOOK TWO: EPISODES 4, 5 & 6  after I asked for more after finishing BOOK ONE.

ONYX WEBB: BOOK ONE: EPISODES 1, 2 & 3 is the first foray into fiction by the  Richard Fenton and Andrea Waltz, a  husband and wife team who have previously published a series of  successful motivational non-fiction books.  ONYX WEBB: BOOK ONE  is projected as the  opening salvo of a 10 book, 27 episode series.  With each book so far (Book Two has just been released) coming in at well over 200 pages, OW looks to be a 2,000 page story.But this is good news for lovers of mysteries, ghost stories and horror fiction, as OW 1 is a very interesting, thrilling opening to the longer story.  It flips back and forth in time from 1904 to 2010, with several intermediary stops during which the main characters are introduced.  The opening narration is by Onyx, who in 2010 is a ghost, but somehow still able to interact with the world of the living.  As a little girl in 1904, she is abducted at the St. Louis Exposition by an insane serial killer, but with the help of her father, Catfish and a police detective, she manages to escape, freeing the imprisoned next victim just before she was about to be killed as well.Another story line opens up in 2010 featuring Koda Mulvaney, 20-something heir to a billion dollar family fortune, who with his pal, Dane, has just managed to blow $20M of his inheritance in 2 years flying around the world staying at the most expensive hotels and partying his ass off with wine (mostly Crystal) and women until his father yanks him back home and puts him to work.And finally in 1971 we meet Juniper Cole, child piano prodigy appearing on the Tonight Show and then a few years later, as a beautiful young woman living with her brother-guardian Quinn who dropped out of College to care for Juniper when they father disappeared with another woman and their mother disappeared into the bottom of a bottle.,There is no possible way to connect all these events and people, as EPISODES 1, 2 & 3 are merely the set up (part of the set-up) to a very large and complicated story that will span over 100 years.  But the writing and pacing are terrific.  There are already several very likable characters as well as some not-so-likable ones, and there is Onyx, who hardly appears at all.If the rest of this series is anything like the ONYX WEBB: BOOK ONE: EPISODES 1, 2 &3, anyone who enjoys a good ghost story, a mystery and/or a thriller will certainly like this.  This is not a children's book.  It contains no graphic sex but does contain some graphic violence, but Fenton and Webb manage to (skillfully) keep most of that stuff implied and/or off-screen, so if one likes horror thrillers that are PG-13 rated, here you go.Highly recommendedJM Tepperdisclaimer:  I received an e-copy of this novel in exchange for a no-strings-attached review .

I ordered a pair of these in size XXL.  For my running shorts, I usually buy XL or XXL, depending on the manufacturer (Eddie Bauer, Land's End etc.).  These XXL were so small that I could not even attempt to put them on.  The material seems fine and the quality OK, but the sizing is way, way off.  I would guestimate that would need a 4 or 5XL from this manufacturer. The XXL that I ordered would not even fit my wife and my 14 year old son who wears Levis 28" waist could barely squeeze into them.Since I couldn't wear them, I can't comment on comfort or wearability.JM TepperDisclaimer:  I received these shorts in exchange for a no strings attached review.

The Crescendo CR-10 capo is a well-made, beautiful spring lock alloy capo.  Mine is electroplated in some gold colored substance and really looks great with my Les Paul Deluxe Gold top and Gibson CS-356 Custom, both of which have gold plated hardware.  The capo works great.  As you can see from the image on the Amazon page, the mechanism is on the bottom, leaving only the bar on top that makes for maximum playability.  The spring is powerful, but not too powerful to manipulate with one hand. I've tried it on both of my GIbsons, my Strat and my Ovation acoustic.  It works great on all of them.It comes with a little soft bag for storage so it won't get scratched.  I don't know what the alloy is, but it feels heavy enough to be steel.  The capo is very well made, with a thick rubber strip on the top bar and a thinner, ridged strip on the clamp below the neck.  This is the best looking, best made capo that I own.Highly recommended.JM Tepperdisclaimer: I received this capo from the manufacturer in exchange for a no strings attached honest review.

THE CLAIMING is a scary, anxiety-provoking modern horror story that is completely original despite evoking a feeling of familiarity, like a folk tale that is half remembered or a cultural meme that one can’t quite place.  Leo and Maria Webb-Sutley have just moved into a large but surprisingly inexpensive and rather run-down mansion that backs onto a cornfield in a high class but strangely deserted neighborhood. Maria is an architect with a new job and Leo (short for Leona) is deliberately unemployed, so that she can work on renovating the house that they intend to flip for a quick profit.  Reed has just entered the 10th grade in a new school and Lizzy and Kyra are about 8 and 6 years old respectively.Author Hamill takes his time introducing all five and their family dynamic that is completely typical, save for the fact that there are two moms and no dad. Reed is a good kid, regular stand-up guy, and the two little girls are best buddies.  The reason that the neighborhood is deserted is not entirely clear, but adds a little creepiness.  The deeper one reads, the creepier things get.  They adopt a faun after its mother is killed by some kind of predator and raise it as a pet after the girls fall in love with it.  Leo and Maria are not so happy about it but can't find anyone to take it.  Things really start getting very weird when Lizzy starts seeing strange people dressed in robes that set off screaming fits.  By this time a feeling of inexorable dread and unease sets in for the reader (for some reason I was reminded of the original film “The Wickerman”, even though the plots of this novel and that movie share almost nothing in common).And then things start to get bloody -  very bloody.  Disaster strikes the family. There is violence and mayhem.  The sanity of some of the main characters begins to come into question.  The family dynamic breaks down.  And worse.  To say any more is to give away too much in this entirely original, yet still somehow familiar thriller.The writing is excellent and the pacing starts out slow and deliberate, and then begins a steady speed-up as the situation deteriorates from bad to very bad to unthinkable and then some.  This is very much a plot driven novel, but Maria, Reed, Leo and the two girls are described in enough detail to make them three-dimensional characters that one cares about.  I read a lot of horror and want to be scared, afraid to turn the page to see what is coming but at the same time needing to turn the pages faster and faster.  THE CLAIMING did that for me, in much the same way that the best of Stephen King, F. Paul Wilson, Blake Crouch, William Peter Blatty and a handful of others have done previously.There is my first Ike Hamill novel and there are bunch of others out there that I look forward to with great relish.Highly recommended.JM TepperDisclaimer:  I received a free, no-strings-attached electronic copy of THE CLAIMING from the author with no guarantees that I would even finish it.  I’m very glad I did.

This is the first and only headlamp that I have ever owned, so perhaps take my enthusiastic review with a grain of salt. My headlamp looks just like the rendering on the Amazon page, although one cannot have the main LED the two smaller side LEDs and the little red LED on all the time, as they are all active in one or more of the 5 different modes that the lamp has.Opening the lamp to insert the 3 (included) AAA batteries is a snap and there is only a single, conveniently large button on the top to control the thing.  A single click turns it on and repeating the singe click turns it off.  The next single click turns it back on, but also toggles between the main LED and the two smaller side LEDs.  Holding the button down in either mode decreases the intensity from what (to me) is blindingly bright to very dim and then eventually off.Switching to either the red light, red strobe or side lamps strobe is a little more tricky.  It seems to involve holding the button down for a few seconds depending on which of the two main modes you're in.  I've only had the lamp for a hour or so and now have gotten all modes to work by trial and error, but I can only switch between the main LED and side LEDs and adjust brightness with any confidence or reliability.  I'm sure I'll eventually figure out how to consistently access these other 3 modes, but it's not clear from my one hour experience or the one page instruction manual, and this caused me to deduct one star from my rating..The headband is comfortable and easy to adjust and the lamp assembly is small and lightweight.I originally ordered this for my wife who runs, sometimes as dusk, but I can think of a zillion uses for it, starting with looking under the bed or couch or on the floor for a small dropped item.  Add to that reading in bed or emergency power outage and this little headlamp has many, many potential uses.  It seems a bit pricey for a small flashlight, but it obviously does a lot more than a single small flashlight and the price seems about right to me.Recommended.JM TepperDisclaimer:  The manufacturer asked me if I was interesting in trying this headlamp in exchange for a no-strings attached review, which this is.

INFERNAL starts off with a bang  and accelerates from there.  Richard Farris and his Saint Bernard, Charlie, are are minding their own business in an isolated Kansas house during a huge snowstorm and power outage, when Charlie brings back a bloody mitten.  Richard ventures out into a blizzard and finds a young woman, barely alive, bleeding from a gunshot wound.  Other than the fact that she has some new kind of cell phone that Richard can't figure out how to work, there is nothing unusual except that the woman is badly hurt and will likely bleed out if RIchard can't get her to a doctor  very soon.The next day an unrecognizable paramilitary force arrives, breaking down the door, guns a'blazing.  From out of nowhere, Richard pulls out some firepower of his own and fights back, both for his and the unknown woman's life. Farris is more than he seems.INFERNAL starts out a a simple, exciting military thriller.  Lots of gunplay, helicopters  and chases.  Just when you think you have a handle at least on the genre, INFERNAL takes a rather abrupt left into interesting SF based around the concept of a multiverse, consisting of an infinitude of universes like ours, but differing from ours in small details (for some) and huge things in others.  The bulk of the first part of the novel follows Richard and Sophia as they try to flee from world to world trying to evade the forces of BanaTech, a huge company bent on controlling the entire multiverse, and destroying Richard, who as it turns out, is someone special quite unique and dangerous to BanaTech's plans.  Just as you become comfortable enough to categorize this as a straight-up SF adventure, the author beers off at an angle, throwing metaphysical- religious considerations into the mix. Enough synopsis, to reveal more risks spoilers.INFERNAL is the first novel by Browder, who in 2012 released an outstanding anthology of very original, scary and darkly humorous horror/SF short stories (DARK MATTERS) and last year a novella, PLAGUE, a grim take on a medical apocalypse that was also excellent.  Browder has an easy way with words, ideas and plots - that much was obvious from DARK MATTERS.  His writing gives the reader the feeling that the author knows what he is talking about.  I don't know much about guns or the military, but all the gunplay and military stuff (and there is quite a bit) seemed very real to me.  The SF is also well done and his multiverse seems based on a one of the several currently viable theories of quantum mechanics, Hugh Everett's "Many Worlds Interpretation, described at length in a recent Brain Greene non-fiction book for lay folk.  The characters are well formed, and we care about them, and I especially liked the dialogue, in that people in the situations described in the novel would really talk they way that thy are written, so if you are easilyboffended by 4-letter words in common parlance, be warned.I liked INFERNAL  a lot, as I did Browder's earlier works, and look forward to more, from any of his universes.RecommendedJM Tepperdisclosure: I wrote to the author after buying and reviewing DARK MATTERS and asked to be put on his mailing list.  We have been corresponding via email since then, and I got a chance to see pieces of INFERNAL as well an ARC of the finished novel.

This is very short story about an American woman one month from her wedding who is jilted on New Year's Eve, by phone (!).  She decides to go ahead on her pre-arranged honeymoon to Glasgow(?!) where she meets a charming, young (presumably) Scot, and despite her former fianceé showing up, goes on happily (presumably) ever after with her new biracial (?!) Scottish boyfriend.I suppose that this is a first effort for the author - perhaps an assignment for a writing class (?).  The grammar, vocabulary and sentence structure are all technically fine, albeit on the simple side.  Where the story fails completely is in the description of the characters and the motivations for their actions.  To describe them as one-dimensional would be an understatement.  There is nothing there. Does Anna work? What does she do?  What does she look like?  What does she like?  Dislike.  Ditto for Robert, the ex-fianceé, and Alexander the Scot who befriends Anna.  Why was the significance of Alexander's biraciality?Why Glasgow for a honeymoon?  That made me laugh out loud.  Having been lucky enough to travel in Scotland several times, I don't think there'd be much argument that on a list of the 10 top tourist attractions in Scotland, Glasgow would be around #23.  Fortunately, there is next to no description of Glasgow either and I suspect that the author picked the name out of a hat and hasn't a clue what the city is like, or even bothered to do any research about it or much of anything else.I was sent an e-mail containing a pdf of this short story unsolicited, and asked for a review, an action that I consider spam. I therefore wrote a completely honest review in which I pulled no punches, made no attempts to soften the blows.  Normally I would not post such a negative review.MS.  Davis, in the future, and I hope you have a long and successful career as an author, I advise you to pay careful heed to all the things that I said in the review.  Additionally, I advise you to learn that all writing requires some research, even for a simply love story.  A couple of minutes of internet surfing would have revealed that Edinburgh would have been an infinitely better setting, packed full of  well-described landmarks that you could have used in your story to add verisimilitude (of which there was none).  A few Gaelic phrases thrown in is another thing that would have added some badly needed verisimilitude.  It's important the reader feel like he/she is really there - and the author is responsible for that, by providing lots of little factoids and examples to keep the reader in the setting and lend confidence that the author knows what he/she is doing.Lastly, I  strongly suggest that before sending our your work, you first contact a reviewer and ask if they might be interested in reviewing your work.  That way they have a chance to decline or not respond, in which case you just write them off.  I sincerely hope that these rather harsh but intended as constructive criticisms serve to improve your future writing efforts.J.M. Tepper

Always wanted one and picked this one up while looking for another knife.  Now I don't know how we got along without it.  If you want to dice vegetables, this is far easier than using a conventional knife.  We've used ours for months now with no sign of dulling, or cracking or rusting as a few others have noted.  I'm note sure why some owners have trouble - the vast majority like this one are  5 star reviews.  It's much better and  easier to clean than the dice-o-matic gizmo I had previously.

These work just as well as the the originals, but at a significant savings.  I was a little scared by some of the negative reviews but thought I would give them a shot anyway.  I am glad I did.  Mine work just fine, no leaking or streaking or anything like that, but given some of the awful reviews, I suppose your mileage may vary.Recommended.JM Tepper

SEVENEVES shares much in common with  a lot of Neal Stephenson's work; it's long, it's very well researched and well written, and it makes one think - hard.  Also in common with his last couple of novels, the title is particularly appropriate on at least a couple of different levels. SEVENEVES is a hard core, hard sci-fi outer space epic, clocking in at over 860 pages in my paperback ARC copy.Stephenson wastes little time, blowing up the moon in the first line of the novel.  We never find out why or how, but it turns out not to matter, because astronomers, astrophysicists and other scientists quickly realize that although the 7 giant chunks of rock orbiting where the moon used to be are not stable, and very bad things are going to happen in about 2 years. Like the end of all life on the surface of the earth.  The first 2/3 of the novel describe what the human race does to try to prepare for the inevitable destruction of everything and everyone on the planet, by mobilizing all possible resources and launching as many rockets and people as possible into orbit using present-day technology, and importantly, a key player is a non-NASA, non-government Elon Musk-type billionaire who can see what is going to happen better than almost everyone else and takes matters into his own hands.  The end result is a kind of a Battlestar Galactica type ragtag fleet of small habitats in low earth orbit centered around what used to be the International Space Station, rapidly expanded and enlarged with the NASA equivalent of bubble gum and shoelaces.  There is a lot of orbital mechanics here and lots of explanations that some may find tedious and difficult to understand that are fun for science geeks, but could have been trimmed significantly, although the simple facts of space travel and and rendezvousing with objects moving at thousands of miles per hour do factor significantly into the plot.  How the first part of the novel ends is surprising and unexpected (at least to me) although Stephenson gives us hints all along including in the publisher's blurb.The second part of the novel fast forwards 5,000 years, as against all odds, humanity has not only survived but flourished and is in the process of re-seeding the earth in preparation for recolonizing it, something that has only been possible for the past few hundred years.  Stephenson's world building, like he did in ANATHEM, comes into full bloom as we see the results of 5,000 years of selective breeding and genetic manipulation that was forced by circumstances upon the original spacers.  Instead of concentrating on space travel, this last part concentrates on sociology, genetics, epigenetics and politics, all done with Stephenson's flair for detail and plotting.I write this one day after finishing SEVENEVES so perhaps as it settles in my brain I will feel differently, but at this point, I think SEVENEVES is an excellent space adventure, but perhaps not as captivating to me as ANATHEM or CRYPTONOMICON, hence four stars.Recommended.JM Tepper

This is flat out the best Lightning to USB cable that I have ever seen. It is about 2 meters long for those who need extra length.  The cable cover is braided nylon and very strong.  Both the Lightning and USB connectors are extraordinarily securely fastened to each end of the cable with high quality flexible strain relievers.  This cable will not break or short out. I delayed this review by about a month to use the cable to charge my iPhone 6 daily, plugging and unplugging  both ends at least twice a day.  Nothing has changed over a month.  Nothing has loosened or shifted.  The cable is easy to coil up for short length use and is super flexible so immediately returns to its full length when unwound with no kinks or bends.The Lightning end is small and fits into my iPhone 6 without having to remove the Belkin protective case (also unlike about half of the other Lightning cables I own).  The cable is (unlike every other non-Apple cable that I own - that number around 6 or 7 different makes) also 100% Apple compatible. No message saying "This accessory may not be compatible with this Apple device". It is the real deal and the price is cheap considering the length and build quality.Highly recommended.JM Tepperp.s. 3 months later after every day use, still working perfectly.disclaimer:  I was sent one of these cables by the manufacturer in exchange for a no-strings-attached impartial review (as are all my reviews, including the one and two star reviews that I have given similar free items).

EXTINCTION  EDGE (THE EXTINCTION CYCLE BOOK 2) picks up right where its predecessor quit.  In the middle of an all-out war against a rogue bioweapon-induced full on apocalypse.  Author Smith still has more tricks up his sleeve.  After Dr. Kate Lovato comes up with a molecular biological counter weapon for the mutated Ebola/Vx99 super soldier serum that has transformed most of humanity into maddened, ravening, mindless beasts, you'd think all would be well.  Uhhh...., sorry not this time.  Although the "cure" does what it is supposed to, i.e., render the mutated Ebola virus once again deadly, killing off most of the infected, there is an unforeseen side effect.  A very nasty one.  About 10% of the infected are not killed by the new virus because were immune to Ebola in the first place (Ebola in actuality really has a kill rate of "only" 60-90%).  Worse, the virus triggers rapid epigenetic changes in the survivors, changing them and imbuing them with enhanced sensory abilities, strength, speed, Spiderman-like wall crawling abilities and worst of all, an constantly evolving sort of intelligence. These "Variants" are far more difficult to kill than the original Ebola/Vx99 victims and they're smart. Maybe too smart.While the middle third of a trilogy often proves to be a letdown, a kind of filler between the opener and finale in a series, this time Smith doubles down on the tension and excitement. There are a couple of new characters introduced and one of Beckham's boys who was critically injured in the first novel along with another soldier who lost both legs in another battle are left to defend Kate et alia on Plum Island while Beckham and his company are back in NYC battling for their lives.  As in the first book, chapters alternate between events on Plum Island and NYC, and the characters seem real, including a crazed general who refuses to believe what is in front of his eyes.I liked this novel very much and am now impatient for the finale but I suspect I have a bit of a wait on my hands.Recommended for fans of military sci-fi and those who like the style of Crighton, Rollins and Beck.JM Tepperdisclaimer:  The author kindly sent me an ARC of this novel upon my request in exchange for a no-strings-attached review, after I read the first in the series and asked for more.

THE SPACE BETWEEN is a short story/novella (~100 pages) that occupies the space between the last two OUTLANDER NOVELS, AN ECHO IN THE BONE and WRITTEN IN MY HEART'S OWN BLOOD.  It takes place in Paris in the mid 1770s, and focuses on Joan, Jaimie's stepdaughter who in en route  to a become a nun.  Joan, it turns out, hears voices and is prescient. The fill in of her back story is fascinating and welcome.  But the most interesting characters are the return from the (presumed) dead of le Comte de Saint Germain and M. Grenouillle, the very mysterious frog-like alchemist/sorcerer/time traveler who knows what from several novels back.The writing is still enchanting and the plotting still captivating.  Ant the characters!  Often the weakest part of fiction, Gabaldon makes them all come alive and the complex interpersonal relationships are fascinating.  This novella focuses much more on the fantasy/sci-fi aspects of time travel and alchemy than most of the novels, and is welcome for it.  The whole series is an amazing amalgam of historical fiction, fantasy and sic-fi, military strategy and romance, and is absolutely addicting.Highly Recommended for fans.JM Tepper

EXTINCTION HORIZON is the first in a projected trilogy that mixes man-made monsters and the military.  As a tried and true trope (OK, enough alliteration already), a somewhat crazed General is behind the development of a serum that will create enhanced fighting men for our armed forces, something akin to Captain America.  Needless to say, something goes horribly wrong, and the virus creates insane subhuman monsters with a thirst for blood.  Years later, in an attempt to eradicate the Ebola virus, another scientist comes up with a man-made virus that in combination with Vx-99 creates a plague of superstrong, superviolent  killers. .These are not zombies, they move very quickly.  And they are very hard to kill.  And the modified Ebola virus quickly spreads to infect every major city.  There was enough science in the science fiction to satisfy everyone but a molecular virologist, and the research that the author did really shows.  The action scenes were also well done, and for most of the novel chapters cut back and forth between following Master Sergeant Reed Beckham and his men trying to control things in NYC and elsewhere, and scientist-love interest Kate Lovato back on a last-stand fort on NY's Plum Island desperately trying to figure out what the hell is going on and how to stop it.No more spoilers for you.  You'll have to read it.  When I did, I wrote the author and asked for an ARC of the second part.  That ought to sum up how I felt about EXTINCTION HORIZON.  Are there some flaws?  Sure.  Do I think the author will continue to improve as a writer? You bet. But for right now, as is, more than good enough!  I'll post a review for part 2 as soon as Amazon allows. For a fast paced, interesting blend of military and science fiction, try this one.Recommended.JM Tepper

I really love this particular product.  I first use either Millionails (which I like) as a base (2 coats)  or my favorite one Sally Hanson Continuous Treatment, Growth formula, which is a clear base coat type strengthener that is very long lasting and effective.  Two coats of that.  Then I use Essie's Grow Stronger which also adds more strength, but more important to me, it actually gives an ever so slight bit of "almost there" but not opaque tint that I really like….it's color without being color, and doesn't show wear damage or chips, and just looks more "finished" than a totally clear coat. It has a consistency that applies beautifully and doesn't show mistakes like darker colors do.  Finally, this combo of things is extremely long lasting.  Both the Sally Hansen base and these two Essie products are impressively fast drying, although I do help things along by using my hair dryer set on "cool".  I hate doing my nails, so I'm a happy camper because finally my nails look fantastic yet are still fairly low maintenance.

Absolutely perfect for making Greek style yogurt!  Yes, the insert mesh is fragile, but treat it right and there will be no problem.  The mesh is exactly what you need to be able to strain yogurt without losing anything but the whey.  I generally strain my yogurt for 3 hours.  Then I flip the insert upside down over an appropriately large bowl and all the yogurt falls right out into the bowl with no need to use a spoon to scoop out the insert.  I immediately rinse with hot water inside and out and make sure all the yogurt is off all parts, and this step is extremely easy to do as long as you do this immediately.  You can also fill up the bottom of the main container with warm soapy water and then dip the insert into that for more thorough cleaning, then rinse out well.  No need to ever push or rub on the mesh at all (and that could damage it I'm sure), and I keep utensils carefully away from the mesh.  I always make a yogurt batch of about 7 cups of yogurt and this container holds that initial amount perfectly. Of course from that 7 cups well over a cup of whey drains out, so the finished yogurt is a lot less than the initial 7 cups!  Great great product for Greek yogurt, a gazillion times better than other drainage methods I'd been using, there's really nothing better out there.  Love this thing!

I really do like this conditioner a lot.  It's not thick, but it gives a nice level of conditioning after every shampoo and it rinses out to the extent I want it to.  It doesn't weigh down the hair (and I have long hair, a fair amount of it, but each hair is fine) at all.  I wish the scent was the same as the matching shampoo (which I love love love).  The scent isn't great, but it's OK and after rinsing you don't smell it anyway.  The product arrives quickly and is wrapped well (in shrink wrap) so it won't leak, and at this size it really lasts quite a long time.  Definitely more affordable than in the beauty supply stores (if you can even find it there in this size).  However, price-wise on Amazon it seems to bop around a lot.

My top favorite green tea for drinking with my breakfast.  Years ago when I gave up my lifetime of black tea with sugar (had to give up sugar, didn't especially like black tea without it), I didn't especially like that under flavor of plain green tea….until I found this one.  The lemon flavor is ever so subtle, hardly identifiable as lemon, but I think the lemon must moderate that under flavor I dislike.  I truly haven't found any green tea I like better, and I've probably bought 100 or more boxes of this tea over the past few years.  I also like how each tea bag is inside an individual foil packet, so that makes it easy to carry a few of these in my purse.  I'll add that I don't especially like Bigelow's plain green tea.  A case of 12 boxes is a pretty good buy here, in most stores (unless on special) this tea can be as high as $3.69 (or more) per box of 20 tea bags!

This has a lovely flavor and it's one of several teas I have on hand at all times and always repurchase.  If I did a blind taste test, I'm not sure I would ever have guessed a peach-ginger combo, but it's still a wonderful tasting tea, and as I write this now this price is great.

I got this one to replace an older model from White Rogers…I'd had that one a long time but the heat up-down buttons were very small and no longer worked well.  I only have a heater (no AC) so this was probably overkill, but I wanted the much larger display that lights up so you can see the temps even in low to no light and I like the setup for the up and down buttons--so much easier to use. Extremely easy and quick to install (no brainer), and the little booklet that comes with it is quite clear and well presented.  I did call the company to ask a question, and I got efficient and pleasant tech help within just a few minutes.  Very pleased and I expect this one will last as many years as the old one.  Odd note:  Less than a week after I ordered, the price went up $5 from what I had paid.  I've seen this before with other items….does a purchase trigger an adjustment to a higher price for the next person?

I LOVE this stuff.  I'm rehabbing my long neglected nails and was searching for not only a good treatment/base coat product to allow my nails to grow and not break, but I also wanted an "almost color" that had a very sheer but slight bit of coverage and hint of tint, but which goes on smoothly and without streaks.  And something that is LASTING.  I got Essie's Millionails which seems pretty good as a base, but it has no color, just a nice shine.  I've bought about 4 or 5 Essie pale pinks (Ballet Slippers, several other in that color range) and none of them had the right color I wanted and when I put one color on each nail to compare, the colors were virtually identical, they were all too opaque and I didn't like the look so much.  But THIS is my holy grail, I adore this product.  It strengthens, goes on beautifully and easily with no possibility of streaking, it's sheer and imparts a tiny bit of tint and coverage without being a true color.  As I said, it's perfect for me in many ways.Now to price:  I don't know why this isn't offered at a reasonable price like the other Essie polishes and treatment products, but $23 is truly ridiculous (plus another $6 shipping!!).  I got mine at Rite Aid for $8.50.

Great tea, fabulous taste, but absurdly priced here.  I got from WF in the past (overpriced there as well, around 12 a can), but it's best bought directly from Zhena, currently 6.99.  Don't know why the price is so off base here.  I've also tried the Coconut Chai Black tea, equally good. Both teas have a subtle but delicious mixture of flavors, and the coconut is also quite muted.  Husband doesn't especially like coconut but he likes this tea.  I drink it a few times a week as a special treat.Edit note:  I never see the Green tea version of this anywhere, but I did see the black tea version (equally as tasty) in Bed Bath & Beyond and also World market for around $6.99.

So far, this seems like a great product. I especially like that what it does NOT have: No DBP, toluene, formaldehyde. That's a bonus for sure. I have terrible nails and I don't like to use darker polish (upkeep!) or fake nails. But I naturally have weak nails that break and split easily. My nails always do better with some sort of polish on them because that strengthens them more than in their natural state. After a long period of doing nothing and hating my nails, I tried this one and so far, it seems MUCH better than anything else I've tried (mostly Sally Hensen products, but a few others as well). It goes on nicely and dries quite quickly to a clear gossy finish. I put on 2 coats and several days later not a single chip anywhere yet, so it's protecting just like I wanted and my nails look pretty good for a change and are starting to look better and better because they are protected. I'm not convinced any particular product will magically change your nails…after all, once a nail appears not much much can be changed in terms of strength, and for that reason, someone like me needs a hardener for protection of an already weak nail. My worry is always whether or not a polish will progressively dry out the nail over repeated use, and at this point I can't answer that one, I'll have to wait and see. So far so good.I've tried other Sally Hansen nail treatment products in the past, and this one really seems the best of them all.  It's also worth adding that this dried to a very nice smooth shine, and it works well as both a base coat and a top coat. I can't see any reason at all to buy something different for the top coat.

Wonderful knife, but oh my, the price here is way out of line.  I just bought this knife at WS for 59.95!  But to the knife itself…..I needed to replace my 20+ year old 5 inch serrated utility knife that just couldn't be sharpened any more.  The 3 candidates I tried out (in the stores) were the Zwilling Pro 5" serrated utility, the Wüsthof Classic Ikon 5 inch serrated utility, and this one.  I never could find this one in any store to "play with", so I took a chance and ordered in from WS online.  Of the 3 knives, I liked this one best.  The scalloped serrations are incredibly sharp (watch out or you'll slice yourself).  Zwilling claims this scalloped serration holds its sharpness, so I'll have to wait and see on that claim.  But it was definitely the sharpest of the three I tested, and definitely cut with more ease.  It was great with the usual tomatoes and smaller, softer veggies, and super for slicing apart a thick hamburger bun, and great for cutting a sandwich in half, so it seems pretty versatile.  Also great with onions.  So in the time I've had the knife, I find myself reaching for this one the most now.  To tell the truth, I liked all three knives a lot and especially the handle and weight of the Wüsthof, but I couldn't justify buying more than one of them since they all essentially do the same thing.  Like the other review below, I liked the wider blade and I think what set this one apart was the angle of the cutting surface…it seemed more natural when cutting and allows your hand to be up higher so your hand doesn't hit the cutting board at the bottom of a cut or slice.  I'm also a fan of this Zwilling Pro line with the angled bolster, which allows a firm pinch grip.  Great great knife, highly recommended.

This is the second knife I've purchased from the Zwilling Pro line, my other one being the 8 inch chef's knife, which is fabulous.  I was debating between this boning knife and the Wüsthof Classic Ikon boning knife, but ultimately I decided I preferred the weight and feel of this one best.  Like with my chef's knife, I especially appreciate the angled bolster that distinguishes the Pro lines of knives as it allows a really great pinch grip that seems very natural, and holding/using this knife is extremely comfortable.  The blade has a mild flex which makes it very efficient when cutting close to bones.  I also decided I liked the narrower blade (compared to the Classic Ikon blade).  Overall, the knife has a substantial weight in the very solid handle, which I especially like.  Great knife overall, very pleased with it, beautiful quality and well worth the price.

I always love the big heavy steak knives you typically get in a good steak house, and these are as close to that as I've found.  Many kitchen stores seem to have these now sold on an individual basis…I only needed and bought two because I had other steak knives, but if you need 12 of them, this price is pretty good and similar to the individual price.  They are staying nice and sharp and holding up well, but I also take good care of them and only hand wash, which I think is important for any knife.Here is a fuller description I found elsewhere:Tramontina Porterhouse Steak Knife Set, 4 Piece : Restaurant-quality steak knives cut quickly and precisely, leaving juicy flavor and savory taste within the meat. These steakhouse knives bring the best qualities of a steak knife to the table: high-carbon steel with extra-sharp serrations slices the thickest Porterhouse steak, T-bone or New York strip. The serrated blades on these steak knives are heat-treated for maximum strength to pierce cleanly and cut precisely. Never need sharpening. Full-tang construction, triple-riveted for superior balance. Ergonomic handle with smooth natural-fitting curve grip fits like a glove in the hand, ensuring firm cutting control. Solid alloy rivets add to the longevity of these steakhouse steak knives. The combination polyresin and wood handle is more resistant to moisture for long-lasting performance. Rust- and stain-resistant blade. Dishwasher-safe; however, hand washing is recommended. Made in Brazil. Introduced to the United States in 1986, Tramontina has emerged as a leading manufacturer of cookware and housewares. Their state-of-the-art facility ensures highest level of quality at every level of the design and manufacturing process, producing durable kitchenware for the restaurant industry and home gourmet. Product Features High-carbon steel blade with extra-sharp serrations cuts the thickest steaks, like slicing butter Heat-treated for maximum strength, ensuring quick piercing and precise cuts Restaurant-quality knives never need sharpening Full-tang construction triple-riveted for superior balance Ergonomic handle with natural-fitting grip allows firm cutting control Combination polyresin and wood handle is more resistant to moisture than, ensuring long-lasting performance Solid alloy rivets add to the long-life performance Stain- and rust-resistant blade

I got a couple of these at a kitchen store and love them.  Perfect size for fried eggs, and eggs don't stick.  I needed a couple more and saw a good deal on Norpro rings (set of 2), but I'm disappointed in those:  the silicone is rougher and eggs stick, and the small button handle is smaller.  This brand is considerably better, cleans very quickly and easily, and although the stated size is the same 4 inches, the Trudeau ring is slightly larger and also better for allowing the egg to spread out just a bit more.  If you have Prime, it's cheaper to order a single ring and then get two singles….the set of two is a bit more and would probably be an OK price if you don't have Prime.

I thought all silicone egg rings would be the same, but not so.  I had a couple of Trudeau egg rings (sold here on Amazon) that are fantastic and eggs do not stick at all.  I wanted two more and thought these would be the same, but they are not….eggs stick quite a bit to these and the silicone is not as slick and smooth as the other brand, the silicone of the two brands feels noticeably different and these have a vaguely rough feel to them.  Sorry I ordered them, and I'm about to replace them with the Trudeau brand (yellow ones).  Although the size is rated the same 4 inches, the Trudeau ones are slightly larger and allow the egg to spread out a bit more, and I like that better.  Another negative for the Norpro is the little handle buttons that you lift the ring with are a lot smaller, the Trudeau brand has larger ones that are easier to grasp without touching the metallic part of the handle.  The Norpro rings are OK in a pinch, but I far prefer the other ones due to the slickness of the silicone.

I have bought several of the Ibis & Orchid Nightlights…this one, and a similar one with a little hummingbird on it.  I originally got it in Hawaii for about 7 or 8 dollars more than the price here, and my daughter loved it so much I ordered her one on Amazon as a gift.  This light is beautifully made, and looks lovely when the light is turned on.  All of the I&O lights are beautiful and well worth the price, and it was wonderful to find a selection of them here on Amazon.

I got this to use for straining yogurt to make Greek style yogurt.  I originally wanted a super fine mesh strainer of some sort, but most of the good strainers are very expensive.  I found some fairly fine mesh strainers with long handles, but I realized the handle was a problem in the fridge, and many of them were also large, but shallow.  This Culina one with the two side handles is absolutely perfect for my purpose.  It's very nicely made, deep enough to hold the 6 to 8 cups of yogurt I'll be putting into it, and it fits perfectly over my stainless bowl for draining the yogurt in the fridge.  It's easy to clean, and although it does say it's stainless and won't rust, I'll probably always hand wash it.  By the way, the mesh is probably not quite fine enough for draining yogurt directly on the mesh, but it's perfect when lined with the large Bunn 12 cup coffee filters I got right here on Amazon.  That makes the draining process very very easy and eliminates the issue of whether or not the mesh is fine enough all by itself.  And finally….how can you beat the price!  The long-handled strainer I just returned to a kitchen store was over 20 dollars more than this, and this one works better for what I need.  I have Amazon Prime shipping, and it came in a large box with the giant bubble wrap stuff protecting it from getting bent in shipping, AND it arrived in 2 days!
Hmmmmm….interesting price.  Are they crazy?

After deciding to get an 8" chef's knife, I started researching.  I wasn't sure how much I would have to spend to get a really nice one, but I definitely wanted one of a higher quality than my 15 year old Zwilling Classic 6" chef's, which was certainly good but not fantastic, and in many cases it was just too short a length and I wanted something longer. Fortunately there are stores to go where you can really see, handle and even use various brands for comparison (Sur La Table as one example).  Reading reviews online is also very helpful to narrow down choices and see what is out there, but I've also realized knife preference is a very personal thing and I didn't want to buy blindly and based solely on reviews. Also, an 8" chef's knife is probably not a good length to start with as a novice so one really needs to handle and test these knives before buying.  I initially thought I liked the Wusthof Grand Prix II, and possibly the Wusthof Classic Icon, both very nice knives.  I prefer a knife with some weight to it and a slightly larger, heavier handle, and those two knives fit that criteria fairly well.  But then I saw and held this Zwilling Pro, and it was immediate knife nirvana for me.  Aside from the superb weight, balance and size of this particular knife compared with all the others, I realized the main reason I liked this one best of all was because of the tapered bolster-free design that permits a perfect pinch grip without the distraction of a bolster ridge under the fingers.  As I held the knife, my "pinch" hit exactly the perfect spot and gave me perfect control!  What an incredibly huge difference that one thing makes, and how much easier it is to cut food due to that design!  As I compared the Pro with the other knives I had originally liked, they suddenly didn't seem as great to me.  When I began my search, I never gave a thought to considering bolster design as something of importance, but it really is!  The lack of a bolster also means the edge can be sharpened for its entire length, although this also means you must be aware of that sharper end point when handling the knife.  However, it is not at all a problem if you handle your knife carefully and with full awareness until you get used to this aspect of the knife design. This feature is probably not ideal for a user who isn't somewhat used to handling larger knives.Overall, this knife is a thing of true beauty and it's a total joy, very easy and comfortable to handle and use.  For me as a woman, it is absolutely perfect for my medium sized hand and has the perfect balance and weight.  It has quickly become my favorite knife and it's the one I reach for the most.  When on occasional special promotion from Zwilling (usually around 99 or so), it's a great price, worth every penny and highly recommended.  If I can judge by my much cheaper 15 year old 6" Zwilling, I expect to get equal longevity from this one!

I'd been debating about buying a slightly larger block (25 slot) because this block is full, but decided this one is best for me after all.  I've had mine for a very long time, at least as long as 15 years.  It not only still looks beautiful, it has held up beautifully.
