I just took all my knives out of it to clean it up, and it was looking rather tired and faded, but the quality of the hardwood is good enough that after using a wood cabinet cleaner and then applying lemon oil, it looks totally rejuvenated and pretty much like new again. I was actually surprised how fantastically it spruced up, and I believe you can keep a lighter color block nice looking more than the darker color ones, which would show scratches and wear much more prominently.  Judging from recent quality complaints in some of the reviews, I'm wondering if Henckels still makes these blocks as nicely now as mine was made 10-15 years ago.  I bought mine in a store where I could examine the block and the wood pattern, which is probably a good thing in terms of choosing a block with nice wood and no damage.  My only real frustration is the steak knife slots:  I have a couple of larger 1-1/8" Tramontina porterhouse steak knives that I love but which are a bit too wide to fit the 7/8" or so slots, so I have to use two of the upper regular slots for those two steak knives. I'm contemplating widening a couple of the slots for this reason.  My other regular steak knives fit perfectly, however.  I use the upper cleaver slot for a Joyce Chen cleaver and that slot is wide enough that my Rosle cheese cutter also fits in the slot with and above the cleaver with plenty of headroom.  I put a couple of my smaller paring knives in the lower steak knife slots.  Another comment about the steak knife slots:  I like their  horizontal position (compared to the vertical Wusthof slots, for example) so the steak knives and any other knives you put in these slots can be placed flat.  In terms of slot layout, after reviewed all the other knife blocks I realized I like this design setup most of all the blocks I saw because I like having the sharpening tool and wide cleaver slots at the top and out of the way of the other knives I use daily, and I like the scissors slot at the bottom center, and no other block is designed like this one.  The Henckels 25 knife block is equally nice and similarly designed if you need a few extra slots, but I decided I just didn't need that many slots after all and didn't want the larger footprint on my counter.  This particular 20-slot block is fairly compact and fits nicely in a side corner, so it doesn't seem too huge to me and isn't distracting…very easy to pull knives out of it quickly and it's heavy enough that it won't move or tip over.  Great block as long as the quality of construction and the good is still good.

These were the perfect size for my purpose.  I make yogurt in a big batch (Yogourmet), then like to put it into smaller containers with fruit on the bottom.  Most of the ball canning jars and other available glass containers were too large, but at 6 oz these are good for single serving storage.  They are a nice shape and the lids go on firm enough, although certainly not as tight as a canning type jar.  Dishwasher safe and they don't appear to be too fragile.  I'll probably get more of them.

Great for use in the microwave to cover a bowl or something small….keeps things from splattering around.  I also use it to cover my 9" pie plate full of cheesecake in the fridge….better than foil or plastic as a cover and fits nicely.  Washes easily, just an overall great idea with a lot of possible uses.  I'm so hooked I bought some other sizes too, as well as two small ones to cover cups of tea or coffee when necessary.

For several years I'd been lusting after the $100 ThermoWorks thermometer, but couldn't quite bring myself to pay that amount for a thermometer which I would use only occasionally.  This one is from the same company, it got great positive reviews, appeared to be nearly as good per other reviewers, so I decided to get this one and be done with it.  My observation after use is that it's fantastic!  I'd had no idea how truly lousy my old thermometers were (they took ages to creep up to a reading of sorts), whereas this one is extremely fast to display a temp reading (a second or two max), and frankly, I don't see how the $100 model could be any faster than this one.  Large, easy to read numbers, easy to use, you can rotate it depending on how you want to look at the reading, and on top of that, a great color selection—I got the purple and love it!  Totally pleased with this purchase, and fast delivery with follow-up from ThermoWorks, which seems like an excellent company overall.

I was looking for a spatula specifically to turn fried eggs, and had been unhappy with numerous others I'd tried.  Seems my drawer is full of lousy spatulas. It's odd that so many spatulas don't work well to turn eggs, but that has been my experience so I was on the hunt for something a bit different.  Reviewers seemed to like this one, so I pulled the lever to buy it.  Admittedly it's a bit overpriced for what it is, but what the heck, the result is what counts and this Matfer works fantastically for my particular purpose and I'm totally happy with it.  The overall shape, handle and angle of it all allows you to get under the egg quite nicely and flip it without destroying it.  It is easy to clean, and the blue color is a nice change so easy to spot in my drawer!

Not sure what there is to love about a grill plate replacement, but after several years our grill needed a new grill plate and this is it, the perfect size for our particular grill.  The price was good (a bit less than on the Weber site), it arrived quickly, and I'm happy with it.

My favorite summer shoes!  Incredibly comfortable, fit perfectly right out of the box with zero breaking in period needed.  They are a bit lighter and less clunky than the regular Chuck Taylors, which look very very similar (6 vs. 5 lace holes).  I wear these when I know I'll be walking around a lot, and from Day 1 never a sore spot or blister or anything, just total comfort.  Love the deep blue color, too, especially with jeans or crop pants.  I have two pair….the deep blue and a light gray, which goes with tons of things.  I usually wear an 8 or 8.5, and these were perfect in 8.  It's worth mentioning that I've also tried the regular CT's, and they seemed to be sized larger…I was able to wear a 7 in those and the 8 seemed a bit large.  So I guess this Dainty model is sized a bit differently.  The only negative is that the laces are too long, so I tie them making the bow part rather big and then double tie to take up the slack, and that works fine.  I think the laces were designed to go with the other CTs, which have 6 holes and thus need more lace length.  Cute style, too…I get lots of comments.
Great and insanely comfy socks…I use with my gym shoes, with my hiking shoes, with my biking shoes.  They wash well and last a long time.  Very happy with them, so I have 3 pair already.

This is one of a very short list of products I seem to buy over and over.  I have long hair, a slight tendency to be wavy and unruly (especially in humid weather), plus I highlight it so my hair is quite fragile.  I have fine hair, but a fair amount of it.  I wash and condition in the shower every day, but need more moisturizing before blow drying.  This spray-in, leave-in moisturizer helps a LOT, and as of now, I like it better than perhaps 6 or 7 other similar products I've tried, it's the best of the lot so far.  Unlike other reviewers, I don't find the scent objectionable or strong, and it disappears almost immediately anyway.  I apply a light spray from a few inches below the roots to the ends, and I'm always careful to not over apply it.  The amount I use does not weigh down my hair or make it sticky or anything, and when my hair is dry I can't tell it's on my hair but my hair does behave much better.  I do think it helps overall, and that's why I keep using it.  I use an additional product (a moisturizing oil from Olay) on the last 3 or 4 inches of my hair because the ends need it…Luxxtress isn't quite enough to deal with my dry ends.  But I definitely can tell a difference if I don't use the Luxxtress (I see the difference on the top part of my hair), and I've just ordered my 5th or 6th bottle of the stuff.  My last order was in early December, so although I use it daily, at the rate I use it, my previous bottle has lasted a good 6 months and probably won't be entirely empty until mid July.  Amazon's price is cheaper by at least 5 bucks than the local beauty supply store or my hairdresser, so good deal here!

Sometimes it's difficult to find a pretty 70 inch round tablecloth.  I'm very pleased with this one as it's quite striking, and I like the "busy" paisley design because it somewhat hides minor spills and things so you can use it longer between washes.  It's machine washable in cold water, and if you remove it from the dryer right away it needs no ironing.  It is soft and drapes well on the table. Very pretty design, and the price isn't half bad.  It arrived in just a couple of days.  My only negative comment and why I took off one star is that the dark blue in some of the paisley areas seems inconsistent and a bit splotchy with very dark blue and then lighter blue as if the dye wasn't quite heavy enough.  I suspect these are "seconds" and that would account for why they are being sold at this price online (it is, after all, Ralph Lauren, and I the dye issues I observed would probably not be acceptable in Macy's or stores like that. The dye did not bleed into the white, but certain areas that should be very dark and solid blue are less than perfectly so.  I don't care much because I bought this for casual, everyday use and the price was right, but the dye imperfections might bother some people. I'll also mention that none of the dark blue bled into the white areas, it was just a matter of the dark blue areas not being solidly one color.

I've used this product probably 5 or 6 times, and I'm fairly happy with it.  I had previously tried Crest strips and they didn't seem to stay in place.  Perhaps the newest ones from Crest do, but I haven't tried them.  I liked the idea of the trays (that's what dentists use),and perhaps I got less irritation because the trays keep the gel inside and you don't get much contact with the mouth tissues.My main observations are these:1.  Obviously the trays are one size fits all.  They were OK….you put one on and then smooth out the gel so it gets on all the fronts of your teeth.  It's not big deal to do that, really it isn't.2.  I had best results from leaving them on 45 min. to an hour each time.3.  They did not irritate my gums, but clearly some people are more sensitive than others in this.  I expected burning, but they did not burn me.4.  This box is for 7 days…you could do it every other day, but I usually did it every day because I wanted to be done with it.5.  I always get very much whiter teeth, so I'm always pleased.  In fact, a LOT whiter, to the point where I was monitoring towards the end to be sure I didn't end up with unnaturally blindingly white teeth as some people do.I was initially wondering about the trays as they don't extend far enough to cover ALL your teeth and seem to be mainly for the fronts.  As I've been reading reviews, I read one that said the dentist trays are much the same.The main negative, and I would suspect this is true for these or for any of the strips:  I pretty much can't talk while wearing them.  I usually put mine on before taking a shower, then leave them on for the shower and doing hair etc. and all the other stuff I do.  That takes up a lot of the wearing time.  I always tried to get at least 45 minutes (I think the box said 30 min.) and sometimes got as much as an hour.  Perhaps that helped, but I could do that because they weren't irritating to me.  As long as you don't talk, the trays stay in place quite well.  If they start to get loose and fall down, it's easy to push them back in place.I was wondering if the new Crest strips might be better, but they are still strips and they cost a LOT more.  This Amazon price is actually the most reasonable I've seen.

Love this machine!  I used to guzzle Perrier, but that got real expensive.  This particular machine handles the larger cartridges (not all of the machines do).  I fizz at least two bottles a day, sometimes more, ad each large cartridge lasts about 3 months.  It's about $30 to refill, but I did the math based on how much we drink, and it came down to about 25 cents per bottle.  That definitely beats other fizz waters at near $2 a liter.  My soda maker has been going strong for several years without a problem, and although the bottles have "expiration" dates on them, I'm still using some that expired over a year ago and they are fine.  Obviously I treat them carefully and all that.  I don't use the flavor packets, I just do plain water and at most, add lemon to it at the end, so I can't comment on the various flavors.  Those would add greatly to the cost, of course.

Really good for a more compact size dictionary.  Pronunciations are given using standard phonetic symbols, and words are in a dark blue so they stand out nicely, with everything else in black.  The text size is good and very readable.  There are 100,000 words, phrases and translations, so that is better than some smaller dictionaries out there.  There is also some other useful information such as a glossary of grammatical terms, abbreviations, grammar summary and section on verbs at the back.  The French-English part is divided from the English French part with a center section (colored blue on the edges so you can easily find where the English-French part starts, and that section of about 40 pages includes info about letter writing, holidays, and some games.  All in all, a very nice dictionary for most purposes.  It has a strong cover and is nicely bound….the one I have has held up like new for at least 10 years.  I don't  know how the 3rd edition is different from this 2nd edition that I have, but I did notice that the newer one has the entry words in orange rather than blue, and I don't like that because they don't stand out quite as strongly when you are searching for a word.  Definitely recommended for French students.

I'm just not at all pleased with this thermometer and I'm searching for a better replacement.  It takes forever to produce a reading and seems inconsistent, not at all accurate.  I've thought meats were extremely underdone, but when I used this to cook until the proper reading, the meat was horribly overdone.  It's virtually impossible to open the batter compartment without wrecking the lid. Can't recommend this one at all, I'm surprised the Oxo would sell such an interior product.

I bought this timer because design wise, it is the most like my previous timer, which I loved (Bonjour large digit kitchen timer).  Like my other one (no longer made, apparently), this timer has large, easy to read digits.  It is quite easy to set or clear, and the beeper can be easily heard without being annoying.  I don't mind pushing the minute button repeatedly to get up to the minutes I want because I mostly use this timer for shorter periods of time between 2 and 10 minutes.  For the occasional 40+ minute time setting it's no big deal to punch the button up to that point, no complaints there.  I like the larger sized buttons, too, as compared to another smaller timer I have with little tiny multiple buttons.  What I especially like is the large magnet plate on the back (a fairly large square, instead of two tiny and useless magnet dots like so many timers out there seem to offer).  This larger magnet allows me to stick it on a magnetic strip on my oven above the door opening.  The one thing I don't like as well as my old timer is that this one is much thicker and potentially easier to knock off the oven accidentally—my prior timer was very thin, which was a good thing when keeping it above the oven.  As for longevity, I haven't had it long enough to determine, hence only 4 stars.  I wish Wrenwane would make a design like the old and thinner Bonjour timer.

I've had his for years, and use it mainly for cutting up things like brownies in a non-stick pan.  I was never all that enthusiastic about using it for cutting lettuce….it does fine with that, but I never found browning lettuce to be an issue, so I rarely use this with lettuce, rarely have the need I guess.  I was looking at several other brands of lettuce knives lately, and some of the others have a much sharper blade than this one, so I think this Norpro knife might be better with non-stick pans for that reason.  The point isn't as sharp either.  Overall, it's just fine for the purpose I use it for and I definitely recommend it for use with nonstick pans.

This is my favorite spatula, which I use with non-stick pans and mostly for scrambled eggs.  In that use over at least 3 years, it has held up perfectly and looks like new.  It's easy to clean (eggs don't stick to it) and easy to use….it's not "floppy" like some silicone tools can be, but being silicone, it's totally protective for no-stick pans.  It's just perfect.  I found one in a nice lime green color, which makes it easy to locate in my tool jar.

I'm surprised to see such low reviews, but the jury is still out for me in terms of rust…I haven't had it long enough to determine whether or not it holds up.  I'll come back and note that later if I have issues with it.  Meanwhile, I got mine in black at Costco for less than half the price here.  Someone said perhaps Costco gets a lesser quality one, but I'd really doubt that.  Design:  I wasn't sure at first, but now I love it.  I have a sink with a high lip that comes up over the counter,so other drainers don't work well due to the lip of the sink and the water tends to drain onto my cabinet top rather than into the sink.  This one, however, is on raised legs and the drip pan under it is also raised, so water drains nicely because it clears the lip and goes easily into the sink.  I like the overall design as well and don't mind the somewhat larger size…there is room to put items that need to be flat, it holds a few plates, and the utensil tray at the side has holes only at one side to drain below properly.  There are two removable slot devices to hold utensils such as knives upright (they don't fall over like with my other drainer).  I wasn't sure I'd like or use those, but turns out they are quite handy.  The drip tray pulls out easily on the sink side to empty and drain, and in fact, you can just tilt the whole thing when it's empty and water goes into the sink so you don't always have to pull out the tray to drain water off.  I'm not crazy about the decorative pieces of metal on two sides because they will get water spots, so I don't know why K. Aid had to put that feature on it, seems kind of useless.  The side with the glass holder prongs unfortunately is on the sink side so glasses would be in a spot I don't like, but I don't use that much anyway so I don't care.  I don't wash a lot of glasses at a time so I just put them in the bottom as there is good room for that.  So now it comes down to longevity and whether it rusts or not.  Only time will tell.  I gave 4 out of 5 stars because of the potential rust factor.

I've been using these tongs pretty much daily for 3+ years now, and absolutely love this particular tool.  I use the tongs mainly for turning bacon, but I've found many other uses as well from time to time.  Very easy to use as they have great balance for one handed grasping of food items.  Costly, but absolutely worth it because they will last forever.  I haven't seen another tongs like this from anyone else, and of course, being from Rösle, it's beautifully made of stainless steel and will last forever.

I first tried to use this opener at my Mom's house and I felt like an idiot because I couldn't figure out how it works.  I have other openers that remove the top of a can with no sharp edges, but this one works quite differently.  However, once you "get it" , the opener is very easy to use and makes opening a can incredibly effortless.  I can't comment on the longevity, but my mom has had it for a few years.  I like it so much I'm going to buy one for myself, despite the crazy high price.  I have other Rosle utensils, and I absolutely love them all.  Fantastic brand, and my experience so far is that their products are great.  My favorite is their garlic press.

I have gone through a few Western Civilization textbooks, and this one is actually quite good compared to others I have worked with.  It's a brief history, as stated in the title, but it's not too brief.  It's extremely well organized, well written, clearly stated with good detail and illustrations.  For a student, another bonus is the very useful online material available from the publisher, much of which is free:  chapter outlines, section quizzes, chapter tests.  All this reinforcement is extremely valuable to a student.  It's too bad most people rated the textbook condition rather than the content.  I also suspect most students don't know about and don't take advantage of the online material, which is a shame.  This is one of the most readable, enjoyable and useful books on the subject that I have encountered.  Enough information to handle, but it's not overwhelming.  And it's interesting!  Kudos to the authors.

As a kid growing up in the 50's, I absolutely loved this book and I must have read it a dozen times.  Wish it were available at a cheaper price, and in print again.  I really think kids today in the 8 to 14 age range would still enjoy it, the story is timeless.  It also appeals to both girls and boys. I remember finding it very exciting, and even though I knew the outcome after reading it the first time, I loved re-reading it.  In fact, I still have this book in my library!

The best scales I've had.  I got it for the pull-out display aspect….if you put a large plate on the scales, the regular position of the display would be hidden by the plate…so you can pull out the display and add items, zero out as you go, and so on. Wonderful feature that I use a lot.  You can do ounces or grams, the display is easily readable, the batteries last a long time, and I'm completely pleased with the product.  Very lightweight and fairly small footprint, easy to clean.  I would definitely buy this again.

I love this brush, and there doesn't seem to be a competitor out there like it…unfortunately.  I say unfortunately because the quality isn't so great and seems to have degraded over the years.  My first one worked well and lasted a long time.  The second one hasn't been nearly as good.  First, the idea of this brush is great:  the "teeth" of the brush don't get caught so easily in the hair (if you are very carefully rolling up the ends), and there is a "release" button you push to make the barrel free wheeling so you can unroll the curled end without tangling.  The barrel doesn't get very hot so it's fairly gentle on fine, colored hair like mine.  BUT….here's the negative…..I've had two of these in the last couple of years that had a brush barrel that tended to stick when the release button was pushed.  My work around is to push the button and manually unroll the brush, and that works, the the basic function should be such that I don't have to do this, it should just unroll easily while the button is pressed.  When I bought my second brush, I had to return it because of the barrel not releasing well, but the replacement did the same thing.  Made in China, and not so great or long lasting any more, I guess.  When and if I find a comparable product that works better, I'll buy it.

Such an excellent film, and it provides a fascinating look into conditions in French schools today in terms of the Muslim students and their attitudes as they attempt to define their place as Muslims within a liberal, secular French society.  There is a real clash of cultures and values, and also a fascinating view into male-female dynamics within the French Muslim sub culture and Muslim male attitudes towards women in general.  Isabelle Adjani is simply wonderful as the embattled teacher who finally faces the situation head on in a surprising way and makes a stand, and the Muslim female students who eventually find a voice and stand up for themselves as Musolim females.  This aspect of the story was most fascinating and rewarding to watch. Overall, this is a complex, rich and tense story that takes place during a crisis within the classroom one day.  There's a bit of a surprise at the end that you don't expect, which also makes the whole story quite poignant.  Definitely a film worth watching a time or two.

My favorite of all highlighters out there.  Lasts well, the tip holds up, easy to hold and use (unlike the fat shaped ones) and the ink seems to be quite a bit more long lasting than many others I've tried.  I've been buying only these for at least 15 years, but they are harder to find now….only on Amazon, actually.

I remember liking this workout a lot when I first bought it in summer of 1982.  It didn't have any competition at the time and was considered quite the innovation in women's fitness, but it was a new idea for working out at home and great fun particularly if you were naturally flexible.  It was probably a bit hard if you weren't very flexible, though!  I took my tape with me to Saudi Arabia because I was working as a teacher there at the time…unfortunately, it was seized in customs because they were so sure it was pornography (note:  anything that showed female body parts in anything less than a black shapeless bag was considered suspicious, and Jane's cover outfit was seen as very salacious indeed).  The last I saw of my tape was in a side room at customs with a group of customs officials eagerly glued to the TV and watching the tape to "review" it for propriety.  I never got it back, by the way, so it's probably still in some customs official's video collection in the kingdom.  But it was a fun tape for sure, and when this comes out again I think I'll get the DVD version for fun.

I had a couple of other brands before this one and they weren't so good.  This one, however, is perfect for quick and perfectly boiled eggs.  It can do a couple of other tricks (poached egg, fried), but I didn't get it for anything other than boiled eggs.  You can do up to seven eggs, and the piercer that comes with the cooker indicates the correct water level for however many eggs you are doing.  They come out perfect every time, which is what I love about this cooker.  There is no auto-off function, and when the water has boiled away the eggs are ready and buzzer comes on.  An auto-off is relatively useless because when done, you want to immediately immerse the eggs into a bowl of cold water to stop the cooking.  Overcooked eggs are rubbery, can turn dark inside, and aren't good, so an auto-off would not be such a great thing.  The only issue I've had is when I forgot to pierce the bottom of one of the eggs…..it cracked and egg oozed out.  But if you follow directions and properly pierce each egg, you'll have perfectly boiled eggs in about 15 minutes every time.  Easy clean-up, and I've had mine for at least 5 or 6 years now, still works like new.  BTW, when you can so effortlessly get boiled eggs with a little tool like this, why mess with a pan of boiling water, often-broken shells, and eggs either under or overcooked?  I never did many boiled eggs before I had the cooker, but after getting it I started cooking them a lot. The Krups cooker makes it so easy, and it's fantastic if you are on a diet that uses a lot of boiled eggs (Atkins!).  Easy-pleasy no brainer, good quality cooker and in my experience, very long lasting.  Side note:  appears to be the only one with a flat top, which is GREAT for storage.  No need to make a cooker look like an egg!

I got this book for a Women in History class, and found the content to be fascinating.  The focus is on women and what they experienced through American history from the 1600's to the present.  Many of the articles are about ordinary women, their lives, their marriages, their restrictions, their struggles, but there are also many great articles about notable women and their achievements despite great odds.  This book is a compilation of articles on a whole range of topics, and I can say I probably learned more from this particular book than just about any history book I've read.  I was left with a whole new appreciation for what women have gone through in the last several hundred years.  I'll add that this book does not have an angry feminist slant as some might expect (I expected this myself going into the class and the book).  Rather, it just tells the history of what happened and "what was" in a way that was pretty devoid of any particular social position.  You are left to draw your own conclusions about what you read.  Of particular interest were articles about the witchcraft hysteria, Sally Hemings and Thomas Jefferson, and the practice of abortion in early America.  The articles were beyond fascinating and I learned so much that I had had no idea about before.  Well worth reading even if you aren't in a class.

I got a 3-pack of these at Costco several years ago ($12 for three!!), they all still work perfectly.  This makes a great gym water bottle…easy to grab a drink with one hand due to the auto seal feature.  I load mine up with ice, sometimes I keep it in the freezer full of ice, then add water before as I leave for the gym.  It's not insulated, but with the ice in it your water will stay cold for a decent amount of time.  I only put water in mine, so cleaning isn't a big issue…I rinse the bottle, and just soap up the mouthpiece part, all by hand.  I like the carabiner handle because it's easy to carry and you can fit several fingers thru the loop.  I'm going to order the Grace version of this and I noticed the carabiner is gone and there is a smaller hole to loop maybe one finger through when carrying it….I'll have to see how well that works.  These bottles seem very durable…I've dropped them a couple of times, no breakage yet.  Recommended, and I'd definitely buy again!

My understanding is that this is a Penney's exclusive...I just bought a new one there on sale for $59.95.  I just wanted a fairly simple toaster....just one that toasts nicely!  So far so good.  I was looking for function and a decent construction and nothing too fancy in terms of digital goodies that would likely break fairly quickly.  However, this is one cool looking toaster, and it' actually a bit fancier than I realized from looking at it in the store.  The front lights up a bit in a rather space age way.  You put the bread in the slots, push down the lever, then either let it toast or then push one of the buttons such as "defrost", "reheat", "bagel" and "cancel".  The cancel button pops the toast up, no need to raise the lever.  The darkness dial "clicks" around, unlike most toasters I've seen that turn freely.  There is a little window shaped like a piece of bread under the lever that shows the timing progress by diminishing from a full orange digital display down to nothing, but not sure what the value of that is.  You can wind the cord around underneath the toaster for storage so no dangling cords.  It looks like a metal exterior...turns out it is anodized aluminum, and it gets slightly warm but not hot.  The top part of course gets hot, like all toasters.  I suspect it's a good idea to clean it off right away if something gets on the surface.  There is an easy to pull out crumb tray at the back.  Now it's a matter of longevity....that remains to be seen.  My last Kitchen Aid toaster lasted barely 4 years, but limped along for the last year or so.  More recently, the handle on the lever popped off.  And it didn't toast evenly or quickly.  I didn't want another Kitchen Aid.  The overall design and construction of this toaster is really nice, especially when compared with many of the usual other grands.Update 10/11/14:  So far I'm really liking this toaster.  I use only gluten free bread, which is often difficult to toast properly, and I've got the perfect spot dialed in for that toast, and it's toasting pretty evenly and is consistent each time.  Once I found the right setting on the dial, it only takes one cycle to toast the bread the way I wanted it.  I like the way the dial is set up...you can adjust bread by one click at a time, and once you find your setting, it doesn't accidentally move off that setting.

Great roaster for garlic, BUT….it's hard to believe the current price.  I've had mine for 8 to 10 years at least, still works well, but I originally paid around $20 for it.  I can't imagine why it's so much now, except that it's apparently in short supply.  In terms of function, it's great and surprisingly quick.  It's large enough to roast 4 or 5 heads of garlic, depending on the size of course.  Easy to clean up, too.  As great as this thing is and as much as I like, I definitely would not pay this high a price for it.

Since these are being sold, I thought I'd offer some comments.  First, I love this phone.  We bought three of them in 2007. Phone 1 is still going strong.  Phone 2 was dropped or got in water (teen son) and died.  Phone 3 was virtually never used...it was a secondary phone I kept in my purse and occasionally turned it on, but in 7 years I bet it had no more than 10 hours of talk time on it.  Seriously!  It was never dropped, it had a protective case, it still looks brand new.  Out of nowhere, when I turned it on all I got was a black screen that was a Bootloader screen that gave software versions, and said I needed to program it and connect a USB data cable.  Sounds  do-able, but no go.  I've searched everywhere, I've taken the phone to various phone guru repair people, and no one can do anything with it.  They are guessing that the internals (ROM perhaps) is corrupted, or some such, but the bottom line is that nothing can apparently get it going agian.  I've emailed Motorola with all the relevant information, but frankly, I don't expect to hear back from them.  If I do get useful info one way or the other, I'll note it on this review later.Meanwhile, I wouldn't really advise buying a used Razr because it's a real roll of the dice at this point, and just know that if you have issues with what you buy, the likelihood of fixing it seems to be less than zero.

I switch around shampoos from time to time, but I really love this one and will stick with it for awhile I'm sure.  It is a lovely consistency, not too thick and not too thin, so you don't have to use a lot of it to get a good lather.  It has a fabulous, subtle scent.  It cleans beautifully and washes out well. This is 33 oz and I paid half this cost for only an 8 oz bottle from my hairdresser, so the price here on Amazon for this size is fantastic.  I'll also mention that this particular seller wrapped the bottle and especially the pump cap very nicely with bubble wrap so it wouldn't leak or bump around in the box, and I appreciated that.  Great shampoo, great buy.  There's a matching Aloxxi conditioner that I tried from my hairdresser, but I didn't like it so much, not bad, but not that great.

This show is such a guilty pleasure, but I love to watch it.  I spent two years in Tehran leading up into to the Revolution, and I adore that country and its people.  I guess most of the Shahs group is mostly too young to remember much of Iran, and perhaps a couple of them were born in the U.S., but within all the over the top trappings of Beverly HIlls and the very rich orbit of their California life, I still see the Persian influence on their personalities and lives.  My favorite has to be Reza, but I really love them all with the possible exception of Lily.  I especially enjoy scences with their extended families, the food, and I love hearing them speak Farsi here and there.  I especially loved the visit to Turkey (Reza's comments on the veiled women were priceless!!), and their visit to the Iranian border was very poignant.

I have a 6 year old Sony HD TV that has only one HDMI plug on it.  I bought the Roku2 about a year ago, and it has been great in terms of how well it streamed.  Only problem was that I had to unplug it to plug in my DVD player (due to the one plug).  This Sony player seemed like it would solve the plug problem since it was both DVD player and had wireless wi-fi built in.  As far as I can see, it works great.  As others have mentioned, the setup is a bit dicey and the directions are almost useless, you have to feel your way through it, for the most part.  What you do have to do first is go to Sony's site and register the player, which has a 5-letter code you will enter there, specific to your player.  If you have Amazon Prime and want to stream from Prime, you can register with Amazon thru a link on Sony's site.  You'll get yet another code from Amazon, which has to be entered as well.  As for Netflix, I had trouble at first and couldn't connect, but then later I found a way to enter my email and Netflix password via the TV screen, and that seemed to straighten things out.  There are tons of sites to connect to, most of which I'll never use.  You Tube is there, also Hulu, Pandora, lots of other things and more than is stated on the box or in the descriptions, far more than my Roku 2 had.  So all works nicely for now, but the jury is still out and if I have issues I'll edit this review.I'll also mention that the price here isn't as good as BBuy at about eighty....they claim it's on sale right now.  If you get it there, and it doesn't work for you, you've got 15 days to return it.After things were hooked up, the resolution seemed horrible and I was thinking I'd have to return this thing.  However, now it has straightened out as well, and in one review here I saw a comment about the player having to "sync" with the television resolution.  I didn't do anything specific to make that happen, it just happened.  I also experienced a couple of loading hang-ups at the beginning, but that hasn't happened again either.  Streaming seems fine, smooth, so now I'm pleased.So it's easy to use, and although small, the remote is easy to navigate.  You press a "Home" button and that takes you to a screen with not only the DVD showing (if you have one in the tray), but all the different things to choose such as Netflix, etc.  This player looks like it does a ton of things I haven't even learned about yet.  The DVD/bluray part works just fine.  You can set it to load faster if you don't want the blu-ray movie to connect to the net (I guess some of them do that).

This spatula is incredible for cookies, and most likely for getting under fried eggs as well.  I don't use it for eggs because I use non-stick pans and I don't ever want to scratch them, but boy am I tempted to use this with them anyway (carefully, of course).  The super thin blade slides under cookies with amazing ease, and I wish I'd discovered this spatula years ago if only for cookies.  It certainly does appear fragile to some extent, but with proper care (and perhaps not using it to turn heavy things) it should last a long time.  I wouldn't throw it carelessly around in drawers, for example.  Great spatula, recommended for sure!

After years and years with a reliable old Sunbeam mixer, I searched for a replacement and hoped this was it.  What I liked was the larger, sturdier beaters (most mixers today have such small, flimsy beaters), I liked how it could be solidly set on end (it has a large, flat bottom, the retractable cord seemed like a fantastic idea, and the rubberized casing seemed nice too.First, the retractable cord isn't so great after all.  It's hard and somewhat laborious to wind it up back inside the mixer, and then fairly quickly it got stuck and I couldn't pull it out very far.  When I finally got the cord out, it had a major cut in the rubber, so now I don't know how safe it is now.  It's hard to get the beaters to click into their slots and once or twice they have fallen out when I start mixing.  I got a black case, but it does show splatters easily and isn't real easy to clean up.  The vents get flour in them and are hard to clean as well.  The mixing power is OK, although as others have noted, the slow isn't all that slow a speed.  The faster speeds seem fine.  As for sitting it on end, it's a bit clunky at times due to how the cord comes out of the case right at the bottom.I don't use a mixer all that much, but every time I use this one I'm thinking of the things I don't like rather than just using it without thinking.  I've had it a couple of years now, but I'll probably replace it once I figure out what to get.  Just kind of disappointed in this mixer, overall.

This is hands down the most intense, graphic, gripping and riveting war film I have ever seen, bar none.  Start to finish it does not let up, and as a viewer you are carried along on this wild roller coaster ride as you immerse yourself into the real life series of events that this film depicts.  The theater was packed with both men and women, which was interesting to note.What these soldiers went through to succeed in Seal training was astounding (almost beyond what most of us could ever imagine being able to do) and their bond to each other was simply amazing but also the necessity that kept them going.  What happened to these guys physically was beyond incredible (for me the most intense was several instances of having to escape by jumping off literal cliffs and bouncing down long rocky slopes, truly painfully hard to watch, and how on earth did they not end up with their bodies entirely broken in a million pieces?) , yet they kept going despite what seemed like impossible odds for a very long time.  Knowing from the outset that only Luttrell would survive did not detract from the story, but it made things so much more poignant as you watch events unfold as people were lost.I was very glad to see that the evil viciousness and utter cruelty of the Taliban was clearly depticted through not only their treatment of Americans they captured but also their eagerness to mow down their own fellow Afghans who do not agree with them.  I was also glad to see a clear portrayal of good and compassionate Afghan people who made it clear they did not support the Taliban (one man emphatically stating "Taliban nistam, I am not a Taliban), and who risked their own lives to save Luttrell.  Overall, I did not see this film as a political commentary on the war either pro or con (although there were a few small things that clearly revealed the political frustrations our military has to operate under in trying to do their jobs), but before long I felt this film had boiled down to the Seal team's most basic will to survive under the most seemingly impossible odds in this war, this battle.As a woman, I have to say I strongly responded to this film despite how hard it was to watch and experience, but I'm not sure I could watch it a second time due to its emotional intensity.  It left me with such profound respect and increased admiration for our soliders and for these Seals in particular.  I would put this film into a category of "everyone needs to see this."  Most people have no idea what war can really be like at its worst, and why any war entered into must be done with clear purpose and resolve to finish and achieve our goals going into it.  No namby pamby politicians doing the back seat directing of war, please.  All this said, I did leave the film wondering why we keep going into wars (Vietnam going forward) but don't allow ourselves to fully do what it takes to achieve our goals.  Politics always meddles too much, and I feel angry about that.  Do the job right and then go home.Deeply gratifying was a long segment at the end of the film which showed multiple photos and some video clips of all the real Seals who died in this incident, giving them a much needed and well deserved face and honor that should never be forgotten by any of us.  It was important to be able to put a real face to the names in the film.  Real people who led real lives and who died terrible deaths, and who should be honored and remembered.  The emotion of this film will make you cry (or want to), and this was a film in which the appreciative audience clapped somberly but with respect at the end.Finally, kudos are due to Mark Wahlberg, who did such an incredible job both in his portrayal of Luttrell and in his role as producer.  He did great honor to the Seals in his telling of this important story.  I hope he gets the recognition he deserves for this film. All of the actors were absolutely superb.

This map shows newer street names, not the old ones I remember from the late 1970's.  Also, the area shown was more limited in scope than what I hoped...it didn't show enough of the Tehran area.  I'm still hoping to find an older map with the prevous names and a wider area of the city.

I wanted a crepe pan to make gluten free crepes, but all the "nice" crepe pans cost way more than I want to spend for an occasional treat.  I saw this one in Wally World awhile back, and for a mere twelve bucks I figured I could try it out...I have other cast iron pans that I like.  The size seemed perfect, and it's nice and heavy for heat retention (important with crepes).  First the pre-seasoning:  yes, it's there, but it's not adequate.  Eggs stuck horribly, as did my first batch of crepes.  I read about pre-seasoning by using a propane grill, and I figured that was a great way to do this since all the smoking that occurs would be outside, not in my house.  Verdict:  this works GREAT, highly recommended.  I used Crisco for the seasoning, and did it about 4 times (45 min. to an hour each time).  The pan is now incredibly smooth and slick, all the tiny surface pits are filled in nicely, and nothing sticks!  This seasoning worked so well I did my other two Lodge pans as well (the wok and a ridged grill pan).  If you have a propane grill, this is a fabulously easy and effective way to season cast iron.  Meanwhile, this griddle is great for crepes (I do use additional coconut oil in small amounts, it works great for crepes) and I can't believe a hundred dollar crepe pan would be any better.  The handle does get hot...I could even feel the heat through the Lodge silicone handle cover I got, although in general this cover works quite well and I recommend it.  Afterwards, easy cleanup as must always be done with cast iron:  wipe clean and wash it out without soap (soap will break down and remove your seasoning), dry well, then put over heat for several minutes to thoroughly dry it, then use a paper towel to wipe on a bit of oil (olive or coconut) to replenish lost oil from the washing.  Weight of pan:  It's certainly heavier than non-cast iron pans, but I like the weight.  It's solid on the burner (I have gas) and doesn't move around, it heats up evenly and retains heat (I heat on medium, but turned it down more towards low for all the cooking of my crepes or eggs).  I'll note that I saw this pan in a local kitchen store for twenty-five plus tax, so Amazon's price is great and I've only seen it cheaper at Wally World.  Cast iron is great as long as you get it seasoned properly (my experience is that Lodge's pre-seasoning is a nice start, but it simply isn't enough) and will wash and dry it properly.  If you do this, your cast iron will NOT rust.1-5-14: Egg update:  Despite all the seasoning I did, when I tried to cook fried eggs...even with quite a lot of coconut oil....they are fairly impossible to turn without them all breaking apart.  I was careful to keep the heat low, but I think it was still too hot perhaps.  I've decided that while this pan is great for crepes, pancakes, grilling sandwhiches, etc., it just doesn't work well for eggs so I'll use a different pan for that.4-6-15:  Update:  When I wasn't looking, my son and his girlfriend used my pan, let it soak, washed it with soap, and pretty much destroyed my seasoning.  I found out what had happened some time later when I went to use it and found rust on it.  Sigh.  But I cleaned off the rust and did my seasoning all over again.  I used crisco (works like a charm for this purpose), put it in the outdoor gas grill at the highest setting for an hour, and then repeated this about 4 or 5 more times (although after the first time, I reduced each time session to about 40 minutes).  Result:  fabulous!  When I went to make crepes I used a tiny bit of butter just on the first one, nothing else needed after that and the crepes slid around like they were on an ice rink.  Absolutely zero sticking, and this pan is so solid and heavy it just sat on the burner (gas) and I didn't have to touch the pan while I was cooking the crepes because it doesn't move around.  The edges are so nice and low that my long spatula could get under the crepes quite effortlessly for turning.  This is also a larger (but not too large) better size than most of the "official" crepe pans out there at 4 or 5 times the price.  I can't imagine any other pan works better, and for the price of $12  plus the time to do 5 or 6 seasoning sessions, I've got a primo crepe pan that I can use metal utensils with AND which is utterly non stick.  Note on heating the pan for crepes:  Allow the pan to heat up before the first crepe, but after I began cooking my crepes, I kept the flame between low and medium and never had to adjust it.  This was the perfect temperature.  This is also a great pan for grilled cheese sandwiches, heating tortillas and so on.  I don't generally use it for much else.

Love love love Pee Wee's Big Adventure, it's the best of the two in this set, but Big Top Pee Wee is great fun too!  Seriously, Pee Wee Herman was genius.  My kids both adored these movies, and I did too!  The humor is best appreciated by adults with a good sense of humor and fun, but the kids got him too, albeit on a different level.  My adult kids STILL love the Pee Wee movies.

Just found this one at Costco for $34.95.  Package of Season 1 & 2, 25 episodes total.  I didn't see it a week ago, must be brand new.  I don't know if more seasons will be packaged later.  Just happy to finally see it out.
Love love love this series.  It doesn't seem to be availale here, but just got a package of Season 1 & 2, 25 episodes, at Costco fort $34.95.

If you check the Lodge website, the brush they now sell is NOT anything like this one.  What they sell is also a couple of dollars cheaper than this one.  I don't know if this brush is the "real thing" or is perhaps older, inferior ones sold the past, but the one currently sold by Lodge is a completely different design and is labeled "new and improved design".  Perhaps this one isn't really a Lodge brush and never was.  It looks a bit cheesy to me.

These work perfectly with the Lodge 10.5 size grill pan, they line up with the grooves on this particular size pan.  However, I do notice from other reviews that the distance of the grooves on OTHER size pans are different so the scrapers won't work with all grill pans.  These work well enough for their purpose and I'm glad to have them.  They help scrape off bits between the grooves although they won't get everything, you still have to use other means as well to get everything off.  The grill pan is admittedly a bit of a pain to clean due to the grooves, but overall, these little scrapers certainly help a lot and despite being a bit pricey for what they are, they are worth the price to me.  Although my Lodge grill pan came preseasoned, I'm currently in the process of reaseasoning it myself and I hope that will help a bit with the sticking end of things, making it easier to clean than it is now.

I've waited until I used a full bottle of this oil before reviewing.  The test is always whether or not I'll buy another...and I did!  This stuff is amazing because after trying what felt like every moisturizing product on the market, this oil solved my flaky skin issues. I had previously been using Bio Oil, but it didn't quite do the job.  This L'Oreal oil is wonderful.  I use about 6 drops in the morning after washing and before my other moisturizers, and 6 drops at night.  One bottle used at this rate lasted 2-1/2 months.  I want to emphasize that once this oil has been applied, the skin is wonderfully soft and not in the least bit greasy or oily.  The only caveat might be if you have very oily skin you would  not want or need this particular product.  But for dry skin, and for "mature" skin it is a wonder!  I'm surprised people would complain about the scent...I'm very sensitive to odd cosmetic odors, but found this oil very pleasant and not at all strong.  Once the oil is applied, the scent disappears anyway, so it's hardly an issue.  I put the 6 drops into my palm and then with my other fingertips dot it around my face and then gently massage it in.  It soaks in very quickly and you do not look or feel oily.  A few moments later, I apply whatever moisturizer cream or lotion I'm using that day...I switch things around and try a lot of things for further protection and SPF coverage.  In just a few days my flakiness pretty much disappeared and has remained gone ever since.  My 64 year old skin really needed just what this oil offers and I'm so happy it solved my long-time problem with spotty dryness and flakiness.  I'll add that I've tried some of the very costly oil type serums from Lancome, Lauder and others, and while they were nice enough, they did NOT work nearly as well as this oil and they did not solve my issues.The price seems to be coming down quite fast...my first bottle was 24, my second one I found at 19, and now I see Amazon has an even lower and very good price on it.  I have very sensitive skin with mild occasional rosacea, and this oil does not irritate in the least.  I can say without reservation I consider it my #1 skin product and the one I simply cannot do without, and I don't think I've ever felt that way about a product before.  It's a real bonus that this is a L'Oreal product you can buy just about anywhere and it's very affordable, unlike the fancy department store brands (where I paid 60+ for half the amount of what I considered a much less effective product for my needs).  I hope L'Oreal doesn't ever stop making this product because I really depend on it now!  I can say I'm 100% pleased with it, and that's not something I say very much about cosmetic products.Update 1/14/14:  Still love this oil, just opened my 3rd bottle.  I've been tracking, and at the use of about 14 drops per day (7 morning, 7 evening) a bottle lasts me 2 months.  This has become my "can't be without" skin product.  The current Amazon price is the lowest I've seen anywhere, by the way.Update 7/5/15:  Stilling loving it, and in general I use it every morning as the first product I use, and almost every evening before bed (then I put a night cream on top of it).  This is probably the mostly continuously I've used any facial product, it's really a "must" for me now.  There are other similar products out there, even in the drugstore lines, but most of them cost far more for the same or even lesser amounts and I doubt they are any better so I don't even both buying them.  It would be crazy to buy one of those elite oils….I had one from Lauder that I paid $50+ for before I tried this oil, and honestly, it just wasn't nearly as good and it didn't do anything miraculous. L'Oreal's oil provides better moisturizing and because of the affordable price, I use more of it than I could bring myself to use of the Lauder product.  For my needs, L'Oreal's performs much better anyway.  Amazon's current price is definitely the best I've seen anywhere else, especially if you have Prime.

This isn't a weight loss program.  Reading this book makes you put up a mirror to your own excuses and behavior about what you do when you attempt to lose weight.  The stories are Tory's life, but within the specific details of my own life I have "been there, done that" exactly in the same way she described, and this book made me see myself in a new light.  I don't know how many people say over and over how weight loss is so much a mental process more than anything else;  this is repeated a lot because it's so true.  Obviously one has to eat carefully, be aware of not overeating, and so on.  The diet details might be different for different people because the fact is, different diets work for different people.  This author found success with a low carb, very Atkins-like diet.  I related to her because after years of trying so many different diet approaches, I too have finally settled on a low carb diet as the only way to lose weight.  This is for ME, by the way.  It works for me.  Those who harp on low carb being dangerous or unhealthy simply do not understand the diet.So success in reaching a weight loss goal is hugely mental.  And that's where we all mess up and lose our focus.  Now that I know HOW to lose weight, the question becomes "why don't I stick with it long enough to reach my goal?"  Bill Phillips of Body for Life fame talked about "crossing the abyss."  He also said "real change starts on the inside", meaning it starts (and continues) in your head, and what goes on in your head leads to what you see on your outside.  If the mental part of weight loss isn't solid and in place, if it isn't a continuing effort, you probably won't succeed.  This is the same concept Tory is discussing throughout the book with her term of "the shift".  Her "shift" is that glaring realization and acceptance that one must decide what is most important:  losing weight and seriously modifying one's diet (and sticking with it!!) in order to lose weight, or whether it's "sort of" trying to lose weight but through too much cheating and indulgence endlessly stalling and never quite reaching that elusive goal.  She calls these ideas "preference and priority."  It became very clear to me that for years I didn't have the  mental stuff totally in place, and far too often I was choosing my preferences and ignoring my supposed priority of losing weight.I love her idea of "Preference vs. Priority".  That really is weight loss in a nutshell, in my opinion.  We all have our preferences about what we'd like to eat.  How many times have you heard someone say they are "desperate" to lose weight, but they "just can't give up wine, or bread, or this or that."  So do we indulge our preferences over and over still expecting to drop weight easily, or do we make weight loss and eating the right foods in the right amounts a priority over our preferences?  After reading this book, I now keep this concept in mind every time I have a food choice in front of me.  Do I indulge in that little bitty donut or whatever it is because I really want to eat that, or do I put priority over that preference because for now, doing something positive to further weight loss is a priority over a momentary desire to eat something not on my plan.  Part of the mental success with dieting means you have these kinds of tools at the front of your mind. This book totally clarified all this for me in a way that other books previously had not.  There was nothing in this book I hadn't read or thought about before, but somehow Tory presented it in a way that made it all obvious and doable. For me it has become:  Priority over preference so I can lose this final bit of weight I want to lose.  No more excuses.  And I have a good strategy to stop myself from that pesky cheating behavior.Above all this, the book is a humorous, enjoyable read.  It capsulizes a lot of good points that I wrote down and find very useful.  I would say a lot of people just aren't ready for this quite yet.  You may have to reach a point of frustration over failed dieting, and that's where you realize that the source of your failure to succeed is precisely this:  in your mind.  She makes it very clear that endlessly searching for a "magic bullet" for quick and easy weight loss doesn't really exist.  I haven't found it in 13 years, and I have an enormous library of weight loss books.  I get something from them all, but after finally figuring out that a low carb diet agreed with my body more than anything else, and that the beautifully muted appetite that goes along with a low carb diet helps me stay on track, the final and missing component in my efforts was exactly what is discussed in this book:  the mental mindset about all of it.  That's the value of this book, if you are ready for the message.  Some of the more negative reviews on the book reflect that the writers aren't ready to work on the mental mindset just yet.

Watched this for a class, but so glad I did.  Two hours long, but absolutely riveting start to finish and beautifully done.  Narrated by Liam Neeson, the film really brought to life the famous Greeks it highlighted.  I got a feel and understanding of this important period of history in a way nothing else has.  Anyone would enjoy this and benefit from watching it, and in fact, anyone from junior high through high school (or more) should watch this of necessity to understand our Western World.  You see a lot of parallels to certain aspects of history repeating itself over and over and over....

I'm finding this book to be an excellent overview, informative and enjoyable for me as a person who has an interest in the subject but who never really got to study much Humanities when I was in college majoring in other subjects.  This book covers a lot of important things without being too dense with detail.  There are a nice selection of very good supporting images, and the book is laid out very nicely and logically.  This is obviously a textbook and is presented as such, with a summary of topics and study questions at the end of each chapter.  For a true Humanities major, this might be too much of a general survey, but I'm enjoying it a lot for my own purposes.I know a lot of Humanities 1 courses currently utilize this particular text for intro survey type clases.  There are a couple of different versions of this text out there.  This one includes selected short readings in the back from the various classics that were mentioned in the chapters...such as writings from Plato, the Iliad and Odyssey, and so on.  The translations of the ancient texts are quite good and modern in style, easy to understand and enjoyable to read, and provide a good feel for the nature of these famous samples of the early literature.  Be aware that there are other versions of this text that do NOT include the readings, which are also sold within separate volumes of just the readings. If your instructor has assigned the text with readings but you do not require an access card to the supersite for the textbook, this is the one to order.  You can safely order a used version of this.  Another version says it comes with a Resource Center Printed Access Card (this would be only with a NEW textbook, be aware you would not get the card with any used book)  but that one does NOT include the readings, which would then have to be purchased separately if they are needed in a class.  The versions of this book that are out there are somewhat confusing, so if ordering for a class be careful which one you order.  I'd suggest getting the ISBN# for the exact text required in your class, and that way you will be getting the correct text.

I've now had 4 of these clocks.  The first two I bought 5 or 6 years ago, a slightly different design.  One still works, the other is several hours off and won't reset itself properly.  I bought two more like this one in the photo about 3 years ago.  They both work in all ways except one of them is about 15 minutes too slow, and it just seems to be stuck like that:  resetting doesn't help.  I really wish these lasted longer because everything about the design is fantastic:  Different levels of illumination are possible, from full brightness to nothing.  I keep mine dark at night, but touching the to bar once lights it up for a few seconds if you want to check the time.  It has two alarms that can be set for different times.  The alarm is soft at first, and each time it goes off (15 mintue intervals) it's a bit louder.  It's really quite easy to set the alarm.  I keep buying these, but it does seem they last only a few years at best.  Very disappointing.  Unfortunately, I've not found any other clock with these great features.  Too bad Brookstone can't figure out the problem with the resetting or whatever it is that makes the time veer off course after a couple of years.

I'll start by saying this is an odd product.  I tried it from a magazine sample, but the amount was tiny and it was hard to say what I thought.  However, it was interesting enough that I remembered the product.  After trying a second sample recently, I decided to spring for a tube.  The usual drugstore outlets had it at full price.  I got mine via a military PX for five less than the full price, but I have to say the price on Amazon is the best I've seen anywhere!  If I buy a second tube, I'll be purchasing here on Amazon!Now for the product itself:  You do have to read and heed instructions for how and when to apply it.  Ladies:  this is NOT a moisturizer!!  I'm 64 and have very good skin with fairly small pores and hardly any wrinkles, so admittedly I'm not battling big problems.  However, my big issue is a bit of dryness and regular flakiness that I constantly have to deal with.  I do a lot of things to protect and moisturize my skin.  Pretty much on a daily basis, mornings, I have to use a bit of scrub to remove small flaky spots.  Then I use an oil as the first thing...right now I'm trying L'Oreal's Age Perfect Glow Renewal Facial oil...so far I like it but the jury is still out as to how well it helps with the moisturizing.  I'm trying to reduce that flakiness, so that's my main goal.  So the oil is the first thing, then I use a moisturizer with SPF, various products actually, I don't have a favorite although right now I do really like Clinique's Even Better Skin Tone Correcting Moisturizer...I love how it goes on, it doesn't irritate my sensitive skin, and it's a nice non-greasy moisturizer for me.  Rather costly, though.  After that I use the L'Oreal Miracle Blur Cream.  Yes, it's quite thick, almost like a paste, although if you dispense just a bit and rub it between your fingers for a moment, it softens and applies better.  Then I apply it very lightly.  It spreads just fine if you don't use too much, and once on, gives a lovely nice smooth finish that I really like as a base.  I put BB cream on top of that, then a bit of Bare Minerals powder makeup, blush, mineral veil on top.  Seems like a lot, but it looks great and smooth like those gals at the department store beauty counters, and so far I'm happy with what I'm seeing from the Miracle Blur cream.The real test will be when I reach the end of the first tube...whether or not I buy another one.  The jury is still out on this too, so I'll see what I think then.  So far, I do see a better look, very lovely and smooth without looking made up, it doesn't irritate my very sensitive skin, it gives a great base for the mineral powder makeup, it adds a 30 spf which is nice.  I'll update my review at the end of the tube.  Only negative so far is that it's a fairly small tube, so I suspect it won't last long even though I'm using a very small amount each time.

I think that many readers will be able to recognize themselves in the complex, vibrant characters Tammy Flanders Hetrick has created for Stella Rose. This was one of those books I want to gift to my friends and talk about afterward. I definitely could see it as a book discussion selection as there are so many themes and elements to debate and discuss. I can't wait to read more from this intriguing author.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I'm on the fence with this one. Though I thought the story was interesting, I never connected to the hero and heroine, which takes some of the fun out for me. I think the failure in connection came from my impression that, as vividly drawn as the characters were, their flaws were just too close to the surface. They were almost caricatures, too much alpha, too much drama, too much angst... too much effort for me to connect. I really liked the first book in the series, and I definitely will keep reading Ms. Jewell's writing, Hard to Break just isn't my favorite.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This is a story about family, understanding, forgiveness. human dignity and justice. If that sounds heavy, yes it was challenging for me. What kept me reading despite the heaviness of the subject matter was Corban Addison's deeply layered and vibrant characters. There are so many themes addressed in this story that I can easily see it becoming a book discussion favorite. It was evenly paced, and the events were a bit predictable, but as I stated, the vivid characters and their reaction/response to events was what made the novel interesting. I will definitely read more from Corban Addison.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in response for an honest review.

Addicted was entertaining but the cover art and synopsis led me to believe it would be a lot heavier on the erotica side than it turned out. I actually enjoyed the meet cute; the heroine meets the hero when she attends the wrong self-help group meeting, one for sex addicts instead of overeaters! In the beginning of the book, I wasnt fond of either the hero or the heroine, I found them both a bit shallow and self centered. I am glad that I stuck with them on their journey, because Amelia Betts managed to include realistic character growth in her story. It was subtle, but effective. I appreciated her writing all the more for that subtlety. I went with a 3.5 rating based on the story and the character growth.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

One of the reasons I chose this book was the creative premise, blogging (and the anonymity it might/might not offer) intrigues and entices. The story is told in the first person, from the heroine's view, which works out well because of the wit and humor with which Amy Sue Nathan infuses her characters. There  are appealing and quirky characters of all ages, enough "I Love Lucy" moments to keep the sense of fun, and a delightful well crafted story. If you like character driven chick lit, in the manner of Jennifer Weiner, this novel would be a great choice. The ethical conundrums encountered during the story lend themselves well to discussion and debate, so I might consider this a solid book club selection.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I found The Good Neighbor to be entertaining, not riveting, but an enjoyable read. It moved along at a fairly even pace, but I needed more surprises in the twists and turns. They seemed to be telegraphed. I had no problems with the characters, they were multi dimensional and interesting. The dialogue was appropriate for most characters and situations.  All in all, it was a pleasant read, and I would try more from A.J. Banner.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

How refreshing! It was such a pleasure to start this new Meg Chambers series, Winnie Wilde. My happiness began with the fantastically quirky and interesting lead character Winnie. It was so nice to read about an older woman that didnt fall apart when he life began crumbling. She was multi layered and so very easy to connect to emotionally. The love story at the heart of this book made it fun and entertaining. I really didnt notice the age difference between Winnie and her new man unless the characters brought up an issue, I found the story well crafted and the pacing was fast but definitely not sweet. I cant wait for the next book.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Unfortunately I did not read the first book in this Dark Mountain series, which made me a lot lost when I started Desperate Deception. The hero and heroine have a past, and it would have helped me to have known the details. I thought the characters were engaging and interesting, especially the  supporting characters. The story is set in the Blue Mountains of Australia, and I really appreciated the beautifully detailed work D.B. Tait did in painting the setting. There are a lot of local phrases and definitions, as well as speech patterns to pay attention to, as well. There is a strong thread of suspense well woven through the book and the twists and turns will keep readers guessing. I think I would like to read the other books in the series.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I started this book quite happy and content. I enjoyed the hero and heroine's meeting, and the premise was intriguing. The first half of the book, I toodled along quite smoothly.  I wasn't emotionally attached to the characters or their happily ever after, but they were interesting and multi faceted. The second half of the book just didn't sell the relationship for me. The exploration of BDSM was less than exciting, the scenarios seemed inserted into the story rather than woven into the plot. Though it wasn't badly plotted, there was too much dialogue description (repetitive too) - He replied, she stated, she cried, he growled, etc. I think the shorter length may have hampered my enjoyment.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Lovely, beautiful friends to lovers, second chances book. I absolutely enjoyed the heck out of this novel. The hero and heroine were such engaging and grab your heart characters that I immediately became invested in their happily ever after. I cant believe this is the last book in a series, now I have to go on the hunt for the previous books! I did not feel at all lost or confused. The storyline was clear and the book stands alone beautifully. I think that what I most appreciated was the humor and wit with which Laura Drewry infuses her dialogue. Well, that and the beautiful love story! I can't wait to read the rest.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Once again, Anne Marsh offers readers a solid novel. Though I had to suspend belief for a bit to accept the premise of this novel, I found it fun, flirty and entertaining. Anne Marsh has a real gift for writing sharp, edgy dialogue and creating sexy, fun situations. Her characters, both primary and secondary are fully dimensional and engaging, as well as vibrant and vocal. Each offering in the Uniformly Hot series can stand alone, but I recommend the series, each story is unique, sexy and satisfying.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This novel was pure escapist fun for me. I truly enjoyed Anna Lefler's light-hearted look at parents and children and the agonies and ecstasies of preschool. There are three families at the heart of the book, and we follow each group during their experiences, hence three points of view. Each voice is engaging and the characters themselves are actually quite layered and complex. It was a fast read and there were several laugh out loud moments. I would like to read more from Ms. Lefler.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This bio of Lou Reed and his music was a bit heavy for me. There was a lot of really strong information, but I found it more music history than personal history. My goal in choosing this book was to find out more about the man behind the music, and I just didn't feel that I got as good a handle on Lou Reed as I would have liked. What is contained in these pages though, is a fantastically detailed account of the making of the albums and music I grew up around. I think this book would appeal to readers that want the "making of" details, and can see it used as reference. I do not recommend anyone try and read it straight through, it would be quite overwhelming.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Wow, I'm a fan of Lauren Layne. Her books are smart, sexy, intelligent, entertaining and irresistible. The same can be said about her characters, as they are vibrant and complex with layers revealed slowly and carefully. Irresistibly Yours is sports centered, with both the hero and heroine being sports writers by trade. It played a part but didnt overwhelm the story. What I really appreciated was the slow unfolding of the story, and the entertaining journey to happily ever after. The pacing was even, the secondary characters strong and the book itself had balance. I truly am enjoying this series. Oh, by the way, this one stands alone just fine.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

There is a story here, including an alpha billionaire and a younger woman. The difficulty I had with this novel was that the passion and story were out of balance. There were beautifully written love scenes, however they were out of sync with the storyline, mostly at the beginning of the book. That preponderance of sexual activity at the beginning made it hard for me to get a good read on the characters, making it harder to connect and become invested in their story. Once the story began to firm up, I became more engaged and I was sorry to see the story end. It did not end on a cliffhanger, but there are enough loose threads that I can see more stories on the horizon.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This is book 2 in an erotic series, and I really think I would have enjoyed the story more had I read book one. It was easy to pick up the story and I didn't feel lost, but I think my connection to the characters would have been stronger had I read the previous installment. Darker the Release had a good balance between story and passion, it moved rather quickly and smoothly. The hero and heroine were engaging and Im interested in what happens next.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Pretending to Dance was a bit too predictable for me. It had a strong premise and an interesting introduction. For me, however, the "lies" and "secrets" were a bit too transparent. I liked the technique of using flashbacks to tell the story and reveal the secrets. The characters were fairly layered and interesting. I have read Diane Chamberlain books in the past and enjoyed them, and I must say that this was an enjoyable read as well. I think fans of Ms. Chamberlain, Jodi Piccoult, and Heather Gudenkaff will be interested in this novel. It could easily be a book discussion selection.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

A little romance, a little suspense and a bit of holiday - just enough of each to make this shifter story an enjoyable read for me. I went with 4 stars because of the quality of Terry Spears' writing. She has been offering readers stories centered on the wolf shifters and always manages to come up with a fresh angle and a strong storyline. A Silver Wolf Christmas could be read as a stand alone, and reading out of order is ok in this series. I did think that the suspense aspect of this book was a little weak, but the romance made up for it well.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

A Christmas centered story and the kick off of a series, what fum! Kim Redford has lured me in with this lovely, fun read. The town and townspeople were so amusing and quirky, it made the setting come alive and I can easily picture more stories woven from them.
