This one was at times both sweet and steamy, with a beautifully written hero and heroine, sharp dialogue and an extremely satisfactory journey to happily ever after. I look forward to the series.*I I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

History comes alive in this excellent offering from Douglas Waller. As always, well researched, and lucky for readers, written conversationally and superbly. The continuation of the Wild Bill Donovan story and the introduction of his "disciples" is compelling reading and I certainly better understand the phrase "history repeats itself" after reading about our country and the Donovan Legacy. This belongs in your collection.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Extremely complex characters make this a compelling read. I liked the premise of this offering from Wendy S Marcus, and the story delivered on the promise. I especially liked the pen-pal exchanges at the start of the book, as it built to the actual meeting. What was difficult for me, was the moodiness and volatility of the heroine. She got to be a little over the top in her actions and reactions, which broke my sympathetic connection to her at times. I was emotionally invested in the hero's happily ever after however, as I found him vivid and engaging. The journey to happily ever after was an overall enjoyable one, and I would definitely read more in the series (All I Need is You stands alone)and from Wendy Marcus.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I am so happy I made the decision to request this book, though I must tell you I did it because of the title and cover. I got so much more than I bargained for when I read it easily from cover to cover. Then I went back and picked out sections to re-read! The Little Vanilla book isn't about letting your freak flag fly, rather it is a really empowering aid in the journey to self-awareness and empowerment. Lux Alani writes in a very conversational manner about authenticity, confidence, body image, resilience, and fear. I wanted to talk about what I'd read, so I think it might make a great book discussion selection. The Little Vanilla Book is the kind of book I will be buying as gifts for so many beautiful women in my circle, as well.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Let me start by saying that I have not read the previous books in the Sinner's Tribe trilogy. Perhaps that put me at a disadvantage while reading Sinner's Steel. The premise of first loves reunited, of second chances at love usually appeals to me, but in this instance I never warmed up to the heroine. Not being able to connect and find the heroine sympathetic made me actually not enthusiastic about the romantic re-connection. I really didn't feel she deserved the hero. I did find the secondary characters and side stories immensely interesting, and that's truthfully what kept me reading. Perhaps had I read the other books first, I would have approached this one differently as I really liked the author's writing style.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This is book 3 in an excellent series, and the writing is superb. My only caveat would be that though it stands alone, it might take a new reader some time to sort out the backstory and players. I think the most benefit would come form reading the series in order. That being said, the premise is excellent and the story keeps the promise of the premise. I really appreciated Jackie Ashenden's layered and complex characters. The heroine is appropriately weak and strong when the story warrants, she was quite vivid. The hero, on the other hand, didn't start out particularly likable. It is to Ms. Ashenden's credit that he was redeemed in my eyes by the end of the book. Well done.* I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

As a romance fan, this novel left me a bit wanting. I understood from the synopsis that the "hero" was going to be tormented however I wanted to see more change and growth. The second chance at love combined with the fake relationship might have worked better for me, had I trusted that the hero deserved the heroine's dedication. It was a well written story, I found it an easy read. I appreciated the strength and depth of the heroine. Rock Redemption is part of a series, but could be read as a stand alone. I found the secondary characters interesting enough and the writing compelling enough to warrant a look at the series.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Great series starter. Lucy Farago manages to deliver a very balanced romantic suspense novel while still laying the groundwork for a series. I am really impressed by her writing. The premise is interesting, the secondary characters seem strong and the possibility of their stories will keep me interested I believe. Sin on the Strip had compelling characters in the hero and heroine, and it was easy to root for their happily ever after. I think that what I liked most was that the suspense didn't overwhelm the romance or vice versa. Well Done. I look forward to the next book.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This novel had a lot going on. At times, I found it a bit overwhelming, however Katie Lane managed to wrap it all up in a beautiful bow by the end of the story ( really, no pun intended :). There are fantastically quirky secondary characters, as well as a beautifully layered, vibrant hero and heroine. I really enjoy the humor that Ms. Lane injects into her smart, crisp dialogue. If you like a fast, flirty, sexy romance with enough interesting characters to make life confusingly fun, this one's for you. I'm definitely a fan.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Wow, just wow! I so appreciated the knowledge William Craig has amassed through his research. This book was written in an almost conversational style, and included so much more than just military facts. We also get a glimpse into the history of the social mores of Japan and the politics as well as the aspect of the monarchy. The Fall of Japan conveys beautifully the events that brought an end to the Pacific War and the  unconditional surrender of the great nation of Japan. It belongs on any military collector's bookshelf.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I enjoy Shelly Laurenston's writing style; her sense of humor connects well with my own.  I hope many more readers discover this writing talent. I think what I appreciate most is that, though this is technically a "shifter" book, the characters only display the traits of their basic animal, rather than actually shift into them totally. That makes for really multi layered characters and such entertaining situations. This is part of a series, I recommend that you read them all in order to get the most entertainment value! I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

This my first Sandra Owens novel, and I think I'm going to like the series. Though Falling For Her is the third book, I didn't feel lost at all. I especially appreciated the world Ms. Owens has created in K2, the operatives are interesting and quirky, and I look forward to the rest of their stories. What I really liked about Falling for Her was the depth of the hero and heroine, such complex and complete characters. I was easily able to become invested in their journey to happily ever after. There's a nice balance between romance/passion and action in this well crafted, evenly paced, beautifully detailed novel.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Fake relationship is the start of an entertaining journey to happily ever after. Stefanie London writes with humor and passion. it was easy to connect to her multi dimensional characters.  This novel seems to be the start of a series, but I never felt pulled out of the story as the series was set up. Pretend It's Love was an easy read, very well crafted, and the extremely witty dialogue and fun situations made it seem to move very quickly. I would definitely read more from Stefanie London.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

A Doctor/Weekend Cowboy and the wrong twin, what could be more fun? This frenemies to lovers story worked. I loved this well balanced sexy offering from Cathryn Fox. It had such an exciting premise and she really delivered the goods. The novella format is difficult, but she managed to pack in a complete story, strong well drawn characters and enough raw passion and heat to make the whole experience sizzle. I can't wait for more in this series.*I received my copy from NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Phil Harvey's novel seems to combine the reality show aspects of Survivor with the battle to the death aspects of The Hunger games trilogy. The premise was really intriguing, 7 people on an island (wired with sound and cameras) must survive the brutal winter, like the survivor show; outwit, outplay, outlast, and the cast members that survive the 7 months will win 400,000 each. The twist comes in when you realize, the producers and the audience don't really care if everyone survives. The scenes are beautifully detailed; I think I could feel the cold.  The characters are layered and interesting, and the story itself is fast paced. I was expecting some adult themes and violence, and that's definitely what Show Time contained. Lots of twists and turns kept me reading and entertained. I think it might make an interesting selection for a book discussion group; lots of themes to explore.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

A sweet story, just a little confusing at times. I haven't read the first 2 books in the series, so I'm not sure if that was part of my confusion. The book started out well, Sydney Bristow laid the groundwork well. It was when the second chance at love story moved 15 years ahead that I began to lose focus. I did find the characters interesting, and the premise and the backstory were strong. If you like a story with a little complexity this one's probably for you.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Though I thoroughly enjoyed the story, the ending was a bit abrupt. I almost felt the hero and heroine were happy for now, and I wanted more. I guess I like my books to end with the happily ever after in no doubt. I might have benefited from an epilogue, I suppose. I really appreciated the beautifully detailed settings in this novel, what a treat for the imagination. The heroine was a very layered and complex character, and I found her easy to connect to emotionally. The hero was just a little two dimensional for me, I wanted to see a little more growth from him to make his actions a bit more believable. The story itself was entertaining and well written, and I would definitely read more from Michelle Vernal.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I definitely did not find this a relaxing book. If you like psychological suspense with many twists and turns, you will appreciate the work of Alexandra Burt. I was impressed by the amount of emotion she was able to evoke from me, I began reading faster because I felt the mother's tension and need to find her baby. I felt at times that I was caught in a dream I couldn't wake myself from, which means the level of immersion in the story was high. So, well crafted, great premise, and the story keeps the promise of the premise. I was thoroughly entertained by Little Girl Gone.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I went with 3.5 - 4 stars because Lisa Marie Rice writes such a great story. The action/suspense/romance in this one is a bit unbalanced towards the suspense area, it seems a little heavy in politics. It didn't take away from my enjoyment of the book, or the series. This is the 4th book in a series, and though it stands alone, I think readers would benefit from the build up of the first three books. Multi dimensional primary and secondary characters, edge of your seat situations, and passionate encounters make this a very entertaining book.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I would purchase this book for the illustrations alone. It is one of the most visually pleasing books I've seen lately. Does it have everything you ever wanted to know about tea? No, I don't believe it is all encompassing, however, it certainly contains a lot of interesting information. Beverly Dubrin is passionate about tea, and it shines through her writing. I think this would make a wonderful centerpiece in a gift basket, along with some examples of the teas from the book and a lovely tea cup....*i received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Well written erotic romantic suspense is how I would describe Right By Your Side. Christ Snow writes with passion, but this book has so much more. The story itself is beautifully crafted and the suspense aspects are woven in seamlessly. There is a definite balance to this book, I never felt cheated by the fact that a series was also being launched. The characters were rich and layered, the dialogue appropriate to character and situation, and the pacing fast and even. I look forward to book 2.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I truly thought I was done with billionaire heroes, but Meghan March roped me in with this one. It's just such a tiny piece of the dynamic, complex hero, that it contributes to but doesn't dominate the story. How refreshing. This is the 4th in a series, I have not read the others, but I was not at all lost or confused. The secondary characters are quirky and memorable enough to warrant seeking out the previous books. I appreciated the depth and layers of both the hero and heroine. It was easy to make that emotional connection and root for them to reach that happily ever after moment. Beneath These Scars is evenly paced, well crafted, and extremely entertaining.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I would call this light comedy, light romance. I just never got a handle on the hero. I believe it's because the story is told first person from the heroine's point of view. That made her a rather unreliable narrator when it came to insights into the hero. I really could appreciate the humor with which Elle Casey infused the book, her sharp dialogue, and the heroine's internal dialogue were laugh out loud at times. I actually found most of the secondary characters quirky and interesting, so I think the series might work. I'd definitely give The Bourbon Street Boys another try.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I found this book to be just plain fun. Would I play most of those games in my office? Probably not, but I think the point of the book is entertainment. It would make a fun gift - perhaps Secret Santa or White Elephant at work. I do however, think that some of the games could be modified as ice-breakers for meetings or training classes. If you are looking for something satirical and fun to read, I'd definitely go this route.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Wow, they say you can't go home again, but that has never rung so true for me as while reading this entertaining novel from Kelly Bennett Seiler. The heroine returns home, a victim of a violent crime, and it seems that her life has taken an entirely different trajectory. How interesting that I read this on the weekend that Cinespia is screening Back to the Future! It is so much fun to play "what if?" and the author certainly explores every aspect of the possibilities. The book and the complexity of the characters drew me in immediately, but it is Ms. Bennett Seiler's writing ability that kept me reading. It was a fascinating subject, a well crafted story and a superb read. I could easily see this book as a book discussion selection.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Having never read anything from this series put me at a disadvantage. Though I enjoyed the book, I think I missed a lot of the references to secondary characters and events. The pacing was quite fast, the action sequences compelling and the twists and turns rarely predictable. The romance side of the story was weak for me, perhaps because I just didn't have a good handle on the hero and heroine; lots of missed opportunities as far as I was concerned, there were holes in their character portraits that might have made them more approachable as a couple. There is a secondary romance that made a lot of sense and was quite entertaining. I believe I will see out Laura Griffin's backlist, as her ability to write suspense is not in question, and I would like to know more of the team.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I liked it, I didn't love it. What kept me from loving it was that I had a hard time connecting with the heroine. Her behavior at times swung toward the petty and childish, and I didn't see enough growth from her by the book's ending, which really disappointed me. I found the hero to be both more mature and more complex. What did work for me was the baseball backstory and the plot itself. The overarching story was really well crafted, and I can see why this series is popular; the writing is strong, the characters quirky and interesting, and though this stood alone well, the info regarding the series and it's characters is compelling enough for me to give the series a look. Katie Rose writes a good story.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Wow, this book was fast and furious. The occupations of the hero and heroine couldnt have been more interesting and farther apart! The book's action started early and Monica McCabe kept up the pace throughout. I really appreciated her beautifully detailed settings, the exotic locale was one thing that attracted me to the story. I also really admire the way she is able to strike such a balance between action and romance, I never felt chested on either front. If you like adventure with your romance, give this talented author a look.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an  honest review.

Knowing up front that this was the first book in a trilogy and likely to end on a cliffhanger was beneficial. I was less critical during my reading, as I believe my questions will be answered in subsequent books. Belle Davis has given readers two interesting characters in her hero and heroine, both are strong and independent. Seeing their relationship grow and change will be intriguing. I appreciated the balance of passion and story, and yes, it was quite passion filled. As I said, it does end on a cliffhanger, but the next one is available (I checked before beginning),. The pacing is fast and the story well crafted.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Though this book was short, it definitely packed a punch. His Stubborn Lover launches a new series, Slade Security Team. I was pleasantly surprised that only a small portion of this novella length book was used to set up the scenario of the series, and that the bulk was dedicated to the current story. It was fairly balanced between action and romance, but I could have easily read more about the characters, I found them interesting and engaging. I hope to see more of them in future books - and yes that means I will be looking for the rest of the series! The only thing that I was disappointed in, was the title, I just didn't think it fit the story.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

Sort, sweet, full of humor and sass. Sharon Kleave has mastered the difficult genre of the novella. This offering is so very balanced, the amount of character development seems more than adequate - I found them to be fully dimensional and endearing, the story it self was complete and well crafted, and the ratio of dialogue seemed well distributed. I think that I most appreciated the dialogue - if you are a fan of wit and sass - this one's for you, and I have the feeling I will be on the lookout for more Sharon Kleave books.*I received my copy through Goodreads.com in exchange for an honest review.

Beautifully written enemies to lovers story. Though this is book 6 in the Cover to Cover series, I did not feel lost at all. In fact, I am so impressed by Alexandrea Weis' writing that I will be seeking out the prior books. Rival Seduction was just a really good love story, well crafted, evenly paced and a lovely journey to happily ever after. The characters were complex and engaging, and the secondary characters were quirky and unique as well. I think one thing I really appreciated was the witty dialogue, it always seemed appropriate to character and situations. The passion factor is high. Well done.*I received my copy through NetGalley.com in exchange for an honest review.

I have used these on several projects now and I really like them.  I was skeptical that they could be plastic and hold up to being fastened over and over again without breaking but they have held up without any sign of weakening.  I like the bright colors as they show up and stand out in my projects. I also have the Clover Split Ring Markers, which also work well, but will slide off of the yarn if you're manipulating your project quite a bit, so these locking markers really come in handy.  I also like how they come in their own flapped storage pouch.

I loved working with this yarn and its indigo blue color.  The saturation of blue dye in this yarn makes it a bit stiffer than lighter colored Vanna's Choice yarns but it is still amazingly soft.  I used 7 skeins on my shawl project and did not experience any splitting and only encountered one knot, which I was able to easily cut out and keep working.  I love how this yarn is completely machine washable/dryable.  I would recommend washing your project in a bag (I use a pillow case) if your project has fringe.  Otherwise, I throw mine straight into the washer and dryer.  I will be buying this Denim Mist again and again to make things for my blue loving family members and friends.  Each skein is 100% acrylic and 3 oz/145 yds.The project I made is from The Crocheted Prayer Shawl Companion: 37 Patterns to Embrace, Inspire, and Celebrate Life.  Happy stitching!

There are 50 applique blocks of flowers and a few cute bugs in this fun book!  I love this book because it inspires me to create my own projects using any selection of these blocks in whatever format my imagination can dream up.  I think their style is whimsical and charming and my first project will be designing my own baby quilt featuring several of the flower blocks and maybe a couple of the cute bugs thrown in for good measure.The blocks are all 8 inches square but if that seems small there are instructions for adding borders to beef up their size.  The book begins with a couple of pages of General Instructions, which covers the basics of rotary cutting, piecing, proper pressing, fusible web applique, borders, layering the quilt, and quilting.  Schaefer also gives a bit of instruction on color and fabric choices along with some general information about yardage and fabric requirements.Scattered throughout the book are tips from the author to aid us in completing a well-done project...for example, Shaefer says, "My best quilt-making tip is: Learn to sew an accurate 1/4" seam."Each block has it's own page, which acts as the layout diagram and the full-size template for the applique pieces.  The projects begin with single block quilts, where we can select whatever block(s) suits us or our decor and quickly work up a fast and fun wall hanging.  Or in my case, to go along with that baby quilt, how about a sweet pillow...or a crib bumper pad made by stringing several blocks together?  See, this book inspires me.  The projects also include a 23" x 57" table runner, 48.5" x 48.5" table topper, three wall quilts, and two lap quilts.  Keep in mind that we can substitute our favorite blocks for the author's choices in all the projects.The individual instructions for each project are comprehensive and very easy to understand and follow.  The one thing not included are quilting diagrams for the finished projects.I love this book and have included photos of the projects so you can see if it is something that you would also enjoy.  Happy Stitching!

Had there been a Look Inside feature for this book, I wouldn't have purchased it, as the look of the finished projects, is too primitive for me.  That said, I can see how those who love this look would be thrilled with this book.  Bonanomi has crammed this book full of practical and decorative projects overflowing with whimsy in her primitive aesthetic.  You'll find bed quilts, pillows, runners, wall hangings, sewing accessories, slippers, a jacket, jacket pins, and hooked rugs to keep you busy.Comfort Zone is chock full of instructions in how to achieve this primitive look by adding age/distressing to these projects using Rit Dye and adding rips and fraying here and there.  The supplies needed to make these projects are few and easy to find: needles, scissors, pins, thread, freezer paper, quilting ruler, and a rotary cutting mat.  Many of the projects would be great for using up materials from our stash/scraps of bits of wool and other embellishments like ribbon, trims, buttons, etc.All the projects in this book assume a knowledge of the techniques involved in producing the finished product: sewing, applique, rug hooking, etc. The templates for the applique are full-size, so no enlarging is necessary.  Take a look at the photos of the projects and see if they appeal to you.Happy stitching!

The cute stockings on this book's cover hooked me. I am a fool for stockings, as I love to give them as gifts! In addition to the stockings, we can make pillow cases, top sheets, mug rugs, silverware caddies, placemats, napkins, a table runner, a mantel runner, tea towels, a wall hanging, a wreath pillow, coffee cup sleeves, tree skirt, a covering for a candle lamp, and a beautiful 52x72-inch quilt. Most projects are embellished with embroidery, some kind of applique (much of it using wool), and crayon tinting, which works beautifully, is long lasting, and has been around for a long time.The projects that made their way to my list is the reindeer stocking, the Christmas light pillowcases, the mug rugs (wouldn't they make cute potholders?), the table runner (with redwork embroidered text), the tea towels, and the "Home for Christmas" pillow featuring a wreath of holly and cardinals. Wow! I need to get busy!Each project comes with detailed/illustrated instructions and materials required. In addition, there are complete instructions on using crayons for tinting fabric (I recommend buying a separate box of white crayons if you're going to be doing a lot of tinting), cutting and piecing hexagons, and an entire section on hand stitching in the back of the book, which covers: working with wool, recommended threads/floss, needles, fabric preparation, transferring embroidery patterns, pens used for tracing patterns, applique, and embroidery. The embroidery instructions include: running stitch, back stitch, stem stitch, fly stitch, closed fly stitch, Palestrina knot, rosette chain stitch, bullion knot, bullion loop, French knot, couching, satin stitch, lazy daisy stitch, and the star stitch. No worries, all of these stitches have illustrations walking us through them.There are no instructions for finishing the quilted projects, instead there is a website to visit for this free illustrated information. All of the templates/diagrams are full size and the embroidery diagrams are in color.Sprinkled throughout the book are a few of the author's favorite seasonal recipes, including: Cranberry Casserole, Razmosas, Salmon with Brown Sugar and Mustard Glaze, Crab Cakes, Christmas Breakfast Strata, and Super Easy French Toast Casserole.Happy Stitching!

As the title suggests all the projects in this book follow the folk art (primitive) aesthetic and were inspired by artifacts of the 19th century and this is reflected in both the motifs and colors used throughout.  There are 14 of these themed wool projects for us to make, enjoy, and give as gifts. I have loved appliqueing with wool for a long time and this book will be a good addition to my pattern collection.  I especially like the 29x46-inch bed rug, cute 16x12-inch pillows, and the five beautifully designed table runners.There are great instructions for obtaining wool (flea markets, yard sales, etc.), processing it (dyeing and felting), and tips for storing it properly.  Or it can be purchased ready to use at many quilting/fabric stores.  Also given are illustrated instructions for the easy embroidery stitches used in the projects: blanket, outline, running, whipstitch, French knot, and stars.  The tools and supplies list for creating the projects is a fairly short one with easy to obtain items that most sewists probably already have, such as: scissors, rotary cutter/mat/ruler, Sharpie marker, various needles, pins, freezer paper (I get mine at Walmart), and embroidery floss.  There's also a resource list in the back of the book for everything needed to make any of the projects.  A bonus, to my way of thinking, is the pull out, full-sized pattern sheets at the back of the book.I thought all the individual instructions for each project were complete and comprehensive with many color photographs.  All in all, I really like this book.All but two projects (a needle case and patriotic table rug) are shown in the photographs that I've added to my review. For some reason, they did not show up when this review went live.  I'll try again later, it could be a small glitch with Amazon.  Happy Stitching!If you like the projects in this book, you might also like A Little Porch Time: Quilts with a Touch of Southern Hospitality.

I ordered this book for the blue handbag pattern and hoped to find more projects to enjoy once the book arrived.  For me, the handbags were the stars of this book of classic patterns.  I also liked the pillow patterns, a lacy shawl, and some cute pincushions  but as far as the remainder of the patterns go, as lovely as they are, they are not for me.All the projects within this book are beautifully photographed and the instructions are clear and easy to follow.  There are projects featuring Tunisian crochet and regular crochet.  There are nearly 20 pages of detailed stitch instructions shown with photographs to help with both regular and Tunisian crochet stitches.  There are also instructions for blocking the finished project.  These pages are very helpful.Included are patterns for wash cloths, hand towels, potholders, placemats, bags, scarves, pillows, shawls, pincushions, crochet hook cases, a ripple afghan, baby/doll blankets, cowls, and wrist warmers.Happy stitching!

I am very happy with this country pendant light.  I love everything about it!  The "rusted" brown chicken wire goes perfectly in my kitchen but I'm considering getting another one to hang in my sewing room.  It's very light weight, comes with two hooks for hanging, and the cord is cloth covered, which gives it a nice retro look.  There is some minor assembly but instructions are included.

I am now on my second set of these excellent sink strainers.  My first set were still functioning perfectly but had become paint stained from rinsing paint brushes in the sink.  These little gems work excellently to keep small bits of food from going down the drain and ultimately clogging our ancient plumbing.  They are much better than the plugs that came with the sink.  They are very easy to clean, I pop mine into the dishwasher.

I switched to the TrippNT Paper Towel Holder that dispenses tri-fold paper towels one at a time over a year ago, but my husband still likes to keep a roll of select-a-size paper towels in the kitchen.  I, too like the select-a-size towels but didn't like how I had to touch the towels and/or holder when my hands were messy/wet to tear one off.This Oxo Good Grips holder works beautifully requiring no touching of the towels or the holder in order to tear off a towel. It works just as shown in the video.  I particularly like the look of this holder and how little space its vertical design takes up in our small kitchen. It's also weighty enough that it doesn't tip or wobble when I tear off a towel.  All in all, this is a well designed and made holder.

Are two color quilts making a comeback?  They are in my world.  I've always been instantly drawn to quilts using high contrast fabrics and what better way to show high contrast than white and another color?  In this book, we see both red, blue, and sometimes both contrasted with white.  All are lovely but my favorites are those with only white and one other color.The Look Inside feature gives us a good example as to how comprehensive the instructions are for each quilt.  There are seven red and white, five blue and white, and five red, white, and blue quilts for us to drool over and hopefully work up.  So many quilts, so little time!  They range in size from a small wall-hanging, to lap quilts, and up to as large as queen size. Of course, all we need is a little bit of math to change the pattern to whatever size we want.All of the projects involve piecing while four have added applique.  The applique templates are full-size and the instructions for applique covers Basted-Edge, Needle-Turn Hand, Traditional Hand, Machine, and Fusible.  It is pretty much up to us to use whatever applique method is our favorite in these projects.In addition to the instructions shown with each project, there is a Quiltmaking Basics section in the back of the book covering Rotary Cutting, Cutting Bias Strips, Making Templates, Machine Piecing, Applique, Bias Vines, Quilt Top Assembly, Borders, Hand & Machine Quilting, Bias Binding Strips, and binding. These basics are a good refresher for the experienced and necessary for the beginner quilter.This is a wonderful book.  I especially love the cover quilt with the appliqued flower border (photo no. 1).  I'm pondering starting a new color trend... purple and white because purple seems to be the favorite color of just about everyone I'd like to gift with a quilt. :-)Happy Stitching!

I've used this product for a number of years in a couple of different ways.  I put it under my glassware in my kitchen cabinets. I've also used it under my dining chair cushions to keep them from skidding out of place and ripping off the cushion ties.  It works very well for both of these uses but lately I've found a new way to use this liner.  I adhere it to the bottom of slippers I crochet to make them non-slip.  It also works well in this application.

The twelve drop-dead-gorgeous quilts we can make using this book are modeled after antiques.  I have long loved red and white quilts and I'm very happy with the patterns the author chose for this book. And, oh... the photos of the antique quilts are so beautiful.All of the antique examples are from the collection of Ann M. Hazelwood.  Ms. Hazelwood also shares the interesting history of the red and white quilt in the foreword, which I found fascinating.The finished "replicas" are lovely but what makes them spectacular and stunning, to me, is the machine quilting done in each and every one.  The skill displayed by those who performed the quilting is amazing.  I found myself oohing and ahhing my way through the pages.  Each quilt comes with "Quilting Notes" from the talented quilter.The book begins with a few brief general instructions covering yardage requirements, border yardage, prewashing, hints on piecing, half-square triangle units, adding borders, preparing for quilting, and binding.  The instructions to make each individual quilt are comprehensive and detailed.Also, for comparison, you might want to look at Red, White, and Sometimes Blue: Classics from McCall's Quilting.  I particularly love the applique that is used in this particular book.Happy quilting!

When I first wrote my review, I gave this fountain four stars...today (5/8/15) I am changing it to two stars because it has begun to overflow.  Other reviewers said that thoroughly cleaning the fountain corrected their overflow problems but this has not worked for me.  It's clean and continues to overflow.  I think the problem is with the lid on the reservoir but I'm not sure nor do I have any idea how to fix it.  I am so bummed out because both my dog and son's cat have enjoyed this fountain.5/10/15...I had no idea how much the cat loved this fountain until I removed it!  He kicked up a fuss like we've never seen so I now have the fountain in a tray to catch the overflow.  Not the best situation but it will have to suffice until I find a better fountain.

These simple holders work well for my husband's extensive golf cap collection.  We have two packages and it's beginning to look as if we'll need a third!  This holder easily adjusts to the size of whatever door you attach them to or they come with the hardware to be hung on a wall.  Overall we are pleased with this Cap Holder.

I'm currently on a "two color quilt craze" and my search for patterns/examples of such led me to buy this book.  All nine of Mary's favorite quilts presented within this book are beauties from the mid 1800's.  She tells us in the introduction that she wrote this book to share her love for them and to show us how to recreate them.I found the instructions to be straight forward and easy to follow.  In addition to those for each quilt, there is one page of General Directions, which covers a bit about Fabrics, Piecing, Applique, Mitered Borders, Marking Quilting Designs, Basting, and Binding.  One of the things I appreciated were the small diagrams of the quilting recommended for each quilt.  The applique templates are full size so enlargement is not required.All in all I'm pleased with this book.

Heese describes autumn as her favorite time of year and how she wanted to create her own "designs that celebrated the season, only with a different feel than the typical motifs you see in autumn quilts and projects."  The six quilts and two smaller coordinating projects, a ruffled table scarf and small wall hanging, accomplish her goal.  Fall is my favorite season too and I love this author's expression of it.  I am especially taken with the first project in the book, "Splendor," an 80x80-inch quilt featuring pops of turquoise, red, and black.  (See photo one.)The book begins with instructions for needleturn applique using freezer paper, Heese's favorite method.  I especially appreciated her recommendation of using Fray Check on the edges of the background squares to prevent raveling and distortion.  This prevents having to cut the block and then resize it after stitching it.  There is also additional instructions given for appliqueing with wool and velvet.  A stitch guide illustrating the stem stitch and French knot is also provided.Each individual project includes instructions in fabric requirements, cutting, sewing, and block assembly with a diagram.  I think an experienced quilter would have zero problems completing the projects using the given instructions but anyone unsure of proper rotary cutting, pinning, pressing, and all aspects of finishing the quilt (backing, basting, binding, and quilting) will need an additional resource.All the applique templates are full size so no enlarging is necessary.

Margarete Heinisch says her daughter's admiration of a Baltimore album quilt at a local quilt show, "set off the first spark" in the back of her head to create her own album quilt.  "Mi Amor" is the result of that spark, a gift celebrating the 25th wedding anniversary of her daughter and son-in-law.  Each block in this magnificent quilt, symbolizes in some way, their life together.  All I can say is, wow, what a lovely gift and magnificent legacy.A CD-ROM containing all the templates, embroidery stitching, and layout diagrams for each block (to print out) is included.  The book begins with detailed and illustrated instructions for fabric requirements, additional supplies (such as batting, embroidery floss, etc.), fabric shortcuts (among others, the author suggests appliqueing silk leaves from artificial flowers), different ways to make stems, how to make circles, embroidery stitches (running stitch, fly stitch, back stitch, stem or outline stitch, couching stitches, buttonhole stitch, lazy daisy stitch, buttonhole scallops, straight stitch, satin stitch, French knot, bullion stitch, seed stitch, and turkey work), making yo-yo flowers, making rickrack flowers, embroidering ladybugs & potato bugs, using fabric paints, assembling the quilt, adding borders, adding corded piping, and finishing the quilt.Each of the 16 blocks is explained and illustrated in detail with the fabric requirements, supplies, sewing instructions, painting (if any) instructions, and an embroidery stitching chart (shows stitches used, thread color, etc.)  I appreciated and found very interesting the explanation given of the symbolism behind each block.The book concludes with what I thought was a fascinating explanation of the meaning of the flowers used in the blocks, such as: the olive branch means peace, tulip means beautiful eyes, nest means security, and so forth.This book has sparked my imagination and provoked my thoughts toward creating my own legacy quilt with blocks symbolizing my family's life story.

Our home has wood clap-board siding.  Our winters are pretty rough where we live and our siding, come spring, reflects the tough time it's been through, it is covered in dirt and grime.  This Krud Kutter worked pretty well when I used a scrub brush with it. On its own, without scrubbing... some grime remained.How I made this product work for me is after spraying it on, I let it set for a couple of minutes (as stated in the product directions), and then while it was still wet, I used a brush with an adjustable handle to scrub the siding. I wish less elbow grease was required to get the results I wanted but it wasn't to be.  Still it worked better than plain water and I'll probably use it again.

This applicator is an absolute hit with me.  It works beautifully for applying lotion and Bengay.  My skin is dry and itchy and because I have limited mobility in my shoulder, I am unable to apply lotion and pain relieving creams to my back and shoulder for relief.It's so easy to use.  Put the lotion/cream directly onto the applicator head and rub it onto your back.  I love using it for Bengay because I don't get the product on my hands.  The applicator head is also easy to clean.  Simply use a drop of shampoo or other liquid soap and rinse thoroughly.  It comes with a plastic head cover for storage.  I recommend this product for anyone with similar needs as mine.

I love Lang cards.  They are beautifully made, sturdy, have a linen finish, embellished envelope, and come in such a wide variety of covers and messages. The graphics of this two design assortment are so cute, sharp, and detailed.  I am over the moon for cardinals and the presence of one in these cards was the icing on the cake for me!  The only thing that would make these cards better would be if they filled themselves out!

Boone, my Shi-Tzu, LOVES these treats!  And he's picky.  He's been handed treats by his groomer, the UPS guy, and others when we've been out walking, but after politely taking them, he won't eat them.  I now gently decline them on his behalf...unless someone were to offer him one of these.  My husband and I have started spelling out the words "good" and "treat" when Boone's within ear shot because he goes wild.  I initially bought these dental snacks for their advertised "health" benefit but in all honesty continue to get them because Boone loves them.  One little hint, these can leave a pink mark on upholstery/bed linen if your dog drools at all while eating them.

I've been hooked on Lang calendars for many years now.  This year I've chosen this one featuring the artwork of Susan Winget.  I have to have a calendar to keep track of special dates and appointments, so I like having one with artwork that appeals to me and looks good in my kitchen.  In addition to its beauty, the squares are just large enough to write in a birthday or an appointment or two.  The paper Lang uses is heavy weight and has a linen look, which holds up to thumbing through to look ahead and write in upcoming appointments.  If there's a problem with these calendars it is that I cannot throw them away!  I have a stack of old ones with beautiful artwork that I keep thinking, "someday" I'll do something with those!If you love the artwork but prefer not to have the Bible passages, Lang also offers The Heart & Home Calendar, which has the same great Susan Winget art without Scripture.

When I received money for Christmas, I immediately purchased this book and one other (Tending the Garden) by Adams & Allen from my Wishlist and I'm very happy I did. I just absolutely love the large-block-applique designs put forth by these two talented women. The large blocks work up quickly and easily and before we know it, the quilt top is completed! A large size is also perfect for framing one of the completed blocks for wall art. These make wonderful gifts! When I'm sitting, my hands are never idle; I always have a quilt block to applique, something to embroider, or a crochet project.In addition to their signature "Feature Quilt" where Adams and Allen always give us their own creative version of it, there are ten additional projects inside the pages of this book. We have six more quilts, a hooked rug, two projects using wool applique, and a cross stitch pillow sham to get us busy. I am a particular fan of A&A's books predominantly because of the large block sizes used in most (not all) of their applique, and also because I enjoy how they often include non-quilting projects in them. In fact, I'm considering learning how to hook rugs. :-)The first two photos I've added show Adams' and Allen's versions of the 84x84-inch Feature Quilt; "Winter Garden" and "Love Letters," respectively named. To tie in with the book's title, the authors' chose plants and flowers that remind them of autumn and winter such as the pomegranate, rose hip, oak leaf, coxcomb, and five others. Their showing the quilt in two different colorways always inspires me to bravely choose my own colors."Autumn Thistle," the third photo, an 85x85-inch beauty has nine 20-inch thistle blocks surrounded by a very special border.For those who love smaller blocks, "Trick or Treat," the fourth photo, is 92x92-inches of 300 appliqued, 5-inch blocks of treat baskets! Wow!"Garden Song," photo number five, is a delightful 24x9-inch project using wool. I love this project! Wool is so much fun to applique (and easy!) and this size makes a perfect table topper, wall hanging, or even framed wall art.Photo six, "Harvest Basket" is 83x83-inches, and has a bit more piecing and a smaller amount of applique."Goldenrod in Bloom," photo seven, shows the designers using a bit of fussy cutting, piece work, and applique in this 80x80-inch scalloped edge quilt.Another appliqued wool project is shown in photo eight, this "Birds and Old Buttons Pillow" at 20x11-inches would make a sweet accent to any bed or seat in the home.Especially for Christmas, "Holly and Mistletoe" is an 83x83-inch stunner, which combines lots of pieced squares with beautiful applique. I especially love the intricate holly border of this beauty. Photo nine.The striking colorway that Barb uses here, makes the 51x51-inch "Frost on the Ferns," (utilizing the coxcomb block from the Feature Quilt) really stand out. Photo ten.Photo eleven shows an interesting use for checked fabric...cross stitch!The 24x20-inch "Rose Hip Hooked Rug" wraps up the projects in this book. I'd have to display this rug where it would be safe from dirty shoes!When it comes to the instructions for the projects, it is assumed that we are experienced at quilting, appliqueing, sewing, and rug hooking. There is instruction for hand applique using the freezer paper method. The whip stitch is called for to applique the wool pieces. There are full-size templates for the applique pieces and each block has an applique placement diagram (this does require enlargement.) The pattern for the hooked rug is also full size.I am experienced in quilting and applique and could complete the projects, which utilize these skills. However, I would need an additional resource to make the hooked rug. By the same token if you are inexperienced at quilting, I think you would probably need additional instruction to complete the quilts in this book. For example, this book does not include general instructions for rotary cutting, proper pressing, and making binding, sewing the binding to the quilt top, making a quilt sandwich, putting together the backing fabric, and quilting the top.

When I was gifted $$ for Christmas, I hastily spent it on this book and "When the Cold Wind Blows" also by Adams & Allen. I love applique and from the moment I stumbled across my first book by these two creative women I've been hooked on their designs. The quilts and other projects within the pages of this lovely book are beautifully photographed and displayed.There are ten projects in this book, five quilts, two cross-stitch patterns, two hooked rugs, and instructions for dying a vintage crocheted tablecloth to transform it into a blanket.As is usual for A&A, they begin with what they call their "Feature Quilt." Usually this quilt is shown in two colorways; one by Adams and one by Allen. In this book, we see the 84x84-inch "feature quilt" done in three different colorways. (Photos 1-3.) Fifty of the 96 pages of this book are dedicated to making the Feature Quilt. The thing I love the most (next to the designs themselves) is the large, 28-inch block size used in this quilt. Right now, I'm into making framed wall art from quilt squares. Of course, they would also make wonderful pillow fronts, too. How about stringing your favorite blocks together to make a runner? I also enjoy substituting wool for the fabric. In quilting, the possibilities are endless and only limited by our imagination!The remaining projects are: "Tumbling Lily," a 65x65-inch quilt with 20-inch blocks; a 60x60-inch throw quilt/wall hanging titled "My Heart is Yours"; a sweet cross-stitch pin-cushion; an 11x6.5-inch cross-stitch sampler; a 35x19.75-inch hooked rug; a hooked sewing box cover; a 24x60-inch appliqued table/bed runner; dying a vintage blanket (no photo) and an 80x80-inch pieced (no applique) quilt, aptly named "Summer Stars."Each project comes with detailed and comprehensive instructions for everything we need to know to sew each block and the quilt top. Instructions are given for hand applique using the freezer paper method. There are full-size templates for the applique pieces and each block has an applique placement diagram (the diagram requires enlargement). There are charts for the cross stitch patterns and rugs. (The chart for the larger hooked project also requires enlarging.)However, if you are unsure of rotary cutting, proper pressing, cutting binding, sewing the binding to the quilt top, making a quilt sandwich, and in general all the techniques needed for finishing a quilt... you will need an additional resource. Currently, Amazon is not allowing the insertion of product links within reviews that contain photos, so I'm linking two resources I have used to help me finish some of my quilts in the Comments to this review: The Quilter's Bible by Linda Clements and Darlene Zimmerman's The Quilter's Edge.Have fun!

This tape worked like a charm attaching accent rugs securely to the linoleum, hard wood, and no pile carpet in my home.  Using this tape eradicated slipping and sliding problems with my rugs.  I was especially impressed that it has kept the accent rugs in my high-traffic carpeted hallway firmly in place these last six months where before using this tape they were constantly "walking" out of place and scrunching up. I am even able to run the vacuum over them while they're taped down.  It was easy to attach the tape to the rugs and it was even sticky enough to withstand being pulled up and put back down a couple of times.

Barb Adams and Alma Allen showcase the home, “the beloved symbol in American folk art that has been used in samplers, hooked rugs, painting and, of course, quilts” in this wonderful book.  I confess that I’m in love with the designs these two incredibly talented women come up with over and over again.  I now have three of their books and I plan on collecting them all!  Really, if you love the look of the projects in the photos I've attached, you’ll love this book.As with the other two Adams & Allen books I have, Home Sweet Home starts out with a featured quilt, worked up two ways.  One created by Adams, and one by Allen, each putting their own unique stamp on the finished quilt.  I love this because it inspires me to apply my color choices to their design.  The featured quilt is, to me, absolutely gorgeous and would have been enough for me!  The additional ten lovely projects in this book are just icing on the cake.The book is set up by seasons.  In the winter, we are instructed in how to make “Family Tree Ornaments,” which are not quilted but instead use copper tape and a soldering iron to make frames for small family photos.  (Sorry, I wasn't able to scan a photo of this project.) There is also a wool appliqued, 49 x 12-inch “Holiday Table Runner” depicting homes around the block.Spring arrives with “Nosegay for Mother,” a lovely, 85 x 85-inch (queen size) quilt sprinkled with bouquets of spring tulips.  A smaller project for spring; “Sweet Pea” is a charming 28 x 28-inch wall hanging or doll quilt featuring appliqued flowers and vines.  Finishing up the projects for spring are two 20 x 22-inch hooked rugs, displaying homes and tulips.“Summer Stars” an 88 x 88-inch (queen size) quilt, which showcases star blocks surrounded by appliqued vines, and “Old Glory” 92 x 92-inch quilt waving the stars and stripes, are the summer projects.Autumn brings us, "Autumn Brunch" a wonderful 42 x 20-inch painted canvas table runner (which I intend to use as a floor cloth) displaying gorgeous sunflowers.  Finishing up the projects, is a quilted version of the painted table runner appropriately named “Sunflower Charms.”  (The photo of this project is spread over two pages so I was unable to scan it.)The quilts in this book are not for beginners.  While the instructions for needle turn applique (using freezer paper), and creating the blocks (for all the quilts) are easy to understand, they assume we know what we’re doing when it comes to cutting, seam allowances, pressing properly, sewing the blocks together, making and sewing on binding, making a quilt sandwich, and finishing the quilt.  Those who are not sure about any of these techniques will probably need further assistance or additional resources covering them.  I have achieved excellent results using The Quilter’s Bible by Linda Clement and The Quilter’s Edge by Darlene Zimmerman.  Also, if you own any other quilting books that include excellent detailed instructions (Fons & Porter’s books come to mind) then you could use them.There are full-size templates for all the applique pieces.  In addition there is a full-size (tear out) placement template for the wool "Holiday Table Runner" in the back of the book.The photos, from left to right, are:Barb Adams featured quilt, "Home Sweet Home"Alma Allen's featured quilt, "No Place Like Home""Holiday Table Runner" by Alma Allen"Nosegay for Mother" designed by Barb Adams"Sweet Pea" designed by Barb Adams"Welcome Home" hooked rugs"Summer Stars" by Alma Allen"Old Glory" by Barb Adams"Autumn Brunch" by Adams & Allen

As soon as I stumbled across the books by Barb Adams and Alma Allen they immediately became my favorite designers, which feature applique in their quilts.  Applique is my favorite medium and I gravitate toward it almost exclusively.  I wish I'd found Adams & Allen much sooner (and that their books had the Look Inside feature!) because if I had, I wouldn't have purchased many of the other quilt books that are gathering dust on my bookshelf!  I'm including photos scanned from this book to help you see if, like me, you love what these two talented people have to offer.In my mind, quilts are works of art and quilters; artists.  The designs of Barb Adams and Alma Allen are timeless works of art that I would hang on my walls.  I can't say that of every designer.  I might appreciate the artistry of their designs but I wouldn't decorate my home with them.  This is my third book by Adams & Allen and I'm once again in love with the projects they have put forth.  Their style suits me perfectly.  Eventually, I will own all of their books!There are twelve projects packed within this delightful book, beginning with "Evening Bloom" and "Country Rose" which is the same quilt worked up two ways, as interpreted by Adams and Allen. In the photos I've attached to my review, you will see that the same blocks are used but each have used different fabric and added different borders.  The blocks are 24-inches square, which is a size I particularly love for a couple of reasons: the applique pieces are large/not fiddly and this block size is perfect for making up one block and framing it.  Framing a finished block makes lovely wall art and manageable gifts.Other projects include a bit of cross-stitch; first in a framed alphabet sampler and then in small sachets.  A framed 14 x 17-inch, "Hexagon Pin Board" and matching pincushion use charm squares (pre-cut 5-inch squares) and the English paper-piecing method.  A "Monogrammed Pillowcase" (shown on the cover) with a cute ruffled edge is made using the cross-stitch alphabet given for the sampler.  "Vintage Tea Lights" (also shown on the cover) makes use of small shot glasses or other small glasses to make tea lights from soy wax.  "Sweet Thing" is a charming 37 x 44-inch pieced quilt, (no applique used,) made using pre-cut charm squares.  In the 72 x 78-inch appliqued quilt, "Bachelor Buttons," Adams & Allen use red and green fabric to create a stunning quilt that I think is perfect for Christmas.  "Shooting Stars," 85 x 85-inches, done in muted red, creams, and steel blue, would be perfect for the 4th of July.  Done in appliqued wool, the half-circle, 42 x 18-inch, "Pot of Posies" table mat will be perfect displayed over a door in my home.  The final project, "Country Charm," is a very cute, pieced (no applique,) 42 x 54-inch ruffled throw.In addition to these twelve beautiful projects there are nine delicious breakfast recipes!  Strawberry Jam, Stuffed French Toast, Date and Walnut Scones, Sausage and Egg Casserole, Swedish Pancakes, Broiled Grapefruit, Cranberry Orange Muffins, Laura Renner's Apple Roll-ups, and Belgian Waffle Bits.  Yum!Each project comes with detailed and comprehensive instructions for everything we need to know to sew each block and the quilt top.  Instructions are given for hand applique using the freezer paper method.  There are full-size templates for the applique pieces and each block has an applique placement diagram.  There are instructions for making the paper-pieced hexagons needed for the pin board and pin cushion.  There are beautiful color photographs of all the finished projects and of each finished square of "Evening Bloom" and "Country Rose."However, if you are unsure of rotary cutting, proper pressing, cutting binding, sewing the binding to the quilt top, making a quilt sandwich, and in general all the techniques needed for finishing a quilt... you will need an additional resource.  Currently, Amazon is not allowing the insertion of product links within reviews that contain photos, so I'm linking two resources I have used to help me finish some of my quilts in the Comments to this review:  The Quilter's Bible by Linda Clements and Darlene Zimmerman's The Quilter's Edge.The photos I've attached are (from left to right):"Evening Bloom" by Barb Adams"Country Rose" by Alma Allen"Hexagon Pin Board" by Alma Allen"Flea Market Pincushion" by Alma Allen"Little Red Hen" cross stitch sampler, by Alma Allen"Lavender Sachets" by Alma Allen"Bachelor Buttons" by Barb Adams"Shooting Stars" by Barb Adams"Pot of Posies" by Barb Adams"Country Charm" by Alma AllenHappy Stitching!

I love Lang cards.  They are beautifully made, sturdy, have a linen finish, embellished envelope, and come in such a wide variety of covers and messages.  I love the artwork of Susan Winget and this cover is particularly beautiful.  The only thing that would make these cards better would be if they filled themselves out!  Merry Christmas!

This was a birthday gift for my tall (6'6") and thin son.  He asked for this Sasquatch hoodie and when I saw they didn't come in tall sizes, I was sure the sleeves would not be long enough.  I ordered it anyway knowing I could return it if it didn't work out.  I am happy (surprised) to say that it fits him wonderfully.  At his height he has very long arms and the sleeves actually cover his wrists.  The body is slim fitting and the length reaches his hips.  It looks like it was made for tall thin people.  I'm not sure it would fit a person with a huskier build.  The best part is that he loves it and says it's toasty warm.  Mission accomplished!

The title, Geese in the Rose Garden, perfectly describes the contents of this book.  Heese gives us twelve different 15-inch quilt blocks featuring six appliqued rose blocks of varying designs and six pieced geese blocks.  She has put all twelve together in a "sampler" quilt that has a border, which incorporates both flying geese blocks and an appliqued rose vine.These are the blocks you'll be getting: Rose Wreath, Wild Goose Chase, Rose of Sharon, Fox and Geese, Rambling Rose, Brown Goose, Ohio Rose, Goose Tracks, Rose Cross, Flying Geese, Rose Tree, and Goose in the Pond.For me, my love of this book is not for the featured 64"x80-1/2" sampler quilt, but for the individual blocks themselves.  I'm inspired to use the blocks in combinations of my own choosing.  I also love the large size of the blocks!  I'm going through a phase right now of working up single blocks, framing them, and giving them as gifts.  I love applique, am drawn to it, and right now, single blocks are what's working for me.  The rose blocks in this book are perfectly suited for my need.In addition to the sampler quilt, there is an example of how we can use a single block, in this case, the Ohio Rose, to create a 54-inch square wall hanging.  We are only limited by our imagination to come up with combinations of blocks and quilt sizes of our own.  Heese informs us that a 4 by 5 block setting will make a twin size quilt.  There is also a pattern for a pillow case edged with a row of flying geese and a sweet pincushion.The directions are clear, illustrated, and easy to follow.  Heese begins by instructing us in how to use needle-turn applique, her favored method.  Also covered are: fabric requirements, general supplies (freezer paper, chalk pencil, silk thread, 1/4" and 1/2" bias tape makers), how to over-dye fabric, sashing, and borders.  Basically we are given all the directions we need for completing the quilt top.  Sprinkled throughout are helpful "Tips" such as: "Before starting your applique, it is a good idea to apply Fray Check to all the edges of the block.  This will prevent it from unraveling, keeping the block true to size."  These tips help ensure a good outcome of the finished blocks.  All the templates are full-size.Just so you're aware, in my opinion, this book is written for someone with general sewing/quilting/applique knowledge. For example, some of the things not covered in this book are: rotary cutting, pressing, binding, and quilting.  If you are not familiar with these things, you may need additional instructions from somewhere else.All in all, I recommend this book!

There are three beautiful quilts and three fun cross stitch patterns in this charming book.  For me, the quilts are the stars of this book.The quilts are whimsical and striking, featuring pieced blocks and oodles of appliqued flowers, bunnies, and butterflies.  These are smaller quilts, measuring 64-inches square, 74-inches square, and 80-inches square but borders, sashing, extra rows and/or blocks could be added to increase their size to fit your needs.  In my opinion, an advanced beginner to intermediate quilter could complete these quilts."Vermilion" is the smallest of the quilts, a real beauty in different shades of red set on a cream background.  To my eye, it is the loveliest of the three quilts, but that's because I adore red!  It is stunning!"In My Garden" is so whimsical and fun!  In this 74x74-inch quilt there are bunnies, flowers, and carrots!  I love the fabric choices Heese made in this quilt as well, utilizing ticking stripe.  The finished blocks for this quilt are 18-inches, which is perfect for making a framed wall hanging (something I've been doing a lot of lately, for gifts.)"Gossamer" is for the butterfly lover.  The entire 80x80-inch quilt is fluttering with them!  This would be the easiest to enlarge to bed size by adding additional rows.The three cross stitch projects include two framed wall hangings, one of which is a sampler, and a sweet pincushion.The book begins with instructions for needle-turn applique (Heese's favorite method,) a stitch glossary, and bias binding.  The instructions for each project includes details on fabric, cutting, sewing, applique layout diagrams, assembling the quilt, full-size templates, and finishing the quilt.  If you're not sure how to make a quilt sandwich, quilt the finished top, or sew binding to your quilt; you may need additional instruction.  Sprinkled within the pages are "Tips" giving helpful techniques Heese used on the various projects.Happy Stitching!

I bought this book for the cover project. I hoped to find additional projects inside that tickled my fancy but alas, the cover quilt, its accompanying pillow and pillow case are all that I will make from this book.If you're looking for a quilt and matching pillows featuring bullfrogs on lily pads, then you will love this book! There is also a table runner with ladybugs and matching placemats, a wall hanging with posies and butterflies, and a cute pajama bag. The two bed-sized quilts are twin sized but could be enlarged if you need something bigger.Each individual project has detailed, clearly written, and illustrated instructions. In addition, the back of the book has comprehensive General Instructions, which cover: Fabrics (selecting and preparing), Rotary Cutting, Piecing (sewing strip sets, sewing across seam intersections and sewing sharp points), Pressing, Applique (preparing fusible applique pieces, and machine blanket stitch), Quilting (in the ditch quilting, outline quilting, motif quilting, echo quilting, channel quilting, crosshatch quilting, meandering quilting, stipple quilting, marking quilting lines, preparing the backing, choosing batting, assembling the quilt, and machine quilting methods), Making a Hanging Sleeve, Binding, and Signing and Dating Your Quilt.All in all, I recommend this book.

There are six stunning projects in this wonderful book.  Five of the six include or feature applique in some form.  Since I love applique, the projects in this book are right up my alley. I also love the 19th century look of these quilts.  The colorways that Heese has chosen give these projects an old-fashioned and almost primitive look.In four of the projects, Heese has used the timeless block designs, Harrison Rose, Rose Tree, Snowball, and Coxcomb & Currants.  In addition she gives us a beautiful sampler quilt featuring nine wreath styled blocks.  There is also a strip style quilt using simple four and nine patch squares, a churn dash block, set on point, with wide sashing. All of the quilts are lovely to my eye but my favorites are Rose Tree, Harrison Rose, and Coxcomb & Currants.One of my first projects will be making one of the 18" square Harrison Rose blocks and framing it as wall art.  This block is a perfect stand-alone project as it features an urn filled with flowers.  Working up a single large sized block like this and framing it makes an absolutely gorgeous gift!The quilts are all throw-size, ranging from the smallest at 50-inches square to the largest at 70-inches square.  I love these smaller sizes because I feel I can complete them much faster than a huge bed-sized quilt.  I am much more likely to finish a smallish project.  For some reason, I feel overwhelmed by the huge projects.  However, if you want a larger quilt you can easily add squares to the existing projects.The book begins with instructions for applique; needleturn, fusible web, and wool.  Heese leaves it up to us on which type of applique we want to use.  If you've never appliqued with wool before, you will love it!  It is by far the easiest medium to use when it comes to applique.  I love how it doesn't fray and gives such a beautiful three-dimensional look to the finished project.Additional detailed, easy to understand instructions with materials list are given for each individual project. Everything we need to know to replicate each project is given.  The applique templates are full-size so no enlarging is necessary.I recommend this book to anyone who loves applique and designs from the past.

There are nineteen vintage looking projects within this delightful book. If you find the cover projects charming then those not shown should appeal to you as well.  Inside you will find an assortment of boxes, bags, purses, and cases you can make to store all kinds of important things: makeup, jewelry, coins, glasses, mobile phones, a sewing kit, and even bread!The book begins with eight pages of good illustrated instructions outlining: materials & tools, techniques & handy tips, and simple embroidery stitches. If you don't already have them, the tools needed are easily obtained in any good craft store: fabric glue, scissors, quilting thread, embroidery floss, various needles and pins, small bulldog or other binding clips, an iron, and while a sewing machine is useful it is not necessary. I've also seen purse frames in my local craft stores but I notice that Amazon sells them as well. In addition to fabric, also needed is batting, and fusible interfacing. Also, an assortment of decorative embellishments are a necessity, such as: charms, buttons, lace, and ribbon to personalize each project. Really, one can let their imagination run wild and doll up any of the projects to suit the recipient's individual taste. A plus is that the pattern templates are full sized, so no enlarging is required.I bought this book because I am always looking for neat ideas for handmade gifts. The projects in this book are right up my alley! I already have a list tucked inside with the names of people for whom I want to make one or more of these darling purses.

It was on her porch that Lynda Hall drew inspiration for the design of the 77"x78" sampler quilt, A Little Porch Time.  As she sat in her rocking chair, sipping her morning coffee, she looked around and what she saw found a place in this quilt. There's the old watering can with the extra long spout, happy sunflowers, fluttering butterflies, a basket or two, birds flitting here and there, a bee skep, leafy vines, and Lynda's kitty, Topaz, also has a place of honor on the quilt. The mostly wool, appliqued shapes are affixed to a patchwork background of homespun plaids, stripes, and checks.  One of my favorite blocks displays two little hands and then one large hand holding a heart.  Lynda explains this block thus, "The larger hand, down in the left hand corner is mine and the smaller ones represent our little girls, Rebecca and Sarah, our granddaughters.  I'm holding their hearts in my hand just like a gramma should."In addition to the large sampler quilt, there are four other smaller projects using the items found in the sampler. In the 14"x20" wool table rug, we see a perky bird perched atop the bee skep, and flanked by flowers.  "Flower Bucket" is the name of the 36"x24" fabric and wool wall hanging/table rug.  On it is the long-spouted watering can with a profusion of primitive posies spilling from it, and three black birds.  Topaz's image is featured in her own individual 17"x22" table rug/wall hanging in "Catnip."  She is standing proudly, among tall flowers, and with a friendly bird perched on her tail.  "Auntie Bean's Pin Cushion" a 7" sunflower, rounds out the projects.There are a couple of pages of general sewing tips/instructions, which covers: fabric applique, wool applique, choosing colors, using the templates, cutting wool, and a discussion of threads to use with Hall's recommendations.  Each project has step-by-step instructions and materials lists. The full-size templates are in the back of the book.It is a darned shame that the Look Inside feature is not available for this lovely book.  I would highly recommend this book for anyone who loves the Primitive look.UPDATE: 3/4/2015  I have added photos of the projects from this charming book.

I bought this book because I love the afghan on the cover.  Unfortunately, the Look Inside feature, only shows one other of the five total projects.  In addition to the cover afghan, I fell in love with one other project, a beauty done in ivory with one crocodile border row in deep red.  I predominantly crochet gifts for others but this afghan will be for me.The skill level required for the cover afghan, 40 inches square, is for the advanced crocheter, while the remaining four are all listed as intermediate. The 35"x42" baby quilt looks very similar to the cover, with its flower like motifs, and crocodile border. The Crazy Crocodile afghan, shown in Look Inside, measures 36"x48" and the Dragonslayer, worked up in panels, measures 48"x64".  My personal favorite, named Westphalia, is 48"x60".Each pattern includes diagrams for special stitches used in that afghan.  At the back of the book, there is a stitch guide, but a more helpful option, is the website listed on the cover and throughout the book.  I recommend using the free website if needed.I recommend this book for the intermediate to advanced crocheter interested in the cover afghan and the crocodile stitch.Happy stitching!

The holiday motifs in this book are sweet and whimsical and cover winter, Christmas, Nutcracker, Christmas characters, New Year, Valentine's Day, St. Patrick's Day, Easter & spring, 4th of July & summer, Halloween, Dia de los Muertos, Thanksgiving, and Hannukkah.  Included also are phrases, borders, animals, trees, and Candyland motifs.  The ultra wonderful thing is that all of these cute motifs are on a CD, which makes printing and sizing super easy to do.The Look Inside feature, unfortunately doesn't completely show all of the 21 sweet, primarily Christmas-themed projects in the book, which to me is a shame because they're so cute. I think the fun thing about this book is that we can substitute any of the other holiday motifs and immediately turn the Christmas projects into whatever holiday we choose.  The projects in this book inspired me to think of my own uses for each motif.  Aimee Ray warns us, in the introduction, that doodle stitching can become addictive, and boy, is she right!The projects are: Elf coasters, Peace Joy Love Advent calendar, Jolly Holidays Mini Wreath, Penguin Stocking Ornaments, Frolicking Foxes Lap Quilt, Soft Nativity, Winter Wonderland Stocking, Felt Star Tree Topper, Autumn to Winter Placemats, Prancer Pillow, Sleepy Mouse Pillowcase, Snowflake Slippers, Let It Snow Garland, Felt Winter Village, Winter Woods Miniature Tree Skirt, Noel Wall Hanging, Plush Vintage Ornaments, Peace on Earth Card & Gift Tag, Fabric Gift Wrap, Teashop Teapot Cozy, and Gingerbread Bookmarks.The instructions are clear and easy to follow.  The good thing about doodle stitching is it's so affordable.  It's a brilliant way to personalize and turn a plain ready-made item into a special one-of-a-kind gift using just a needle and a bit of embroidery floss.  My one tip to add to all that Ray includes in this great book, is the use of freezer paper to stabilize the fabric onto which you're transferring your motif when using the tracing method.  I cut a piece of freezer paper, a bit larger than the motif to be traced, and iron it to the back of the stitching fabric.  This holds the fabric straight and stiff while I'm tracing the design.  It makes a huge difference when tracing larger patterns.I love this book and highly recommend it!

This great book contains all the instruction needed to make beautiful rag rugs for every room in your home.  There are ovals, rectangles, hearts, and a few made from simple blocks sewn together.  On some of the projects fringe is added and on others, borders.  The best part?  They're all easy to make, easy enough for beginners, using single and double crochet, and a Q hook.McNeill spends a few pages at the beginning of the book to give a brief history of rug-making, which is followed by "Basic Tips" where all we need to know about: materials used/needed, cutting or tearing strips, different methods for joining the fabric strips, single crochet, double crochet, slip stitch, changing colors, and the finished edge is outlined and illustrated.  The Look Inside feature shows a bit of each of the 16 projects in the book.I grew up watching my mom crochet rag rugs using old clothing.  She painstakingly removed buttons, zippers, sewed together the cut strips, and then crocheted throughout the winter months.  Toward the end of her life, I tried to teach her to join her strips using the slit method, which I thought was easier than sewing the strips together, but she'd have none of it.  She did it the way she had always done.  Whichever way you choose to join your strips, whether you use yardage of fabric, recycled clothing, or old sheets to make your rugs, the instructions within this book will see you to the end of a beautiful finished product.

I have long loved the beauty of Aran knitting and lamented the fact that I am not a knitter.  I've crocheted for over 40 years and it's what I'm comfortable doing.  Bonnie Barker shares in the introduction to this fabulous book that her love for these stitches led her to put together these spectacularly beautiful patterns.  I am so happy she did, because I love this book.  So much in fact, that I'm buying another copy to give to my sister for Christmas.Right away Bonnie reassures the reader not to "run away screaming in fear from any perceived difficulty in any of these projects."  The Aran stitches all use the basic chain, single, half-double, double, and treble crochet.  We are taught, in step-by-step photographs, how to combine these fundamental stitches to create the Arrow, Baby Feet Toe Popcorn, Basket Weave, Big Toe Popcorn, Braided Cable, Cable, Celtic Cross, Celtic Weave, Diamond, Honeycomb, Knurl (Reverse Single Crochet), Shadow Box, Shell With Picot, Wheat, and Woven stitches. The photographed instructions also include all the basic stitches and how to make fringe.
