If we get stuck, we can access Bonnie's website for step-by-step instructional videos.Each project is given a degree of difficulty, starting with Easy and increasing up to Experienced, the difficulty rating is determined by the amount of specialized stitches used in the project, the more stitches, the more difficult the rating. Bonnie recommends starting with the easier patterns, such as a scarf, and then moving on to the more advanced as we become more confident.  Practice, practice, practice.I particularly liked how we are given the exact yarns used in each project.  A lot of the time, I really love the color or texture of a particular yarn used in the model, and am frustrated because I don't know what it is. Of course, we don't have to use the exact yarn shown in the projects, we can substitute another brand, by weight, and making certain it meets the gauge requirements.  Some of the projects use #4 Fine, DK #3, #4 Worsted, and Bulky #5.  While the cover photo shows the use of the typical Aran color, other projects, throughout the book are done in a variety of colors. In the Resources Guide, at the back of the book, the websites are given for each of the yarn companies that supplied yarn used in the book.Of the projects there are shawls, baby blankets, purse, backpack, carryall bag, afghans, scarves, headband, sweaters, vests, covers for MP3, iPad, cell phone, and even a pillow cover.Sprinkled throughout the book are a half dozen, or so, photos of the drop-dead gorgeous Irish landscape. I'd love to see Ireland in person, but for now I'll look at the photos and dream, while I'm crocheting the patterns in this book.If Bonnie Barker puts out any future Aran crochet pattern designs...I'll be all over it!  I highly recommend this masterpiece. Happy stitching!

I'm hooked on Crabapple Hill's style!  I love this sweet flower pot design.  When completed, the tea towels made from this pattern are absolutely charming.  The colors are bright and cheerful, and their old-fashioned look really dresses up my farm-style kitchen. I have gone on to make several towels for gifts.  In gift giving, I changed the day of the week inside the little tag to the name of the recipient.  Wrap a homemade goodie in one of these towels and you have a spectacular gift that keeps on giving after the sweet treat has been eaten.The embroidery is quite easy, utilizing the stem stitch, or instead you could use a back stitch, and the French knot.  The pattern does not come with an iron-on transfer.  Instead, you'll trace it onto your towel, using a .01 brown Micron Pigma Pen. If you do not have this pen, you can substitute another fabric safe pen.  To aid you in transferring your pattern, it is suggested that you use a bit of freezer paper, ironed to the back of the towel, to stabilize it.  If you've never used this freezer paper method before, you will love it!  A #7 or #8 embroidery needle is recommended.  I used Aunt Martha's Flour Sack Dish Towels and they work great.  If you use flour sack towels, I very much recommend that you iron them well using starch.  Doing such, makes embroidering so much easier.  Floss requirements are DMC brand and requires 15 colors to complete all seven patterns. For the fabric embellishment, only an 8-inch square is needed for each towel.I purchased this Crabapple Hill pattern (and lots of others) from their website.  I wish I'd known Amazon carried these patterns!

Let me warn you up front, this series is not for the faint of heart.  The subject matter covered is rape, kidnapping, and murder.  There were brutal and emotional images of beatings and one murder.  I found myself cringing and holding my breath.  In fact, the last time I was so emotionally affected by a program was during my viewing of Broadchurch.  Happy Valley took me hostage for six hours where I could not take my eyes from the screen.  When the final credits rolled I felt emotionally drained but at least I could breathe freely again.  This is not a series where I will rewatch the episodes over (and sometimes over again depending on the series).Sarah Lancashire, (The Paradise, Last Tango in Halifax) gives a stunning performance as Police Sergeant Catherine Cawood, a tough and hardened copper who's given up her life as a detective because of family matters.  And that is putting her situation mildly.  Lancashire has won my respect with her considerable talent amply displayed in this role.  I kept thinking to myself, wow!We are introduced to Catherine at the scene of a threatened suicide-by-petrol taking place in a playground.  Cawood arrives with a borrowed fire extinguisher in hand and when the high as a kite young man begins telling her his reason for setting himself alight, (his girlfriend has broken up with him), she replies, "I'm Catherine, by the way!  I'm forty-seven, I'm divorced, I live with my sister, who's a recovering heroin addict, I have two grown-up children. One dead and one who doesn't speak to me. And a grandson! So."As the story unfolds from there, we learn the details behind Catherine's statement.  Little by little, over six episodes, we see why Catherine's husband divorced her, how her daughter died, why her son doesn't speak to her, why her sister lives with her, and how she came to have custody of her eight year-old grandson.  Catherine's story is incredible and her strength is admirable and inestimable.  I found myself admiring her immensely and feeling intense sorrow for her at the same time.  This story touched me deeply.I do not want to go into details of the story because I don't want to ruin one minute of this program for you.  I will tell you as much as the video case reveals.  Kevin Weatherill, played by Steve Pemberton (Whitechappel,) instigates the kidnapping of his boss' daughter, Ann, when he becomes bitterly angry about being turned down for a rise in pay. The man to whom he suggests the abduction, Ashley Cowgill, is someone he trusts not to harm the girl. However, Kevin has no idea who and what Ashley is nor does he know that in Ashley's employ is one Tommy Lee Royce, just out of prison for drugs crimes, and believed to be responsible for the death of Catherine's daughter.  Royce is cruel and his involvement in the kidnapping sends everything spiraling out of control.  Kevin and Ashley are out of their depth.  Catherine, knowing that Royce is out of prison on her patch, will not rest until justice for her daughter prevails, even if that means taking matters into her own hands.  Let's just say that things get messy.Catherine's life is filled with personal and professional trials.  Her grandson is disrespectful, slinging insults at his gran that made me want to send him to his room, and constantly in trouble at school. His behavior causes Catherine to question if she is doing right by him.  Her ex-husband has remarried and has nothing to do with their grandson but still pursues Catherine for dinner and more.  Why?  She is haunted by the image of her daughter's disfigured and dead body.  Why?  I liked how I kept looking for the answers to the why's.  In addition, as the sergeant of Happy Valley's police force, Catherine's job is a stressful one, to say the least.  Even so, she slogs along day by day as more and more is heaped upon her.Clare, Catherine's sister, quietly and masterfully portrayed by Siobhan Finneran, plays a huge and pivotal role in Catherine's life.  I found myself hoping for more back story about the two sisters.  I wondered what their childhood was like and about the life events, which shaped them.This series is one story shown over six episodes.  There is no murder mystery to be solved.  We know who is doing what but we don't always know why.  I particularly liked how plot points were doled out bit by bit so I had several ah-hah moments.  I found myself analyzing all the characters and looking for their motivation at every turn.  I loved this!I was also wowed by Catherine's capable handling of hooligans.  She was fearless in facing violence and dished out a bit of her own when the situation called for it.  And the situation called for it more than once.  I couldn't help but pull for her throughout the episodes and almost pray that everything would turn out for the best for her.  I wanted a happy ending for Happy Valley in the worst way.  I guess a happy ending is in the eye of the beholder.All in all, I was completely taken in by this program and while at times the brutality sucked the breath out of me, I was enthralled and compelled to go the distance.  I want to see more of Catherine Cawood.  I hope there are further seasons in this series.There are subtitles, which is immensely helpful, even for those with an ear for the strong accents of Great Britain.  The brogue is thick and spoken quickly.Edited: 8/28/2014 Folks, this series is now on Netflix.

In my constant search for series in this genre, I stumbled across this gem on Amazon UK.  When I saw it was based upon the writing of Ann Cleeves, (Vera,) I snapped it up.  While I have never read Cleeves' books her stories as portrayed in these two adaptations really appeal to me.  I love Vera and now I love Shetland.Shetland, like Vera, is character centric.  In Shetland, our focus is upon the head of CID, Detective Inspector Jimmy Perez, portrayed by Douglas Henshall, (Collision, Primeval,) a widower with custody of his beautiful teenage step-daughter, Cassie.  He moved away from the Islands, where he grew up, but on the death of his wife, he returned to Lerwick, where they met and fell in love.  He feels close to her there and wants Cassie to know the place and people from where her mother came.Inspector Perez appealed to me as a main character because he's a good man, with a hard job, navigating through an even harder time in his life.  I am a huge fan of crime fighters/sleuths being good people.  Perez is good, as well as smart, shrewd, intuitive, moral, and fair.  As he deals with the survivors and family members of the dead, witnesses, and suspects he does it with kindness, sensitivity, and respect.  He is soft spoken but direct.Cleeves' deft hand is clearly seen in the main character closely watching people with the ability to look deeply inside of them and see more than they wish to reveal.  Jimmy's interactions with his step-daughter's biological father had me approving of him even more.  Perez is a good dad.  Henshall fills the role perfectly.  His portrayal was spot on with no slippage in character.  He was always believable.The crew that surrounds and aids Perez are perfectly suited to him.  While his Police Sergeant, Billy McCabe (Lewis Howden) is older and wiser, the other two officers who help him do the legwork involved in murder investigation are young and inexperienced.  Still, what they lack in experience, they more than make up for in enthusiasm and determination. PC Sandy Wilson (Steven Robertson), is dreaming of and studying to become a detective. Sandy displays maturity and emotional fortitude in the face of familial loss. Rounding out the crew is DC Alison "Tosh" MacIntosh (Alison O'Donnell).  Her forensic skills and quick mind aid Perez in surprising ways. All three are Shetland Island locals having lived there their entire lives.  They know the land and better yet, they know the people.  This gives them insight and awareness of the goings on and proves, at times, to be invaluable in solving the murders that devastate the small, close-knit community. Unfortunately, and sadly, this means they also know and in some cases, love the victims... and the murderers.Sandy and Tosh, while young, are sharp and eager to learn the craft of murder solving.  I liked that they were aware and appreciative of Perez's obvious abilities.  Also they respected him, but then he's a man who earns respect.  Formerly a detective in Glasgow, he brings an impressive resume, experience, and skill to Lerwick.  Jimmy Perez is an excellent role model for the aspiring detectives on his team.  I liked how he lead by example.  A visiting forensic officer from the big city of Inverness said to him, "You know you're wasted here."  Oh, no he is not!  He's right where he's supposed to be.The Shetland Islands of Northeast Scotland are stark in their harsh beauty.  I was completely captivated by the windswept land, gray churning ocean, and hovering clouds.  The often gloomy appearing landscape seemed the perfect setting for tragic death by murder.  The locale haunted me and I found myself yearning to go there and experience it for myself.  The Scottish dialect can be difficult to understand but I found it lyrical and charming.  There are subtitles so nothing is lost to our listening ears.In addition to the beautiful scenery I was struck by the haunting Celtic theme music.  It set the mood of sadness, which accompanies death, perfectly.  In the credits, the only reference to the music was the composer, John Lunn.  I would love to have the soundtrack...if one were available.There are four episodes, based upon the best-selling books, Red Bones, Raven Black, Dead Water, and Blue Lightning.  Each contain murder, compelling characters, and surprise endings.  I loved pitting my crime solving wits against the culprits' and adding my will to Perez and his team's efforts to find and bring the murderer(s) to justice.I highly recommend this series.  If you have not yet seen Vera you are missing out.  Recently released in the UK is Vera 4, another masterpiece of murder.As noted in the product description, this set is Non-USA format and requires a multi-region DVD player and compatible television to play.

Quilting Quickly contains 13 projects we can whip up in a jiffy by making use of pre-cut fabric (the greatest invention in fabric since the fat quarter.) However, if you have a large stash of fabric you can easily substitute your scraps for the pre-cuts.The projects range in difficulty from Beginner, to Easy, to Intermediate.  The eleven quilts range in size from wall (or crib) size, to twin size, and in-between.  A table-topper and pillow sham round out the total projects.I really liked the feature of 'Video' sprinkled throughout the book whereupon we can visit the Fons & Porter website to access video tutorials for the projects.  It's worth checking out their website for these.The instructions are detailed and comprehensive.  All templates are full sized so no enlarging is needed.  Also, in the back of the book you'll find a primer on pre-cuts and a cool feature called Quilt Classroom.  In this classroom, instructions are given for: How to identify straight grain and selveges, making an ironing pad, making triangle squares, free-motion quilting, binding by machine, and using the Fons and Porter Binding Tool.  Video tutorials are available online for each of these classroom topics.If you aren't familiar with the Best Of series by Fons & Porter... these are a few of my favorites:The Best of Fons & Porter: Tabletop QuiltsBest of Fons & Porter: Favorite QuiltsBest of Fons & Porter Kickin' Back Quilts

When it comes to quilting books, I trust Fons & Porter.  I have never been disappointed in any of their "Best Of" books and Kickin' Back Quilts is another hit with me.In this collection of 25 quilts, all are lap or wall-hanging size ranging in difficulty from easy, intermediate, and one challenging; the majority (14) being easy. All are scrappy and will work well for using up our stash.  There are size options for increasing to twin, queen, and king for several of the designs.The quilts are beautiful and would make wonderful gifts.  I'm writing this review in June but I'm sure Christmas will appear...tomorrow!As is usual in Fons & Porter books, the instructions are clear, comprehensive and concise.  Additionally, scattered throughout are 'Sew Easy' pages outlining various techniques used in one quilt or another. Examples of these are: Quick Triangle Squares, Making Tilted Blocks, Cutting Half-Square and Quarter-Square Triangles, Set-In Seems, and Freezer Paper Templates.  Everything that needs to be known about creating a quilt from basic supplies to binding is in the back of the book with color photos.I also liked the feature 'Web Extra' whereupon we can visit the Fons & Porter website for additional video tutorials on various techniques.The templates are all full size so no enlarging required.I highly recommend this book!  In fact, I enthusiastically recommend all of the Best Of Fons & Porter books.  Just a few of my favorites:The Best of Fons & Porter: Tabletop QuiltsBest of Fons & Porter: Baby and Kids QuiltsBest of Fons & Porter: Favorite Quilts

I bought the SmartCat Ultimate Scratching Post for my son's cat, Rogue, and I love it.  I thought the height of the post would be perfect for him to sit upon and look out of the window, if only there were a perch on top of it.  I was elated to find that I could get one!As soon as the package arrived, I quickly opened it and easily slid the perch on top of the post.  I placed the post strategically in front of the window looking out over the garden; hoisted Rogue atop the perch and eagerly watched to see his happiness at having a spot to look out at the birds.He stayed there for about 10 seconds, long enough to look at me, with a look of disdain, as if to say..."Hey! I can't even lie down on this itty bitty thing!" and then he jumped down.  He has never once jumped up on the darned thing.  I've put him on it every day since we got it but he just isn't interested. In case you're wondering Rogue measures 20-inches from his nose to the beginning of his tail. He doesn't seem overly large to me.  Measure your cat to be sure they'll be able to enjoy this perch.  It's such an excellent idea. I wish it were bigger.This product is well made.  The cover is removable and washable.  I believe that if this perch were bigger...it would be the cat's meow.

I happened upon this bottle with pourer quite by accident.  It caught my eye because I love its shape.  I bought it for its looks but after using it the design has a purpose.  Grasping and pouring/drizzling is comfortable. The green tint of the bottle was icing on the cake for me.  I would still have bought it in clear glass but I prefer that it's tinted.  I like the convenience of leaving the oil out on the counter near my range and the beauty of this bottle is much preferable to the oil's original container.The stopper/pourer fits snugly but removes easily enough for cleaning and adding more oil to the bottle.During a move, I lost my previous bottle with pourer that I used for olive oil.  Since then I've been pouring it straight from the bottle in which I buy it.  This works fine for putting oil in the pan but is not ideal for drizzling oil directly onto salad or other foods.  Certainly, holding my thumb over the bottle's opening restricts the flow and I would have been okay with continuing in this manner if I hadn't had a pourer in the past.  Having a pourer spoiled me.All in all, this bottle/pourer is perfect for me and I highly recommend it.

In my ever-constant search for inspirational applique, I stumbled across this gem.  It is a crying shame that we are not given the option to Look Inside this book.  UPDATE 3/5/15  Photos added.Adams, Allen, and Creamer have put together designs for 12 projects in this book.  The book begins with an 84x84-inch Feature Quilt by Adams & Allen worked up in two different colorways.  Each block uses applique to showcase blooms found throughout the garden.  The blocks feature these flowers spilling from various baskets, vases, and pitchers.  One thing I love about the blocks is that they measure 20 inches square.  I love this because the larger size makes these blocks so versatile.  For example, I can use an individual block as a pillow front or a wall hanging. This makes for a manageable project for gift giving, for which I'm always looking.  Another plus to the block size is how quickly a project will work up and the applique pieces are of a nice size; not small and fiddly.The blocks are broken down by seasonal blooms.  Seasons are also depicted in the color choices used.  The two winter blocks features poinsettia, holly leaves, berries, and amaryllis. In the two blocks for spring; bleeding hearts, peonies, pansies, and tulips.  There are three blocks for summer featuring; geraniums, and summer herbs (rosemary, dwarf myrtle.) The third summer block varies from using a container, there is instead, a delightful depiction of an English cottage surrounded by a riotous English garden. (This is my favorite block.)  The two blocks of Autumn feature; cone flowers, cockscomb, oak leaves, and acorns.  In each of the blocks we also see vines, leaves, stars, bees, and a butterfly or two.A delightful bonus to this amazing book is that each quilt block is accompanied by a beautiful photo of a container garden and instructions for planting it!  This is absolutely wonderful for me as I am not a gardener but I want to be one!The eleven additional projects include: a sheet set & pillow shams; a top sheet & pillow; seasonal purses using even more applique designs; a 29½-inch square quilt featuring stars and tulips; a 68-inch by 85-inch quilt using patchwork (no applique in this quilt); a 44-inch square quilt using applique and patchwork blocks of stars and butterflies; an 8x8-inch hooked rug of a cottage; 4½-inch square needle-punch vase of flowers; 10-inch square red-work pillows embroidered using a stem stitch; a 64x64-inch quilt of appliqued containers of blooms; and a 70x70-inch Christmas quilt featuring containers of poinsettia, holly, and berries.As to instructions and templates: the instructions are clear and comprehensive. There is a section of specific instruction on turned edge hand applique using freezer paper.  Instructions for specific techniques are included with each project using them.  The applique templates are full size so no enlargement is necessary there.  However, the applique placement diagrams for the seasonal blocks do require enlargement.

Kim Diehl once again delivers on her signature style of patchwork complimented by applique in quiltmaking.  I love applique mixed with patchwork and her designs really appeal to my personal aesthetic. I love the high contrast mix of fabrics she uses in many of her designs.  I love her color choices of deep and dark: red, gold, tan, green, blue, brown, and black.  However, the pink, turquoise, purple, and soft green in the cover quilt, "Late Bloomers" has really grown on me! I'm already imagining how I can incorporate these beautiful hues in other projects.I love Kim's books because the projects she designs are beautiful, many include applique, they always have great instructions, and the finished product is accomplishable and a treasured keepsake.  She combines traditional patchwork squares with her own style of appliqued flowers and pennies to bring us her personal design sensibility.The 14 projects range in size from two twin bed sized, seven wall hangings from 13½-inches square to 76½-inches square, two table toppers, and a framed 8½x11-inch mini quilt.  There is also a pincushion. The quilt designs include patterns familiar to quilters such as log cabin, nine patch, four patch, and half-triangles.  In several of her projects, Diehl uses wool in her applique.The step-by-step instructions accompanying each design are comprehensive and easy to understand.Scattered throughout the pages are "Pin Point" boxes, which offer added tips and information to instruct; I particularly found Kim's suggestion of using a clear plastic over-the-door shoe organizer to keep fat quarter and fat eighths corralled a creative idea. There are many more pin point suggestions to aid us in our quilting pursuits.At the back of the book, is Quiltmaking Basics, which includes: Yardage Requirements, Rotary Cutting, Cutting Bias Strips, Pinning, Machine Piecing, Chain Piecing, Pressing Seams, Pressing Triangle Units, Invisible Machine Applique, Preparing Pattern Templates, Making Bias-Tube Stems and Vines, Basting Appliques, Preparing Your Sewing Machine, Stitching Appliques, String Applique, Removing Paper Pattern Pieces, Completely the Machine Applique Process, Wool Applique, Felting Your Wool, Preparing Wool Appliques, Stitching Wool Appliques, Completing the Quilt Top, Adding Borders, Batting, Backing, Basting, Marking Quilting Designs, Hand Quilting, Big Stitch Quilting, Machine Quilting, Binding, and Attaching a Quilt Label.For me, this is a must have Kim Diehl book of designs.  I wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone who loves beautiful quilts and the work of Kim Diehl.

Right before Christmas I began crocheting cowls, hats, scarves, and hooded cowls for Christmas gifts using Lion Brand Thick and Quick Yarn in various colors.  A friend of mine is a hunter and I wanted safety orange for his cowl but I could not find a bright orange in Thick and Quick.I am so pleased to have found this orange in the Hometown yarn.  There are several colors from which to choose.  It works up just as quickly as Thick and Quick, is extremely soft and comfortable next to the skin, and is warm.  I did not encounter any knots and splitting was not a problem. The color stays fast when washed. Projects work up fast; I can complete a cowl in three hours. Wonderful!I love this yarn and highly recommend it! Happy stitching!

Lately, I've been crocheting daily.  Crocheting relaxes me and I feel a sense of accomplishment by creating beautiful things while sitting on my behind.  I have always used Boye hooks and the embossed printing upon their hooks make my thumb sore.  I have groused over what I consider a "design flaw" of Boye hooks for a long time.  I've covered the printing with tape, band-aids, worn band-aids on my thumb, and tried other cushioning fixes including sponge hook and pen covers.  None of my homemade fixes have been satisfactory.In addition to the issue with my thumb the palm of my hand gets sore where I rest the end of the hook. Maybe I'm overly sensitive but the friction of the hook irritates my skin.When I saw these Clover hooks with the cushioned grip I swooned at the possibility of being able to crochet in comfort.  Within minutes of using these hooks I could feel the difference.  Ooh! Ah! The soft and padded handle is perfect for the way I hold the hook.  One side is flat, where my thumb rests, and the opposite is slightly rounded.  No need for homemade cushions any longer!  The padding also protects the palm of my hand and there is no friction from the hook moving across my skin.  I'm in love!If you are used to crocheting with Boye hooks, the Clover hooks will be an easy transition for you.  I have not noticed any difference in that regard with these hooks.I'm so happy I bought these hooks, so much so that I'm going to get a set for my sister for her birthday! I highly recommend these hooks if you have experienced a sore thumb and palm while crocheting!

This is a great beginner pattern for really cute slippers.  The stitches are simple: chain, single crochet, slip stitch, half double crochet, and two single crochets together.  The instructions are clear and easy to follow and there are accompanying photos showing how to work two single crochets together to decrease.  Because these sweet slippers are so simple to make; they can be whipped up quickly.  This simplicity makes this pattern perfect for giving these slippers for gifts.  I love the sweet pearl beads that decorate the buttons but my imagination is running wild imagining substitutions for the pearls to further individualize and personalize the slippers for each person on my gift list.The pattern is written for UK size 5, which is European size 38, and US size 6.  In parentheses sizes 7, 8, and 9 are given.  If you want to make any larger sizes, Medoza explains that we can add two chains per size increase.To make my slippers non-slip, I dot Dimensional Puffy Fabric Paint to the bottoms of the slippers.

I purchased this Thermos mug for my husband to keep his morning coffee hot for his 40 minute commute to work and for the coffee he drinks throughout his work day.  His commute is really the longest amount of time he required it to remain hot, at present, he'll also use it when we travel, which are longer trips.  However, the first day he had it, he forgot it in his truck and at the end of his day, ten hours later, he had hot, not warm, hot, coffee to drink on his way home.  We were both happily surprised by this.  We live in the southwest desert so it's not freezing cold here right now but it was cool, in the 30's the day this happened so, we're very pleased.The lid screws in, which is another feature my husband wanted.  It certainly prevents accidents of not getting the lid completely on mugs that the lid pushes on or fits inside the mug.  In addition, the lid top has a twisting mechanism to open a slot for the beverage to flow through.  When open for drinking the word "OPEN" is clearly shown, when closed, it says "CLOSED".This Thermos tumbler is not dishwasher safe but this doesn't bother me.  I'm purchasing another.  Husband/coffee drinker approved and recommended!

My dog Boone, is an AKC standard size Shih-Tzu and this stand with bowls fits his height perfectly.  I measured Boone and his mouth is 13-inches from the floor.  The top of the bowl in the stand is 5.5-inches making it so he doesn't have to hunch over to eat and drink.  This is good for his digestion.I love the size of the bowls, especially for water because they hold 24-ounces (three cups.)  I like that they are stoneware for clean-up.  I believe they are dish-washer safe but the bowls don't say they are, and I hand wash them before filling them.  I don't care for plastic (I read that bacteria is prevalent in plastic...true? I don't know, but I'm not chancing it!) and stainless steel bowls aren't cute.  These bowls are extremely cute with the playful puppies cavorting around the edge.  Because the background color is white, it is easy to see if the water is dirty.  Because of Boone's flat face, he is forever getting his water dirty from "washing" his face in it! I give him fresh water daily but now that I can see when it's dirty, I change it often throughout the day.The stand is sturdy and not flimsy.  The feet are padded to not only protect the floor from scratches but also from black marks that wrought iron can make on some floors.  I also like that there are four small rubber-like covers over the bowl rings to cushion the bowls.  You'll want to be careful with these as they slip off fairly easily.I highly recommend this product, in fact, I'm going to purchase the kitty sized one for my son as a gift for my grandkitty.

I was desperate to find an affordable product that would help my long, fine, and flyaway hair to settle down! I recently moved from a humid climate in the southeast to the southwest desert and my hair now snaps, crackles, and pops sending sparks zipping through the air. When you were a kid, did you ever rub a balloon on your hair to produce static electricity, which then caused your hair to stand up?  Well, that is my hair in the desert sans balloon.  Not pretty!  My hair attaches itself to my clothing and floats in the air up around my ears!  I've moisturized and conditioned.  I've applied other products but either of two things happened, after an hour or so my hair would be dancing around my ears again or it was limp and oily looking!  I want silky, soft, shiny, calm, and in its place hair; not oily-limp.  This Argan Oil does the trick on my hair. It is now smooth and shiny!I apply the oil while my hair is still damp after shampooing and conditioning.  I smooth the oil on the ends of my hair from ear level to the tips.  I particularly pay attention to the very ends making sure to apply enough oil to not just tame but treat them.  I don't apply the oil all the way to the scalp on a daily basis.  I do however use this oil once per week on my scalp.  I apply it directly to my scalp, this takes several squirts.  I rub it in well and leave it on while I do things about the house.  Later, I shampoo and condition and then reapply the oil as described above.I also apply this oil on my skin.  Since moving to the desert, I'm about to dry up and blow away with the tumbleweeds!  One morning, after doing my hair I was enjoying the feeling of the oil on the palms of my hands.  So, I pumped a bit more and smoothed it on the back of my hands. Ooh!  I pumped a bit more and smoothed the oil over my forehead.  Ahh!  From then on, I went crazy and dobbed it around my eyes, cheeks, and throat, avoiding the T-zone area.  I love this stuff.  I'm old enough to be past breakouts to my skin so using it thus is not a problem for me.  I also don't apply it to my skin on a daily basis as I have facial moisturizers with sunscreen that I love and use.  However, this argan oil feels marvelous on my skin! It's great on my nails and cuticles.  And you know what else? I've used it on my feet! At first, I just rubbed some in and then I had the brilliant idea, well, I thought it was brilliant, of putting a few pumps in a pan of water, and soaking my feet in it! Ding, ding, winner!This oil smells fabulous!  The fragrance is warm and soft.  It isn't an overpowering, make your eyes water, and your nose sneeze kind of scent.  It's soft and wafting.  Which is a darned good thing since I now am covered in it...head to toe.You might laugh but you know where else I use this amazing oil?  On my dog's fly-away hair! Yes, I do!  Boone is a Shih-Tzu and the hair on his long tail and ears is also acting up and flying around in this desert clime, hey, he can't be walking around looking like that!  I'm a good dog-mother and will not let my little guy be embarrassed in the neighborhood!  This great product works on his hair too!  And he looks, hot!I highly recommend this product if you have a similar need to mine...and Boone's!

I purchased this 4-piece knife set based upon the recommendation for Victorinox knives in The Complete America's Test Kitchen TV Show Cookbook, 2001-2013.Since their arrival into my kitchen, I've sliced tomatoes, onions, bread, and meat.  I've peeled apples and potatoes.  I've chopped garlic, nuts, carrots, and celery.  Each knife handled their tasks with ease.  The softer Roma tomatoes cut like butter.  I love the handles.  They fit nicely in my hand (medium sized) and the rough surface does not slip. The handles were also large enough that my knuckles did not hit the counter while chopping.  I paid $68 for this set of knives and would recommend them for the chef on a budget.

First, a little bit about what formed my opinion...I love Agatha Christie's books.  I also love Joan Hickson as Miss Marple.  These two loves have influenced how I feel about the Miss Marple films featuring the talented Geraldine McEwan and Julia McKenzie.  For me, the story is what's important.As much as I love the Hickson versions, I believed there was room for improvement, minor tweaking, freshening up, but by no means rewrites of Christie's work.  All are really showing their age.  I was looking forward to the remakes.  Christie's work is so great that I was excited about having it brought to the high definition era.  I was not disappointed in the appearance of the remakes.  On the other hand, I was not happy with the content changes in most of the remakes.  Some were good, some were okay, and then there were the bad.No matter how hard I try to be objective about these remakes and not make comparisons to the books and the Hickson versions, I find I can't. I found myself watching and muttering things like, "What?! Miss Marple did not have an adulterous affair!" About other characters, "they weren't married, an alcoholic, divorced, the murderer, a Nazi..." to name but a few.McKenzie is a "softer" Miss Marple than Hickson and I like this a lot. She really does shine as Miss Marple.  Where Hickson gave a serious, unsmiling, austere, and flinty portrayal; McKenzie is more approachable, and to me, she added an increased believability of Miss Marple being everyone's Auntie Jane. All in all, I love her as Miss Marple.In Series Six we see the final remake of the Hickson twelve, A Caribbean Mystery.  While there were alterations galore made to the original, the main plot and characters remained the same, these being; Jason Rafael, his secretary, his physical therapist, Major Palgrave, Molly & Tim Kendall, Greg & Lucky Dyson, Edward & Lynne Hillingdon, and Victoria. If you are not familiar with the story, we see Aunt Jane in Barbados.  Her generous nephew, Raymond, has sent her there to aid in her recovery from a bad bout of arthritis. (In the original, she went there for a "pig of a bronchitis.")  During her stay, a fellow guest suddenly dies.  Jane has reason to believe it is murder but the local Inspector does not.  She enlists the help of fellow guest, Jason Rafael, a self-made multi-millionaire to try and persuade the police otherwise.  The Inspector practically tosses them out of his office as old crackpots.  When another murder takes place, Jane is convinced that unless the killer is identified, even more will die.  With no help from the police, she sets out on her own, to ascertain the culprit.  How many and who will die?The differences between the original and the new that bothered me the most are: 1. The attitude of the Police Inspector; in the original he had heard of Miss Marple through Sir Henry Clithering (once head of CID at the Met,) who said, "She is the best personality analyst in the world and she has a ruthless forensic brain." When Jason Rafael informed the Barbados Inspector of her presence upon the island, his response was, "Magnificent!" In the new version, the Inspector had no use for Miss Marple or the rich and powerful Rafael.  2. There is no mention of Nemesis!  This is integral.  How could they forget this when the mention of Nemesis in A Caribbean Mystery is the basis for the follow-up titled, Nemesis!  I give, A Caribbean Mystery, three stars even though the filming is absolutely stunning and the supporting cast, as always, is brilliant.Episode Two, Greenshaw's Folly, is not based upon a Marple novel and therefore was completely new to me.  In this offering, Jane comes to the rescue of her "niece" Louisa, who is running away from her abusive husband with her young son, Archie.  Auntie Jane finds refuge for them at Greenshaw's Folly, the home of her friend, Katherine Greenshaw, the daughter of the eminent scientist, Decimus Greenshaw.  Luckily for Louisa, Katherine is in need of a secretary.  Louisa can "hide out" in Katherine's country home, tagged Greenshaw's Folly by the locals.  The home is shrouded in mystery.  There is a hidden and locked laboratory that holds terrible secrets of Decimus' past. Not long after their arrival, and while Jane is still there, what happens?  Murder.  Yay! It is left to Jane to continue to protect her charges and uncover the killer.  Once again, Jane is on her own while the local Inspector pooh-pooh's all of her ideas and observations.  I loved it; five stars.  Should more Miss Marple films be made, I would be elated if they shadowed Greenshaw's Folly.  I love Jane and I want to see more of her with McKenzie.The final episode, Endless Night, was a fail for me.  It was dark.  It had a film noir feeling and used narration by the main character, an impoverished young man with big dreams of wealth, to tell the story.  Miss Marple is oddly placed within the story.  She would just pop up here and there, into the life of this man.  Ultimately, she was in the story often enough to figure out whodunit when no one else could.  For me, it didn't work.  Everything revolved around this young man, which in and of itself is okay, but what wasn't okay is the way Miss Marple was fitted into the story.  It was not about Miss Marple.  I was also put off by the darker and sinister tone it just wasn't what I was expecting. I give Endless Night two stars.Let's add it up...A Caribbean Mystery was okay, I wish it had followed the story and mentioned Nemesis: 3 stars.  I loved Greenshaw's Folly: 5 stars. Endless Night was a bit "dark" for me and Miss Marple's part seemed forced and odd: 2 stars.  Overall, 3.33 stars.

After John Nettles' leaving spear-headed a mass exodus from the program, with the exception of Jason Hughes, I began a period of mourning.  I was more than willing to give the "new" MSM with Tom's cousin, John, taking the helm of Causton's CID, a chance.  I was sorry to see Nettles leave but, oh so happy that the series would be continuing.  However, I was not thrilled with Set 21 but believed it would get better when the transition from one Barnaby to the other was complete.  I was totally bummed when Set 22 seemed to be worse; I didn't like it all.  I was disappointed in the storylines.  Well, I was unhappy about a lot of things but I shared those in my review of that set.All this backstory to tell you that I had trepidations about purchasing this set.  In fact, I wasn't going to, I even said I wouldn't, but I did during one night of sleepless boredom.  I'd seen everything!  I needed something to watch to feed my addiction to British mysteries.  In a fit of impulsive desperation I one-click purchased this set. (I definitely need to turn that off!  Note to self: Don't grocery shop when hungry and don't shop Amazon in the middle of the night.)  Guess what happened next? I had buyer's remorse!  When it arrived, I put it aside for about three weeks until again during another sleepless night popped it in the DVD player.  Oh! Bother!  I should have watched it right away.  Miraculously, in my mind it was a miracle, I loved it.  Yippee!  I've pre-ordered Set 24!Set 23, marks a return to the original quirky but not outlandish (like Night of the Stag in Set 22) stories that made the original MSM of old one of my favorite British mystery series.  I loved the humor that once again made its way to the circumstances surrounding the deadly dramas.  There seemed to be a new affable rapport between Barnaby and Jones that was missing in the prior two sets since Neil Dudgeon's appearance.  I also noted a subtle but definite change in how John treated Jones, which gave an appearance of his having more respect for Jones than I saw previously.  All in all, I am very happy with what I see as improvements.I enjoyed the storylines: A headless horseman targeting an aristocratic and country family? Ancient battle recreations? Great!  Murder and mayhem from the movies? Wonderful!  A weird whodunit with twists?  Now you're talking!One indicator, I use in rating films and TV is the "will I re-watch the episodes" quotient.  If I will definitely re-watch...five stars.  Maybe...four stars.  Probably not...three stars.  No way...two stars.  If I "hate" something, which on Amazon is the one star designation, I usually don't watch the entire film and therefore do not review it.  I will re-watch Midsomer Murders Set 23.  Actually, I'm doing so right now.

All the quilts contained in this book can be made without the use of the specialty rulers.  There are actual size templates, which can be used instead. However, if you already own the three rulers used in the Lintotts' designs, they have provided 18 pretty patterns to encourage their use.I loved the designs contained in this book.  I love quilts that use a light background color.  For some reason, they remind me of the quilts from yesteryear made from clothing scraps and flour bags.  These were the types of quilts that adorned the beds of my childhood.  Pam and Nicky, mother and daughter, respectively, bring a modern sensibility to retro (in my view) with whimsy and color choice.  Of course, different colorways can be substituted, if their choices don't suit our tastes.  The quilts shown are all small/throw size, ranging from the smallest at 39"x39" to the largest, which is 70"x70".There are six patterns using the Two Peaks in One Ruler, six using the Double-strip Kaleidoscope Ruler, and six more for the Multi-Size Flying Geese & 45/90 Triangle. Creative Grids rulers are shown in this book, but the Lintotts state that other brands can be substituted.Each quilt has detailed instructions and diagrams.  At the back of the book are instructions of general techniques covering: pressing, pinning, chain piecing, removing dog ears, joining border and binding strips, adding borders, quilting, binding, enlarging the quilts, setting on point, and calculating backing fabric.I love this book for the instruction in using these three specialty rulers to make quick and pretty quilts.  I like the sizes of these quilts for wall-hangings and for gift giving.

I recently moved into an apartment that does not have washer/dryer hook-ups.  Oh, no! I knew lugging laundry to the laundry room would wreak havoc on my bad back.  What to do?  I searched Amazon and found this little gem.  And it is a gem!I can transport three loads of wash easily without breaking my back.  This cart is sturdy and the wheels roll smoothly over the rocky (cobblestone-like) sidewalk.  I like that it comes with an attached "roof" that can cover the contents of the bag.  It also has two handles on the sides of the bag, which I (mostly my husband) use to carry it down a flight of stairs.I highly recommend this cart to anyone looking for something similar to transport their laundry without breaking their back.  When I am reunited with my own washer and dryer, I will still have many uses for this handy cart.  It will be perfect for hauling groceries from the car to the house.

Let me start by saying that I've owned the first Silhouette Cameo since it's release and I've since purchased another Cameo. I've had the Cricut Personal cutter, Cricut Expression, and the Brother Scan N Cut. Of all of these machines, the Silhouette Cameo is by far my favorite. I'm VERY familiar with this type of machine and the Silhouette Studio software it uses because it is the same software that the Cameo uses. I ordered this machine because of the things it is supposed to be able to do that the Cameo can't do. I cut vinyl and heat transfer vinyl with my Cameo all the time. It has a larger cutting area and I'm familiar with it, so I have no desire to use the Curio to do that, but the Curio is capable of cutting vinyl and heat transfer vinyl. I tried the embossing function on water color paper and was unimpressed. It just didn't emboss well when embossing alone. It did fair when I scored and embossed. I used the stippling function, a pen holder, and a sharpie marker and it worked ok.  I have no desire to do paper crafts, but only attempted it because none of the tools to do what I want to do with the Curio are available. I want to cut, etch, and engrave wood, metal, and leather. The deep cut blade, etching tool, and larger base are now on back-order until November. The Curio was released in August with the accessories set to release in October. I'm extremely disappointed about this. I had really high hopes for this machine and I really think Silhouette dropped the ball by not releasing the accessories at the same time as they released the machine. I gave it 3 stars because it cuts vinyl, heat transfer vinyl, paper, and etc well. I received an email this morning stating that the accessories I ordered for this are going to take EVEN longer to be released so I was being issued a refund.

2:41 MinsI've been excited about this machine's release ever since it was announced. I already own 2 of the first Silhouette Cameo machines and the Silhouette Curio machine that was released last month. I'm very familiar with the Silhouette Studio software and the Silhouette Studio Designer Edition Software, which the previous machines use. The Silhouette Mint came with a new Mint Studio Software which is a very similar format to the Studio Software, but it is only for the Mint so far. The software was missing from my pre-release bundle, but after a couple of calls to Silhouette Customer Support, they sent me the link to download it. I'm 100% sure that this only happened because of the early release, so I'm not going to lower my 5 star rating because of it. I made a video/tutorial and took pictures I'm uploading to accompany this review. I was very pleased with how simple it was to open the software, import my own photo, and adjust the brightness and stamp filters to my liking. I clicked on the different stamp filters in my video to show the many choices, but I ultimately chose realistic for my dog stamp. The program automatically mirrors your design so that the stamped image looks the same as it does on your computer screen. After you are satisfied with your design, send your design to the Mint in the software, and insert the proper size stamp sheet into the back of your machine, in about a minute it comes out of the front of the machine, you then tear the cardboard on the dotted line around your stamp, peel away the cardboard, but try to keep the plastic that actually covers the stamped image on until after you've attached your stamp to the block, just to protect your image. Now attach it to the stamp base. Next, squeeze the ink onto your stamp and let it sit with the image face up for 5 minutes or more so that the stamp soaks up the ink like a sponge. The longer it sits, the more ink it will soak up. You then dab the excess ink off by stamping it on a sheet of paper until it looks good. When you are satisfied with the amount of ink on your stamp and it is stamping a crisp image, cap the stamp and use it up to 50 times before having to re-ink it. You can re-ink it in a different color the next time or several colors mixed together. The machine comes with enough materials to make 2 individual stamps, but you can buy the stamp sheets in the size of the blocks you already have and slide them on to the base you already have instead of buying more blocks every time. So, you only really have to buy one block per size and just use them with all of your Mint stamps. I am thrilled that this machine really does do exactly what it is supposed to do and it does an amazing job of it. I can't wait until the rest of the ink colors and stamp sizes are released so that I can make personalized address stamps as gifts.

This interactive camera has given our family, especially our ten year old son, a piece of mind when we are not home.  We have a puppy that's about a year old.  We enjoy being able to check in on her when we are out and about.The camera setup with our Apple products was rather quick and easy.  The app on our phone is quick and responsive.  We haven't had any issues with the operation of the camera or app.  The camera inside the cube is pointed downward so you'll need to place the cube higher up if you want the best point of view of bigger areas.  One thing I dislike is when you add someone to your family group for camera sharing purposes, you can't limit the time when they can view the camera which means they can access the camera anytime it's on.  So, don't add anyone to the family group unless you are okay with this.  It would've been nice had this one come with night vision, but we've read the next version will most likely have it.We recommend trying this one out if you enjoy checking on your loved ones when you are away from home.

I'm really into crafts and have several of the popular brand daylight type craft lamps. I was excited to try this because it's LED and has 3 brightness settings. My others don't have that option. I did a side my side comparison of this next to a comparable one of the other brand and this was brighter. This one also stood taller so it lit up a larger area. I'm often knocking my other ones over because of their lite bases, but this one has a large heavy base, so it stays in place if I accidentally hit it. The base also features a USB port which is perfect for me because I'm usually using my iPhone or iPad to read instructions on what I'm making. The design is slimmer than my other ones, so I feel like I can kind of look down at my project with nothing much obstructing my view.  It really is a nice lamp for crafting.

I was really excited to get these because I love over the ear headphones, but the excitement ends there. The entire ear piece is made out of hard plastic, even the part that goes in your ear. They're very uncomfortable and bulky. The piece that goes around the ear slides up and down so that you can secure them to your ear better, but they still don't feel secure or comfortable. My 10 year old son tried them too and immediately told me ouch, those are hard and too big to get in my ear. I'm not even going to try to run with them because I don't even feel like they're secure when I'm sitting on the couch using them. The sound quality is decent for inexpensive headphones, but that is the only positive thing I can say about them. Save your money for some better ones.

I have an iPhone 5s and my husband has the iphone 6. So far, this cable is working great for both of them. It seems to be made well. It is definitely long enough to still talk on my phone when it is plugged in to the cigarette lighter in my car or at home. I will update my review if it doesn't hold up.

I was excited to get this because I loved my little ponies when I was growing up and wanted to share the love with a little girl in my life. I must start by suggesting that you go to a quiet place alone to put this together. It's not hard, but there are several pieces and having tiny hands "help" you isn't ideal. I chose to put it together alone and was able to do it in about 45 minutes. I read directions thoroughly and try to make sure every part goes together properly. So, others may be faster at assembling it. I was happy that it came with one pony and her pet and many accessories, so there's no need to run out and by anything really, just to have things to go with it. Some of the scenery parts are cardboard, but the rest is durable plastic. I think it will hold up as long as some really destructive children don't intentionally destroy it. I love that it is large with several floors and that the doors and elevator actually work well. I highly recommend getting this set to any My Little Pony fan, young or old.

I just got my first FoodSaver machine on prime day. It's the basic V2244 model. I only purchased the off brand rolls with it and it came with a few FoodSaver brand ones. All of those worked fine for the produce, boneless chicken breasts, and ground beef I've been freezing, but for nuts and steak, I needed something that wouldn't puncture when the machine vacuumed the air out. I used these to freeze almonds, pecans, and sirloin steaks. It worked perfectly with no punctures at all. These are rolls, not individual bags, which I prefer because I like to choose how large my bags are instead of having waste or bags that are too small. I like to cut them in half after cutting the length I need to make individual portion size bags. These are what I'm using for nuts now. The box says Gamesaver on it, but as others noted, it worked flawlessly with my very basic machine, so I assume they would work with any vacuum seal system, as long as the seal area on the machine is wide enough for the bags.

I ordered this roll feeder to use with my cameo because I always have issues with the roll rolling off the table or getting sideways or bunched up. I didn't get it out of the box for over a month in and a half because I figured it would be more of a pain to use than it was worth..and THEN I was cutting 2 feet of vinyl off of a roll and it was almost done and the roll rolled off the table hitting the ground and yanking the cut part to the side and cutting it all crooked...so, I got this feeder out of the box, read the instructions, and had it all in place and working in 5 minutes. It was so simple to use. I just unpackaged it, pulled up the 2 side pieces that hold the vinyl roll, much like a wall mounted paper towel holder in my grandmas kitchen. I placed the roll in the perfect groove and with the holders in both ends then fed the vinyl thru the slit on the front. I used the included slicer to cut a perfect line. I love love the groove and slicer feature. I have the first cameo version, so mine didn't come with anything like that. When cutting vinyl from a roll, having a straight starting line is extremely important. Everything worked perfectly and I didn't have to worry about the vinyl rolling off the table. My only complaint about this roller is that they didn't make it go up to 15". I buy 15" htv rolls and would really like to use this with them as well. I skull love this, but figured it was worth noting. Maybe that is in the works for the next one. I do highly recommend this as long as you aren't using vinyl rolls larger than 12". It really works great!

I this on the ironing board I use for sewing and I absolutely love it! The ruler helps me to get an idea of how long a piece of fabric is while ironing. I don't always want to iron a full length of fabric, so with this I can know that I am ironing enough. It is great quality. It doesn't feel cheap, like the covers I've owned in the past. It also looks great in a craft or sewing room.

We have used various safes throughout the years to secure valuables and this one is the best yet.This safe is substantial, but if you're needing it to stay in place you'll need to bolt it to the floor or wall.We've had a similar safe in the past.  About six months past before opening it and the batteries had corroded inside the battery compartment so much that we had to throw it away completely.  So, yes batteries came with the safe, but we replaced them with fresh brand name batteries.The battery compartment is inside and at first I grew agitated because I could not figure out how I could open this safe if the batteries inside were dead.  I was getting frustrated until our 9 year old son pointed out where a separate battery can be connected in case this ever happens.  Yeah, I was a little embarrassed, but I was thrilled he discovered this feature.  This compartment is on the right side of the keypad on front of the door.The removable tray that locks is fairly flimsy.  The locking mechanism only secures one side of the tray which leave the other side somewhat easy to defeat.  I guess if you're already inside the safe there's not much need for a secure tray.Overall the safe is well made.  I would recommend it to anyone who needs some fire protection for valuables and documents and if your location allows you to secure it to a wall or the floor it would be ideal.

I do a lot of crafting and sewing and have always printed out instructions and patterns and saved them in binders. I had always used a regular small 3 hole punch. I was lucky if it would make it through 2 sheets of copy paper let alone 45. This one does exactly what it advertised to do. It will punch through 45 sheets of paper with a little effort. I prefer to only do 10 or so at a time because I want my tools to last forever, but it can do it. It also punches through several sheets of card stock at once. I'm very happy with this hole punch and will be using it for all my print outs from now on. It is easy to align the paper. They don't slip when you punch down either. The chip tray holds enough of the chips to where I don't have to empty it every few punches too.

This indoor grill is the next best thing to actually grilling outside. I have had the Cuisinart 4 in 1 griddler for years and loved it, but then I got this one and loved it even more. The best thing about this one is that it comes with waffle plates as well as the regular ones. The Cuisinart only came with regular ones and I would have had to buy the waffle plates separately. I had the personal size Foreman when they first came out and I liked it ok, but I didn't like the clean up. This one is easy to clean. The plates are easily removable and wash up with minimal effort. They are labeled top and bottom where as the Cuisinart ones work on both sides. They are easy to put pack on as well. This grill cooks evenly every time and has plenty of room to cook everything for our family of 3 at one time. I can honestly say I'm finally giving up my beloved Cuisinart for the Evolve. It really is a great indoor grill and I highly recommend it.

I've been using a Fiskars 45mm rotary cutter, 6x24 Fiskars ruler, and cutting mat for years, and like them, but I started a beginner quilting class a couple of weeks ago and actually didn't like doing all that precise cutting. I found that after cutting for a while I'd get tired and sloppy and somehow measure wrong or my ruler would start slipping making my cuts off. After all the cutting, I was thinking I'd never quilt again after I finish this class until this morning, when everything changed. A very sweet lady I've become friends with in my quilting class told me about this and it happened to be on sale in a local store, so I headed out to get it. I couldn't wait to get it home and try it out on the rest of my "homework." I had to cut some more 2.5" strips and it worked flawlessly. It takes very little pressure to make the cut and it's much safer than a regular rotary cutter because it's enclosed on top and doesn't even come out of the bottom until you press down to cut. The ruler part didn't slip around on my fabric because it has a pad that kind of grips the fabric on the bottom. The cutter doesn't slip because it's on it's own slider system that doesn't move from side to side. I can't wait to go back to class to show the instructor. This thing is a must have for quilters, crafters, and everyone in between. I could have used this a million times over the years, so if you're thinking about getting it, do it! My favorite quilting tool so far aside from my sewing machine.

Just an FYI to anyone thinking of purchasing this machine. It is the same exact machine as the Singer Studio S18 machine. The only difference is the price, color, and brand. They are both made by Janome and all parts are interchangeable. I hope this helps. I have the Singer and left my review there.

Just an FYI to anyone thinking of purchasing this machine. It is the same exact machine as the Singer Studio S18 machine. The only difference is the price, color, and brand. They are both made by Janome and all parts are interchangeable. I hope this helps. I have the Singer and left my review there.

If you have the standard straight shower rod, you should seriously consider getting one of these.  The extra room in the shower is wonderful.  I've enjoyed these types of shower rods while vacationing in various hotels before.  Now I get to enjoy this luxury in my own bathroom.Installation was fairly easy.  One person could do it, but it's much easier with two.  I recommend you pay close attention to how high you mount it as others have mentioned about the length of your curtain and how high you want it to fall.  We held the shower rod up with the curtain on it to see how high we wanted to mount it.  We used a level to make sure the brackets and rod were level, marked the holes to drill, then took the rod down and mounted the brackets to the wall.  Overall it took us approximately thirty minutes.This shower rod looks great, feels durable, and is extremely functional.  We love it!

We have used your basic cheap coffee makers, your k-cup makers, and even a Jura.  This is our first that is connected to the internet.This machine has a lot of possibilities.  The one advantage this has is the Wemo app allows you to schedule one brew in your coffee maker each day of the week.  For example, you can set your maker to brew at 7:00 am on Monday, 9:30 am on Tuesday, 6:00 am on Thursday and 5:00 am on Saturday and leave the rest of the week off.  If you're out and about and ready to head home, you can go onto the app and schedule a brew to be ready when you get home...as long as you have the water and coffee grounds in the machine.  The app is supposed to alert you when 90 brew cycles have been performed or when the brew time takes longer than it is supposed too which means it is time to run some white vinegar through it to do a 50 minute cleaning cycle.Set up was straight forward.  I downloaded the app.  My phone found the machine with no issue.  It connected to my router without issue.  Then it indicated a firmware update was available which I had it to install and took less than five minutes.I brewed some water to clean it as directed, cleaned the carafe (which is very nice compared to those glass ones I've been breaking), and got my first brew running.Moments later I received an alert on my phone telling me my coffee was ready!  It all worked flawlessly and my coffee turned out spectacular.I've included some pictures of the unit so you'll see what you're getting.It would be nice if the app would give you an option to immediately turn the unit on.

This case and charging system works, but the standard Apple Lightning cord does not fit.  I already have at least five lightning cords throughout the house and two vehicles.  I did not want to purchase the same number of cords to replace them for a new way of charging.  The case works fine for my phone, but it makes the overall phone larger than what I was already using.If you have just purchased an iPhone 5S this might be something you should consider.  If you already have a case you like and a few cords, I'd say you should consider passing this one up.

We recently purchased an older house that we have remodeled.  We replaced all outlets, all light fixtures, painted all walls and ceilings, replaced all baseboard trim, put down hardwood throughout the house, and put a floating cork floor in the bathroom.  The house has a light above the refrigerator and the switch is behind it.  It was very hard to get to so we decided to install this dimmer.Installation was pretty easy.  If you have never installed anything electrical, I'd recommend you attend one of the free classes at your local home improvement store...the orange one :) and if you are still not confident you should consider hiring a licensed electrician.  Don't forget you need to turn the breaker off first!After the dimmer was installed and the smart bridge was connected to our router and the app was installed on our phone, it was basically following the steps to get everything working.We have had no issues with the dimmer or the smart bridge.  It would've been nice had the smart bridge been wireless because we already have a number of devices connected to our router.I've posted a few pictures of the boxes and contents so you'll be able to see what is included.I recommend this dimmer.  Our 9 year old son says we are in the modern age now :)

The HP Stream 14 Quad Core Laptop with Beats Audio (Natural Silver) performs great for its capabilities.  This is no powerhouse or high-end gaming computer.  It isn’t weighed down with a heavy battery, so don’t expect the juice to last a long time before recharging after extended use.  We browse the internet, watch a few videos and have to plug it in to charge about every three days or so.  The product states the average battery lasts 6.5 hours.  This is just about what we get with our use.  This computer is thin and lightweight, yet it feels sturdy and well-constructed.  It performs all basic internet browsing and word processing without any major issues.  Internet pages load reasonable well.  It isn’t the fastest, but it isn’t the most expensive either.  Music sounds great for its speaker size.  Videos are crystal clear.  For the price, you’ll be hard pressed to find a better Windows PC.  I am not a fan of Windows 8 without a touchscreen, but that capability adds more expense.  I am not a big fan of AMD either, but I’ve had no problems with it so far.  Chromebooks have their advantages like quick startup, but they have their limitations as related to Google to some degree.  This HP doesn’t start as quickly as a Chromebook, but it operates more like a regular PC since it is Windows based.  It’s not a full blown PC in that it has no optical drive and its hard drive space is very limited.If you’re looking for a basic computer, this one fits the bill.  It’s so easy to operate, our nine year old son has basically taken it over and calls it his.  Don’t take that wrong.  This is not a toy PC.  Our son is technologically advanced and he gives this his stamp of approval.  You should also look at a few other reviews and note that HP does read the reviews and takes the time to reply to those who have had issues in an attempt resolve problems.  That’s worth a lot in my opinion.

Let me start by saying I've never used a roaster oven, but have always wanted one, so I have nothing to compare this to. I actually loved the results I got with it. I read other reviews and decided to stick my chicken in a roasting bag because I like the crock pot bags in a crock pot because of the clean up. I figured this would have about the same clean up, and it did. I always spray the sides of my crock pot with non stick spray before using it, so I did with this as well. It really makes a huge difference. This roaster is huge. I imagine with my family of 3, that we will only use it during the holidays, but at least it gives us other options since there are always things going in and out of the oven when all the family is here, so my bird can be in another area not occupying the oven and getting dried out as people open and close it putting bread in and out etc. I got even cooking with my bird, but did notice that some of the juices that were in the corners were kind of burnt to the roasting bag. The same thing happens with my crock pot and crock pot bags. I gave this 5 stars, because I liked it and without having ever tried another, I would recommend it to others. It frees up much needed space on the holidays.

I've used Oral-B Pulsonic Sonic Electric Toothbrush (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001CX4JSS) for about the last five years and it is still going strong.  The Oral-B has two speeds.  I use the sensitive speed setting.  The handle part is rounded and easy to hold.I've always thought I wanted a Sonicare, but I haven't tried one until now.  This Sonicare has one speed and it's intensely powerful...much more than the Oral-B to me.  The handle  doesn't feel as comfortable in my hand either.  The bristles are extremely soft and with the higher speed it does tickle somewhat.I'm going to give it a few weeks or so and see how it goes.  Right now I'm tempted to go back to my Oral-B.  There's nothing wrong with the Sonicare and if I had never had an electric toothbrush before, I'm sure I'd love it.So, yes, I'd recommend it, but I'd also recommend trying out others.  Everything is a personal preference.The Sonicare left my teeth clean and it did exactly what it was supposed to.  It's more powerful than what I'm used to.

I was really impressed with this pet bed. We got it for our new puppy. It's too nice for us to trust her alone with just yet, so she lays on it in the livingroom when we are watching her, but when she is old enough, this will be her main bed. She really does like it because it is very tall and she is very short. It allows her to be raised up to get more attention when we are sitting on the couch and we place it next to the couch. It makes it easier for us to bend over and give her attention. It is very comfortable from what I can tell as well. It really is like a mattress for her. I think it looks pretty sitting out too. My son wants it in his room by his bed so she can sleep near him eventually. I love that the cover zips off, so that I can throw it in the wash. It comes off easy and is easy to put back on. I've had harder times stuffing a pillow into it's pillow case than getting this back in the cover, so it's a winner for me. I like that they added a handle because it is pretty bulky and it makes it easier to carry around, if you take it from room to room, like we do. Our dog is small, but I'd imagine that this would be great for tiny all the way to medium size dogs.

This paper towel holder was a breeze to install. We simply measured to see where we wanted it and used a level to make sure it was straight, then drew a mark where the 2 screws should go, drilled the holes large enough for the anchors to slide in and then put the holder up and screwed in the screws. We are totally remodeling a house we bought and this was the easiest installation we've had this far and we've had MANY! I highly recommend this paper towel holder over the cheap plastic ones any day!

I’ve tried two different cases for my iPhone 6.  I normally carry my phone in a top closed shirt pocket during the week in the daytime.  In the evenings and on weekends I carry it in side pockets of cargo pants and shorts.  I’m quite conscious of my phone and handle it as carefully as possible.I wanted a case that was minimal and did a good job of protecting the phone on the corners.  I first tried the http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LL60JU8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1Spigen Tough Armor case.  It has a slick back to it.  The areas where the sides of the case are cut away seem weak and flimsy.  I carried it for about three weeks with no issues other than disliking the slick back.  The front, inside edges of the case are very minimal…more minimal than what I preferred, but it was doing the job.I decided to try the http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LCAVSO4Urban Armor Gear case.  This case looks much more durable.  After I placed my phone in it, I immediately could tell the difference between it and the Spigen Tough Armor.  The Urban Armor Gear is not nearly as slick on the back.  The sides have ridges and spots that are easier to hold on to while using my phone.  The places that have cutouts for the ports on the sides are a little weak and more flimsy than the rest, but not nearly as weak as the Spigen’s sides.  The Urban Armor’s corner areas on the front are deeper and much better protected too.  The outside of the corners are actually raised higher than the sides.I’ve kept the Urban Armor Gear on my phone.  I feel my phone is better protected with it.I’d recommend the Urban Armor Gear case to anyone who wants a minimal case with exceptional features.

I got this at a deep discount from my local big box hardware store. It was easy for my husband to install and looks nice hanging in the hall of our house we are completely remodeling. I highly recommend it even at regular price. It resembles some in the high end lighting catalogs at a fraction of the cost. I'm adding a before and after picture of it in our unfinished hall. I hope this helps.

I'm no professional painter, but I painted a lot in the first home we owned and now we've purchased a house that we are completely redoing. We are priming and painting every surface that can be done in the house. I'm talking built-ins, ceiling, trim, walls, doors, AND cabinet paint, so I needed a more effective corner or trim brush. I was previously using the Wooster Short Cut, which I've been using for years, but this is a huge job and having to be done over a short period of time. I only painted when I wanted to change up a room in the past. So, I opened this brush up yesterday and started cutting in on the wall where it meets the textured ceiling. It worked perfect. The tip is much sharper and smaller than the shortcut, so it allowed me to get right up in the groove between the wall and ceiling for a seamless job. I cut in around the windows, door trim, and cabinets as well with ease and perfection. We removed the baseboards because we are putting in new flooring as well, so I can't review on how well it works there, but I would bet just as well. It took a little getting used to holding the fatter triangle shaped brush, but I got used to it and actually think it's more comfortable to hold. I'll be repainting the door and window trim in the next week or so and will update my review to reflect my thoughts on that part of the job with this brush. My overall all advice as of now is, don't be afraid to try this brush because it looks strange. I wish I would have tried it several years ago when I first saw it. It would have made all my projects come out more perfect and saved me some stress. I hope this helps!

Let me start by saying I collect Le Creuset cookware. This looks similar, but features the non stick finish and isn't nearly as heavy. I hate to admit it, but I prefer using this over my Le Creuset grill pan now. I've used it a few times and it's just better. I love love the non stick feature. It cooks evenly on my largest burner and everything comes out tasting great without leaving the best part stuck in the pan. My favorite thing to cook in it is bologna because I love the crispy grill marks and flavor it leaves. I choose to hand wash mine, but it says it can be washed in the dishwasher. In my experience, you will get the most longevity out of cookware if you hand wash it. I also don't use abrasive scrubbers. I use the one made for non stick surfaces. Only time will tell how the non stick coating holds up, so I will update my review as needed. If this pan holds up, I will be investing in many more.

I can't say enough great things about this adapter. It solved a few problems we were having using regular outlets. We have many devices with the big box type plugs, so we could only charge one of those at a time. With this, we can plug in 4 of the large box type plugs and 2 of our USB devices. We've had all the plugs going at once with no problem at all. I haven't used the mounting part yet because we are in the process of moving and I don't want to mount it until we are moved in to our new home, but I will update my review once I do. This is heavy, but I place it in a partially opened drawer when in use so that it doesn't slide around or fall if someone is using one of the devices that's plugged into it. I can't wait to get one for each family member for Christmas this year. We all love it and need our own.

I plugged this in and switched it on and it worked perfectly. It heated was fully heated and ready to go in a matter of minutes. I used the pouches that came with it and some scotch brand pouches and all worked flawlessly with no bubbles or fogginess. I even used the small business card size and it ran through flawlessly. It isn't too terribly hot when it comes out the other side and it doesn't smell terrible which is a huge plus. This is a great little laminator.

Let me start my review by saying that I currently own the Polar FT7 heart rate monitor, Fitbit Flex, and now this, so I'm not a complete stranger to this kind of thing. I'm a runner and like to know how hard I'm working when I run. This tracker does that pretty well, but isn't as accurate as the Polar FT7 on the heart rate. The Fitbit flex has the same issue, so if your main concern is your heart rate when you're working out and you want accuracy, choose the Polar FT7, because it has a chest strap that makes it much more accurate. So, when I run, I wear this one one arm and the FT7 on the other. I like that I can keep up with my entire day of activity with this and have it stored in my Basis account. I have the iphone 5s and had no issues at all with installing the app and syncing my device. It was simple to sync after as well using blue tooth. I charge this every few days when I notice it getting low, but it doesn't take long, so you can get right back to wearing it. It is pretty bulky, but that is to be expected with this type of watch. It reminds me of the calculator watch my dad wore when I was young, but I'm getting used to it. I love that I can see my workout on the screen, compared to the fitbit, where I have to look at my app to see my progress. My main complaint I have about this tracker is that the band wouldn't stay snapped onto the watch face after only a few times of me wearing it.
