So, I tried my best to call the company, but there is literally no customer service phone number anywhere on the internet. I ended up emailing them with my problem, because I couldn't even wear it for a second without it popping back off. They didn't answer my email for several days, but were quick to respond to my public posts on their facebook page about my tracker. I just have issues with companies that I can't call personally and speak with. I even asked them to please call me in my email, and nothing. They did replace the watch and I sent the defective one back with a prepaid label. The new one stays together so far, but it took a few uses last time, so we shall see. I will update my review accordingly. I gave this 3 stars because it is a nice concept and I do enjoy it, although it's not completely accurate, it does give me an idea of how active I've been and how my sleeping is going. I recommend this to anyone looking for an all in one type of tracker mainly to just track your daily activity. I gave this 3 stars because of the slow customer service and the first one being broken. I hope this helps.

I already have the Panasonic ES8109S Men's 3-Blade (Arc 3) Wet/Dry Nanotech Rechargeable Electric Shaver with Vortex Cleaning System, which is essentially the same as the Panasonic ES8103S Men's 3-Blade (Arc 3) Wet/Dry Rechargeable Electric Shaver with Nanotech Blades, just with the cleaning system, so I'm not new to this type of electric razor. I'm a woman and I suffer from razor burn if I use an actual razor in some areas of my body, so a couple of years ago, my husband bought me the ES8109S to use in my bikini area and my arm pits. So, I was excited to get this one and that it was washable. I would never buy one that couldn't be rinsed clean. So, with that being said, this is a great razor, especially at this price point. It is a fraction of the cost of the Panasonic, but functions just as well(minus the waterproof function). The handle is slightly bulkier, but not enough to make it uncomfortable to hold. I had to charge it for a day initially, which is standard with most rechargeable devices, so that was no big deal. After the initial charge, it charges extremely fast, so if you let it die, you can use it plugged in or you can charge it rather quickly without it ruining your morning. The pivot head is great for all of the angles your body or face has. My only complaint is that I can't use it in the shower, it's not a big deal and it isn't marketed to be used in the shower, so I'm not taking off stars for that. This shaves just as close, if not closer than my Panasonic, so I've been using it non-stop since getting it. This is a great little razor and worth trying out.

I'm a runner and I currently own the Fitbit Flex, Basis health tracker, and  the Polar FT7 Heart Rate Monitor Watch, so I have a few things to compare this to. The only good things I really have to say about this tracker is that it is comfortable to wear and it has a great price point. In this case, you definitely get what you pay for. I used this with my son's iphone 4s because I didn't want to add another app to my 5s. Entering all of my weight, height, etc info was easy enough and  getting it to sync the first time was easy, once I got the phone close to the band, but after the initial sync, it was a pain. I can't stand that I have to make it sync on my own. The Fitbit flex and Basis band, both have the ability to do it on their own when I'm within range of my phone. I wore this, the fitbit flex, and the Polar FT7, which I wear a chest strap with and know it is accurate, all together for a day and I found this one to be the farthest from the accurate reading. It wasn't even in the same ball park. Like others have stated, this thing tracks every wiggle as a step and you end up "supposedly" walking a half marathon each day, which was way off. The sleep pattern feature is a joke. I forgot to switch it to sleep mode almost every night I wore it. The Fitbit senses you're sleeping on it's own eventually, if you forget to switch it to sleep mode. Depending on what you're actually looking for and your price point, I recommend the Polar FT7 or a Fitbit flex. The Polar FT7 is what I use only during my workout to get the most accurate calorie count, heart rate, etc. It wouldn't be good for an all-day type of thing, because it does require a chest strap. It doesn't track sleep patterns and there's no online competition with it. I recommend the Fitbit flex or similar Fitbit products if you are looking for an all around type of device. It at least gives you an idea of your sleep pattern and activity levels. It's not as accurate as the Polar FT7, but without a chest strap, you aren't going to get a 100% reading from anything. I hope this helps. The one good thing about this band, is that my 8yo son, now has this band as "his" since I'm not using it. He's happy he has one like me and he loves putting it in sleep mode and seeing how many steps he's made in a day. It's completely inaccurate, but he has no clue, so that may be a good reason for someone to purchase this, but it isn't for anyone that is serious about tracking their activity.

This vacuum out of the box was extremely easy to assemble. It took only a few minutes for me to have it up and running. I already own the Hoover Tempo WidePath Bagged Upright Vacuum U5140900, so I know how well Hoovers work. This one was no different. It has great suction even compared to my older Hoover and the fact that I can vacuum my kitchen floors by turning off the brushes is a huge plus because I despise sweeping the floors. It's extremely easy to empty the canister too. I use the upholstery/dusting brush attachment for my couches and recliners. I have microfiber furniture and sometimes things tend to stick to it, so this was probably my favorite feature. I don't find this heavy to push around either, but it is a little difficult to wrestle up and down the stairs. I only took it upstairs one time then decided that I'd just leave my old Hoover up there since I have an extra one that works well. I've never found it fun to wrestle any vacuum up and down the stairs, so this one wasn't any more difficult than my other one. My only real complaint about this vacuum and the reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5, is that the cord is sticky on mine. It gets stuck when it's almost all the way reeled in, about 75% of the time. When it happens, I have to pull it back out a little ways and try again. This isn't a big deal to me because I'm used to one that doesn't wind inside, but since it's a selling feature on this unit, I took a star off because of it. Other than that, I highly recommend this vacuum. We love the color and high end look, but budget friendly price point.

We just moved into a 3 story condo and the bedrooms are in the basement, so they stay cold. When I saw this, I was so excited to try it because my son's bedroom stays the coldest as it is in the middle of the house and gets no direct sun. We were using one of those small heaters, which was great, but uses a lot of power. This mattress pad solved all the problems we were having. It is perfect on low. We turn it on about 30 minutes before he goes to bed to get it warms up for him and it's nice and warm when he gets in. It's 19 degrees here and he's sleeping in shorts and a t-shirt and completely comfortable. It has a 10 hour auto shut off, which I love, but I do push the on and off button just before I walk out of his room at night to start the 10 hours over. He can't stand it any higher than low, but that's fine with me. It's just enough to keep him cozy. I highly recommend this to anyone sleeping in a cold room. It really works great, and unlike an electric blanket, it warms the mattress and essentially the comforter, because heat rises. My son cannot keep his covers on at night, so an electric blanket wouldn't stay on him either, this one, he can't kick off. It's perfect for us all the way around.

I have owned the Brother 1034D serger for several years and this is identical. The only difference is the color scheme and that this comes with 2 extra presser feet and some extra thread. Amazon even uses the 1034D pictures in this ones listing. This, like the 1034D is the best serger on the market at this price point. They are also of very high quality. My 1034D has been dropped off of a collapsing table and still worked. They are tough machines. If you're buying a serger, I assume you are somewhat experienced at sewing. I consider myself a little experienced at this point, but still can't figure out how to thread this thing from start to finish even with watching the videos. So, ALWAYS tie it off like the video recommends and just change your thread like that. I wouldn't try to thread it yourself from the start unless you're sure you know how. If you're considering this machine look at the 1034D as well, as it is currently cheaper on Amazon, but doesn't come with the extra 2 presser feet. I only use the standard one myself, so the 1034D would be all I need, but you may need the others. Either way, you're getting a high quality serger at a really low price, so you can't go wrong.

I was a Janome snob up until a year ago when I got my first Brother sewing machine. It was the Brother HC1850 computerized sewing and quilting machine and is identical to this one. This one has a few more stitches and comes with a few more presser feet, but other than that, I can't tell a difference.This machine is extremely easy to set up. You can use it with or without the pedal since it's computerized. I did use it without the pedal to test it, but I don't like sewing without a pedal, so I only sewed a few stitches, which stitched perfectly, then sewed with the pedal. I'm old fashioned like that. I feel more in control using my foot, like in a car. I don't sew elaborate outfits, but I do sew pretty often and this machine can do anything I want to do and comes with the presser feet for every job I could dream of. I don't quilt, but do enjoy using the large quilting table when I sew baby blankets.The only issue at all I've had with the Brother machines is using the threader. It's user error on my part. I guess I missed it in the instructions on my first one, but you push that button to the top right of the needle with the needle and thread picture on it to get the needle in the upper most position before pulling the thread lever down. I was trying to turn the wheel to do it manually and it would never be in the perfect position. There's also a line on the wheel that you can line up with the machine if you prefer to turn the wheel on your own, but regardless, it needs to be in the perfect position before threading to work properly. That's the only issue at all I've had and like I said, that was my own fault for missing it in the instructions.In my opinion, Brother has the best sewing machine on the market for the price. The customer service department is awesome as well. If you have any issues at all, call them and they'll make sure you're helped.

Out of the box, the Camelio is easy to start up. It does say you have to charge it first, so we were able to play with it within 2 hours. This tablet is no ipad, but good as a starter tablet for younger kids that don't already have an ipad or equivalent. We already have an ipad, so I thought my 8 year old was going to laugh at this, but surprisingly, he was really into it for a week or so. I think because it was "his", but then the newness wore off and he hasn't showed much interest in it in a while. Keep in mind he has a ton of other electronics, so that may be why he lost interest. The wifi works most of the time, but this is extremely inexpensive, so maybe that's ok with most people. I gave it 4 stars because it is geared toward younger kids, does do what it's supposed to do, for the most part, and is inexpensive enough that if your child was to lose it, it wouldn't be a huge loss. My son was able to get online and on twitter with no issues. It's much slower than our ipad and iphones, but once again, in this price point, I'd expect it to have minor issues. It still isn't terribly slow, just not as fast. I like that it has the option of buying character covers and theme, but my son is a little past that, so I just bought a generic 7" tablet case and it works great.

These came with my Brother Designio Series DZ820E Embroidery Only Machine and they work perfectly. I thought with the size of them that they wouldn't last long, but I've done a lot of projects with the first one and it is still over half full. I know they are pricey, but I think they're convenient and have heard of other people having trouble with ones they've wound themselves. I hope this helps:)

I will start by saying that I am a complete beginner when it comes to embroidery. I sew, but had never even attempted embroidery until I got this machine. I actually bought Brother PE500 4x4 Embroidery Machine With 70 Built-in Designs and 5 Fonts and was so intimidated that I gave it to my friend without ever even trying it. So, this shows up at my door and I immediately get it out and set up. It was extremely easy to set up and the instruction manual was super easy to follow. Threading the machine was even easy. You just pay close attention to the instructions on where the thread goes. The arrows guide you the entire way. The needle threader works flawlessly, just make sure you put your presser foot down before threading the needle. I speak from experience when I say it won't work unless you lower it. This machine doesn't like 40 Spools Polyester Embroidery Machine Thread. I tried several different colors and they kept getting knotted up and would eventually break. I was worried it was the machine, but switched back to the Brother thread included with the machine and it ran flawlessly, but that thread is hard to find, so I ended up buying Floriani thread from a local sewing shop after a friend recommended it and it has ran flawlessly with it.This machine comes with every single thing you need to get started besides the fabric. I loved that because I didn't know if I'd prefer tear away stabilizer or cut away. Different people prefer different things. I learned that I prefer tear away because it's one less step I have to mess with, but it's really just my preference. It comes with quite a few prewound bobbins for the bottom thread and several extra bobbins as well. It also comes with some amazing little scissors. They are so sharp and the perfect angle for trimming applique designs after you stitch the basting stitch.It has many preloaded designs, but most of those really aren't my style, so I was eager to use my flash drive to transfer designs. From what I read in the book, you can't have more than 200 designs on the flash drive you are plugging into the machine or else it won't read and you can only have PES files on it. So, I made sure the flash drive I used was empty then just added the designs I had ordered from a website. I could view them once I plugged the flash drive into the machine. It's grainy looking, but still easy to make out and tell which design you are choosing. I did several appliques as well as just plain embroidery designs. I'm still trying to master how to get everything perfectly centered and straight, but I'm sure I will get better with time. I've uploaded several pictures of what I've been working on since receiving this machine.I highly recommend this machine to anyone looking at getting into embroidery. It's a great entry level machine, but still nice enough for people that have been doing this a long time. I'm just thrilled with the results. Don't be intimidated. If you can thread a sewing machine, you can do this. I did have a hard time finding information about this machine on the internet, so I just used tutorials I had found for the Brother PE770 5 inch x7 inch Embroidery-only machine with built-in memory, USB port, 6 lettering fonts and 136 built-in designs. From what I can tell, they are the same exact machine, this may just be a newer version. All of the tutorials I watched applied to this machine as well, so if you find yourself stuck, look that one up.*Update*Since writing this review and doing a ton of research, I found a much less expensive embroidery software that works like a dream for me. It's called Sew What Pro and is highly recommended in the embroidery world. It can be downloaded straight from the internet with a simple search. They even offer a free 30 day trial which allows you to do 50+ designs just to make sure you like it before purchasing. I just couldn't see buying the Brother software for my little hobby. I hope this helps other hobbyist like myself, because I was so excited to find it. It works like a dream with this machine.

I'm not new to craft cutting machines. I've had theCricut Mini Cutting Machine, Cricut Expression Electronic Cutting Machine, and Silhouette Cameo Starter Kit Bundle Cutter. I thought that since this machine is Brother brand and advertises it's ability to cut appliques, that it would work with my Brother embroidery machine, but it won't. I had even seen a machine in my local sewing shop and they said that it could  cut appliques with the PES software, but after contacting Brother, they said that is false. The embroidery machine and the Scan N Cut use completely different files and there was no way to use them together. So, that was a big let down. I have software for craft cutting machines that works on my Silhouette Cameo and my original Cricut Expression, but won't work on the Scan N Cut because all the other machines take SVG files, but this one takes FMC files. I read on the website that Brother is working on cloud based software that will allow me to convert all of my SVG files into FMC files, but I wonder how much that will set me back? I like the scanning feature, but don't like that 99% of the things I want to cut I can't find a clear image for. Even when I do find a clear enough image, I have to waste ink printing it out on my printer, then scan it in and try to edit, size, and move the image on the tiny screen. I much prefer using a computer screen with the virtual mat, then just positioning the paper to be cut on the mat and pushing cut.I did attempt to cut Oracle 651 vinyl on the machine following the settings recommended in the little start up guide. It recommended cutting on a blade setting of 4 on the turquoise blade. That cut way too deep. When you cut vinyl, you only want the machine to cut through the top vinyl part, not all the way through the backing, so I tried it on 3 and it was still too deep, so eventually I set it on 1 and that was perfect. It cut through only the top layer leaving the sticker backing so I could peel away the negative space and use transfer tape to apply my vinyl to my project. I cut card stock successfully using their recommended blade setting of 4, but it left deep cut marks in my mat, so I reduced it to 3 and that worked fine without such a deep cut on the mat. I would definitely recommend playing with it to see what your preferences are. Cutting that deep all the time will wear your mat out in a hurry and they are pretty costly. Which leads to my next issue with this machine. The replacement mats and blades are more expensive than the replacement items for the Cameo. The tools that this machine comes with look like toys in comparison to the Cricut and Silhouette brand tools. The edges aren't sharp enough to really get under things and there's no hook tool at all for weeding vinyl.My overall thoughts on this machine are that they should have waited until they had the SVG software to release it. They really jumped the gun. As is, it doesn't even compare to the Silhouette Cameo's design capabilities. They should also be very clear in their advertising that this machine doesn't work along side the embroidery machine to applique designs. I'm learning that many other people thought they'd work hand in hand as well. If they release some amazing software that makes this thing great, I'll update my review, but as of right now, I say go for the Cameo instead. The scanner is very nice on this and it would be a great machine if it had the design capabilities that other machines have, but it just doesn't. My fingers are crossed that they get it figured out and release something. It has so much potential.*Update*Since writing this review, Brother Released the Canvas program on 11/08/13 that allows you to design projects on your computer to cut on the Scan N Cut in an online program. It works ok, but doesn't allow you to download svg's as of yet. The Brother website say's it's coming, but it the ability to cut or convert your SVG files is not available yet, and my biggest gripe about the software is that I still have to put my design on a flash drive and plug it into the machine. I wish it was like other cutter programs that allow you to use a printer cord to plug your computer directly into your machine, then do everything on your computer, but feed the mat and change the blade depth. This still has a long way to go to compare to those programs. I would still recommend the Silhouette Cameo and software over this.

This is a decent monitor for this price point. I currently own the Fitbit Flex Wireless Activity + Sleep Wristband, Black and the Polar FT7 Heart Rate Monitor, Blue/Lilac, which requires a chest strap. I find that the Polar FT7 is he most accurate, then the LifeTrak and the least accurate is the Fitbit, but the fitbit isn't a heart rate monitor. It's actually just an exercise tracker. So, I will only compare this to the Polar. The LifeTrak is much larger on the wrist than the Polar, but much more comfortable considering there's no chest strap. The step counter is usually about the same for both when I wear them together, but the heart rate is off by a point or 2 at times. I would still choose the LifeTrak over the Polar even with it being a little off just based on the comfort level. I think that alone makes it worth buying, not to mention the price point. I am a smaller female and this watch fits me with plenty of room to expand. It has a lot of holes, but could be an issue for a man or woman with larger wrists. I don't really sinc mine much because I record it on my calendar each day when I'm done exercising, but I did sinc it to my newer iphone just to make sure it's possible and it did it flawlessly. So, I definitely recommend this for anyone that's looking for a comfortable and no fuss heart rate monitor. It will definitely give you a fairly accurate idea of how much you're body is working.

The reason I got this monitor was because of the temperature sensor. My son's room is on the front of the house and is always the coldest room in the winter and the hottest room in the summer. I didn't even know that monitors with temperature sensors existed before seeing this one, so I was excited to get it, to say the least. It was easy enough to set the temperature alert by following the instructions and it's not an annoying alarm that goes off if the temperature gets in a too hot or too cold range. It's just a beep. I've learned to read the instructions carefully before starting any electronics over the years, so it was easy for me to set up after studying it for a few minutes. After getting it set up, I tested the nightlight, which isn't too bright, but isn't too dim either. It's more like the unit just glows which is nice. The lullaby function is nice, but nothing that I will use on a regular basis because I leave a radio and air purifier going in his room at night. I have the sensitivity set on medium and I can hear the low roar of the air purifier and just a little bit of the music, but that's something I'm used to listening to in my sleep. When I set it on low, I don't hear anything unless he calls me or cries and then it just kicks on so that I can hear it. The range on this is great. My yard isn't tiny and I can take the parent monitor out to take the trash out at night and to check the mail during the day without any static or issues. The only thing that could make this unit better is if it had a video function, but I know this isn't a video unit. I trust the Philips brand and highly recommend this monitor. It's working like a charm so far.

I really had high hopes for this cabinet, but it's just ok. The instructions were easy enough for me to follow and it was easy for me to assemble alone and then I had my husband help me hang it, which wasn't difficult considering we've hung tons of things over the years. I gave it 3 stars because it does work good for storing spray paint, paint brushes, and small stain cans, but is too lightweight for the heavier tools my husband was hoping to use it for. He just didn't trust it for his heavy and high quality tools. I would imagine most people that want this are planning on storing heavier stuff, so it might not be ideal for some people. I would have really liked a locking option as well, just in case someone leaves the garage door open, but I knew that it didn't have one on the front end, so I'm not reviewing based on that. It's just a suggestion. My cabinet actually came packaged very well and was in perfect condition out of the box. I liked the finish on both the doors and cabinet itself, so if you are looking for a cabinet for lightweight items, this may be the one for you, but if you're wanting it for heavier items, you should definitely look at getting something else.

First, let me say I am not the most technologically advanced person ever.  This review will cover my experience in setting up, updating, and general use of this laptop.My family and I have had various brands of computers.  Before we tried this one, we've had HP, ASUS, and Gateway.  We have one wireless router that has been working well for several years.  We have an older iPad, two iPhone 4S smartphones, an iPhone 3g that's used as an iPod by our 8 year old son, and a couple gaming systems.  Before this newest addition to our electronics world, everything was working just fine.Enter Toshiba.  We knew this was going to be bigger than the laptops we were used to, but this was bigger than expected.  It's not too big for home use.  I wouldn't want to lug it around an airport on a vacation trip though.This thing is gorgeous.  The back-lit keyboard is in red.  The logo on the outside glows red when closed and its really a good looking computer.The power cord is much thicker and bigger than any others we've used before, but to feed this powerhouse I guess you have to have a good flow of juice.  The way it connects is different than others we've had.  The plug has a larger diameter insert.  It doesn't feel like it really plugs in very solidly.  I can only wonder how it will hold up over time as it gets moved around the house being plugged and unplugged.The initial start-up was fast and easy.  When we went to download some larger programs from the Internet, it would bog down and lose our wireless Internet connection.  This happened over and over.  We went to Toshiba's website and made sure to install and update all new and current drivers.  We spent about two hours researching potential issues online until we decided we couldn't figure it out and called Toshiba.After going thru the normal automated phone system we finally reached a person with Toshiba.  He asked typical questions.  He did not attempt to have us do any software updates.  Instead he had us do a complete restore which he said would take several hours.  We were not happy.  He tried to get us off the phone and to have us call back later when the computer is finished, but we kept insisting a restore would not fix anything since it was probably a driver or software issue.  He pushed our issue to a Tier Two person.  As we were talking with her, the computer restore function finished.  It took maybe 20 minutes, not hours like we were told.  This lady remoted into the computer. She had us download some programs which would cause the computer to lose the wireless Internet connection.  She went into our router and changed the frequency, but that had no positive effect.  As she was remoting into the machine she went to the Toshiba website and check the updates and drivers.  All the newest updates and drives were installed.  After a couple hours she basically said we would have to box it up and sent to Toshiba.  We insisted there must be an issue with the driver for the wireless card.  She had us download the driver and save it on the desktop.  As she was talking to us on the phone, she had us uninstall the driver that was in the computer and restart it.  Of course this made it where we could not connect wirelessly until we opened and installed the wireless driver.  We found out the newest version of the driver was not working, but when an older version from earlier this year was installed everything was good in the world again.Overall we spent over seven hours working on this computer just to get it running like it is supposed to.  Had we not stuck to our guns, it would've taken much longer and it would've been sent back to Toshiba just to probably have the same issue again.  We were told they were sending this to their developers so hopefully by the time you read this, you won't have this same issue.We use this computer to operate a Silhouette Cameo Starter Kit Bundle Cutter with the Designer software and a Cricut Expression Electronic Cutting Machine with Sure Cuts A Lot 2 software, that need a lot of system power to run.  These cutting machines were previously connected to a smaller computer with much less power and size and when we used it, it would slow down and take some time to complete a crafting project.  With this Toshiba, there's not one hiccup.  It blazes thru it.I'd say our precious computers were more like an economic 4 cylinder manual transmission and this Toshiba is at least a V8 automatic powerhouse.This isn't your basic, entry level computer.  So, if you're considering this we imagine you know what your looking for.Good luck!

Let me start by saying that this is a nice little kit and comes with 3 different sizes of stamping blocks that have the grids to help you get your stamps straight. It comes with three sheets of stamping material, a special stamp material mat, a silhouette ink pad in black, a download card for some exclusive stamping designs, and a DVD tutorial that leaves a little to be desired. When I ordered this I thought for some reason, that it would produce a carved stamp instead of just a cut out letter or shape, but it doesn't. So, if you cut out the word "stamp" and you don't weld it to make the letters connect, then you will have to line up each individual letter one by one and make sure you get them completely straight on your stamping block. This can be really tedious if you have small or a lot of letters. My cameo cut the stamping material the first time with no issues at all by simply following the tutorial, changing the mat to the one in the kit, and changing the blade setting to the recommended number. My letters were perfect and the ink included worked perfectly on card stock. I tried to use Staz On brand ink and it beaded up and wouldn't produce a clean image. I tried several times and it just would not work. The ink was brand new, so I'm thinking that the stamping material just won't soak it up properly. So, please keep that in mind when using this material. Overall, this is a great product. Just keep in mind that the machine is not carving the stamp out. You will have to position your stamp on the block every time you want to use it. Also remember to flip your words to be backward when the bottom of your stamp is facing you and to where it looks correct when you flip it over like you are going to stamp with it. Both sides of the material are the same, so you can use whichever side you want. There's no need to flip your word in the program. I'm posting some pics to show my results. I hope this helps.

I must say that I was skeptical of this grill mainly because it is a George Foreman and I always thought his products were too commercialized and not of good quality, but they thought of everything with this one. I have the Cuisinart GR-4N 5-in-1 Griddlerand love it so much that I used it at least once a week, until I got this one. What makes this one superior, is that it cooks more evenly, even when there is a lot of meat on it and the option to lean the grill to drain off fat or to leave it flat to cook in the juices. The Cuisinart only allows for flat cooking and the grease always leaks onto my counter top. I assumed they all did, but I've had no issues at all with this one leaking. This one is a little larger, but is a pretty color, so that helps with aesthetics. It is easy to clean and has removable dish-washer safe plates, although I recommend hand washing them in order to prolong the life. I also recommend using butter or oil over non-stick spray because it will eventually cause the non-stick coating to come off of the plates. All in all, this is a great indoor grill and a great value over the more popular brands. I will update my review as far as durability as time goes by.

I have had the pleasure of trying both the Honeywell 12,000 and 10,000 BTU portable air conditioners.  Both were used in bedrooms approximately 12 feet by 12 feet on a second floor.  Both were packaged well.  Both had convenient wheels on bottom to make it easy to move around.  The main units required no assembly.  Both came with the same hose and window brackets to allow the exhaust and heat to escape.The one main problem was how the window brackets fit in the window.  I had to use some extra foam insulation strips to fill in the gaps.  The bracket is in two pieces that slide together in the middle to allow you to use it in different size windows.  One side is more narrow than the other side which allows you to adjust the width for the size of the window.  This means the wider side fits fairly snug in the window and the narrow side has a gap.The hose connection at the rear of the unit can be finicky and wants to disconnect fairly easily.Both units worked like a charm.  Both dropped the temperature of the room rather quickly and kept the room a constant temperature.  The noise of the units were no louder than a typical air conditioner in a hotel room.The 10,000 unit seemed to push more air, but the 12,000 unit seemed to push colder air.  The difference was very minute to me.I would recommend the Honeywell Portable Air Conditioners to anyone.  I'd think they'd work best for people who have rooms that aren't used often or for smaller areas on a temporary basis.

DISCLOSURE: *I received this item at a discount, in exchange for an honest review*I used this screen protector to replace a similar one that I originally purchased from a local brick and mortar store. The old one cost me 4 times more than this one and didn't fit my phone as well, so in that regard, I'm very pleased with this item. It is packaged very well (see my photos in the item's listing) and is made from real glass, not cheap plastic. It includes a wet and a dry cleaning wipe to prepare your screen and remove fingerprints. There is also a "dust removal" sticky tab, but it didn't work well and left a residue, so I discarded it and simply used the included wipes. Instructions are provided, but it seems obvious whoever wrote them is not a native English speaker, as they are unclear at best. Thankfully, attaching these things isn't rocket science. The protector attached easily with virtually no air bubble problems. Another nit pick is that it could have been made a few millimeters wider, in order to extend a bit past the iPhone screen. As it is now, the edges align almost exactly with the display screen, which is fine and also how my old screen protector fit. Final verdict is this is an excellent quality product for the price, good value!

I received the new Fire TV on release day after pre-ordering it. Overall I am very happy with it and would rate it 5 stars, but for one problem. It will not play any of my purchased music, it will only play PRIME albums. When I select an album I own outright, it acts as if it's loading, but then nothing happens and the track timer stays at zero. I've attempted to call support and somehow they hung up on me, so now I've just sent them an e-mail and am awaiting a response. Is anyone else having this problem with their purchased music? If I can get this resolved, I'll upgrade my review to 5 stars for sure. Movies and TV shows play perfectly through my wireless connection, so far no buffering issues as I had with the old Fire TV and my older Apple TV. Picture quality is excellent too.UPDATE! - I finally got through to someone in tech support and they solved my issue. I simply had to clear my data for the Amazon Music app and allow my library to reload. I'm including the instructions below:Perform "clear data" for the Amazon Music app. Here's how:Go to Settings, select Applications and select Amazon Music and then Clear Data.After performing Clear Data, reboot the device. When Music is launched again after the reboot, it will perform a DRM reset (this reset is automatic).

Holy Moly, these went beyond my expectations! The sound quality is great and they pair without problems on my iMac and Audio/Video Receiver. The charge lasts a loooooong time too. Very lightweight and comfortable to wear for long periods. I edit video for a living and use these when I need to balance audio tracks, so I'm often wearing them for hours at a time, with no trouble. Highly recommend over much more expensive units.

Excellent quality, much better than anything I've found locally in stores! Plenty of outlets and nice subdued colored lighting along the edges. I mounted it to the underside of my desk, utilizing the slotted screw holes on the unit. The 4 corner outlets are also a smart touch, good for those plugs with attached voltage transformers.
I've tried other brands of hairball control treats, but my cat by far prefers these and they seem to work wonderfully.

Man, for the price you can't go wrong with this set. To my ears the sound quality is exceptional. My only annoyance is that with multiple albums on each CD, iTunes or your favorite MP3 player, can't recognize individual albums. However, with iTunes in my case, each song was recognized, so I simply separated each album (by looking the tracks up on Google) and created individual listings for each. I also downloaded the album artwork online and now I have each album listed by itself in my iTunes music library. Super deal!

A decent lightweight tripod for your DSLR. It's very versatile with multiple angle adjustments and attachment for your phone and GoPro. I like the quick release snap type adjustments for the leg extensions. The included nylon storage bag is also nice, makes everything very compact and easy to transport. I would say this makes a good travel tripod for vacations, or as a backup for lightweight shooting. If you plan to do nature photography or anything requiring a larger telephoto lens, I would recommend going with something more substantial. In my opinion, this tripod would be too easy to accidentally knock over with a camera and large, heavy lens attached.

This is my 4th Kindle Fire, I also have the first generation, an 8.9” HDX and the new 6”. The first thing that impresses is how thin and light this new model is, despite being the largest Fire to date. I love the more narrow, widescreen design of the screen, perfect for watching videos and reading books in portrait mode. Anyway, before I get carried away gushing, I’ll just list my pros and one or two cons, to make this easier to read and save time.PROS:Wide screen design is perfect for videos and allows more text on a page for books.The stereo speakers sound incredible, even better than the previous HDX modelFor comic book readers; comics purchased from Amazon now utilize the active panel reading mode from Comixology. I was wondering when Amazon was going to incorporate this feature for their comics, finally!Battery life seems to be similar to my 8.9” HDX, but I’m happy with that considering the larger screen and thinness of the device.Considerably faster response time across the board.Finally! We can add a micro SD card to expand storage capacity! Yay!The camera takes photos that are much better quality than previous FireCONS:Would have preferred a rubberized back and case. The glossy finish is a fingerprint magnet also.Still deciding on the new software layout, maybe it’s because I’m so familiar with the old Fire OS, but let’s just say I’m not blown away be the design so far.

I'm a huge fan of Jeffrey Thomas. His writing skills and vivid imagination are second to none and this book is no exception. The dual settings and overlapping storylines are both compelling. I was especially intrigued with the portion of the story that took place in a plastics factory. Why? I don't truly know, but factories and large buildings have always inspired a type of wonder in me. The characters were relatable and felt real, making you concerned for their eventual fates; an absolutely vital ingredient for a horror story to work. The denouement in each parallel tale was satisfying; probably the most difficult part to pull off for any novel, let alone a twofer. The inventiveness of Jeffrey's imagination seems limitless. As long as he keeps writing 'em I'll keep reading 'em.

If I had to attempt a description of this novel's plot, I'd say a Michael Crighton medical thriller, shoehorned into a military action tale. Sounds exciting, but unfortunately the writing leaves much to be desired. As with so many self-published novels, it appears that the author has relied on friends and family to edit and critique their work. There is much telling and very little showing. The action and plot are propelled along swiftly, but everything seems to take place in an undefined world, filled with clichéd characters. I have several writer friends and the good ones share their work in writer's groups. Exposing your work to other writers and seeking out unbiased opinions can be painful, but also highly beneficial. This book reads like a decent first draft, but would benefit greatly from some serious rewriting.

A nice collection of short horror/thriller tales. I love having several collections like this on my Kindle, because the stories are short enough to read while waiting at appointments and such. The kicker with these stories is that they feature twist endings, a'la the Twilight Zone, or more appropriately to this collection, Night Gallery. I'm deducting one star, because it features a story written by Lou Columbus. Who does that guy think he is?
0:44 Mins I received this video message via an old CIA connection and was told to post it here.

From the opening paragraph of this novel, the spell was cast. Told in the first person by protagonist, Bogdan Bogdanov, this unusual story will entertain you and give you much to think about. Bogdan is a cybernetic scientist, a man fascinated with quantum mechanics, but equally fascinated with the human mind and emotions. The tale of his life is told in the past tense and gradually leads us up to the present. We learn that Bogdan was a gifted child who received special advanced schooling. Eventually his knowledge begins to outgrow the parameters established by his teachers and he becomes an outcast among his peers. Feeling dejected he contemplates drastic measures, but soon meets Lucco Mancini, a financial adventurer of questionable ethics. Lucco introduces Bogdan to the stock market and encourages him to develop an automated system for trading. He complies and the two men form a temporary partnership. Eventually Bogdan tires of the relationship, but it inspires him to create his robot mind, which he calls Semmant. Bogdan takes an apartment by himself and begins working on his Semmant. He shares all of his thoughts and feelings with his creation, in the form of letters. Bogdan also becomes involved in relationships with several women along the way. Each of his experiences become new data that he feeds to Semmant, enhancing the robots intelligence, intellectually and emotionally. Eventually, through a series of mishaps and sexual drama, both Bogdan and Semmant begin to breakdown. The book concludes by taking us back to where it began and providing an explanation of how Bogdanov ended up in his current accommodations. Mr. Babenko writes in what I would call a classic style. At times I was reminded of reading the Russian greats, like Dostoevsky and Tolstoy, the language had an almost poetic rhythm to it. In fact, I could well imagine that had one of those gentlemen written a science fiction novel, it might look something like this.

Well, the book starts off with a quote from Rumi, who I very much appreciate as a fountain of useful living advice, so that was a good start. The author takes insights from teachers like Rumi and others who have reflected on human empathy and mutual understanding and created a concrete process to follow. The goals being to not only better understand our fellow human beings, but also eliminate stress, build resilience, release negative feelings and more. The concept being, the root to accomplishing all of this, is by better connecting as humans. What I appreciate about this book and the process, is that it’s not simply about affirmations or uplifting stories. To make this work, you will need to put it into action in your life. There are study questions at the end of the main content, as well as an extensive list of resources. If you are looking for guidance in interpersonal relationships especially, I would recommend this book.

While I appreciate what the author has to say in this book, it was difficult for me to follow. The subject bounced around constantly and from character to character, with almost no narrative thread. Each section read like an unedited blog post, as if the writer was simply trying to get their thoughts down, but never went back and attempted to make everything connect. I did appreciate some of the descriptions of locations and encounters and the uplifting messages of perseverance, but felt as a whole it would benefit from a content editor.

No one could disagree that this is a wonderful little tale, with a positive and hopeful message. The story and illustrations are very simple, so I would recommend for young children who are just beginning to learn reading, or who are lucky enough to have parents read to them. One word about the Kindle version (which is what I purchased), it would not open on the PC Kindle app, but looks wonderful on my Kindle Fire. I'm not sure if that's a limitation of the computer version, or something else. However, I would imagine anyone considering this will most likely be reading from a tablet and not a computer monitor, but just in case. We can certainly use more children's books with a positive message like this one!

I had originally bought the DVD at our local big box store, but when I saw the Blu-ray was the same price, I returned it and ordered the Blu-ray. I don't recall if the DVD version included all the same features, but the Blu-ray has two commentary tracks; one with director, producer and editor and another (technical commentary) with director and cinematographer. There is also a music video included for the song "Silent Night" by Raya Yarbrough.
Nice heavy construction and fits our 2013 Altima 4 door like a glove.

YES! This album is one of my all time favorites and now it's even better. It sounds crystal clear and the live concert DVD features a wonderful performance of many of the songs from the album. Best of all though are the new bonus tracks. These songs are just as good as anything on the original release and I'm thrilled to be able to finally hear them. If you are a fan of Shelby and especially this record, you will want this added to your collection.

This review is for the Norton Critical 150th Anniversary Edition. I've read several other versions, as this is one of my favorite books, and this edition would easily be in my Top editions to own. Despite being a paperback and filled with supplemental material, I was surprised at how compact it is. The annotations and illustrations really add to your reading enjoyment of this classic novel.

This charger has a small footprint, but packs a wallop of power. I keep it on my computer desk and always have plenty of charging ports for my phone, Kindle Reader and Tablet. It saves time not just by consolidating everything into one location, but it also charges things faster, as advertised. Super Deal!

This was a deeply touching story, written in the first person, as the author experienced the events personally. It is a tale of courage, survival, family connections and most of all love. While there are Christian themes mentioned, anyone would enjoy reading HI-DONG CHAI's story and should take something away from it. Despite all the tragedies related in the book, the author incredibly and admirably maintains a hopeful outlook on life. This is simply a plainspoken narrative, detailing one man's personal feelings and losses caused by war. It is an anti-war treatise, but not in a preachy way. It speaks louder than any essay or fictional anti-war novel, because it's honest and true.

Certainly a uniquely personal view of what constitutes engaging photographic composition. Entertaining to read, I appreciate Mr. Mortensen's no nonsense writing style and approach. It has certainly given me food for thought and practice. One note about the book itself; the size is only slightly larger than a typical paperback book and all the photographs are B&W. The size is listed in the description details, but I didn't read them and was surprised when it arrived. Still, glad I got it though.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is a deceiving bag.  It looks small, tidy, and easy to carry.  It's all of those, but it can containing a surprising amount of stuff in it!  It looks good, and for the price, there's really no comparison between this bag and others with a "name brand" on it.  This bag is high quality, stylish, suits a man and woman equally well, and has the feel to it that it will last a long time.Overall, I like this bag a lot, and given the price compared to what you'd find in stores for something comparable, this easily surpasses those as a whole.

I received these bags free of charge in exchange for an honest review.As with most other reviewers as of this posting, I received these garbage bags for free.  From the best I can tell, unlike other reviewers, I actually tried them.  First, they pretty small.  Not many people have this small of a trash bag in their kitchen, unless it's a side trash bag not the main one.  Secondly, they are NOT very strong.  A corner of a cardboard box sliding down to the bottom can, and does, tear them.  Third, they are not tapered or reinforced at the top, and have no drawstring - hence, they do not stay up when any weight (ie, trash) is added (in our bathroom can, which is small enough to make it fair.)Not sure what's going on with others, but our main bags are Costco kitchen bags (13 gallon, so quite a bit bigger), but the quality different between the two is astronomical.  These bags are only useful for very lightweight trash without corners.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Other reviewers are crazy:  these are NOT durable enough for kitchen trash bags.  If you only put in paper, tissues, and nothing of weight, then perhaps, but that's not what most people put into their kitchen garbage cans.  Upon opening these, it was abundantly clear that they would not hold up - and a simple test of putting a small box with corners in it proved the fact - they rip, and they rip easily.I'll be using these in an office trash can where most items are small food wrappers and papers, which is really the only place these should be used.  For that purpose, they're good bags.  As advertised...not a chance.

Got this after seeing on from a friend.  Not particularly useful or interesting from my perspective, but the kids seem to have fun with it - balancing it on its little home stick thing, on their finger, nose, forehead, etc.  I'm not quite sure how long it'll hold anyone's attention, but it's cheap enough so it doesn't need to for very long to be worth it...  All in all, I'm guessing most people will have similar thoughts to me:  "what a ridiculous...'toy.'"  Then again, others have seemed to enjoy it, so maybe I'm in the minority.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is a terribly odd (and cheap feeling) product that, despite it's quirks, works for its purpose.  The product pictures match - mostly - at the top of the device, there's actually a company name that's essentially random letters glued on, and they're not glued on with any precision (or, seemingly, order.)  The box brags of things like "Wrieless" and then, on the side, they figure out how to spell "wireless" but in a context of "Wireless Digital Cord."  I am speechless attempting to determine what a wireless digital cord is, but I'm glad, I think, that's it's not a wired analog cord.As far as function - it seems to work, but it's not anything special.  For the price (around 18 dollars right now), there are other products on the market that do the same thing - you mostly just need to get lucky with a Chinese product like this, or spend more for a name brand product that has a Quality Control department.  It's OK if you're getting to try it out for yourself; I personally wouldn't give this as a gift, however.  (Unless you're both up for a good laugh at the Engrish and quality control...)

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review."The heart has in a big bag, and the outside world is wide, respect for nature, the pursuit of freedom is our pursuit of the true meaning of life, so that our freedom, random, and alive, it is Gerun has always been the pursuit"The above lovely quote (I'm not entirely sure what it means) is embossed on the leather on the front of this pack.  Along with "Gerun," which is the brand name from what I can tell, and "Originalism derived from life."I'm not sure if this is Engrish at it's finest (and again, embossed into leather) or some poor, lonely artist-type describing his thoughts to the world, but it's weird.As far as the rest of the pack is concerned, it's well built, looks nice, roomier than it looks, and is pretty versatile.  For instance, it can have a shoulder strap (single) by attaching it to the back - or, as pictured, you can unzip the back compartment to expose the dual shoulder straps (like traditional backpacks), velcro the back lining to the top, and it converts into what a normal backpack would look like.All in all, it's quite the nice pack, and if you were to compare it to the price of a name brand (jansport, nike, etc) for a comparable size/quality pack, it'd likely be about double the price.  All in all, recommended if you can live with some weird quite embossed into the leather.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Maybe I'm a bit odd here, but it's difficult for me to rate something very high that does an adequate job (no better than the competition), looks nice, but feels somewhat cheap.  So, I'm going to say that this is right about average for the product - it does work (requires a USB port to plug into; you may want to get a USB "power" strip), it charges controllers, lights up, and is mostly good in those regards, but it doesn't do anything better than similar products.  Not great, not horrible...recommended if it's cheaper than the competition.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Spatulas are pretty simple things - they scrape stuff, and are either bendy enough or not.  These ones perform quite well for a variety of tasks.  As far as the looks of them - they look just like the pictures, which don't make it seem like it's an abundance of blue, but it is!  Not bad, but if blue clashes in your kitchen (and if that's the kind of thing you care about), you may want to look elsewhere...  All in all, a good product that works well for a reasonable price. I will mention that I still prefer my other set, whose brand name I don't recall, that has a big spatula on one end and a small one on the other end - 2 spatulas in a single piece!

Not a ton to say about this stuff - it was well packaged so it didn't leak, works well in the Zippo hand warmers, and pretty much does the same job as the Ronsonol lighter fluid for about the same price.  However, this stuff comes in a metal can which I prefer over the plastic Ronsonol.  Good product, just make sure you're looking for lighter fluid and not butane!

Fits my Lumia 640 perfectly, doesn't get any bubbles in it, applies easily...but...it appears that, on mine, there is a tiny defect in it that results in a tiny off-colored circle near the bottom left.  I've applied it multiple times and it's certainly not an air bubble, but that dot is always there.  So, not perfect, but fits well and is better than an air-bubbly plastic protector.

It's a little difficult to say if these are the reason, but taking these in the short term have addressed a consistency issue with some poo.  The pills go down easily and produced no negative side effects, which is obviously good.  All in all, if they did help rather than a timing coincidence, they're great!

I'm torn with this book... On one hand, it's a good story and interesting/witty in parts.  On the other hand, after two chapters in, a 10 year old that was excited about the book originally was completely interested.The author does use some oddly worded sentences at times, and tends to be a bit wordy.  And during an early chapter, the number of times "the boy" and "Rodrigo" were referenced was comically ridiculous.  Oh, and speaking of Rodrigo, he murders another guy like it's second nature by crushing his skull with a large rock.The premise of the book is certainly better than the actual writing of it.  This book didn't get much traction in our family.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Probably the weakest part of this clock/sign/USB hub thingy (yes, it's all of those), is the fact that it has to plug into a USB port.  Presumably, this sits by itself because...well, if it has to plug into a computer, computers already have clocks...and USB ports...  However, we do have a 8-port USB charging station that we have near a night stand that we're able to use; and if you really wanted, you could go with 3 AAA batteries.For the gadget itself - it does it's job pretty well.  It looks nice, but probably nicest when the lights are dim or other.  It does have a bit of a cheap-o look and feel to it otherwise, but once it's setup in its "normal" location, it's an afterthought (like most clock, signs, and USB hubs) but does look nice with a dark backdrop.  All in all, it's an interesting device that performs well.

I received this headlamp free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is an average headlamp given its price.  Entry level with a couple nice things about it that still doesn't push it over the top.  The ability to "zoom" is the selling feature of this, though I was somewhat unimpressed with the results. It certainly works, but zooming in all the way creates a square light - bright, but not as blinding as possible had it focused to a smaller point.  Zooming out creates a large circle of light that adequately brightens a room.  It requires 3 AAA batteries (not included) that keep the unit lightweight.Overall, for the performance and price, it's not a bad buy...but be aware that this is an entry level headlamp with zoom, and not a refined high end headlamp.

I received this headlamp free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is a very bright headlamp.  Because of the overall power of the light, you do have to make other sacrifices, namely in comfort and weight.  Powered by two 18650 batteries, these are the same powerful batteries that power laptops!  They're great batteries and not overtly heavy until themselves, but when you compare them with the size and weight of a couple skimpy AAA batteries, they're certainly bigger.  Secondly, the lamp area itself is metal - quality metal that after being on a while gets a bit warm (goes to show you how powerful the light is.)  And the metal itself isn't as light as cheap plastic of other headlamps, obviously.So what you're getting here is a very bright light, powered by some powerful batteries, and that takes a small toll on the overall comfort.  It's by no means uncomfortable and never slid off my head or anything, but its certainly something to consider.  Having it on for 30+ minutes may be more uncomfortable with modification (adding padding towards the front), and wearing it for over an hour almost necessitates adding some extra comfort.That out of the way, if you're looking for a great light, this is it.  The zoomable portion of it always you to twist the blue light part which brings the light closer and closer to a magnifying glass; at it's sharpest, it produces are square beam of light; zoomed "out" all the way is a large circle of light.  Either one easily light a very large room.All in all, knowing what you're getting with this headlamp is probably most important.  I certainly wouldn't recommend this to anyone that wants to use it to read in bed for an hour each night - too bright and not comfortable.  For folks that need a bright light for safety, for instance, I would highly recommend this light.It's awesome that it comes with 3 charging cables in the box - USB, car cigarette adapter, and AC adapter.  However, the OTHER end of each of those cables is a tiny circular connection.  I would have highly preferred it had it been a standard microUSB cable - those things can do like 2.5amps, so I don't think it would have been difficult to charge the batteries.  But basically, once I lose or the 3 cables are damaged, the headlamp is less valuable.  (Lucky for me, however, I have 18650 battery chargers for my flashlights, so I could charge them independently.)All in all, a great light for a very reasonable price (20 bucks, currently) - the batteries themselves aren't cheap if you buy them separately.

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.I was pretty interested in this watch to give to a kid - it's simple and somewhat creative so that the kids can be "cool" when wearing a watch.  However, the implementation of the watch leaves a lot to be desired.  Most notable is that the digits of the watch itself light up, but they're dim and aren't even solid through their entire length. Overall, it's still an OK watch, but they could've done better - either reduce the price a couple more bucks or made it so the display is vivid enough to see.

I received this flashlight free of charge in exchange for an honest review.I have a lot of flashlights, my favorite of which are the Fenix brands; the Fenix TK35 and Fenix Flashlights TK75 are my go-to flashlights.  But I'm not one to turn down competitors, so I got this one, too!And what we have here is a knock-off flashlight that isn't bad by itself, but when compared to quality flashlights, doesn't get close.  The "List Price" of $129 is a farce; apparently they're attempting to show what a great deal you're getting because the "real" price is $89 - but wait, it's on sale! Now only $35...  I wouldn't spend more than about $25 on this light.It's a poor choice for a gift because it comes with no box, instructions - nothing at all.  Just a flashlight and charger (no battery) in a padded envelope.  The light itself isn't horrible, but also isn't as bright as the lesser rated lumen lights I have.  The zoomability is OK - there's a magnifying glass over the light and twisting the top gets the light closer/further from the glass.  It works-ish, but when zoomed "out," you lose a good amount of luminosity.It's not a horrible flashlight despite what I've mentioned here - and for the price, it may just be a bit overpriced.  However, if you like quality flashlights with varying features, this one isn't going to do much for you.

Great little pocket warmer - classier and probably better for the environment that the disposal pockets, too!  I bought some Ronsonol lighter fluid at a local store (cheaper than buying online), filled this hand warmer up, lit it "on," and its been putting out steady heat with minimal odors for hours now!  The odors, in fact, aren't noticeable at all unless you actually sniff the warmer or cloth pouch it comes in, but why would anyone want to do that?All in all, this is a great hand warmer that's a bit bigger than I had expected...and it works great!

Just got this for a newly purchased Lumia 640 from the online Microsoft Store.  It perfectly, snugly, leaving all the exposed pieces exactly as they should be.  I particularly like the larger buttons on the side (power and volume), which makes it easy to find which side of the phone is which without looking and/or with little light.  All in all, it's a great case that provides reasonable protection.  Recommended!

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.I love the concept of these bug repellent / air fresheners.  Something natural that isn't laden with chemicals for either the scent or the repelling of the bugs.  They seem to work quite well (no bugs near them, but then again, I didn't have a bug infestation prior, either.)  However, they do have an earthy smell that if you're not expecting it and/or don't enjoy it, then these won't do you much good because it's the scent that's doing all the work.  For me, I don't mind putting these in larger, open rooms with a lot of circulation, but I wouldn't put one in a closet with circulation just because the scent doesn't appeal to me that much.  Overall, it's a good product that does what it says it does.

I use hearing protection when working with power tools, which is fairly regularly.  I've always hated earplugs, and thus have used ear muff hearing protection.  My usual ones, Howard Leight 1030110 Sync Noise-Blocking Stereo Earmuff have been great - pretty comfortable, reasonable sounding audio, and, of course, great noise reduction.These 3M one up them in a couple ways.  First, they're wireless (or wired, if you really want to use a wire), so that's a first big plus.  Second, they feel like they're made more for daily use; they're rugged and well built.  However, their strong build does lead to one downfall - they're not quite as comfortable as the Howard Leight - mostly because this 3M set is rather rigid on the head band and doesn't provide much padding there.  I could likely rig something up, but I don't use these often enough to figure that out.  Then again, perhaps they need to "break in" a bit.  The strong band does, however, ensure that the ear muffs stay over your ear and don't like around (exposing your ear) while you're working.Overall, these are quite nice with good audio, very easy bluetooth setup, and a nice set of features (FM radio, easy to use dials/buttons even with gloves on, etc) that make these hearing protectors an excellent product.

Overall:  this is a good product with a terrible product description.Turns out, this is actually the "Shakira" licensed kids toy.  Shakira, as in, the Americanized pop singer from Columbia, if you're not familiar with her.  For the most part, most baby toys are coming with a Spanish option, most likely to save money at the company so they can put out 1 product for all the Americas, rather than 2, one for N America and a different one for Central and South America.  We've been fine with that.However, we don't - and likely aren't - going to be teaching our kid Spanish.  Most toys don't force Spanish on you, but for this toy, Spanish is at the fore front.  If you're aware of that and are actively looking to teach your kid, it's probably a great learning device to do that.  If you want to teach your kids English and then another language...this may not be the best approach.For the flash cards themselves - good quality, same with the bucket.  However, I wouldn't have got these had I known it was Spanish-centric.  Not recommended unless you're raising bi-lingual children.

I didn't realize how small this bowl was before ordering...  it's not large by any means, so if you're a soup fan - and hungry - this cup of soup will need to be a compliment to something else in your meal.  Also, it's not insulated, so you'll need to warm up your small amount of soup, eat it soon after putting it into this cup, or eat it at whatever temperature your room is.While I liked the concept behind this, the small and lack of insulation makes it a poor choice for me when spending an extra 5 bucks will get a metal, highly insulated and bigger Thermos to stow away my hot foods and keep them that way.  Not as pretty, but much more functional.  Only recommended if you're fully aware of what you're getting with this - a small portion of soup that needs to be reheated.

These are cups, and everybody knows how to use them and what's expected of them.  So personally, my thoughts on these are that They're Big, They're Sturdy, and they don't leak and well...can hold a beverage.As for sturdy - you may feel a bit of remorse after throwing them again, because they are very strong disposable cups.  If you're looking for good cups that don't disintegrate after a couple poured drinks, these are the ones to get!

I'm used to my favorite headset, a pair of several-year-old noise cancelling Audio Technica headphones.  Over the years, I've stuck with them because nobody has been able to beat (or even match) the sound quality.  Then again, I hadn't tried V-MODA.These V-MODA headphones sound excellent - very clear sound reproduction and not just a big headphone with a big driver that produces big bass, like many companies decide to make these days.  These certainly have bass, but it's not their only or main goal - the main goal, which is well done, is excellent audio.  The audio is excellent, but they didn't stop there.These are some of the most comfortable headphones I've used as well.  While they advertise and military grade durability and "steel flex" and such, it was a bit concerning that they might be a victim of their own design - durable but uncomfortable.  Again, that's not the case with these; they're big, sound great, and are comfortable to boot!Overall, these are some of the best headphones I've used and likely some of the best on the market.  I never tried using the built in mic because...well, it feels a little odd to talk on the phone with high end headphones and the thought never occurred to me to try.  Great headphones, highly recommended.

Don't get the 3 stars wrong - there's nothing blatantly wrong with this heated throw or anything.  But it's kind of average...  except for the price, which is WAY above average (89 MSRP, selling for about 72 at time of this review.)I've owned a couple heated blankets, throws (and even socks!) before, and they each have their pros and cons.  This one is really middle of the road overall.  The big plus this Serta has over other ones I've tried is how soft is it - others that I have (including the cheap "Sunbeam" or whatever) isn't nearly as soft and at times you don't even want it to touch you.  This one is very different - even if it wasn't heated, it still feels great!However, comparing it to whatever brand that Costco sells each year - well, the Costco one is much larger than this, not quite as soft but is fine by itself, and twenty bucks cheaper.  For my money, this Serta one loses - I can tuck a bigger blanket away if I only want part of me covered, but I can't stretch a small one when I need a big one.  The Costco one also beats this one by how quickly it warms up (very fast.)  However, the Costco one (at least the ones we've had) not only get hot (and hotter than this Serta), but "smell" hot, as in something may be a bit too hot.  It's never given us an issue one we realize that it's just getting very hot and we should probably turn it down anyway...All in all, this is an OK heated throw - if you really want a smallish blanket to cover your shoulders or your lap/legs and you want it very soft and cuddly, this may be what you're after.  If you're going after the most bang for your buck - you might want to shop around or wait until the sales start.Completely unrelated to the product but for some reason Serta thought it was quality marketing material:  what's up with the guy in the product photo's sitting the couch, cup in his hand, the controller for this unit in his other hand.  I'm not sure if his expression is smugly puzzled or modestly inquisitive, but the controls are very simple - press the button to your desired temperature then leave it alone.All in all, another product in a crowded product space that doesn't really do anything differently except cost more.  Good by itself, its weaknesses show when compared to the competition.

I hate to leave a bad review for USA Pans, as this is our 4th baking pan from them (cookie sheet, cake pan, and round pan) that we got because all of the other ones are absolutely the best pans we've ever used.This pan is barely better than the sub 10 dollar pan you can find at a big box store.  Our brownies never slid right out of these.  Our first attempt was no grease, no flour - based on experience with other pans, it was never needed.  We've broiled cheese (somewhat accidentally) onto the cookie sheet and it came off with a damp sponge.  Anyway, our second attempt was oiling each well, which did no better but did leave the brownie bottoms glistening in grease.  Third attempt - grease and flour - and again, we had to dig the brownies out.Perhaps our favorite brownie recipe just isn't well suited for this (brownies from scratch, not out of a box.)  Regardless, my expectations were high based on the perfection of their other pans, and this one by no means lived up to how great the others are.  Not recommended, unfortunately.

I bought these just wanting to be able to make my own rounded eggs to slap on an English Muffin for quick breakfast on the go.  And, they work fairly well.  I found that it works best to slowly put the egg in rather than dumping it quickly (and moving this rather lightweight circle.)  The little wire/arm thing that I think is supposed to be used to pull the gadget up when the egg doesn't need it anymore doesn't have enough rigidity to actually stay up, and routinely falls into the pan and heats up.As a whole, these do the job as intended.  For the price, they're not awful, but I did find that I use a maximum of 2 at a time, and it does slow down egg cooking a bit, but for on the go, it's nice to have everything a standard size instead of following out everywhere.  Recommend, but if you can find some cheaper (or fewer quantity), there's probably not a huge difference between these and any other ones.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.If you're building a scarecrow, these may work.  Or maybe a Halloween costume.  Otherwise...These goggles are small and NOT made for Snow/Ski as the description states.  There is not a comfortable "seal" that rests of your face, instead, it's foam.  Like the foam that used to be on earbud headsets or cheap microphones.  Basically, uncomfortable, not moisture proof, easy to shift around on your head.  But wait, there's more!  The foam is held on with a black tacky substance that almost feels equivalent to the black liner that holds your windshield in place.There's more, still!The goggles look good from a distance, but once you touch them, you can feel they are of very low quality.  And you get to FEEL the low quality on your nose, because the shape of the goggles and the lack of any adequate padding has the cheap plastic rubbing up against your nose when wearing it.I know I mentioned these are small, but I didn't mention that they're adjustable.  They can go from "children's size medium" all the way down to "toddler" if you want.As a whole, I would not recommend these to anyone to actually wear them for any real purposes.  They are extremely low quality, low comfort, and would be best suited for a movie prop that never gets touched.

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.I'll be honest on this one - I've been buying this vinegar (and Bragg salad dressings) for some time.  It's simply the best, highest quality vinegar you can buy, has mother of vinegar in it.  Organic and unfiltered, you can rest assured that this is a high quality food (although I see another reviewer decided to use it as a window cleaner - probably works, but you certainly don't need a high end vinegar like this to do cleaning.)  Apple Cider Vinegar (ACV) has been proven to have numerous health benefiting properties, so if you're looking for a quality vinegar for that purpose, you've found it with Bragg.

I received this item free of change in exchange for an honest review.This is a very good quality bat costume. It's soft, it's warm (except for the legs, of course, as there's no cloth there), it's sturdy...to me, it's really worth the price, especially considering those awful "Halloween stores" that crop up for a month that charge more for very low quality stuff.  As a whole, this is a great costume, both look, construction, and quality.Be sure that you have the rest of the costume ready - this is for the bat suit only (covering the torso) - it does not include any leg coverings or boots!  Recommended costume, looks great.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.The same company that sells this also sells a black version (Women's Vampire Eye Mask Halloween Bat Mask) and what I think is an overall better one, Women's Deluxe Vampire Eye Deluxe Mask Halloween Bat Mask.  While this one is still great quality, fit, and comfort, I prefer the Deluxe one because it looks a bit nicer...  but for this particular one, white just doesn't work.  Unless you're of darker complexion or doing something more creative with these masks than I am, the white just kind of blends in without standing out to really show of what is otherwise a nice looking lacy vampire/bat mask.  As it stands, it's a good quality mask, but I'd certainly check out their other ones first.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.While this mask looks nice and is a bit more "form fitting," for the overall looks, feel and quality, I actually prefer Women's Deluxe Vampire Eye Deluxe Mask Halloween Bat Mask.  This one is a bit more basic, which can be nice still looks great, fits well, and doesn't make your face sweaty (or have a rubber band to dig into your skull), so all in all, it's a good mask.  Personal preference has me liking the other one more, though.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.While giving 5 stars to such a small Halloween mask seems a bit odd to me, it's well deserved with this product.  The product images show exactly what you're going to receive, and it's not hiding any quality concerns.  In fact, the quality of this mask if much better than I expected - this is (or could be, at least) more than a one-and-done mask.  It looks great, and quite frankly, you could wear it to several events and it will hold up extremely well.  And it doesn't make your face sweat, which is an obvious plus.  Recommended.
