I received these free of charge in exchange for an honest review.These are great little bat decorations - they bend at the wings to create "3D" bats for decorating walls, or whatever else you may want to decorate.  They're a shiny gloss black, which looks great and have a couple different sized bats for variety.  The only thing keeping it from being 5 stars for me is that I'm not convinced they'll hold up year-over-year, as they are rather small and it's not yet seen how well the folded wings will hold up to time.  At just around 7 bucks, as long as they last a couple seasons, I'll probably be happy.  All in all, nice looking and good quality decorations!

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.A great variety of exercise bands (basically, great big and strong rubber bands with varying degrees of tension - some need more strength than others to stretch out.)  Color coded to denote the "strength" of each, they come in a nice case and feel good quality - I never had the feeling that any were about to snap no matter how hard I pulled them.  For the price (around 12 bucks), it's a fair price...  for the supposed "list price" of 40 bucks - well, that would be a joke on anyone who bought them for that price.

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.When I ordered this, the product image showed a squeeze tube and not a jar like it does today - and I received the squeeze tube.  That said, I'm running with the assumption that the content is the same but packaging is different.  And if that's the case, the best reason to use this is that it smells great.  OK, that's maybe not the best reason, but it's the first reason that will come to mind.  When using it, you'll notice that it essentially works as an occasional super-charged conditioner, which as a whole, it quite nice.  I, however, am not entirely sold on the ingredients, mostly because they're the same chemicals that are in the vast majority of products today.  It's not a big mark against it as it's par for the course, but a personal preference.On the whole, this is a good product with a great smell, and if you're looking to try something new, I'd recommend giving this a shot!

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.For a kids toy/coin bank, this is a fun way to count the coin savings.  It's not terribly accurate (put a quarter in too slowly, and it'll register as a nickle - and then a quarter, for example.)  It could certainly have used some smarter circuitry and sensors to know what you put in and when you put it in.  Also, putting the coins in isn't as simple as just dropping them in - they do need a fair amount of force to put them into the bank.The negatives aside, as long as you're not using this to actually count coin totals with utmost of accuracy, this is a fun way to get kids to save up their change.  The display is big enough, it works well as long as you put the coin in quickly, and the coins remain visible - something that kids like to see.  All in all, I was torn between 3 and 4 stars - and went the high route because one you figure out its limitations, you can work around them.  Recommended for kids.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is a great pruner!  I have two other pruners - a cheap pruner, and one of the world-renowned Felco F-2 Classic Manual Hand Pruner.  They both do their jobs well (the Felco doing it better than the cheap one, naturally) - but they are really designed for somewhat lighter duty.  This Gardenite ratcheting pruner helps to hold the larger branches in place and not squeeze the life out of the branch, pruner, and your hand in one swoop - but most notably (to me, at least) is the ease of cutting through branches larger than 1", where the Felco ones like to max out at.All in all, I'll keep using these ones for larger jobs, and my Felco ones for smaller ones - and I'd recommend doing something similar, as they do solve two different needs.  Recommended!

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is excellent shampoo and conditioner!  Of the various Luseta shampoo/conditioner varieties that we've tried (3-4 total), this one has the best scent and leave hair very soft and lighter feeling.  While I wish some of the ingredients were a bit more natural, that's not what the product portends to be...  However, given this versus any other similar product, this stuff wins for us for a few reasons.  First, the scent is great and not overpowering.  Second, it works very well.  And third, while it may seem a bit more expensive than more mainstream products, you're getting a lot of product in these bottles!  Overall, I recommend this shampoo and conditioner (as well as other Luseta products!)

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Luseta knows how to create some great hair products!  We've also tried their similar shampoo and conditioner combination, Luseta Argan Oil Moisture & Repair Shampoo Shampoo & Conditioner, which like this Keratin shampoo and conditioner smells great and leaves hair soft and feeling airy and lightweight.For us, using these products on a variety of people and hair types (kids, adults, "ethnic" hair, etc), we didn't notice a ton of difference between the two products (except the scent.)  Then again, we don't really have "damaged" hair, and were simply expecting clean, soft, full and manageable hair - which is exactly what we got!  My biggest/only negative towards this is that we generally prefer products that we eat or use on our body to be sourced by as few ingredients as possible, and as many of the ingredients to be natural.  This Luseta product certainly doesn't fall into that category, but doesn't claim to...and works well.  Overall, a great product.

I'm not quite sure if I'd want my young son reading this by himself due to some violence and such...  But on the other hand, I'm not sure if he'd make it far enough to actually be concerned with.My son made it through a couple (maybe three) chapters in this book before he realized that nothing was happening and he lost interest and found a different book.  I figured I should read it, and felt the same way - for almost half of the book.  For the first half of the book, chapter and chapter is basically telling the same stuff about the main character in different ways, and trying to set up some excitement for when something does happen.  It just takes a long time to actually get there.The rest of the story gets better, but even when (small spoiler here.......) ...even when the ship gets "lost," it takes way too many chapters explaining what's going on rather than something driving the action and story.  While some parts of the story were quite interesting, others were repetitive.  As far are overall writing - the character development wasn't great, but sufficient for books for younger kids.  Combing the lack of character development with violence seemed like an odd choice.Overall, not a bad story and book, but not a great one either.

A potential ground breaking say to for solo practicing!  Tracking shots is nice (and has around 80% accuracy in our outdoor court), and the vocal feedback is good as well...  However, this ball is very much designed for solo practice, who h requires motivation from the person, obviously.The ball itself is great - feels just like a high quality regulation ball.  All in all, this seems to be the next line of personal, targeted training in sports.  Do know that the "connected" functionality is designed for only shot accuracy for a single person...other aspects of your game will need to be practiced independently - with or without this particular ball.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Tried using this on some straight, boring hair as well as on ethnic hair, and it works great on both.  Hair is left feeling much software and easier to work with without a gross greasy feeling.  For ethnic hair (and lots of it), the dropper cap makes the work go a bit slow, but as a whole, a little of this oil goes a long way, so it's better to have the dropper cap than just an open cap that could spill (or routinely give too much.)  All in all, a great feeling hair treatment that works well as a conditioner.  Recommended.

I received this product heavily discounted (roughly half price) in exchange for an honest review.I always balked at buying expensive screw extractors because I had no idea if they'd work.  Instead, I'd get a powerful drill and strong drill bit, and drill the existing screw to shreds...which certainly does work in many cases.  However, this is a safer and easier approach:  drill an extractor into the damaged screw and unscrew it!  Works great!While it does work (and pretty well), I will say that I had a lot more success on larger screws than smaller ones - this comes with 4 sizes, but small screws were more difficult to try to drill into and catch with an extractor.  Overall, it was a success, and if you have screws that need removing, I'd recommend getting this!

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.First impression - and judging a book by its cover - is this is going to be some good shampoo and conditioner.  I don't know why, but just the bottles themselves appeal to me...maybe the color.  But that's unimportant - what IS important is the fact that this is some good shampoo and conditioner.  The shampoo lathers and cleans well without feeling like it's stripping hair of everything; the conditioner makes hair very soft and fluffy feeling.  And both of them smell very nice - not overpowering, just a subtle, pleasant scent.All in all, this is great shampoo and conditioner.  While it's not exactly "natural" in any way (that is, the ingredients are mostly what you'll find in other similar products, and not things that are easy to pronounce or even know what they heck they are - they certainly aren't minimally processed things growing in nature.)  However, it's difficult to find a product like that, and this shampoo/condition does a good job; overall, I'd recommend this shampoo/conditioner combo!

It only took a few tries before our 11 month old figured this out and be able to get his own liquid when he wants it.  We're using these to move away from the sippy cups or cups with nipples (artificial, of course) on them...and these have been successful so far.  Still not quite as exciting as getting "mom's juice," but this should be a good stepping stone to start the weaning process.All in all, a quality cup that works well and that, luckily, the straw isn't completely lost on the first day of use.

As far as flavor goes, this is pretty good tea.  It's not as strong as I'd hope (sometimes I use two bags; sometimes I let it steep for an hour or so in an insulated car mug to get it stronger), but the flavor is still nice.  For a box of organic tea, it's a large quantity for the price, which makes it worthwhile to buy it in bulk here.It does have some problems.  When pouring hot water onto the box, with some bags lose A LOT of their insides, and you end up with all the green tea and mint making some murky water floating on top.  Sometimes the string isn't fully fastened and it pulls out all the way...  and even better, sometimes the staple that closes the bag and holds the string didn't go through all the way.  As far as the "tea delivery" system goes, this stuff pretty much fails - there's another tea brand that doesn't use strings, tags, or staples, which is way better than this.  Yogi tea uses a string and tag, but no staple, which is a little better.  This way (bag with staple, string, and tag) is probably the worst method that's still being used.For the tea, it's great and recommended.  As far as bag setup...it's horrible, but until someone else offers an organic mint green tea in bulk, I'll keep buying this stuff.

While this is a decent little carrier, it certainly not without its share of issues.  The biggest one for us is that it's a 2-person job to actually get it on - so for the stay-at-home mom, the idea of heading to the store with your little one and walking around hands free is rather hindered by the fact that it's incredibly difficult to get this one with only one person.Once it is on and the kid is in, it's pretty comfortable and the baby doesn't seems to enjoy it, but it feels like it could use a bit more support where the kids' butt is - something that could latch around a chest to keep the child from sinking into the weight of its own rear end.  Outside of that, we like this carrier and it works well when both parents are around to help each other out.  Compared to others for children this size, this is one that we prefer - but are looking forward to the days that we can use more of a back-pack carrier rather than a big wrap like this.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is a very sturdy and solid practice balisong; it's "blade" is for practicing only (not sharpened at all), and while it could still hurt a bit if it slams into your knuckles or hand, at least you won't be drawing blood.  The locking mechanism for when the knife is folded/closed is strong, and overall, the knife looks great and works well for practicing with these types of knives.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is a great looking Roman costume helmet.  Finding something like this in one of those temporary Halloween stores and of the same quality would not only be difficult, but would also be much more expensive than this.  This helmet looks good, doesn't get your face all hot and steamy from having it on, has quality construction, and for the price, is a great deal for a costume.  Recommended!

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Many times, pictures of items look a lot better than the actual item.  That's not the case with this Crusader Helmet.  It looks great, is very good quality and durable enough to last a long time, and is a fraction of the cost that you'd find something like this for at a seasonal costume or Halloween store.  All in all, it looks good, doesn't get horribly steamy and hot when wearing it, and is a great value.  Recommended!

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest review.Ignore the overzealous claims of how multi-purpose this tool will be for you:  yes, you could take it camping, you could do some gardening with it, and if you had enough spare time - likely measured in weeks - you could dig a trench with it.  What you REALLY are getting this this portable shovel is a very convenient and portable shovel that's great to keep in a car or emergency pack for on the go.The shovel head is small and mostly flat - it's certainly not a big digging shovel.  The handle is two pieces that screw together to make it a little easier to get leverage, but still - if you have to use it more than a few minutes outside of an emergency situation, your body is going to hate you for all the effort expended to move very little dirt.If you treat it as it is - a small portable shovel, then it's a good buy and a handy thing to have.  If you buy into the marketing of how many various uses it will have in your daily life, you're likely to be disappointed.  For the former, I'd recommend this shovel.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.As an emergency shovel, this will certainly do the job - once or twice.  The shovel is quite small, but would certainly be helpful in cases that nothing else is available.  The handle actually separates (unscrews) to become easier to store - which is the first problem.  Not that screwing a handle to make it longer is a big deal, but the threads on the screw had signs of corrosion/rust on them out of the package - before I'd ever used it.  I'm guessing if this is getting wet (or I'm trying to free a car from a recently salted icy road, for example), rust is going to set in pretty quickly.Also, given the side of the handle (short) and shape of the blade (mostly flat), this really should be considered an emergency shovel to stow away in a car - in which case, the unit is a great fit and a good price.  However, the whole "Camping hiking backpacking gardening tactical army..." multi use function is vastly overstated.  If you're camping with this and using it, it's not going to last long unless you apply anti corrosion to all exposed metal - AND you're not going to be gardening with it because the size of it wouldn't work well for a shovel for more than a couple minutes - and the shape doesn't lend itself to being used as a trowel.All in all, it's an inexpensive shovel that I'd certainly recommend for part of an emergency kit - but not for everyday use, or even extended use for camping/backpacking.

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.This is one of the weirdest things I've got from Amazon.  I'm not quite sure if I should wear it on Halloween or Thanksgiving...or both.  It does look pretty nice and is good quality (though I haven't tried - and probably won't try - washing it to see how it holds up.)  All in all, it's a nice hat-type apparatus (not quite sure what to call this), but a couple minor issues.  First, I think the color could have been slightly darker, and second, if you have a big head, this won't be comfortable for long periods.  It's not too small, but snug and can get warm pretty quickly.If you can figure out when to wear this, then I'd recommend picking it up - good quality given the reasonable price!

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.When you go into various season costume shops, you're pretty much assured the cheapest of quality for the highest of price.  And that's why I recommend this.  The quality is great on this, both in the materials and the fact that it will last more than a single occasion, as well as the overall looks of it.  To go along with that, the price is probably half of what you'll find in a Halloween or such store.Looks good, fits nicely, and a very fair price.  Recommended!

I tried both the beef and the turkey honey brown sugar varieties.  The beef is certainly better, but not without its share of flaws.  The texture is like a drier version of a Slim Jim, while the flavor is a bit more natural beef stick (pepperoni) flavor.  The smoke flavor is lacking, the spice is lacking, and the overall flavor is somewhat underwhelming.The turkey one is rather unpleasant.  It's outer coating is a bit slimier with a rancid-sweet flavor to it that overwhelms any hint of actual mean.  It's not as squishy or "creamy" inside as other non-beef style meat sticks, but it's not very good if you're used to a beef stick and have to settle for a lesser meat.All in all, these are par for the course of mass distributed meat sticks, which is to say far below the standards set by independents - but still useful was a quick bite to eat.  For me, I'll stick with a local meat market's landjäger for a more natural solution to being shelf stable and overall flavor and texture.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest review.These are attractive little Santa hooks - iron hooks screwed onto what I believe is a ceramic painted cartoony Santa.  While the hooks are probably not sufficient to hold up a Christmas stocking (at least not one of ours - heavy!), they can easily hold up any raincoats or jackets, hats, etc.  They look pretty festive (we'll put them back up once we're closer to the holiday - it's still early October!)Depending on what you intend to hang from this (anything over a couple pounds is probably out), these work as an attractive set of wall hooks and are reasonably priced (currently just under 10 dollars.)

Great towels - larger than other kitchen towels I've purchased in various stores, too!  Even bigger than my current favorite kitchen towels, All-Clad Textiles 100-Percent Cotton Solid Kitchen Towel...and while they're not quite as absorbent, for the price, I'd probably spring for these given my pay grade.The pattern on these is very vivid and looks great - on one side; the other side didn't really get the pattern, so it's "behind the red lines" view of the world.  However, for what they are, what they do (and do it well), and the price, I like these towels quite a bit.  Recommended.

I received this free of charge in exchange for an honest review.For the price and function of this mop holder, you can't really go wrong.  Each of the holding areas is adjustable (that is, it moves left to right and can grab onto handles of varying girth), so all but the most oddball uses will be covered here.  The biggest negative I've seen so far with this is that the holders feel like hard/cheap/brittle plastic, but even with that, it's never failed so it's not that big of deal.Nice holder...recommended.

A grisly discovery at the local dump has the little town of Himmarshee on edge.  Bad enough the poor girl was murdered, but that bondage getup she was wearing has the whole town gossiping (which is something of a pastime in Himmarshee, even during the best of times).This time around Mace Bauer has no intention of getting involved in the investigation.  Mace is working on another kind of investigation – the kind where a cheating husband has her sister feeling heartbroken.  But what if the two things are connected?  Just what the heck is going on these days in sleepy little Himmarshee!This series takes place in the kind of small Florida town that sadly seems headed for extinction.  Light years away from gaudy theme parks and tourist attractions, Himmarshee is a small ranching community.  Mace, her two sisters and their Mama are native Floridians, and proud of it.  I like “cozy” mysteries set in small towns and this one doesn’t disappoint.  There’s a unique sense of place and the characters are simply charming, especially the eponymous ‘Mama’.  The dialog is sharp and witty and I enjoy the banter that goes on between the main characters.  Most of all I appreciate the underlying themes of family, sisterhood and strong women who fiercely look out for each other.The mystery was fairly interesting, though in typical “cozy” fashion it requires that you suspend disbelief.  The side story about Mace’s sister and her marital woes was handled really well – a little humor, but no so much that the infidelity was trivialized.  Overall I think this was a good addition to the series and I hope the author plans to write future installments.Occasional strong language.  While there’s no explicit sexual content, there are some “adult” situations.The series, in order:*Mama Does Time (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Rides Shotgun (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Gets Hitched (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Sees Stars (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Gets Trashed (A Mace Bauer Mystery)

In this fourth series installment the Little Detective Agency (Bernie and his canine partner Chet) are searching for a boy that’s gone missing after an overnight camping trip.  With Bernie’s smarts and Chet’s nose this case should be solved in no time, right?  Well, not exactly.  Things get complicated, and Chet’s got to do a little independent thinking (not his specialty).If you’re not familiar with this series, Bernie Little is a slightly down-on-his-luck private detective and Chet – a self-described “hundred pounder” – is his partner.  Chet (aka “Chet the Jet”) narrates the story, and therein lies the charm of this series.  Chet doesn’t magically solve crimes on his own, we get his interpretation of what’s going on and that’s often pretty hilarious.The mystery itself is well thought out, though the “bad guys” would be right at home in your typical “made-for-TV” movie.  The best characterization is saved for Bernie and Chet, which is fine by me.  The plot moves along at a nice clip (like Chet himself!), and the dialog is nicely done.  This is not edge-of-your-seat suspense, but there’s enough going on here to keep a mystery reader engaged and entertained.Do I read these stories for the mystery?  Not really.  I read these books because Chet’s narrative is charming and clever and, as a lifelong dog lover, it rings true to me.  Ever wonder what your dog is thinking?  Apparently Spencer Quinn knows.  The mutual respect and love that Chet and Bernie share is heartwarming and reading one of these stories always leaves me feeling just a little bit better about life in general.I don’t recall much in the way of swearing or strong language and there’s no sexual content.

I read a lot of “cozy” mysteries and thought the premise of this one sounded good.  We have a young widow (Bella Jordan) and her 5 year old son who find themselves in the charming, albeit somewhat odd, town of Lily Dale, New York.  The tiny town is home to psychics and mediums and during the summer season it’s also a tourist magnet.  Bella arrives in Lily Dale shortly after the death of a woman who owned and operated a small Bed and Breakfast.  Bella agrees to take over the helm in the short term; just until the woman’s heir can find a replacement.  Strange happenings ensue, and Bella becomes embroiled in a murder mystery.While this one had all the right ingredients – a down on her luck heroine, unique locale, and quirky characters – it fell kind of flat for me.  While the writing is technically competent, the Third Person present tense wasn’t a wise choice in my opinion.  It kept me from feeling any connection to Bella and left me feeling annoyed with her repetitive inner dialog.  I felt bored for long stretches of the storyline as Bella was pretty much stalled in a state of grief (completely, 100% understandable but it doesn’t make for entertaining reading).  The potential (future) love interests are rather unceremoniously dumped into the plot and I can already see the makings of a protracted “love triangle” that will no doubt be a running theme as the series continues.While this story didn’t really work for me, it does have some great things going for it.  I think the town of Lily Dale has a lot of potential for further series installments – it’s a fantastic location and the author does a good job of bringing it to life.  Using a Bed & Breakfast as a setting allows for lots of interesting plot and character variations, and I’m assuming Bella’s grief will be downplayed and the focus will be more on her “fresh start” in Lily Dale.Bottom Line:  A “cozy” with a unique setting, but it’s definitely not breaking any new ground.  It was OK, but didn’t pique my interest enough to make me want to read any future installments.I don’t recall much in the way of strong language/swearing and there’s no sexual content.

The premise of this story is that two complete strangers, Richard and Elizabeth, are offered one million dollars to do nothing more than spend two hours a week together for one full year.  They don’t know anything about the person making the offer – the whole transaction is handled by an attorney – nor do they have any idea why the offer is being made.Richard is a 29 year old wanna be movie producer who is dead broke and barely scraping by; Elizabeth is a thirty-something attorney whose life revolves around work (and little else).  Neither one can pass up the opportunity to split a million bucks, so they agree to the proposal.  If you think you know what happens next you’re probably  right, though there are some interesting twists to the story.I’m a little torn on this one.  I like the author’s writing style – it’s very engaging and witty and he has a keen eye for characterization.  The dialog comes off as effortless (and you know that takes some work!).  I am also struck by how the city of Los Angeles becomes a character in its own right; he does an excellent job of bringing the city to life. So that’s the “good”…now for the not-so-good:I never warmed up to the main characters, particularly the man-boy Richard.  Richard is the type of guy that will be described as “boyish” when he’s 45.  It’s mentioned about two dozen times that he’s extremely good-looking.  In fact, his physical beauty is dwelled on so much that I started to get annoyed.  I get it – he’s gorgeous (even by L. A. standards).  Got it.  Check.  Can we move on already?  Elizabeth is slightly more relatable, though she remains somewhat wooden throughout most of the story.The story itself was…fine.  It’s pure fantasy but I was intrigued by the “mysterious benefactor” and the motivation behind the offer, and that kept me turning the pages.  I’m not sorry I read this one, but it’s not a story that I’ve thought about since reaching “The End”.Occasional swearing/strong language; no sexual content.

I have to say that appearance-wise this is your basic, nondescript, black carry-on bag.  It is however extremely well put together and made to last.  The nylon material is sturdy and the zippers are heavy duty (though they glide easily).  The bag zips open to one main compartment with a hard shell bottom.  There’s a smallish interior zip compartment with Tumi’s ‘ID Lock’ to protect encoded data on your credits cards, etc.  There’s also an exterior zip pocket, removable shoulder strap and combination lock.I like the size of this bag – it’s not too large for an overnight trip but I can also easily pack enough for 2-3 days if I need to.  While there’s no doubt that this is a quality item, I confess the price (currently over $300) is a bit of a shock.  It is a nice piece as long as you don’t find the price prohibitive.

I like to use  toner as part of my evening skin care routine; it ensures that my cleanser has done its job and no traces of make-up have been left behind.  This toner is alcohol-free, non-drying and pleasant to use.  There’s a subtle fragrance – nothing overpowering – and it leaves my skin feeling soft.  There is no residual “sticky” feeling and I’m able to apply my night cream within a minute or two.  I’ve experienced no irritation, redness or breakouts.  My skin type is normal with a slightly oily t-zone and this product does not leave my skin with that tight, dry feeling.While I like this product very much, I’d pause before spending $18 (current price) on a toner.  It’s not that I think the price is outrageous (it falls in the mid-range), but toner is just not one of those skin care items that I’m likely to splurge on.  I have purchased alcohol-free toners for half this price and been happy with the results.  In the end it all depends on your beauty budget – it’s a nice product and if you’re not on a tight budget then definitely give it a try.

I have “normal” skin with a slightly oily t-zone, and this cleanser works very well for me.  You need only a tiny amount – less than pea-sized – to work up a creamy lather on your face and neck.  It rinses easily and leaves my face with that squeaky-clean feeling that I love but without that tight, dry feeling that I can definitely do without.  The product has a very light, barely-there fragrance that I find pleasant (it doesn’t linger once you’ve rinsed your face).  I’ve experienced no redness, irritation, dryness or breakouts.There’s nothing too impressive about the ingredient list – pretty much what you find in most mid-range cleansers.  Since you need to use so little of the product, the 4.2 oz. size should last quite a while.  I would consider purchasing this item again.

“…but somewhere in my twenties I feel like I got stalled in the process and now I’m drifting, marking time without any great passion to move forward.” – Page 227Oh Stephanie, how insightful of you!  You have been stalled.  When I first met you in 1994’s “One for the Money” you were a 30-something single woman who barely scraped by on the money she earned as the world’s most inept bounty hunter.  Now here we are, over 20 years later and you’re still in your 30’s, still in over your head in a job that you have no qualifications for and still waffling between the two men in your life.  But I won’t judge – if I had been given the opportunity to stay in my 30’s forever I can’t say I wouldn’t have jumped on it (and Joe too, while I was at it!)While I found the early Plum books to be fresh and funny with a blue collar heroine that I was happy to root for, I now only read the books out of nostalgia.  The plots are recycled and the characters have grown stale.  I just finished this book and couldn’t tell you what it was about; I’ve already forgotten the details.  Something about Ranger and polonium and a trip to Atlantic City.  Joe gets jealous, Grandma Mazur goes to a funeral, Lula is busting out of her spandex and a couple of cars get trashed.  You know the drill.I won’t even try to tell you that this is a “good” book, but I still enjoyed it.  Why?  Because even recycled Plum is good for a laugh, and because every time I pick up one of these books I’m immediately transported back in time to the 1990’s and I remember how delighted I was to find a heroine that I could totally relate to.If you’re new to the series then book #21 is not where you want to start.  Do yourself a huge favor and start with book #1 – the early books are wonderful.  There’s some swearing and strong language with adult situations (though no explicit sexual content).

The allure of a BB cream is that (in theory) it’s a beauty multi-tasker, combining foundation, moisturizer and sunscreen in one product.  In reality I have yet to find one that does all three things well, though this Vichy Idealia BB cream comes darned close.This product can be worn over your moisturizer or on clean, bare skin.  Its primary purpose is to provide UVA/UVB protection (SPF 25) along with sheer coverage.  So, the big question is…will it replace your moisturizer and foundation?  The answer is a definite “maybe” – it all depends on your skin type and how much coverage you’re looking for.My skin type is normal with a tendency to be a bit oily in the t-zone.  This product provides enough moisture for my skin (but keep in mind that my skin is not dry).  The coverage is sheer – this is not going to conceal any significant discolorations or skin imperfections, though it will warm up your complexion and even out the skin tone.  It has a very moist, dewy finish – a little too “dewy” for my oil-prone t-zone, but a little bit of pressed powder fixed that.  It has a very light scent and has the same consistency as foundation make-up.  It smooths on easily and blends in well.My thoughts:I do like this product and find that it’s perfect for days when I’m going to be outdoors a lot and need dependable sun protection.  The dewy finish leaves my skin looking a bit too shiny so I need to use a touch of powder (though drier skin types probably won’t have that issue).  It’s non-irritating and feels light on my skin.  While it’s supposed to work for all skin types, I’d recommend that those with oily or acne-prone complexions proceed with caution – that dewy finish may not be what you’re looking for.Active sunscreen ingredients:*Homosalate*Octisalate*Octocrylene*Titanium Dioxide

These earrings are really very pretty in person, however they are not as “sparkly” as pictured on the product page.  The stone is cut so that a lot of the surface is flat, and they don’t reflect light in a way that creates a lot of sparkle.  That said, they are a lovely deep purple color and large enough to be noticed (these are not teeny-tiny stud earrings).The earrings are lightweight and don’t feel heavy on my earlobe.  They fit nice and snug – comfortable but secure.  The two-tone setting is versatile; these pair nicely with either yellow or white gold jewelry.Bottom Line:  For under $35 (current price) you get a lot of bang for your buck.  I like these a lot and think they’d make a lovely gift (and they’re boxed nicely).  The lack of sparkle is a bit of a disappointment, hence the 4-star rating.

A movie crew filming a Western has descended on Himmarshee and Mace is in charge of the horses.  While Mace sees this as an opportunity to earn a few extra bucks, Mama sees this as her big break - finally, a shot at stardom (not)!  But the movie is plagued with problems, not the least of which is the murder of the executive producer.  The man was so widely disliked that the question isn't "who had a reason to kill Norman Sydney?" but rather "who DIDN'T have a reason to kill him?"This book was a lot of fun!  The usual crew is on board - Mace and Mama, sisters Maddie and Marty, and Mace's on again/off again love interest, Carlos.  In addition to the "usual suspects", there's the Hollywood contingent:  a drugged out starlet, a gorgeous actress, an aging leading man and assorted other eccentric characters.  There are plenty of suspects to go around; more than enough to keep an armchair sleuth on their toes.  But the real fun is all the bickering/bantering going on between Mama and "her girls" - I enjoy the way the author keeps the dialog fresh, funny and engaging.  There's also a great sense of place - small town Himmarshee comes to life in all its humid glory.This is the fourth book in the series and I've enjoyed them all very much.  I do have one small gripe though...enough with Mace and Carlos already!  Jeez, these two act like they're in 9th grade and their "on again/off again" relationship is getting stale.  Reading about those two and their complete inability to communicate like adults was the one sour note in the book for me.  I sure as heck hope they gain some maturity by book five!Very little (if any) strong language and no explicit sexual content.  This is book four in the series and while it does work as a standalone novel I'd strongly recommend that you start the series at book one.The series, in order:*Mama Does Time (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Rides Shotgun (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Gets Hitched (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Sees Stars (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Gets Trashed (A Mace Bauer Mystery)

This 7th installment in the series kicks off with a grisly discovery:  the body of a man is found in the woods on the outskirts of St. Denis, and the cause of death is far from "natural".  Complicating the investigation is the return of Sami, a young man from St. Denis who had become entangled with Islamic extremists and is thought to have ties with known terrorist groups.  Is Sami just an unwitting pawn that was exploited because of his uncanny talent with electronics or is there something more going on....Where to start with this one?  Let's start with the good stuff first.  I found the central plot very compelling.  Sami is an autistic young man who spent a good chunk of his childhood in St. Denis.  Bruno feels that he knows Sami, and yet do we ever really know what another human being is capable of?  I like the way the author explored that issue.  There's also a storyline involving a bequest made to St. Denis by wealthy siblings who escaped capture by the Nazis when they were sheltered by a local farmer and his wife.  This was a touching story based on real-life events and I found it very moving.This book had more of a Spy/Action Thriller feel than the previous books in the series and I'm not sure that I'm 100% on board for that.  I like the "Bruno" series because of the underlying themes of community and loyalty; I like the portrayal of Bruno as a small town policeman with an innate sense of justice whose approach to law enforcement is colored by common sense, decency and respect for the people of his community.  In this book we see Bruno as something of a superhero, a Ramboesque action figure if you will.  I wasn't thrilled with that, and frankly the ending of this story devolved into a kind of B-Movie action sequence that had me rolling my eyes.I'm a little torn on this one.  The story was compelling and well written, but I missed the down-to-earth Bruno from the previous novels.  Part of the appeal of this series for me is the charming portrayal of small town life, and that was mostly missing from this novel.  Then again, I did find this to be a page-turner, so it would be unfair to say the book was just "OK" simply because it departed from the formula a bit.  Hmmm....it's precarious sitting up here on this fence!  I'll call this a 3.5 rounded up to 4 for Amazon.Occasional strong language, some descriptive violence, no explicit sexual content.  This is book 7 in a series and I'd strongly recommend that you start with book one,Bruno, Chief of Police: A Novel of the French Countryside .

I really like this modern take on the classic wooden spoon.  The silicone handle is textured for a solid non-slip grip and is somewhat heat resistant.  I like to use red as an accent color in my kitchen so the pop of color on the handle is a plus for me.The spoon measures approx. 14” and has a solid feel without being heavy.  It’s a nice multi-purpose utensil and I’m getting plenty of use out of it.  I’m interested in checking out some more from this Rick Bayless collection – I like the look and the quality.*Dishwasher safe

I’m a sucker for “cozy” mysteries set in the south.  An old plantation in Cajun country that’s been turned into a Bed & Breakfast?  A small town populated with quirky characters?  Yep, you can count me in!  While “Plantation Shudders” wasn’t an unequivocal hit for me, there was a lot that I liked about the story and I think this series has plenty of potential.Thirty-something Maggie Crozat is at loose ends.  Broken-hearted (as well as just plain broke!) she left New York and returned home to Pelican, Louisiana.  Working as a plantation tour guide and helping out in the family owned Bed & Breakfast helps pay the bills while she figures out what to do next.  With finances being somewhat precarious, Maggie and her parents are thrilled when the B & B is booked solid for and end-of-summer food festival.  Unfortunately, the thrill is gone all too soon when two guests die under suspicious circumstances, and Maggie hopes to save the family business by finding out whodunit.I thought the author did a good job of creating a sense of place – I could easily picture the plantation house as well as the town of Pelican.  I didn’t particularly warm up to the character of Maggie, and I’m not sure why.  It could be that she seemed more like a twenty-something who is still trying to decide what they want to be when they grow up than a woman in her thirties.  I liked the character of Maggie’s grandmother, who provided comic relief.  The stereotypical bumbling small town cops and the buffoonish chief of police were disappointing (yawn) and I would like to have seen something more imaginative.  The love interest felt forced and contrived – everything fell into place too easily.The mystery was standard “cozy” fare:  lots of suspects and plenty of convenient coincidences.  I think the suspect list should have been pruned down a bit – I felt like there was a cast of thousands!Despite all my picayune complaints, I did actually like this story.  The writing is smooth and professional and the author has set the scene for an enjoyable “cozy” series.  The B & B offers endless plot possibilities and Pelican sounds like a charming little place.  The first book in a series can be tricky – you get a whole cast full of characters thrown at you all at once and it can be hard to get a feel for any of them.  If there’s a second book I’d definitely be willing to give it a chance.

This toothpaste more or less covers all the bases:  anti-cavity, freshens breath, etc.  I feel pretty neutral about it – it gets the job done but nothing about it makes it stand out from other toothpastes as far as I’m concerned.  I do like that the flavor is not overly sweet and that the texture is not unpleasantly gritty.This toothpaste does contain triclosan which seems to be somewhat controversial but apparently has been shown to reduce gingivitis.  I did use up the entire tube but wouldn’t go out of my way to purchase it again.

I’ve tried Burt’s Bees products before, but this skin care trio is the first time I’ve used the products consistently.  I’m really impressed with the quality of this skin care line, especially given its affordable price tag.  I’m middle-aged and my skin is “normal” with a tendency to be a bit oilier in the t-zone.  Here are my thoughts on each product:Deep Cleansing Cream:  Love this stuff!  This is a true “cream”, and a dime-size amount is enough to cleanse your face and neck – a little goes a long way.  It does not produce a lather, but it does a thorough job of cleansing your skin, including removing make-up.  It’s got a bit of a menthol type smell but it’s not overpowering.  It doesn’t leave my skin with that tight, overly dry feeling – just soft and clean.  It’s 100% natural and I didn’t experience any redness or irritation.Towelettes:  Not impressed.  These don’t do a great job of removing make-up; even my non-waterproof mascara doesn’t budge.  These are probably best just to refresh your skin in a pinch after a work-out, or they might be OK for those who don’t wear make-up.  On the plus size they are super gentle and non-irritating.Daily Moisturizing Cream:  This product is perfect for my skin.  Just simple, lightweight moisture that absorbs right in with no sticky feeling.  Works great under make-up and is 100% Fragrance Free.The only thing that stops this skin care trio from being 5 stars for me is the towelettes, which were a bit of a disappointment.  The cleanser and the moisturizer are products that I will purchase again.

This conditioner turned out to be a pleasant surprise.  It’s very thick and rich-textured but it rinses clean and doesn’t weigh your hair down at all.  I use a little over a tablespoon on my long(ish) hair, applied from mid-shaft to the ends (I don’t need conditioning at the roots).  It leaves my color-treated hair tangle free and lightly moisturized and my hair has plenty of volume when I blow it out.  The light floral fragrance is pleasant and just smells clean and fresh once your hair is dry.I think this could work for a lot of hair types, though if your hair is extremely dry/coarse/damaged you might want something a bit richer.  For a mass-market hair product this is very nice, and the generous 25 ounce size should last a looong time.

It's been over a year since Odelia has stumbled across a dead body, but she picked one heck of a time to end her dry spell!  It's Zee's daughter's wedding and everything is just lovely...right up until Odelia runs into the wedding planner.  In the cloakroom.  Dead.Now this time around Odelia has no intention of sticking her nose into police business - uh-uh, no way.  But she is willing to help out a "friend" by doing a little digging around in a missing person case.  Is it Odelia's fault that the missing person(s) has a connection to the recently deceased wedding planner?  Of course not, and how much trouble could Odelia possibly get into with her amateur sleuthing?I was going through a little rough patch and found myself desperately in need of an Odelia Grey "fix", and this book provided just the distraction that I was craving.  In addition to the delightful Ms. Grey, this story featured the usual cast of "regulars" along with a couple of new additions.  The mystery actually felt a little unwieldly, but I don't mind because I read "cozy" mysteries primarily for the characterization and this series gets an A+ where that's concerned.Like its predecessors, this installment was loaded with warmth and humor, quirky characters and a heroine that you'd love to have as a best friend.  I love the themes of friendship, loyalty and second chances that permeate these stories, but most of all I guess I just love Odelia Grey.This is the 6th book in a series, and I'd recommend that you start at the beginning with book one: Too Big to Miss (The Odelia Grey Mysteries) .There's little (if any) strong language and no explicit sexual content.

As autumn settles into the Dordogne Bruno, chef de police of St. Denis, is looking forward to a quiet spell as the busy tourist season comes to a close.  The usually unflappable Bruno finds himself a bit star struck when he has the opportunity to meet a boyhood hero, a WWII legend and national icon widely known as "The Patriarch".  At a party for Marco Desaix (aka "The Patriarch") a suspicious death occurs and Bruno's subsequent investigation stirs up a hornet's nest involving long-buried Cold War secrets and political machinations.I was really looking forward to this 8th installment in the delightful "Bruno" series, and this book did not disappoint.  I thought the plot was cleverly executed - interesting tidbits about Cold War relations between France and Russia interspersed with Bruno's characteristic common sense and compassionate approach to community policing.  It's always entertaining to observe the interplay between the usual cast of characters and, of course, the village of St. Denis is a character in its own right.  The dialog is beautifully done, seeming so natural and effortless, and there were no lulls in the storyline.And never fear, as with all the previous books in the series we are treated to fabulous meals and yet another wrinkle in Bruno's already complicated love life.  I love the themes of community, friendship and quiet honor that are hallmarks of this charming series, and "The Patriarch" did not let me down.As I mentioned earlier, this is #8 in the series and while it does work as a standalone novel I'd highly recommend reading the series in order as the relationships between these characters evolve as the series progresses.  Contains occasional strong language (though mainly in French!) and there's no explicit sexual content.The series, in order:*Bruno, Chief of Police: A Novel of the French Countryside*The Dark Vineyard: A Novel of the French Countryside*Black Diamond: A Mystery of the French Countryside*The Crowded Grave: A Mystery of the French Countryside*The Devil's Cave: A Mystery of the French Countryside*The Resistance Man: A Bruno, Chief of Police novel*The Children Return: A Bruno, Chief of Police novel*The Patriarch: A Bruno, Chief of Police novel**There are also two short stories available on kindle

While I enjoyed the first two entries in this charming "cozy" series, I guess the old saying "three's the charm" is true because I just flat-out loved this story.Not only is Mama about to take a fifth (!) trip down the aisle, but she's insisting on a full blown "Gone With the Wind" themed wedding.  No thirty-something single woman should have to dress up in a Scarlett O'Hara bridesmaid's gown, but Mace is willing to do it to make Mama happy (not to mention that the word "no" doesn't seem to register with Mama).  But all the hoop skirts and ruffled parasols have to be put aside when Mama's caterer is murdered on the eve of the big event.  Who would want poor old Ronnie Hodges dead?  Since Mace would rather hunt down a murderer than hear one more word about tulle or party favors, she sets out to find the killer.This series is set in a small Florida town on Lake Okeechobee, a far cry from the tourists and theme parks that we usually associate with state.  I love the way the author describes small town life, where gossip is an art form and everyone knows everyone else - for better or worse.  The characters are delightful, from the commitment shy Mace to the (charmingly) manipulative Mama.  The banter between Mace, her two sisters and Mama is priceless.  This story is told with a lot of warmth and humor and it made me miss my own mother who, like Mama, was born and raised in a small Florida town and knew the secret to getting your own way was to lay on the Southern charm with a smidgen of guilt (as needed).Like all series, I'd recommend you start at the beginning, though this does hold up as a standalone novel.  There's little (if any) strong language/swearing and no explicit sexual content.The series, in order:*Mama Does Time (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Rides Shotgun (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Gets Hitched (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Sees Stars (A Mace Bauer Mystery)*Mama Gets Trashed (A Mace Bauer Mystery)

This notebook is definitely an upscale version of the generic spiral notebooks you buy at the drugstore, but those nice features come with a hefty price tag.The sturdy plastic cover will hold up to a lot of abuse and offer some protection from spills.  The fabric covering the spiral binding is a really nice touch – no snagging everything in its path if you’re pulling it out of a backpack!  The moveable divider with pockets on each side is a great feature to help keep you organized.I have nothing negative to say about this product – it’s a well thought out design and the quality is impeccable.  As nice as this notebook is, I find the price (currently in the $10 range) prohibitive.

Wendy Corsi Staub is a prolific writer and I’ve read (and enjoyed) a couple of novels she wrote under the pen name ‘Wendy Markham’.  While I thought the writing in “Blood Red” was polished and professional, as a Mystery/Thriller it missed its mark.I’m going to keep this synopsis vague as I’m leery of wandering into ‘Spoiler’ territory.  The gist of the story is that a happily married, middle-aged teacher (Rowan Mundy) starts getting creepy gifts out of the blue.  The person sending the gifts is anonymous, but has knowledge of an indiscretion committed by Rowan well over a decade ago.  This sends Rowan into a tailspin of anxiety and self-loathing; she doesn’t want her husband to discover her secret so she flails about trying to resolve things on her own which only serves to deepen the hole she’s managing to dig for herself.  Meanwhile, unbeknownst to Rowan, a serial killer with a thing for redheads has her in their crosshairs.By far the best thing this story has going for it is the setting.  Mundy’s Landing is a bucolic village tucked away in New York’s picturesque Hudson River valley.  The town’s one dubious claim to fame is that it was the scene of a series of bizarre (unsolved) murders a hundred years ago, and a virtual cottage industry has sprung up in exploiting the town’s eerie past.  I can see why the author decided to set a new series here – it’s a gold mine!Other than the setting nothing about the story felt unique to me.  The villain came straight out of central casting (cue the scary music!) and Rowan’s constant guilt and angst over her troubled teen years was tedious.  A woman who is nearly fifty years old and has made a very nice life for herself and her family should be able to put some petty juvenile antics into perspective.  And as for that terrible, awful secret that she just has to keep from her husband?  I found it ridiculous.  So Rowan annoyed me, her husband was a cypher, the storyline involving her son was uninteresting and Rowan’s sister was painfully one dimensional.  That about sums it up!Mystery Thriller?  I think not.  There are too many extraneous characters with storylines that go nowhere, and really there were few surprises.  The story stalled too often to maintain any sense of tension and whatever suspense builds up is inevitably offset by page after page of the main character’s tiresome internal monologues.Bottom Line:  Despite competent writing and an intriguing setting this story fails to “thrill” on any level.  Unfortunately there’s nothing new here, folks – you’ve read it all before.  2.5 stars

While there are some beauty products that I’m willing to splurge on, toner isn’t one of them.  I’ve tried dozens of them over the years, from the inexpensive mass market brands that you find at the drugstore all the way up to the pricey boutique brands that you can only buy from an esthetician.  While I’d give a slight nudge to the pricier “professional” brands, for the most part they all seem to perform about the same.  That being said, I’m surprised at how much I like this Phyto 5 toner.I expected a toner that contains both witch hazel and alcohol to be drying, but (surprisingly) this isn’t.  My skin type is “normal”, with a tendency to be slightly oily in the t-zone.  This toner leaves my skin feeling soft and not at all tight, with no sticky feeling whatsoever.  It doesn’t sting or cause any irritation or redness and I’ve been able to incorporate it right into my regular skincare routine, which includes a retinol night cream.  It has a strong medicinal smell reminiscent of poison ivy medication, but that quickly fades.Now to address the elephant in the room…this is expensive!  Prices tend to fluctuate here on Amazon, but right now this in the $50 range.  While I’m impressed with how well this product works for me, I don’t see myself spending that kind of money on a toner.Would I recommend this product?  I think this will work well for oily, normal, or combination skins, but dry and/or sensitive skin types might have a problem with the alcohol.  If you’re not on a strict beauty budget then it’s certainly worth a try.*49.4% of the total ingredients are from Organic farming*99.2% of the total ingredients are from natural origin

This is a nice, multi-purpose kitchen knife.  It weighs in at approx. 4 ounces; lightweight but with a solid feel.  It’s made from 1.4116 German Steel, which is generally considered to fall into the “medium to good” quality range when it comes to kitchen knives.While this does a fine job of trimming meat and cutting through poultry, I find myself using it mostly for chopping/dicing fruit and veggies.  I like the size and weight of the knife and it slices through even the denser raw vegetables with ease.While it’s listed as dishwasher safe, the manufacturer recommends hand washing.  There’s no such thing as “Stainless” steel – all steel can rust eventually if not well cared for.  As I understand it, 1.4116 German Steel is highly stain resistant.This knife comes very nicely boxed (if you’re thinking of giving it as a gift).  I’m not sure what the price point for this knife is going to be, but I’d expect it to be in the budget-conscious range (as opposed to the high-end brands that carry a hefty price tag).

My skin is not terribly dry (except in the winter months), but I do apply a light body moisturizer after every shower.  I thought this wet skin moisturizer might be too oily, but it’s surprisingly light textured and doesn’t leave my skin with a tacky, greasy feeling.  You towel dry after you’ve moisturized and you can dress immediately.The sweet floral scent is initially strong, but it fades quickly.  I can barely detect it an hour after I’ve showered – it just smells clean and summery to me.  While I do like this product, I have to laugh at the claim that you can “get ready in  the time”.  How long does it take to put on moisturizer – 20 or 30 seconds?  What difference does it make if I reverse the order by moisturizing before I dry off?  Silly advertising gimmick!Bottom Line:  Nice for people who don’t mind a floral scent and don’t require a heavy-duty moisturizer.  This is a mass-market product that you’d find in a drugstore or supermarket and I’d expect it to be priced accordingly.  The ingredients are nothing special, and the almond and coconut oils fall so far down on the list that there can't be anything but trace amounts of both.

I'm a little late to the `Odelia Grey' party, but I'm making up for lost time by binge reading this delightful "cozy" series.  How fun is it that California-based Odelia is in my neck of the woods for this 5th series installment?Odelia plans to spend the long Labor Day weekend by confronting her estranged mother, who she hasn't seen in over 30 years.  Odelia has barely set foot in Massachusetts when she stumbles across a dead body, and it looks like her long-lost mom may have had something to do with the crime.  Instead of getting the closure she was craving, Odelia gets a family she never even knew existed and yet another murder investigation under her belt.This was a fun read.  Characters from previous books make an appearance and we're introduced to a couple of new players that I hope to see more of in future installments.  There's a lot going on in this story, with different mystery subplots that intertwine - there's plenty here to keep an armchair sleuth on their toes!  But at its core this is a true "cozy", with the emphasis firmly on the characters and the setting.I love Odelia Grey.  Let's face it, middle-aged, plus-sized women don't typically get the starring role in a mystery series, but Odelia takes center stage and she owns it.  I think a big part of her appeal is that she's something of an `everywoman':  Attractive, but not cloyingly perfect.  She has a job she loves but a boss that gets on her last nerve.  She found her soulmate later in life, but boy was he ever worth the wait!  There's something uplifting about celebrating life's second act instead of worshipping at the altar of youth 24/7.  It's a nice change of pace.If you enjoy "cozy" mysteries with female sleuths then I highly recommend this series.  The writing is solid and the author infuses her narrative with warmth and humor.  It's clear that she has a great deal of affection for Odelia, and I think it's contagious.Occasional swearing/strong language.  There's some mild sexual innuendo, but no explicit content.  This is book 5 in the series and I'd recommend starting with book 1:Too Big to Miss (The Odelia Grey Mysteries)

I've been bingeing on the delightful "Bruno" series, and this 4th installment was chock full of the things that make these books so appealing.  First we have Bruno doing what he does best:  looking out for the citizens of St. Denis when some student activists target local farmers.  Then a dead body is discovered and Bruno switches into "investigator" mode, while juggling security duties for a last minute summit between France and Spain.  Phew.  Don't worry though, there's still plenty of time for Bruno to show off his culinary skills, vacillate between the two women in his life and walk his beloved hunting dog, Gigi.I enjoy the way the author reveals more about Bruno's past as the series moves forward.  There's so much that explains his strong attachment to the small town of St. Denis and his fierce need to protect its citizens, who are his family of choice.  These stories are strongly character based, though the mysteries are not simply window dressing (as they are in a "cozy" mystery).  There are a lot of layers to this particular storyline, and the mystery kept me completely engaged.  As always the characterization was excellent and the author's vivid descriptions of food and wine had me raiding my fridge in the wee hours of the morning (sadly, I was unable to locate any foie gras or Pomerol, and had to settle for some goat cheese from the supermarket - the shame!).If you enjoy mysteries that have more substance than a "cozy" but still focus on all the charming details that bring a locale to life, then I'd recommend this series.  Good, solid mystery storylines that are heavy on the characterization and domestic details and light on the blood and gore.  You'll want to start at the beginning: Bruno, Chief of Police: A Novel of the French Countryside .Occasional strong language/swearing.  No explicit sexual content.

...but nobody really wants to deal with an icky nail fungus.Almost a year ago I got a puncture wound to one of my toes and the nail bed was damaged.  As the nail grew back it didn't look quite right - yellowish color, bumps and ridges - so I consulted an expert.  No, not a doctor - my friend that owns a spa!  Diagnosis:  Nail fungus.  She wasn't optimistic.  Seems over-the-counter meds take a long time to work, that's IF they work at all.  There are prescription meds available, but they have side effects.  So...what to do?  Was I doomed to walk around with an ugly nail for the rest of my days?  I live in flip-flops; I wear them from the time the snow melts until the first frost. "Old Yeller" has got to go.I've been using Probelle twice a day for nearly three weeks now, and I've seen a big improvement.  The color of the nail is *almost* back to normal and the texture of the nail is much better.  I think the product is definitely working, but I've been doing a few other things as well:*keep the nail as short as you comfortably can*file down the thickness of the nail, but don't get carried away*try to avoid nail polish as much as possible while you're treating the nailWhile I'm very happy with the results, I am experiencing one side effect:  the product is making my skin dry and flaky.  I've been using a vitamin E oil to counteract the dryness, and that seems to work pretty well.  I also don't care for the dropper style applicator - you end up wasting a lot of product and getting it on skin that doesn't need to be treated.  Wouldn't a brush type applicator (like nail polish) make more sense?Bottom Line:  The product is working for me and I plan to continue using it.  The side effects are mild. The product has no odor, dries quickly and you don't need to use a lot of it.  I suspect that results will vary based on the extent of the problem (how many nails are involved) as well as how long you've had the fungus.

This is a comfortable, good quality chair that’s affordable and perfect for my home office.  Set-up was straightforward – clear instructions and everything you need is included – and I had it out of the box and set up in under 15 minutes.  My thoughts:*The firm cushion seat is comfortable and the fabric is durable*The mesh back offers surprising support; I really like it*Height adjusts easily, as does the back tension (recline)*Wheels operate smoothly on hardwood floors and a low-pile area rug*The armrests are plastic and cannot be adjustedOverall I’m really pleased with this chair.  I’m petite and my husband is over 6 feet tall, and the chair easily adjusts to accommodate either one of us.  If I were going to be sitting at my desk for 8 hours I’d probably want a chair with a bit more lumbar support , but for a couple of hours at the computer this chair is perfect.Bottom Line:  A good value in the under $125 price range.  Good quality; sturdy construction.

This cable works fine for charging my iPhone and iPad, and the 4ft length is convenient.  It’s a bit bulkier than its Apple counterpart, but that’s not an issue for me.  The red color comes in handy around here:  “Hands off, the red one is mine”.  (For some reason *certain* members of my family think that charging cables are community property and are not above pilfering one of mine).Like most folks I’ve had cables that last for years while others fizzle out after a couple of months.  In general I find Belkin products to be reliable, but I’ll update this review if any issues arise.

This 4th entry in the series opens with Odelia enjoying life as a newlywed, sharing a cozy house in Seal Beach with husband Greg and their assorted fur babies.  So all this wedded bliss means Ms. Grey won't be sticking her nose into any more murder investigations, right?  Everyone knows it doesn't count if you're just doing a favor for a friend...A serial killer the press has nicknamed the "Blond Bomber" has everyone in the LA area looking over their shoulders.  Over lunch Odelia's friend Lillian drops a bombshell of her own:  she believes the "Blond Bomber" is her own son, a prominent plastic surgeon.  Odelia thinks Lil is way off base, and all she agrees to do is prove that Dr. Brian Eddy is not a killer - how dangerous could that be?I'm not going to post any "spoilers", but right off the bat I have to say that there's an element to the "Lillian" storyline that was downright icky, and I had a hard time getting past it.  Other than that it was a fairly enjoyable connect-the-dots mystery, with suspects aplenty and a red herring (or two) tossed in for good measure.  I think the author telegraphed the identity of the "Blond Bomber" a little too early in the storyline, but there were a few surprises tossed in to keep me interested.Just to be clear here - this is a straight-up "cozy" mystery, so I'm willing to suspend disbelief when it comes to the investigation.  In real life police do not take kindly to civilians mucking around in murder investigations, nor would most people be foolhardy enough to put themselves in so many potentially dangerous situations.  For me a "cozy" is all about the characters, and I thoroughly enjoy spending a few hours with Odelia and company.Odelia Grey is a breath of fresh air in the "cozy" genre.  Middle-aged and unapologetically plus-sized, she's confident and her self-esteem is firmly intact.  The series is populated with a charming cast of characters and the author writes with a great deal of warmth and humor.  As with most series, this one is best enjoyed when read in order, so you'll want to start with book one: Too Big to Miss   .  Relax and enjoy!Occasional swearing/strong language; no explicit sexual content

Nothing good ever comes from attending a High School reunion, but Odelia's 30th is murder...literally.When the class bully is murdered there is no shortage of suspects.  Donny Oliver was a nasty piece of work, and plenty of people had reason to hate him (including Odelia herself).  Teaming up with an old High School "frenemy", Odelia does a little snooping and uncovers a few surprises.  Meanwhile, Odelia's boss has pulled an uncharacteristic disappearing act.  Nobody knows where Mike Steele has gone, but it's starting to look like he may have been involved in something shady.  The man may be a pain, but he's Odelia's pain and she intends to find him...one way or another.This third entry in the series was a bit sillier than its predecessors, and relied quite heavily on what I'd call "convenient coincidences" in order to move the plot along.  Still, there was a lot to like about the story.  I love the way the author is developing the characters, especially the supporting cast.  In this book the focus is on Greg and Odelia's relationship, and the friction that's caused by Odelia's penchant for insinuating herself into police investigations and putting herself at risk.I think the author has the right formula for an engaging "cozy" series here:  A unique, lovable protagonist that you want to root for, supporting characters that evolve as the series progresses, and a setting that feels realistic and natural.  While I could find plenty to nitpick in the way this story unfolds, I won't.  Why?  Because it really doesn't matter as it didn't detract from my enjoyment of the book.  A "cozy" is all about the characters, and I thoroughly enjoyed the time I spent immersed in Odelia's world.  It's on to book 4 for me - Booby Trap  .If you're not familiar with the series, Odelia Grey is a middle-aged, plus-sized woman who doesn't have an insecure bone in her body.  By day she's a paralegal, but on her own time she has a knack for solving crime.  This is a charming series that doesn't take itself too seriously; there's always room for a laugh (or two) and Ms. Grey is a winner.Some swearing/strong language.  No explicit sexual content.  This is book 3 in the series and probably not the place to start if you're new to the series.  The first book is Too Big to Miss (The Odelia Grey Mysteries) .

These microfiber cloths are  great for just about any cleaning task.  They’re ideal for polishing furniture (no lint!) and work well for cleaning glass or mirrors.  The generous 16” x 24” size and absorbent material make cleaning up spills a snap.  I’ve been using these in place of sponges and paper towels and am pleased with how well they work.These can be machine washed and tossed in the dryer on the ‘low’ setting (no bleach or fabric softeners).  Even after several washings and trips thru the dryer there’s no shrinkage and the material hasn’t lost any of its absorbent quality.  As an added plus the design is actually kind of attractive; I keep a couple of these in a basket on my kitchen counter so they’re always handy for a quick clean up.  Very nice – recommended!

I’ve read most of Marian Keyes’s books (not the last few), and enjoyed them very much.  She has a biting sense of humor and a keen eye for the ridiculous.  Her female characters are often a bit self-absorbed, even a tad shallow, but this just provides fodder for Keyes’s wicked sense of humor.  Take this observation from the novel’s heroine, wistfully recalling the days when she had a personal trainer to keep her fit:“Between that and the running, it kept me a size eight.  A European size eight, I should stress.  Not a US size eight, which is really a size twelve and which nobody admires.”Keyes manages to poke fun at the character and our weight obsessed culture at the same time.  Clever.  That being said, this was not my favorite Keyes book by a long shot.  It had its moments, but overall it missed the mark for me.As the story opens we meet Stella Sweeney, a 41 year old divorced woman who has just moved back to Dublin along with her surly teen-age son.  All we know is that her life is in a shambles, she had obtained –and subsequently lost – some degree of celebrity and now desperately needs to write a book to get herself back on track financially.  The story unfolds as Stella thinks back to when she contracted a scary (and very serious) illness several years ago and how that illness served as a catalyst for her to change her life.  And so it goes, back and forth between past and present until Stella’s story is revealed.I didn’t have an issue with the story being told in flashback sequences per se, but I admit that it made it easy for me to put the book down…frequently.  I just never got engrossed in the story, and I suspect a lot of that had to do with the disjointed narrative.  I also thought the book was too long – there just isn’t enough story here to warrant 400+ pages.  Frankly I found some of it boring, even tedious.While this isn’t a huge departure from the author’s previous works, it lacked something for me, and I think that “something” is a compelling heroine.  Stella Sweeney was just too passive and glib for my taste.  I’m not sorry I read the book, Keyes is a darned fine writer and she can always wring a laugh out of me, but this isn’t a story that I’ll be thinking about days from now – I’m afraid there was just nothing memorable about it for me.

Thule has a reputation for producing high quality products, and this daypack does not disappoint.This daypack offers good protection for your laptop and your tablet as well as easy access to both.  The material is rugged and resistant to tearing/ripping.  The zippers are sturdy and glide easily (no need to fumble with them when you’re traveling and need to get at your devices).  The straps are comfortable and the fit can be adjusted fairly easily.  I’m petite and my husband is 6’2”, and both of us use this daypack comfortably.I think this pack is ideal for bike commuters.  It fits flat against your back and feels secure; it’s roomy enough for your “essentials” without being overly bulky.  I also used it as my carry-on luggage on a recent trip and found it roomy enough for a few “extras” (with the main purpose of keeping my electronics protected and easily accessible).  While I’m not a huge fan of the look of the roll top, I have to say that it does allow you a bit of extra room when necessary.I really have nothing negative to say about this product.  It’s intelligently designed and the quality is top notch, with a price tag to match.

I’ve been meaning to replace my two Teflon coated cookie sheets for ages.  They are scratched and have long since lost whatever non-stick qualities they ever had, and they’re a royal pain to clean.  This Doughmakers cookie sheet puts them to shame.The pebble pattern is not just a gimmick – when they say it allows for “easy release”, they’re not kidding.  Once the cookies had cooled I was able to just lift them off the sheet by hand, no spatula required.  Clean up is super easy, just a quick hand wash (no scrubbing necessary).I did have to adjust the cooking time somewhat when using this sheet.  I found that I needed an extra 4 to 5 minutes of baking time when making a basic chocolate chip cookie recipe (compared to the cook time using my old Teflon cookie sheets).*Use of non-stick spray is NOT recommended*Not recommended for dishwasher*Made in ChinaBottom Line:  A good quality baking sheet that performs well.  I would definitely purchase more Doughmakers bakeware (it’s high time I replaced some of my ancient cake pans!)

This is a Spoiler-Free review.After spending 40 years as a fugitive, Ian Holzner has decided to turn himself in.  Holzner is accused of being the mastermind behind the 1975 bombing of a VA Center that claimed four lives.  While Holzner admits to being part of the radical anti-war movement, he denies responsibility for the VA Center bombing, and he intends to stand trial.Parker Stern reluctantly agrees to defend Holzner, but finds his client secretive and (for the most part) uncooperative.  What is Holzner hiding?  Is he guilty?  The media circus surrounding this case shines a spotlight on Parker's personal life, but that's the least of his worries - this case is dangerous, and Parker's involvement could (quite literally) cost him everything.This is the third "Parker Stern" novel, and like its predecessors it is an excellent Legal Thriller/Mystery.  The storyline is well thought out and skillfully executed.  The tension never lets up, which is exactly what I want when I pick up a "Thriller".  The author does an excellent job of making the judicial process approachable to the reader without getting bogged down in arcane "legalese".  In this era of "Court TV" an author can't rely on "Perry Mason" type courtroom theatrics, and Mr. Rotstein does not do that.  What he does do is give you the sense that you're getting a behind-the-scenes view of what's involved in a high profile trial - some of it fascinating, some of it absurd, much of it surprisingly mundane.At the midpoint of the book I was feeling quite smug, pretty confident that I had figured out a key plot point.  I may have been correct, but it did not prepare me for a later revelation - I did not see that coming!  You know how sometimes you give in to the urge to flip to the last few pages to see how everything turns out?  Well, I'm glad I exerted a little self-control this time and just allowed the story to unfold - I was not disappointed!Would I recommend this book?  Absolutely, but with one caveat:  I'd strongly suggest reading the series in order.  This technically works as a standalone novel and you won't be lost if you haven't read the earlier books.  However, much of Parker's past is revealed in the first two books and knowing that history greatly added to my enjoyment of this book.The series (in order):*Corrupt Practices: A Parker Stern Novel*Reckless Disregard: A Parker Stern Novel (Parker Stern Novels)*The Bomb Maker's Son: A Parker Stern Novel

In this second series installment (following Corrupt Practices ), Parker Stern has given up on being a trial attorney and taken a job as a mediator.  Once a topnotch litigator, Parker now is paralyzed by stage fright whenever he enters a courtroom, and at barely forty years old his legal career seems to have reached a dead end.Out of the blue Parker is contacted by a video game developer who goes by the alias "Poniard".  Poniard has created a game that implicates a powerful media executive in the disappearance of a young actress, and is facing a civil suit for libel.  Parker is essentially blackmailed into taking the case, but is intrigued by it at the same time.  Who is Poniard?  What really happened to the troubled starlet, Felicity McGrath?  What role did billionaire William Bishop play in her disappearance?I love a good legal Mystery/Thriller, and this one checked off all the boxes.
