Parker Stern is a complex and compelling protagonist, there's a multi-layered mystery fueling the plot and the storyline never loses momentum.  The author deftly handles the tricky problem of making the legal aspect seem plausible (at least from this layman's point of view), without overwhelming the reader with dry and tedious technicalities.  There's no treading water in this story, everything that happens advances the plot and kept me thoroughly engaged from start to finish.  This is author Robert Rotstein's milieu, and boy does it show!Obviously this was a "hit" for me, and I highly recommend it.  There's some occasional swearing/strong language; no explicit sexual content.  This is the second book in a series, and while it does work as a standalone novel I think you'll enjoy it more if you start with book one.The `Parker Stern' books (in order):*Corrupt Practices: A Parker Stern Novel*Reckless Disregard: A Parker Stern Novel (Parker Stern Novels)*The Bomb Maker's Son: A Parker Stern Novel

In this second Odelia Grey mystery (following Too Big to Miss: An Odelia Grey Mystery  ), Odelia gets caught up in the chaos caused when a valuable collectable lunch box goes missing.  A lunch box?  Yes, a lunch box with a whopping six-figure price tag,  and there are people willing to do whatever it takes to get their hands on it...including murder.Odelia Grey is a refreshing addition to the "cozy" mystery genre.  Too often middle-aged single women in a cozy are portrayed as fusty, matronly homebodies who run tea shops or sell knitting supplies.  Odelia delightfully dodges that hoary old stereotype.  She's in her late forties, happily single with a job that she enjoys and does well.  She has an active social life and never lacks for male admirers.  She's stylish, attractive and unapologetically overweight.  It's easy to picture yourself enjoying a night out with Odelia, trading blind date horror stories and enjoying a good laugh while polishing off a bottle of merlot.As mysteries go this one is firmly on the "cozy" side of the street so expect to suspend disbelief.  There are suspects aplenty and one or two plot twists that caught me off guard.  I thought the denouement was a tad convoluted, requiring a few square pegs to be forced into round holes plot wise.  Nevertheless I still thoroughly enjoyed this story and I think the author did a great job of creating a likeable protagonist and a supporting cast that you just love to root for.  The SoCal location is used to good effect and Odelia's sense of humor injects a dose of fun into the plot.  I'm looking forward to reading book #3, Thugs and Kisses  .Very occasional swearing/strong language.  There's some mild sexual innuendo, but no explicit content. This is book #2 in the series and while it does work as a standalone I'd recommend you start with book #1.

These shower curtain rings are sturdy and well-made.  The polished nickel finish is clean and sharp looking and the simple, classic design will complement many (most?) decors.  The safety-pin style closure makes hanging a shower curtain or changing the curtain liner a snap.  Best of all, these rings glide smoothly – no pulling or tugging on the shower curtain necessary.These are much, much nicer than plastic shower curtain rings and I’d expect them to be priced accordingly.  These are made of brass (with a nickel finish) so rust/corrosion should not be a problem.  I’m really pleased with this product – stylish and functional and made in the USA.  I’ll update this review if anything changes, but right now this is a 5-Star product for me and one that I’d highly recommend.

In the four weeks since I’ve had this shredder I’ve been able to give it a good workout.  Earlier this year we had to sort out my mother’s house, and I got the job of going thru all her paperwork (lucky me).  I had 4 or 5 large cartons that eventually wound up in the shredder.  Here are my thoughts:*At approx. 22-1/2” high by 12” wide this is a large unit, so it’s very convenient that it’s on rollers.  When I’m not using it I can just roll it behind my desk.*I could not get this thing to jam!  Credit cards, CDs, overstuffed junk mail envelopes…it makes fast work of them all.  While I don’t recommend that anyone else do this, I stuffed more than the recommended 10 sheets of paper through the manual feed and still it didn’t jam.*After about 10-12 minutes of continuous shredding the unit does overheat and automatically shut off for 25 minutes.  If I start shredding again immediately after the 25 minutes is up, the unit tends to overheat and shutdown even sooner, sometimes with less than 10 minutes of continual manual shredding.  (Keep in mind though that I’m talking maximum amounts here, and the machine is running continuously).*Auto Feed – Here’s where things get tricky.  I find the auto feed function to be very finicky.  Even using well under the 200 sheet auto feed capacity, I usually have to open the lid and realign the papers at some point because shredding just stops.  The papers have to be pristinely flat – no fold marks (no matter how much you try to smooth them out).*The bin has a large capacity and slides right out for easy emptying.*Fairly quiet operation as far as shredders go.Bottom Line:  Easy, dependable manual shredding and this unit is more than adequate for home office use.  However, I find the auto feed function to be hit or miss, so if that’s an important feature for you I’d hesitate to recommend this unit.  At this price point I don’t think you should have to make many concessions.

I’m a fan of the L’ANZA hair care line; I’ve been using their shampoos and conditioners for years.  This “Silk Serum” is a disappointment.  The first 5 ingredients listed on the back of the bottle are all some variation of silicone.  I know that most mass market “shine serums” use silicone as their main ingredient, but I expected better quality ingredients from a higher-end brand that’s sold in salons.This is supposed to “provide weightless shine and silky softness” when used on damp hair before blow drying or as a finishing serum on dry hair.  I do find that it adds shine (there’s certainly enough silicone in it!), but even the tiniest amount leaves my hair looking very flat and stick straight.  This is NOT a good product for fine hair, even when used very sparingly.  This will weigh the hair down, so if you’re looking for fullness and volume this is going to work against you.  If your hair is thick and/or the texture is coarse, then you might like the “flattening” effect, but I’d still recommend using only a very small amount.I was tempted to toss this out, but humid weather is right around the corner and I can probably use a little of this on the ends of my hair to control the dreaded frizzies.  Still, there’s absolutely nothing special about this serum, certainly nothing to warrant the salon product price tag.  You can pick up just about any drugstore shine serum at a quarter of the price and it’ll work just the same.First five ingredients listed on the back of the bottle:*cyclopentasiloxane*dimethicone*c. methicone*p. trimethicone*p. dimethicone

I need to ‘fess up here:  I’m not a fan of puppets or ventriloquists.  As far as I’m concerned ventriloquists and mimes are about as entertaining as listening to elevator music.  What does any of this have to do with a Romance book you ask?  Well, the heroine in this story is a ventriloquist/puppeteer, and it’s treated like she’s got this super-awesome talent.  She just seemed dorky and annoying to me.Annie Hewitt has hit a dead-end.  At 33 she has to accept that her acting career is never going to get off the ground, she’s deeply in debt and physically ill.  She arrives on tiny Peregrine Island (off the coast of Maine) in the middle of winter during a snowstorm.  She’s hoping to find something of value in the cottage that her late mother used live in.  What she finds is no heat or electricity.  Things go downhill from there.Theo Harp was Annie’s stepbrother for about 5 minutes twenty years ago, and he’s nothing but a bad memory to Annie.  Unfortunately, he’s now her neighbor on the island.  Funny thing is, Theo is all grown up and not as creepy has he used to be…or is he?I’m not reading a lot in the Romance genre these days, but since I really enjoyed Susan Elizabeth Phillips’ “Chicago Stars” series I figured I’d give this book a shot.  Well, it’s not in the same league as those books, but it’s entertaining (if slightly odd).  Annie’s character loves classic Gothic Romance books and this story is something of homage to “Rebecca” or “Jane Eyre”, and I thought that was pretty clever.  There’s a surprising darkness to this story, with all the main characters having tragic pasts and the setting is gloomy and mostly depressing.I never warmed up to Annie.  The author goes on and on about how gawky she looks, and while I have nothing against a plain heroine, Annie just sounded goofy.  Add to that the fact that she carries her puppets EVERYWHERE SHE GOES (!!) and in her head they “talk” to her…well, it just sounded like a character that Fred Armisen  would play in “Portlandia”!  I can just picture him with a Raggedy Anne wig on his head bouncing around talking to puppets.  How am I supposed to believe that Theo, Mr. Tall, Dark and Handsome, is attracted to Annie?  Good grief!But all is not lost.  Despite the dorky heroine and the unconvincing romance, the writing is good.  There’s a little suspense/mystery that kept me interested and I was eager to find out what Theo’s backstory was.  If nothing else you have to give the author credit for coloring outside the lines with this one!Occasional swearing/strong language and moderate sexual content (nothing particularly explicit)

What a clever idea for inexpensive decorating that doesn’t leave permanent damage to your walls!Hanging these tiles could not be any easier – no tools required.  The back of the base has a Velcro square that the Command strip attaches to, then you remove the liner from the strip and attach it to your wall.  The base even has a built in level that makes the process virtually foolproof.  The decorative face of the tile attaches magnetically to the base and can be swapped out for another design without having to reposition the base.Second thoughts about where you’ve hung the tile?  No problem!  Simply grab the bottom corners of the base and peel it away from the wall – it comes right off.  The Command strip can be removed by pulling down (follow the instructions included with the product) and doesn’t leave a mark or remove any paint from your wall.I really love this product.  We just painted the walls in our home office and I’m not sure what I want to permanently hang up in there.  Instead of looking at boring bare walls (or making a bunch of nail holes to hang something temporarily), I’ve hung up 3 of these black and white photograph tiles.  If I decide to replace them somewhere down the line I won’t have to worry about any pesky marks or holes that need to be touched-up.  This product would be perfect for renters or college students living in a dorm – no damage to the walls = no “damage” to your security deposit!The brochure that came with the product shows many tile designs available, as well as a chalkboard, a dry erase board and a photo frame.  I can definitely see myself purchasing more of these.

Cooler temperatures are not the only thing November brings to Abbotsville - a newcomer has decided to take the town by storm.  Wealthy Connie Clayborn is a northern transplant and finds that the town is just not up to her standards, and she's not shy about doling out the criticism.I think you can imagine how well that went over with Miss Julia.Miss Julia has every intention of putting the uppity interloper in her place, but instead of delivering a well-deserved dressing down to Mrs. Clayborn, Miss Julia finds herself at the center of a criminal investigation.  Really, who has time for such a thing when she's in the middle of planning her annual Christmas "soiree"?I'm a big fan of this series and I've faithfully read all the installments, enjoying each and every one.  That said, I was a tad underwhelmed by this storyline.  The humor in these books is usually more understated, relying on Miss J's clever musings about human nature and changing social mores.  There's less of that in this story and a lot more silliness.  I still enjoyed it - time spent in the company of these wonderful characters is never wasted! - but I felt like it was missing something.  Normally I have a few favorite quotes from each book and this time...nothing stands out.Now lest I start sounding  too cranky, there's a lot to like about this book.  The author has created an absolutely charming cast of characters and just reading the dialog alone is a joy for me.  She really captures the natural sound of a conversation and she's able to convey dialect that comes off as pitch-perfect.  This book is full of warmth and humor.  It left me feeling uplifted and optimistic, and as far as I'm concerned that's worth the price of admission.If you're new to the series then the 16th installment is not the place to start!  Do yourself a huge favor and begin at book one,Miss Julia Speaks Her Mind .  You won't be sorry.  There's no swearing/strong language or sexual content.

I never expected to find a casual rain jacket that was actually flattering, but this one really is.  This Columbia hooded jacket has a fitted look and when you wear it belted it highlights your curves.  I normally wear a Women’s size 4/6, and the size Small fit me perfectly.  I can wear a lightweight sweater underneath but anything too bulky would make for a tight fit.  The attached hood has a drawstring closure so it stays in place (and keeps your hair dry) even when the wind picks up.  We’ve had a lot of rain over the past two weeks and this has kept me completely dry.Fit:  True to size, but it’s a slim look.  Consider sizing up if you plan on layering it over heavyweight clothing.  I had to cuff the sleeves, which is a little odd as my arms are fairly long.Warmth:  Not lined, so offers minimal warmth.  Not a cold weather jacket.Misc.:  Great for travel; packs well and the nylon material resists wrinkles.  Two-way zipper, removable belt, drawstring hood, snap closure, deep inside pocketsI love this jacket – it’s functional and flattering and Columbia products are good quality.  I got this for around $60 and I’m very happy – I would have paid more for it.  Highly recommended.

As acting chief of police for the small East Texas town of Jarrett Creek, Samuel Craddock's "official" duties consist mainly of settling minor disputes and keeping an eye on the local high school kids on prom night.  "Unofficially" he begins to poke around in the past of his neighbor (and close friend) Jenny Sandstone when her ailing mother fears that Jenny is in danger.  This puts Samuel in a precarious position - does he risk losing Jenny's friendship by prying into her private life or does he respect her wishes and leave things alone, even if that means she's in some kind of danger?This is the 4th entry in the series, and while it technically works as a standalone novel I think I was at a slight disadvantage by not having read the previous books.  Clearly these characters have well-established relationships and quite a bit of history between them, and as a newcomer I wasn't privy to all that.  Despite that I did enjoy this story and plan on going back and reading the series in order (and really, most series should be read in order, don't you think?).Samuel Craddock is a seasoned (a nice way of saying "not young") investigator who believes in serving his community by upholding the spirit, if not the letter, of the law.  He knows his town and his people and cares deeply about both.  Calm, intelligent, intuitive and a true gentleman, Samuel is the kind of man who engenders trust and respect.  He's a very likeable protagonist and it's interesting to watch him piece together the evidence and solve the mystery.This is definitely a character-driven story.  At first glance this could almost pass for a "cozy" mystery, but I wouldn't pigeonhole it as one.  Jarrett Creek may have a wholesome charm to it, but it's no Texas version of Brigadoon.  The characters are complex and have real problems; there's alcoholism and spousal abuse - not typical "cozy" fare.  The strength of the story lies in the fine characterization and the author's knack for setting a scene so realistic that you feel like you're standing right there.  The dialog sounded authentic to my Yankee ears (so take that for what it's worth!) and while the pace is deliberately slow, I didn't find it plodding in the least.Bottom Line:  A low-key, character-driven Mystery with an engaging protagonist.  The small town, East Texas setting is charming.  I don't recall much in the way of swearing/strong language and there's no sexual content.Book One:  A Killing at Cotton Hill: A Samuel Craddock Mystery Book Two:  The Last Death of Jack Harbin: A Samuel Craddock MysteryBook Three:  Dead Broke in Jarrett Creek: A Samuel Craddock Mystery Book Four:  A Deadly Affair at Bobtail Ridge: A Samuel Craddock Mystery

Everything is booming in the tiny town of Grimstad, North Dakota – oil, housing, jobs…and crime.  Cassie Dewell’s first day on the job as lead investigator for the sheriff’s department starts off with a bang when body parts are discovered strewn throughout the town.  Is it drug related?  Gang related?  Cassie will have to scramble to get this case solved before a huge influx of crystal meth hits the streets and the body count escalates.What struck me about this story is the way the author brought the town of Grimstad to life.  On the surface it seems like an oil boom would be a good thing.  The economy is thriving, there’s virtually no unemployment (fast food workers make $18 an hour) and people are becoming rich practically overnight.  But there’s a desperate, seedy quality to the town:  overcrowding everywhere, an explosion of drugs and all the related crime that goes with that.  On top of it winter is setting in and daytime temperatures dip well below zero.  The cold is oppressive and the author uses it to good effect.Cassie Dewell is an interesting character, not a cookie-cutter heroine.  She’s 36, plump, a widow and a mother.  She’s a talented investigator but it’s clear that she’ll bend the rules to get the outcome she wants.  I would have liked her to play a larger role in the story, but she competes for page time with several other characters.This is my first C. J. Box book and I can see why he’s so popular.  The writing is very solid, with good characterization and authentic sounding dialog.  I thought he did a great job of maintaining a sense of tension throughout the storyline and I could never find a good place to leave off whenever I had to interrupt my reading – “just let me read this next part…” became my mantra.My one gripe about this book is that I had issues with an element that comes into play at the very end.  I won’t “spoil” anything, I’ll just say that there was something that lacked credibility for me and required more suspension of disbelief than I would have liked.  Overall though I did enjoy this and would recommend it.Occasional strong language, some violence, no sexual content.  While this works as a standalone novel, the character of “Cassie” clearly made her debut in an earlier book because part of that storyline made its way into this story.

My son is away at school and loves to get “care packages” from home.  (OK – what he really loves to get is money, but food is a close second).  This box contains 32 single serving (vending machine size) name-brand snacks.  What you see pictured on the product page is what you get – there are no substitutions.  Pepperidge Farm goldfish, Famous Amos cookies, Skinny Pop, Skittles…a smorgasbord of junk food!  He loved it.  Everything arrived intact and well within the expiration dates.This makes a great gift for a hard-to-buy-for college kid – it was a big hit!  I only hope it lasts the weekend…what I wouldn’t give to have the metabolism of a 19 year old again.  Sigh.

When Odelia Grey learns that her friend Sophie has committed suicide, she's completely shocked.  Sophie was outgoing, vivacious and successful - why would she take her own life?  As Odelia begins the process of getting Sophie's affairs in order, she finds out that her friend harbored more than a few very big secrets - did one of those secrets lead to her death?  Odelia feels that she owes it to Sophie to find out, and she manages to stir up a whole lot of trouble in the process.I liked this story, but mostly I just really liked Odelia.  How often does a middle-aged woman who is considerably overweight get to be the star of the show?  Odelia pulls it off nicely.  Attractive and happily single, Odelia has a good job and a nice life in Southern California.  She's smart and self-confident and there's not a lot of weight-related angst in this book.  She's big, she knows it and what's more - she OWNS it.  Great character.The mystery is pretty good, with lots of secrets and layers to keep you on your toes.  It doesn't stray too far from the "cozy" side of the street, so don't expect CSI-like reality - suspension of disbelief is definitely required!  Still, the author gave Odelia some smarts and she's not just bumbling her way through the story, she's putting the pieces together in a way that makes sense.It's unusual for a "cozy" to have any sexual content, but this story does.  There's nothing explicit - no, not at all - but there's at least one scene with Odelia and her romantic interest that's not the usual fade-to-black.  Also, online pornography plays a role in the story.  I'm not doing any pearl-clutching here, just a `heads-up' to "cozy" readers who might not expect any sizzle in their storyline.I do have one tiny little bone to pick with the author.  While I'm aware that there's plenty of "fat shaming" that goes on in our appearance-obsessed culture, it was a little over-the-top in this story.  I hope that gets toned down as the series progresses.To me, a good "cozy" is all about the characters, and the author nailed it in that department.  The setting (So Cal) is nicely described and I think the author has laid the foundation for an interesting series.  I've already purchased the second book,The Curse of the Holy Pail: An Odelia Grey Mystery (The Odelia Grey Mysteries Book 2),  and look forward to reading it.*There are a few kindle formatting issues - nothing too distracting, but there were places where the dialog got confusing because there were no paragraph breaks.

If you’ve ever felt like there wasn’t an inch to spare when you were stretched out on your yoga mat then this might be what you’re looking for.  At 10 inches longer and 2 inches wider than a standard sized mat, this will accommodate taller folks quite nicely.The black side of the mat has a textured feel and the blue side is smooth.  It’s slightly thicker than my old Gaiam mat, and offers a bit more cushion, but it’s a yoga mat not an air mattress – don’t expect total comfort (especially on a hard surface).  I find it reasonably comfortable for yoga/floor exercises, but I’m a fairly small person.  If you’re dealing with sore joints or back issues then you might want to look for something that offers more padding.  I don’t have any problems with the mat being slippery when I sweat, but I always have a towel close by.  The extra size makes the mat a little more awkward to tote around with you, but it’s certainly doable.  I’ve had good luck with Gaiam mats (I have two that have lasted for years and years), so I feel comfortable recommending this one.

I have to confess that I'm a hair product junkie and love to experiment with new products.  My "experiments" are not always successful, but this conditioning mask really worked for me.  My hair is long and color treated; I shampoo and blow dry daily and use a curling iron or flat iron more than I probably should.  Despite the abuse I heap on my hair it's in good shape, though it's on the dry side (no surprise!) and this product leaves my hair soft and smooth with plenty of bounce and shine.How to use:  Shampoo hair and wring out the excess water.  Apply a small amount (I use a Tablespoon but you may need more or less depending on length and texture) and leave on for a few minutes.  Rinse thoroughly and style as usual.  For more intense conditioning I apply the mask and cover my head with an inexpensive plastic shower cap then wrap a warm towel over that, and leave it in my hair for 15 minutes before rinsing.Tips:  1.69 oz. is not a lot of product but you can use it sparingly.  Most people don't need a lot of conditioning at the root area, so you can apply from the mid-shaft to the ends.  In fact, if your hair texture is fine and you're worried about the conditioner weighing it down and making it look flat, I'd recommend skipping the root area.  This is a weekly treatment and not meant for use as a daily conditioner.Bottom Line:  Leaves my hair soft and shiny with lots of volume.  I'm not mad about the vanilla scent, but I don't find it unpleasant or overpowering either.  May not be rich enough for coarse or very damaged hair types. **Not Recommended for those who prefer fragrance free products**

With two large hairy dogs in residence I vacuum frequently.  My house has hardwood floors throughout with tile in the baths, and while there is no carpeting I do have several large (low pile) area rugs.  Any vacuum that comes into this house had better be ready for a workout!  I’m happy to report that this Miele canister vac is up to the task.This vacuum is easy to assemble.  I had it out of the box and up and running in under 10 minutes.  At approx. 14lbs this is a surprisingly lightweight vacuum and is easy to maneuver.  The low profile canister is solid and not prone to tipping over.  The extra-long cord allows you to vacuum a large area without having to switch outlets, which is a real plus.  The cord retracts automatically with a push of a button.  Using the most powerful setting this vacuum does a great job of picking up dog hair.The standout feature for me is the parquet twister attachment for non-carpeted flooring.  This glides easily over hardwood and tile; has a 180 degree rotation that allows you to vacuum right up against your baseboards as well as in tight spaces (under and behind furniture).Other notable features:*Six power settings*extendable stainless steel wand (great for overhead cleaning)*cleaning attachments for upholstery, drapes, etc.*relatively quiet operation*Airflow indicator on the front of the canister indicates when it’s time to change the filter bagA couple of concerns…*I was underwhelmed by the suction when vacuuming the area rugs.  Even at the highest setting I had to go over the same area repeatedly in order to pick up pet hair.  I’ve owned vacuums that were far less expensive than this one that did a better job on low pile carpet/rugs.*Miele replacement filter bags are not inexpensive, and with the amount of dog hair I pick up I’ll be changing the bags fairly frequently.Bottom Line:  This is a very nice, high quality vacuum.  I would highly recommend it if your living space is mainly uncarpeted.  I don’t think this is the best option (especially at this price point!) if you have dense or high-pile carpeting.  The cost of replacing filter bags is a consideration, though if you’re not dealing with a lot of pet hair you probably won’t be replacing the bags as often as I need to.

This story takes place in Louisiana’s Gulf Coast, after the double whammy of Katrina and the BP oil spill have crippled the shrimping industry.  We’re introduced to a cast of characters, each just trying to get by now that their entire way of life is threatened.  Some are determined to continue shrimping, even though they can barely eke out a living; some have moved on to more lucrative (and less legal) ways to turn a buck; some get by on booze, pills and pipe dreams about pirate treasure.  Their individual stories intertwine, and by the end of the book these characters will have collided with each other resulting in some interesting consequences.The characters don’t just carry the storyline, they ARE the storyline.  The author managed to depict this can of mixed nuts so vividly that I felt like I had actually met these people.  Their appearance, their accents, their mannerisms…these characters took on a life of their own, and with a mixture of revulsion and fascination I just couldn’t look away.This is not a novel that fits comfortably in any one genre.  I wouldn’t classify it as a Mystery; perhaps Southern Noir is a more apt description.  At any rate, it’s an often dark story that manages to avoid being overwhelmingly depressing because the author lets some humor seep into the mix.  Interestingly, while some of the humor does come at the characters’ expense, I also could sense the author’s compassion for these people, which made them seem all the more human to me.Would I recommend this book?  I can tell you that I definitely enjoyed it; the writing is very good and the characterization is outstanding.  If you’re a very plot-driven reader then the lack of a central Mystery might leave you feeling that the story lacks focus, but if you enjoy rich characterization then you might want to give this a try.Occasional swearing/strong language.  No explicit sexual content.

If just the thought of assembling a piece of furniture makes you want to scream in terror, let me put your mind at ease – the only thing you need to do with this futon is screw on the legs.  It takes 10-15 minutes (tops!) and everything you need is included, even the little “L” shaped thingy (that’s the professional name) that you use to tighten the bolts.This futon arrives in a big bulky box.  The product page lists the shipping weight as 90+ pounds (you may want someone to give you a hand hauling this into the house).  All you do is unfold the futon, screw on the legs and – voila! – Instant couch!I think this futon is quite comfortable to sit on, but the cushions are very firm – this is not soft, plush seating.  It’s a solid, sturdy piece and put together well.  At 6’2” and 200 pounds my husband is not a “dainty” guy, and he can flop down onto this without causing the futon to wobble or move.  The weight limit is listed as 600 pounds – or my husband times three (and there’s a thought I don’t wish to explore any further).  You can call it “faux-leather” if you like, but it’s vinyl and it looks like it, but it’s stitched and finished very nicely and is a handsome looking piece.The seat backs fold down easily to create a (smallish) bed.  My measurements disagree slightly with those on the product page.  I measured this as 68” x 43” when it is folded out.  If you plan on using this as a spare bed, I’d highly recommend getting an inexpensive mattress topper; it’ll go a long way towards making your guest more comfortable.  Tall folks won’t be stretching out on this – my husband’s calves were hanging off the end!The one negative thing I have to say about this futon is that it had a very strong plastic/chemical odor when I took it out of the box.  After airing it out for 48 hours the smell is barely noticeable, but this could be a problem for those who are sensitive to such things.Bottom Line:  Budget friendly, low profile, comfortable seating.  The vinyl is fairly thick, but take care with sharp objects (keys, pet claws, etc.).  Easy to wipe clean.  *Made in China*German Shepherd tested and approved ;-)

My expectations for any anti-aging product are pretty modest.  I think that certain products can make your skin tone appear more even resulting in a brighter complexion, and skin that reflects light prettily tends to appear more youthful.  I do not think that there are any miracle creams out there that are going to make you look decades younger, and I find most of the hype surrounding many anti-aging products is just that - hype, with no science to back it up.  That being said...SK-II is a well-known, high-end skin care line and I was excited to give it a try.  This product arrived without any instructions, which I find odd.  Does it replace your toner or do you use it after your toner?  I had to go online to the company's website to do a little research.  You apply this product to clean skin.  You can use a cotton pad or pat it into the skin with your hands.  It absorbs into my skin quickly and completely; there's no sticky feeling nor is it oily.  It has the consistency of water and a very slight (and not unpleasant) odor.  I experience no stinging, redness, irritation or breakouts.  This does leave my skin feeling a little tight, and I follow up with my usual daytime moisturizer and nighttime retinol cream.After nearly four weeks of use (twice daily) I have to say that I've noticed absolutely no change in my skin whatsoever.  Now I'm pretty happy with my current skin care regimen, and it's entirely possible that what I'm using is effective and I'm not going to see any major changes by adding another product into the mix.Bottom line:  Pleasant and easy to use; no unwanted side effects but also no noticeable improvement.Would I recommend this product?  Hard to say.  Everyone's skin is different and I've read online testimonials by women who swear by this stuff.  Since it didn't do anything for me, I can't be too enthusiastic about it, and frankly I find the price a bit prohibitive.

I’ve reached the point where the mountain of books in my to-be-read pile will surely outlive me, so I seldom re-read a novel.  This book is a rare exception.  I loved this one when I first read it back in 2000, and I loved it every bit as much when I re-read it earlier this month.Elfrida Phipps made her living as a stage actress.  Not a famous actress or even (perhaps) a particularly talented one, but it paid the rent.  Now that she’s reached retirement age she’s decided to move away from London and buys herself a tiny cottage in a small country village.  End of story, right?  Hardly; it’s just the beginning of Elfrida’s ‘second act’.The bulk of the story takes place just before Christmas, in the north of Scotland where Elfrida is ensconced in a stately old manor house.  She’s joined there by a mix of family and almost-strangers, none of them looking forward to the holidays.  But a funny thing happens – this holiday that they’d all been dreading (each for different reasons), ends up becoming a celebration of healing and starting over.“Winter Solstice” is not, in my opinion, Rosamunde Pilcher’s best novel.  The dialog often has a very scripted feel to it, especially when it involves the teen-age characters.  Now normally awkward dialog is the kiss of death for any book I happen to be holding in my picky little hands, but not so with this one.  The central themes of this story – healing, starting over, second chances – are so powerful and appealing that I can’t help but adore the book.  The author draws you into the story with such succinct and vivid descriptions of the places and the people; everything comes to life on the page.  The emotions that these characters are experiencing are bound to resonate with almost everyone, and the overall hopeful feeling that pervades the story makes it a wonderful book to pick up if you’re in the mood for something uplifting and life-affirming.  Just lovely, *sigh*.No strong language (that I recall) and no sexual content.

While this wasn’t a bad book by any means, it just didn’t hold my interest.  The characters are pleasant enough but there’s not a whole lot going on here.  This story is S-L-O-W, and it feels like the same scenarios play out over and over again.Brooklyn Harvey is a kindergarten teacher in a small town in the Hill Country of Texas.  She’s been a widow for two years and is living a fairly isolated life.  Feeling like she needs to do something drastic to propel herself out of her self-imposed social exile, she plans to travel to Italy at the end of the school year; she’s not sure when (or even if) she’ll be returning to Hope Springs.Callum Drake is a single parent and his daughter is in Brooklyn’s class.  A former “bad boy” biker, Callum now makes his living creating artisan chocolates.  Callum is all about setting down roots in Hope Springs and giving his daughter a stable childhood.When Brooklyn and Callum meet it’s lust-at-first-sight, but the timing couldn’t be worse.  Brooklyn will have to decide if she’s really and truly ready to “move on”.Callum’s character had a lot of potential.  He’s not a sanitized Romance version of a “bad boy biker”; he’s done some bad things and made some really lousy choices.  But he’s turned his life around and he just adores his daughter.  The best part of the story was seeing them interact; their relationship is just sweet and wonderful.  I wish the story had focused more on Callum.I didn’t’ feel like there was a whole lot of chemistry between Callum and Brooklyn.  From the moment Brooklyn meets Callum she obsessively lusts after him, but it felt like she was just tired of living like a nun more than anything else.  And truthfully I don’t know why Callum was so besotted by Brooklyn, since she is the Queen of mixed signals and half the yummy mummys in town are lusting after him.  85% of the story consists of Brooklyn making up lame excuses to run into Callum and then telling him (repeatedly) that she doesn’t date the parents of her students.  Given the circumstances it’s probably understandable that she couldn’t seem to make up her mind about anything, but I found it tiresome to read about.The writing is solid and there are some sweet moments (mostly between Callum and his daughter), but for a story about a young widow it sure didn’t pack much of an emotional wallop.  Three stars.This book is part of the Hope Springs series, but it easily works as a standalone story.  There are few characters besides Callum and Brooklyn and none of them are really central to the storyline.  There’s occasional swearing/strong language and some brief sexual content (not particularly explicit).*I borrowed this from the Kindle Owners Lending Library

Through deeply personal anecdotes and essays author Barbara Mahany shares her belief that God can be found in the ordinary moments that make up our everyday lives.  Divided into Seasons, this book is a collection of her thoughts and observations about learning to slow down, pay attention and really be aware of what's going on in the moment.While the author is a Christian, this book is more spiritual in nature than it is overtly religious.  Hers is a multi-faith family, and she embraces her husband's Jewish faith and traditions, as well as incorporating elements of the natural world into her belief system.My Thoughts:  I could definitely identify with much of what the author had to say.  We are probably close in age; I'm also a wife and a mother and much of what she writes about is familiar to me.  I'm not a religious person, but I share her belief that the key to happiness and contentment is to find meaning (and joy) in all the "little things" that make up our lives.  If you're looking for practical advice on how you can find more meaning in your everyday life, you may not find it here.  This isn't presented as a "How To" type of book, it's the author's experience.This book reminded me in many ways of Sarah Ban Breathnac's "Simple Abundance".  There are similar themes:  finding the "Sacred in the Ordinary"; "cultivating gratitude"; "living by your own lights".  The new-age catchphrases may not appeal to everyone, and at times the writing was a bit too flowery for my taste.  However, I also found some of the passages to be really lovely - sincere and thought-provoking.Since I knew I'd be reviewing this book, I read it "cover-to-cover", and I don't believe that that's the best way to experience it.  The book is broken down into seasons, and that's how I'd recommend reading it.  Start with whatever season you're in and read a passage or two every day.  Take a cue from the title - "Slowing Time" - maybe the key to finding the Sacred in the Ordinary is slowing down long enough to recognize it when you see it.

I’ve been looking for a pillow to match a cable knit throw that I’ve had for a while now, but every time I find one that looks like a good match the price is outrageous.  This is a pillow cover rather than a pillow (you need to provide your own insert), but it matches perfectly and it didn’t break the bank.The quality of this pillow cover is excellent.  The knit is tight and there are no gaps or pulls in the material.  The seams are finished beautifully and the zipper is truly hidden – you won’t have to position the pillow to cover the zipper side because you don’t even notice it.  The material is soft (I believe it’s cotton) and can be machine washed (though I’d recommend the gentle or hand wash cycle).  I wouldn’t throw this in the dryer.  I got this for around $20 and, considering the quality, I think it was a bargain.*Made in China

This is a concise and copiously illustrated, but somehow dry, paperback survey of all major buildings, projects, and concepts from 1906 to 1963 on only 199 pages published in German under ISBN 3760881238 by Artemis (Zürich) and ISBN 3764355670 by Birkhäuser (Basel...).Following 4 pages with analysis of the architect's style, each of the presented 71 of all 95 life works is headed by a description from as little as just a few lines to over a page long followed by illustrations from one to several depending on the work's scope.  All of 182 only B&W illustrations - at least a half of them technical (plans, sections, sketches, elevations, etc.), but also B&W photos of a good quality - are well balanced, superbly crisp and perfectly legible.  On several pages at the end, there are: biography, selected bibliography, list of works, etc.Like all from the Studio Paperback series, this book holds a solid position among architectural monographs even of a bigger size.  Unfortunately, not published in a slightly smaller format of the similar Works and Projects series by Gustavo Gili (GG) in English and Spanish.

In ISBN 0847812111,  Brunelleschi's early architectural, interior, and structural projects are depicted in excellent illustrations: 6 in color and approx. 200 in black-and-white including many photos as well as plans, sections, elevations, axonometric views, hand sketches of high quality, and models. The ample textual analysis is excellent. It is well published on 175 pages inlc. splendid graphic design, printing on glossy paper, and hardcover binding.FROM FRONT FLAP:Professor Heinrich Klotz, highly influential critic of art and architecture offers, in this book, a unique and fresh way of looking at the beginnings of Renaissance architecture. Filippo Brunelleschi (1377-1446), born in Florence, recognised as the first Renaissance architect, learnt the canons of Classical architecture in Rome. His debt to the Classical tradition and the development of the Renaissance style are not disputed. This book examines his early works, not in their Roman setting, but in the light of Gothic architecture, revealing that the architecture of the ‘Proto-Renaissance’ was not just a Classical revival, but depended on the continuing influence of the architecture of the late Trecento. Brunelleschi’s style is examined in detail, and for the first time the elements of the medieval tradition on which he drew are precisely identified. His position in stylistic terms, precisely on the dividing line between the end of the Middle Ages and the dawning of the Modern Age, makes him the first architect of the Modern era. This book, exploring the historical links between these two ages, makes a vital contribution to the study of the great master of the early Renaissance.CONTENTS: FOREWORD 7PART I BRUNELLESCHI'S STYLE 9I THE COLUMN  11 1. Round and Octagonal Shaft 11 2. The Ground-Level Base 12 3. Repetition and Rule 15 4. The Corinthian Capital 15 5. The Throated Ionic Capital 16 6. ‘Major’ and ‘Minor’ Orders of Columns 21 7. ****½ Silk Vault Slim Wallet for iPhone 5/5s is tub-style, 15 mm (0.6 in) thick, and made of the somewhat soft and shock absorbing rubber with a mat surface, which may show scratches.  The case's walls wrap around the phone's edges and protrude above the display to amortize falls without covering it. The embankments are not very high and do not make too difficult the thumb typing next to the phone's edges, as bad cases do.  A thin layer of soft-touch rubber would be insufficient to protect the phone's back, but here comes the cleverly added-on pocket integrated with the back and protecting it.At 1.1 oz (30 g), the case is lightweight, rounded, fits well in the palm of hand, not slippery, does not cover anything requiring direct access including controls and dock connector allowing charging while in case, and does have very functional protrusions covering the buttons and allowing to feel and press them as without the cover. The bottom's surface is mat and may little attract grime, though it can be easily washed.The glass screen is not easy to scuff or scratch, but protecting it preserves the pristine condition & the resale value. The enclosed screen protector is durable, masks fingerprints, diffuses ambient light, reduces glare, but also clarity, especially of the crispiest screens, due to the finish and the increasing accumulation of the invisible fingerprints, and causes the rainbow effect that might be annoying. It is easy to remove without a residue left.First, read the instruction and clean the surface. Tape the protector's edge (the clear backing down) to the surface edge with an alignment strip or a substitute. Flip the protector over the attached edge, lift the protector's backing starting from that edge, and roll the exposed sticky protector's back over the surface slowly covering it with the aid of the edge of the cardboard packaging or a short ruler. Applying light pressure initially allows easy peeling back for corrections, as the adhesive is sensitive to pressure.

****½ Extreme Max 3006.7228 BoatTector 24" Contour Fender Value Pack is well made, practical, durable, and aesthetic.  The black fender lines constitute good looking accents over the white marine-grade tri-laminate cover with double thermal-bonded seams and corrosion-proof polycarbonate grommets.  White in marine applications works like black on land unless the boat sails in very dirty waters.  It is more practical than black, as it will very, very slowly and gradually aged by getting darker and maybe minimally yellowish while retaining its clean and natural look with distinction.  Black - on the other hand - shows caught grime as a yellow-brown  residue looking dirty.  The 3006.7228 effectively protects 1000-lb boat against a bump-caused damage at the speed of at least 1 mph.  The flat construction prevents it from moving up caused by heaving, unless its amplitude is greater than the fenders vertical height.  Then, traditional, heavy,  rope-made fenders are better.  The black ropes are modern: strong, durable, lightweight, and flexible.

****½ K'NEX 47556 K-Force Double Draw + Target provides a lot of fun beginning with assembling 365 parts into 2 blasters (red and blue) for 2 players active at the time, where some components can be customized into various looks and functionality, according to the step-by-step instruction from the included Construction Book with clear photos, on excellent graphic level, and understandable for older children.  Also the target stand needs assembly, as per the Book, that has options and can be fun.  The same 365 parts can be used to build 1 super blaster for 1 player at a time in 2 variants with a single or double barrel, as per additional instruction available on the manufacturer's Web page in *.pdf files, one of which is over 40 MB and really requires compression to be posted.The set and its type are for visually oriented and methodical children, and not those who could not assemble a simple bookcase from IKEA.  Thus, not for everyone.  The assembly does not require much imagination, because of the detailed pictorial instruction to be rigorously followed, but has the educational value in teaching reading the instruction and translating it into the assembly process maybe accompanied by cooperation between children incl. younger ones playing together with the older, but using guns - not so much.  Nevertheless, target shooting is a great sport and practicing it develops the skills of concentration, focusing, body control, and steady hand.  The blasters and target are well designed, except maybe the load chamber ring somewhat hard to pull entirely, and made from durable plastic easy to clean, but the foam darts are not durable.  Maybe it is, as with cheap printers, where the manufacturer (HP) makes real profit selling the ink.

Ringside Pro Style Training Gloves BG16 are manufactured under the umbrella of Combat Brands LLC of 2012.  They are modern like sneakers in comparison to traditional Ringside Heritage Sparring, with a good design, hi-tech materials, advanced construction, consistent with their low price.  Comparing sneakers to dress shoes is like apples and oranges.  Ringside BG16 are well made, including stitching, but poorly ventilated.  Their average padding provide satisfactory protection when (always) wearing hand wraps.  They are easy to put on and take off with only one hook and loop fastener closing strap attached to the glove and not integrated with it, like in firmer and better ventilated Ringside Arrow Sparring.  Ringside BG16 have a lot of competition from other similar gloves, like low priced sneakers.

Phantom Aquatics GTT20447 Speed Sport Mask Fin Snorkel Set is an almost even set.  The toe is connected to the fin allowing to kick strongly, unlike the fundamental design flaw of separating the foot pocket from the fin called 'Pivot-Flex' and boasted as advantage by U.S. Divers.  The plastics used for the fin are not too hardm flexible enough, and well connected to the pocket in the technologically advanced construction, which is also ergonomic.  Thus the fins are longer, as it is not too hard to drive them similarly to also long Cressi Palau Adjustable. The mask and snorkel are well formed and ergonomic, but slightly inferior to those by Cressi, which Italian design seems superior in detail and elegant simplicity.  The worse part is the cheap black bag instead of a nice and durable carrying case in the shape of a shoulder pack, like by Cressi.

Elixir 14207 Electric Bass Nickel Plated Steel with NANOWEB Coating: 5-String Light/Medium, Long Scale are round wound and covered with high-tech polymer-made, ultra-thin tubes that contact the strings on the tops of the windings only.  This keeps gunk out of the gaps between the windings, frees the all-important winding-to-winding-to-core space from any negative interference affecting tone and elongates tone life.  Nanoweb coating permits optimized string tension profiles, flexibility, superb feel, bright tone, and punch of traditional strings.  The Elixir's promise of the longest tone life no matter what you put them on or how often you play is to be seen, but the Nanoweb coating rather supports it.

Elixir 14782 Electric Bass Stainless Steel with NANOWEB Coating: 5-String Light/Medium, Long Scale are round wound and covered with high-tech polymer-made, ultra-thin tubes that contact the strings on the tops of the windings only.  This keeps gunk out of the gaps between the windings, frees the all-important winding-to-winding-to-core space from any negative interference affecting tone and elongates tone life.  Nanoweb coating permits optimized string tension profiles, flexibility, superb feel, bright tone, and punch of traditional strings.  The Elixir's promise of the longest tone life no matter what you put them on or how often you play is to be seen, but the Nanoweb coating rather supports it.

2-material (strong + soft) ****½ Obliq OBLIQGS6-SMTST01 Dual Poly Bumper for Galaxy S6 has all the benefits of the concept of the strong frame made of hard polycarbonate swaddling the softer, elastic, and shock absorbing, thermoplastic polyurethane tub-shaped bottom, which has a mat surface with a beautiful pattern, and sticks out above both frame edges (on both sides) to amortize falls, but not too high over the screen surface to make it difficult for some to touch the screen next to the edge using the thumb, like some other cases.At 1.8 oz, the case is almost lightweight, but rounded, fits relatively well in the palm of hand, not slippery, does not cover anything requiring direct access including controls and dock connector allowing charging while in case, but does not have very functional protrusions covering the buttons and allowing to feel and press them as without the cover. The bottom's surface is slightly textured and does not attract grime, though it can be easily washed in the unlikely event. The frame's surface is reinforced and metallic.  This Dual Poly Bumper is slightly inferior to Spigen covers, but 3 frames at lower price are difficult to beat.

SmartScoop Automatic Automatic Litter Box is well designed and built of robust parts.  It is easy to assemble and disassemble for periodical cleaning.  After each use, it automatically scoops the waste, lifts the lid, deposits the waste in the bag, and releases the lid, which closes.  So, the closest contact with the waste has the litter, the scooping rake, the bag, and... the lid.  However, the lid is not removable for separate washing.  It can be washed only together with the waste unit after the disassembly.  Soft waste may stick to the rake.  Despite those 2 'minors', the box is very functional and practical.The manufacturer's website features many short instructional videos. The '"How-To" Videos' are titled (where 'SmartScoop' is abbreviated to 'SS'): Watch SS in Action!, Setting up SS, Disassembly of SS, No-Touch Waste Bags, Activated Carbon Filters, Changing the Litter, Acclimating your Cat.  The 'Troubleshooting Videos' are titled: Waste Sticks to Rake, Waste Lid Doesn't Close, No Power, Mode Light Blinks Red, Motor Runs Slow.  They give idea of potential problems, which are easy to remedy when occasionally happen.

SOG F182N-CP Voodoo Hawk Mini has the 2.75-inch long blade of 3CR13MoV stainless steel made by adding more molybdenum (Mo) and vanadium (V) elements to the 3Cr13 formula (of F18-N Voodoo Hawk), which is similar to 420B with .32 % of carbon, 13 % - chromium (Cr), and hardness at approx. 51-53 HRC (Rockwell scale C) after heat treatment.However, the hardness of this tomahawk's 3CR13MoV steel is at only 46-52 HRC, so - 49 HRC on average.  Its economical-grade 420B-class steel is used in budget knives and also in diving knives due to its high resistance to corrosion.  More expensive, 10.5" long Shock N' Awe at 1 lb 2 oz is made of 1055 steel with .55 % of carbon and at 50-55 HRC.  Even more expensive Vox T-Hawk - of SK-5 with .85 % of carbon and at 57+ HRC.  Exorbitantly expensive Benchmade 172 - of 1095 with .95 % of carbon and at 57-60 HRC.Otherwise, Voodoo Hawk Mini is well designed, made, and balanced.  Its handle is flattened and rounded, though not as ergonomic as curved ones also twice its price, such as Kangee T-Hawk and Ranger RD Hawk II at 53-55 HRC, both having the handles more flat and better fitting the palm of the hand.  SOG uses extensively 9Cr18MoV (440B modified) with .9+ % carbon, 18 % - Cr (58+ HRC) for knifes, but not this tomahawk.

This book with the afterword by John Hejduk was published only by Oxford under ISBN 0195020766 and by Warehouse (2nd US printing) under ISBN 0902063308, and contains works from 1966 to 1976 depicted in 370 illustrations on 240 pages. Each work presentation is headed by a short description on 1/4 of its initial page containing also usually the site plan. Then comes a b&w photo on 1 or 2 pages, and subsequently hard-line b&w plans, sections, elevations, more b&w photos, sometimes hard-line b&w 3d axonometric view, various schematics, or even conceptual hand drawings - all of the top quality. Everything is very well graphically designed, printed on semi-glossy paper, and softbound.

ISBN 0195020766 from Oxford and 0902063308 from Warehouse (2nd US printing) contain works from 1966 to 1976 in 370 illustrations on 240 pages. Each work presentation is headed by a short description on 1/4 of its initial page containing also usually the site plan. Then comes a b&w photo on 1 or 2 pages, and subsequently hard-line b&w plans, sections, elevations, more b&w photos, sometimes hard-line b&w 3d axonometric view, various schematics, or even conceptual hand drawings - all of the top quality. Everything is very well graphically designed, printed on semi-glossy paper, and softbound.

The world of travel guides is dominated by two giants: classic, illustrated in color, very detailed Baedeker (since 1839), and more exclusive, profusely illustrated in color, detailed Eyewitness Travel Guides. Lonely Planet (LP) resembles more Baedeker, but Baedeker is better published and handier, has clearer layout and better maps, and its plastic wallet cover holds the guide and map protected in all weather.The *** LP Pocket, like Discover, series is - as this relatively thin ISBN 1742208908 Paris - in full color, but less detailed than the Baedeker, the Eyewitness, or the LP basic series. It has a similar number of illustrations as the 1.25 inch longer and 0.5" wider Baedeker, but fewer than, and not as good as, the Eyewitness, which is 2.5" longer, 1" wider, and thus less handy, but has excellent flexible vinyl bindings, greater number of details, and superior layout, graphics, clarity, and - in general - the quality of being a souvenir\memento.The LP Pocket series including this Paris has covers laminated only outside. For the record, the LP basic series has text detailed comparably to the Eyewitness, however it is not as profusely illustrated and mostly only in 4 colors: black, blue, red, and beige, except a few dozens of pages with photos in full color printed on low quality paper, but still superior to the LP Pocket series.

The world of travel guides is dominated by two giants: classic, illustrated in color, very detailed Baedeker (since 1839), and more exclusive, profusely illustrated in color, detailed Eyewitness Travel Guides. The new improved Lonely Planet is almost like Baedeker, but Baedeker is better published and handier, has clearer layout and better maps, and its plastic wallet cover holds the guide and map protected in all weather.The content of approx. 99 pages of the book is shown by the Amazon.com's "LOOK INSIDE!" function. What cannot be seen is that the LP basic series including this ISBN 1743215703 Ireland has covers laminated only outside, its text is detailed comparably to the Eyewitness, however not as profusely illustrated and mostly only in 4 colors: black, blue, red, and beige, except a few dozens of pages with photos in full color printed on low quality paper.Though the LP Discover series is in full color, it is less detailed than this improved LP basic series, has fewer illustrations than, and is not as good as, Eyewitness, which is 1 inch longer and thus less handy, but has the excellent flexible vinyl bindings, greater number of details, superior layout, graphics, clarity, and - in general - the quality of being a souvenir\memento.

It is a survey of only 16 architectural works of Itsuko Hasegawa published under ISBN 3764356057. It is different than and slightly inferior to more voluminous and hard-/softbound "Itsuko Hasegawa: Selected and Current Works 1976-1996"/"Itsuko Hasegawa (Architectural Monograph No 31)" published under ISBN 1875498559/1854902032 and containing 21/18 works on more photos, and a/no firm profile respectively. In all 3 books architectural projects are well illustrated by excellent photos in color, also mostly b&w plans, sections, elevations, hard line axonometric views, hand sketches of excellent quality, and short text descriptions.FROM PUBLISHER of ITSUKO HASEGAWA (ARCHITECTURAL MONOGRAPH NO 31)Hasegawa graduated from the Department of Architecture, Kanto Gakuin University, the strongest formalist school in Japan, in 1964. Since then, she has challenged the present tendency to analyse in a formalist way. Taki Koji's essay. presents a new and convincing angle suggesting that Hasegawa's oeuvre should be viewed in social terms. Her projects, Koji claims, have the appearance of an aspect of society made comprehensible in the form of architecture'.Hasegawa's work should not be viewed simply as stimulating design; her optimism is evident in her recognition of the potential for society's transformation. Through her dialogue-based programme, an empathetic approach to architecture is made possible.Among the projects featured here is the Shiranui Psychiatric Hospital and Stress Care Centre in Ohmuta, where Hasegawa and the client spent three years discussing the relationship between architecture and medical care to en sure a holistic architectural response. Experimental therapeutic space was achieved through the use of light reflected from the sea which also provided the comfort of the natural rhythm of the tides. Similarly, for the Shonandai Cultural Centre, Hasegawa involved the local residents, allowing for close communication between the design team and the community. Through Hasegawa's reciprocal method of planning, a new, flexible architecture can be provided that accepts a diversity of individuals.

***½ Martha Stewart Crafts Fringe Cutter is working OK, as specified, but requires slow methodical approach and accuracy that is barely achievable by, and thus prohibitive for, the most, like other things by her.  The tissue paper has to be accurately folded twice and accurately aligned with the 0.5-/1-inch mark.  The cutter is quite safe and made OK of sturdy plastic easy to keep clean.  It stores blade covers under the base door.  Removing every 2-nd blade allows to make cuts 1 inch apart instead of 0.5.  It works as intended successfully replacing less accurate action of scissors.

Sentry Fiproguard Plus for Cats contains the same ingredients as the Fiproguard for dogs except the amount of (S)-methoprene is 11.8 % instead of 8.8 %.  So, the cat's version has 34 % more (S)-methoprene than the dog's ones.  The cat's packaging cost (prices tend to change):3 or 6 x 0.017 fl oz (0.50 ml) at $29 or $36-$50 = $569/fl oz ($19.33/ml) or $353-$490/fl oz ($12-$16.7/ml).For comparison, the dog's version costs from:1-22 lbs: 3 or 6 x 0.023 fl oz (0.67 ml) at $14.44 or $16.09 = $209/fl oz ($7.18/ml) or $117/fl oz ($4.0/ml)to as little as:89-132 lbs: 3 or 6 x 0.136 fl oz (4.02 ml) at $15.31 or $15.02 = $38/fl oz ($1.27/ml) or $25/fl oz ($0.83/ml).Thus, the cat's version is up to over 23 times (23289 %) more expensive than the cheapest version of 6 applicators for dogs 89-132 lbs.

All Sentry Fiproguard Plus for Dogs contain the same ingredients for all dog weights and as those by FRONTLINE, but are much cheaper.  Their quantity doubles from one dog weight category to the next, but the prices fluctuate around ~$13, ~$29, and ~$50 without any relation to the quantities (you need to click on all), and they change often.  So, the max. price per 1 fl oz (1 ml) unit is up to 10 fold of the min.  You may find that the price for 3 applicators is the lowest for the heaviest dogs 89-132 lbs, where the quantity is the greatest (0.408 fl oz or 12.06 ml), and the for the lightest dogs 4-22 lbs, where the quantity is the smallest (0.069 fl oz or 2.01 ml).  The prices for 6 applicators may be the same for all dog weights exempt the heaviest.  But you may find that the price for 2 packages of 3 applicators is lower than the price for 6 applicators in the same dog weight category.  Obviously, the most economical are the lowest-priced applicators for heaviest dog categories.

***½ Antec X-1 Cooler is lacking in the design.  The cooler could be wider to cover the entire Xbox One's width, instead of only almost its half, to allow not only to stack things on the top, but first of all to install a bigger fan rotating slower and thus being not noisy, if also its blades' shape was improved to resemble those in the submarine propellers. Such silent computer fans are widely available on the market.  The location of the temperature display and the blue light indicator horizontally on the top of the cooler is unfortunate for those who like to keep their Xbox high on the shelf, because they face up, instead of being located on the front vertical surface to face forward. Also, the exhaust could face left, instead of back, and thus the farthest from the Xbox intake in order to reduce sucking in the hot exhaust air by the intake especially important in closed cabinets. The Antec did cool an Xbox by at least 10 degrees.

ISBN 3764361182 (Renzo Piano) is a concise and copiously illustrated paperback survey on 254 pages of all major buildings and projects from 1966 to 2001 published in English and German side by side. Following a few pages of the analysis of Piano's architecture, each of the presented 75 works is headed by a description from as little as just a few lines to over a page long followed by illustrations from one to several depending on work's scope. All of several hundreds only B&W (many multi-picture) illustrations - many of them technical (plans, sections, sketches, elevations, etc.), but also B&W photos of a good quality - are well balanced, superbly crisp and perfectly legible. The book is ended with a biography, selected bibliography, list of works, etc. on 20 pages. Like all from the Studio Paperback series, the book holds a solid position among architectural monographs even of a bigger size. Similar to smaller books from the Works and Projects series published by Gustavo Gili (GG) in English and Spanish, though lacking this title.

Quite strong ullu SnapOn Grain Leather is lightweight, rounded and without edges, somewhat hard, but still flexible, too thin and compact for good protection (below 1/16 inch), fitting perfectly, not slippery, and has the elegant textured leather surface that will mask marks of use OK, when darker, and not so well, when brighter. The surface is bumpy and may attract grime, though it can be cleaned. The case does not cover anything requiring direct access including controls and dock connector allowing charging without removal, but without very functional protrusions covering the buttons and allowing to feel and press them as without the cover.  It is very simple, if not simplistic, and significantly more expensive than the excellent cases by Spigen (incl. spectacular Spigen Slim Armor in dark grey), and than Speck MightyShell, but worth consideration when the leather incl. its color is a priority.

**** CleanGrow CGWMAXQT Watermax Neutral pH contains 0.028 % of hypochlorous acid as its active ingredient that is quite natural, biodegradable, and environmentally friendly. Hypochlorous acid is a weak acid with the chemical formula HClO. It forms when chlorine dissolves in water, and it is HClO that actually does the disinfection when chlorine is used to disinfect water for human use. HOCl is an oxidizer, binds with calcium and magnesium creating their salts, and as Ca(CIO)2 calcium hypochlorite, or its Mg(CIO)2 magnesium hypochlorite, is used as a bleach, a deodorant, and a disinfectant excellent for water treatment.

For a brief moment, a spoiled, 8-year old and heavy dog was reluctant to eat ****½ Purina ONE SmartBlend True Instinct. But shortly thereafter, when it got hungry and did not have choice, the dog begun eating this dry food and soon enough - losing weight. Its balanced ingredients seem to constitute a completely nutritious diet.  As a consolation, the dog gets a treat to chew or - sometimes - scraps of meat.  At almost $3 per pound, this food is comparable to canned one even that sold at a discount quite frequently in big cities.  Additionally, with only max. 12 % of water, this food is concentrated while canned food can contain more than 50 % of water.  Thus, it is much cheaper and always available hustle-free.

Montana Decoy "Kojo" Coyote is very realistically painted on a cleverly folding flexible material.  It is easy to unfold and works well in scaring animals for a while until the clever ones notice that the position of the decoy has not changed for a day or two, gain the courage to explore the decoy, and discover that it is not an alive coyote.  Thus, it is necessary to move the decoy every day or two to a different spot to effectively drive animals away. But such a limitation characterizes all the static decoys and does not render this one inferior from to the others.  Quite to the contrary.  This one seems to be superior. It is well made, durable, lightweight, and easy to store.

ISBN 0856709603, 1854901788 (Academy Editions), & 0312045263 (St Martin Press) edited by Lisa Green: 266 illustrations incl. 116 in color, 227 ppFrom the Publisher:Richard Meier is one of the world's leading architects, whose formidable contribution both to private and public architecture, has been recently recognized by the Royal Gold Medal. This book presents a comprehensive selection of buildings and projects to date, together with speeches given by David Carson, Kenneth Frampton and Richard Meier himself at the RIBA Gold Medal presentation ceremony in 1988. A unique series of interviews between Richard Meier and Charles Jencks, conducted over a number of years, sets the work of Meier in an historical context. "Essentially Meier belongs to the Modern tradition of Enlightenment thinkers and Le Corbusier's white architecture, even though I would argue his is a late-Modern version of this movement. By contrast, the Post-Modern tradition emphasises creation within convention, public comprehensibility, ornament and symbolism and the reader will see that Meier has attacked this in the interviews and his RIBA Gold Medal Address": [Charles Jencks].

ISBN 0856709603, 1854901788 (Academy Editions), & 0312045263 (St Martin Press) edited by Lisa Green: 266 illustrations incl. 116 in color, 227 ppFrom the Publisher:Richard Meier is one of the world's leading architects, whose formidable contribution both to private and public architecture, has been recently recognized by the Royal Gold Medal. ***½ Stanley interlocking mats are made of high density polyurethane foam, which is much lighter, softer, and better shock absorbing, but also much less durable, than the rubber traditionally used for anti-fatigue utility mats.  The edges are tapered from the 5/8 inch average thickness to just 1/8 inch at the end. The interlocking zipper ends only 1/8" thick seems prone to tearing at the tapered edges.Since quite a long time ago, the shock absorbing property of the floor mats has been added to work boots (sneakers and even sandals useful where hot) by improving their insoles made also of high density polyurethane foam and - if insufficient - also available separately as add-on made of even better gel, e.g. by Dr. Scholl's.  For physical workout, a standard yoga mat is lighter, cheaper, and better, as of larger size in one piece.  As anti-skid work surface, Stanley interlocking mats are also too delicate and inferior to rubber-made ones.

Corel VideoStudio Ultimate X8 is a stable advanced multifunctional video editor in 6 languages now 32-/64-bit that is surprisingly easy to use thanks to the clear and simple interface. It has a multitude of tools for making the video funny, supports the 4K Ultra HD (4K UHD) resolution of 3840 pixels × 2160 lines (8.3 megapixels, aspect ratio 16:9) and 3D/3-D (three-dimensional)/S3D (stereoscopic 3D) media, creation of the video Web pages in the HTML5 markup language, as well as the motion tracking allowing adding text, effects, and objects that follow a moving element. It has unparalleled stop motion capability to create high quality animated movies.Now, VideoStudio renders (processes video) almost as fast as Pinnacle Studio Ultimate and CyberLink PowerDirector, faster than Sony Movie Studio Platinum and Adobe Premiere Elements, but still lacks organizational tools of the Elements, like tags and search for effects or media, and allows just 20 overlay (video) tracks (Elements - 100).VideoStudio performs multiple cuts/trims (e.g. removal of unwanted TV adds) better than the Elements and Movie Studio, shines where it counts, and lags where it does not.

A very good biography of this great writer by Mr. Suchet. I can't imagine a better introduction to her great works and strong character and the way she overcame many stumbling blocks that appeared in her life. I will always treasure this great work!

These were just barely large enough to mount in the center of my Toyota Camry's hub caps. I finally had to order the 65mm set to get the job done right.Also, a couple of these had bad ripples on the edges which badly defaced them and I could find no way to eliminate them.

As delivered, there were a HUGE number of loose and extremely too long brush whiskers that had to be pulled loose and cut off to get the brush in usable condition. They were sticking out all over the place in every direction. Also, the touted tough resin block that the handle mates to had a stud broken off right out of the box! Other wise, once all necessary corrections were made, the broom worked pretty well.

Works great at raking every kind of yard trash including a big bunch of fall acorns all over the driveway. One complaint: the black top of the handle keeps falling off under use. Guess I'll have to glue the thing on to keep it where it belongs!

These little bottles are the cat's meow in quality, ease of use and outright usefulness. They are extremely well designed and built and are tough to boot. Useful in the kitchen, bathroom, bedroom and in the shop. Even using one to spray cleaner on the car to loosen debris for car washing.Will probably order more since I'm already out of empties to put stuff into.

This little series with the GREAT Helen Hayes was another of her outstanding presentations of the great Agatha Christie and was another overwhelming success! I HIGHLY recommend it to anyone who likes well presented and GREAT Christie stories.

I really have mixed emotions about this particular presentation. I, as usual, was overjoyed with Helen Hayes' performance but the appearance of Bette Davis in her waning years was almost too much to deal with. In this presentation, Miss Davis was, as usual doing her best, but was obviously having great difficulty in everything she did due to her having to deal with her VERY advanced physical problems of old age. I left me feeling a great sadness!However, the story line and presentation as a whole was marvelous and the cast was truly outstanding. Another coup for Agatha Christie and Helen Hayes!

As already expressed by other reviewers, this glue is not a good choice for plastics and it should ALWAYS be used sparingly since it REALLY DOES EXPAND in most instances. Also, DON'T let it set-up in the end of the application spout! Always clean out this area after use!This is THE glue to use for things like bonding wood to concrete or leather to leather, etc. I believe that it is the most useful glue for the most applications on the planet but it REALLY has to be used with great thoughtfulness! I have worn sandals almost all of my life and have been sold on Columbia sandals for the past 2 decades. After almost wearing out my last pair, I ordered these to try out. They certainly have not disappointed me, probably because they are of the same design that I am used to. The main difference is that I have grown used to a more firm and maintainable sole pad of molded, fairly firm, synthetic rubber and these have a somewhat padded suede pad of leather-like material. I have grown to appreciate these probably due to the softer foot pad that is extremely comfortable. I like these a lot and will probably order them again if I am still around when they wear out!

My only complaint could easily be solved with just a LITTLE thought by the makers: The electrical cord plug comes all the way out of the end of the handle which leads to real wear problems on the cord's insulated covering for those who would (like me) like to store their saw by standing it on end, possibly in the corner. I'm solving the problem to the best of my ability by wrapping that part of the cord with electrical tape but this won't last long if I use the saw often, which I'll probably do.Other than that, I like the saw and will probably use it often because it performs it's job very well when put to use.I only wish that I had gone a little further in my research when I ordered it and discovered a later model (Sun Joe SWJ802E-RM) that allows changing the cutting angle of the saw blade (at practically the same price). This small and simple change in design greatly increases the use of this device!Also: If you go to the manufacturer's web site to register this saw, there is a very frustrating flaw in the registration process. In entering the serial number of the saw in the online form, you will probably be told that you need to enter more digits than the saw came with on it's paperwork and labels. I was told by phone by one of their representatives to simply add zeros to the front of the serial number until the number is accepted. Works like a charm!

After taking this for only 3 days, I am already feeling and recognizing the good things this can do for my overall health and well being. I was beginning to suffer from constant diarrhea, a roughening and blotchy skin tone, sleeplessness, and overall listlessness. Life was getting to be a real chore and more dreary every day. For the last 3 days, I have taken one of these every morning and another every evening and am beginning to feel like a real human being again. The diarrhea is gone, I am sleeping better and feeling better all over.Starting tomorrow, I will cut my usage down to only one of these every morning and see if any thing changes.I have been doing research on probiotics and have learned some very important things that I believe should be taught at every grade schooler: First is that antibiotics, which are frequently given to people with infections, normally will kill many of the healthy proboitics that we were born with and may times, these just don't come back well. I have also learned that all probiotic pills don't have the same probiotics that we need and the differences can cause the restorations that we need to be sporadic and lesser or more effective for different people. If I don't get a really positive continuation of the effectiveness that I feel I should be getting from this particular brand, I will next experiment with taking another brand along with this one to see if there is any improvement.Will try to keep this review updated with my results.Also: I strongly recommend that everyone who has a good search engine in their web browser, do a search on the word, "probiotics" and do a little research. This has proven to be VERY educatioal for me and my family!
