I was extremely impressed with the special insights we can see into the specific nature of the type of warfare and the service people that were involved in each movie."They Were expendable": This introduces the specifics of PT Boat naval warfare in WW2 in the Pacific theater in the lives of those who participated and the practices and personal sacrifices and actions that took place to make our service in that effort and made us successful."Flying Leathernecks": This also gives us a great introduction into the specifics of aerial warfare in WW2, also in the pacific theater and gives us a pretty fair look into the lives of those who took part and their families sacrifices while the war was going on.All in all, this DVD offers us great insight adorned with educational satisfaction with reality exposed into these 2 special groups of our freedom fighters during extremely trying times for America.

I have a really nice set of car top luggage carriers that had mounting clamps that could scratch the paint on the car when they were clamped on. I tried painting the clamps with silicon glue to protect the car from scratching but the paint proved to be unreliable due to it's ease of rubbing/peeling off under stress. I purchased this tape in hopes that it could do a better job of hanging onto the clamps and stop the problem of paint scratching. This turned out to be the cat's meow in doing what I wanted it to do. The tape has proven to be durable to the frictional wear of the clamps and the car's paint is out of danger. This tape might prove useful in other ways around the shop so I have decided to always keep a couple of rolls in the tool cabinet.Thanks Tressostar and Amazon for saving the day!

For all the bad reviews of this product, it is absolutely obvious that the biggest problem with it is that those who hate it don't know how to order the right product for their vehicle or don't have the thoughtfulness or initiative to properly assemble it and make it work. I have one of these for my 2006 Toyota Camry and it works perfectly and hangs on tightly and well without ever scratching the paint. Yes, it would not have worked so well if I had mounted it with no thought or modifications but I simply added a bit of Tressostar bicycle handlebar tape to the hook of the mounting clamps to keep them from scratching the car's paint and then bent the clamps, by hand, to properly grab the roof at the right angle which was super easy to do.The racks are now very easy to mount quickly and solidly and they never give me the least amount of trouble.I WILL agree that it would have been more thoughtful and advantageous if the manufacturer had included assembly instructions and would have added to the acceptance of their product, but I had no real problem in figuring it out with a little thoughtfulness.Makes one wonder why so many people don't realize why we were born with brains.

Update - 9/3/15:Much to my dismay, this stuff has seriously let me down. I have learned after several uses of the car-top clamps I put this on that it easily peels off of the clamps under stress. IT WILL NOT HANG ON TO THE SIMPLE METAL CLAMPS. I have replaced it on the clamps with simple strips of Tressostar bicycle handlebar tape and the problem is solved; the tape hangs on doggedly and does it's job remarkably well.Update 9/12/15:More negatives experienced: Installed some rubber pads on plastic framing with this over 2 weeks ago and discovered that this stuff was still mostly in the liquid state and not holding on. The way that I discovered this is that I put a little pressure on one of the pads and it simply fell loose. Only the bare edges were even attempting to harden on just a few of the installations. Then, getting the old soft and gooey GE5030 removed to reuse the rubber pads and plastic framing was an extremely difficult chore in which I had to remove it with a very strong paint remover and paint brush cleaner in order to reuse the pads and framing.Don't buy this stuff!!!

Some serious logistical problems here! Package arrived in a cardboard box that was very poorly sealed and one end was split wide open for almost 2 feet. The long metal crossbars were covered with rust. Bags holding smaller hardware were split open and contents were running around loose in the box, It's a wonder that none of these fell out of the split in the box. The so-called 8X11" instruction sheet was crumpled and torn and poked with holes so badly that it was almost totally useless.The long metal top bars had jagged metal ridges on the ends that required a lot of filing to remove them and make the bars safe to handle. The clamping plates that gripped the top edges of the car also had these jagged metal edges that required a lot of filing to assure the safety of the car's paint where they attached. Even after getting rid of these jagged edges, I had to coat the clamping parts of these plates with Tressostar's bicycle handlebar tape to further protect the car's paint at the mount clampinging points. Also had to trim the very rough edges of the rubber mounting foot pads and glue them to the plastic uprights to get them to stay on.Helpful hint: To complete assembly of these 2 racks, after installation of the end tabs that grab the roof, it is extremely helpful to manually and carefully bend them down and in to the point that they have to be manually spread a bit to get them to go around the roof edges of the car. They really need a good spring action to get them to successfully clamp onto the car.Also, FYI: My car is a 2006 Toyota Camry 4 door and after making all necessary adjustments, this rack fits it perfectly and nice and tight. I have NO fear of it coming loose or sliding off under load stress or highway speeds!The real shame of all of these problems is that this rack is of a great and useful design, at least to me. After I corrected all of these problems, this rack is a really useful accessory.

A couple of weeks ago I had to go into the crawl space under my house to check out possible problems with the air conditioning ducts and was swarmed with fleas that I later learned were living on a family of possums that were nesting there. I immediately called an extermination company and had the possums and fleas killed and removed. However, I was severely infected by the flea bites and suffered for over a week with their festering and toxicity. Nothing I tried made the infections begin healing and eventually I did some online research and discovered this chlorhexidine. After a LOT of reading about it, I decided to try it out and ordered it from Amazon. They got it to me very quickly and I immediately saturated a cotton cloth with it and began rubbing it into the festered open sores I had been troubled with. Miracle of miracles; the sores IMMEDIATELY began healing and after just 1 day, there is hardly any sore spot that hasn't closed over and started serious healing. Most of the smaller spots have almost completely disappeared and all the soreness and itching is gone. THIS STUFF IS MAGNIFICENT!I highly recommend that if you have a troubled sore spot that isn't healing well, try this stuff out. I'll never be without it the rest of my life!FYI, My research explained that this solution was perfected by some Veterinarian researchers and was originally intended for animals but it was soon learned that it was perfectly safe for use on humans. I think that I have well proven that belief. Also, the label instructions recommend that this 2% solution be further diluted but I don't seriously believe that further dilution is necessary! I am living proof that it works perfectly well as delivered.

There are several very important things to be mindful of in evaluating this recording properly.1. These recordings were not made in the prime of voice and energy by Mr. Price. Not only had he been having a well aged voice and had been suffering greatly from the end-of life medical problems for a dying man, just the energy consumed in having to go to the recording studios, etc. was radically tearing him down.2. I really don't believe and never will I expect that these recordings were made for my entertainment and for his world of devoted fans. It was an extremely heartfelt GOODBY to his family and to those of us who cared so much for his devotion to us!Yes, he always cared for us and his family during his good times, and I sincerely believe that he gave us the most of himself as he could in order to satisfy our enjoyment of his GREAT and DEVOTED talent in his last days.  Ray always was a giver and part of his final gift to us in these parting efforts reflects what he also thought of us, let alone providing a small amount of final financial comfort for his loving wife, Janie. I now want to use this opportunity to thank him for 'The Good Times' he gave me in just being able to hear his great and caring talent. He certainly will be missed!

The first system scan was fast (only took seconds compared to ESET's half hour) but extremely complete and it was very informative as to what it looked at and what it found.This package comes on very fast at start-up compared to ESET and is ready to go instantly (I used to have a lengthy wait time before I could check my email). It doesn't have all the bells and whistles of ESET but who cares; IT WORKS WELL AND IS FASTER, ESPECIALLY AT START-UP, AND MORE RELIABLE!I got a strong sense of real professional thought and action from the Trend folks during the installation and start-up and am eagerly looking forward to using this software.Update 5/13/2015:Starting with the use of ESET, my internet connection took quite a while. However, I have recently noticed and verified it's continuation, that the internet connection is now instantaneous and flawless every time I start up.I can only attribute this to a possible update by the Trend program which I frequently request. As expected, the install went without a hitch and the system, especially on start-up, is much more responsive.

Let me start with a few comments on posted complaints. For those who are complaining about how slow this little guy is, what do you expect? This isn't a garage size compressor with a 4 inch diameter piston that runs on 110-220 volts! And, of course it's loud! How much would you like to put up with enough insulation to make it run quietly. And, who cares! Who will you be disturbing if you need this on a busy road or highway?Now for a little information for the uninitiated: I had questions about how far the thing would reach with its attached cord and the supplied air hose. If it's any help, I did tests on my 2006 Toyota Camry (a standard size sedan) and there was very ample (left over) power cord and air hose to plug this into the cigarette lighter and fill both front tires and both rear tires. And something left out of the user's directions: To fill a tire, after you remove the tire stem's screwed on cap, you have to "screw" the hose connector onto the valve stem and make sure that it is in straight and tight enough to keep the air from leaking while filling the tire. You can't just push it on and hold it because there isn't enough mating surface to keep it from leaking like a sieve when attempting to air up a tire. The correct set-up procedure is to connect the 12V plug into the cigarette lighter, take the pump and air hose to the tire, remove the tire's valve cap, thread the end of the hose onto the valve stem, clip the air hose connector onto the compressor and then turn the compressor on. When you have achieved the air pressure you want on the pump's pressure gauge, turn the pump off and immediately un-clip the hose from the pump (I let the pressure gauge go about 1 PSI over what I think I need just to be certain that I don't loose too much pressure in disconnecting.).Now to the rating of this little guy! I think that it is the absolute best buy you can make for truly portable insurance for the loss of air pressure under any circumstance. It is small, lightweight, portable and comes with a really neat little bag to tuck it into and toss into the trunk. For it's size and usability, I have absolutely NO qualms about its size, noise, or tire filling time. And, let's see if you can beat the price???An added thought: There are several extra air nozzles supplied and I have found that one of those can be extremely helpful in blowing away debris from trees, etc. that collects in the car's body cracks!!!

When you cannot get it here, get it in Walmart or maybe from La Sabroza directly.  Worth it!  It's usually out of stock in Walmart too, so I order online by the case, going through a bottle per week.  Just for me.As sauce, I use it on virtually everything except breakfast cereal.  It's really great on chicken livers and rice, but of course fabuloso in any version of chili.  Very hot.But best of all, it makes a great drink.  Usually 4 oz sauce per quart of filtered water.  Chill.  Shake to drink each time.  As you probably know, when you add water to hot sauce, it gets hotter.  So the drink is much spicier than the hotsauce itself (which is very savory, alone).  Really great on hot Texan days.(I do the same thing with Louisiana brand hot sauce, but you only need about two ounces per quart.)Sabrozita taste is like half La Morena and half La Costena pickled jalapenos plus tomatillo, very savory.  Life without it, is not worth living.If you like the taste you won't feel like eating, so it saves you cooking time and calories, too.

As someday you'll unhappily learn, Windows 10 takes away all your customization.  EXCEPT that somehow, this little cute program will indeed be the ONLY way you can change or fix desktop fonts, in Win10.  I used it for 64-bit Windows 10 to get the fonts I wanted for the desktop.  Else, no matter what you read on the internet (for the alleged font fixes are all 2014 fixes, no longer work) -- only this works.How?  Well, first you gotta install this on an XP or Win98 or Win95 machine, and create a theme.  Here's the key:  ALL the theme elements, including mouse, wallpaper -- must be in the Themes folder.  So place those things there before you create the theme.  Create the theme and store it also in the Themes folder.  Also, copy the fonts you used to the same folder, in case your Windows 10 won't have those fonts.That folder is inside the Plus! folder post-installation, so post install and post making the theme you'll want to use in Win10, copy the Plus! folder to Windows 10's root Program Files x86 directory.Next, in Windows 10, first check the Windows Fonts folder and see if the fonts you copied over into the Plus! folder, are in Windows 10 Fonts. Go to the latter, try to copy the fonts over, and if Win10 tells you it already has that font, then do not copy.  Else, it will auto copy.Next, still in Windows 10, create a desktop shortcut to THEMES.EXE which is in the Plus! folder, and put that shortcut on your desktop.  Then, double-click on the shortcut, and select the theme you wanted.Now, Windows 10 is borky, you know this by now;  so it won't always REMEMBER the change, nor will it show all the change, but it will remember most of the time.  If it forgets, just double-click on the shortcut again.If you want to change the theme, then you'll have to change the theme in the older Windows machine first, copy all the theme elements and the .theme file you created, to the Themes folder, and repeat the above.PS, this works in Linux too, in much the same way.  After Amazon approves this review I'll add comments with the links and how-to's.

UPSHOT: YOU TURN YOUR COMPUTER/DEVICE INTO BIG BROTHER BY AGREEMENT IN THE LICENSE AT INSTALLATION, IF YOU INSTALL WINDOWS 10.  Never before in history has such a 'license' created such awful terms.  Look in the comments for links so you can see the language for yourself.  I can't put the links in an Amazon review.SERIOUSLY YOU NEED TO SEE FOR YOURSELF PRIOR TO INSTALLATION, WHAT HITLERIAN TERMS YOU'RE AGREEING TO.Installation is also extremely glitchy.  About 50% of the installers' reports I've read, are 'smooth', especially from Windows 8.1.. else, glitchy.  Given the above warning, I spend a lot of time watching how people in tenforums, wilderssecurity forums, bleepingcomputer and even microsoft community, are suffering with installing this horrible new Windows 10.  I do have it, but as an Insider.  I write extensively about it in bleeping computer and vimeo PC World Alumni forum and brainout(dot)net frankforum (latter two are my own), so you can read more there.  It has no confidential data on it, and the hard drive is removable.I personally own 16 Windows machines which are eligible for this thing 'free'.  So obviously if I found it good, would get it for them all, and say so here.But Windows 10, is scary.  First time, Windows is scary.  You'll have to see it yourself to believe it:  at least, I did.  That's why I became an Insider, first.So here, I feel I owe it to my fellow Amazonians to disclose the upshot of this awful installer:1.  It will only allow you to do a so-called 'inplace upgrade' ON TOP OF your current Window 7 or 8, which 50% of the time results in disaster.  People do it, to keep their current programs and settings.  Don't bet on this working.  Even experts are getting it wrong, see the 1st paragraph's forums.  That is also how the free version works.  Just avoid this option like the plague it is.2.  The other option is 'clean install', which here is only available if purchased.  But people who use this, are having really bad luck, and Windows help personnel always blame the seller, so make you go back to the seller.  So here, unless the seller sells you support with the license (and they usually do not), then you shouldn't buy.The problem with 'clean install' is the installer looks for a key.  The key you are supposed to provide, is a Windows 10 key.  The key you get is a Windows 10 key, but the installer often won't recognize it. When you call MSFT for help, often you're told they can't help, you must go back to the seller.  So if they are not the seller, you're s.o.l.More importantly, the license is downright frightening.  It's so much worse than turning your machine into Big Brother, but Microsoft tells you that you agree to let IT play Big Brother on you, even if you turn off all the privacy destroyers baked into the thing.  This is a series of lawsuits waiting to happen.And what do you get for all this?  Nothing you didn't already have.  Frou-frou that doesn't work:  Windows 'Hello' requires a special camera you don't have, Windows Xbox requires Xbox too, Hololens can't work yet, Cortana is a joke, Edge is a gray sheet of paper which gets papered with ads you can't get rid of, your search bar is turned into advertising if you search on the web, you can't get rid of Bing, you can't customize, there is no real Start Menu but instead a vertical version of the Win8 start Screen... and on and on with the nonsense.Oh, and no you really can't revert within 30 days, they overwrite your windows.old folder with the first Windows 10 cumulative update.  Which happens, the day or the day after, you activate.  IF IF IF you managed to activate.Do you really want to go down the rabbithole with Alice and be much poorer afterwards?  I thought not.It gets two stars for two things it does well:  it runs old software and hardware which businesses use (not consumer stuff, business stuff).. really well. I use 1980's and 1990's business hardware and software, and Win10 can work with them.  Consumer stuff, maybe yes maybe no.The MSfanboy proselytizing is at an all-time high.  Which should warn you immediately.  If faith is warranted in God or some product, then it shouldn't need salesmen.  So if everyone's trying to 'convert' you to it, something's VERY wrong with that idea of God or that product.  Right?DISCLOSURE is one thing.  That, you need.  Selling is quite another, and the fanboys never tell you the many dark undersides to Win10.  So...PLEASE DO YOUR HOMEWORK BEFORE BUYING THIS.  Links will be in comments after this review is approved, so you can read the license fright for yourself.

EDIT, 10/29/15:  the Backspace key sticks unpredictably and often, so either i have to change the keyboard settings in Windows 7 to make backspace key non-destructive, or use a different keyboard.  I reported the problam to AramediA weeks ago (it began about two weeks after purchase), and they were very nice, sending me a replacement keyboard and didn't ask for the original back.HOWEVER: the replacement stinks, literally -- like it was soaked in really sour turpentine. So does the original, but only if I put my nose near the keyboard.  Yes, after months of use, and with the screen open, fan always on, still stinks.  The replacement stinks so badly I put it in another room.  Have not yet tried it to see if the Backspace key sticks as well.I have no idea whether this edit will destroy my previous typing, as the new Amazon review system allows no preview.  So hope that doesn't happen.  Shame on you, Amazon, for changing the review input and commenting system. CHANGE IT BACK TO HOW IT WAS LAST YEAR, please.EDIT, 9/17/15:  it still smells like burning plastic (strong chemical smell).  Not quite as bad, but you don't want to be too close.  the Backspace key is starting to stick (so it won't stop deleting), but maybe I can unlock it, or change what it does.  But oh, I love typing on this keyboard, nonstop.Original review, follows below.=======30 years ago, when IBM first came out with its own 'personal computers', its model had a tank for a keyboard.  The things had a very distinct touch and LOUD clack, heavy and big.  And we loved them.This one isn't quite so heavy, but emulates the IBM right down to the pebble finish on the key surfaces, so memorable to an IBM typist.  And hooray, I don't have to look at my fingers anymore, the keys are spaced better than those cramped 'new' keyboards so faddish now!It's big.  It's bold.  It's loud.  And for the first 15 minutes outta da box, it's smelly. But it's a trip down memory lane, to type on it.I'm so sick of black I could scream, so I got this because it wasn't black.  Although, I must have a dozen other keyboards that sit in boxes.  This will be fun to use when the sun's going down and I'm too busy typing to turn the light on. NO MORE BLACK DEPRESSING KEYS, YAY!!!!At the top, also in yellow, are 11 extra keys for multimedia, kinda like the multimedia Dells:  volume, fast rewind and forward, play, mute, sleep button (lol my machine went to sleep when I touched it just now, thought I lost my typing!), Favorites, Search, Mail and Home.  The keys are all the same color and the icons saying what they are, can't be seen too well, so you have to hold the keyboard up against your nose.But they work!I really like this keyboard.  Will rerate to Five stars if it passes longevity test.  I type almost 24/7.  Never broke a keyboard yet.  This one feels like it will last.

Unit being returned, return policy good (UPS will pick it up).  SPARKS came from the plug when I first plugged it in and turned the timer.That method of turning on, is a disadvantage, even if the unit worked.  In other words, the second you close the door (with unit plugged in), the very second you start to turn the timer past zero, the thing turns on.  Maybe you like that system, I don't.Pity, because the unit is cute.  Dimensions in the description are accurate.  No clock.  Sound was quiet.Gonna buy another microwave.

Cloning TipsWD has backup software I never use, but instead these little drives are great for cloning.  What's that?  Well, it's far better than backups, as I'll next try to explain.Linux has a program called 'Clonezilla' which functions as a standalone program for cloning, purchasable in Amazon for $10 or less (CD is better than stick version), or download free at sourceforge dot net (or you can get it in Linux Mint's Package Manager).  A 'clone' is an exact physical replica of a hard drive, which means its files are LIVE and BOOTABLE.  Very much better than 'backup' or 'image'.It is a lifesaver, but to clone rightly, you need a drive the same size or bigger, as the drive you'll be cloning TO.  Bigger is sometimes a problem, because with Linux you don't need much space, and you're better off storing your data separately from the OS.  (They tell you otherwise, but Linux' filesystem is from hell, so the 'home' directory they tout is a nightmare to actually use.  Frankly, the same is true for Windows.)Now you need Linux if you routinely use Windows, as Linux can do better file management, surfing, DVD writing, partitioning than Windows can.  And, if Windows dies, Linux can rescue all your files, correct your boot record (the usual cause of Windows failures), and many other nifty things.  Best of all, Clonezilla makes a LIVE COPY of your Windows system so you can use the files, boot, clone back to your Windows-update-trashed drive when needed.  So when Windows crashes, you just clone back to your drive, and in 20 minutes you're good as new (so long as the problem isn't your hardware). You can do this clone daily at the end of the day, or beginning, while you shower or something.  Thus you always have a fresh live copy of everything.  Hence the value of these little drives, for you can take your computer with you, entire!So you need two Linux distros (can't only have one), and Clonezilla if you want instant repair of all things Windows.  I learned this the hard way five years ago.  The two distros which work the best are Mint (currently 17), and either Fedora or Debian.  These latter two are big-house distros major corporations use, and have glitches, but they are full-featured.  Avoid Ubuntu, if you value flexibility and sanity.  (Ubuntu is only good if you never saw a computer before, or you only write your own program code.  Its graphical interface is vaguely like a Mac, and is very annoying to most.)So to make a live Linux distro, you need Clonezilla (sold here in Amazon or freely downloadable at Sourceforge, just Google);  and, a USB stick (I prefer Kingston or Patriot);  plus, one of these little drives.  Finally, you also need another external drive which is the same size or bigger than, your Windows' machine's drive, if you plan to clone for Windows.The objective is to create an external drive and stick which has one distro(=Linux nickname for 'OS'), then do it again for another distro.  So for that, you download a good distro: Mint 17 is easiest to download, install, learn.  So then burn its iso to DVD, then select its 'install' -- and then the place you install TO will be either the stick, or one of these little drives.  Use the little drive, first.  Make sure the stick is same or bigger than the drive, hence the importance of a small drive, as the biggest stick is still only 128 GB.With Mint, installation is slick and fast, with two simple questions up front and an internet connection:  takes maybe 40 minutes using a stick (faster, if using one of these little hard drives).  Be aware that 'sda' is your internal hard drive's 'name' in Linux, so you don't want that (they order drive names with 'sd' and then in alpha order, internal-drives-first).Note carefully the SIZE of the drive, so you're sure of picking the right one to install TO (again, an advantage of these small drives).  When installation ends, you'll be told and then you can reboot and configure Mint as you choose: you can do taskbars and tool bars and cascading menus with it just like XP or Win7, as well as backgrounds, slideshows, any coloring you like for the menus.  It has an automatic updater, plus a bunch of 'packages' (programs) you can select to install, very easy to do.  Be sure to pick 'GParted' and 'Clonezilla' (search on those names, and the 'package' will come up, witn one-click installation).  Updating and installation of the hundreds of packages will take maybe 2 hours.  It's pretty seamless.After you get it as you choose, then you can use Clonezilla as a standalone (not within Mint), to CLONE the installation you just finished to a stick, so you turn off the machine, boot using only Clonezilla offline; then select the drive you'd just installed to as the source, and the stick as the 'target', doing a 'local' 'device' or 'drive' installation.  This will take a long time, maybe overnight (took me overnight to do it on a Fedora clone of 64 GB).So now, you have one distro on both stick and hard drive.  The stick will run slower, but you can plug that stick into any machine you have, and your machine will stay unaffected.  A real boon when travelling:  say you have an old XP netbook you love, but now you can't use it online due to XP's vulnerability.  No problemo, just stick in the stick:  browsers like Firefox run natively in Linux.  You can still copy files, etc., and many of your fonts/cursors can be recognized and used in Linux, too.Now to the Windows cloning.  You want to clone TO an external drive which is the same size or larger than the Windows root.  So again, you use Clonezilla as a standalone, this time specifying your Windows drive as the source, then the external drive as the target: takes about 20 minutes to clone a 70 GB Windows 7 drive to an external, using Clonezilla.  (If the target drive is bigger, you'll have 'unallocated' space left over, which you can later partition and use in other ways. Linux can partition better than Windows.)Now here's the best part:  you can then take that cloned drive and in Linux (i.e., Mint) using Clonezilla -- clone the clone again, this time to a stick.  That saves space.  Windows XP can boot from the stick thus made, so presumably later Windows can, too.  Aha.  But even if not, you can clone the stick in Clonezilla back to your hard drive.  Great again, if travelling.Enfin, having a small drive for cloning helps you save time in cloning, and makes the Windows messups less troublesome when they occur, for you can always clone back using Clonezilla.So why the second distro?  Because sometimes you have to partition or do other stuff ON the distro which it won't let you do.  So if you have a second distro which is not of the same 'family' you can make otherwise prohibited changes.  Ergo the need for a clone and a second distro, in case those changes go wrong.  I did this with Fedora 22 as my second distro, but it is nowhere as useful as Mint (no Clonezilla, and you have to severally download Gparted from Fedora's 'Apper', which is annoying).  Debian is another choice, but both Fedora and Debian are more complex to install, and Fedora's updating is horrendous.  I chronicled the procedure as 'Fedora 22 installation horrors' in vimeo 'PC World Alumni Group': you can Google on the title, to find the listing.  With Fedora, you do NOT want to have an internal hard drive installed on your machine.  So take it out, or clone the internal drive first.  Fedora writes to that drive, can't stop it unless there's NO drive.Debian is buggy, too.  So pick maybe some other distro, but do pick a second one.  (Mint is a hybrid, half Ubuntu and half Debian.)Now, if you're on Windows 8 there are other problems, as Windows 8 requires a kind of lock on the BIOS so you can't just clone with it as simply as described above.  There are workarounds, but too much has to be said to explain.  So treat the above as good for cloning Windows 7 and prior.  I think your machine has to have 1 GB of RAM for Clonezilla or any Linux distro to work, though maybe some allow for lower RAM (like Puppy or DamSmall Linux, neither of which I've tried).If I'm unclear, yell at me.

Ever notice how website and most other product design has tanked?  As if the designers lost the ability to test and think?  Well, most ethernet cables now are horrible, with that plastic clip at the end usually the worst:  either the clear plastic breaks off easily, or the 'snagless' design elected makes it nearly impossible to put the clip into the back of the modem or machine.This one, is happily better.  The only 'snagless' component is atop the clear clip, which is the only place it needs to be, so to protect the clip from breaking off.  No side 'walls' making it hard to put the clip into modem/machine.My only complaint is that I bought these too small:  at 10 feet, they don't reach very far.  So I'm gonna now buy the 20-foot ones, which come in the same colors.Rated 4 stars only because I've just gotten them, and don't know how long they will last.  Yet at this price for five, who cares?  Colors are as pictured, too.They would be great for travel: when you want real Ethernet, rather than the always prickly, wifi.

Captures the wit and satire of the series perfectly.  Watch this if you're undecided, if you loved the series so far, or if you've heard bad stuff and wanted to verify it, in under 5 minutes.I REALLY wish every great satirist, Juvenal, Rabelais, the apostle Paul, and Jonathan Swift were each alive to watch this!  Heck, I bet even heaven is glued to this series, laughing their heads off!

I have a bunch of these.  They come in black and red, for the 32 GB.  I put Mint 13 on one with full persistence (using unetbootin), several years back (you can clone to them also, using Clonezilla).  Far preferable to the slide or glide version, since the slider gets stuck so it's hard to insert.  These little babies don't have that problem.What also distinguishes these little puppies is their narrowness.  As you might know, on lappies there is often very little vertical or horizontal space between USB ports (esp. on Dell Latitude 6510 and 6530, which piggyback the ports).  So often, when my normally-fav Kingston Data Traveler won't fit, these will.Wish they came in 3.0, but I'll take what I can get.The 'axle' will sometimes pop off, but that doesn't hurt the data or the dongle.  Easy to label, too.I use 'em nearly every day, no complaints about data retention.  Have reformatted them in Linux as well.  If you partition then format these with only 2 GB as FAT16, you'll 'fool' programs requiring only 2 GB for USB boots, yet the remaining partition can still store data (but only Linux can see it).If you're worried about losing them, put a keyring around the 'axle', or pop it off, put on the keyring, then pop it back on again.  They fit well in coin holders.  Sturdy.

EDIT: see below the second set of === marks for comments on the DVD set, which I just got.  Original review below is for buying some episodes ON Amazon.  I also bought the full DVD set as a result, from another vendor.===============..with a nod to the Rumplestiltskin story, a generous dash of Buffy wryness and James Joyce's Ulysses wit.  You know, his book focusing on the inner petty thoughts:'Dang my johnson, gotta get me sum poon tang.'  Or, per the movie, 7+ minutes into Season 4, Episode 2, 'You smell like Dinner': numnuts anti-Vamp guy outside 'Fangtasia', among picketers contra 'fangbangers', says in rejoinder, 'I am a Christian, goddammit'.Or, as 'Jason' proudly says in the Season Five Finale, with his 'dad' smiling on the couch:  'If I want to be a fool, then I will be a fool.  That is my God-given right as an American.'Then there are the sight gags, such as the one, halfway through Season 5's finale, of a vampire receptionist reading 'Marketing Basics' textbook against a wall of partly Greek Bible-mss type script: most of the letters and some of the words are real Greek, replete with diacritics, but some are Aramaic or even Roman alphabet letters.  Just above her head is the (pseudo?) word 'archomonou', which is not in the Bible, = 'archos' (leader) + monos in the genitive='only', play on monogenes in John 3:16.Gems like that abound.  So this isn't your typical vamp show, and the combo of script writing, camera work, direction, acting is sheer genius on so many levels I have to watch each episode several times a session;  each time, I find yet another layer I missed before.Wit like that, is priceless.  This series plays it coy, though.  The satire is slow-cooked, seeping heatedly up through the episodes:  by Season 4 Episode 1 -- an episode I wanna watch over and over and over -- Jonathan Swift, has taken over.  And you got hooked.  :)I didn't think anything could top the Buffy series for varied wit.. but this does.  Though the spoofing begins in the very first scene of the series, you don't catch onto that until later.  If you are considering a career in acting, directing, film editing or production -- you MUST watch this series.Yeah, and after you watch this series, you'll NEVER EVER EVER wanna* view or have sex again,* see ANY naked bodies, even your own;* use the f word,* go near a southern rural area, especially at night;* attend covens, circles, seances, jump-or-sing-or-give-for-Jesus churches, or anything supernatural;* hear that horrific, loud, annoying, ugly opening and closing music, nor the Cajun fake or real or any hillbilly accent sported by the cast;* wear or even glimpse, red.I will personally boycott the opening song and every closing song.  HORRIBLE that they play a minute or two of real episode (no recaps) before that awful song comes on, just as was so horrifically popular in Smallville and Grimm.  RUDE, okay?  Loudness in LCD TVs is much worse due to audio compression.  So you're constantly futzing with the sound.  Probably the ugly music is intended, to match the ugly story line.The series overflows with ALL of the above, and YES it's all necessary to the story (the sex is plentiful, graphic, usually tawdry, ugly, but vital to the story line).  So it's tragi-comic, self-deprecating, at times farcical; how the actors manage to deliver their lines well, I do not know.  I couldn't do it with a straight face.Yet for all that, the series is quite profound.  Frankly, if you carried out the devil's goals in the 3 Temptations of Matthew or Luke 4, the world painted in this True Blood series would result. FYI, Luke surgically tracks and wraps Matthew's Gospel verbatim (see my Synoptics channel on vimeo which shows his style);  then, Luke reverses the 2nd & 3rd Temptation to make the 2nd his chapter theme, re Satan's twisting Psalm 91.  Seems like one of this series' writers, employs the same literary device.  Thus you get, self-righteous silliness abutting animalistic silliness.  Cinched with wry wit, in between: 'So I recommend an iron supplement.. and vitamin B twice daily', says Vamp Bill after drinking a bartender.  Call all that, Satan's 'Modest Proposal'.I absolutely hated the first episode in Season One, but due to the brilliant acting, kept watching, then got hooked.  The plot and acting always stay on the edge of campy, yet so over-the-top with the sex thang, the swearing silly religion thang:  spoofing all of them, yet not disparaging Bible or God.  The series draws a line between whatever or whoever God and Bible really are, versus those claiming to believe in either/both.  Series then mocks and somewhat cuddles ALL practitioners: as weak, frail, scared.. hypocrites.By Season Five, storyline transitions from the small Louisiana town to the big picture of vamps trying to live with humans, and their own political divergence -- yet always with a campy undertow.  Example, its Episode 1, when this shift to macro reaches full steam -- an erstwhile 'Christian' vampire hater screams at his prey, 'Love Me!'  Yeah, and at the other end you have the vamps' own faith, own Bible.. in which God is Vampyr.  Cute play on Lilith myth, too: series twists that myth, just as most people twist Bible.And unlike many reviewers here, I liked the way it ended:  the series' slow-cooked beginning has alike a slo-mo yet surprising, ending.  VERY well done.  Perfect, even.Enfin, this series is often a sympathetic yet honest look at how we all suck 'God' dry and then call ourselves holy.  Very clever.  Some of the other reviews castigate the script writing from Season Five onward, claiming Ball left;  I don't see the basis for their complaint.  Again, Jonathan Swift would be proud.  Or God, for that matter, as the satire here is very much like Bible's own Hebrew and Greek text (i.e., Genesis 1:2 where the Holy Spirit casts Himself as a mother hen, Hebrew verb rahaph).So if you're into political correctness of ANY flavor, do NOT watch this series, as nothing is sacred.  The LGBT community is satirized, as too all straights, religious, or self-styled free-thinkers, moralists, nudists, traditionalists and 'my family my family my family' folk.  The series makes fun of them all, shows up the tawdry nature of all human pretensions and frailties by using vampires, werewolves and other skin walkers/shape-shifters, po' white and non-white trash.  Series is gruesome, hard to watch yet compelling.  I can only stand it, 15 minutes at a time.  But I find myself returning to watch again and again, maxima mea culpa.How much this series diverges from the books by Ms. Harris I don't know, but other reviewers cover that.  What I do know, is that this series is horrific, yet wholly brilliant.  I wish Jonathan Swift were alive to see it.============About the DVD set:It's really each individual season boxed together.  So if you've got the individual seasons, this complete set doesn't offer anything different.  However, unlike other HBO series I've bought (Game of Thrones, for example), THIS one is easy to navigate and has 'hours and hours' of features, just as claimed; plus a handy index, as well as the usual Languages options.  Frankly, the resolution is only 480p even on my 1080p HD TV, and also the Amazon episodes are better resolution even in SD;  that is, using a commercial DVD player.  If played instead on my computer's DVD (Win7), I get full 1080p resolution on the same TV (which is a second monitor for my Win7 computer).  Seriously, if you have a choice between playing this on computer versus on your TV with a commercial DVD player, pick the computer.  The LAG using a DVD player for TV is awful, and you can't bypass the first minute or so of play easily.Some reviewers here claim that after Alan Ball allegedly stopped writing (Season Five was supposedly his last), that the series goes downhill.  I beg to differ.  It just gets better every season.  I've never been so enamored of a series as this, watching it over and over again.  So the above comments about the genius of the series, stand.  It's not really about vampires, but about society.  What Frank Herbert and Isaac Asimov did for science fiction, 'True Blood' does for the vampire genre. Again, how it compares to the books I don't know, nor do I care.  This is one of the greatest series I've ever seen of any kind for its variety of satire and yet profundity.  And despite all the nudity, f words, graphic violence and what most people would call satanism, it never disparages Bible or God, but rather keeps begging the question of AUDITING one's beliefs.  Since the latter is my internet theme (i.e., brainout.net and brainout on vimeo), obviously I would find that undertheme quite important.  Maybe you will, too.  Sometimes you hear the writers talk about it in the audio commentary or the many 'Inside the Episode' vignettes.Nearly every disk has at least one episode with writers or actors talking through it, saying little of importance to the storyline: they instead mostly focus on the technical details of shooting, on the actors and their experience while shooting.  Many episodes, especially beginning in Season Four, have one or more 'Inside the Episode' snippets of up to 8 minutes, often saying little about the story line that you didn't already know; but it's interesting to hear their perspective.Season One's last disk also has 'Beverage ads' in English and French (the French one is quite different and adorable), 'Vampire service ads' and 'Public Service Announcements on 'Vampire Rights' and 'Vampires in America' mockumentary which are kinda cute.Season Two's last disk has 'The Vampire Report' and 'Fellowship of the Sun: Reflections of Light': these are really campy, too, mocking TBN rather aptly and baldly, with rampant misuse of Scripture.  The latter is divided into four subparts.  About 40 minutes' worth, altogether (both features).For Season Three -- which begins the shift to the 'big picture' about how vampires are organized worldwide -- two disks have special features:  Disk 1 (episode 1-2) has 'Anatomy of a Scene', plus 'Post Mortem' running almost 14 minutes (some of the material is repeated), about how they used real wolves and how they effected the 'transformation' into humans.  Also, an interesting audio commentary on Episode 2 with Alex Skarsgard, better than the usual Episode-long (nearly an hour) audio commentary while the full episode plays, despite the fact most of the comments are about the technicalities of shooting.  For these commentaries, it's a good thing to turn subtitles on.  Yes you can have English subtitles though the language selected for play, is also English.Season Three's last disk contains bonus features on fairies and a commentary about Season 4 (sum is about 3.5 minutes), under the label 'Post Mortem',  plus some 19 minutes of (six) 'minisodes' which seem like deleted scenes: they are really good, too, filling in some minor plot holes which got glossed over during Season Two and Three.  Plus, Snoop Dog's 'Oh Sookie' 3-minute music video (not my taste, but maybe is yours).  The fairies' bit you can also watch for free in Amazon;  see the bottom of the Season 3 page in Amazon.Season Four, besides the usual audio commentary, the last disk of the season has 'Inside the Episodes' of about 10 minutes.  Also, there's a 28.5 minute segment called 'True Blood: the Final Touches' on the post-production work in the series.  It's useful if you're interested in how movie/series are made.Season Five and Six's disks continue that trend;  the disks have audio commentary and most have up to 10 minutes of 'Inside the Episodes'.  Amazon has some free specials for Season Five which I didn't find on the DVDs.  No bonus features are listed on the disks.So too, for Season 7.  Its ending Episode 10 disk is followed with an Epilogue 'Farewell to Bon Temps' as a Bonus Feature, with Alan Ball and each of the major actors talking about how the series affected them.  It's well worth watching, and runs 28 minutes.As usual, the folks who made the casing (those awful hubs which make you PRY the DVD so you're likely to break it);  they did a poor job of the navigation options for DVD players, but are great and fast, if you play on your computer.  Even so, these DVDs are far better than the Game of Thrones DVDs, and unlike the latter hallelujah you DO get Scene Selection (missing, from GoT Season 4, for example).Thank you for your time!

There's a reason why this edition is free:  Gibbon's Greek notes or quotes are instead transcribed as "[GREEK TEXT]".  Never get Kindle for anything to do with Greek or non-Romanized letters.  Frankly, Kindle has gotten much worse over the last two years.  As if the people working there hated their customers.  Kindle's interface is horrible, now.  You can no longer copy or use it for citations you can paste into your research, and if you complain (good luck figuring out how to send them a messasge, and NEVER use the forum, it's populated by vultures) -- if you manage to complain, no one listens.  I SO regret all my many Kindle purchases.So I guess now they gotta give it away;  pity, because the original Kindle program five years ago, was to die for: a real boon to researchers.In Ebay, I'm bidding on a CD version of Gibbon (already have two hardbacks and a full set on 3.5" floppies).  Hopefully it will have the Greek notes.  I've asked the seller who is in the UK for confirmation.  When I get it, I'll annotate that here.

This just arrived today.  I opened it as fast as I could, for life without cilantro, is not worth living.  Since I keep forgetting to buy it fresh in Walmart (which I freeze in the bag, so it will crush easily) -- having this baby on hand is a godsend.  So as I started to say, I opened it quickly, put some in my palm, touched tongue to palm, and.. heaven!The normal 'lime' version is 'meh', but this stuff has VERY strong lime, garlic, and especially cilantro, taste.  I didn't expect dried cilantro to be so flavorful!KEEPER, will keep buying, too.

Although Kevin Spacey is one of the best actors on the planet, he can't save this detestable Americanized remake of the original BBC version starring Ian Richardson.  Script in this American version is boooorrrrriiinnngg and lacking the rich detail of the original.  I forced myself to watch it.  The key lines in the BBC original were replicated and POORLY.  Direction was absent, the dialogue was hackneyed.  The opening scene with the dog and the 'aside' (drama term where the actor talks directly to the audience, also used in the BBC production) was the only good one.Lackluster cast, but then what kind of script do they have?  Garbage.  West Wing this is not.  Seriously, I had to start and end and start the video over and over like a C-grade movie you tell yourself you must finish because you paid for it.  Fire the scriptwriter, fire the director, fire whoever handles the sound because it's bad, nearly inaudible.  And God bless Kevin Spacey for living out his contract.  Every day I'd regret signing on, were I him.Final Cut?  Bleh.  The BBC ending of the same Final Cut title is to-die for.  This American one, who cares.  So this American is very disappointed.

Some months back, I got these and also nolie's naturals, to compare which was better, since nolie's is about 30% more expensive.  The price difference, is due to nolie's having more ingredients that ease vascular constriction (chiefly horse chestnut, bilberry and avena sativa).  So I bought the extra ingredients here in Amazon, then added them to this Harry formula, to see if there was a difference both with and without, the added ingredients.  Versus, the nolie's.Yet the nolie's still worked better, even though I doubled the Harry's dosage with the added ingredients doubled as well.  By this time the Harry pills, coupled with the added ingredients, were more expensive than nolie's.  Even after a month of use, the Harry version here, was less effective.  But the nolie's, though more effective, wasn't quite good enough.Disheartened and in desperate need of a solution, I doubled the max mineral oil dose (which is usually listed as three tablespoons) daily for a week, and stopped pills entirely.  That high a dose of mineral oil worked, and well;  but it took a week or more, to seep through.  Prior, I'd tried the pills in combination with lesser mineral oil doses daily for some weeks, to little effect.Notice that since fecal impaction from constipation is the CAUSE of hemorrhoids, the 'rhoids themselves should shrink over time, due to lack of straining.  So no surgery, certainly worth a try.  The only caveat is to take the mineral oil on an empty stomach, lest fat soluble vitamins like A and D, be rendered invalid.  So take at bedtime: or eat at least an hour afterwards, so these vitamins will absorb.Google on 'I always feel bloated', which is the primary symptom of fecal impaction, meaning stools don't pass because they are too dry (need to drink much more water); or, because you're not eating enough fiber.  The problems can be antithetical;  if too dry, then eating fiber makes the problem worse.  Gets to where you can't eat solids anymore.  Since hemorrhoids come from decades of prolonged constipation, hemorrhoids are considered an old person's disease.So fecal impaction can be decades old, won't be noticed until severe.  That was my problem (heh, I'm full of doo-doo, it figures).  So try smaller mineral oil doses for a week, see what effect it has.  Try senna also in small doses, daily.  They build up; only if you get no results after a week, should you go to the high levels I did.  And of course, don't do anything without consulting your physician.

I was going to return this.  Providentially, when I started the return and then waited TWO DAYS for UPS to pick it up and they didn't, I then changed the return to my taking the thing to a UPS dropoff.  Since that would cost more in my time than the pitcher, it then seemed best to buy the cheaper Mavea filters, which apparently lack the foibles of Brita filters (actually both have the same flaws, but Brita is more expensive).So just now I cancelled the return, and here's how the pitcher needs to be improved:1.  MAKE THE HANDLE SOLID, not hollow:  mold will accumulate in the hollow handle, in six months or so.  Since the pitcher is wildly overpriced, that's too much expense for something going bad every six months due to poor design.  To stave off the mold, only use the pitcher to make batches of potable water you'll store in other containers, so the pitcher can dry out.  The filter will have to stay wet, but that's an easy task:  just put it in a large-enough jar or glass you can cover and keep in the fridge.2.  Make the Pitcher wider and shorter:  the style is quite ungainly and heavy.  It's only good for filtering water, not for using the pitcher.  Horrible to use, but the filtering works well.  So change the SHAPE, somehow.3.  Make the pitcher out of more pliable plastic: the current plastic used, is brittle and smells.  YES you have to wash the pitcher and resevoir with soap upon removing it from the box, the smell is overwhelming.  Brittle plastic and the ungainly shape combine to make for easy breakage.  So why not redesign the plastic to be the same as for distilled water, with a shape like a gallon of that water, commonly sold in stores?  You just need a wider mouth.  Again, because the pitcher is so overpriced, keeping the current design will result in revenue loss to Brita.  For sooner or later, people will get sick of the hassle and cost.Time is money.  At some point the time spent using the pitcher will outweigh the small savings versus buying and lugging gallon bottles of distilled or 'spring' water.  But for immediate gratification, and if you use the pitcher in batches to make 'clean' water you then transfer to other bottles, it's useful.  (The filter can be submerged in a smaller jar between uses.)

Houston water is notorious for being over chlorinated.  Same as Los Angeles water, Chicago water.  So I had high hopes this filter would work.  Granted, I've only done the three-initial-rinse throughs (product description claims you don't need these, but filter box descriptions says yes the first two or three must be poured out or on plants.  The fourth is sitting now and no discernible reduction in chlorine when I tasted it.Will let it sit an hour, see if that makes a difference.  EDIT:  it does make a difference.  For the test, I submerged the filter in a spouted, glass milk/beer pitcher (you know, the kind used in US restaurants, back in the 1970's).  It didn't make a lot of difference, but it made some.Then, because I still have a Brita pitcher I was going to return, I put the Mavea filter into the Brita after having washed the pitcher (and yeah, it needs washing, smells horrible right outta da box).  At first, I just filled the pitcher with the pre-filtered water, not reading the instructions.  No difference versus submerged.  So, I emptied the pitcher.  Then, I READ the instructions, and only filled up the resevoir in the top of the pitcher, as per the instructions.  This is a much slower process, for the water in the resevoir slowly drips down into the pitcher.  At which point, YES there is a big difference in taste.So now I'll go back to submerge and do it longer.  For that pitcher is awful: too big, too heavy, plastic too brittle, and the handle is HOLLOW so eventually it will crud up with mold.  For you have to keep the filter wet.  So I'm thinking constant submergence is better, anything to avoid that badly-designed pitcher.  Will report back later.

EDIT, 5/31/15:  I now have three of the 128GB sticks.  Also, I've now read the other reviews and I think I can explain why there are complaints:A.  No 3.0 flash drive works at that speed unless it's put in a NATIVE 3.0 port.  By NATIVE, I mean 1) the Anker 3.0 hub you can buy here at Amazon, which I used to test, and why I posted my initial 'Lightning' review (below), or 2) the actual port in the machine itself is 3.0, i.e., in a Dell 6530 (which has a 3.0 port).  It might also work with the 3.0 cards you can slip in laptops, but I didn't test that.  See:  if the hub is separately powered from the computer and itself is all 3.0, then you get 3.0 speed from the drive.  Else, you don't.  The slowest 'connection' into the machine is what governs speed, not the stick itself.  So if you used a 3.0 hub separately powered, but a 2.0 extension cable, then 2.0 is what you get.  If the ONLY connection between stick and machine is 3.0, then  you get 3.0 speed, which is lightning on this drive.Example:  I had to change webhosts for my brainout.net domain, and download my entire domain from the old host to the new one on this stick.  It was what prompted the 'Lightning' review, because that's how fast the transfer occurred.  I was shocked.B.  To make a bootable flash drive in Linux is tricky.  It's not the fault of the flash drive, but of the distro.  First problem is to get persistence, which so far I've only gotten with Mint 13 (which thereafter won't recognize '/cow' but does have persistence anyway) and with Fedora 17.  Both of those distros are now outdated, but not only do they work fine (esp. Fedora, which has its own proprietary program for making a persistent stick), but you can CLONE them with Clonezilla.So that's really the better avenue.  Create a new distro or clone your hard drive with the distro of choice -- use a genuine external HDD for that.  Then, clone that hard drive TO the stick using only Clonezilla (not via the distro).  It takes ages to clone because Clonezilla isn't equipped for 3.0 transfers;  my 64GB clone took overnight.  But it works fabulously.  In fact, that's a big reason I bought three of these puppies, I plan to clone my existing distros onto sticks.  But the catch is, due to Linux limitations you first must INSTALL to a regular external HDD. After you do that, futz with the options to customize it to your liking, then clone to a stick using only Clonezilla (again, you can't be in the distro to clone).So:  I installed Mint 13 to an external HDD, then customized it to my liking, then clone to the flash drive.  Any flash will work, but this one is easier to use and has a smaller footprint.  Remember when cloning, if you clone to a stick, make sure the drive you're cloning from is smaller than the stick.  You'll have unallocated space left on the stick, which you can partition using GParted, afterwards.  Hope this helps.C.  Reports of the flash not working aren't due to the flash but the need for the USB port to be flushed out.  I must own 25 or 30 flash drives, and all of them at times seem not to work, until I put them in another computer or wait some hours.  Then they work just fine.  I think it's a problem with the USB port not accepting a flash drive which has too quickly been in another machine.  The problem is intermittent and I'm not sure that the CAUSE of the problem is what I say here. I'm only sure of the remedy, which is to wait and insert, or reboot the machine and insert, or take it out and wait 10+ minutes and re-insert.  This is a big problem in Windows, so maybe it's not a hardware problem?Original review follows below.====================I really didn't expect the 3.0 to be much better than the 2.0 for this 128 (really 115) GB size, but the 3.0 is definitely faster.  That's only true if plugged into a 3.0 USB, however (I used Anker 3.0 external USB hub, available here in Amazon).  So if you don't have any 3.0 USB ports on your machine, you'd be better off with a 2.0 stick.Then again, this one is cheaper, too.  The cap fits tightly on the 'green' end when you need to use the drive, and also tightly on the USB portion when you want to protect the dongle.

When in the first 30 seconds of the film you find blatant disregard of Bible, then it's time to stop watching.  Examples:  per Bible but contradicted needlessly in the movie, JEREMIAH found the Bible in the Temple, and he was an ADULT, not a child.  He was already at least 20 years old when called by God, and Josiah had just turned age 21 (13th year of Josiah in Jer 1:1-3 plus 2 Kings 22:1 says he was 8 years old upon accession, which also means the kingdom was badly run).  Hebrew na'ar means a man of MARRIAGEABLE AGE not a child, Jeremiah 1:6.  He was the son of the High priest who was so dang dumb about Bible, Jeremiah's father didn't even know what the book WAS and had to ask Huldah the robe cleaning lady about it, 2 Kings 22 again.Saddest thing is, the Bible's story is a lot more juicy.  Jeremiah was called by God to eschew the High Priesthood which as a son of Aaron he should have become, his own father who was the High Priest was a dufus, and collaborated with the dufus king to put Jeremiah in a SEWER ('cistern' is the translation, and that's such a coverup!) -- so the father was against his own son. Unlike the movie naturlich -- Jeremiah had no lovers, no love interests, only God, see Jeremiah 1.  So the story claiming he had a romance was just invented. The truth was far more juicy for a producer to sell:  they used to have male prostitutes in the Temple for crying out loud (a practice instituted under Manasseh, see 2 Kings 21-23 and 2 Chron 33-35).So any smart producer would make more money by actually telling the BIBLE's story, rather than twisting or ignoring what it says.  Yet instead, a flop is made, like this movie.  Nearly every Bible movie is a flop production.  Just as no one ever makes a decent movie about Passion Week, which PER BIBLE shows FOUR DAYS OF SEVEN TRIALS between 10 and 14 Nisan (March 31 and April 3 each year, generally, going by Exodus 12, SOLAR YEAR never lunar and nothing like that insanity they call 'Easter computus' which is as anti-Biblical as it gets) -- a Mosaic Law timing which when He died, went from 'deemed' passover to actual Passover because they didn't intercalate.So not Biblical though alleging to be Biblical, and not a good production: hackneyed script, staging, characters, amateurish camera and directing.  It gets two stars for the actors, like Vince Regan, Klaus Maria Brandauer, and Oliver Reed.Enfin: believe or don't believe in Bible, that's your free right.  But if you claim a Bible story then you'd better use the Bible to tell it: for anyone can check your story, and if you didn't use the Bible, all your own credibility dies.  Even a brainout then knows you were incompetent -- or dishonest -- in making the movie.  Lots of revenue lost as a result.

Just give up on any movie ever being even remotely like the Bible;  for example, Bible NEVER SAYS that when the Rapture happens, millions of people will just disappear.  Instead, Paul laid out a 'time map' for Church in Ephesians 1:3-14's Greek which is so grim, the picture at the end is that there are few Christians left, when Rapture happens: a kind of winter of discontent, in Eph 1:13-14.  So it happens, because no one will believe, anymore.  I've been documenting how you can prove all that since 2010, see my vimeo paulmeterggs11 channel and watch the videos in order: they go through the Greek text and the FUTURE HISTORY (relative to AD 58) until Odovacer.  For by then, Church is so stagnant, believers are few.  That was back in AD 476!  All the NT books are on the same subject, too, 'tagging' the Ephesians timeline with additions (most notably, in 1 John and Revelation).  Been doing videos showing that, and have only just started proving the text.UPSHOT: Bible's own version, is that almost no one is left, to Rapture (not like English, 'rapto' in Latin means to SNATCH UP VIOLENTLY, translating the original Greek verb harpazw in 1Thess 4:17, one of the better-known Rapture verses).  Instead, Revelation 11 says that on the first day of the Tribulation, two JEWS show up at Temple to protect the Holy of Holies from anyone entering, with the power to withhold rain, throw fire, all that stuff no one ever believes.  THEY announce what happened, along with an angel flying at high noon.  John writes Revelation following Aristotle's Poetics, so creates what back then would be called a quadrilogy, three tragedies and an ending comedy (as in happy ending, not haha).  So the Greek readers understood him well.  We stopped teaching our kids to read Greek of Bible within 100 years of Revelation's writing (back in AD 88 per John's own dateline in the book).  So we do NOT know how to read it.  So all our Bible movies about 'the Apocalypse' are completely wrong.So if you want to make a good story everyone will disbelieve anyway, then pick the Real Bible's Real Story.  Not, this junk.Even so: if you ignore the fact that this movie -- like every other Bible movie ever made, just repeats Bible words, and in reality has little to do with Bible -- if you ignore all that, you'll find this movie thought-provoking at a basic level:  does God exist?  If the God of the Bible were true, and if mankind was sick of Him 'not showing up', what would the world want instead?The entire Apocalypse series is amateurishly shot (cameraman maybe was badly directed), middling to great acting, hackneyed script.  Left Behind should be left behind in the trash, for the writers wouldn't know Bible if it bit them;  and, for the most part, so should this series: but the acting is worth watching.  The actors did well with the poor material they had.Judgment itself, is a bit better than the rest of the series, as it aims to also be an amalgam of two very good shorts:  Twilight Zone Season 2 Episode 29 'Obsolete Man' (which Prime members can watch for free online, Amazon Instant Video) and another great oldie starring Vincent Price as the Devil, called 'The Story of Mankind'.  You'll notice that the main 'stage' in this movie, 'Judgment', is about the same.  So kudos to the writers or director for at least nodding to those other two movies.  Much of the bad script can be forgiven, as it too is like those oldies.Able acting all around, and thank God this time Nick (hahaha nickname for The Devil) Mancuso didn't go over the top with his acting (and maybe he was directed to be so goofball in the rest of the series, so just did his job).  So it's worthwhile to watch THIS film.  The others are too childish and anti-Biblical to be of much use.Bible's story, however, is actually quite political, as Bible is always persona non-grata even as God and the Jews always are: which of course begs the question, why THEM more than all other religious claims and ideas and books?  Aha.  So maybe this is the right story the actual truth? But it's not a nice or comfortable story, and if the truth, it's one any sane person would want to disbelieve, every day.No Christian can tell the story rightly, and as a Bible addict who makes videos on the Greek and Hebrew (in vimeo), I'm not sure I can either: for it takes YEARS of understanding the real Bible, to even know what the story.. is.  You can know the story, but telling it rightly is another kettle of fish.  Essentially, God lets you decide if you want Him or not, but if you do, then you have to understand that He's Righteous and you are not, so BELIEVE HIS SON PAID FOR YOUR SINS and you are forever saved from hell, when you die.What recommends this movie is that in the mouth of Corbin Bernsen, that last sentence was made clear.  First Bible movie I've ever seen which actually repeated the Gospel, correctly.  Hence 3 stars, minimum.Okay, but what about your life down here?  Seems like God doesn't get involved or care.  That's not true, but you don't know that.  Sooner or later, it should occur to you.. to ASK the ceiling, as it were: and that's when the answers begin.  You are to learn this old book (great lines about 'old book' in the movie), and it seems utterly irrelevant to your current life.  Just the opposite is true, but you won't know that until you've spent a decade or more learning that Book.So then, the premise of this movie, is quite apt:  WHERE IS GOD?  If He really exists, really paid for your sins, WHY WON'T HE SHOW UP?  Yeah, good question.  And that, dears, is the heart of this movie.  It never answers the question, either.  People ask the question daily, too: complaining.  So, they don't get answers.  We Christians have answers no one wants.  And we don't know the answers any too well, as we like everyone else, don't really ASK as we should.So maybe watch the movie just to see the QUESTION, and then maybe ask yourself if you too want the answer.  If not, then not.  But there are consequences.  You know what they are.

Seems like a drunkard or someone who likes imagining us spill coffee, made the cannister.  The old style was a barrel grip, nice and sturdy.  This new one you can't grip, too shallow at the handle.  Of course, the cannister is also 6 oz smaller, so you've lost nearly 20% of the coffee.  So the price is effectively hiked 125%.  Which would be fine, if the grip were the old barrel style.Genuine dark roast, a tad bitter.  Again, worth rebuying were it not for the grip-to-slip cannister.  BTW, If you left the coffee on too long or it tastes a bit stale/bitter, add a dash of True Lime to the pot (then let sit and swirl for a few second), http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001Z2O0T4/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 .

These are well-made hooks, and underneath they have little 'pads' to mitigate against sliding, but your drawer or cabinet might still be too thin.  You can instead cut small amounts of kitchen liner, fold over where you want to hang the hook, and then hang the hook on the kitchen liner.Sample of what I mean by kitchen liner, is here: http://www.amazon.com/Duck-855145-Non-Adhesive-12-Inch-20-Feet/dp/B0027P9516/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1422583094&sr=8-2&keywords=kitchen+linerI wish they'd make these in light colors, since most of us don't like dark kitchens or bathrooms, so don't have dark cabinetry.

I love Corelle, and especially these pasta bowls.  I use them two-at-a-time in the microwave, constantly.  You can put a full leg of chicken in the lower bowl and then 'top' it obversely with the other, and microwave.  (Really quick meal: squirt mustard, catchup, soy/Worcestershire sauce over the frozen leg, mix them a little, nuke for 10 minutes.)  Don't be too careful about fitting the two bowls on each other, leave the top bowl a bit 'off' so air can escape during microwaving.They are essentially non-stick, they stack well, position easily in the dishwasher, are practically unbreakable.  I think they are oven safe to 350 degrees, but haven't tried that.My only complaint is that Corelle doesn't offer them in solid colors.The seller packed them right on top of each other, only the label on the bottom (easily removed), and no cardboard in between.  They were just fine!  Easier to unpack, than in Corelle's own packaging!

I'm an over-the-door addict.  I hate having to look for stuff, so I hang things on every door, back and front, so I can avoid having to buy furniture to store it in.  So my domicile always looks like a warehouse, but I don't care.  However, if you do care, then you can save space by hanging stuff on doors you don't want normally visible.  You do not have to use these hangers, merely for wreaths.  They hang lower, so you can cantilever the objects hung, and thus save space, versus the normal over-the-door hangers (of which, I must have every type, dozens of them).  So you can hang a bag of plastic bags behind a door on the lower hanger, or even a thick mouton coat (which I just hung on THIS hanger, and it works better than the usual wreath hanger).The normal 'wreath hanger' you can find in Dollar General or other stores, is far less sturdy.  I have a bunch of them.  The hook is much shorter, and the metal much thinner.  By contrast, THIS hanger is about twice as big a hanger at the curved end, twice as thick in the metal, and still the door closes well.  Since now the trend is for white doors, it's unobtrusive, too.Bought two, gonna buy more.  Keeper!

What the average person 'knows' about 'Rome' is usually restricted to wildly-inaccurate but popular movies like Gladiator, or the Bible movies like the Robe, Quo Vadis, Ben Hur, etc.  The actual life of Romans in Rome was considerably worse, and Rome itself was a swampland.  The gases must have inflated the egos of those who scrambled up its seven hills when the malaria (yes, mosquitoes) became too much late summer, for those seven hills birthed a crazy populace like nothing you can imagine:*They PRIDED themselves on not working, the reverse of their origin as a people.*They PRIDED themselves on taking what didn't belong to them, as if the success of thievery, proved them virtuous.*They PRIDED themselves on not being able to count time and years properly.*They PRIDED themselves on silly superstitions, like unlucky days, and whether a liver pointed in a 'bad' direction, or eclipses;*They PRIDED themselves on living over swampland.*They PRIDED themselves on myths so stupid, you know the people were crazy, viz, that their PROUD ROMA came from two boys suckled by a she-wolf??And how were they able to do this?  Simply because the lands they took over, each had a populus which was far nuttier!  So by comparison, the 'Roman' values were superior, and people flocked to those values.  So Rome won the peace, and Pax Romana was born just in time for Christ's arrival.  Few believed in Him, of course.  But the course of history per Bible, is that this attempt to 'Romanize' will continue, so if you're a believer in Christ, you gotta get a handle on this Rome thingy.  If not a believer, it's still a provable trend of history in your own land in your own day, which echoes in everything you do and all the media, you consume.And what you then find, is this:  We are just as crazy as them, when we laud their history.  But study it we must, because it's the same crazy set of values the world holds dear, now.  All the wars of the 19th-20th centuries, are due to someone trying to go back to those 'glory days of Rome', with Adolf Hitler in particular, monitoring Speer's attempt to reconstruct those buildings.Something about this insanity captures the human heart.  So what was it?  You can't find the WHYs in the typical tomes by the greats like Gibbon, Mommsen, Bury or Cary.  You can only find that they too were enamored.  Indeed, those chronicling Rome at the time, who were themselves Romans or Greeks nearly of the same periods, are also enamored.  So look:  Gibbon wrote in 1776 (first edition of Decline and Fall), but Tacitus wrote in the 2nd century;  the praises of Rome by Romans and others are all over the historical map, proven in stone and bone and blood as you study why oh why did these people fight, and the vanquished, get converted?  So clearly the WHYs are important.This extremely incisive book helps you see the reality Romans lived on a daily basis, and helps you understand the WHYs.  It's not attempting to do that, but instead to do what a movie intends to do, to RELATE your own life 'now' to their life 'then', so you can identify.  So, the book is simple and short, good reading on an airplane, and good to keep afterwards for epitome (summary) reference.If you can't stomach reading, then rent/buy the miniseries ROME ( free for Prime Members, http://www.amazon.com/Stealing-from-Saturn/dp/B006GLM9OM/ref=sr_1_1?s=instant-video&ie=UTF8&qid=1422428768&sr=1-1&keywords=ROME ) .  It's an eclectic mashing of the culture, for some of the things depicted don't belong to the time period of the storyline, but even the storyline is helpful (though largely fictional) to help you grasp the culture of the day.THEN go read any of the books of better repute (CARY being the next-most-incisive author I've found,  http://www.amazon.com/History-Rome-Down-Reign-Constantine/dp/0312383959/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1422428930&sr=1-1&keywords=Rome+Cary but you can find earlier editions elsewhere) -- bearing in mind the cultural underpinning of daily practice you got from this Cowell book.  For here, you get the living conditions and hence the mindset.  So when you read the more scholarly tomes (though this one exhibits that quintessential scholarship of an INTEGRATED appreciation of the whole) -- when you read those other tomes, you can read them 'as if' a 'Roman', yourself.The only reason this book gets 4 stars is that it's too short, but maybe Cowell wrote a sequel.  I must check into that.  Great read, great writing style, can't put it down.I've compiled a bibliography of contemporaneous and current Roman history tomes which are all readable on the internet, which I'll put in the comments.

I've been studying Roman history for maybe 30+ years.  Would never want to study it at all, if it weren't necessary, for the sake of understanding Bible.  For all the writers of Roman history both as it occurred and now, are horribly disorganized in their presentation of the facts.  For it was always the style of writing about this history, to turn the story into a commentary, presuming the reader was long familiar with those facts.  But, we aren't.  Consequently, when you try to study, you spend hours and hours just getting familiar with the geography and the three-pronged names, all of which sound alike.  No one ever fixes these problems, but instead the style of commentary continues today, in every modern historian's rehash of those facts.  Very frustrating.Enter, then, the value of this book.  Example: pages 79-84 are on the Year of the Four Emperors, aka the Long Year, and are vital to understanding, esp. if you are a Christian.  For, the Bible makes much of this Year, and it's triggered per Bible, by the death of the Apostle Paul, which occurred (per Bible, not per Christians) circa March-June, 68 AD.  Yeah, and that's when Vindex started to rebel against Nero.  From that point onward, a chain of rebellions occurs which in Bible you realize are to explain that if the Christian doesn't mature, all hell breaks loose.  To that end, in quick succession you had the books of Peter (who died after Paul), then Jude, then Mark's Gospel and then the Book of Hebrews (maybe written by Mark, definitely not by Paul).  All to explain the current events, so a believer could learn how to interpret that history, since it was long expected that the Rapture would occur by 70 AD (which Paul had hypothesized).  So the idea was that it may or MAY NOT happen, and the newly-issued Bible books in 68-69 just enumerated, would be valuable for rapid spiritual growth.  Of course, that growth did not occur, so there was a hiatus for a decade, at which point John writes to explain what happened, and would happen, as a result of the lack of growth.So knowing that period would be vital to understanding Bible, for a Christian, as a part of isagogics.  Alas, you can't get much on that period, except as commentary -- but THIS book, pages 79-84, gives you a handy explanation I've not found anywhere else, so you can quickly see the panoramic meaning.  Then, you can actually understand the contemporary writers, as well as the more modern ones like Morgan and Wellesley, who wrote specialized tomes on this Long Year (here in Amazon, just look of their names and Year of the Four Emperors).Of course, most people aren't Christian, and wouldn't have that reason for studying Roman history.  Great: you'll still find this book a vast timesaver, because again the normal practice is to write up SPQR's history as if the audience were already long familiar with it.
