You’ll have to get past one fellow who is so racist and misogynistic he’ll leave you feeling queasy, but then again, it’s not hard to find people like that running loose.  As for the main bad guy, well, he’ll leave you cringing as he hacks a bloody path across the landscape.So, get past the premise, brace yourself on the edge of your seat, and enjoy the read.  This is the best first-novel I’ve come across in a while, and I highly recommend it.

Mary Grant has some serious problems.  Her youngest daughter has cancer.  Her other, older daughter is suffering teen angst in the form of rebellious nerdicism.  Her husband, an FBI agent, has just been shot and killed while working with an informant out in the lonely wilds of the Texas prairie.  But she’s not buying the FBI’s official version of the story – basically, “your husband died because he was stupid” – and she’s determined to find the truth.  Her investigation is about to make her problems a whole lot worse.At the core, there could be an interesting story here.  Ian Prince, one of the world’s richest men, is taking over the supercomputer industry and selling his very best to U.S. intelligence agencies, with back doors installed at no extra charge.  Since he also owns one of the largest telecommunications corporations, he’s able to tap into any data on anybody, and any corporate secret, and any foreign intelligence, whenever he wants.  He can of course also manipulate anyone’s finances on a whim.  Being your typical 1-percenter, he naturally has no qualms about ruining or killing everyone who gets in his way.  He does have a soft spot for widows and orphans though, not that it slows him down much.  He plans to live forever, and has built his huge empire for the single purpose of tracking down his long missing father.  And it’s all going swimmingly until Mary starts asking some indelicate questions and her daughter starts probing into Ian’s software.  What it boils down to, here, is Suzie Homemaker and the Katzenhacker Kid take on the evil, omniscient, omnipotent, billionaire.  If you can swallow that one, you’re going to enjoy this book.Christopher Reich is a superb author, and I love some of his other books.  The writing here is good but the plot is implausible and Ian’s motivation is just plain silly.  Unless you’re living the Occupy Wall Street dream though, it’s well worth skipping.

A level-headed scientist at The Lux, an elite think-tank, begins to show signs of distress and strange behaviour.  One day he comes completely unhinged, injuring his assistant and getting himself locked into a library by security for his own protection.  Bent on destruction, he manages to kill himself in a thoroughly horrific way.  Enter Jeremy Logan, the world’s only enigmalogist, and an alumni who was invited to leave the Lux some years before.This is the fourth in the Logan series, which lives in the shadow of the Agent Pendergast series that Child writes along with Douglas Preston.  I don’t think it’s quite on the same level, but it doesn’t miss by much.  Child is an exquisite writer who doesn’t describe a scene so much as paint it, and then brings it fully to life along with his characters.  The Lux, an old and slightly creaky mansion, takes on a disturbingly eerie aura.  It’s supposedly haunted, and you’re left to wonder if it really is, or if there’s another explanation for the strange events that continue to unfold.  Nothing is predictable, and you’re kept perched on the edge of your seat for the entire ride.  The book starts out at Loch Ness, where Logan was hired to debunk the Nessie theory, and provides an enchantingly entertaining take on that enduring old myth.You can read this without having read the other Logan entries, but it’s really better to start at the beginning.  That said, this is easily the best entry in the series, and highly recommended.  My only criticism is that I read Child’s books much faster than he writes them, and I really wish he’d crank up the production just a tad!

Ray Bowman, who survived “Sting of the Drone”, and has quietly retired to the Virgin Islands to start a new and less violent life, returns in “Pinnacle Event”.  A nuke explodes in the Indian Ocean, and it’s soon evident that it was only one of six that recently went missing from South Africa.  The President is concerned that they are headed to the U.S., probably to influence the upcoming elections, and wants Bowman to track them down.  Reluctantly, Bowman begins a whirlwind world tour to discover who has the nukes, and what they plan to do with them.I really enjoyed Clarke’s first book, but this entry falls short.  The premise suffers first from a pretty far-fetched group of bad guys with a rather outlandish motive.  Second, any time you claim there’s only one person who can possibly save the world, and fail to make an awesomely convincing case as to why, things start to come apart.  Sure, Bowman  is presented as a smart and knowledgeable guy, but he’s no James Bond.  The writing here is very jerky, to the point that several times I had to back up a few pages and try to figure out what was going on.  For example, Bowman is introduced as sorta/kinda living with two women who were in a relationship, and having a baby with one of them.  If you’re going to drop something that bizarre into the reader’s lap, then you need to make it a part of the storyline, or at least explain things.Overall the story was interesting, but unlike “Sting”, not at all plausible.  And Bowman is not nearly a compelling enough character to base a series on.  Call it a disappointing second book.

I bought this kit and followed the directions exactly.  There was no pre-soaking, I planted the seeds directly in the pot and soil provided.  After about 20 days, I had 6 seedlings poking up, ready to transplant.  Granted, the pot is very tiny and not very useful, but if you want good seeds that will give you something to work with, this delivers exactly as promised.

There is no shortage of books about aliens visiting Earth.  Or invading our planet.  There are even a number of tales of Earth ships blundering their way into the middle of an intergalactic war.  But suppose – just suppose – that two advanced civilizations invaded Earth simultaneously.  They’re not interested in our resources, or our technology, and view humans with the bored disinterest you might give a bug you find on your lawn.  They’re fighting over, and destroying, Earth because we lie smack dab on the border between their civilizations.  And there’s very little chance anyone will survive, until a very strange boy becomes an unexpected game changer.McCammon takes that premise and runs with it to pretty good effect.  We start out in the middle of a firefight, with the boy running for his life, and we learn bits and pieces of the backstory while things are happening very quickly indeed.  Character development is on the sparse side, which is fine because everyone and everything is vulnerable to sudden destruction.  Nifty technology and scary aliens push onto center stage instead, and the author paces things almost perfectly to keep that perspective working.There are a few problems though.  The readability level at the beginning seems to be around 8th grade level or so, and I thought this might be intended for young adults.  But there is one longish chapter in the middle that’s as graphically sexual as it is unnecessary for the story.  The author could have made his point with a lot less crudity.  The writing too seems a bit uneven, with the dialogue occasionally strained.  These things don’t ruin the novel, but they do bring the enjoyment level down a notch.Overall, there’s some clever ideas and good writing here.  It’s a pretty good book, but a sharper editor’s pen could have made it into a great book.

A deadly epidemic is getting underway.  A new bacteria can enter from the smallest cut, and very quickly spread while turning your insides into mush.  Of course, there is no cure.  This bacteria is no accident: it was created and released by a shadowy group that wants to blackmail the U.S. government.  Lou Welcome, recovering alcoholic and surgeon, has to race to find a cure before his best friend dies a horrific death.Lots of promise there, right?  Too bad the book never delivers; instead, the story circles round and round like a one-oared rowboat.  Rather than Lou’s friend having a simple accident that lands him into the hospital, pages and pages are spent setting up and dealing with a nasty accident.  Characters pop in and out with no purpose.  There’s also a lot of verbiage devoted to Lou’s second job, but it does nothing to advance the story.Then, there are the bad guys, a very nasty conservative group called 100 Neighbors.  They believe that America’s social welfare programs are destroying the country, and are determined to eliminate every form of entitlement.  They are quite happy to have millions die in the process, and even happier to murder assorted good guys and random strangers as well.  In case you are a little slow catching on to the fact that conservatives are nasty, evil people, there’s a quote from the group’s founder at the start of every chapter to remind you.  The author even takes time to paint fundamentalist Christians as child-beaters.Common sense – nowhere to be found.  As bad things start to happen, Lou is brought in for questioning by the FBI, and decides, beyond all reason, not to say a word.  Later, Lou and his FBI friend decide to go Rambo and take out the bad guys, but don’t tell anybody to avoid tipping them off.  Mind you, if they don’t survive, nobody else has a clue about the Neighbor’s location or identities, so they would win by default.  The bad guys have tons of money, which is pretty much a tautology, but lack the sense to put any sort of electronic sensors outside of their headquarters.  They are probably so busy thinking up evil deeds that they can’t hear the gunshots and C4 explosions in their front yard.There are cardboard characters, comic book bad guys, and clunky writing.  If you slog through to the end, you are rewarded by a couple of chapters that are just plain silly.  Avoid like the plague.

Buffalo had a serial killer who specialized in kidnapping and hanging teenage girls.  The police only captured him after a failed suicide attempt, and after years in prison, he is showing signs of recovering from the self-inflicted brain injury.  Somehow, he manages to escape while being moved to a different facility, and returns to Buffalo to continue his killing spree.“Hangman” has a certain eerie vibe, which leaves you feeling distinctly uncomfortable as you read.  Anyone who has children can instantly relate to the sense of terror a city would feel with a child stalker on the loose.  The author does an excellent job of building and refining this mood as Abbie, the lead detective on the case, scrambles to find the killer before he can hang his latest victim.  It’s very suspenseful, and some judiciously laid red herrings keep you nicely off-balance.While the plot was superb, the characters seemed a bit off.  Abbie isn’t fully fleshed out, although that may have been done in the first book of this series.  Other characters, like her boyfriend, pop in and then out with no real purpose or definition.  And there is a very odd plot hole.  The Hangman is being moved in a van by a corrections officer and a guard.  The guard tells the officer to get out and buy some oil, so he guard can have some time alone with the prisoner.  The guard is killed and Hangman escapes, but the officer never re-appears in the story.  He clearly would be the first person the police would look for, either as a victim or accomplice, but somehow he’s completely forgotten.That aside, this book definitely succeeds as a clever, dark, edge-of-your-seat thriller.

If you’re a pro athlete, it’s a good thing to be thinking about a second career.  Because no matter how good you are, or how good the pay is, your body will only last just so long.  Johnny Adcock, a pitcher, has been practicing his for a while.  He helps out other players who need some discreet investigating done.  When one of the catchers on his team asks for help tracking the source of a newly surfaced explicit video his wife made years before, it seems like a pretty routine request.  It turns out to be anything but.“The Setup Man” starts with an intriguing premise and fleshes it out pretty nicely.  Johnny – who still needs to concentrate on his day job – is drawn in to the world of pornography and prostitution, and quickly finds his life on the line.  He’s no Sherlock Holmes, but does a fascinating job of tying together clues.  He’s also very believable in most of his actions, reactions, and insights.The problem is the plot itself seems too ambitious and far-flung.  The original investigation gets “super-sized” and loses credibility.  There are also some odd scenarios which don’t make sense.  A very laid-back friend kills a man, and Johnny just shrugs it off.  They decide to get rid of the body, and Johnny insists on dumping it at a church rectory.  Why he did this is never explained, and you’re left scratching your head.Overall, it’s a decent read, and includes some interesting insights into MLB.  Note there are some very graphical sexual depictions, so this is definitely not for young readers.

Mark Watney is having a bad day.  He’s part of the third manned mission to Mars, but while outside on an EVA, a large windstorm hits.  It’s so brisk that it tears the satellite dish off its mount, which impales Mark.  He’s last seen blowing away, and his suit telemetry confirms that he’s dead.  The rest of the crew has no chance to search for him, because the wind is getting ready to topple their ship, so they have to blast off immediately.  Thing is though, Mark isn’t really dead . . .This book starts with a great and original idea, but in the world of sci-fi, that’s no guarantee of success.  Weir takes the idea, fleshes it out, breathes life into it, then lashes a rocket engine to the pace and lights the darn thing.  It’s fascinating, spellbinding, and nearly heart-stopping, while staying completely realistic and believable.  The challenges and roadblocks Weir invents are as diabolically evil as Watney’s solutions are ingenious.  He no sooner solves one life-threatening problem and something completely unexpected pops up.  But he’s far from perfect, as his own mistakes and oversights nearly kill him more than once.  Fortunately he has total confidence in himself, and a wickedly twisted sense of humour to keep himself company.  If you’re familiar with Stoker Ace (from the book “Stand On It”, not the movie), you’ll have some idea of what to expect.There’s a lot of science in this sci-fi, but it’s not just for techno-geeks.  There’s a surprising amount of authentically handled human drama and emotion on display as well.  As news of Watney’s survival spreads, he becomes the media darling of the century.  Many authors would have let this spin out of control, but it’s tightly contained here and very deftly handled.If watching someone overcome near-impossible adversity gives you a nice warm-fuzzy glow, you’re going to love this book.  It is simply superb on every level.  Very highly recommended.

Having a great new idea can be a dangerous thing.  In fact, in the world of “Influx”, it could cost you your life.  That’s because the Bureau of Technology Control is worried that too much innovation can be disruptive for the teeming masses, so when a major invention is close to being introduced, the inventors are seemingly killed but actually spirited away to the BTC headquarters.  There, they can “join the team” and continue their work, while helping suppress other technology, or sent away to undergo some not-so gentle persuasion.  Jon Grady is getting a little too close to controlling gravity, so he’s snatched by BTC.  But he won’t play along, so he’s locked up with a robotic minder that will stop at nothing to change Jon’s mind, including snatching little pieces of it away from him.This sci-fi thriller is as inventive as it is engrossing.  There’s a lot of technology explained which you don’t really need to understand, but once the story gathers steam things really fly along.  It’s very realistic and entirely believable, with Jon transforming from an ordinary scientist into a very gritty hero.  The one weak spot is the bad guys, who slip a little too close to parodying themselves.As with any good sci-fi story, there’s a message tucked away inside.  Here, we’re exposed to the dangers of unlimited power and the accompanying hubris, and how ordinary people can come to see themselves as being superior to their peers.  The end result of an accelerating nanny state is horrible to behold, as the BTC gradually embraces the philosophy of “we had to destroy the village in order to save it.”The overall tone is dark but there are little bits of humour sprinkled in, just to keep you off-balance.  At 400 pages it’s an amazingly fast read.  Mark this as a solid success in both the sci-fi and thriller genres.

Ballistic missile sub USS Kentucky is heading out on a routine patrol.  But they’ve barely left Hawaii when they receive and authenticate an order to launch all 24 missiles at Iran.  Unknown to them, the order wasn’t valid, and some clever espionage prevents them from receiving the launch termination orders.  The President and his National Security Advisor decide that destroying the sub before it reaches launch range is the only way to prevent the deaths of millions, and send the entire Pacific fleet to sink the Kentucky.The good news is the story is pretty well plotted, and the pacing is kept brisk.  The main players are well drawn and act the way you would expect, and the dialogue is well handled.  The author does a wonderful job of grabbing your attention and keeping it.But, the book does have some quirks.  People in the midst of a nuclear crisis find themselves distracted by stray romantic notions.  There are some “by the most remarkable coincidence” relationships.  The guy in charge of figuring out how to destroy the Kentucky just happens to have a son serving aboard.  The NSA just so happens to have an ex-husband who is a major player in the story.  And inexplicably, the Secretary of Defense plays absolutely no role in any of this.Finally, there are some plot holes big enough to launch a Trident missile through.  Fast attack subs are sent to find and contact Kentucky, and know they’re very close.  They can’t reliably track it with their passive sonar, so they just give up.  Why not use active sonar?  Why not use the WQC underwater telephone that appears later in the book?  The Kentucky approaches, and identifies, a large group of U.S. Navy ships in their path.  This puzzles them, and they decide it must be an exercise.  An exercise – days after Washington gets nuked?  Another attack sub gets close, but has a reactor accident, leaving only partial power.  Rather than launch torpedoes and risk being destroyed in a counterattack, they turn around and sail home.  That sounds extraordinarily timid for a fast attack captain.  There’s more, but this should give you a fair idea.Flaws aside, the book was a fun read and pretty absorbing.  The author is working on a sequel, and I liked this one enough that I’m looking forward to reading the next.

If you’ve read Eisler’s previous books, you’ll know that John Rain is a half-American, half-Japanese, ex-Special Forces Viet Nam veteran, and a paid assassin.  This is the eighth in the series, and if you haven’t read any of the others, don’t worry, you won’t be lost.  Here, you’ll learn how Rain, fresh out of the Army, grew from being a lowly CIA bagman into a highly effective assassin.  It’s anything but a smooth journey, as he learns valuable lessons only by repeatedly cheating death.  But this is much more than a standard action thriller.  Rain struggles with his conscience as the body count mounts, and has to make conscious decisions about whether it’s worth killing again.  And there is a surprisingly tender love story that’s skillfully interwoven so that it’s an integral part of the main plot, rather than a stuck-on afterthought.As always, everything is very detailed but the pacing never suffers.  Not only is the story amazing, but 1970s Tokyo is brought fully and convincingly to life.  People, places, motives, sights and sounds: everything is realistic and believable.Things do get a bit graphic at times, so this is not appropriate for younger readers.  Other than that, I can recommend this book highly for old and new Eisler fans.

Eric is an ordinary guy, who gets a call from a kidnapper demanding $1M in ransom to have his daughter returned.  And of course, he’s told not to call the police.  The only thing is, Eric is single and has no children.  Geez, what to do, eh?  He should call the police, since the kidnapper obviously has the wrong number.  But no, instead he calls his private detective buddy Jack, who recently left the police force under an unexplained cloud.  Clever lads that they are, they have Eric keep taking the kidnapper’s calls, pretending to be the right person, while Jack spends his days eating donuts and talking to his girlfriend, who is also a cop but hasn’t been thrown off the force yet.  After much muddling, they determine who the victim is, and contact the father, who is “Canada’s Donald Trump”.  He swallows Jack’s story without a shred of evidence, and serves as a sympathetic character while the muddling continues, and the police are left out of the loop.Sadly, this book has absolutely nothing going for it.  The narrative is awkward and embarrassingly insipid, but the dialogue is downright stilted and clunky.  The hapless characters are stuck dancing to the tune of an awful premise, making bad decisions, and overall, acting in ways wildly inappropriate for people who are supposed to be vaguely intelligent.  Most of Jack’s time is spent making mooneyes at his girlfriend, or thinking about his girlfriend, rather than trying to track down the missing girl.  The book is a tedious slog through utterly pointless minutiae, which is as mindless as it is meaningless to the story.  Pages are spent needlessly detailing ordering and picking up Chinese food.  Even more pages are devoted to ordering, consuming, and critiquing donuts and coffee.Although set in Vancouver, the location isn’t even mentioned until Chapter 5, and only once thereafter.  There is absolutely no local colour; it could as well have been set in Seattle, or Phoenix, or outer Timbuktu.  The infrequently encountered Canadian terms should have been explained on the off chance the book would ever cross the southern border.  For instance, most American’s won’t know that “Timmies” refers to Tim Horton’s, a superb purveyor of coffee and donuts and sort of a second home for many Canadians.Towards the end, Jack is sent to California to get the one thing the kidnapper, who is now in police custody, demands in order to release the missing girl.  He gets back late at night, and is told the station is closed and come back in the morning.  Presumably, with donuts and coffee.  If that makes sense to you, by all means, give this book a try.  Personally, I think the McKenzie brothers could have solved the case in half the time and been a couple of 2-4s to the good by page 90.

Think of a restaurant.  A nice restaurant.  Probably the nicest and most expensive place you’ve ever been, serving you the best meal you’ve ever eaten.  That’s where Michael Gibney is going to take you for a “day in the life” as a sous chef.  What he describes isn’t a single, real place; it’s a conglomerate of kitchens and people, representative of places he’s worked.  As the opening sous chef, he covers everything from preparation for an exceptionally busy Friday night service – complete with VIPs from the press – and concludes with preparations for Saturday’s brunch.  He details what’s required from each person, includes some of their personality quirks, and covers what they did, how they did it, and how they interact.Sound boring?  Anything but!  It’s not simply fascinating, it’s absolutely riveting; this book sticks to your hand like a first-rate thriller.  You get an intense exposure to the pressures of preparing meals in a very fast-paced environment, where perfection is not a goal but the minimum standard.  Some personalities work well together, some clash; some cooks rise to the challenge, while others crumple.  Gibney takes us out for drinks after service, and explains via character conversations what motivates someone to embrace such a high-stress profession.One minor flaw is the random conversations conducted in Spanish.  It interrupts your reading flow and leaves you stumbling over unintelligible passages.  It would have been better to simply put everything into English, or at least include the translations parenthetically.  On the other hand, while he uses a lot of cooking terms, there’s a superb listing of “Selected Kitchen Terminology” at the end of the book which explains everything.If you’re a cook, or aspire to be one, or simply want to understand what happens behind the curtain in an upscale restaurant, you’ll certainly enjoy this book (and learn a lot too).

Start with an original and slightly wacky idea: an organization known as HR Inc. is actually an assassination bureau.  They specialize in higher end targets, using agents who have literally been brought up from the gutter, trained, and if they survive, are placed as corporate interns to get close to their targets.  John Lago is HR's premiere agent, and because he's getting a bit long in the tooth to pose as an intern for much longer, he's been given his final job.  That's it; just one more hit, and he can retire in comfort.  Just a walk in the park ...Of course, it's not that easy, and John tells his story through an instructive handbook for new interns.  And what a story!  It's wildly imaginative and strangely believable.  In flashbacks, John relates several of his old jobs to help illustrate the "Rules" of interning.  Each is intricately crafted, brilliantly told, and most display a thoroughly wicked sense of deepest darkest humour.  You'll find yourself torn between laughing out loud and cringing in horror.I won't say any more about the story, it's really best if you walk into it like getting onto a roller coaster blindfolded.  It's only January so it's easy to say this is the best book I've read all year, but I have a feeling it will hang on to the title for quite a while.  While I've never commented on cover art before, I certainly hope the cover of the advanced readers copy appears on the final copy, as it's exceedingly clever.Highly, highly recommended.

This book contains some good recipes for fruit and vegetable smoothies. I prefer to juice but mostly the recipes would work just as well for juicing as blending so that is no problem.Some health information is included, and it wasn't so good. For example, the book claims that carrots have vitamin A, but they don't. Beta carotene can be converted to vitamin A in the body, but it is not vitamin A and this conversion doesn't work very well in the body for some people. That is a common myth and not such a big deal, but what really bugged me were comments like where the book said insomnia has only three causes and they each can be fixed by having a watermelon and apple drink. Actually no, of course there are far far more than three causes and some involve foods other than fruit and vegetables and there is also often far more to insomnia than dietary changes. Such silly comments are unhelpful to those with real health issues to say the least.The book also includes recipes with terrible ingredients such as caramel sauce, non-fat vanilla yogurt and ice cream. Not sure what these are doing in a book which presents itself as a health book. Some of the recipes were also very high sugar, even where the sugar was coming only from fruit.

I've just discovered frozen banana chocolate ice cream (frozen bananas whizzed up with cocoa...sooo good) and was hoping for some more banana-based recipes.Mostly recipes are just the same old muffin recipes with some banana added though. Not at all healthy, even a little bit and all stuff you could easily search the net and get hundreds of recipes for. Some recipes also include banana essence (yuck!), corn oil, bought pie crusts and biscuits and are very high sugar even for standard dessert recipes. There are also a lot of typos, and some ingredients are listed wrong. This book needs a good edit and a few new and exciting banana-based recipes maybe. I'd also suggest ditching the banana essence!

The section in this book on orthomolecular medicine is ignorant, arrogant and very condescending as regards the motivations and intelligence of Linus Pauling. The authors have not understood even the most rudimentary facts on what Paulings Orthomolecular opinions and theories were, unfortunately. I felt embarassed for the authors as I was reading it. It is like reading someone explain why the earth is flat.The analysis is so poorly done and silly there is no point taking the time to refute any of the claims made in it. (You can easily see the facts explained in any of the books listed below.)Fortunately many others have done a far better job summing up Linus Pauling's Orthomolecular work and advocacy.Dr T. Levy's new book Primal Panacea explains that some of the most common myths about vitamin C include:1. There are no studies on vitamin C2. There is no proof that vitamin C works3. Vitamin C is not safe4. Vitamin C causes kidney stones5. Our need for vitamin C is met by diet6. Vitamin C just makes expensive urine7. If vitamin C really worked we would all be using itAside from Levy's great book there are also:* Ascorbate: The Science of Vitamin C by Dr Hickey and Dr Roberts,* VITAMIN C: The Real Story by Steve Hickey, PhD and Andrew Saul,* Orthomolecular Medicine For Everyone: Megavitamin Therapeutics for Families and Physicians by Abram Hoffer,* Fire your doctor! : how to be independently healthy by Andrew W. Saul* The healing factor: Vitamin C against disease by Irwin Stone* How to live longer and feel better by Linus Pauling...and many others.Despite what this book states, in fact Linus Pauling 'the man' will be remembered by many of us.That includes so many of us who have seen for ourselves the huge impact ascorbic acid at a correct dose and Orthomolecular medicine generally have had on our health. Standing up to what is popular and politically correct but unscientific is not easy, as we admire Pauling for his pioneering spirit, guts and determination as well as his intelligence. We really need more people like him in the medical field.Just had to add a few C quotes to the end of the review:'Man's body was designed to function best with high blood and cellular levels of vitamin C - synthesised as needed by the liver. Due to an inborn error of metabolism, the vast majority of us no longer have the ability to make it, but that does not lessen our need for vitamin C or the benefits derived form it.' Dr Levy"Modern medicine's narrow approach, to treat every disease as if it were a drug deficiency, has resulted in a steep price for humanity. It is obvious millions have died prematurely since vitamin C was first discovered over 80 years ago. Brave and resolute men and women, Albert Szent-Györgyi, Irwin Stone, Linus Pauling, Ewan Cameron, Emil Ginter, Matthias Rath, Andrew Saul, Tom Levy, Steve Hickey, Raxit Jariwalla, John T. Ely, Hilary Roberts, and others promoted the idea of vitamin C therapy but were readily dismissed, even belittled." Bill Sardi'I could also spend millions to prove that the small amounts of these nutrients will not prevent car acci­dents. Who is funding all these silly stud­ies? No orthomolecular physician ever claimed that giving 200 IU of vitamin E and 500 mg of C cured anything.Perhaps you should write a paper with tongue in cheek in which you announce, "An­tibiotics Do Not Cure Infection". Then, report somewhere hidden in the paper that you only gave them 200 or even 20,000 IU of a drug that requires doses of one million or more. Such report­ing is a superb example of the cynical, expensive and sleazy research so loved by Big Pharma. This is because it delays the real introduction of good medicine, in the same way that tobacco companies denied smoking causes cancer and we supposedly needed more and more and more research to prove anything.All this allows the companies to add millions of dollars to their coffers. Their defense is delay, delay and delay. The only objective of Big Pharma is to make money, lots and lots of it. How dare we try to prevent them from doing so?' Abram Hoffer, M.D., Ph.D.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds

This book was far more about positive thinking, affirmations and promoting Christianity than gratitude. Not the same at all and so just not what I was after.(Especially as I just finished reading the book 'The Antidote' as I read this one, which talked about how counter-productive positive affirmations are, and why positive thinking is disempowering to people and not very helpful!)The affirmations here are also all seemingly aimed at quite well off and healthy people. Very simplistic. The book also needs a good edit.While I'm grateful I was able to read this book for free, I won't be keeping it.

A solid meditation introduction and simple instructions on how to get started with different types of meditation such as mindfulness meditation, meditation focusing on the breath, loving kindness meditation, mantra meditation and more. It is a good absolute beginners guide.The only part that was just not for me was the mantras given in the book as examples. I'm not at all a fan of mantras which sound like positive affirmations. I dislike this sort of forced and to me, fake feeling, optimism. (Especially after just finishing reading the book 'The Antidote' which talked about how counter-productive positive affirmations are!) I'd have much preferred some more suble affirmations listed, and also some that were not in English. But that is just a personal preference. I also don't think meditating is going to get me any more money, despite what the book subtitle is. Nor will it cure all health issues, though of course it can have some positive effect.I found this book useful, well-written and well-edited and would recommend it.

The world needs more books with talking cats in them. It just does.It also definitely needs more books in where the people who talk to the cats end up 'cattifying' their speech a little bit and even occasionally using some cat terminology and (very non-rude) swear words! More exclamations of cat-specific moods than swear words I should say. These are some of the funniest parts of the book.(I wont post a spolier here by sharing any of the specific words though!)The cats are also not too human-acting which I like, and still display very cat-like tendencies to try and order people around to suit them and make sure their food needs are met before anything else is done. They hang around doing their own cat things a lot of the time, as cats are always wont to do.I like too that the book touches on issues of corporate greed and how it can (and does) corrupt science.I could probably have done with a little more information about the feline mystery that forms the topic of the next book. Just a few more teasers, I guess. But perhaps it all being almost a total mystery until you start reading book 2 is the point.This is a well-written, well-paced and interesting book suitable for young kids who like cats or just animals in general. A solid start to a series. I'll definitely be saving my copy for my niece/s and nephew/s for when they get a bit older.[Important disclaimer: I was asked to provide an honest review of this book by an activism colleague of mine, whose partner is the author. This was because I am fond of writing (almost all non-fiction) reviews and because I am a big feline fan and an avid fiction reader. I read a free Kindle copy of this book, but that was due to it being free for a short period of time on Amazon as a promotion, and not a special deal made to me personally in exchange for a review. I wouldn't have written a review for the book if not asked to as a favour as I almost never review non-fiction due to time constraints, but the statements in this review are all my own opinions.]

This book contains a few excellent new tweaks to the basic Dr Rogers program for her regular readers, and also a lot of specific information about reversing diabetes.There is a lot of useful information here about supplements and which types and amounts and brands to take, the importance of nutrients as well as why many common diabetes drugs not only don't work but will make you sicker even quicker. The dangers of statin drugs and aspirin are also explained at length.Hands down the best book of Dr Sherry Rogers' to start with however is Detoxify or Die.This book is excellent. It is also very easy to read and understand. It talks about the importance of treating the causes of disease and the most important chemicals to avoid in food and in cleaning and personal care products, the impact of each of the major chemical types on the body, tests which can be used to determine your toxic load (as well as your nutrients levels and how well your detoxification pathways are functioning etc.), the problems with many common prescribed drugs, the benefits of a daily detox cocktail, the benefits of juicing and enemas, the benefits and safety of regular FIR sauna use, how to use the sauna safely and what to expect when doing a sauna program, and so much more.Dr Sherry Rogers explains that with treating the causes of disease, 'A life sentence to medications that block physiologic pathways is avoided.' She continues,`Bear in mind that since medications do not fix anything, they allow the underlying problem to continue uncorrected and actually accelerate. Meanwhile, new symptoms and new seemingly unrelated diseases are the inevitable consequence of this biochemical faux pas. Furthermore, drug side effects are the leading cause of death. NSAIDs as an example of only one group of medications, are fatally toxic to thousands of people each year by damaging joints, lungs, kidneys, eyes, hearts, and intestines. And they are covered by insurance.You and your doctor have been screwed into believing every symptom is a deficiency of some drug or surgery. You've been led to believe you have no control, when in truth you're the one who must take control. Unfortunately, the modus operandi in medicine is to find a drug to turn off the damaged part that is producing symptoms. A simple example is the prescription of calcium channel blockers, the number one drug used by cardiologists for angina, hypertension, congestive heart failure, or arrhythmia. But as with any drug, this does not fix anything that is broken. It merely poisons normal physiological pathways, thereby forcing the chemistry in a direction that attenuates symptoms.It should not come as a shock that this type of information is ignored, since studies in the Journal of the American Medical Association document how the practice guidelines for American medicine are made by physicians who receive compensation from the drug industry. (Choudhry, JAMA 2002; 287: 612-617). In addition so is the FDA, the very government regulatory body that approves drugs, riddled with advisers with financial ties to (and is heavily lobbied by) the very drug industry that is seeking its approval. And as the New England Journal of Medicine and Journal of the American Medical Association warm, even the hired clinical investigators for new drugs may have their price. 'In short, to get well you need to:A. Get the good stuff in. Give your body the fuel and tools it needs to work at an optimum level. Good food, nutrients and all the proper vitamins, minerals and antioxidants. Make sure you aren't deficient in any of the major nutrients as the different nutrients all work together.B. Get the bad stuff out. Make sure your body can detoxify out all the toxic substances and toxic by-products of bodily processes properly. Stop as many toxins from getting in in the first place, and do a detoxification program to get rid of the ones you have. Stop doing or eating the things which cause inflammation and have a pro-oxidant effect, and so on.Once you've read Detoxify or Die you can go on from there and build on what you know with some of her other books. Is easier to take it all in if you start with a book that explains all the basics first. After reading a couple of Dr Rogers' books, you may also then like to subscribe to Dr Rogers' monthly newsletter, to stay up to date with new developments - if your budget allows for this. These books etc. will be helpful no matter what disease label you have, or even if you don't yet have a correct diagnosis.This new book was good. Lots of people would have lots of different opinions but for me what would have made it even better would be:a. More information on healing reactions and the need to start very slow with each treatment especially if you are very ill. Far more information for the very weak and ill would be so welcome. Listing those treatments which it is extra important to go VERY slowly with due to the massive healing reactions they can cause such as vitamin C, RALA and Silymarin would also be very welcome.b. Some real discussion of the massive problems high carb diets can cause, and the fact that the diet recommended (which I could in no way follow, or recommend) would make many of us very ill and fat and weak as we can't cope with even a 40% carb diet, let alone 70% or more, and also do poorly eating grains and legumes. Many also need a ton more fat than a measly 10% to be healthy and such a low fat diet could be disastrous for their health.(I recommend the healing approach of Dr Rogers overall but not in any way her recommendation for the Ornish or Macrobiotics diets. This book has no useful dietary information at all really for those who do poorly on macrobiotic diets aside form a bit of good information on avoiding dangerous trans fats etc. Wonderful diet books which explain that a high fat, moderate protein and low but not super-low carb suits our genes and is so healthy for us and especially those with insulin issues include Primal Body Primal Mind by Nora Gedgaudas and many others.)c. Maybe a page of information explaining why vitamin C is so important as not just a vitamin but an anti-stress factor and how it used to be produced in the body by humans. Vitamin C can also be used to minimise symptoms while healing is happening, and can reduce fevers and the need for fever reducing drugs which have side effects.d. More information and specific examples about how much healing exactly may be expected, in particular when a person has been ill for many years. This would also make it clear to readers that to assume everyone who has this information could be completely cured is unrealistic and it'd be unfair to treat all ill people as if they could all be cured if they just did the right things. Some damage is permanent and I'd like to see at least some discussion of this in books on healing so people don't get the wrong idea and withhold help and assistance needed to ill people.I do understand that space in a book manuscript is very tight though and not everything can be included.All of the recommendations in the books can seem overwhelming, but all you need to do is start small. Do one small thing at a time and make gradual changes. The worst thing you could do, especially if you are very ill, is jump into taking and doing lots of different things all at once anyway. You have to start so slow with each thing if you are very ill!A big thank you to Dr Sherry Rogers for sharing all this valuable information!A last quote from Dr Sherry Rogers in `Detoxify or Die',`I have to laugh when people ask me if I do alternative, herbal, acupuncture or holistic medicine. 'No,' I reply. 'We do state-of-the-art medicine. In other words, we find the biochemical, nutritional and environmental causes and cures rather than blindly drugging everything. Sure, herbs are gentler, safer and more physiologic than drugs and holistic medicine attempts to incorporate many diverse modalities, etc. But there is no substitute for finding the underlying biochemical causes and cures. This is real medicine. This is where medicine should and would have been decades ago, if it had not been abducted by the pharmaceutical industry.'Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This book was just not good. There is so much conflicting, bad and misleading information here.This book recommends so many unhealthy foods and even foods which are known to cause a leaky gut issue or prevent you from healing it. This book is not really about healing gut issues, just modifying the symptoms slightly maybe.This book thinks soy products including soy cheese are wonderful and also recommends rice milk and rice cheese, rice cakes, rice chips, canned soup, baked potato chips, instant oats, puffed cereal products and lots of other heavily processed, unhealthy, low-nutrient foods. Soy milk and cheese are not remotely healthy foods, as books like `The Whole Soy Story' explain. Advising people to cut right back on sugar but then telling them to eat tons of white bread and refined carbs - which the body instantly turns into sugar/glucose - is illogical.Highly allergenic foods such as soy milk are allowed on the 2 week dairy tolerances test diet, making the test useless and very misleading. Readers are told that if they don't feel better avoiding dairy for two weeks they are safe to drink it again - but they completely ignore the huge possibility that drinking soy milk in this two weeks could easily account for a lack of improvement in many very dairy sensitive people.A quiche recipe in this book uses egg whites only and also a bought pie crust. How healthy! Any nutrition book which is ignorant enough to tell you to throw out the yolk of an egg - the healthiest part of it and one of the healthiest foods we have albeit one surrounded by propaganda by the cholesterol myth supporters - well, fails as a nutritionist really. It is such ignorant advice. Use whole eggs to make a crustless quiche instead!The raw food diet is recommended and the same old nonsense about how high the enzyme content is and how this means you'll digest raw foods so easily. But it is absolute nonsense! Raw veggies are extremely difficult for those with digestive issues to digest, and can cause massive pain and bloating. It can feel like you have eaten rocks or pebbles to eat a bowl of raw veggies. Far easier to digest are slow cooked vegetables that are very soft such as those in soups and stews. Adding something that really is super high in enzymes such as homemade sauerkraut or kefir to your meal will help digestion significantly, but it is a myth that raw veggies do this. It's quite the opposite.There is a tiny amount of vitamin and mineral information, with a big focus on magnesium. There is also some information on herbs and also homeopathy and this information is given as much weight as the vitamin and mineral information. This could lead readers to waste all lots of time and money on these unnecessary extras rather than the essential vitamins and minerals which can actually treat the cause of a health issue and not just suppress or modify some symptoms.Forget this book and look into the GAPS diet book instead or the book by Dr Sherry Rogers on healing your gut and identifying food allergies etc. or Primal Body, Primal Mind: Beyond the Paleo Diet for Total Health and a Longer Life by Nora Gedgaudas. They each run rings around this book and are very well referenced and solid.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

If you can't eat all the packaged convenience foods you used to due to medical advice to avoid gluten or dairy then this book may be just what you are after to help you make your own gluten- and dairy-free versions of these foods at home.This book left an enormous amount to be desired in the healthiness and nutrient density of the recipes and also in basic nutritional knowledge. Some of it was terrible. Fake non-dairy cheese is included in some recipes, along with sunflower spread and hard white vegetable shortening. Unhealthy and just horrible!The author also recommends cooking and frying food in sunflower oil. But any good nutritionist will tell you that this is a fragile oil that should never be heated to high temperatures, as it so easily oxidises when heated. Eating oxidised oils is really not a good idea.The recipes are very sweet in some cases as well. One recipe for chocolate sauce had a cup of sugar in as well as soy milk. (Soy is anything but a health food, as books like `The Whole Soy Story' explain). But you can make a lovely chocolate sauce using coconut cream, 85% chocolate and a bit of honey. It'd taste far nicer and be a lot healthier. It was just so hard to see any benefits or point to the recipes in this book, yes they were gluten free but they could have been a lot tastier and better for you.There are a ton of better recipe books out there on this topic. Or you could just do net searches for specific recipes you are after.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This is a solid recipe book for anyone choosing to eat dairy, grain/gluten and legume free. It's great to have a recipe book where the meals don't contain lots of junk you are trying to avoid, and where all the recipes are not just gluten-free OR dairy-free etc. but all of these at once.I like that the book isn't all about trying to recreate unhealthy foods using healthy foods. That gets so boring and ties you to that unhealthy mindset for longer. A few replacements are listed such as spaghetti squash and a cauliflower mash to replace potato mash but I liked how the authors little comments on the top of the recipes made it clear it wasn't really aiming to taste like actual spaghetti etc. I like the tone the author has in this book a lot. The author is serious about real food yet this book has a light touch and is very engaging and likeable throughout as well. It is anything but one boring lecture.The book includes a list of panty essentials, ideas for a weekly cook-up and lots more tips. Each recipe comes with tips on how you could modify it and what you might like to pair it with. It could be a really great all-in-one basic foundation book for someone wanting to go from a standard diet to a really healthy one but that isn't sure where to start. You'd need to have a bit of time to cook though, and work everything out.I had a very few minor quibbles with the book such as the use of frozen veggies *barf!* and the use of iodised sea salt. If it is iodised it is not real unrefined sea salt. Iodised salt is to be avoided.The food photos are good and the recipe layout is clear. I found the book horrible to view on my Kindle due to the 2 column format though, as it displayed at about 4 point text even with the screen set to sideways. But on my computer there are no problems with viewing the text of course. I'm going to delete it off my Kindle now. The photos were lovely but there did seem to be a lot of photos as compared to the number of text pages, possibly.I got this book for just a few dollars as part of a health themed ebook bundle. I'm following a gluten/dairy/legume-free diet as part of a program to improve a serious neurological disease. I like the look of quite a few recipes here, more than I do in many Paleo type books. I'm excited to try the sunflower seed satay sauce and basil/walnut pesto recipes very soon, and I'm going to see if I can find coconut aminos at a shop near me. I'd never heard of such a product before and it sounds good.This book for healthy savoury recipes and the `Indulge: 70 Grain-free Desserts' book for healthy desserts....  mmmm!Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

A friend put me on to these recently and they are so much easier to use than standard dental floss I was hooked right away. Made my day really as I had been finding normal flossing very difficult and not been doing it as much as I should.I bought 3 or 4 different brand ones at first and this is the only one that didn't fray and break. It is the only brand I will be buying from now on even if these are a bit more expensive than some.I don't throw mine away after a single use, I prefer to clean and reuse them. If you can clean and reuse a toothbrush head, why not these things, I reckon. They work well and leave your mouth feeling very clean.I really recommend giving these a try especially if you are ill and have issues with hand strength and flexibility. They may not be for you but if they are it's well worth spending a few dollars to find out.

Book one in this series is a fascinating read. It reminds us how slow the medical profession is to accept new ideas, even when the evidence for them is overwhelming. There is so much more going on than unbiased and logical analysis of the evidence.The idea that the medical profession has no vested interests but the best patient care is not just called into question but proved to be not the case again and again over many hundreds of years by the information in this book. Many case studies and examples given are quite shocking - for example how long it took doctors to agree to wash their hands before delivering babies, and how the doctor that first identified this problem and pushed for handwashing was ridiculed and suffered a huge blow to his standing and career. New information in the medical field is rarely received well, as this book explains.Doctors unwillingness to admit they were wrong is a huge problem and this affects individual doctors as well as the profession as a whole. There is also the issue of financial liability for doctors and medical organisations as well. When does the medical profession ever admit it is wrong? They almost never do. Yet the medical profession has a high degree of public trust.We need to be aware that much of what is promoted as `absolute medical fact' today has already been utterly disproven. Yet it persists and will do for many years to come due to vested financial interests involved in medicine as well as how slow medicine is to accept new ideas. We should not assume that the mainsteam medical information we are given is based on logic. Often this is not the case.We should also not assume that following what is accepted as best practice in mainstream medicine will give us the best health outcomes. At best the information may be decades behind the latest research and especially when it comes to anything not closely aligned with drug company profits.From the author/book cover:"This book is dedicated to the memory of all those medical doctors who, since history has been recorded, have contributed to the progress of the science and art of medicine. Medical Mavericks are practitioners who did not follow conventional paths. Instead they chose to go where there is no path and leave a trail. This is not an easy journey. Schopenhauers made the observation that new thought and new truth most often go through three stages. First they are ridiculed. Next they are violently opposed. Then, finally they are accepted as being self-evident. Medical Mavericks Volume One chronicles the tales of 17 different practitioners who were mavericks in their thinking.The word "maverick" is derived from an American pioneer, Samuel A. Maverick, who chose not to brand his cattle. Through usage the word "maverick", in addition to meaning an unbranded range animal, has come to mean an independent individual who refuses, because of what he or she has learned, to conform to prevailing group thought.Often reviled by their contemporaries, medical mavericks blazed the trail of scientific progress. These tales of discovery, personal hardship, court intrigues, and hardball professional rivalry make for fascinating reading. Medical Mavericks will raise the eyebrows of many, and bring a sense of relief to contemporary mavericks who can take comfort in the thought that at least they aren't being burned at the stake.The word maverick is derived from an American pioneer Samuel A. Maverick who chose to not brand his cattle. Through usage the word maverick in addition to meaning an unbranded range animal has come to mean an independent individual who refuses to confrom to his group. This book could just as accurately have been titled "One person can make a difference" or "Burn him at the stake and use damp straw." Often reviled by their comtemporaries but revered by subsequent generations these medical mavericks blazed the trail of scientific progress. These tales of discovery personal hardship court intrigues and hardball professional rivalry make for fascinating reading."Book three in the series makes this already good book concept even better by adding in case studies of some of the world's orthomolecular medicine pioneers. Information is given on Dr Abram Hoffer, Dr R. Cathcart, Dr Cheraskin, Roger Williams, Linus Pauling and many others. The chapters on Hoffer, Pauling and Riordan were the standouts for me.From the third book: "Medical Mavericks: Volume Three, is the completion of Dr. Riordan's trilogy of biographical vignettes about these fascinating trailblazers. It also marks Dr. Riordan's final publication. This book is dedicated to the maverick in you - that wonderful element perhaps obvious, perhaps hidden, which has moved you to choose to read this bit of writing."Dr Riordan was a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and the University of Wisconsin Medical School, and had practiced clinical medicine for nearly 50 years. He is also quite a medical trailblazer himself as the book `Pyramid on the Praerie' explains. He has done a great job with this book and I recommend it, along with the other two books in the series. The myth of the lack of bias in the medical profession has to die! There is bias, and it is large.Thank goodness for all those real medical pioneers out there. And free excellent health books!Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

These tales of discovery, personal hardship, court intrigues, and hardball professional rivalry make for fascinating reading. This book could just as accurately have been titled "One person can make a difference" or "Burn him at the stake and use damp straw." It includes many more case studies and details of very sad lost opportunities. It's a madddening but enlightening read.Dr Riordan was a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and the University of Wisconsin Medical School, and had practiced clinical medicine for nearly 50 years. These sorts of files are so much better than metal files or pumice stones or those impossible to use pumice stones on sticks things. This file is very easy to use and because it is quite fine, it gives a superior result to harsher products. It is also very easy and quick to use. The wooden handle/body of the file is also very sturdy and easy to hold making the product easier to get a grip on than similar products which have a thin plastic handle/body which bends when in use. I'm going to keep buying this product for sure. Recommended.

These socks feel very nice and soft and fit well. I like that they have a nice nature-y print on and also that they have a heel sewn in so you always wear them the same way up, so the dirty side stays on the bottom and they don't move around or slide off. They do what they are supposed to when worn after applying a good natural heel moisturiser cream and are comfortable enough that you almost don't feel like you're wearing socks ar all. Couldn't ask for more. The moisturising gloves by the same company are just as good too. Recommended.

Linus Pauling is a real hero to me and his intelligence, logic and compassion for people come through on every page of this book. The world would be a far better place with more people like him in it.Having said that, after reading this book I do think it is clear he continually honed his message and the basic points he wanted to make about nutrition and orthomolecular medicine as time went on. For that reason I would recommend reading Pauling's book 'How to Live Longer and Feel Better' above this earlier (though still excellent and historially very important) book.'How to Live Longer and Feel Better' includes a lot of the excellent vitamin C infomation contained in this book but also so much more. The discussion has a lot more depth, more research is quoted and practical advice is given about a basic but fairly complete orthomolecular program and not just how much vitamin C to take. It is pretty wonderful.This is a slightly paraphrased version of Pauling's basic regimen for a healthy life:* Take 6 - 18 g of vitamin C daily* Take 400 IU, 800 IU or 1600 IU of natural vitamin E daily* Take 1 - 2 B vitamin supplements daily* Take 25 000 IU of vitamin A daily* Take a multimineral tablet daily* Keep your intake of sugar low* Eat what you like in moderation, but avoid sugar. Meat and eggs are good, and fruit and vegetables are good. Don't eat too much of any one food and don't eat so much that you become overweight.* Drink plenty of water* Keep active, but do not severely overexert yourself physically.* Drink alcohol in moderation only* DO NOT SMOKE CIGARETTES* Avoid stress, work at a job you like, be happy with your family.This is just such a great and simple list, I had to type it out for those who can't read/afford the book. (Note that Pauling comments that the amounts given for supplements are for healthy people, and that those suffering serious illness may need higher doses of some of these, including vitamin C to bowel tolerance.)It's appalling that more than 20 years after this book was published, the same old scaremongering (ie. lying!) about the safety of vitamins and their effectiveness is still going on, and people are still being told vitamins are not safe, helpful or necessary and that all that is needed is a balanced diet. (A nice story, but one that isn't based on fact.) Sadly, the same old nonsense that Pauling describes, where vitamin studies are set up to fail by those who want to prove that vitamins don't work, is still happening; doses much smaller than would be effective are used, the time periods are too short to allow the vitamin to actually work, and so on. Many different studies are quoted in a lot of detail, thus Pauling's arguments are very convincing.Pauling had high hopes that all this was about to start changing and that soon vitamins would become far more accepted and used in mainstream medicine. To some extent that has happened, but for the most part little has really changed. It's quite depressing.I'm very passionate about vitamin C due to the amazing books on it I have read, and all the accounts by doctors that were or are vitamin C experts and also because of the impact it has had on my own life and the lives of others I know. I got this book of Pauling's because I had heard that it went into detail about why humans lost the ability to synthesise vitamin C, and why it is almost impossible to regain this ability even if it would not be very beneficial for humans to do so. And it did. I now understand that issue much better than I did before.Other excellent vitamin C books include Ascorbate: The Science of Vitamin C and Vitamin C: The Real Story, the Remarkable and Controversial Healing Factor and The Healing Factor: "Vitamin C" Against Disease (available free online) plus articles online by Dr Cathcart and Dr Klenner and most of all probably, the books Primal Panacea and 'Curing the Incurable: Vitamin C, Infectious Diseases, and Toxins' by the brilliant Dr T Levy. These last 2 books are about the only ones I know of which also discuss liposomal vitamin C which allows you to get many/all of the benefits of IVC orally. Liposomal vitamin C is wonderful stuff whether you're using it to maintain health, prevent or treat a cold or flu or any other disease.A big thank you to all the vitamin C pioneers!Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

I found this product much easier to use than the Himalayan Institute one. If you have weakness in your arms (as I do) then the more ergonomic design of this pot really does make it easier and more comfortable to use.The design of this pot makes you use less arm strength to hoold it up as you don't have to hold it so far away from your face. You can hold it up by kind of bracing your arm against your face. It also means it holds more water so you can do both nostrils on one fill, and the pot also spills a lot less often due to the spill barrier it has.Used daily the neti pot has made an amazing difference to my allergies and sinus pain due to allergies. It just makes so much sense to do this before you consider taking pills to just suppress the symptoms. Having allergies and not using a neti pot daily is madness! It helps so much and is so easy. It takes only a minute and a half a day and while slightly annoying to do, is not at all hard or unpleasant to do once you get the hang of it.I'm often surprised by how well I can breathe after doing a neti pot in the morning, how much doing one has reduced or gotten rid of a headache and even sometimes a fuzzy brain...and how quickly the endless sneezing and sinus pain comes back if I forget to do it for a week or so.If you aren't suffering with arm strength issues etc. and don't mind refilling your pot a bit more often then both pots are probably close to equally good and all that matters is that you use them often. Both pots are very good but I prefer this one hands down.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

I found the Ancient Secrets neti pot product much easier to use than this Himalayan Institute one. If you have weakness in your arms (as I do) then the more ergonomic design of this pot really does make it easier and more comfortable to use.The design of this pot makes you use less arm strength to hoold it up as you don't have to hold it so far away from your face. You can hold it up by kind of bracing your arm against your face.
