Both pots are very good but I do prefer the shorter chunkier Ancient Sectrets one.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This 1979 book is an interesting read. It is a bit dated and the book would likely be very different if written today yet it is also true that the same core issues of ignorance and corruption in medicine remain. Hospitals are still causing lots of unnecessary suffering for their patients and for many doctors their `high and mighty' attitude is as present as ever.  To get the best care we need to question established medical practice and all of our doctors, as much as possible. The medical profession is very slow to change and slow to admit they were wrong about anything, if they admit it at all. Mainsteam medicine and media is so far behind when it comes to the best health information in many fields. You have to do your own unbiased research and be your own advocate.If only more doctors and more importantly PATIENTS understood that 'every drug stresses and hurts your body in some way' and that 'doctors are not trained to attack the core of any problem, merely to suppress symptoms' as this author explains. Ignorant doctors with good intentions can still do a lot of harm.I disagree with the `universal healthcare is bad' message of the author's and a few other things but this is still a funny and sharp and useful book that is worth reading, if not that high up on my recommended health books list due to there being so many other must-read titles.Linus Pauling, Dr Abram Hoffer, Dr Sheery Rogers and others have brilliant books out on this topic.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

After reading all the glowing reviews of this book I found the book itself quite underwhelming. What this does well is explain the basics of kidney disease and the tests used to diagnose and monitor it. It is a good basic guide or very simple beginners guide.Even with the basics I often found parts of the book too brief to tell me what I wanted to know and I ended up doing lots of extra internet searches to clarify points the book made. I wont ever read this book again and I don't think it was a good value purchase for me.The information about being a major participant in your own healthcare was good. The advice to get two or three second opinions and that does so is not cowardice but wisdom, is also good.The dietary advice is mixed. Advice to avoid allergens and gluten in the diet was good to see (as many experts point to links between food allergies and gluten and kidney disorders), but advice to eat soy and lots of whole grains and to avoid saturated fat in the diet is misguided.For anyone considering buying this book primarily for the discussion of `complementary therapies' it contains I would say don't bother. I was hoping for information that was specific to kidney disease and which also talked about any particular issues kidney patients may have with supplementation. Things that are needed in higher amounts than usual or things which should be avoided, or avoided by some perhaps. But it was all very brief and superficial and generic. It wasn't all that up-to-date either. You could easily get information of this quality online in just a few minutes of internet searching. You can get instructions to take small doses of a few random things such as CoQ10 anywhere!Maintaining good vitamin D levels is mentioned as is taking higher amounts of B1 to lessen protein in the urine. Meditation, probiotics and losing weight are recommended. Unfortunately the myth about high dose vitamin C causing kidney stones is included in the book (for the facts on this see `Primal Panacea' by Dr T. Levy.) Diuretic drugs are mentioned but only really as a way of lowering blood pressure. The difference between mineral sparing herbal or other diuretics vs. diuretic drugs which can dangerously deplete minerals such as magnesium wasn't discussed.I was surprised that stinging nettle herb as tea or capsules and asparagus extract tea or capsules weren't mentioned as these two things have helped me enormously due to their diuretic actions and the way they let you drink a lot more water and so flush your kidneys out really well. I was put onto them by a friend that has had kidney issues and decided to give them a try after researching their effctiveness and suitability online and in books. The extra kidney flushing these products allowed seemed to be just what I needed.Mostly drug based treatments are supported and few warnings are given about the drugs recommended. Books such as `Is Your Cardiologist Killing You?' and `Detoxify or Die' and others explain that the Ace inhibitors or blood pressure medications recommended in this book can in fact have catastrophic effects on your health and that treating the actual causes of the issues that led to the drug prescription makes so much more sense. But this book talks barely at all about what may cause kidney problems and treating these causes once found. Mostly it is aimed at finding good ways to suppress symptoms using drugs. Many drugs are recommended including statin drugs and few warnings are given about them. For real information about finding and treating causes of disease I recommend books by Dr Sherry Rogers and others.I'm not reviewing this book as someone that has even stage 1 or 2 kidney disease. I do not have kidney disease as such luckily. My tests don't show that. Just mild unspecified kidney problems of 12 months duration which with some treatment interventions are improving as each month passes.This book explains the kidneys can be `stunned' by illness or dehydration and that detoxification issues or dehydration can lead to various kidney issues. I have some sort of mild kidney issue and have done for about a year now and it may be caused by dehydration while doing a dedicated detoxification regime (?) or things I have done in the past such as eat a higher protein diet for a few years. It may also just be the latest lovely part of the severe neurological disease I have called Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (M.E.) which also affects all organs and all metabolic and detoxification functions. Some patients with M.E. do have kidney disease so there does seem to be a link there. I am just not sure, and I'd hoped to find out more about `other' kidney problems which aren't strictly diagnosable kidney disease or kidney stones or a UTI in this book but I had no such luck.This topic was barely discussed which was a shame as I would have loved to have gotten some answers for my own case. All I can do is keep going doing what I am doing I guess and hope it disappears soon. I was eating very well and allergen and gluten-free and taking a basic orthomolecular program already and so have just added to it daily nettle tea and asparagus capsules and a higher and more consistent (and focused on early morning drinking) water intake - plus extra liposomal vitamin C for when I get mild fevers or pain related to my kidneys etc. The C is a lifesaver and so are the two herbal diuretics. So far so good. I'm improving constantly if slowly so I suppose I can't complain.Overall this book is good on the basics of kidney disease diagnosis and testing, contains the standard basic drug recommendations and a tiny amount of mixed diet and supplement advice. It is a very short and simple read that will probably leave you with more questions to ask than answered. Best wishes to everyone battling serious kidney disease.Update December 2013: I have just found out the actual cause of my unusual kidney issues! It was damage to the nerves in my bladder (and kidney too?) caused by severe vitamin B12 deficiency. Demyelination of the nerves. If this had not been discovered when it was or in the next year or two I would have ended up eventually doubly incontinent and possibly unable to walk. So if you have any unusual bladder or kidney issues such as burning kidney pain and UTI-like symptoms (with normal or abnormal UTI tests), oedema, feelings of incomplete bladder emptying, inability to start urination and a hard bloated stomach please look into vitamin B12 deficiency and at least rule it out. The book Could It Be B12?: An Epidemic of Misdiagnoses will tell you all you need to know.It's one of the few health isuses where treatment is very simple once correctly diagnosed and if caught in time the damage can all be reversed. I'm doing great and am only about 40 days into treatment. It'd be great if the author talked about this common cause of kidney and bladder issues in future editions of this book.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

It's flawed in parts but I got a lot out of this book overall. The core messages of this book are solid and timely; Listen to your body and eat real food that makes you feel good. Starving yourself to be thinner ends in weight gain for most of us and a raising of your set-point weight, so don't do it. Move in ways that make you feel good without worrying about burning calories. Don't pay attention to super-skinny ideals or weight-loss-diet-hype and just do what works for you and makes you feel healthiest. Skinniness is not the same as healthiness and it is the latter which is most important.The writing of the book seemed clumsy at times. I feel the main points could have been put more simply and that some of the text was too long and meandering in getting to a point.The parts on accepting and finding your set-point weight were quite good. One of the strongest parts of the book was the letters at the back of the book which were to give to family to let them know it'd be great if they made no positive or negative comments about your size changing because you're focusing on health and not mere weight change. A letter for doctors was also included.There are also some not-so-good parts of this book. I feel this book would have been a lot stronger if the sections on nutrition were omitted entirely and the book just made the points about health being more important than weight more clearly and powerfully. The author should focus on the topic she really knows a lot about.The nutrition information in this book really is bad. It's basically a description of the food pyramid. 30% of calories from fat is talked about as way too much fat - this despite the fact lipid experts such as Mary Enig PhD say that for some of us 30% is nowhere near enough dietary fat. 10% of calories from protein is said to be too high a protein intake. So what you're left with is a diet that is probably 70% or more carbohydrate. That is a level many of us just cannot cope with and which makes us feel constantly starving hungry, ill and weak even after meals. Not to mention making us gain weight like crazy even if we're putting everything we have into eating in a healthy way.For some of us eating beans counts as a hungry-making starch food, not a protein food. Not telling readers that some people just can't cope with high-carb diets and are not suited to them sets them up for failure following the HAES plan and then blaming themselves for it. The same is true for people with food allergies to common foods such as grains and soy. Eating foods you are allergic to makes you crave them, it is one of the symptoms. The concept of eating the same old junk but in moderation just doesn't work for many of us. It sets us up to fail.The message to enjoy junk foods and other not-so-healthy common foods in moderation is problematic. Some of us physically can't eat these foods in moderation, that is the whole problem. They do things to our bodies which shut off our bodies natural satiety signals and make us feel unwell afterwards too - or constantly unwell if we eat them often enough. This subject is tackled brilliantly in the book `A Life Unburdened' - I highly recommend it. It also explains why saturated fat is a healthy food that is good for you, along with cholesterol-containing foods! It is the new fangled unnatural fats which don't suit us, not the ones we have been eating for tens of thousands of years such as animal fat.There is so much wrong information in the nutritional chapters, but it's also very badly written and constantly contradicts itself. The research quality is poor. The author says we have virtually the same genes today as our Paleolithic ancestors had so we will do best eating the same diet they did - a diet which gave animal foods very special importance. Then she says that because of industrial meat farming practices the best way to emulate a Paleo diet today is to eat a diet of mostly plants with meat there as a condiment only or avoided entirely because everyone knows meat and animal fat is unhealthy. Ummm...what?High-fibre (highly processed) breakfast cereals are super healthy and so are highly-processed foods such as tofu says the author. The huge problems with soy as a staple food (as explained in books like `The Whole Soy Story') are never mentioned. The problems with anti-nutrients in whole grains are never mentioned as of course are the ways to soak and otherwise prepare grains to reduce them. The book repeats lots of myths about fibre and omits information that explains that for some of us a lower fibre diet and fibre from vegetables and fruits only (and not grains) suits us best. No amount of fibre in your diet will make your meals satisfying to you if you aren't eating enough fat in your diet, or protein.Accurate information on eating what our ancestors ate and the foods our genes are best suited to is in books such as `Primal Body, Primal Mind.'I'm not convinced by the `thrify gene' theory this book puts so much importance in. A few good books - such as `Good Calories, Bad Calories' - have done a great job debunking this myth far more convincingly. Seeing how ignorant and misled the author was on basic nutrition theory it also made it hard to have much faith in the quality of some of the more novel ideas on body chemistry and weight regulation put forth in this book.At the end of one of the nutrition chapters the author says that if in doubt eat food that is as whole as possible and as minimally messed with as possible. That should have been the entire nutrition section really. Eating what makes you feel good makes sense but doing so when guided by a bit of basic nutrition knowledge is essential too, especially if you have any health or nutrition issues. It helps you better understand the messages your body is trying to send you.I give the sections on focusing on health and not the scales 4.5 out of 5. I give the nutrition section 1 out of 5 so have settled on a 3 star rating overall. I'd love to see an updated edition of this book that was much shorter and sharper and that omitted all nutrition information. I'd buy several copies for friends and family. But right now I couldn't give anyone a book with such problematic nutrition information in it.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This book is written by an expert in the field and contains a lot of good information. Dr Ian E. Brighthope talks in this book about the different types of diabetes (there are more than just two), the vital need to avoid junk food, sugar and large amounts of processed starch, and the need for properly dosed and chosen nutritional supplements along with a healthy diet.This book contains only a very small amount of dietary information and what is included could be of better quality to be fair. The information on sugar being a toxic chemical is very good. But the awful DASH diet is supported, despite the fact the science on low-salt diets is dodgy and unrefined sea salt has many health benefits. So is the Mediterranean diet, with lots of legumes and starch in. Only a sentence or so is included about the need for some people to limit carbohydrate intake quite severely, and that some people do best eliminating foods such as legumes and grains. Food allergies or intolerances or macronutrient ratios are not mentioned at all.What this book does really well is explain which supplements are most important for people with diabetes and why. It covers the basics and is a great starting point although it really doesn't go into looking into your own nutrient levels with tests, or finding your own individual illness triggers or causes and that sort of thing. Clear information is given about dosages. The doses recommended are up-to-date and not the too-low-to-do-much-good ones contained in many books and especially older books. The book also doesn't neglect the basic necessary nutrients in favour of discussing herbs or other non-vital products, as many books do. Taking herbs and other fancy and exotic things before making sure you have the basic necessary vitamins etc. covered is madness!The book warns readers throughout to get help with working out dosages from a qualified practitioner if at all possible, and especially if you think you need to take some items are the higher dosages listed. It takes quite a cautious approach to some extent.I did find one error in the book that should have been picked up by the editor. The section on vitamin B2 says that the maximum safe dosage is 5-10 mg daily which seems to be an error. This is bizarrely low for a start but also later in the book a B100 supplement is recommended to be taken daily. B100 supplements contain 100 mg of vitamin B2 (riboflavin). The dosages of vitamin C generally recommended also seemed quite low (1-4 grams daily minimum) when considered with the safety, affordability and usefulness of far higher doses. A dose of 10-20 grams is mentioned at one point though along with vitamin C given by IV.I don't have diabetes, only hyperinsulinism, hypoglycaemia and a PCOS diagnosis, along with having a severe neurological disease that is slowly improving through the use of orthomolecular medicine etc. I read this book because I wanted to check out the cut of Dr Brighthope's jib because he's the only Australian on the Journal of Orthomolecular Medicine board.If your major health issue is diabetes this book is a good one to read. It gives you an excellent overview of supplements for this condition. To read good quality and far more detailed books on diet there's The Schwartzbein Principle, Primal Body, Primal Mind or The Perfect Health Diet and many others. Not much point taking lots of supplements if your diet is poor as it'd impede your progress enormously.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This book is an interesting and compelling read. After detailing some fascinating experiments on regrowing limbs and detailing the electrical systems of animals the author explains that there is a massive bias towards establishment and authority rather than facts. Medicine is operating more like a religion than a science and new ideas are suppressed or ridiculed and their originators often punished.Scientists' pronouncements are often self serving and misleading. We're learning more and more about less and less. Studies on trivial topics are often funded while important research gets no support as it threatens the status quo. Yet the public largely thinks that the study of medicine is based on science and logic.This book explains that promise of a future of golden health and extended life thanks to wonder drugs and fancy new surgical techniques and the like turns out to be empty. The body has an amazing capacity to heal, but only if we give it the tools it needs to do so - adequate nutrition and all the necessary vitamins and minerals etc.Keeping pollution to tolerable levels is also vital for health and EMF pollution, the author explains, is at least as dangerous as air pollution or common toxic exposures. At the moment we're all participating in a giant experiment to see how harmful EMFs really are. We need to know more about EMF issues but a multitude of risks are well already well documented. For more on this topic including practical tips on minimising the health problems EMFs can cause the book on 'grounding' called  Earthing: The Most Important Health Discovery Ever? by Martin Zucker is worth a read.Lots of drawings and descriptions of cutting off limbs from frogs and salamanders are included in the first part of the book. Readers squeamish about animal experiments may find parts of this book difficult to read.Reading the findings and also problems and unfair criticism and political opposition faced by those with genuinely new ideas on health and healing is wonderful and inspiring but also somewhat depressing. We need many more scientists with this much integrity, intelligence, logic and insight to even make a dent in the corrupt corporate medicine system we have. Year after year the quality of medical studies gets worse. The drugs-are-the answer-for everything marketing hype gets ever more shrill and monotonous and detracts ever more from real medicine based on reason and scientific fact.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This is a useful little book for anyone due to have a hospital stay in the near future and also just anyone interested in getting the best health outcomes for themselves and their family generally.Some of the facts and statistics given in this book are shocking. It doesn't sugar-coat any of the grim facts but it also provides a lot of reason for hope and positivity in the way it describes how to improve your outcomes and empower yourself.This book explains that:* Corporate medicine is one of the 10 leading causes of death in the US. It kills tens of thousands of people every year. Problems include financial conflicts of interest, poor management, complacency and misinformation, a lack of focus on personal health responsibility and many others.* It is not actually clear whether hospitals give benefit or not, overall. Emergency medicine saves many lives but it is not clear whether this and other interventions outweighs all those killed by drug side effects, drug interactions, DVTs, hospital-borne infections, and so on.* Hospitals should be avoided unless absolutely necessary. They are dangerous places to be.* 30% of patients that die in hospital die due to a misdiagnosis. Misdiagnosis is a huge problem.* Many doctors do not read tests or study results properly and do not understand complex statistics. This ignorance is taken advanatge of by drug comapnies to make certain drugs appear far more effective than they actually are.* It's rational to be paranoid about corporate medicine and hospitals. Medicine based on personal bias and profit doesn't give the best outcomes. Trusting authority is not the same as supporting good science.* Polypharmacy is dangerous. Each drug has risks of side effects and very time a new drug is added it has its own risk of side effects as well plus extra risks due to drug interactions. Drugs should be kept to a small number and minimised as much as possible. Many drugs have vitamin or mineral alternatives which are very safe, effective and inexpensive.* Don't be talked into taking any drug to prevent a disease you don't have. Avoid statins and daily aspirin.* Medicine has a shameful history of following authority rather than data and reason. The new term 'evidence based medicine' is misleading to say the least.* Psychiatry is not scientific. "Psychiatrists should realise that their discipline is not scientific and would be well advised to show a little humility."* Producing negative studies on nutrition and vitamins is very easy to do and is often done to suit the interests of certain vested interest groups such as drug companies. Studies designed to fail often use the wrong form of the nutrient, in the wrong dose, without supportive nutrients and/or with too short a follow-up time. Any treatment can be 'proved' to be ineffective if the study is set up in a certain way.* Many doctors are ethical and caring and would not knowingly harm a patient. The problem is with the way medicine is organised and controlled.The book outlines many problems but also spends a lot of time talking about solutions as well.Information is included on how to negotiate with your doctor, the importance of developing a good relationship with your doctor, how much should you defer to your doctor and when should you stop trying to negotiate, what your rights are to refuse or demand a treatment, what your rights are with taking your own supplements in hospital, how to win medical arguments or at least lose less often, how much should you expect a doctor to listen to you and your own research findings, why making idle threats of legal action or backing doctors into a corner may get you worse medical care than you'd have gotten otherwise, and lots more.Some of the most helpful information given was on how to choose a good doctor and what questions to ask before you agree to see them and pay for a consult.The book also provides a very easy to read and follow beginners guide to orthomolecular medicine that can be used before and after surgery to speed healing, to prevent DVTs and bedsores, to treat heart disease, or to prevent illness and improve health generally. The doses recommended are up-to-date and not the too-low-to-do-much-good ones contained in many books and especially older books. The book also doesn't neglect the basic necessary nutrients in favour of discussing herbs or other non-vital products, as many books do. Taking herbs and other fancy and exotic things before making sure you have the basic necessary vitamins etc. covered is madness!One in ten hospital deaths are due to clotting issues. A simple nutritional protocol is included which can cut the risk of DVT dramatically when taken before and after a hospital stay. It involves basic supplements such as high-dose vitamin C, fish oil, and vitamin E etc.  Vitamin C at an appropriate dose can improve your changes of surviving a hospital stay significantly. 3 - 10 grams a day (preferably 10 grams) is a minimal dose and if possible a bowel tolerance dose is best. A bowel tolerance dose varies from person to person and how ill a person is; the more ill you are the more vitamin C your body needs.This book does just focus on doctor and hospital related issues and so doesn't contain enough information on how to really get stuck into healing serious disease with orthomolecular medicine. For that one needs to read some of the other books by these authors, or others such as Linus Pauling, Dr T. Levy, Dr Sherry Rogers etc. This book also has little information on diet aside from a few general comments about avoiding junk food and sugar - and most food served in hospitals.I'd have liked a lot more information about the huge problem of misdiagnosis and the disastrous-for-patients use of wastebasket diagnoses. But that is a personal bias I guess. These let the doctor off the hook by giving the patient a meaningless label instead of a real diagnosis and also stops anyone looking for the real cause of symptoms. Many are labelled as mentally ill or with motivational or attitude probelms or malingering when they in fact have a physical disease too. Wastebasket diagnoses have enormous benefits for medical insurance companies as well, which seems to be their main purpose. Many payouts are far smaller for 'controversial' or psychiatric diseases than they would be for the patient's correct diagnosis of a real and physical disease. Diseases caused by chemical exposures, prescription drugs and poor food quality are also conveniently hidden. It is a huge problem which affects some of our most ill and vulnerable people. It's hidden in plain sight with most people having no idea about the issue at all.Dr Abram Hoffer is a very well respected orthomolecular pioneer and has authored many books on the topic. He died in 2009 and this was the last book he worked on. Dr Hoffer has a very long history with having to try and battle the current medical system to try and get the best outcomes for his patients. Along with the other authors, he really knows what he is talking about on this topic.Overall this book is very good. The authors have done a great job with it and should be congratulated. It contains lots of information essential to us all. It could be really helpful for lots of people or even life-saving, especially for those not already acquainted with basic orthomolecular medicine principles.This book advises readers to act rationally when making health decisions and to think for themselves and not trust doctors or any other medical authority, blindly. Being compliant and just doing and thinking what you're told is not the way to get your best health outcome. It is very had to argue with that!Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This is an excellent product, but I have to say I'm not a fan of some of the very overstated claims and hype on the Unique E website which imply theirs is the only safe and effective product to take. Carlson products are also very good, and very similar, and their labelling is better and clearer as well without use of vague terms like 'proprietary blend' which set my warning bells ringing just a bit. How much gamma does this product have? I think I read it listed as 30% on their website but why can't this be stated clearly on the label?There is a pump pack version of this product but it is so much cheaper and probably a lot easier to buy the Unique E capsules instead and just cut them open and eat the contents, if you want to take as few gelatin capsules as possible. If you snip a capsule with scissors once across the middle then put it in your mouth and bite down on it a few times you can easily swallow all the E and then you just take the empty smashed up capsule out of your mouth and throw it away. The taste is fine as it is with other very good quality E products such as Carlsons.This product is also made from GMO soy oil I assume as it does not say non-GMO or organic on the label (although I'm told apparently the site now says it's non GMO. Perhaps this changed recently?). I feel the labelling and marketing is a bit misleading on this issue. Even if the soy is highly refined and so no longer an allergy risk, some of us would prefer soy- and clearly labelled 100% certainty GMO-free products anyway. It'd be great if the company made a non-soy version.

By my costings a dose of Unique E in a capsule costs 26 cents, while the same dose in this pump pack costs you 43c! Almost double. I had assumed the pump pack version would be cheaper but the pump bottle must add a lot to the cost of the product. So far the pump dispenser is working well for me, maybe because the weather is warm so far. I'm not sure how it'll go in winter. I wonder if this product would be a lot more cost effective if the bottle held more than a measly 30 ml/1 floz?As it is the only reason to buy this product is if you want your supplements to be 100% vegan.Otherwise it is so much cheaper and probably a lot easier to buy the Unique E capsules instead and just cut them open and eat the contents, if you want to take as few galatin capsules as possible. If you snip a capsule with scissors once across the middle then put it in your mouth and bite down on it a few times you can easily swallow all the E and then you just take the empty smashed up capsule out of your mouth and throw it away. The taste is fine.I've contacted the company that makes this and they said the pump pack version is expensive compared to the capsules because of the lower number of units sold. (BTW they answered my questions very well and quickly - they have great customer service.)This is an excellent product, but I have to say I'm not a fan of some of the very overstated claims and hype on the Unique E website which imply theirs is the only safe and effective product to take. Carlson products are also very good, and very similar, and their labelling is better and clearer as well without use of vague terms like 'proprietary blend' which set my warning bells ringing just a bit. This product is also made from GMO soy oil. I feel the labelling is a bit misleading on this issue. Even if the soy is highly refined and so no longer an allergy risk, some of us would prefer soy- and GMO-free products anyway.It'd be great if the company made a non-soy version.

This product's website says that if you take their 2 E products you'll be getting all all 4 tocotrienols and all 4 tocopherols yet the label of this their tocotrienols product says it has delta-T3 (90%) and gamma-T3 (10%). Where are the alpha and beta tocotrienols? It is confusing.I have read that alpha tocotrienol has particular benefits but it seems like this product has none of that at all. "Each beef softgel capsule contains High-Delta and Gamma Delta-Gold Tocotrienols derived from the Annatto Bean and contains the highest concentrates of tocotrienols at 125 mg per gel capsule."The capsule is the tiniest I have seen which I really like. I've been cutting mine open and eating the contents. A strange taste lingers for a while afterwards (unlike other milder tasting tocotrienol products I have had before) but it isn't too bad.Until the issue with this product only having two of the four tocotrienols is cleared up though I am going to go back to the Carlson's Tocotrienols product which is also very pure and which clearly lists the exact amounts of all four tocotrienol dosages on the label.This product would also be better in a 180 capsule count rather than just 60, to save on plastic a bit.I have to say I'm also not a fan of some of the very overstated claims and hype on the Unique E website which imply theirs is the only safe and effective product to take. Carlson products are also very good, and very similar, and their labelling is better and clearer as well without use of vague terms like 'proprietary blend' which set my warning bells ringing just a bit.UPDATE: I've contacted the company that makes this and they have confirmed that yes, this product does only contain two of the four tocotrienols. So that wasn't any type of misprint and it seems this is a poor choice of tocotrienols product as it contains only 2 of the 4 types.

This short book is written in a light conversational tone and much of the practical advice given is quite lightly explained as well. If you haven't read this sort of book before and you're affected by food and chemical sensitivities it could have a significant impact on you all the same, both emotional and physical.The author talks about her experiences with anaphalaxis type food allergy, and in a much more limited way, about MCSS. Despite the title and what the author says in the book this isn't really a book that focuses on primary MCSS and what she means by terms like Fibromyalgia and 'chronic fatigue' are probably different (as they often are) to how others may define them. Symptoms are not the same thing as diseases.But if you have the same type of food allergies the author does you may find her personal story interesting, and in particular her tips for minimising an allergic reaction once it's triggered and how to travel when you have very specific food and environment needs.The book provides an okay quality introduction to how leaky gut problems can be caused and how they can lead to other health issues.The author became ill after taking NSAIDs which can, and in her case did, cause leaky gut syndrome. Leaky gut syndrome can then lead to other health problems such as problems coping with foods and various chemicals, the author explains.The book discusses elimination diets, some supplements, lymphatic massage, colonics and enemas (with colonics being a far better choice), juicing, dry skin brushing, castor oil packs, digestive enzymes, Candida and dysbiosis. It also talks about the dangers of taking daily aspirin and NSAIDs.The information on treatment given in this book overlaps with that given by many others, including Dr Sherry Rogers. But this book contains only about a fifth of the information given in Dr Sherry Roger's book, it misses out so much important information. Some of the information is incorrect as well. Raw foods are actually much harder to digest than cooked ones and especially so if you are ill and have poor gut function. To see a book about allergies and MCSS that recommends such a paltry amount of vitamin C was disappointing, for example. That alone is a huge omission. Vitamin C is so essential if you have these health issues, not just a few grams but a proper bowel tolerance dose. It is essential long-term but also very helpful when you need to quickly treat yourself after eating an allergic food etc. It helps so much!Considering that this book uses Dr Rogers' books as a reference I thought it was very misleading that on the back cover it is claimed that this is the first book of its kind. That is not true and just marketing hype. The title and design of this book is pretty hypey and not great as well. I was surprised the book was as good as it was, considering the cheesy title!To learn about how to treat leaky gut and symptoms of food and chemical sensitivity I would highly recommend Detoxify or Die by Dr Sherry Rogers, which talks about detoxification, nutrition, supplementation and the use of FIR saunas for detoxification, plus her book on healing the gut as well. They are both absolutely brilliant and essential. Very good information on healing the gut is in the GAPS diet book too.These treatments work, but the better quality and more comprehensive the information you have the more successful you'll likely be. This book may be a good basic introduction but its far too light on the basics to be anyone's one book to rely on. It's worth a read though if your library has a copy, I think.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

This book explains that it's not true that we have total control over our health, but nor is it true we have no control. The truth is somewhere in the middle.The author also explains that symptoms are not small issues that should be ignored or suppressed, but warning signs that we need to change some things in our environment before these small problems become large ones. Just suppressing a symptom or ignoring it allows the disease progress to continue and to become more pronounced, it only fixes the problem in the very short term at best.Our health is not just chance it is aligned to a large extent with our habits.There is a bit of anti-dietary-fat and pro-carbs, soy and grains bias in this book that it'd have been far better without, and few actual orthomolecular recommendations, and there are a huge number of questionaires on different topics to fill out if you'd like to too.The core principles outlined in this book are just as timely today as when this book was written, even if parts of the exact advice given have changed and become outdated. This book covers much of the same ground as The Wonderful World Within You by Dr Roger J. Williams. This book is worth a read, but the Dr Williams book is easily my favourite of the two as I am just a big fan of his writing style.This book is available as a cheapie used book and a free digital edition is also available.Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

The author of this book is Dr Roger J. Williams, author of the highly regarded 'Biochemical Individuality' book - a real health book classic. He is also the person who discovered pantothenic acid (vitamin B5). As well as being a very intelligent and compassionate writer, Dr Williams was also a good writer and this book was very easy to read and understand as well as friendly and engaging.This book says it's part of the movement to abolish nutritional illiteracy and a layman's guide to biochemical individuality.The book starts with some photographs which show very clearly what difference diet and nutrition can make to health and growth and development, using rats as an example.There is a lot of information here about biochemical individuality. It's an important concept to understand in terms of maintaining and improving health but it's also just interesting. The author talks about how our differences affect our aptitude and liking for different activities, for example.For growth and maintenance we need over 40 different nutrients and these can be grouped into vitamins, major minerals, trace minerals, amino acids and others. How much we need of each varies considerably due to biochemcial individuality. We also need higher levels of nutrients for reproduction. lack of certain nutrients in utero are why certain organs become the target organ when the body is stressed by a nutrient deficiency etc.This book is an oldie but a goodie, absolutely. Some of the information is outdated and of course the dosages listed for many nutrients are far lower than you'd see in similar books today, and so other books should be used to determine exact dosages that are customary and recognised as safe, but this book still has value. The main message of this book is just as relevant today as it was when this book was first published in 1977.Many illnesses are caused by nutrients deficiencies and so there is real hope for treatment because nutrient deficiencies can be treated. Prevention of disease is even better and easier. A junk-free diet and intelligent supplementation have enormous potential to keep us well and to improve or cure disease. Given the right materials the body is a wonderful and remarkably self-healing machine. Orthomolecular medicine works.As well as cheapie used printed versions a free digital edition is also available. Either way this book is worth a read. The main theories in this book are timeless and so important for more of us to understand.Some quotes by Dr Williams:'Normal individuals are highly distinctive with respect to their stomachs, esophagi, hearts, blood vessels, bloods, thoracic ducts, livers, pelvic colons, sinuses, breathing patterns, muscles and their system of endocrine glands. In all of these cases inborn differences are observed which are often far beyond what we see externally.'"The basic answer to the question "Why are you an individual?" is that your body in every detail, including your entire nervous system and your brain (thinking apparatus) is highly distinctive. You are not built like anyone else. You owe some of your individuality to the fact that you have been influenced uniquely by your environment, which is not like anyone else's. But from all that may be known about basic inborn individuality ... it seems clear that the amount of individuality we would possess if we were all born with exactly the same detailed equipment would be puny, indeed, compared with the individuality we actually possess."'Every individual organism that has a distinctive genetic background has distinctive nutritional needs which must be met for optimal well-being.'Jodi Bassett, The Hummingbirds' Foundation for M.E. (HFME) and Health, Healing & Hummingbirds (HHH)

Dress it up with a shrug and heels, or downplay the design with simple flats--this maxi dress does any occasion beautifully!  I will say right off the bat that it is long, and unless you are super tall (I'm talking 6'), you will need to throw in a hem.  Beyond that, however, I found this to be just the perfect version, for me, of a little black dress.I love the detailing here--especially the patterning on the bottom of the skirt.  It adds such depth to the dress!  The gathered waist line softens the appearance of any bumps or imperfections, and the fold over bodice with bow will enhance any cleavage. The feminine straps add to the sexy allure, whilst the dual layering of the skirt allows it to flow fluidly over the body.Highly recommended!  Note that I did receive a discount on this dress in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

0:59 Mins I ordered this William Wang creation in rose to match a pink tourmaline ring my husband recently gifted to me.  The sparkle of this piece truly outshines and out sparkles the ring!  What really surprised me when this pendant arrived was the sheer size.  This gorgeous stone is a little over 1/2" wide and is a statement piece that has elicited gasps from friends and family.The stone is Swarovski Crystal and in keeping with the Swarovski tradition of excellence, is faceted to capture every bit of light.  That light is reflected in prisms of sparkle that dance and provide the illusion of movevent in a way that is breathtaking.  The pink rose color is rich and deep and is enhanced by the clear stones set atop the pendant.  The setting is a polished platinum that gleams, as is the 18.5" snake chain with 3" extender.  I love the fact that I can adjust this to fit perfectly in the hollow of my neck.I cannot recommend this gorgeous necklace highly enough!  Wear it with jeans and a sweater or an evening gown--that's how versatile this necklace is in presentation.  Note that I received a discount on this in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This solar spot is exactly what we needed to illuminate our American flag at night.  One of our neighbors to whom we are very close recently found out their son was being deployed to the Middle East.  They are a proud family, but mom is understandably scared to death.  We wanted to be supportive and did something we should have done years ago--erected an American flag.  We promised her to keep it illuminated every night until he comes home safely.  This spot has helped us to keep our word.Initially, we used a wired spot.  Unfortunately, the timer we had attached failed miserably, so we found ourselves out late at night to turn it on, then again early in the morning to shut it off.  When I saw this spot, I wondered if our increasingly shorter and overcast days would effect the performance, but I knew I wanted to give it a go.  I'm so glad I did.  We have had this installed for a week now, and without fail, it comes in at dusk and shuts off at dawn.  The light at night is bright and vibrant, and it brings attention to the flag in Scott's honor.Overall, highly recommended.  Note that I received a discount on this spot in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I ordered this headset for those times when I'm sitting at my computer and want a comfortable listening experience with noise cancellation, as our home is constantly abuzz with activity.  I couldn't be more pleased.First, these are wired headphones, which for me means a far clearer sound than I am able to get form Bluetooth devices.  In fact, the sound from these is quite impressive at this sub $30 price point.  The bass is warm and rich whilst the treble captures the high end frequencies without the annoying tin.  I get zero distortion even when listening at what some would consider to be deafening volume (blame it on those concerts in the eighties).  The padded ear piece covers are super comfortable, even when worn for extended periods of time, and the portability factor is off the charts with the great folding design.Overall, highly recommended!  Note that I received a discount on these headphones in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I ordered these screen protectors to help to safeguard what was a fairly substantial purchase of my iPhone 6s.  I wanted something that would "disappear" upon installation and not interfere with the functionality of the touch screen. I got both!First, the protector was super easy to install with zero air bubbles.  That alone was worth it's weight in gold.  It fits perfectly and my screen continues to be super touch sensitive.  If you look closely, you can tell there is a screen protector, but it does "disappear" to the point that I can barely tell it's there when in use.Overall, with the guarantee from Maxboost, this is ano-brainier investment to protect your device.  Note that I received this at no cost in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I ordered this case to give to a friend who carries a naked iPhone 6s plus.  She insists that she appreciates the look and feel of her phone too much to add a bulky case.  As she is also a klutz, I feared for the little device's safety.The day she received this, she reluctantly installed it and was pleasantly surprised to find that it fit and felt great!  All buttons, ports and both cams were easily accessible via the accurately placed cut outs, and the clear back allowed the natural "beauty" of her phone to shine through.  After three days, however, the green bumper edge began to turn colors a bit and appeared a tad faded.  Maybe it has to do with the oils on her hands, the moisturizer she uses, or just from tossing it into her purse, but after two weeks even I agreed it just looked bad.Overall, a great case, but with the uncertainty as to the origin of the color change, I knocked off one star.  Note. That I received this case at no cost in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I love this case!  I am one of those women who carries a purse the size of small luggage.  As such, I can never find what I need without a flashlight to accompany me on my foray into the bottomless depths of my bag.  This case has changed all that!In lieu of a purse, I decided to try carrying only the essentials via this case.  I loaded up my debit and a few credit cards, my drivers license, a little cash and my phone.  Surprise, surprise--it was liberating!  Each card was easy to access, my drivers license was at the ready and I didn't need to dig for cash at the register.  In addition to that, no one had to leave a message whilst I struggled to free my phone from my bag.The case itself is aesthetically pleasing, offers my phone great protection and is well-made for durability.  All cut outs are accurately placed, meaning easy access to all the buttons, inputs and both front and rear cams.  The closure holds the case securely shut, so I know my items are all safely nestled within.Overall, a great little case!  Note that I received this at no cost in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

Great case for my iPhone 6s. I love that it's lightweight, yet provides minimal protection, especially around the corners.  The bumpers do offer absorption on impact, which I discovered after my phone went crashing to a concrete floor. The finish is a nice matte that allows for an easy grasp that discourages any slippage, and all buttons, ports and both front and rear cams are easily accessible.  No bells or whistles, lights or sparkles--just a sound case that will enhance the appearance of your phone whilst offering protection.  Note that I received this case at no cost in exchange for an honest review.

These lights are beautiful!  I love to decorate our landscaping and porch with anything that illuminates at night.  I think the effect is just stunning, and I spend a lot of time finding just the perfect lights for each area.  When I saw these, I knew I wanted to place them on our wishing well--the color shown was exactly what I needed, so I hoped they were true to the listing.  When they arrived, I was thrilled to find that the purple is even more vibrant and soft than shown.I strung these the same day I received them.  It was after eleven AM, and it was pretty overcast, so I didn't expect much the first night.  Imagine my surprise when, at dusk, the strand came on--and it was stunning!  The strand produced a soft glow that was magical!  The little flowers glowed until we went to bed some three hours later.  They were off in the morning, but each evening, despite the weather conditions, we are treated to a lovely glow of light that even the neighbors love.  We have had them up for over a week now with zero issues.  Should they become faulty, I will update this review.  Note that I received a discount on these lights in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I thought when I ordered this ice cream scoop that it would be difficult to review.  How much can you say about a scoop?  Wow, was I wrong!  First, this utensil comes packaged beautifully in a two piece box that makes it perfect for gift giving. Nothing helps heal better than ice cream!Beyond the presentation,  this scoop is wonderfully heavy and balanced, which makes it so easy to scoop even heavy ice cream blends. The handle is also ergonomically shaped for a great grasp every time with less slipping.Overall, I highly recommend this for any ice cream fanatic! These gloves are simply amazing.  I purchased two pairs--one for my husband and one for me, and we couldn't be happier.  I left this review for the other pair, but it bears repeating! These beekeeper gloves are the only gloves we will ever own for handling our lizards!  We own several Chinese Water Dragons and a particularly obstinate iguana.  When we mentioned to our pet store that they were becoming more difficult to handle, and showed the scars on my husband's lower arms from our Iggy's whipping tail, they suggested apiary gloves for protection.  This pair has proven to be perfect!First, the gloves are pliable enough to allow for a firm grasp, which is critical if you want to maintain a captive audience. The tablet even comes with a silicone case that is perfect for little hands to grasp and hang on to.Overall, this is a great first tablet with features you just won't find on sub $100 tablets. This seller obviously does, as this Milk the Cow Playset has all the components necessary to stimulate a child's mind and encourage imaginative play.Th set includes a variety of study plastic figures, as well as a tractor, wagon, wheel barrow and milking station. There are also milk cans, barrels and even signage.  Each piece is wonderfully detailed (the cows even have udders!) and vibrantly colored to hold a child's attention.  From the farmer in the tractor to the woman dressed for the job (Mrs. Farmer?), all elements add to the versatility and options for role playing and let's pretend.Overall. Highly recommended for the simplicity and possibilities!  Note that I received a discount on this set in exchange for an honest review.

0:51 Mins This two in one grinder has changed the way my family feels about my cooking!  I should start by admitting that I was a late bloomer when it comes to the kitchen.  It wasn't until I was in my 40s that I discovered that I actually enjoyed cooking.  Unfortunately, my new hobby didn't always translate into something edible.  My family's biggest complaint was that the food was bland.When I discovered this gadget, I went out in search of the types of salt and pepper to grind.  Wow, was I surprised to discover that there was a world beyond table salt!  Since my initial shopping trip, I've added a half dozen grinders to my kitchen for pink sea salt, fleur de sel, coarse salt, etc.  I've also added black, green and pink peppercorns to my repertoire, much to my family's delight.  Of all the grinders I now own, however, my two Nuvita electric grinders are by far the fastest, easiest way to get the perfect grind every time.The grinder is a two in one product, as it houses two spices (usually a salt and pepper).  The compartments are easily filled via small plastic "buckets" that emerge from the sides of the grinder when the ridge-edged dial is turned.  Once filled, a press of a button produces a customized grind that adds flavor and excitement to any dish.Overall, highly recommended.  Add six AAA batteries, and you will never use shakers again.  Note that I received this device at no cost in exchange for,an honest and unbiased review.

1:25 Mins This play mat will provide baby with hours of interaction that will stimulate the senses.  With the addition of three AA batteries, the mat lights up at the control panel and activate the mat to play music with a touch.Each area of the mat plays a different sound or song.  The fence posts at the bottom will play individual notes or songs, depending upon the chosen mode; each animal will play a sound; and the barn and little farmer play a tune.  The volume is reasonable and the lights are just bright enough to draw interest.The mat is generously sized, printed in vibrant, full color and is full of shapes and animals to hold baby's attention. 1:29 Mins This isn't your ordinary water bottle.  In fact, this is one of the smartest water bottles I've ever seen. If you aren't familiar with BPA, it's time to do a little research on the dangers.  I love that this seller has pointed out that this cup is food-grade quality stainless steel, as it just makes me more confident in the product.The cup comes in three pieces--the stainless steel lined cup, an infuser cup and the lid.  The infuser is generously sized for any fruits or herbs you may wish to add and can be removed in a snap.  The lid is the real star here, however, as with a simple touch, it displays the temperature of the contents. My single complaint is also my British husband's favorite part of this cup--the temps are displayed only in Celsius.  As such, learning to convert was, for me, a bit of a learning curve.  With that said, I love knowing that at lunch time, the soup I packed is still warm enough to be safe for consumption.Overall, brilliant idea brought to life in a most beautiful way.  It's leak proof, eerily accurate and insulated to maintain inside temps for hours.  For both form and function, this one is a winner! Well, Halloween is over and already the stores are gearing up for the holiday season with lights, ornaments and trees. 1:04 Mins This micro-copter drone by Top Race is a little high flyer you don't want to miss.  At less than 2", this amazing rolling quad goes higher, faster and further than many twice its size.The copter comes packaged with not only the remote, but also extra propellers, large side wheels that can be removed and a protective cage for new pilots.  If you get nothing else from this review, hear this:  use the cage.  The components on this drone are tiny and difficult to find should they release on impact.  The wheels and cage will protect the device and keep it intact.The remote is, admittedly, a learning curve, but if you're an experienced droner, it should be a cakewalk.  It's super sensitive, so the copter climbs very quickly and can get away from you if you're not on top of it.  I was amazed at how much height we were able to get and maintain whilst hovering.  It's difficult to capture this on video, as the size is prohibitive, but I've attached a few brief flying clips to give you some idea of the speed.Honestly, you will not be disappointed in the performance!  Highly recommended for beginners and seasoned pros.  Note that I received this rolling quad copter at no cost in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This set of colored pencils has one of the most extensive color selections I have ever seen!  From pale pink to vibrant orange to matte black, it would be a challenge to seek a shade that isn't included.These pencils come housed in what at first appears to be a convenient carrying case. This tote is not only well made, it garners quite a bit of attention.  I am a Marvel comics fanatic and have tried to impart my fanaticism to my fourteen year old daughter to no avail. The sky blue canvas is heavy and durable, finished with tight, straight stitching and no loose,threads.  The violet handles are also canvas and attached with reinforced stitching.The transfer features five favorite super heroes, surrounded by the shape of a heart, in bold, vibrant colors.  The Hulk, Spider-Man, Captain America, Thor and Wolverine are each presented in full action mode. Once again, SoundLogic has proven that it deserves its current membership in the pack of top dogs producing quality audio devices.  Everything I've ever purchased that was SoundLogic badged and branded has been of the highest caliber, and this little speaker is no exception.  If the budget-friendly price point has you questioning the quality or sound, think again. It's durable, aesthetically pleasing and sounds great, even wowing serious audiophiles.The design of this device is so simple.  It is mounted upon a large suction cup,which allows the device to adhere to any smooth surface--and it stays put! The speaker itself is atop the suction cup and below a rudimentary press-to-activate control panel.  The panel is covered with a waterproof silicone that is effective and responsive and boasts volume control, track management and phone answering capabilities.SoundLogic Bluetooth devices are a breeze to pair, and so it was with this speaker.  Immediately upon powering up, it was recognized by my iPhone 6s and paired with no necessary configuration,  it just couldn't be any easier.  The speaker is also rechargeable via the included charging cable, so no searching for batteries--EVER!I was surprised at the boss sound that wailed from this little unit.  The bass is rich and deep, whilst the high end revealed every note in the range without that tinny echo that is so prevalent amongst small Bluetooth speakers today.  The icing on the cake here is that I can even answer my phone from this speaker with just the press of a button, meaning I'll never miss a call whilst I'm in the shower ever again.Overall, a quality speaker manufactured by a top-notch company and brought to market by a reputable seller.  Highly recommended!  Note that I received a discount on this speaker in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

When I saw this tshirt, I knew it was a must have for my fourteen year old daughter. Tried this and the BARMIX. This one is PERFECT. The other one was horrible. Why? When you use it on cheese blocks like Gouda this one cut the perfect slices. The barmix one was way too thick and would bend. The kids could not use that one, so it goes into the forgotten tools drawer. The Linden is truly a great slicer. Even slices and not too thick and not too thin. It is flexible but does not bend and very very sharp so even at the end of a cheese block you can slice it to the last edible cheese layer. VERY GOOD!!!

This slicers is made of BENDABLE metal. So when you put pressure on ut to slice cheese it bends out of shape and stops slicing. Its NOT good for harder cheese blocks like gouda but fine for softer cheddars.Gave it one star because ANY slicer should be unbendable.

Background you can skipIncluding this fuel belt I have 3 in total. The reason I decided to add this one to my collection was that the previous hydration belts had smaller bottles (6 and 8oz) and I liked the fact that this one came with 2 extra bottles and a -somewhat gimmicky- arm band that flashes.In short, the price and all the extras swayed me, combined with all these 5 star reviews... My other belts cost me 40$ plus so I was happy to find a 5 star item at this price. I'm an intermediate runner,  in peak season I do about 35 miles a week, weigh 185 lbs, athletic build, 7.40 min/mile is my race speed for half marathon, 45 yrs old.Well, the saying is true: you get what you pay for. As an intermediate runner I was simply surprised to see this item fail on its first run.When putting it on I noticed that the front is simple nylon/polyester as you'd find in any cheap messenger bag. It has a dual center pouch that fits a iphone 6 but not anything much larger (like my Lumia 1520). Next to that are, on each side, the bottle pockets. The back of the bottle pockets and the pouch has NO grip beads or anything else that will stop it from sliding and bouncing. Also, given that this nylon is not stretchable, the entire stretch is coming from the back strap and that is big problem number one: the tension get unevenly distributed and I got "hot spots" on the upper pelvis bones after my first 8 mile run. My skin was ran and it was a serious distraction during my run.Also, given that the stretchy elastic is on the back and just that piece, combined with the inside of the front section having NOTHING to keep it in place, you'll have to pull it much tighter than any of my other running belts to stay in place.Now, further about that first disastrous run: I had filled the bottles with my favorite hydration fuel and turned my first corner picking up speed and I felt weight drop. Looked down and the right bottle was gone... despite it being held in place by a loop in the top. What gives... I figured I had done something wrong. Put it back in and secured it and started running again....flop... gone again... What gives... So now I am completely out of my rhythm and annoyed that my gear is actually stopping me from my run. The problem: when the bottles are filled the poorly designed pouches do not secure them and the can slide out of the bottom. If you look at the photos carefully you'll see they saved money by using elastic bands to create a T in which you slide the bottles. Well, the bottle moves around and with the weight of liquid it flops right out.Silly me I kept on running and every 1 to 2 minutes I had to look down to adjust the bottles so they would not fall out. The solution? I emptied the bottles by half and that seemed to do the trick, but defeats their purpose.Also, did I tell you that this thing moves? It does not stay still like my other neoprene belts. No rubber or anti-slip dots on the inside and no stretch in the front section makes for a poor poor belt. A few items in the pouch like a cellphone and some fuel packs and you will feel it bounce. Tightening it tigher will make it better but you'll get chafe.The bottles: the caps are decent but the BPA free bottles have bad thread. When squeezing drink in during a run, it sprayed out from unde3r the caps. So you have to do low pressure 'suck'. Not cool either.The plastic claps / buckle on the back sticks out: I felt it the whole run.There is no bib-tie on the front.So for me, its a complete failure and am stumped at the reviews. I wanted this to be a great find but its useless because of these shortcomings. Running gear that breaks your concentration and has this many downside is developed in some sewing shop without any care or understanding of what runners need.In summaryThe good:- cheap- extrasThe bad (everything else):- bounces- nylon non stretch front that does not stay in place- leaky bottles- bottle holders that do not secure the bottles when full- bad clasp on the back that dug into lower back- you need to over tighten it to keep it from too much bounce which created chafing on my pelvic bonesShell out more and look for something that has had more serious runners review and use. You really do get what you pay for. This thing will never be wonr by me again and I feel lots better about paying 45$ for a good belt now...
Jacked up reviews to make this look like some formidable competitor to real smartwatches. Can't believe Amazon isn't better at detecting review jacking by vendors and manufacturers.

Background you can skipWe started on a journey of replacing the Calphalon / Cephalon / Tefal / and Stainless potts and pans that we accumulated over the years. The reason is that the non-stick stuff, over time, comes off and who knows what it really does to your body long term.The cast iron pan we received of my mother, already 35 yrs old when we received it, was an eye opener as nothing stuck in it and it was glorious to cook in. So we decided to go pan by pan and build up a full "site" of cast iron pots and pans.We've tried various brands, initially, thinking "cast iron is cast iron". WRONG. The smoothness of the surface, quality of the seasoning, fit of the lid, even thickness etc are all critical in making something GREAT cookware versus a horrible failure. Lodge has been a winner in every category of cast iron cookware for us. At this point we have a complete cookware collection and 90% is Lodge and we love it.The trick with cast iron? Read up on directions on how to cook with and hot to properly clean. Too many people ruin the seasoning by not understanding how to care for it. If the seasoning ever gets sub-par or you make a mistake: re-seasoning is very easy with any oven and some cooking oil.Here's the good:- perfect thickness of iron- deep even and eternal seasoning: we have yet to re-season any of the pans after several years of intense use- smooth cast iron surface. The combination of seasoning and smooth surface make for virtually non-stick cooking, be it crepes or sunny side up eggs. Works great!- lid of this item fits precisely- Handle on pot as well as lid: its heavy- can withstand very very high heat, unlike non-stick. Great for over use- Keeps heat very long so dinner doesn't go cold in secondsOn the downside (we're nitpicking on the first):- heavy to handle, so not great for older people. You can get a serious wrist workout from handling these- Amazon seems to have a crazy price band for this. Bought mine in the low thirty bucks and today, when writing this review, its 88. Nutty. Watch and time your purchase as it goes up and down and thats just not cool.

Please look at all the JOHN named reviewers on and around the same date buying this womens product. Its the seller doing verified sales to pad his own ratings. Just so you are informed before you buy.

I know I will be unpopular but this review reflects my personal experience with this keyboard:When it was fully functional it was as great as people claim it to be. However, when I ran into trouble and reached out for support I was thrown for a loop:- A key came of under normal use and I didnt figure it out in time and could no longer find the key. I sent a note to Anker support with a picture of the item and the missing key and asked if they could help me get my hands on a replacement key.Instead of a yes or no I received an email where they wanted proof it was theirs by seeing the USB cable with the serial. I have no idea why the serial would have been on the usb cable but since that cable was a simple micro usb cable that I have millions of I have no idea where to find it.So I sent a picture of the item with NO ipad in it so you can see the Anker branding and so on. I gave them my order number from Amazon as proof but to no avail.Seems they are heading the same route as others: avoid support at all costs.So, the one star is because I paid good money for this, it didnt last in in normal use and I cannot get support despite the promise of warranty.Anker not so good.UPDATE: Anker reached out after the review, so thats a plus. They care about public image. Instead of sending the missing key they exchanged, that was great.Still only upgraded my listing to 3-stars (ITS OKAY) because:- the bluetooth connection often drops and I have to re-attach the ipad- the keys are not that nice to type on. Mine came off on the previous one and its not a smooth click (flimsy)- it only hold the ipad in one angle with the magent and you have to use the magnet for it to activate the bluetooth. Thats not so great with video conferecning or lap use as the angle is not good for meFrankly, I liked my old Logitech keyboard better on my previous ipad.

We put a lot of text on that tag and they got it all correct. Believe me, I've tried this elsewhere and it's not that easy to get right. Also, the tag (Bone) is a thick quality stainless steel with a high quality engraving. If our dog could opine he'd give you a thumbs (paw) up.Also love the fact that we could engrave both sides with this much text. We were able to put on the day's name, age, gender, his home address, our email and telephone number as well as chip ID and chip provider lookup URL.  SUPER GOOD DEAL!!And lastly: thanks for the fast shipping and processing.
Fit perfectly on my stock 2014 SGS. Could not tell difference from Harley stock part.I used this as I installed colored LED inserts on my signal lights and worked out great.
A very short review explaining the 3-star rating:Had to use serious (mallet) force to get the bushing installed. Wasn't precision engineered. Chrome had a missed spot on one side.

Background you can skipWe got this via Vine as a test case just when we had bought the Ninja MC701 (3in1) and the InstantPot IP-DUO60. It took us about a month of use to settle on the rating for this item and it is very much driven by the price. The other items are 100 to 150 bucks more expensive but can do a lot more than just slow cooking but given the price range and being good at its single purpose we think this is a great slow cooker.About this itemThe inner pot is deep. Much deeper than that of the Ninja. It is also made from a ceramic type material rather than the obligatory Teflon type material. This matters to us as the non-stick coatings inevitably fail over time.The other notable thing about this slow cooker is its singular purpose, which is reflected in the very very basic operation of the unit. It's so simple that I can do it without wifey having to provide direction.We've used this for great Turkey chili's, morning apple oatmeal recipes and so on and they all came out gorgeous. All in all, at this price point, we think this pot is a winner due to its simple and elegant execution and use of quality materials.Pros- Deep slow cooker that is great for shops and chili's as well as the regular slow cooker stuff- ceramic pan in the unit that can be taken out- simple LED display and control- glass lid- size, unit can feed a family of 6 easily in a single prep- inner pot does not stick- a great value when looking at price vs materials used. many of the more expensive units are non-stick (bad!)Cons- Timer could have been 24hr.- Perhaps they could have added a searing option, but at this price point? No, that's nit-picking.In summaryThis is a great unit that we love using over the somewhat complicated Ninja machine for slow cooking. Its deep pan and ceramic build combined with a glass lid make for simple operation. We love it and have used this over the 3x more expensive item.

A short review:Purchased these for motorcycling between say 65F and 40F (with an extra fleece or wool liner). I also purchased a pair via auction site for the same amount. What I didn't like about this glove the auction version had correct. Photos attached.Just a note up front: the seller advertises these as motorcycle gloves because of the "gauntlets", however, these are note really motorcycle gloves. They are not padded in the palms, the gauntlets are too wide so air flows in, the back of the hands are seamed and wind comes through. The fingers are not well cut: i feel the seams pressing against my finger tips and sides and I bought a size up (normally an L @ 5'10" and 180 lbs) because I wanted to add an inner liner.Having said all that, they are soft and for short rides they are meh-OK. If you want comfortable riding gloves then ou cannot get 100$ quality for 35$. that holds true in this item.Pros:Reasonable price for deerskinRelatively soft leatherCons:Not cut very well, one glove is larger than the otherOne velcro strap is shorter than the otherCan feel seams in fingersWind comes through seams on back of my handDeerskin is not that thick compared to competing productGauntlet too wideNo paddingIn comparison:In the photos you can see gloves without the seams on the back of the hand (on the right). Those are softer and have thicker deerskin. Also, the gauntlets are narrower letting in less wind. The stitchings can not be felt in those in the finger tips and they have no need for the velcros that these Amazon gloves have (not comfortable and w=one is way short).  I also find the lining more pleasant in the auction ones. Anyways, not trying to advertise other products but merely trying to state that these aren't that AMAZING deal that the reviews make it to be . I was disappointed and find the auction ones a better deal. Plenty of options in this price range that are better made.

Use: on 2014 FLHXS Street Glide Special.Pros:- medium to heavy duty quality compared to the more expensive competitor items- well stitched- sturdy zippers- fit perfectly on 2014 Touring with hard bagsCons:- none whatsoever for this price range. Great deal.

0:10 Mins Background you can skipWe received this through the Amazon Vine program and that was opportune as we normally just clear away small dishwasher loads by hand and let the items drip out in the deep sink. Problem is that the kids sometimes simply run water over them and the items do not properly dry and drip out.  Some of the racks out there are open metal or plastic covered frames. What we never liked about those is that they drip straight onto the counter underneath the rack and secondly that they, always, start rusting over time (unless you get chrome or plastic covered copper but that is becoming increasingly rare given cost).About this itemI have added a 1 minute video so you can see what the actual folding capability is and what the features are of this item. Thought that might help a bit.What seemed to make sense about this design:- all plastic (and heavy plastic so it can hold weight)- thick metal frame on outside to keep it in form and properly unfolded- foldable so it uses less storage space when not in use- relatively versatile (glass, pots , plate and utensil space)- reasonably large to be meaningfulSo now that we have actually gotten to use item here is what we found in reality:Pros- the plastic is indeed heavy / durable quality so this think can stack some weight and the outside metal bars keep it feeling solid and substantial- the hinges give a positive confirm/click when opening or closing the wings (see video) and feel sturdy as well- The silicone sleeves on the feet keep it in place on the counter , however the fold out EXTRA rear feet to light the rear up and drain to the water outlet are plastic and have a little less grip. Should not be a problem when stacked with plates etc as its own weight will hold things in place- the water outlet is both a cap as well as a water channel that you can hang over the sink to drain. Quite practical- utensil baskets stay in place even packed full- foldable dish section helps when using cereal bowls and needing space for more pots etc,Cons:- cost. I think 40 bucks is steep for a dish rack. quality is good but 40 dollars .... Thats also the reason I reduced a star as I would not have bought this at that price. 30 would have been my appetite given choices out there- folding the wings in does reduce the footprint that much (see video) so I think they could think that through better- the utensil baskets can be removed so you can add 4 glasses/mugs  but the "pins" over which to put the glasses are not long enough to hold anything deep- the dish rack section does not hold our cereal bowls: the slits are too narrow. will work for soup dishes.

Background you can skipMy setup at home is a mix of Mac and Windows machines for me and my kids. I am predominantly on Mac and my teenagers are Windows gamers and also use their machines for school projects. My router is an Apple Airport Extreme (tower), in case you're wondering if there are quirks with wifi setup on an apple hardware network: no problems.My main "bulk" printer is a Brother MFC7680, which is a black and white laser printer and fax/scanner/copier unit.This Canon Pixma MG6620 is only used for their school projects and for photo printing.About the setupIn the box you will fix a large fold out installation poster and as long as you follow the numbers you will have it setup in a breeze. I set mine up without connecting a cable and I did not use WPS either. Anyways: long story short: you remove some plastic tape on the machine, insert some supplied cartridges and go through the setup steps on the little display. Super easy and was foolproof for me.
