Once you print your test page and subsequently scan it you're all set. The whole setup took 15 minutes including unboxing. And the printer was also automatically visible on all my computers.What a great experience.What was not so great, and which case me to deduct a star were the following:1) The cloud printing/email printing setups were a pain. You have to print numbers, then go find a computer, go type in long (!) website addresses, setup accounts, wait for email links, reclick those and so one. What a pain. And I still don't know what it really does or how it works.2) The software I installed on my Windows machine felt like bloatware. It created all kinds of running control panel screens that appeared on startup and clogged my screen. What a pain.  The route of uninstall it went as these apps were not really great.OperationThe operation is great. The printer/scanner/copier showed on my Windows and Mac machines without a hits and I could print immediately.What is even better: I was able to scan directly from it into apps like Paperless. Very very easy.As with all ink jet printers: ink dries and can clog print nozzles. Make sure you use this regulary, by the way. If you do not it can become a real pain and unusable, is my experience but that is just inherent to ink jets.Let's face it: ink is not cheap so it is important that you find a good cheap source. I am happy to report that I have found those on Amazon. Just look for the cheap 5 star reviews. Those work great as I am on my first kit.Conclusion:Pros- Easy as pie to set up- great color print quality, especially on photo paper- efficient with ink compared to my old HP Photosmart- Scanner and copier function a plus and comes in handyCons- not-so-great software/bloatware- horrendous setup for web print services

Background you can skipI wear a size 11.5 medium width. This always holds true for Nike, Adidas, Converse as well as Timberlands. However, when I received these I had ignored other reviews stating these ran half a size large and ordered an 11.5 thinking that a Timberland is a Timberland. I was wrong. I ended up switching them for a size 11 in both the brown as well as the black. At 11 they fit perfectly.I travel a lot for work, spending about 5 days a week away from home and therefore shoes have to:- hold up well to abuse- be comfortable to walk on- breathe well as I have them on 12 hrs a day- be able to be worn casually under jeans as well as under a suit- be easily put on and off as I go through airports- last a long time- handle rain/snow (no slipping or soaking)- be water tight or resistantAbout the Earthkeepers Zip bootI first bought this boot in black a little over a year ago while I was still on a pair of Stacy Adams in the 250$ range. The SA's finally looked too abused from winter use. They made it to about 8 months with regular airport shines and a sole replacement.I gradually started wearing these Timberlands more and more and really like the dress boots look under a suit as, standing up you can't tell they are boots, and sitting down your socks do not look as forlorn. Not for everyone, dress boots, but something I brought with b me from growing up in Europe I guess where it is much more common to wear in an office environment.When I first ordered them I was not sure they would look good as dress boots as the black was definitely of a faded kind called burnished black. And the shoes were not categorized as dress boots but as regular/casual boots.Having used them under a suit: the burnished black is definitely not a shiny black but certainly fine for use under a suit. Same for the brown. However, when I had them shined the first time at an airport (great shoe shines in Tampa :D) they took on a very shiny, polished look. There obviously are more "dressy" boots out there but I can safely say that after a year plus (got these in April 2013) the black ones are still in very good shape. The leather is high quality and the soles have kept up. Mind you, it has been almost DAILY on these shoes since then.Also pleased to note that they fulfilled every aspect of my wish list in the previous section. Unheard of at this price point I think.I have since bought the brown ones. More like a tan color that can go great with a gray suit or under jeans, whichever pleases you.Oh yeah, I also wear them where I sometimes go motor biking.The foot bed is very comfortable and I never bought insoles for them. They also do not make my feet sweaty as the leather breathes well. They honestly never took on foot odor or even in summer weather made my feet hot.The nicest part? They have laces that make them look like regular shoes, but the zippers on the insides are a blessing when going through security checkpoints or kicking them on or off on planes.They have honestly gotten so soft from wear and care (I treat my shoes with Obenauf's leather oil to fully water and scuff proof them and Leather Nova to condition them) that these fit like a supple glove around my feet. I truly bought another pair in brown because of the comfort and experience with these boots. The price, at this quality, is a steal.I have tried many brands, from popular cheapskates (Madden, Aldo) to medium priced (Stacy Adams, Timberlands, Ted Baker, Varvatos) to 300 dollar + shoes (Cole Haan's. Mezlan) and think the Ted Baker's and Timberlands are the best price quality you can buy.Do make sure you watch the price for these as I have seen them as low as 90 and as high as 160. It fluctuates a lot. I do know that I will probably buy another black pair to save in a box for when these finally wear out, that is how pleased I am with them.Now if Timberland could only create everlasting soles these would probably hold up for a decade.VerdictPROS: (all the things I was looking for)- superb quality for the price (18 months of daily use and still great looking and comfortable)- hold up well to abuse- comfortable to walk on- breathe well as I have them on 12 hrs a day- able to be worn casually under jeans as well as under a suit- easily put on and off as I go through airports- last a long time- handle rain/snow (no slipping or soaking)- water tight / resistant- quality zippers- thick supple real leather- Earthkeepers recycling materialsCONS (really had to think hard, nitpick)- use leather conditioner or Obenauf's (Amazon has this) on your shoes to truly waterproof them as they will soak in after a while in slush- BEWARE TO BUY 1/2 SIZE DOWN- the soles are a little rugged looking for under a suit, but in fairness not visible and these are meant as casual.- front footbed less comfortable / soft. Not a problem but rear part much softer.... told you I had to really nitpick on the cons, so in summary:** well deserved 5 stars, the price/quality is amazing value compared to competition I have tried**

Some sizing comparisonSizing: I am 180lbs, 5'11", athletic build. Jeans size 29x32, and normally wear size M for tops like this. I purchased the black one in size M and it fits slightly large. Not a problem as I would normally wear a thermal layer or base layer underneath that is a little thicker. I could have ordered a small and it would have had a better fit but the reason I did not return it is that I like the fact that I can pull the bottom part over my fitletics hydration belt in the front. Doesn't look as dorky :D that way. Also, had I used a small one I believe the sleeves might have just been a little shorter and not as comfortable for using the thumbholes to keep my hands warm. In the end I recommend, if you're my size, to go with a small instead of medium.Final comparison: all of my Adidas (my preferred brand) running jackets fit me perfect in M. This Asics simply runs of a little larger template than Adidas.About this itemThe fabric is lightweight and breathes well. It is great for use in the gym with just as sleeveless t-underneath, from my experience, not just for running outdoors.For outdoors: you can wear this casually on a jeans and it would not look bad at all. But that is not why most would buy it: I use it as a running top as it was intended. Reason I did not review it immediately (had it for a month) is that I needed the weather to get colder to test the ideal range for this item, and that happened in the last week or so. Today I ran a 13.1 at sunny 37F weather, very very light wind.  I wore a long sleeve base layer shirt and just this hoody over it. I was NEVER cold and being a heavy sweater I never became clammy and cold. So I can safely say that it adequately wicks moisture from your base layer and does not soak. I also ran earlier in the week at about 49F and this hoody was still great but I had to zip it open a little. Would have been better with a thinner, sleeveless, base layer in 50 degree weather. Higher than that I would not likely wear this. I know this is somewhat personal preference but I'd say this works great between 30 and 50F.I'd also say that the fabric is lightweight and not a great wind blocker, so in colder windy weather I'd go with a thicker weaved item.It is somewhat tailored and the hoody gives it a good look. Also, as should be the case with these jackets: your behind is partially covered as the back is a little longer than the front. The front end just above the crotch area. The fit is tailored in the waist and narrow in the arms. Very common design for a running top. There is a slight pattern in the weave that seems "pressed" into the fabric. And then there are reflective accents on the pockets.Also, there are no seams in bad places (e.g. I have a top that has a seam right where the nips are, and after 13 miles that stuff gets raw) and the pockets are not bunching up and are the right size for some running gloves, a phones (pocket located by heart is best for that given bounce of heavy item) and maybe some keys and fuel.The neck zipper has a fold and stays in place. The ONLY thing that bothered me at times was the hood as it would sometimes hang over a shoulder a bit and snag my headphones. I stitched in some Velcro the inside of the hood and some on top of a running can and now, when I run I can keep the hood up to cover my ears and have a visor to boot. Without Velcro and a hat it will not stay up in a run.VerdictPROS:- for under 30 bucks this is great fabric and value- airy weave that keeps you covered and cozy between 30 and 50F- wicks very well, dries fast- cool hoodie design, most are without- reflective accents are stitched on- pressed pattern gives it an expensive feel- thumbholes- plenty of pockets- good athletic and flattering cutCONS- sizing slightly on the larger size- not wind or waterproof (layer if for wind protection)- hoodie flops around too much. Should have had Velcro to stay in placeIn summary: for the price you can't go wrong. If it had been more towards 40 to 45$ I'd given it 4 stars as there are more options in that range. But for this price I have yet to find something that keeps me dry and warm enough in that fall temp range.

Background you can skipI selected this item for review given that my sons' martial arts school had only a little plastic box with some band aids. What better to try than an industrial size cabinet chock full of first aid items. At time of this review the pac kit 6155 was retailing for around 130 bucks, so I factored that into the review. Obviously I received it through Vine, but am reviewing as if I had purchased it in the store.About this itemThe pictures look great. Looks like a well stocked sturdy and professional set but that is just the cover. When I received the item I was pleased with the case: it is quite heavy duty and has a handle as well as wall mount holes in it. But once you open it, it becomes rather disappointing:- even though there are tons of individually packed items it is all very very low quality of unknown brands. As an example: the gauze is so think that in certain places it looks like some random threads packed together.- the tape comes in such small quantity that they can barely claim it is included- band aids do not hold well at all.- the 493 items is accomplished by stacking it full of worthless items at high quantity. Had the set been cheaper I would have understood  but in this case you are looking at something like 20c to 30c an item, not counting the cabinet, and that is really not even close.- the hardware items (scissors etc.) are throw away. They do not cut andI have stocked our own bathroom medicine cabinet (IKEA 2 shelves) chock full of items I bought individually here and on the auction site and barely spent half of what this item costs. And all brand names in high quality and quantity.- I haven't validated the items against the claims but assume it is all there, even though the photos look like there is more and better organized stuff. Not like that.PROS:- Sturdy portable and wall mount cabinet- ANSI- Decent date range on items (2 to 3 years on some)- Lots of "stuff"CONS:- Cheap non-brand stuffing. You can buy better brand name stuff on Amazon individually for a fraction of this cost and in decent quantity- Poor hardware (scissors, tweezers etc.) is not even worth trying to use- Clearly quantity and "marketing" over quality and valueIn summaryYou would hardly want this case in your home or car, so it is aimed, with the ANSI statement, at a more serious environment. And for that it falls short. This is NOT something you'd want to bet someone's life on as it is not the quality material it deserves to be at 100 plus bucks.The ONLY redeeming factor was the case, but I am sure you can but a better fish box for a fraction as well. Assemble your own selection for MUCH less and with quality right here on Amazon. Nothing to like in this marketing spin.One more thing:I just went through Amazon and filled a cabinet with brand name versions (if available)  of the items in this case. In most cases this came in significantly higher quantities than what was in this case. For something in the range of 900 items instead of the roughly 450 in here you'd pay about 114 bucks, incl individual shipping. Anyways, do your math and you can make up your own mind. (50) Acetaminophen tablet  - $2.32(100) Alcohol antiseptic wipe  - $4.57Antiseptic spray, 5 oz.  - $3.33(25) Antiseptic towelette  - $4.57 (for 100)Burn spray, 4 oz.  - $4.79(100) Cotton tip applicators  - $1.87Elastic bandage, 4"  - $2.03(10) Exam gloves  - $6.95 (for 100)(50) Fabric strip, 1"3"  - $ 6.08 (for 100)(10) Fabric strip, extra-large  - $ 6.68 (for 20)(25) Fingertip bandage  - $ 4.80 (for 40)(25) First aid/burn cream packet  - $ 4.46Forceps  - $ 2.55(10) Gauze pad, 2"  - $ 5.32 (for 50)(10) Gauze pad, 3"  - $ 6.99 (for 50)(10) Gauze pad, 4"  - $ 5.20Instant cold pack, large  - $ 6.95 (for 2)Kit containing 4 oz. eye flush, eye cup - $ 5.52(25) Knuckle bandage  - $ 5.06 (for 40)Scissors  - $ 2.84Sterile gauze bandage, 2"  - $ 4.20 (for 50)Sterile gauze bandage, 4"  - $ 7.94 (for 50)Trauma dressing  - $ 4.62 (for 50)(2) Triangular bandage  - $ 4.59 (for 2)(2) Tri-cut adhesive tape, 2"  - $ 6.95 (for 5 yds)(25) Triple antibiotic ointment packet - $ 2.69 (for 144)

Background you can skipMY MEASUREMENTS: 185 lbs, 6' , athletic build. Jeans size worn 30 x 32I own a huge drawer full of running shorts because I run a lot and have been less than satisfied with some of the brands used.I have, being true runner shorts with inner briefs or compression shorts:- Gore Running xrunners with internal compression shorts- Nike 2 in 1- Mizuno 2 in 1- Asics running shorts with briefs- These Asics 2 in 1I ended up buying 4 pairs of these as they had the least issues from the various shorts.About these shortsThey have pockets and drawstring and the liner is a short compression short without seams and with gripping material on the thigh part so they do not roll up.The inner compression short is shorter than the outer part but that poses no issues with my typical 8 to 10 mile runsThe outer short is typical running short material: thin and airy. The inner compression short is not the shiny polyester material but feel more like a "harder" blend of coolmax.On the red shorts the inner short is grey, in case that matters to you.Whats works:- inner compression short wicks moisture VERY well- inner short doen not ride up and has no seams- outer short is just long enough to look stylish and hides the inner compression short completely which I like- has pockets, in case you ever want to wear these casually but the pocket material and seams do not interfere or become noticeable while running- price / quality: this is as good as it getsAny complaints?- the compression short could have been tighter but is good enough. You can go a size smaller but would not risk that given overall fit.- the outer short does not wick as well as some other shorts I have- the waist could have been made as a flat seamless waist (but not really a problem)Not entirely fair to duck a point for that given the excellent price point, but also not perfect.

Although the build of this item seems very sturdy and on par with the Anker items (perhaps all using the same source manufacturer?) I am not too pleased with the actual quality of this item:- This is the second USB 10-port hub I bought of this brand. The first one died a sudden death after a few months of use. Simply wouldn't power up anymore.- This second one has 4 of the 10-ports not powering up or even registering plugged in devices out of the box.So I no longer consider it luck of the draw: 2 out of 2 within months is bad odds.A few other things to note:- the USB 3.0 cord is somewhat short, s if you have your PC under the desk and want to route a cord up it might be tight.= the USB ports themselves have varying fits. In some the cables slide in in others you have to use some force.I would have stuck with 4 stars but simply cannot accept the quality for this price.

I wanted faded, lived in looking t-shirt that would be slim fitting without body hugging or clinging.I ordered the M, which is my nomad size at an athletic build: 185lbs, 5'11". The t-shirt was clinging too tight out of the plastic but when I stretched it a but by pulling it gave and fitted perfectly: follows the contours but does not cling to the body.The sleeves are relatively short but not as short as they look in the picture.The fabric is artificially faded at the seams and does look like an older item. The body and sleeves do not have white sticking, but rather a faded seam (photo appears as contrast stitching.The fabric is cotton, 100% but feels soft.Overall, at slightly over 10 bucks, I am happy with this shirt:- it fits well on the body: slim fitting- long enough to look nice on jeans- looks faded a bit- no loose threads and seams- a both of stretch- true to size- looks pricier than it isthe - 1 star?- made in China, so it should have been cheaper. USA USA USA!

Will keep it short as I am irate at this point and don't want to spoil your mood:When this coffee maker works its fine. However, we seriously doubt the quality controls at Hamilton Beach and more so, we detest their lack of customer centric support.The first one died within 6 months. First the timer stopped working. Then the power button stopped working.We didn't check the warranty and figured it was just bad luck and we went out and bought another via Amazon.3 months later this one died. It simply wouldn't switch on anymore.This time we checked the warranty and figured we could call them to get a new one.Here is the trick with that: they make it really hard to get a new one. Kinda like insurance companies putting in fine print to ensure there is no payout. That, by itself, should be a deterrent for buying.They make you try and read the melted/ stamped bottom and that is sheer impossible. I could not read it to the rep and even sent a 13mp photo to them to read for themselves which they couldn't. When I finally offered to hold a current news paper next to it with a sign reading" it's really me" the rep gave in and asked me to take photo's of the plug cut from the cord and email it to them.HOWEVER, BEFORE THEY DID THAT THEY ASKED ME TO PAY 11$. That is where they go dirty: regardless of whether they send the item they keep the 11$. So if they then come back and say your photos are rejected, you are still SOL and need to file a creditcard claim which they will win due to the fine print stating you are paying them 11$ for the sheer awesomeness of getting their support on the phone.Anyhow, fast forward 2 weeks: no response anymore to any of the emails with the case number and the photos. They simply went on mute. Absolutely ridiculous, Hamilton Beeatch.Ipso FactoSo here is what I recommend: it's a good coffee maker when it works but myluck was suspiciously short lived x 2. And when you need their client service, despite warranty, they will make it heart attack level tough to get that replacement. So DO NOT buy this online, but rather in a store that offers the 10 or 15$ 2 year no questions replacement. You will get the value out of that as this thing is possibly going to fail and you can avoid dealing with HB-BS.Good luck.We moved on to a Presto 02811 and due to its simplicity we love that, HB lost a customer and we don't care. Hope we warned you sufficiently as companies that treat customers like suspects in a line up and then hit the ignore button deserve no ones' business.PS: yeah, I do dislike them this much, given their utter lack of customer care let alone service. It should be called the HB Customers we-don't-care plan.

Background you can skipSomehow I forgot how my mom used to cook and what she used to cook with and got caught up in the hype of teflon and stone coated flimsy ware pots and pans. None of those coatings lasted or came with so many instructions hidden in the manuals (how many people realize that non-stick pans should not used above low-medium heat, or not to use Pam on them?) that we ended up retiring those (300$ and up) sets within 2 years after buying.We them progressed to stainless steel high end French cookware, Problem was that everything stuck to that and they became unsightly quickly. So that 550$ set went the way of the salvation army.Then my mom gave us this magical big black 40 year old cast iron pot that she had used to cook for the family. And to our surprise, when simmering meat or evening abusing it to make pan cakes: nothing stuck to it. This became our defacto ACME pot for everything.Fast forward: since we wanted a complete kitchen and love cooking, we started adding to the cast iron cook ware. Most of the items we bought on Amazon from the American made Lodge brand and we LOVE LOVE LOVE those. Whether its the pizza plate, the wok or skillets or the grill or larger cook pots.HOWEVER, we could not find a Lodge made soup pot that was narrow and deep like this one and based  on the photo we decided to order. Based on some unused credits we had on another website we strayed and bought it there. Price on Amazon is the best out there at time of writing this but with my credit it made sense to buy there.About the itemI know that people think that all cast iron is alike and I don't believe that. The finish of the pot is notably rougher on the surface than anything Lodge that we own. Lodge items tend to feel very smooth, with is a sign of better/purer raw material and manufacturing.Also noted that the lid and the pot don't seem to fully close. This is a problem when getting things to a boil: a properly closing lid will get things to a boil much faster.Regarding the seasoning: it definitely is not the same quality seasoning of the Lodge item and I think there is a problem with the metal in general bleeding into food. Others have reported on this an we have found it to be true. We re-seasoned the pot in the oven on top heat which surely removes any residue that can "melt" and still that patina didn't seem right.More so, when putting water in or even chicken stock it continues to discolor the water.My personal assessment is that the iron is less pure and more porous than that of the Lodge items. The Lodge ones are smooth and deep black or very very dark grey turning into black with continuous use. This Bayou product also still makes even onions or roux stick at the bottom of the pot. I think you get the overall picture: this pot is probably OK for the occasional outdoor fire pit party but I certainly resist using it in the kitchen given the low quality and questionable discoloring that we experience.In summaryGOOD:- Cheap, cheap cheap for a baseline pot (but what is cheap if you cannot use it...) compared to brands like Lodge- No one else seems to have a soup pot shapes cast iron potBAD:- Rough finish- Poorly fitting lid- Poor seasoning- continues to discolor food despite re-seasoning- seems lighter than equivalent Lodge type items- Made in China, sorry, I prefer job creation in the US and I prefer quality controls.In the end, we stopped using this pot and are waiting for Lodge to hear our cry for a soup pot made in America.

Background you can skipWe started using Oxiclean when it first took the market by storm (remember those infomercials?) and wow, did that stuff work. Over the years it seems that the makers of Oxiclean have chosen to "water down" their formula and make it less pure. Somewhere along the way, they lost us as a client as we went on to other oxygen cleaners that still seemed to have that Ooomph in their products.This was about 5 or 6 years ago and recently we received a small bucket via Amazon to test and review.I had a batch of white T-Shirts that are made of modal and that I love wearing as under shirts and I had yet to bleach them back to pure white as they are yellowish gray tinged because of well-water and use. So I thought this not-so-harsh product could be put to the test.About our experienceIt was a bit of an anti climax: the first time I washed the batch of shorts with it they came out the exact same. Not a shade brighter.However, i had just used the recommended dose and added it to the drum of our front load HE GE washer.So we decided to try again, but this time using the "revive whites" instructions and we dissolved the powder and pre-soaked the t-shirts. We then washed with another load of the powder. I mean, serious powder usage at this point... and this stuff is not cheap.When the T-shirts were dry  they were still the off color yellowish gray. Could not see a difference on the modal shirts at all (and they used to be truly white). When I wore the shirts they felt itchy to me and I think my skin simply does not react well to OC, or its perfume.Frankly, the smell they added is less than wow and hard to ignore but perhaps because we used so much of it.Personally, I would think they should shun scenting it and focus on its basic oxygen cleaning power instead.At this point I was a bit frustrated and decided to re-wash with some bleach and that did the trick: the shirts brightened. I did make sure to rinse them extra long to get the chemicals out. Now I do not want to wash with tough chemicals but Oxiclean is certainly not the same quality that it was when they first launched so they will have to figure out to get back to that old recipe.I believe it cleans like a laundry detergent but it down not have that wow factor anymore.About the ingredients: even though they write that there is no harsh chlorine in it, they have one side completely filled with warnings about harsh chemicals that can burn skin and eyes. I did have slightly irritated skin from it but that is partly because it wasn't perhaps properly rinsed out or maybe the scenting they used.Verdict:For the price I could not warrant buying it as it didm;t seem to work. It seemed overly scented and lightly irritated my skin. I would have loved a non-harsh whitening detergent other than bleach but this one is far less potent and doesn't seem to be that harmless either.Not for me.

2:41 MinsAbout ZeroLemonI first used the Zerolemon brand when I needed extra batteries for my old Optimus LG Pro. They offered 2 batteries with a charger and a great warranty. The quality was great and I made a mental note of the company if I ever needed batteries again.Since then I upgraded (if you can call it that) to the Nexus 5. So when I noticed that I could not simply swap out batteries given the fixed cover I was aiming for a battery case to accompany me on business trips. I shied away from all the other brands because, frankly, they looked like they were over priced and not that well rated.When I saw ZeroLemon was planning to come out with this case on March 10th I decided to wait for it and I am glad I did.About this case, or should I say casesI didn't realize that this case was as big as it was. I should have figured it out knowing that it was a 3500mah battery that somehow fitted around the small footprint of the Nexus 5. Don't get me wrong: its not a problem. Not even for my 5'5" wife: you can hold the phone just fine but it is certainly a little deeper and wider than you might expect.I decided to do a video where I unpack and pack the phone into the case. It might look difficult but it really isn't once you figure out you are looking a 3 cases:-There is an inner case that consists of a screen protector (thanks!!!) that clicks onto a back. That back has the opening for the battery and the bridge between the battery and the Nexus 5.-Then there is a rubber housing around that: if you drop your phone it won't mind anymore.-And finally, there is a belt clip (pretty big!!!!) that you can click the whole thing into. When it arrives its all clicked together and looks big, but don't worry.Now that I have the phone in it I am fine with it. It still fits in my jacket or inner pocket of my suit and frankly, I find it easier to hold the Nexus with this on.Operation:All the ports and buttons are accessible behind covers. The buttons work better with the cover than without for the nexus as they are more distinctly pronounced.The ONLY problem I noticed is obviously when  you use Qi charging: it does not work for that. Perhaps a next generation of this cover. But I decided it was more important to be able to travel with my phone without worry of power shortages versus NOT having to stick a cable in (that extra second of work is not that big of a deal in hindsight).The protector, even though my phone was already covered with one, works great. No swiping or touch issues.The camera, given the thickness of the case, sits quite deep, but I have not had any issues with photos and flashing: it does not seems to affect it or cast any type of shadow.On the back there is an ON/OFF button where you can decide to charge, which works fine. Ot will show LED's when charging or discharging. Problem I had is that only 3 of the 4 leds worked. It did not hinder operation so I decided not to return. Do note that if I wanted to, ZL would have replaced it. Not sure who would have had to pay for shipping given that it had a manufacturing defect rather than a breakdown at my home. I emailed them on topic just to see what they would say. I will put that in the comments later. IF they think I should pay for return shipping then you will see me deduct a start from this review.Summary:Pros- Protects your phone and then some- Battery lasts through massive video watching and surfing. I can now charge once every 2 days or so.- Provides great grip- Buttons work well- Comes with a built in screen protector- even if you skinned (my Nexus had leatherskin on AND a screen protector) it still fits well.- Has a belt clip with itCons- Might be bigger than the photos suggest- The charging port was a bit tight- Doesn't work with Qi chargersHope the video gives you a view of how it clicks together.UPDATE:Regarding the 3 blinking LED's instead of 4: that turns out to be just an oddity of how the charging works. once the battery fills up more the 4th light goes on. So even if you think, like i did, that the 4th led didn't work, it's actually working when fully charged. All is good.

2:28 MinsBackground you can skipI opted for a video review to make you hear the "power" difference with like-kind corded clippers that I normally use compared to the Norelco ones.My experience with Philips/Norelco personal grooming / hygiene has been polarized: the Philips Sonicare stuff has been great but the co-branded Norelco battery powered items never lasted that long.This particular item is just OK compared to the much cheaper Wahl:http://www.amazon.com/Wahl-79300-400-Color-Complete-Haircutting/dp/B000JNQSIQ/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1395347844&sr=8-2&keywords=wahl+clippersThe reason I am comparing the 2 is that A: the cheap Wahls have served me for over 2 years now and  B: cordless isn't that important a feature on clippers UNLESS they have the power to keep up with corded items.You do not necessarily trim your hair every day , frankly I don't even trim weekly (incl. my beard) and batteries like this tend to lose their charge over time. So when you are ready to use them I found myself plugging in the item into the wall.About this itemMy main gripes that are keeping it from my LOVE IT 5 starts:- The blades are not adjustable, only the plastic head is: for short beard trimming this is useless- When I did force it through a beard trim: the blades snagged my hair a few times. Painful and my adjustable Wahl (see video) has none of that- the clippers work somewhat OK with the trim head on, but for precision trims (around the ears) the naked blades pouch away my thin hair and it really doesn't work well. Its almost as if the blade distance is too narrow or so. Others have said the same thing.- It lacks power which you can feel when trimming, compared to a true electric clipper. No comparison, even when plugged in.- It's too expensive for the plastic you get. It's not even thicker plastic.- If your hands are wet, or the bathroom is misty then the buttons are slippery. Its hard to switch on. Maybe my item is just defective but the button requires some force as does the trim head dial.- The trim head is too big and bulky. Makes it harder to precision trim.What I liked:- It is lightweight- If you're into cordless: it is but remember, it doesn't hold charge that well over time.PS: sorry for the accent in my video. I try!

Background you can skipI have mainly used the Garmin )Forerunner) series of sports GPS watches in the past and decided it was ready to upgrade given the size of the Garmins.Naturally I was overwhelmed with the sheer offering of alternatives in the market and the similarities between specs and the large divergence in pricing.Having great success with the TomTom brand in general for other equipment and knowing that they powered the Nike offering I decided to hone in on the Multi-sport and Runner watches they offered:- they looked smaller than most- had convertible bands for men and women (wife uses it too)- advertised features that others didn't have like the "race yourself" feature where you run against your own best time and position on a previously run track- it was affordable- I loved the upgradeability they claimed (more on that later)- I loved the implementation of the joystickWhat made me worried were the 1m2 and 3 star reviews. I studied those closely and do want to note the following pattern: most of those reviews are based on VERY early adopters. Back in Mid 2013. The software was still on its beta and many functions, though advertised, weren't there. I myself purchased the first GPS Runner watch in August of so and croaked on the fact that the "race yourself" function was not ready yet even though they advertised it.I blame these depressed reviews on the go-to-market strategy of TomTom with this device. They wanted it out there for the summer 2013 season but weren't fully baked yet with software. This is what annoyed the early adopters and caused the review impact.But what is also notable of those reviews: TomTom replied to most if not all. Not a canned response, but with actual timelines, apologies and solutions. THAT is worthy of TomTom and made me stick it through. Now, about 6 or 7 months later: I am a convert. Best GPS watch I can imagine. It does everything and then some and they keep expanding the capabilities and software.About my experienceThe biggest thing to note is that TomTom cares about what they build: the watch has been constantly upgraded since I have purchased it (I was an early adopter when it just hit the market). I can not only race myself, race against pre-set goals, I can also start racing others via software linkage. They recently (v 1.6) introduced DIRECT syncing with IOS devices and the Android roll out is coming soon: you can disconnect the USB cables and sync over bluetooth 4.0.What's so cool about this is that this device is almost a year in since its 2013 launch and they are adding features that others would create new models and price-hikes for. This si what I think is the greatest testament to TomTom's mind set. You can obviously tell I have gotten somewhat attached to them but it is because they have treated us right from a consumer perspective.A great example of this is with earlier firmware: it was easy to accidentally stop a run because the joystick was hit inadvertently. They listened and implemented a pause into the button that required a continuous press of a second or 2 before it would record as a stop. That's a great response to a fair complaint.The watch, hence the Multi-sport title, is basically Swim, Run and Bike ready. You can buy the heart rate strap, cadence sensor and be set for Tri-workouts. Note that they need to add a few training lap calks and analytics and this thing is a magnificent deal.It also accurately measures my treadmill runs based on the built in 'accelerometer/step counter" or like kind ability. And it is actually within 2%  accurate with a 5 mile run on my treadmill and it can be fine tuned after every race. Why is this important: harsh winter in Chicago anyone? I could not run outside for 4 months almost. This way I have accurately kept tabs on my total distance and improvements.The software is also constantly expanding and they are doing a lot to integrate with MVP (MapMyFitness) and like kind services and the item also comes with many built in export formats of your data.  I like the combo of the dashboard of TomTom and the MapMyFitness aka MapMyRun as it shows your progress analytics and can even show you a flyover via a google maps plugin of a scenic route you ran (or any run outside). I just did a run through the "Strabrechtse Heide" in the Netherlands while on a trip which was absolutely stunning and I could see a Google maps flyover with milestones etc in picture and map view. Very cool.It connects to satellites REALLY FAST. About this Holland run: it took a few minutes (about 2) to find its location given that I had moved continents but it did so. The next day it took less than 10 secs to be ready to run. Nothing compares in this price range (up to 225$ range I looked at). This speed is often cited by others as key. Nothing worse to tell your running busses to wait for the watch.The interface: its great to have the joystick as my hands get sweaty and I want to operate the watch (different views during run, watch for stats etc) while moving. The joystick as the main control is great and possibly kept the watch small. Great implementation of an idea that was obviously thought through by runners at TomTom I would think.Also, no one really talks about this, but the tactile (bussing) feedback when using the menus is very clever. When I hit a milestone, fall behind in a race, accidentally trip a button I can feel it on my wrist.The screen is lit when needed (when you tough or tap it) and legible in full sun (Kindle like paper lcd) and there are many stats and views you can use during runs. Too many to name.VerdictPros:- TomTom listens and does not abandon hardware. They have been unbelievable in upgrading and improving and listening to customers. Amazing, really- Price for what you get is a bargain compared to others- Great contra mechanism with joystick- You can change straps- Syncs with phone / iPad (android in works, IOS is ups an running)- You can race against targets that are pre-set but also against yourself- tactile feedback- works in treadmill- fast satellite tracking- great integrated software- small size. I sometimes forget its on after a run.Cons:- you cannot setup multiple profiles in a watch. I.e. you cannot have one watch that is used by more than 1 person as only 1 profile can be setup. This is a software/firmware issue and could be in a future upgradeI highly recommend this watch. It beats every Garmin I ever owned and certainly the Nikes and other entry levels. Read up on the specs and ability.

I have previously bought the 1st generation of the Jot Touch (the pressure sensitive high end sibling of this non-pressure sensitive device) and liked it... to a certain extent. I write fast and furious, draw a lot in my line of business and needed something that could replace the scores of note pads that I devour so I initially set out to buy the Jot Touch last year.I never really liked it as much as the online pro reviewers gave it credit for. The software was sometimes fickle in recognizing the pressure accurately (big fat globs of virtual ink on the screen..)  and finally it died altogether just barely out of warranty.The pen was somewhat bulky and unwieldy and there was just a that lack of accuracy that you get with a real pen. And then there was that 0.2 seconds of lag between the writing and the result on screen. I wasn't in love with it and peeved that an item that costly died so fast that I shied away from buying a new one.Then I moved on to the Galaxy Note 10.1 with some hotel points as I had heard great things about the pen use. Lo and behold: the s-pen by Samsung got it right. Truly a writing experience like on paper and pressure sensitive while still keeping the stylus small. I never looked back.However, Vine came by and showed this item as available for testing and I decided to try it out with my new iPad Air (5th gen).About the Jot Script for EvernoteSetup was easy enough and I opted for Penultimate as the app of choice.The very first thing I noted was that, when writing normally (I use a bit of pressure when I write, can't help it) the pen seems to leave marks on my iPad screen that I cannot fully get rid of when wiping down the screen. It looks like it actually affects the glass. Given that it is a narrow metal nib and with little "give" it seems unwise to run this without a screen protector (I don't use one).Secondly, possibly worse, is that when you write at normal speed the pen really has the same lag the old Touch had. Even the new fast iPad Air has that issue which leads me to believe its somewhere in the software or interface.Thirdly, the nib is not accurate. I cannot read my handwriting half the time due to this pen. It flattens or creates straight lines where I used curves and it makes for bad handwriting unless you write in block or are neat. I am a fast fast fast cursive writer and it does not work well.Finally, this is truly annoying: half the time there is no palm lock. not sure why but even when using Evernote's Penultimate I would all of a sudden wipe something away or get an accidental pop up etc. Just drove me mad.I wanted to try the pen for a day during meetings where I would have normally used my Galaxy Note with s-pen but after about 2 hrs of getting frustrated because  of what I outlined before I simply gave up and went with the other solution.Perhaps If I never had tried the s-pen I would be a bigger fan of this but it really doesn't feel like writing on paper where the s-pen does.In summaryThe iPad and Jot Script do not make for a good combo that truly feels like a realistic alternative to writing on paper. The biggest downsides are:- poor accuracy (my writing doesn't look like my writing)- poor software implementation (palm smudges anyone)- lag when writing- left marks on my iPadPositive:- the pen itself is well built, it's heavy, with a little led for operation and holds well in the hand.For the price the performance is VERY disappointing. Trust the (declining) Amazon rating on this one and don't hate the lower reviews on this one as we are really trying to like the item.As stated, once you try the s-pen you can compare this to something else and the s-pen is so far ahead of this there is no comparison. Samsung all the way for pen-based note taking on a tablet.

Background you can skipWe have recently (in Sep 2013) completed 3 bathroom remodels: 1 large master bathroom for which we ordered a 60" glass Dreamline door that had a 1" out of plumb adjustment (NOT this review) and 2 small bathroom that had tub/shower units in them.At first we wanted to remove the relatively new tub/shower units but decided that having the small tubs in there was actually convenient. We did want to upgrade the look of those units by adding a glass door to them rather than the obligatory curtain.After some searching we decided that this Dreamline door looked right and certainly was the most affordable out there. We went with the chrome unit.  The reason we decided for this one is that it is a single door, so no complicated alignment for multiple glass panels.Given that ht stub/shower units have a perfectly plumb opening this would be a good fit.Again, there really is no out of plumb adjustment with this door so it really needs to be on perfectly square openings.The trouble was, of course, that the tub unit was made of fiberglass/plastic of some sorts and therefore would never be strong enough to carry this door on 2 hinges without cracking.Note that the door is relatively light but still, you don't want to take the risk.  We therefore ordered a flat aluminum plate the ran about 60" and affixed it to the vertical wall, between the tub/shower wall and the hinges.We then drilled though the aluminum and used hollow-wall anchors the screw in the hinges. The hollow wall anchors were rated for 139 lbs an anchor and they affixed without a problem. The door is steady as a rock and feels like a part of the tub/shower unit itself.About the Dreamline doorInstallation: for anyone that has ever (attempted) installed a full glass shower door (door and glass panel separate) , you know that that can be quite complicated and requires some decent level of skill to make sure the panels are aligned over a wider space and securely held in place and properly sealed act.None of that with this door, from my experience. AS LONG AS you have a pretty precise 90 degree angle. It can withstand maybe 1/2" of misalignment but really there are no other adjustments. For most installations this should be somewhat OK.Install was really simple: affix the hinges to the glass. Lay down a horizontal 5/8" piece of wood so you get a proper gap under the door when installing, which is later sealed with the included "weather" strips. Note that you do need to make sure you have a strip or a few shorter 5/8" pieces you can lay down. They do not supply them. Also do not guess, make sure you have something of the right thickness from the wood section as this need to be wide enough for the strips to properly seal.The you hold the door against the wall where it will be affixed with the hinges. Make sure the door is held level vertically as well otherwise it will open by itself towards the angle it leans towards. Again, make sure someone is there to help you level it.Then you mark the drill holes through the hinges and put the door aside and drill. Normally, if you properly install, you drill into a stud or solid wall behind tile. See comments in sidebar below.Sidebar: the gentleman that left a review that stated that everyone that rated this item well must be a conspiring criminal with Dreamline, I really don't know where he is coming from. The door is 1/4" glass and not that heavy and these hinges are SERIOUS solid metal construction. Smaller versions of the huge hinges that hold the 3/8" glass walls and certainly way stronger than anything you could throw at it.I get the sense the problem there is the installer. Especially the comment about not holding the door up. The hinges are supposed to be drilled into the stud behind the tile. The shower opening where a door like this is normally installed will have a stud behind it if properly built. That's what you bolt the hinges into.In case you do not have that and have tile over something like drywall: I do not recommend it but you can use VERY STRONG hollow wall anchors like I did and they can hold a ton more than this door. This door was easily carried by a 5'10 180lbs guy that has a desk job. Again, the door is not heavy.End of sidebar.Once the drill holes are there you simply bolt on the door and then remove that 5/8" strip you had under the door. Add the door bar and some strips you slide on et voila. Door is done.About the use over timeWe have had no issues with mold as that one particular reviewer noted he had in the water strips. To me that might have to do with insufficient ventilation in the bathroom to begin with. The strips do not hold water if slid on fully,The door / shower area sees much use from guests and the kids and we have had 0 problems. The door looks great after 5 months or so of sustained use and there are no signs of rust or mold or "out of plumb".The one thing to note is that you obviously need to figure out what type of shower head to use as the door is only 34" wide. I hard  and wide spraying shower head might spray beyond the door boundaries and get your floor wet. We use a rainfall shower head and have had no issues with overspray or splattering on the floor.In conclusionPros- Simple installation- Solid construction of parts- For chrome item: heavy brass parts that are chromed over. This will not rust.- Only very few parts to install- Cheapest of single glass door options we could find that is made for use with a tub- lightweight considering quality, so should be great for many if not most walls , even hollow.- Looks expensive give than it lacks rails like some of the cheaper units you find in home improvement storesCons- bring your own 5/8" strip to install. Can be annoying if eager to install- requires perfectly plumb openingGreat item considering the cost and quality and simplicity of install!

Background you can skipWe are heavy heavy coffee drinkers. It is frankly the ONLY thing I drink at this point. About 4 full pots a day gradually from early Am till about 6 or 7 in the evening. I guess I am a caffeine junkie and am used to that constant fidgety pressure on my body the caffeine create from the inside out. It makes me think fast and helps with focus but it does also make me fidgety and often keeps me from a good nights sleep. The problem with drinking coffee in the early evening is that it takes apparently about 4 hrs for the caffeine to get fully into your system so If you drink it at 6PM you feel the effects at full force at 9 to 10 in the evening which is right about when I go to bed.So when I saw this product and had the opportunity to get a bottle for testing I jumped on it.About the ingredient(s) of Rutacleanse:The active component in Ratuacleanse is an alkaloid called rutaecarpine.  From prublished 2011 studies on rats, apparently, 80 milligrams per kilogram of body mass in the lab rats (given each day for three days before administering with caffeine) is enough to raise two liver enzymes sufficiently to promote caffeine metabolism and subsequent excretion of the metabolite (according to an independent blogging website)However, the product contains just 100 milligrams of rutaecarpine per tablet and there are 30 in a bottle. An average adult male human weighing 80 kg (175 lbs)  and hoping to see an effect would based have to ingest 6400 milligrams of the active ingredient for three days to experience the same relative activity as was observed in the rats. That’s a couple of bottles of the stuff every day for three days before you could have a coffee.So the product works but mass quantities should be used to get some physiological effect on the liver... Lets try fact versus logic.About using RutacleanseI'm not going to re-hash the claims of the manufacturer, you can read those. Merely the perspective of a caffeine junkie.The first thing to note is that you only take 1 capsule at a time and do so once a day. It doesn't say when but states that it takes 2 to 4 hrs to reach its full effect. So for me the most logical thing to do is to take one 3 hrs before bed to get me down from that humming caffeine high.Again, it takes few hrs to get to work according to the manual, just like coffee so it's not an instant de-caffeinator that works like a switch.VerdictI did not experience a noticeable difference from using the product. If I stop drinking caffeine / coffee at 5 I can fall asleep at 9 or 10 with or without Rutacleanse. It did not make me less jittery, any less than coffee working through its effects when I stopped drinking it in time and the fact that I would have to take it 4 hrs before bed to have some effect made it ... well, kinda useless. Especially at the price its advertised for.I also think there is merit to reading the rutaecarpine research online. The quantities needed would be very large but then again, homeopathic solutions do seem to work and talk about low doses of active ingredients in there so I am not going to claim science is the only answer here.I simply state that I didn't feel a difference between stopping coffee 4 to 5 hrs before bed and falling a sleep vs stopping coffee 4 to 5 hrs before bed + taking the pill and falling a sleep. It was all the same and didnt make me less jittery or give me a better deeper sleep.Rebranded versions of this go as Rutasomn I believe, marketed as a sleep aid but with the exact same single ingredient. Again, everyone's body is different and not everyone drinks as much coffee as us German and Dutch people but I got nothing out of it so I would never spend money taking the pill...

Basckground you can skipWe wanted to replace our old and worn 50 cfm Broan 4 sones fan/light unit. This unit was installed in a slanted ceiling with NO attic access.Naturally we wanted to go fancy and install a fan/light/heater unit but when the unit arrived the electrician told us we needed to rewire to accomodate all the switches and connections and on top we'd need to upgrade the circuit from the existing 10amp to 20 amps.He then charged us a 75$ show fee and left even though he had recommended the fan.Anyways, we ton ed down our expectations and decided we wanted to just replace with something quieter, less obtrusive, more modern, more energy efficient that could also be installed easily without attic access.About this unitWell, this is probably your best bet when looking for as no-hassle retro fit with no attic access. The opening required was a quarter inch more than that of the existing small Broan unit and it came with one wide metal clamp that could easily be installed from below. with 4 screws into a ceiling beam or cross stud. The housing, once the duct is connected and the wires are connected then simply slides in with a satisfying click.I then was able to connect the VERY simple electric wires for the fan and light unit.The light and fan components then plug in.The other great thing about this retrofit is that it is very forgiving. The unit did not sit flush with the ceiling because my cross beam was way out of plumb but then i added the cap and screwed it on it pulled it fit against the ceiling.The whole ordeal took me, a novice with little electric experience other than understanding the basics, about 30 minutes.Also, this unit is very basic/modern. The light cap is almost as white as the housing trim and therefore the whole unit is not very visible until you switch it on and the bright light shines. Due to the the light cover not being transparent it has a clean look even when switched on since the bulb remains hidden.Also, it is as quiet as they promised on the box.We are very pleased with this unit as our bathroom no longer fogs up when taking that hot morning shower. Not even our glass shower doors fog up.PROS- Extremely simple retro-fit installation, even when no attic access.- Very forgiving design when it comes to out of plumb situations, slanted ceilings etc- Requires 10 amps dedicated but this is an energy star unit that requires minimal power and I did not use a dedicated circuit and have no issues.- simple wiring needs. Most homes will be able to install this unit whereas some of the newer units require expensive rewiring or over the top dedicated 20 amp circuit installs.- the unit is very quiet for this price-range. you can hear it but just a little and when the water is running you cannot hear it at all-it comes with a 100 watt equivalent bulb (13 watts) that is very bright. Nice they included that.- the light cap is not see through or semi see through so you don't see an ugly bulb, even when on.CONS- Haven't found any yet. Compared to the Broans and Panasonics and the aero Pure's this unit has superior specs and performance in the sub 60$ 70CFM, <2 sones fan/light units spectrum. Excellent choice, especially for retro fitting.

It is advertised on Amazon as a 10 amp unit but here are the pitfalls I found once I received it:- its a 15 amp circuit requirement, which many homes and retro-fit situations cannot handle- it requires separate and distinct wiring for the heating units to get it to work with the included switches. Most retro fit situations won't have that and be prepared to shell out big $$$ to an electrician to get that remedied.- They do not disclose the wiring requirements and you won't find out until you are in an install situation what you are missing.- The lights do not perfectly fit the grille openings and the thing looks less than industrialThe good: the 15 amps it does require is for the whole thing, i.e. fan, light and heaters. So no separate circuit for the heaters only.In the end: they are wrong with the 10 amp listing and the wiring requirements are unsuitable for those of us replacing basic fan/light units. Price-wise it seems reasonable for the specs.

Here is my setup: I have the Simon XT and use Frontpoint Security (alarm.com powered). Shout out to them as they are goooooood.Now on to the review, or more like: some hints and tips to make this work with the Simon XT and XTi.When I received this item I had to go and find the manual online. Just do a search for 45600 Z-WAVE and you will get a link to some PDF's. The standard PDF manual for this item is misleading and for that I deducted a star.Thankfully, reviewers like Mike left hints on Amazon pointing to the fact that it can be done. Even by the novice.I will say it a little more detailed than reviewer Mike but it is essentially his tutorial:FIRST, YOU NEED TO ADD THE REMOTE TO YOUR SIMON XT:Simon XT 1.3 or higher- At keypad: System Programming > Enter Code > Interactive Services > Z-Wave Setup > Add DeviceTHEN PUT THE REMODE IN PAIRING MODE (essentially you are following Mike's comment that you need to start at the bottom of page 11 where it says COPYING NETWORK AND/OR DEVICE INFORMATION TO THIS REMOTE):- Press and hold SETUP on the remote until the red and green light blink twice- Then on the remote enter 9 6 7The green LED's on the remote will blink twice.NOW GO BACK TO PAGE 3 OF THE MANUAL AND FOLLOW "ADDING A LIGHT DEVICE/NODE TO YOUR REMOTE"If you do this diligently it will work. No need for complicated workarounds with scenes etc that others described elsewhere.Anyways, thanks Mike and hope my re-run helps others.For the 11 bucks I paid this little remote is worth it.Great as a panic button and get a few to keep in various rooms.

We bought this as a sunroom by our pool and looking at the photos online thought this would be neat looking at a reasonable price.Well, it's a sunroom alright but here are the negatives first:Installation:-The PDF manual is very poorly done, so look carefully and look again before you install- Some of the installation drawings were off- There are screw holes in the ceiling slats that have no part to screw in- We were missing screws in several categories and had to go out and find matching ones- The doors are incorrectly built as some youtubers noted: you cannot solve the riddle of the weatherstrip showing and our doors had the panels reversed.- The metal parts do not have precisely aligned screw holes. The while thing is slightly "off" and you cannot really get it fully squared. Nothing visible but nevertheless- The roof panels were squashed on some edges and were almost impossible to keep in their rails during installation- Again, biggest grief here is that nothing really perfectly lines up and you're constantly adjusting and hammering to get it fully standingAfter its up:- It's not weatherproof. With a heavy rainstorm we have roof drip and water runing down the beams so be careful what you put in. The panel structure on the roof is begging for trouble, once you see it up close: it's not built for significant water or snow backup- The wall panel are warping a bit from stress- The door has started to jam- the window panel latches are rusting and hardly open- plastic latch parts are crackingIn summary: not many redeeming factors than that it BARELY serves its purpose but be ready with lots of silicone and weatherseal to attack this thing. Others maybe have better done samples but mine was a travesty. We build lots of Palram items (carports, patio covers) and those are built precisely and the assembly is actually fun. With this thing I was ready to choke a kitteh after 8 hrs of aggravation. It takes 2 people and about a full day to do it.I think this is a 1500$ item at double the price. It's not worth the price and you're better off spending much less or some more for a better deal or decent quality.

We bought 2 of these and are very glad we did. They were installed on our concrete driveway which slopes a bit but the installation/design makes sure this is all square and neat looking IF you follow the instructions. These instructions are VERY clear in most parts and can be downloaded via google in case you want to have a peek.The end result looks very clean and modern and adds value to your home, whether used as a patio cover, carport or what other use.The clear polycarbonate roof lets through a lot of sunlight, so just be aware. It does keep our cars cooler than pure plazing sun. The protection from snow and rain is what we wanted and it does that quite well.A couple of findings:We did this between my wife and I. She is not handy and I am a banker... It took about 11 hrs for the first one and about 9 for the second one. So plan in a full day to get one done.Secondly: the concrete anchors are the galvanized ones: 5/16 by 3 1/2 inches. They break easily. We went and got some better ones at the depot. Dont find out too late: when the first one breaks get the high tensile ones.Here is another key piece of info: within a few weeks after building our student driver son backed into one and a pole was really bent.We called PALRAM and guess what: Tina from PALRAM sent us a new pole free of charge!!!!! I mean, seriously, I was embarrassed to accept it and was ready to pay the couple of hundred dollars that it should have costed. Her answer was: just write a review if you like us and appreciate the service. Well we do so here is that review Tina!A couple of facts / pros:Everything is high quality: even the painted parts are rust free galvanized steel parts. This thing is heavy quality.The screw holes are PRECISE. If something does not fit its because you have the part backwards or so. Precisely manufactured.The screws, nuts, bolts are high quality. Except for the concrete anchors. Those are regular ones and to do a good job I always prefer the blue high tensile ones. 25$ out of pocket for that.They look good. Everyone asks where we got them and compliments their looks. We're growing some ivy over one and boarding up one side of the other to create some accents.Follow instructions: don't tighten stuff when it says hand tighten or you will have a hard time getting the whole building square.All in all: wel spent money.ANyways, we're not that handy and did 2 of the PALRAMS in 2 days. And we had great fun doing them.

There are some good things to say about this GPS watch that others have spelled out. I would just like to highlight why I am unhappy with this watch:- In the advertising and on the website they clearly advertise that you can race against yourself in RACE mode. This will grapically display where you were in a previous race vs the current etc.This was the SOLE reason I bought this watch. And now I am finding that you can only run against 5 presets and that the race yourself feature might come in the future.Now, I believe there is something called TRUTH IN ADVERTISING and selling something based on features that do not exist is a no no.TomTom you clwealy opted to come to market with a beta product not fully fleshed out as is evident in your wesite and that just cost you several stars for this product.Update : they finally came through and added what ws claimed in the advertising and I am hugely grateful for that. Stars are up no to where they belong. For the price, the accuracy, the online concern they show and the features this now deserves top stars.

I received this outside of Amazon for someone thinking I would like it since I am into smoothies for my health. Green for life anyone.I tasted it and frankly it tastes great! It's the reason why that bothers me. It is definitely high on fructose. Small amounts of that are ok but given the sweet sweet nature of this stuff it means that your liver will be unable to process the fructose. It'll turn into fat. Secondly, maltodextrin. Processed starch derivative low cost filler. Again best left for use in smaller quantities. Guar gum: laxative side effects anyone?Short of it, despite the calories being somehat reasonable youre filling yourself up with fruits, veggies and a scoop of candy. There are other sweeteners and mixes you can use that actually have some benefits for your bod.If you're in it for taste and love sweet then this is for you. If you care about what enters the temple... Eject.

Surprising how many people are gullible... Makes me worried about the species in general.Do your homework and you will find they aren't recased by Motorola from white to black. That'd be ridiculously expensive and make no sense as a business practice if they could simply change the serial in the firmware or re-sticker it.Anyways, do your homework and you will find that the black versions are typically ISP batches that ISP's like Comcast and Cox would distribute as leased modems.You're not getting a used lease modem but rather a production unit that is new that is destined for an ISP. Said it 3 times now.Anyways, the reviewer is hilarious with his READ THIS stuff.

Background you can skipI was considering buying wither the Fitbit Aria or the Whiting WS-30 scale on Amazon and started leaning towards the Whiting given that it had a better average rating. I did like the BMI feature and the aesthetics of the Aria better and also wanted the Aria to be the choice because we have Fitibit One's, so the whole experience would be more integrated. However, as said, I did not like the fact that there were so many 1 and 2 ratings.Before I 1-clicked the Whiting I decided to read the negative reviews on the Aria and it stood out to me that they mostly revolved around setup issues and especially network connectivity. Given that I am a network tinkerer and think highly of my computer skills I decided that I would not run into those issues and decided for the Aria (hooray for logic).About the SetupThe Aria is very sleek. I bought the black one. Nice scrolling text in the window etc etc. But you can see all that from the other reviews. Also pretty clear setup instructions:You go onto your fitbit account, download some Mac or Windows software and then activate the scale by removing the plastic strip in the battery compartment.Make sure you're on wifi and the software will do the rest during install and upload the wifi settings to the scale and BAM! you're done.Not so simple.Being the self proclaimed genius I followed all instructions to the letter and sat back when the on screen prompts were telling me the settings were downloaded to the scale. Then it stopped. The scale showed WIFI ERR and my wifi connection on my Mac was off.Ipso facto: the same issues that hit other hit me and my wife came to lend me support (and to make sure I would not smash the scale against the pavement in frustration as I have a temper when it comes to bad product).After some tinkering I found the following:If you're use Wifi encryption / security the software DID NOT collect and pass my password to the network to the scale. The way I found out is that I created a guest network on my Airport Extreme router and chose NO ENCRYPTION. I figured that the Wifi Error most likely had to do with my network encryption.When I then re-ran the software and it asked me if I wanted to use my main Wifi network to connect to the router I chose NO.It them presented me with the network options of my encrypted and unencrypted guest networks.I also noticed that my main wifi network was showing a password box but it was empty. So I typed in my network password and tried again instead of using the guest network.It worked this time.So the issue is in the software and how it deals with passwords. Most likely an unencrypted network (i.e. the guest network) would also solve it but again, why add another network if the encryption settings can be added.My verdict:Minus 1 star for sh*tty setup software and messing up something basic like that. Does Fitbit NOT understand that this is the FIRST experience with the device and if it is bad then people, in this online real time world, will complain and ding you for it immediately????Shame on fitbit.However, 4 stars for when it does work: it is consistent in readings, weight as well as BMI. It also AUTO-RECOGNIZES up to 7 users of your choice and uploads to their fitbit.The screen is very legible and the integration with Fitbit is great.Little expensive for a scale but the fact that it is Wifi keeps me weighing more often which keeps me motivated and watchful of what I consume. That is work a 50$ premium to me.Hope the troubleshooting findings helped. And yes, I am not genius with this stuff but I did solve this scenario for myself !

I needed some screen protectors for my Samsung Galaxy S2 D710 and tried various brands. I tried anti fingerprint/smudge and glare filters but they frankly took the life out of the screen. Somehow it looked pixellated and you could tell clearly that there was a piece of plastic over the screen.Worse, though, was that even the TINIEST speck of dust would create a bubble... I am a pro at applying wet and dry and could not get those protectors right. They were also very thicka nd hard to position.So I tried the cheapest of the bunch and it came in a packet of 3. I decided to wet-apply it and am glad I did.My findings:This screen protector is not listed as anti smudge/fingerprint but it really does not seem to smudge at all with my greasy skin.It also goes on crystal clear, i.e., you cannot tell its on. The screen looks WAY crisper than the thicker anti fingerprint protectors I used.Most importantly: it goes on bubble-free when wet-applied.Finally it does not change the sliding feel of your fingers.I simply clean the screen with some lint free clot and window cleaner.Then I spray the screen and sticky side of the protector with a light mist of solution (left over from other wet-apply kits).Then I lightly mist the surface so that the squeegee will slide smoothly.Slide and position the protector on the phone and squeegee the excess out from under it with the supplied squeegee.Again, no bubbles and invisible.Cant go wrong at this price!!!

We use this to pick up stray trash on our street. This one broke on the 2nd use picking up weightless thrash.Also, you can only pull some parts open to try and fix but the head is riveted, i.e. cannot be fixed.It is, frankly, low quality garbage and I am VERY surprised it got the ratings so high on here.The trigger is low grade plastic and the parts are held together with more low grade plastic.5$ item in a 20$ disguise.

Background you can skipI am quite the collector of gadgets given that my kids and wide all have cellphones and uploads and laptops and so on.I have a bit of the wrap everything in plastic gene . Not my sofa but certainly all of the expensive gadgetry . As such I have lots of experience with putting wet and dry protectors on my devices and other people's devices as well. I have used the zagg, armorshields, bodyguards and a few nameless brands from eBay.About this itemI read a few negative reviews of this item,  claiming it was hard to put on and that it bubbled etc  but still decided to go ahead as I used skinomi before and always was very pleased with the packaging and cuts .This item was well packaged in a black cardboard mailing tube.  In the tube:Solution for wet applicationSqueegee2 large sheets with detailed full body protectors for back and frontMicrofiber cleaning clothInstructionsAbout the materialThe clear protection film looks like any other but it is cut with many parts for the specific casing of the galaxy note.even the thin sides and the oddly cut parts are cut out with all the relevant openings exactly in the right place. Some of the other brands are not always as precise with their cut outs and you'll have trouble lining up the cut outs.Apparently this film is not going to turn yellow over time which is also a plus.The thing that worried me most was that the film would somehow obstruct the use of the s pen,  I thought it would potentially stop the s pen from sliding smoothly over the screen. Well it does not,  I am happy to report. I would almost say it makes the use of the pen better. This review was completely done by Swyping the s pen , for instance.Putting it onSo now about the issues with putting it on. There are no issues. The folks that complain simply have not done this before, properly followed instructions or are not very adept at DIY. This goes on like any other wet application and the cut outs are exact.I cleaned the device thoroughly with alcohol before applying and sprayed the sticky side of the film lightly. I also do always lightly mist both the surface of the device and my hands,  key here is to do it lightly.  If the environment is dusty then do this in the bathroom after creating some steam from the shower to keep dust from getting between the film  and device.Put the film on and and carefully position the various relevant cut outs. Once in position I Squeegee from the center outward in a star pattern until there are no bubbles.  Don't press hard, just Squeegee diligently.Keep brawny handy to absorb the Squeegee' d solution.If might look hazy or not fully clear for about a day or so but if you did this right it does cleat dry clear with no bubbles whatsoever. I cannot even see it on my note.It is truly invisible on my note and the pen slides with no problems .This is really not that hard and takes about 30 minutes to do the whole device.This is very well priced for this quality and again, this is like any wet application protector . I am glad I chose Skinomi and will use them again where I can for my next gadget purchase.

I bought this sd card to expand the memory on my Samsung tablet.  I had read that the galaxy note could only be expanded up to 32gb as the sd card would have to be formated as fat32.Long story short,  I inserted it and without any problems or formatting it showed as 60 odd GB.Noyce!

Since the are already so many reviews on here for this item I thought I would add a specific angle. One that focuses on the use of the tablet as a graphics design tool mostly.I will also spend a moment discussing my other uses for the tablets I own and tell you what my experience is.Background you can skipI am not necessarily an Apple fan. As a matter of fact, I was always the type of guy building PC's, creating FreeNAS servers, experimenting with software etc. more Microsoft than Apple.The adoption of Apple into my household came when I started to buy computers for my Dad, nephews and nieces and MIL. Due to distance it became aggravating to get the calls where they were stuck with a blue screen or something else after downloading some virus or upgrading some driver. It was always something. So I decided that I would buy a tablet to see if my dad would be able to use that. That was e first Apple device into my home.I liked the usability, simplicity of the interface and the Apple-typical lack of buttons. All in all, I was pleased with how fast my 80+ year old dad was able to use it. No reboots, complex downloads or installs etc.then cam iMacs and time machines and MacBooks.I found that I spent way less time fixing computers and instead was using them. I was a believer.I stuck with the iPads and am currently on the 4th gen. Since iPads are invading my workspace I find myself using it mostly and running into some of the limitations.How I use the tabletsI mostly use my tablet work wise for the development of graphics for presentations that outline complex solutions. We do not use standard PowerPoint stuff but have a philosophy of custom and hand drawn pictures that can, if necessary, be Peter live on a whiteboard.Since the ipad does not have any native pressure sensitivity I had to wait until someone came out with a pressure sensitive stylus. At this point there are a few on the market and after looking at reviews I settled for the Jot Not Touch. I mainly use it with Sketchbook Pro, Touchdraw and so on.Here are the limitations I have found:- the disk tip that is needed for precision on the ipad is still somewhat inaccurate and hard to handle. I often have to press screen buttons multiple times to get it to register.- the pressure sensitivity seems to go off and on. Sometimes I find myself pressuring harder and harder to get the same results. This makes for lots of time spent handling the stylus and ipad combo rather than thinking about the quality of my graphics design- the styluses for the ipad that have reassure sensitivity either have weird tips or are bulky to handle. I am 5'11".I also use the ipad to communicate via iMessage with all my family all over the world. iMessage is so simple and effective and I get it everywhere.without ads and other nonsense.Finally,and this is quite important once your have the Apple drug in your house: I have connected my home with a series of Airports and time machines. The airports connect to various stereo systems and apple TV's and I can simply control. Everything from my ipad, or my wife from hers.it is supremely easy and connected at a fraction of the cost I would have had if I bought the Sony or Bose solutions for this.Now about the GN10.1I bought it because I was working on another graphics project and got fed up with the clumsy stylus and ipad combo. I even paid overnight rush shipping to get it. And you know what, the Samsung embedded pressure sensitive stylus is so much better than the solution needed with the ipad. The tip is precise, the stylus is the right size, perhaps a little too light and thin but better than what I had for the ipad.I have spent less time messing with the hardware and more time on my work, so great kudosto Samsung.Also, the GN is fast, there is nothing to complain about with the 1.4 quad core compared to the ipad.The screen, however, on the ipad, is visibly better when. Drawing thin lines.
