I love that!  Furthermore, leave it in the cradle regularly should you with.  With the lithium technology, you do not have to worry about batteries being affected overtime as dramatically as shavers from a decade ago. Sure, the battery will not last forever but it will hold up longer.Third, the shaving performance is as expected for this price range and even some shavers nearly twice as much.  Nevertheless, as other reviewers suggest, these products always leave some to be desired if you're particularly fussy regarding your shave.Overall, this is a quality product from Remington.  They have brought forward many premium features such as wet use technology, lithium battery technology to not see decreased battery performance over time, a charging cradle, and solid performance.  All of this can be had at an attractive value.  Recommended.

I was excited to try Office 365 Home Premium as I have purchased both Mac and Windows versions of Microsoft's Office suites for nearly two decades.At first I thought it might be some kind of online version of Office, but it most certainly isn't.  You receive a pin code with the purchase that you register at Microsoft's website.  You are then able to install Home Premium Office on up to 5 computers.  The cool factor?  The cool factor is that those five machines can be split between PCs and Macs.  Therefore, if you have 2 PCs, they can have the latest version of Office for Windows, and your 3 Macs can have the latest version of Office for Mac.  The catch?  The software on all those machines will expire in 365 days, and you will then need to purchase another year.Truthfully, if you're a Mac only or PC only household without many computers, you might get more value out of the non-expiring version if the number of licenses included will suffice in your home.There are two reasons one might choose the 365 product: First, you have Macs & PCs, so you want the latest version of Office for both platforms in one purchase.  Second, you have five machines in your home and the non-expiring version does not include 5 licensees (the non-expiring versions of office normally include only 1 or 3 licenses in certain family editions).Otherwise, you will likely get more value from the non-expiring version of the software.  The choice is yours.  Always up to date on 5 machines across 2 platforms with an annual cost, or a one time cost with less versatility.  One solution is not the best for everyone.

Meguiar's new White Wax is a terrific product and don't let the name fool you, it can be used on any color, not just white.Why is it called white wax?  Simple, it helps address a problem most visible on white and lighter colored vehicles.  On light vehicles, you can see contaminants on/in the paint more easily.  That spec of brown/black that doesn't want to come up, overall dullness, etc.  These issues are extremely visible on white and light colored cars.White wax helps address it because it is a cleaner wax with a heavy dose of cleaning properties, to help remove those contaminants that ruin the look of the paint.  Furthermore, it has enough cleaning ability that it could potentially remove very light scratches as well!What makes it even more powerful is that it includes a terrific applicator.  One side is very soft, like you would use to apply any wax, but the other side is soft with just a bit more texture, this gives the product even more "bite," to remove contaminants or light defects.  The applicator is great.  I have even used the applicator with a more aggressive product to remove scratches.Truly, I have used white wax on a silver and black vehicle.  Meguiar's also makes a new black wax.  The black wax can also be used on any color.  The black product is called Black Wax because on a black car the contaminants in paint are less visible, so it cuts back on the cleaning/cut, and instead adds more polishing oils.  On a black car, polishing oils always add depth to the paint that makes it oh so deep looking, and it can also hide minor imperfections.Overall, these new White Wax & Black Wax products are great and not for only the colors the name suggests.  If you want more cleaning in your All in One Wax, White Wax is a great choice and comes with that great aggressive on one side, applicator.  However, if you want more polishing oils in your all in one product to add depth to the paint and hide some minor imperfections, try black wax.  Some fanatics are applying white wax, followed by black wax.  I will say that the longevity of White Wax does not seem as long as some of Meguiar's sealant only products, such as NXT Wax.  However, at the same time, since White Wax does remove some contaminants, it helps prep a cleaner/smooth surface to apply the wax, which could help a heavily contaminated car stay protected slightly longer.White wax targets the main issue of lighter colored vehicles.  Nevertheless, it can be useful for any vehicle.  The longevity of the wax protection in the product could be longer, but waxing is so easy with this "liquid paste," that you won't mind waxing more often.  The only downsides: the toothpaste tube packaging gets wrinkled up, the liquid paste psychologically encourages you to use more product than you need, and therefore you will use this product quicker than you would a traditional liquid wax or paste wax.
Very attractive, beautifully-realized in sterling silver, the high quality of the Hallmark brand is immediately apparent.

These measuring cups are extremely handy, particularly if you're making something with many ingredients that need to be measured. Instead of having to have several regular measuring cups on hand, or repeatedly cleaning one between measuring different ingredients, you have four specific sizes immediately at hand. And if you do have to repeat a specific measurement with a different ingredient, these smaller cups are easier to rinse and dry than a full-size measuring cup.They also lend themselves to more exact measuring. No longer having to interpret when you've hit the measurement line in a full-size cup, you simply fill the appropriate size cup with your ingredient then scrape across the top with the flat back blade of a knife or other implement. Voila! The exact right amount of ingredient!These cups are very high quality, and it's immediately apparent. Heavy-duty plastic with secure grips, dishwasher-safe, very attractive (for what they are...).A solid 5 stars.

OtterBox has to make the best cell phone cases available.This is now my second one, having used one for my HTC OneX for years. It's easy to install and fits perfectly. There's a screen protector element that's clear, so your screen view isn't obstructed in any way and still functions perfectly, and essentially seals the entire unit, all surfaces, making it virtually water-proof. The input port is protected by a tight-fitting flexible flap.The gripping surface is textured enough to provide a secure grip on the phone without feeling "tacky". Very attractive in appearance. I simply can't think of a better phone case in the market.

I bought this book on the strength of the John Sanford brand; I'd never heard of the other guy (Ctein), and now I know why.I really enjoy a good space opera. Unfortunately, this ain't one. Oh, it starts off with some of the classic elements: a mysterious starship is spotted by chance decelerating in deep space, then coming to a stop somewhere in Saturn's rings. Governments on Earth decide to secretly develop and launch our own spaceships to go there and explore the alien phenomenon. A space race ensues between the USofA and China. The usual assortment of "quirky" characters assemble on America's space station to convert it for deep-space travel. Off they go...Where this book badly misfires is that good space opera has to actually have some excitement, suspense, a sense of menace. Instead, we have a repetitive, tedious, uninteresting recitation of endless mundane detail and minutiae. Tweaking the cooling system; cutting off the ends of the living modules; repetitive recitations of the function of the ship's acceleration. Who cares??? Move on!!!The players aren't characters, they're caricatures: cartoonish, shallow, two-dimensional, interchangeable. The studly playboy; the gorgeous newscaster; the nerdish female engineer; the stoic ship's captain; the cuddly intellectual. Like that. Not one player with a lick of originality.In all honesty, I've made it a bit past the halfway point of this book, and I'm just giving up. I just can't finish it. Too boring, by far.Maybe it finally picks up later, I don't know, and frankly don't even care anymore. This thing's as thick as a brick, and weighs as much. I can't even imagine wasting as much time going forward as I have so far, hoping for something to actually finally happen. Maybe, like a brick, I can find some use for it as a doorstop or something.

I like a big watch. My everyday timepiece is a Rolex GMT-Master, which is pretty substantial. Since it’s also an expensive watch, being worth several thousand dollars, there are times when I’m going places, or doing things, when I’d rather leave it at home rather than take the risk of marring, losing, or damaging it.Because of that, I’ve been kind of half-heartedly in the market for a much less expensive alternative to wear on those occasions, so when this Swiss Legend became available to me through Amazon’s Vine program, I snapped it up.First, to address the price issue, I think Amazon’s “List Price” of $550 is wildly optimistic. No matter where you look on the Net, this is a sub-$100 watch. Which actually suited me just fine for my purposes: an inexpensive watch that, if it got damaged, I wouldn’t spend a lot of time mourning.It’s a quartz movement with analog display, and seems reasonably accurate, seeming to lose about 1 – 3 seconds a day, suitably within acceptable parameters.But I have to say, this is one MASSIVE watch! I didn’t actually weigh it, but holding both watches in hand, I’d guess the Legend watch is a good 15% heavier than the Rolex, at least. The Legend’s face is 3/16” larger in diameter than the Rolex’s, not including the bezel. When you include the bezel, the difference increases to ”. The case of the Legend is easily 50% thicker than the Rolex. The actual case is even wider than the face, and coated with a rubber material. It’s marked as being “water resistant” to 330 feet. As I said, this is a bathyscaphe for your wrist. According to the owner’s manual, it’s suitable for use while scuba diving.I find it to be a very handsome watch, but one caveat: the dial is harder to read than indicated in the picture on the product page. The watch face is noticeably darker than pictured; the numerals are very hard to distinguish; and the ends of the watch’s hands are coated with some black material that matches the coloration of the numerals. So though it’s very attractive, it doesn’t easily lend itself to “at a glance” use.But overall, I’m very pleased with it. I think it’s an excellent value for its price; it seems very robust (to say the least!) and durable; and if something does actually happen to it, it’ll be easy to replace and move on from.A very solid 4 stars.

In many ways this book reminds me of the BBC TV series “The Fixer”. A highly-skilled and superbly trained government operative drops out of service and goes off the grid, dedicating his life and “certain skill set” to helping strangers in desperate need in life-or-death situations.Evan Smoak is Orphan X (as in the Roman numeral). Now living a solitary life in Los Angeles, he helps people who are referred to him by previous “clients”. He doesn’t charge them anything, other than with the responsibility to pass his contact number on ONCE to someone else as desperate as they are. He’s the Nowhere Man.But something’s gone badly wrong. His last client seems to have quickly – much too quickly – passed his contact info on to TWO people, a violation of the protocol, and to further complicate matters, his new “clients” seem to be in the crosshairs of their pursuers to a deadly extreme that Evan hasn’t encountered before.As he tries to assess the situation and adjust his strategy, the net just seems to keep closing tighter and tighter, with very deadly consequences.I think Hurwitz has come up with a real winner in this book, and a fascinating protagonist in Evan Smoak. Unique, interesting, fully-realized and three-dimensional. The story had excellent plotting and pacing, exciting and believable action sequences, and a full cast of secondary characters.The only nit I have to pick, and it’s a minor one, is that I didn’t really get any sense of LA as a setting. That’s even though I actually live in the ‘burbs of that city.But I really recommend this book, and look forward to Smoak’s next outing.

My 6-year-old granddaughter just loves this set.As soon as we opened it and got it set up with three AA batteries (not included), she went right to work cranking out art work for her mom and dad, rightfully proud of her results. It's easy to set up and use, and allows your own munchkin to create really nice artwork that will make their eyes glow with pride.After trying to position the top sheet (upon which one draws the picture) into the corner slots designed to hold it in place, and then maneuver the pattern sheets (from which one traces) under it, we just gave up, as that wasn't really necessary. She simply held everything in place with her hand as she drew her picture with the other hand, making the whole operation easier and more successful.There's an entire set of colored pencils included, and my munchkin wanted me to mention to the makers that they should include brown as one of the colors (got that, Alex Toys?). But be prepared to buy more, because you'll probably go through them pretty quick if your own munchkin, like mine, wants to color in all the background, too.There was more than enough like to shine through to the top, making tracing very easy.A solid 5 stars. Well done!

How to describe a scent or aroma?When I first applied this cologne I was put off by a dominant scent of lemon. I'm not into citrus aromas. But after a few minutes, undoubtedly once the cologne had started reacting to my skin, that dominant note went away, and left a very refreshing and clean scent, with sweet and spicy tones such as vanilla with a bit of cedar.I really like this, as I'm not into "girly" scents for men. This is more masculine, though not too overtly woodsy. The scent seems to last longer than the ones I've currently been using, too. You don't have a flash of overpowering smell that quickly vanishes away to nothing, as has been the case with some I've used.I like this... a lot.

When I saw the new Mitch Rapp book “The Survivor” in the bookstore, I have to admit I bought it with mixed feelings. The sorely-missed Vince Flynn wrote top-notch political thrillers in this series, and I’ve been a fan from the start. So I was eager for the series to continue, but my experience with books written by substitute authors hasn’t been very good.This book continues with the elements that made the series unique: a blend of politics, espionage, and action.And credit due where earned, author Kyle Mills does a creditable job of trying to continue Flynn’s work.But I guess when an author conceives of – and then essentially lives with – a subject as the author of a continuing series over a period of years, there are just certain unique perspectives he brings to the work that no one else can.In this case, most noticeably to me, there were certain nuances, particularly in the characters and most particularly in Rapp himself, that just didn’t ring QUITE right to me. Rapp seems to me to be more thuggish than he has throughout the series to now; less subtle in his thoughts and actions; less strategic in his approach to issues. I felt some of the same issues pertain to Irene Kennedy, too. The characters just didn’t resonate quite right with me.Overall still an enjoyable book.

Very easy to install. Auto-install worked flawlessly.I'm running Win 7 Pro on a Dell Studio XPS 8000. This software was very easy to use; intuitive. I've primarily been using Windows Movie Maker to now (though I've tried several other programs with varying success) because I find it very simple to drag and drop my clips in place, add title cards, menus, sound tracks, etc. with that program. And that's what I want: simplicity. I'm really not interested in wasting time at an editing board.Cyberlink's PowerDirector 14 is virtually just as simple. Drag and drop your clips, title cards, subtitles, what have you, onto the timeline. Insert your sound track into the sound timeline. Create your movie. Easy peazy.There's also an "Easy Editor" mode, which opens a "Magic Movie Wizard", which creates clips that are presented kind of like previews of coming attractions. I'm hard-pressed to see the value of it; maybe if you just want to jam something together for Facebook.This is just what I've been looking for. Very well done.

My 6-year-old granddaughter loves this boat/mansion.First of all, it IS a boat and converts to a mansion, so it melds well into the other scenarios she sets up with settings she has for Disney princesses, as well as from other manufacturers.The boat's very well made, high quality, sturdy, and well-designed. She had a lot of fun personalizing her boat with the included decals. She was absolutely delighted that the little doll actually speaks, and she gets a kick out of changing her various outfits and hair styles.It's very easy to assemble (which, again, she really enjoyed doing).All in all, quite a hit with our munchkin.

This is essentially heavy-handed political propaganda masked as a kid's movie. Worse yet, as a movie it's not very well done.There's a whole lot of sound and fury wrapped up in a poorly plotted story. The visual effects are well-done, but that's the movie's biggest accomplishment, and if that's all you're looking for you can get better at the theme park rides. The level of violence makes me question what audience this film's targeted at. It's far too violent for young children, and from the amount of political preechifying it seems to me it's supposed to be a movie for grownups. But if it is, then we should have had better writing, which pretty much takes us back to the start of the vicious circle.Bottom line: don't bother.

I won’t write a story synopsis as you can get that from the book’s Amazon product page, which I would assume is how you got to the reviews in the first place.In this outing, we get to revisit Elvis Cole and Joe Pike doing what they do best: solving crime. This time out they’re joined by LAPD officer Scott James and his K-9 sidekick Maggie, previously seen as the protagonists in Crais’s novel “Suspect”.Briefly, a chemical engineer who specializes in explosives, Amy Breslyn, has disappeared from her job and fallen off the grid after her son was killed overseas in a terrorist suicide bombing attack. It’s been reported that Amy’s now trying to sell several hundred pounds of high explosives to the terrorist underground. Amy’s supervisor hires Elvis to find her and bring her back into the fold. Naturally, things aren’t as simple as they seem, and from that premise all things flow.Crais does his usual credible and entertaining job in presenting the story. Elvis seems to be maturing with age – he’s not as flippant as in the earlier works – and this works well. If you do the math, Elvis is a Vietnam vet, which makes him a guy who’s easily in his late 50s by now, if not older. In fact, that’s actually one of my prime nits to pick with this (and some of the earlier books of the series) story. Elvis and Joe Pike seem to have been bitten by the Peter Pan bug. Don’t these guys EVER age?But the book still works if you put that aside. Very good pacing and plot presentation; the story moves right along, and is easy to follow. There are some pretty good surprises that are entertainingly revealed. The main characters are three-dimensional, and we have some pretty good action sequences.Blending Scott James and Maggie in with Elvis and Pike also worked for the book.A solid 4 stars.

Newcomer Nicholas Petrie has entered the thriller field with a new protagonist named Peter Ash.Ash is a former Marine, now a civilian, suffering from PTSD brought on by his tours in the Sandbox (Iraq and Afghanistan) which expresses itself as pretty extreme claustrophobia. Due to his condition, Ash lives pretty much off the grid, either in his truck or in the open wilds.When he learns that one of his former sergeants has committed suicide, Ash decides to help out his widow and kids by doing some repairs on their house. While doing so, he finds a suitcase filled with money and some plastic explosive, guarded by a monster dog. This discovery puts him on the trail of a conspiracy that will ultimately endanger not only his own life, but those of the people he set out to help in the first place.Overall, I thought the book was entertaining, though I do think there are some aspects that are a bit problematic.To begin, I think Petrie has a lot of talent, and shows promise. But I found the exposition of the plot to be uneven, and sometimes choppy and hard to follow. The action sequences were well done. The presentation of the main characters was pretty well done, and most of them were pretty three-dimensional, a common failing with many first-time authors that Petrie avoided.As this is a “thriller debut” (according to Amazon’s product description), I’m assuming Ash will be starring in his own series. I’m also assuming that when an author is creating a new series protagonist, at least part of the goal is to make that character unique and memorable. In that respect, Petrie has made Ash a claustrophobic, which will put him in the position of living off the grid and moving around a lot, maybe along the lines of Lee Childs’s Jack Reacher character.But I think that’s a curious choice that presents a problem, and one of the things I actually found somewhat annoying about this book. Every time Ash goes into a building or other enclosed environment, we’re subjected to this repeated exposition about his symptoms flaring up, to the point that it becomes a distraction, and Ash starts coming across as kind of whiny. It also seems to happen somewhat selectively in its severity, in that the character has to rapidly egress some settings due to the problem, but can function just fine at other times when the advancement of the plot requires it. This is a troubling inconsistency.Further, I think this could well present a serious problem, and limitation, of what Petrie is going to be able to have Ash doing if and as this series progresses. It’s one thing for Childs’s Reacher character to stay off the grid out of choice, as he can still – and does – operate in normal environments constantly. But that’s not the case with Petrie’s Ash character.Anyway, as I said, it’s an entertaining debut. I’ll be interested in reading the next entry in the series.

Over the last several years the Reacher canon has been in a downward spiral and this latest entry in the series is plumbing new and disgusting lows, not only in the antagonists, but in protagonist Jack Reacher, too. After reading it, I felt completely disgusted, and felt as if I needed a scalding hot shower to wash off the filth.When the series started, Reacher was the knight in slightly tarnished armor who found himself helping out some poor soul who’d found themselves embroiled in some kind of sticky situation they couldn’t handle themselves, and Reacher would step in, like the Lone Ranger, and save the day.But as time has gone on, and particularly of late, author Child seems to have tired of the formula that made his success, and instead has created these utterly unbelievable situations that border on the surreal, if not outright insane, and the result has been to turn a formerly entertaining and enjoyable series into something beyond dark, almost absurdly gothic.In this case, a very small town in the middle of nowhere – literally, a place surrounded by flat wheat fields to the visible horizon, so far out that it’s hours to the nearest area with cell phone service – named Mother’s Rest is the locus of events, starting with the disappearance and murder of a former FBI agent cum private investigator.Reacher gets off the daily train out of curiosity about the town’s name and meets Michelle Chang, a colleague of the missing PI who’s trying to locate him. Without revealing details that would contain spoilers, I can say that their investigation leads them to a deadly conspiracy based in the Dark Web – that underbelly of the internet that most of us never even access – that’s located in Mother’s Rest, leading to a final and very deadly confrontation.As I mentioned earlier, my biggest problem with the book was the nature of the secret upon which the conspiracy is centered. Quite frankly, it was beyond disgusting and disturbing. It was depraved. This was more Stephen King territory than Jack Reacher.But also problematic is that author Child has once again created an utterly unbelievable locale in which to base the story, in order to create a situation in which Reacher can operate.Mother’s Rest is so far out in the sticks that it seems to be enclosed in an impenetrable bubble from the outside world, like in the TV series “The Dome”. How is it that no cops of any type ever come by? How is it that a whole bunch of townspeople are involved in this conspiracy, but in a town this small no OTHER townsfolk seem to be aware of it, and called the authorities for an investigation? Why is it that Reacher and Chang themselves don’t just call the authorities – county, state or federal – once they learn the exact nature of the crimes?Not only do you have to suspend your disbelief to buy into this story, but you have to shut down all common sense, too.Further, the character of Reacher himself has changed dramatically from the early days of the series. Gone is the creaky knight, the literary Lone Ranger. This Reacher no longer seems to have any interest in anything much other than blowing the bad guys away. And somehow he manages to do that without ever having to answer or explain anything to anyone anywhere in a position of authority. More of that vacuum I mentioned earlier.Based on this book, and coupled with my experience with the last few, I have to say that from this point on I’ll be waiting to buy any of these Reacher books until I find out more about them. I can’t recommend this one at all.

My granddaughter (almost 6 years old) really loves good plush toy animals, and she fell right in love with this little owl the moment I unveiled him (or her). She named him (or her) "Spotty".It's of very high quality and very well made. Your hand goes into the body of the bird, allowing you to manipulate a small handle inside which causes the bird's head to rotate, just like a real owl's.The wing tips can fasten together, allowing one to position the bird into a sleep configuration, too.All in all, it has the Munchkin Seal of Approval at the Baker Hacienda, and that's good enough for me.

My almost-6-year-old munchkin is really into horses -- what little girl isn't? -- so I thought this set would be right up her alley, and I was right. She likes it very much.I have to say, the detail and quality are amazing. The texture to the groomer's clothing, the horse's coat, the hose, the brick work of the stall... everything. That's why I called this a "diorama" rather than just a toy. It really is of that quality.It's also of a size that allows her to incorporate it into the scenarios she sets up with her other toys, such as Disney princesses and My Little Pony castle and such.Everything is very well made of robust materials, so this set should last a very long time. We're very pleased.

When we opened the box, my almost-6-year-old munchkin's eyes lit right up. Assembly was easy (you need to supply your own batteries) and the fact that she could stamp and color without having to worry about making any mess was a huge plus.The set comes with 10 stamps that fit into the stamp handle, which itself lights up when it's applied to each of the ink supply wells (which she thought was really cool).Further, the set comes with three markers, which can be used either to color directly onto the special paper (the key to the mess-free ability) or to apply ink to the markers, which gives even more options for stamping colors.The set sturdily built and should stand up to moderate abuse (there are a couple of moving parts), and I've checked and found that supplies (ink, special paper) are available from the manufacturer on-line at a reasonable cost.I thought the price of the set itself was also very reasonable, taking into consideration the bang you get for your buck. A very solid 4 stars.

This dinosaur is incredibly detailed, and of obviously high quality. It's made of very dense material, and is quite substantial and robust.The jaw moves to either an open or closed position. It should last for a very, very long time, either as a toy or learning aid in a class setting.It is a bit pricey, but in this case I think you get what you pay for.

I've been a fan of this series from the first book, and in this entry authors Coughlin and Davis take protagonist Kyle Swanson into new territory.The book opens in Mogadishu, Somalia in 1992, when Swanson was a young three-striper Marine sergeant still in the early stages of his career. While "the Mog" is in meltdown mode, with local warlords grappling for supremacy, the Marines are trying to keep the peace.Swanson and his crew find themselves caught up in the struggle, and while trying to meet their mission parameters Swanson manages to alienate a psycho enforcer for one of the warlords -- the Cobra, a maniac who seeks his own vengeance by destroying everything Swanson holds dear in the region.Flash forward a couple of decades, to the present, and Swanson is mandatorily "retired" from the Corps, but his skills are still deemed useful to the government, so he's seconded to the CIA. At the same time, the Cobra, finally on the loose again after the events of 1992, has come to the US to seek his own vengeance in yet another terrorist attack, this time targeting one of the biggest malls in the country.This leads to a final confrontation between Swanson and the Cobra, as both do their best to destroy the other.I really liked this book. The pacing and excitement are on a par with the rest of the series, but we also get a look into Swanson's past as the Somalia events unfold. This really gives us valuable insight into important events that molded Swanson into what he ultimately became. I think it's also important to note that the authors allow Swanson to change and develop over time as this series has progressed, avoiding the error that so many series authors make by seemingly freezing their characters in time like some kind of Peter Pan, never aging and with their circumstances seemingly embedded in amber.

The story synopsis on the book jacket sounded really interesting. Unfortunately, the book itself didn't live up to that promise. In all honesty, I finally gave up after about 120 pages.I didn't like any of the central characters, finding them unsympathetic, and therefore didn't care at all what happened to them. For a book to succeed for me, I have to be able to emotionally invest with at least one of the protagonists, otherwise forget it.Then there's the fact that a homosexual love story is a central element, with very graphic depictions. I know it's all the PC rage to get behind that stuff, but frankly, I have less than zero interest in reading about it. This is probably a great book for the gay niche market, I don't know. But for me it was a total turnoff.

As usual with Revlon grooming products, this is a very well-made and useful implement.It has six combo settings (three heat levels, and two speeds), affording you a wide range of options to best suit your individual styling needs. There's also a cold shot ability. They all work extremely well, with the variations being very noticeable. When you set the speed at "high", it really puts out some air!It also comes with a styling brush, as well as two hair clips (not really useful to me, as I'm a guy. And I don't do "man buns").It's very well made; sturdy and durable, with excellent fit and finish. The filter screen is easily accessible for cleaning, too, to ensure proper air intake as time goes on (those screens do have a tendency to gather lint).A solid 5 stars.

My granddaughter's just shy of being 6 years old, and she immediately loved these toy binoculars when I gave them to her.Let's be clear: they are TOY binoculars, not made for adults. As such, they're made of plastic, and of "toy" quality. If you're expecting a unit suitable for adult field use, this isn't for you.That having been said, these toy binocs are a great way for your own munchkin to learn how to use them. They're bright and colorful. They do noticeably magnify whatever's being viewed, which adds to the fun factor. The focus knob really works (as opposed to other toys binocs I've tried). The breakaway strap is a great idea that's already come in handy in just the first couple of days. It prevents your tyke from becoming trapped by a "noose" around their neck if the strap snags on something.Overall, lot's of fun for the little one; she gets a big kick out of these toy binocs.And let's face it: that's the bottom line, right?

Cuisinart makes very high quality products, and this blender is no exception.Very sturdy, robust, and powerful, it should meet all your culinary needs for blending, crushing, mixing, etc. Smoothies and other mixes are a snap.It's very attractively designed, and the parts all seem to be of top drawer quality. The blades are stainless steel. It has push-button controls on the front panel that are clear and easy to understand. The mixing container comes off easily for pouring and cleaning, and the entire unit stores easily.What more could you ask for?

The story was really well-written for younger children. Though my almost-6-year-old granddaughter can't reliably read by herself, she loved the story, particularly as it centered around animals like horses and dogs, which she loves. Also, the central characters are sisters (girls), which made it easy for her to identify with them.My copy is a pre-publication version, so it didn't contain all the planned illustrations that will be in the retail version, but the pictures that were there were really well done; artistic, and captured her imagination.I think this book is particularly well-suited for girls.

In "The Governor's Wife" Michael Harvey returns to the style and scope of hard-boiled detective fiction that put him on the map, leaving behind the unbelievable nonsense he had his Michael Kelly character doing in the last couple of books.This time around Kelly's been hired by an unknown client to track down a disgraced and convicted former governor who disappeared from custody immediately following his conviction at trial and sentencing to 30 years in prison.As Kelly probes the case it slowly becomes clear that there are a lot more things in play than simply someone trying to escape a prison sentence, and that other players have their own agendas, which they seem willing to forward even if there's a price to be paid in blood.Harvey's portrayal of Illinois and Chicago corruption is appropriately dark and cynical, and PI Kelly is the proper knight in tarnished armor to wade through it as he seeks to clear the case and find out exactly what's going on.This is a concise, fast-paced story with several fun plot twists. Is it "great literature"? No. But it doesn't pretend to be. It's a fun read, great for the beach or poolside, or on the flight.

"The Power of the Dog" was the first Winslow book I read, and liked it so much I was motivated to read the rest of his body of work, which includes "Savages" and "The Dawn patrol", among others. I don't know why, but he seems to be one of the overlooked gems in the literary world.In "Cartel", he picks up the story of the vendetta between US drug agent Art Keller and Mexican drug lord Adan Barrera.Years after the events described in "Dog" Keller comes out of retirement when Barrera escapes from the prison Keller's arrest confined him to, and picks up trying to recapture his dream of consolidating control over the massive drug activities in Mexico by establishing himself as the sole emperor of the drug realm.This is a huge, complex story because, just as in "Dog", Winslow's research seems to have been impeccable. The drug wars in Mexico, as has been extensively detailed in actual news coverage, are incredibly complex, with many factions vying for control, constantly killing each other as the power shifts from faction to faction, all accompanied by unbelievable "collateral damage" in civilian deaths and government corruption.Essentially, Mexico is a failed nation-state, and Winslow's book gives us a pretty clear idea of why that is.This isn't necessarily an "easy read", as there are so many "players" involved -- just as there are in real life -- and in many ways it reminds me of "The Godfather" (the Puzo book, not the movies) as it paints the picture of the plays and counterplays, betrayals and alliances; you have to pay attention or you'll lose track of the players.But I think it's a pretty accurate reflection of real life (as was "Dog"), and was very well done. A very rewarding read.I thought the plotting and pacing were excellent, and the portrayals of the main characters were vivid and three-dimensional. There are definitely gut-punches emotionally, as well as payoffs.I recommend this book without reservation, and if you read "Dog", it's a must-read.

I tuned into this show for a "binge-watch" while it was running on the NBC website. It was plugged as being a "mini-series", and as such I expected it to follow a conventional story arc with a beginning, middle, and end. Which leads me to my first BIG problem with the show: it doesn't actually end.Contrary to the ads (or at least my understanding of them), this is actually only "Season 1", meaning the story lines DON'T end. In fact, the end of the last episode concludes with several plot line "cliffhangers". Frankly, this really ticked me off.Having lived through the era, I can say that there's a lot they got right... BUT there's also quite a bit they got laughingly wrong, starting with the slang people use in the dialogue. Anachronisms abound, with people using words and phrases that hadn't yet come into the parlance.I question the use of a historical figure like Charley Manson. I understand the dramatic theme they wanted to explore with the character, but I think the story would have been better served by using a fictional character to represent his element rather than a monster who really existed in real life. By using the real Manson as the antagonist, a lot of the potential dramatic possibilities are simply removed from the equation. We KNOW that no matter what Manson does, Duchovny's cop character isn't going to arrest or kill him.I also found that other than Duchovny's cop character, I didn't find most of the other characters very appealing or sympathetic. Thus, if or when bad things happened to them, I didn't really care all that much.But again, my biggest peeve is that the story didn't actually end. Though I found it fairly entertaining, it wasn't entertaining enough that I'm at all interested in tuning back in for another season of it.

I'm half Armenian, and our cultural cuisine often uses olive oil as an ingredient. Further, I grew up in a military family, and spent my teen years in Iran, and again, olive oil is essential to Middle Eastern cuisine. Though not an oil "expert", I do know what I like.My go-to oil is Pompeian Extra Virgin First Cold Press.Always being open to trying new things, I jumped at the chance to test-drive these new (to me) offerings. Frankly, I was very disappointed.Both had a bitter taste I didn't care for, especially compared to the Pompeian. I don't like the flavor of the oil to overpower the inherent flavor of the main ingredients of a dish. They're supposed to complement, not subdue.The bitter taste was stronger in the Arbequina, in addition to which it hit the back of my tongue with a strong peppery taste. If I want to pepper my food, I know where the shaker is.The Cornicabra wasn't as overpowering, but again there was a bitter note I just didn't care for.So for now, I think I'll be sticking with the Pompeian until something better comes down the pike.

My 5-year-old granddaughter was very excited when we opened the box, and loves these markers.First, we had to sample all the scents, and they are accurate and easy to identify. Next, it was on to drawing and coloring.The colors are rich and vibrant (and thankfully, washable), lay down evenly and easily, and my munchkin was delighted with this set.If she's happy, I'm happy. And we are.

As I wrote in my review of the prequel to this book (The Counterfeit Agent), there isn't enough actual "story" here to sustain two full books. I gave that book a 3  star rating, but this book doesn't even rate that highly.I won't recap the story line here. You can get that on the book's Amazon Product Description page.If you haven't read "The Counterfeit Agent", rest assured that Berenson spends somewhere around 80 pages or so bringing you up to speed. If you HAVE read that book, prepare yourself for a bore fest as you wade through stuff you already know.The problems continue. Because Berenson's trying to drag out a story long enough to justify a book of its own, the pacing is just simply snail-slow. Wells and his buddies, Dutro and Schaeffer, meander from place to place. Nothing much happens for pages and pages at a time, other than pretty pedestrian descriptions of locale, or characters navel-gazing.Berenson's early works were notable for their complex plots and engaging action, along with three-dimensional characterizations, usually coupled with a topic that seemed ripped from the headlines about current events. Though the plot revolves around Iran's potential nuclear WMD capability, it's lacking the other aspects of those early works. I have to wonder if Berenson's simply lost his mojo.In all honesty, many times I'd find my mind just wandering away while trying to read this story, and by the time I came to the end, I just didn't care much at all anymore.Buyer beware... really.

Making it an excellent value.Let's face it. You're not buying a Galaxy or iPhone here. This is a no-name low priced UNLOCKED cell phone with a lot of bells and whistles. And because it is a no-name phone, you're also not paying $500 or $600 or more for it.First and foremost, it's unlocked, meaning you can use it on any of the major networks' 4G systems. And because it's not system-dedicated, it doesn't come pre-loaded with a bunch of network garbage software. It comes with the Android OS and a couple of basic systems to go online and operate the cameras, and that's it. You then can go to the Android App Store and download only that software you actually want to have on your phone.The cameras are fine, especially the main camera, which is 13 MP. Screen resolution is quite nice. The back is detachable, so you can access the interior compartment to change the battery - especially useful if you have a spare on hand - as well as add a sim card to expand the onboard memory to 32 GB.The phone comes with some of the accessories that you typically have to pay extra for: a protective case, screen protector, and stereo headset.Its Achilles Heel, I think, is that the removable back of the case is made of thin plastic that I can foresee easily cracking or breaking. It hasn't happened to me yet, but it sure seems flimsy to me.The OS is Android Kit-Kat 4.4.I am quite impressed. In all honesty, when I ordered this phone I was pretty skeptical about the quality of what I'd be getting. But it exceeded all my expectations.

And that's not meant to be a good thing.I'm not going to do a story recitation here. You can get that from the book's Product Page.Unlike "Jurassic Park", there's no effort made whatsoever to actually establish any suspense, background, a plot, or three-dimensionality to the characters. A bunch of people are dropped into a setting -- in this case a theme park in China at which the main attraction is a bunch of actual living dragons -- and in literally just a few pages the dragons go on a rampage and everyone's running for their lives, fighting dragons, dangling from cliffs, fighting monster crocodiles, etcetera etcetera ad nauseum.If we're going to compare this book to "Jurassic Park" -- as the publishers do on the book jacket, as well as many of the other reviewers -- then let's actually do it.What made "Jurassic Park" such an entertaining book (and movie) was the mounting sense of doom and dread, culminating in a life-or-death confrontation with the dinosaurs. Chrichton took his time in establishing the sense of wonder at the science and setting, and firmly established his characters so we felt we knew (and sympathized with) them.There's absolutely none of that in this book. It's like a cartoon. As I said, we have a bunch of two-dimensional characters dropped into a locale like lumps of coal in a bin, and immediately they're off fighting dragons. It's as if Chrichton were to start "Jurassic Park" at a point thee-quarters of the way through, and try to stretch what little story remains into a full-length book.To sum it up in one word:  boring.
What a piece of ....If this movie hadn't had Affleck attached, it would have gone straight to some basic-cable chick-flick channel like Lifetime and been promptly forgotten.Deservedly so.

Depp's first two Spandau entries were sharp, edgy, somewhat satirical mysteries rooted in the Movieland sub-culture, affording us an insider's peek at the slime under the façade that is mythical "Hollywood".Unfortunately, I didn't think this book lived up to that same standard.I found the story line to be muddled; characters' actions were all over the map, with consistent inconsistencies. Spandau seemed somehow "diluted", less grounded than in the earlier books, less forceful. Easier to distract and push around. Less decisive. I actually found some of the secondary characters, particularly Pookie and Leo, far more entertaining than the protagonist.Pretty disappointing. Hopefully Depp will be able to get back on track next time.

These outdoor path lights do exactly what they claim: they sense motion, then cast light down onto (presumably) your pathway.One has plenty of options in the marketplace, the most common being ornamental path lights, typically powered by solar cells. Those have their advantages: they're generally aesthetically pleasing, and low maintenance (as they're solar-powered). However, the drawback is that they typically don't generate much light; more ornamental than functional.These units take a polar opposite approach to the issue. They're far more functional than ornamental. In fact, they have a somewhat "industrial" appearance. Depending on your design taste, you may not really want them somewhere prominent on your lot. There's not really much the designers could do about that, I suppose, as the body of the unit has to be big enough to hold the batteries.Which raises another issue: they are battery powered, meaning you have to, at least occasionally, actually change batteries. That's a labor and cost issue, when comparing to solar units, the trade-off being brighter light from these units. I don't yet know how long a set of batteries lasts, but they are powering the light AND the motion sensor. I guess we'll see.I've put them near a brick deck that's in a dark and recessed part of my lot, and they work very well. On a personal note, they aren't something I'd particularly want to place on the front walkway of my yard leading to my front door, but that's a matter of my own taste, and your aesthetic sense may well be very different from mine.Overall, 4 stars.

This book isn't a "thriller". It's a legal mystery novel, or "whodunit". "Thriller" is a term rightfully applied to a story with a lot of action, bullets flying everywhere and car chases up the yin-yang. A hero dodging evil villains, in imminent danger of being violently killed. This book ain't that.What it IS is a well-crafted mystery novel based in the legal arena about a man wrongly accused of murder, and his efforts to clear his name and keep from being sent to prison.Mitzner's clearly in his element in this melieu. He knows his lawyering; his characters are fully three-dimensional; the plot is satisfyingly complex; and the climax and Big Reveal was a complete surprise to me, as I was absolutely sure I'd figured out "whodunit"... and was completely wrong.Very entertaining; a solid 4 stars.________________________________________________________________A side note to the publishing industry: not every book that isn't a romance or scifi is a "thriller", and your constant abuse of that term is annoyingly brain-dead. Stop it.

I've really enjoyed Coughlin's Kyle Swanson fiction series, and based on the readability of those books and Coughlin's own experience as a Marine sniper, I thought this book would be a great read about the inside "scoop" on the effectiveness and doctrine of sniping.Unfortunately, in that regard it's a big disappointment. Instead, it's primarily a bunch of non-fiction stories about some snipers' experiences in the Sandbox during the War on Terror. Though the stories are interesting, after a while it becomes pretty repetitive, and there's VERY little insight into the training, psychology, or doctrine of the sniper profession. It's almost just one long shoot-'em-up.I really don't think this book is what it professes to be on the fly-leaf, or the impression given on Amazon's Product Description. Caveat emptor.

Cell phones and tablets keep getting bigger; laptops and notebooks keep getting smaller; the dividing lines between the various device types keep betting murkier.This is a great thing for consumers because it means more options.This Dell laptop/notebook is a great example. It's small for a laptop, but the screen size is too big to be a traditional tablet. Yet the keyboard swivels around to the bottom of the unit turning it into a large tablet.Setup was easy. Turn it on, set up your logon info, connect to the internet, either wirelessly or by cable, let Windows Update do its thing, and you're done.Screen resolution is good, but not great. One problem, and I don't know whether it's an issue with this type of computer or just a problem with my individual unit, but the little light that typically illuminates when the hard drive's running doesn't do anything other than briefly light up when the unit starts up. At one point during the update process the screen had been dark for a long time and that light wasn't on. I didn't know whether or not the unit had frozen up until I put my ear next to it and could hear the hard drive working away. There is an HD icon next to the light, so it is what I think it is; it just doesn't seem to work.There's no optical drive, so if you need to access DVDs for any reason - software, data storage, disc burning, whatever - you'll need to buy an external drive to connect up.One caveat, for which I'm not deducting any stars: this unit is comes with the Win 8.1 operating system (OS) installed. I HATE Win 8.1, and the minute the next OS comes out in a few months (Win 10, reportedly) I'm upgrading to it. Naturally, this isn't a Dell issue; they manufacture hardware using the latest and "greatest" from Windows. But Win 8.1 has been an unmitigated disaster as an OS - rightfully so, in my opinion - so if you're in the market and can wait for the new OS to come out, you may want to consider that option.Overall, a very nice laptop/notebook/tablet/whatever, with the limitations inherent to the type.Four stars.

This printer's not an all-in-one. It doesn't fax. It doesn't hold much paper. It's not really suitable for a busy home or home-office. But then, it doesn't claim to be, and it's not priced that way.It is inexpensive at under a hundred bucks. It prints directly from your handheld wireless device (tablet, cell phone). It sets up easy. It's well made. Picture and document quality is excellent. It's easy to use.On those criteria, 5 stars.

I'm a pretty good cook, and I always enjoy eating my home-cooked meals. Unfortunately, I DON'T enjoy the actual preparation of it; the grunt work of cooking. So I'm always on the lookout for anything that'll make that chore easier.When I was given the opportunity to get this grill through the Amazon Vine program, I jumped on it.Unless you live in a cave, you're probably familiar with the George Foreman Grills, even if you've never seen the ubiquitous infomercials. I was. But somehow or another, even though that awareness was rattling around somewhere in the back of my mind I never actually got one. So when it arrived the other day, I had to try it out immediately.Set-up couldn't be easier: unpack the box, and you're ready to go. Plug it in; it pre-heats; then the green light tells you it's ready. Throw your food on, cook, eat.I tried it out with a 10 ounce filet mignon. As advertised, the steak cooked to the desired doneness based on the time I left it in the grill, in my case 8 minutes for "well done" with a touch of pink inside. Almost no smoke while cooking; very little fat run-off as filet mignon is a very lean cut of meat; the outside was nicely browned (charred, caramelized, whatever term you want to use); it tasted fine.This is extremely convenient, the main benefit I think these grills address. My usual prep for a steak like this is my outdoor grill, which entails preheating the grill, then putting on the steak and cooking it for about 8 minutes per side, all the time having to schlep outside for every step of the process. This is far more convenient, as the grill is right on my kitchen counter, and BOTH sides of the meat are cooking at the same time, cutting total cooking time in half.One big caveat:  the pictures, and the advertising copy, indicate that you can cook a lot of stuff on this grill at the same time, and I'd take that with a HUGE grain of salt. The ad copy says: "With 80 square Inch of cooking space, the personal grill can cook four servings of fresh or frozen grilled favorites at a time." (All the spelling and grammatical errors are theirs, BTW).Well.... Hmmmm.....Probably true, IF you're using small portions. The picture on the product page of those four salmon steaks (I think that's what they are).... Well, those must be pretty small steaks. I measured the cooking area inside the raised boundaries, and it's actually about 10" X 7", for a true effective area of a bit over 70 sq. in., and my 10 oz. steak took up a lot of that area. I probably could have fit a bit more stuff onto that grill, but it would have been a tight fit, and I'm not really interested in trying to do jigsaw puzzle food placement on a hot griddle.You might be able to get 4 burgers on it, if they're small. More realistically, think 2 or 3 good sized burgers at a time.Bottom line: you're not going to be using a single one of these to feed yourself and several friends you have over. Which is why I got two!Clean-up is incredibly easy. As advertised, due to its non-stick surface all you have to do is wipe away any residue with a paper towel. If the plates require washing, they're dishwasher-safe, and easily snap out of the unit.Overall, I'm very pleased, and think this will be a welcome addition to my kitchen arsenal.

I didn't like this book nearly as much as the others in the series.Department Q, headed up by Inspector Carl Morck, handles cold cases in Denmark. But this book departs from the usual format in that they're investigating the "disappearance" of a victim that we readers know has been murdered, but Morck and his crew don't. In fact, the case is very much a current case (unbeknownst to the Dept. Q folks), as the killers, as well as a witness (the titular "Marco"), are all still running around pursuing their individual agendas.Much less time is spent on Morck and Company in this book than in the others, to the detriment of the story. A lot of time is spent on Marco and his pursuers. Frankly, this leads to a very disjointed feel in the storytelling, a somewhat Keystone Kops atmosphere, and I didn't care for ANY of these characters, in all honesty, so I just didn't really care what happened to any of them. Further, the "plot" involving the murder, corruption in Africa, and all the rest was way too convoluted.As opposed to being an enjoyable read, I found it a chore to actually make it all the way through this book.Two stars at best.

Photography and videography are my Joneses, so when this little camera was made available to me through the Vine program I had to try it out.As with all things Logitech, it's very well made. It's a videocam with a fixed focus and ultra-wide fixed focal length lens. It shoots relatively short video clips (with sound, of course) that can be edited together to create longer "home movies".It doesn't have a viewfinder or display screen, so in essence you're shooting blind. I have no idea how you're supposed to compose your shots this way. "Blind" luck, quite literally. Even when people use equipment with aiming capability they shoot a lot of just plain bad pics and video. How can this POSSIBLY be better?The "work around" seems to be that if you have an iPhone, you can link this camera to the phone (Android users such as me are just out of luck on this) and use the phone as your aiming device...... but if you have an iPhone on hand, why do you need this camera at all? The iPhone has a viewer, so you can compose your shots, as well as zoom capability, making this Bemo utterly superfluous.At its price point of over a hundred bucks, there are plenty of pocket cams available that shoot not only video but still pics, as well as having zoom capabilities and viewfinders of some kind.I can't for the life of me figure out what market niche Logitech's chasing with this little Bemo, unless it's people who want to shoot a bunch of "selfie movies", and for some reason don't want to - or can't - use their cell phones or pocket cameras.That seems to me to be a pretty limited market.

For years now we've all been at the mercy of the crusade against incandescent light bulbs (ILB). Frankly, I am, and always have been, a fan of ILBs. They come in a range of wattages; they come in a range of types of light they emit (warm, cool, soft, etc.); and they're cheap.For quite a while, the only viable alternative was compact fluorescent lights (CFL), which had a lot of drawbacks, in my opinion. They were expensive. They were fluorescent, meaning they didn't come on instantly, and there was a flicker to them. I do not like the "quality" of the light they emit.Now we have the latest entry to come down the pike: light emitting diodes (LED). When given the opportunity, through the Vine program, to try this out I jumped at it.Again, in comparison to ILB, these LEDs are expensive. Frankly, I'm not sure when the financial break-even point would come in switching from ILB to either of the alternatives, given the unit price of ILBs in comparison to both CFLs and LEDs. I suspect it will be years down the road, if ever.That having been said, the first impression I had was solidity. This bulb is very heavy and solid. The term "robust" comes to mind. It fit handily into my desktop lamp in my home office, replacing a GE 95 watt "Soft White" ILB.It came on instantly when the switch was thrown, just like an ILB. Good!I was surprised by just how "white" the light from the LED is, especially when compared to an ILB that is itself "Soft White". It's VERY "white". Almost a "sterile" feel to it. Light "quality" is a very subjective judgment, and I'm not sure I like this yet. I'll have to give it some time, and I may come back and add to this review at a later date; an addendum.Due to the bottom half of the unit being made of a finned plastic housing - probably for heat dissipation - the actual "bulb" or lens itself only exists from its equator up. So the light is, to some extent, projected upwards and laterally, as opposed to the radiant dispersal pattern of an ILB. However, it does light the entire office adequately.When I look at things illuminated with this light, I'm seeing colors rendered truly and accurately. As a photography buff, this is very important to me, as I view my prints in my home office under the lamp illumination. I have to say that I've never seen such accurate color rendition under room illumination before. That's a big plus.I think this LED would be less than ideal in the living areas of the house; the living room, dining room; family room. It's too "cold". But I can see a "warmer" version being very suitable.All in all, I'm impressed. I consider this a successful proof of the LED concept in home lighting, with the possible proviso of the price.ADDENDUM.... Okay, some math.I decided to work out the numbers. This bulb is supposed to last 25,000 hours according to the warranty. It costs $24. Therefore you get 1,042 hours per dollar spent.A standard 95 watt ILB costs a buck, and gives you a 1,400 hour life. Advantage is CLEARLY to the ILB, on that basis, by about a 40% margin.To produce the same "amount" of light, the ILB uses 95 watts versus the LED's 19 watts. Over that same 25,000 hour period, the ILB will use 2,375,000 watts versus the LED's 475,000. Advantage LED, by about a 500% margin.I currently pay 10 cents/KwH. That means that over that period, the ILB will use $237.50 of power versus the LED's $47.50. A saving of $195 over 25,000 hours of usage (supposedly about 23 years, based on Kobi's assumption of 3 hours of usage daily). That saves you about $8.48/year.So it looks to me like the break-even point will be a little under three years down the road.

This is your own personal "cloud", and I really like the idea and practicality of having this much actual storage available without actually having to use the REAL "cloud". I don't like having my personal data floating somewhere in the ether, accessible to who knows who.It's a full 8 terrabytes of storage, which can be used in a 4 X 2 terrabyte configuration, too, essentially a dual backup system.It uses USB 3.0, which in my case is driven by the backward-compatibility USB 2.0. Setup was fast, simple, and intuitive. Transfer rate is very fast (it must really sing in full USB 3.0 format).I'm using a Dell system, Win 7 64-bit. No problems at all.I'm an avid still photographer and videographer, and I can't even imagine shooting so much stuff that I'll run out of storage space on this unit. It's simply MASSIVE.Now bear in mind, that's what I use it for: storage and backup. I'm NOT using it as a primary drive, though one could easily do so, I suppose. I have no idea what the slower transfer speed of USB 2.0 would do to its accessibility. I suspect it would be pretty slow as far as being used as a "primary" drive. I still use my Dell's internal drive as the primary, and use this as my storage/backup of finished product.I'm very pleased, and I may add to this review in the future if and as I discover more capabilities, and gain more experience with it.

This book's a welcome return to the style and elements of the classic Jack Reacher books, and far superior to the very disappointing offerings of the last few years.Reacher has been recruited by one of his old Army bosses to hunt down a former top-tier military sniper - a guy Reacher had arrested while still an MP - who is one of several such men suspected of targeting an upcoming G8 summit meeting in London. The search takes him to Europe, affording us the opportunity to see Reacher in a new environment, and pits him and his temporary associates against a challenging set of dangerous foes.The story line and pacing are crisp; the settings are well described; the ancillary characters are all fully fleshed and three-dimensional. This is definitely a return to the Reacher of yore. Author Child seems to have blown out the cobwebs and ennui, which had become so evident in recent years with the rote offerings we'd seen lately.One nit I do have to pick, which is especially germane in stories in this genre: Lee Child, if you're reading this review, PLEASE get some help from someone knowledgeable about guns and ballistics if you're going to include a lot of gun stuff in your next book. The gaffes in this one were truly cringe-worthy to any gun guy.Yes, the .44 Remington Magnum is a larger diameter caliber than the .223 Remington, the 7.62 NATO, the .308 Winchester (which is actually the civilian version of the 7.62 NATO), and the British .303, BUT............. the .44 Mag is a HANDGUN cartridge, and has nowhere near the destructive power of any of those RIFLE calibers. Even the relatively puny .223 Remington (the standard service round of the M-16 rifle in its 5.56 NATO configuration) has more muzzle energy (read "destructive power") than the .44 Mag, at about 1700 ft/lbs of energy versus 1500 ft/lbs in the .44's most powerful loading.The other major problem was that several times in the story a key element was the time it takes a bullet from a .50 BMG round - the "sniper" round from a Barrett rifle - to travel 1400 yards. Child wrote that it takes three seconds. In fact, the velocity of that round is approximately 3,000 feet per second, meaning the travel time is actually 1.4 seconds. Until you read the book, you won't understand how important that error really is. But take it from me; it is important.That having been said, a welcome addition to the Reacher saga. Four stars.

I'm not going to write a plot summary here, as this is a review and not a school book report. I assume that if you've made it this far you've already read the Amazon Product Page and have some idea of what the book's about.My experience with Barclay's books over the years has been mixed. I thought a couple were really good, and some were pretty bad. I'm afraid this one falls more into the latter category.It's a sequel to a previous book, "No Time For Goodbye", picking up the central characters from that book a few years down the road. So, the first problem; a lot of time is spent re-establishing the characters, and what changes have taken place in their lives. It's pretty slow going.Barclay sometimes has a habit of pausing the action - repeatedly - for the characters to indulge in a lot of contemplative navel-gazing.  This can be effective in fleshing out a character, but when done to excess it becomes boring, repetitive, and annoying. This book is a classic example of doing it to excess. I found myself skimming and even skipping pages at a time.Without going into undue elaboration (so as to not reveal any spoilers), I found the underlying main plot premise to be completely preposterous.Vince, one of the characters returning from the original book, has been transformed from a knight in very tarnished armor to a mean-spirited thug with few - if any - redeeming qualities. In that respect alone, Barclay would have been better off using original characters instead of making this book a "sequel".Barclay loves his plot twists. In a good book, that's a good thing. But this time, there was one final twist that, in my opinion, was enough to take it over the top. It was just ... too much.This book just didn't work for me.

We got this ship a couple of days ago, and my almost-5-year-old munchkin -- my granddaughter -- absolutely loves it.It's the perfect size for her to play with the enclosed Playmobil pirates (very similar to Lego), who apparently are perfect suitors for her little Barbies and Disney princesses. The whole gang piles on board to sail off to their group "wedding", which usually takes place at one of her princess castles or Barbie Dream Houses.I find this toy to be pretty impressive. It's not some dinky toy boat; this thing is pretty big, with plenty of room for her to move the figurines around so she can actually have them do things on board, as opposed to other toy ships on which you can only place the figures and not have them do much for lack of space.It's really detailed, right down to the binnacle compass.It was very easy to assemble, taking only about 10 minutes or so. The instructions -- consisting of pictograms -- were easy to understand and follow, with only one exception: be advised that the treasure chest isn't mentioned for some reason. I kept trying to pry the darned thing open, to the point of almost breaking it. FYI, it turns out that if you slide the keyhole escutcheon to the side, the chest unlocks and opens. I'll also publicly admit that it was the MUNCHKIN, not me, who actually figured this out (all that wasted time and money studying engineering in college... go figure).it's very sturdy and I'm sure will stand up to a lot of abuse. Be aware that there are quite a few small parts that I expect will ultimately get lost, at least some of them: swords, knives, a flintlock pistol, hats, pirate booty consisting of individual tiny gold coins. I'd suggest storing the stuff in  the lockable chest or the enclosed barrels, but let's face it: kids will be kids, and at least some of this stuff is going to "vanish".Overall, I'd consider this a job extremely well done by Playmobil. Terrific toy worth every penny of its price.

I've read a couple of Carcaterra's previous books; "Sleepers" sticks in my mind, which was a pretty terrific book.On that basis, I bought this one. I wish I hadn't bothered.The basic premise is that an American mob boss's wife and kids are killed in a terrorist takeover of a commercial flight, and he's pretty ticked off about it, wanting vengeance. He enlists the help of a slew of other mob bosses - people running crime syndicates all over the world - in his effort to do so, pitting top-drawer criminals against top-flight terrorists, with pretty predictable results.Okay. Maybe light poolside fare, right?Unfortunately, it goes downhill from there.There's just so much in this book that crosses the line between stretched credibility and the patently absurd.Supposedly, these mobs are so omnipresent and powerful that they almost completely run all private enterprise in, essentially, the world. They "get a piece" of every transaction that takes place anywhere. They operate with de facto immunity because law enforcement is so corrupt and in their collective pockets. They control the international financial markets. Each of the bosses is the ultimate "Don" of his or her individual country; little gods.Oh, please... Really? We're supposed to buy this? I'm surprised Carcaterra didn't endow them with super powers while he was at it.Then we're supposed to accept the idea that people with this much power are actually going to get personally involved in the gunplay and other action themselves. Isn't that why they have minions? So they can order THEM to do things? When was the last time anyone ever heard of an army general picking up a rifle and running at the enemy lines himself?There's a plot point about a "betrayal" that was so obvious that I felt that my intelligence, such as it is, was being insulted. You can see it coming for at least 50 pages.The characterizations are all over the map; a few are pretty three-dimensional, most are shallow and cartoonish.Worse yet, the book doesn't even have a real "ending". You're going to have to wait for the obviously-planned second part for a final resolution. I hate that in a book.I was originally going to give this book 2 stars, but as I read what I've written, I think it only deserves one. So be it.

I'm not going to write a story recitation here; you can get a synopsis on the book's Amazon Product Page.Essentially, this book follows Weldon Holland, a poor Southern boy, from his boyhood in the `30s through World War 2 and into his adult life as a self-made successful businessman. By that time he's partnered with his war buddy, married to a concentration camp survivor, and his world is threatened when he refuses to compromise his principles by surrendering control of his company to a wealthy but corrupt local family dynasty.As always, Burke's use of the language is simply masterful; truly a thing to behold. He is the most articulate and descriptive author on the American scene, in my opinion. His descriptive passages, ability to establish mood and setting, and personify his characters is beyond compare. His works are truly "literature" in every sense of the word.In many ways this book reminded me of the works of a couple of other authors: Irwin Shaw, particularly the novel "Rich Man, Poor Man"; and the early works of Harold Robbins, especially "A Stone For Danny Fisher". Like those books, this one covers a time period of decades, and centers on the protagonist of a poor boy who makes good.However, in contrast to Burke's usual fare, this book leaves us wanting as to final resolutions, and I think this is a bit of a failure.Burke's usual style is reflective of the real-life fact that we can never really be sure of what other people are thinking, or be crystal clear about their motivations. That's simply a fact of human nature; we can't read minds. However, in the world of storytelling, we have to compromise on that, regardless of how reflective of real life an author wishes to be. After all, the author and readers are sharing a journey into the lives and thoughts of others, with an almost God-view perspective.In his other books, this hasn't been an issue before, at least for me. But in this book, Burke never really resolves some of the major plot points. Who was really behind all the attacks on Weldon and his group? Yes, it was one of the Wisehearts... but WHICH one? Or was it a collaborative effort of all three of them?I don't know, because that's not cleared up. And because of that I found the ending to be very unsatisfying. There was no sense of justice, or retribution, or rehabilitation; whichever would have been appropriate depending on the actor involved.I found the ending itself to be very ... abrupt. After reading several hundred pages of, basically, "setup", it's "resolved" in about 20 pages? With an explicatory Epilogue? That's like getting all ginned up for a great hamburger, only to find when you go to bite into it that it's a veggie burger.There's another issue I found to be distracting. Throughout the book Burke uses Bonnie and Clyde (yes, that Bonnie and Clyde) as a device he used similarly in his Robicheaux book "In The Electric Mist With Confederate Dead"; a touchstone of dead people - "spirits", if you will - that show up at critical moments to help the protagonist clarify his thoughts. Though I think it worked in "Electric Mist", I found it to be strained in this book. Maybe it was because in the Robicheaux book the dead people were Southern heroes and honorable men, and Bonnie and Clyde were murderous scum, and therefore inappropriate for our "hero" character to continually reference. But for whatever reason, it surely didn't work for me.Anyway, a lot of plusses, a few significant minuses, for an overall rating of 3 ½ stars.

I find carrying around earbuds a hassle.  You either need a separate case for them or they get tangled.  And unless you carry them with you all the time or stash multiple pairs everywhere, you don't always have them when you want them. This case does a good job integrating a decent phone case and decent earbuds. The case provides adequate protection--not as much as the best cases out there, but it's a solid case that will withstand dropping on a hard floor, and much tougher than the inexpensive rubbery skins.  Unlike some cases, this one is easy to get the phone into--it splits into two pieces to allow that. Although the case extends to accommodate the earbuds, it's not much longer than most cases, and no fatter.The earbuds also are adequate for casual listening. Of course you can easily buy much better buds if you're willing to pay, but these really aren't bad.  They come with an in-line microphone and button for answering calls and advancing tracks.  The buds retract promptly and smoothly when you push the button, but it's a good idea to hold them and guide them in; the wires are thin and will probably break eventually if they get snapped into the case over and over.  In fact, the thin wires are the one aspect of the design I question; we'll see.

Kids can use all the help they can get to become aware of geography; a large proportion of adult Americans are clueless on the subject.  So this modestly-priced item is certainly better than nothing.  However, it has a lot of flaws, too, and for my money, I'd much prefer to spend a little more for something more accurate and durable.This set is quite small, and as a result, it has to try to cram all the countries of the world into it.  Since there are almost 200 officially-recognized nations, it simply omits some.  Many of those included are identified in very small print, making it hard for anyone to read without peering very closely.  In terms of construction, the pieces themselves are thin and (weakly) magnetic and stick to the backing, but they aren't cut out to follow any political borders--areas that include several neighboring countries are lumped together in one piece. I suppose this has the advantage of allowing the user to appreciate that these countries are geographically connected, but it does not allow the user to get an accurate idea of the shape or size of many of the countries.  In fact, most countries' actual borders aren't shown at all; their names just float in the general area where the county is. For example, we can see that many of the countries in the Middle East are neighbors, but can't see the borders of Israel, Jordan, Kuwait and Syria or their relative sizes.  Japan and Mongolia look to be about the same size, while in reality the latter is four times the size of the former.  So the puzzle is fine for a child (or anyone) who knows nothing and wants to have a general idea of where places are, but leaves a lot to be desired .

Few people who aren't already fans are likely to read this, other than perhaps someone doing a research paper, but if you're a Deadhead, you'll find what Kreutzmann has to say interesting. Although there are other Dead memoirs, some of them pretty good, it's different to have one of the members himself, who was there at virtually every performance from the very beginning to the very end, not only offer his recollections but his opinions about other band members, the band's music, and so forth.  It's not great literature, but hopefully no one expects it to be. With the help of his ghost writer, Kreutzmann comes across as thoughtful and insightful.  The narrative is reasonably coherent and articulate.  He covers the band's early years, the Europe tour in '72, the Egypt trip, the Festival Express, and other highlights.  He doesn't shy away from some honest critiques of other band members, although he's gentle about it.  Since it's a memoir, the book is about his personal life as well as about the band's history, and his personal reflections can be touching.  Still, he wisely understands that most readers are much more interested in the Dead than in Bill Kreutzmann.  (Of course, when you're constantly touring with the same crew for thirty years, your life and the band's life overlap a great deal.)
