Even a hard-core Deadhead is likely to pick up something from this, and it's a very pleasant way to fill in the gaps in your knowledge of the band's history and the culture from which it emerged.

I take astaxanthin to reduce inflammation and enhance healthy immune response. The two are closely related. It's well known that the immune system is what keeps us from succumbing to illness. Inflammation is a response our body has to a wide range of conditions that it sees as a threat. In the short term, inflammation can be healthy, and is perfectly normal. But chronic inflammation, which can result from a wide range of problems, can lead to a great many conditions. Joint pain from arthritis is an obvious example, but it goes far beyond that. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is a form of chronic inflammation. Some believe some cancers result in part from chronic inflammation. In any case, astaxanthin is one supplement that can help reduce chronic inflammation while enhancing immune response.You can decide which supplement to buy based on price, or on the additives, or on dose, etc. All are relevant. I like Jarrow supplements because they're consistently high quality at a fair price. If you read the description they offer about astaxanthin, you can see that they're making a serious effort to inform the consumer, without making up a lot of malarky to get you to buy their product.

Not only aren't these earrings made from the leaves of the tree the Buddha sat beneath, or from any of the trees that were grown from cuttings of that tree (there are several), but it seems unlikely to me that these are made from leaves of the same type of tree (a fig variety). They do look similar to the much larger leaves I have from a tree grown from a cutting of the actual Bodhi Tree, but  leaves this small don't exist. You can find many identical earrings on Amazon and elsewhere that claim to be made from aspen leaves, which seems more plausible, and for half the price. This seems fraudulent to me. (And notice the product description says "handcrafted by artisans in India," while down below it says "product of Thailand.")

This duct tape is the best I've used in terms of the adhesive grip and the strength of the tape itself.  A lot of duct tape will deteriorate surprisingly quickly when used outdoors; the adhesive dries and separates from the tape. This lasts longer.  The tape itself is thick and tough. I respectfully disagree with the reviewer who said you'll need a scissor to cut it--I haven't had a problem tearing off pieces as necessary.

I was not familiar with Millhauser's work before reading this collection of stories, other than to know that he'd won a Pulitzer for one of his novels.  I was less impressed than I'd hoped.  There's no doubt he's a talented writer who knows his craft, but for the most part I found these stories insubstantial and underwhelming.  For example, one of the longer stories concerns Siddhartha Gautama's youth and his transition from pampered, cloistered prince to spiritual seeker.  It takes an intriguing concept and stretches it out to fill dozens of pages, during which the story progresses very slowly and repetitively.  Ultimately, there was not much to it.  Another story concerns a town experiencing an epidemic of suicides.  Some clever images and turns of phrase, but again, a simple concept spun out into a story that left little impression on me.  In most of the stories I felt little for the characters; it was all about the concept, yet the concepts seemed slight.  Millhauser's fans may enjoy this, but it didn't motivate me to go search out his other work.

Black and Decker is best known for its tools, and in my experience their tools aren't of the highest quality.  My experience with a Black and Decker food processor left me unimpressed with its design and sturdiness.  So I wasn't expecting much from this coffee maker.  But I like it in several ways. It does a good job grinding beans so you don't need a separate device for that, and I would never choose to buy ground coffee, which has lost a lot of flavor before it gets into your cup. The grind is adjustable. I like the paperless, permanent filter; although some have complained about it, I much prefer it to having buy and use and dispose of paper filters.  I like that it has a heating element under the pot to keep the coffee warm.  Granted, leaving coffee on a warming plate for a long time will eventually ruin it, but I prefer it to the Cusinart model I have that uses a metal carafe without a heating plate, in which the coffee gets cold in about half an hour and every cup after that has to be put in the microwave to heat it back up.What isn't ideal about this coffee maker is (1) it's big, so be sure you have room for it on your counter top before you buy it, and (2) if you're going to grind beans in it, you need to make at least four cups.  So it's not ideal for a household in which you're going to drink only a couple of cups.  But if you're going to drink a fair amount of coffee in a day, or have an office, it's fine.

These are extremely comfortable shoes.  Almost magically so--my feet feel better with the shoes on than off. They're remarkably light, yet seem well made, with decent quality leather, a nice insole, and sewn-on soles.  The soles seem to be made of a material similar to what's used in Crocs, which makes them extremely light, but also prone to wear out.  I always wear a size 10 but have very wide feet, so I ordered the 10EE, since there was no 10E and a number of people said they run small.  A 10E might have been better, because they're a little roomier than I'd like, but they do fit reasonably well.  They also don't have much arch support. But I like them.

Every foam pillow and mattress is now marketed as "memory foam."  This pillow is not memory foam, it's foam rubber.  If you press your hand into it it won't make any impression, but will immediately bounce back.  So if you really want memory foam, keep looking.This pillow is, of course, designed for those using CPAP, and since I don't, I can't comment on the value of the cutouts that are intended to accommodate the hoses.  But what I can say is that the pillow is quite firm--comfortable, but if you like the feeling of your head sinking into something soft, even moderately, this pillow doesn't provide that. Also, although it's described as "contoured," there's really no contour.  One side is slightly wider than the other, but not by much; there's no bulge to fit under your neck as with some other foam pillows, and it's pretty much a solid rectangular block with cutouts.The pillow is covered with a soft removable cover, so although you could use a pillow case you don't have to.  I've been using it for the past couple of months and have found it quite comfortable and my sleep has improved, to my surprise. But if I were choosing one I'd prefer something slightly softer and more contoured.
